Incredible!!. If you haven't been you need to go at least once. The views are great from the top, most definitely want to go on a clear day. It is a tourist attraction and the security is tight as you would expect. The elevator ride is interesting and the view is well worth it.

Spectacular View. We got a ticket at 6:15 so we could watch the sunset (7:25) and then watch city lights come on. Interior lighting and glare made some good pics difficult but we were greeted by a rainbow when we got off the elevator. I was not fond of being rushed to the next area where they wanted you to rent an iPad or something. Restaurant and bar are pricey.
A must-see. Excellent views of the city. We did the 'Top 3' towers and this was by far the best one. In hindsight, I would not have done all three.

Mixed emotions about this amazing building. We went the day prior to 9/11 in the morning, fine weather is a must. You get a real sense of how much this building means not only to the people of NYC, but all Americans, they are rightly very proud.Main reason we made the trip downtown to do it was to pay respect to the effort that NY and it's people had made to show these terrorists that we will and have prevailed, and our way of life is unchanged largely (apart from the security everywhere). It was our way of saying up yours and thumbing our nose to these people and their ideology. From a view perspective obviously it is awesome, but to be honest almost too high and the Top of the Rock uptown probably is better view (looking back to WTC). It was not about the view for us.....

Nice Monument. This was a very touching monument and the building is very beautiful. However, there was a line so we did not go in. Around the back outside there is still very nice tribute with water and wings of hope and all the names of the people lost in this horrible attack.

Average. Ok the view is great and it's something to tick off the bucket list but they've tried to incorporate small video clips etc into the experience. You have to stand in front of a screen then it lifts up to show you the view outside. You then get ushered along into a different area where they try sell you a virtual tour on an iPad at extra cost when it's already cost about $36 to get in. It's a bit of a tight squeeze through all that stuff to finally get to the observation area. Not a great place for photographs due to reflections on the glass. I would recommend the Rockefeller observatory instead.

Amazing views. Booked ahead & entrance went very quickly at 9am. Lift ride is awesome. Views are fantastic. We went on a clear day. Hired a tablet for more info on what we were looking at, shame it doesn't give a bit more info but that's just me liking knowledge and history. Did not feel rushed so could enjoy the views. Definitely worth a visit even if you don't like heights!

USA Trip 2016. I really enjoyed my visit to the one world observatory the lines weren't that bad and the escalator ride to the top was very good the views are amazing and the guides are well worth listening to in regards to the new history of the buildings at ground zero, a very tragic event but the NY people have done the city & country of USA proud in ther fight to re-build is a credit to the country....

Nice Views, but skip the Explorer Tablet.... Great views of the 5 boroughs. I enjoyed my time there as a native NYer. Elevator trip was wonderful. However, my advice to others is to skip the antiquated One World Explorer tablet and keep thier $15 because it is useless. Many of the landmarks in the boroughs outside of Manhattan are missing. It is actually disgraceful that Apple is associated with such a poorly made tool with all of the technology available. The managers/developers at One World Trade really need to rethink what they want the One World Explorer to do for visitors because it currently falls so short of the intent it was originally designed for.

It's ok. The views are great, but if you want to take photos it is not the best place to do that. Everywhere you try, you have a window stick next to you. Don't use flash!! I'm only here to take pictures with my girlfriend and I can't do that.I won't come back again, it's to expensive.

Zero visibility. We went on a very rainy September morning. When we got in line with our priority admission tickets a member of the OWO staff informed us it was a "zero visibility" day and offered to let us reschedule our tickets! We couldn't take advantage as we were on a tight schedule and it was our last day in NYC (thus the priority ticket purchase). We were really impressed with the offer though (which really shouldn't have surprised us as much as it did because people in NYC are generally nice and helpful) and still managed to have a neat visit. We went to the One Cafe looking for something to drink and weren't planning to get anything to eat but the OWO staff in the cafe were so helpful and engaging that we bought a breakfast sandwich which happened to be quite good. When we go back we will probably plan to eat breakfast in the cafe!

Enjoyable Views with Shopping. Went to the WTC on 9/10 to see what they completed and it was amazing. We took a 2 hour walking tour at first and it was worth it just to hear the feedback from 15 years ago and how this new WTC is totally different. I believe they did a great job with the underground areas for shopping and transportation connections. Grab your walking shoes and enjoy the views.
an amazing experience. worth the money an amazing experience with so much information and lot to learn ! i was in awe . and i used to live in ny .
Very good. Excellent views of the harbour, downtown and surrounding areas. Very clever with the film presentation. Overall great stuff.
Fantastic. So worth the price. From the moment you get in the lift, the show starts. Obviously the views are spectacular. There is a coffee shop and restaurant but the view are the reason to go.

It's an experience.. Ever since the OWO opened, I've wanted to visit, and was finally able to do so this week.They really make it an experience: there's video, entertainment, iPads to enhance the experience,... This made the experience a little bit too commercial for me, but the view is of the whole Island of Manhattan and the surrounding boroughs is one you don't get in any other observatory.

Touching . A very touching tribute - it was a moving experience for me to see the film and to listen to voices of the people that had to live thru it -- just brings tears to your eyes even after all these years --- it still touches the heart and this too is a must see!Thank you NY for such a beautiful tribute - I was very fortunate to make this journey to finally see this beautiful wonder!The views are awesome!
Wonderful!. This was a wonderful experience. It was not the clearest day, but we did get some awesome pictures of New York City!! Highly recommend if your in NYC to do this tour!

Did not visit, the $37 elevator ride seemed too expensive. I'm sure the views are nice, but just too expensive. Views in midtown, like from Rockefeller Center and the Empire State Building are more impressive.

Add on the iPad.. First off, add the iPad rental available at the observatory. You can pick out and identify a number of sites around the area. Being a first time visitor, it really helped to quickly find well-known locations.We bought Flex Tickets since I was not sure of the exact time we would enter the observatory. It did cost a bit more, but entering was quick and easy.The ride of the elevator includes three walls displaying the development of Manhattan over the last several hundred years. While the elevator moved quickly to the top, it did not feel it. You can look through the top of the elevator and watch the ascent as well. The introductory theater, about a three minute film, has a memorable surprise at the end.We chose to order the photos (in advance) as well. The service is typical of other attractions. I had hoped the brightness level would look better, but I am ok with the final product.We rode the subway from Times Square to the Cortlandt St Station. I was surprised to see that we exited at the WTC memorial/mall area. It seems as though all of the trains merge to this one spot (Fulton Street Station, Cortlandt, WTC). After exiting the train, you can enter the 2016 opened WTC mall, and then exit outdoors to the 911 memorial.My biggest complaint is elevator access on the subway system. It is confusing, hard to find, or broken. A member of my group cannot easily take stairs, but it seemed this was not an option with the subway. I have never seen an area (New York City, in general) only sort-of ADA compliant; I am thinking I do not know the literal definition of ADA compliant.

Stunning views, reflective moments, and a worthwhile experience.. One World Observatory is a place where I like to bring visitors and guests to NYC to learn more about lower Manhattan and the history. While the location is certainly focused on 9/11 and post 9/11 efforts to revitalize downtown, it is also about the historical elements of NYC as a whole.There are a few great surprises for first time visitors and I won't ruin what they are so you can enjoy them. I definitely recommend going during the sunset schedule and taking your time to really experience the different views of all 5 boroughs.
Amazing. Got to visit this. Chilling and tragic but at the same time so memorable to go up and look out from the 125th floor. A must see.

Best observation deck ever!. This is by far the best observation deck in the best location anywhere I have ever been in my life! The views are stupendous. And best of all the views are 360 Degrees around, you can walk around the Tower observation deck and see the entire Skyline in all directions. And it's not cramped or tight fitting, there is plenty of room. The elevator ride takes a few minutes of time but it's worth it. Buy the day Flex tickets and you'll save a little time.

What a view!. I have lived and worked in the New York area from time to time. And I had been to the observatory at the Empire State Building several times. But the view from the One World Observatory are amazing. The people are very helpful. You can get tickets on line and shorten the wait. And while it is not a cheap visit, it really is something that you will enjoy and remember always.

A bit overrated . Enjoyed our trip but was left a little underwhelmed We thought it would be more exciting traveling up in the lift!Also felt as though it was a selling opportunity with the standard group photo and extra for iPads to enable zooming in on certain locations
Must See. Americans overcome and this is the perfect attraction to celebrate that fact. If you're heading to NYC this (and the Memorial Museum) are not to be missed! Incredible!!

Disappointing . Long line ups (even with pre-purchased tickets). Following the usual security checks you are taken to the highest level and headed into a long room facing a wall several feet back from the rail. A short video is projected onto the wall. Then the wall rises to display the view but immediately drops again. If you don't have your camera ready to go you won't have time to turn it on. This is deemed your "glimpse" at what is to follow. You then go down to the lower floor where you can see the views and the next floor down. The views from that floor were great, but if you wanted to know what you were looking at, that was an extra charge. Enjoyed the view but felt the "glimpse " to be pointless.

See the world. From the moment you step into the elevator the attraction begins. Once you get to the top the views are spectacular. Roomy and comfortable to walk around. On a clear day you truly can see forever. Well worth the money.
Beautiful Memorial Tower. A must visit while in New York. The views from the top are spectacular. The restaurant facility is too small for the number of visitors and the shop was very cramped

Nice view. The view and the overall structure and organization of the One World Observatory are amazing. I visited it at day time and it was sunny. You can see almost all of the major NYC landmarks from up there. However, you are always behind windows, so glass reflections are an issue for pictures (which is not the case at the Top of the Rock and the Empire State building). The One World Observatory is the highest one, though. It is the one that allows you to see the furthest away.If you have to choose, go for the Top of the Rock. One World comes a close second and the Empire State is the third, in my opinion.

Just do it!. Went to this activity with my girlfriend and the kids (6 and 9) and everybody loved it! We had to wait in line around 15-20 minutes to buy tickets but once you have your tickets, everything goes very fast. You go downstairs, watch a couple of pictures on your way to the elevator and when you go from the 1st floor to 102, it's quite an experience! On the way up, you see the city transforming from around 1910 till today with all the buildings, it's very impressive. Then you go out on floor 102 and there's a little movie and then the screen goes up and you have the view,Then you have floors 101 and 100 to enjoy the view so even if it's busy, you will always be ble to go near the windows. Also, you have staff on the floor if you have questions about buildings and I had some and they were all very nice. So this activity is quite expensive (130$ US dollars) for a family of 4 but it was totally worth it, we took great pictures and my kids loved it so I strongly recommend you do this the next time you go to NY.

Good but highly over priced. They views where beautiful but I did not need the up sell at every turn. First the iPad experience and then the cruise book picture. Which they don't let you see until it time to buy it. It would be nice to just walk around without the add-ons.

Apsalutly breath taking . If in new York do not miss this amazing experience. The staff are all really good and friendly. Once in the lift you are told to turn and look in front of you, the lift goes up really fast that's an experience. Then you come to the top and you stand in front of a big wall with pictures moving on it and they give you a presentation talk 'it's a big build up' then wo the shutter goes up and you can see right out over NYC we wasn't expecting that it was quite emotional. 360 degree views. then you can walk around for as long as you want take lots photos have a drink or snack if you want, its little pricey but that's to be expected. Or you can just sit and enjoy the wonderful views.
Best observatory in NY. Don't miss it, you have other options but it's the best observatoryThe best view in Manhattan, great service, fast entry

Amazing views 🗽. We booked this online after finding out we can now go up it ... Works out about £30 each ... So well worth it and one of the things I have to mention is the lovely lady on the counter at the cafe selling cakes and coffee was wonderful and very funny .... Loved her humour , also the guy on the till was so lovely to . Felt so welcomed to this beautiful building that I almost forgot what i was up there for . Loved the talk on the round board very interesting and really spectacular views . Well worth a visit . Thankyou .

Great views. We had advance tickets, but line to get ticket was short (Friday in Sept). Was expensive, Top of the Rock was almost as good, less costly. There was slight overcast, but still very good views.

Beautiful! and Inspiring. enjoyed very much....technology was amazing, views were amazing and I got the chills, especially at one surprising point. The feelings you get when u really think about all the reasons why this building is here. Just amazing!!

Great views, requires enduring a bit of marketing gimmickery. Really great views of Manhattan. Very fast elevators to the observatory. However, you have to first go through a bit of marketing/showmanship fluff before they turn you loose to walk around the observatory and see the city.

Quick to access , staff generally bossy and unhelpful , don't bother taking your camera. This was the third "top of the town" view I'd tried (Rockefeller Plaza and the Empire State the other two) We bought basic passes and got into the building and to the top very quickly compared to the other two where there are multiple queues (...for entry, security, tickets, lift one , lift two and exit lift to gift shop ,then queue to get the lift to the lobby.!)The view was spectacular and the viewing area much less crowded than the others- for the disabled,those with strollers and younger kids it's a much better experience ... as a keen photographer I was looking forward to getting some great pictures but sadly I got almost none. Like other attractions they ban tripods (fair enough) but the very thick (dirty)glass , coupled with the strong interior lighting means that getting a good quality nightcap photo was nearly impossible. I would be willing to pay a bit extra to get up there and have access to a spot outside. There are food and drink options at the top but they are pricey and so-so quality - the bar is small and the staff seem to to go out of their way to make it awkward to get in (or back out!) Like most of NYC they think a Cappuccino is watery stuff with soap foam on top so give the food a miss and take water with you as there isn't much access to water fountains upstairs

Amazing memorial . This was my first trip to NY and I only had one day to pack in all my must sees....this was top of the list. The WTC Path station was incredible and the actual WTC memorial and the observation tower did not disappoint. The elevator ride was really interesting because a screen shows you the progression of NYC over the years..watch out motion sensitive folks!! The big reveal of the view was just the right amount of surprise. Although a little pricey, it is New York....and the views are stunning!! Totally worth it!

WOW- What a View . The views are stunning when you get up the top. But just getting up is fun too as the lift (elevator) experience going up and coming back down is so much fun with the lifts turning into projection screens. Great fun.

good views but not the best. Staff were friendly; very cool and dramatic welcome and observation decks are very spacious with plenty of room even when it's incredibly busy at peak times and of course the views are incredible. We visited the observatory as it only opened last year and had been up Empire State and Top of the Rock in previous visits to the city however I would say if you are only doing one of these then DONT do WTC. The views are mainly of downtown and NJ and I would recommend doing Empire State or Rockefeller as their midtown locations mean you get a much better view of all of Manhattan - you can't see Central Park from WTC. But I would definitely recommend going to the area to see the tower and the 9/11 memorial and museum.

A must do. We bought our tickets online in the UK- we didn't have to queue when we got there. The lift experience is a must do in itself- I won't say why as it may spoil it but it was fantastic and cleverly done. The views were spectacular, so glad we came I would definitely make this a visit

Amazing views cafe very expensive and no seating . We visited at 9.30 in the morning. The queues were short and we got in quickly. The views were incredible. The staff were generally very pleasant. We had coffees and a breakfast sandwich, but it was quite expensive and the lack of seating could be an issue for those with mobility issues and needing to sit to have a drink.The gift shop contained very few items made in the USA !! Most came from China - which was disappointing.Loved the experience though, well worth a visit although it rather pricey.
Amazing. Amazing views. Really worth going up, but remember that is all it is to see the landscape, take a good camera
Loved it!. This was one of the best things we did while in new York. Make sure you go for the sun set tour. The elevator was mind blowing and the view was memorable, I won't forget my trip here

Unmissable at the WTC . This is the best triumphant finale to a very sad visit to the WTC Museum and Memorial. Buy your tickets online in advance. Unbelievable 360 degree views as far as your eye can see.
Can cope with a lot of visitors. Great views, all that you would expect from such a tall buildingEnjoued the introduction and staff were very friendly

Amazing views! High tech experience!. We enjoyed the "whole show" of the One World Observatory, which starts long before you actually arrive at the top. Displays, holographs, video's, etc. and an IPad to guide your viewing.

Beautiful!!!. This was a remarkable venue which I highly recommend. As a matter of fact, if you have only one thing to do, this should be it. The building is impressive as the tallest in Western Hemisphere and beautiful. Now the elevator ride is a little scary but once you get to the top there is a two minute presentation then they lift screens and you see the view. It actually brought tears to my eyes. You are allowed to walk around, listen and learn for as long as you like. We enjoyed cocktails in the bar which were quite good. Just sitting and taking in the view would be enough though if you don't drink. The staff there is so friendly and when I asked them about their job there, they each said they had been there from the very beginning. That says it all for me.

One world...three words: VISIT THIS NOW!. We booked this place for the view and was offered so much more than we bargained for!Upon arrival, you are taken through a tour of how it was built whilst being unknowingly guided to the elevator which provides an entertaining video on the walls...it's really helpful as it takes your mind off being whizzed up 90+ floors. After this, we were taken to a short demo, my advise would be to have your cameras at the ready as it's quite something having an unexpected reveal to all of New York!The views are breathtaking. With no time limits on your ticket you can stay as long as you want until kick out time and with bars and cafe's up there with you, it helps pass the time. We decided to invest in a One world observatory wine bottle which was really good; this was created especially for the observatory so its that something a little unique and abit more special whilst enjoying the view. We were fortunate enough to see the transition from day to night where NY really does become alive!All in all, its definitley worth a visit!

A must-do when visiting NYC.. This building is living proof that terrorism will never defeat us. It is a beautiful building with spectacular views of the city. The lines moved quickly and the elevator ride is quick and enjoyable. Just the site of this building upon entering NYC is enough to elicit many memories as well as pride. Both of our children were born in the post-9/11 world, so it was important to us for them to see the results of terrorism and the fact that evil did not and will not win.

Day visit. Great views all round. I would have loved an outside area for viewing. This is all inside. You don't get the feeling of the Empire State as you can go outside there. Well worth a visit though
great veiw. a little costly but I was well worth it. I wished they had my to talk about 9/11 then just how the new building was melt

Visited on Sept 10th. Amazing structure and the memorial park below is a superb memorial to those affected by the atrocity. I won't spoil the experience but the lift journey to the top of the tower is excellent and the observatory deck won't disappoint.

Simply stunning . We visited just before sunset and the views gave me goosebumps. A must do for any visitor to New York . I did pay extra for priority and that was great not having any queuing . If time is precious, it is worth those few extra $$$

Amazing Views of NYC. This is a must for anyone visiting New York City. The 360 degree views from the top were spectacular from being able to see the fabulous Statue of Liberty to the iconic Brooklyn Bridge to name but a few. I have visited the Empire State Building and 'Top of the Rock' but this is definitely the best aerial view of the city. If you only have time to visit one of these places, this is the one to choose.We had tickets so were able to avoid the fairly long queue which was a bonus particularly as it was a very hot day. We went mid-afternoon and it was very busy at the top but we still managed to see everything that we wanted to. You can also walk round as many times as you want so it wasn't a problem.
Rebuilding. Again a must to visit and a great tribute to all the people who lost their lives on this day that changed the world forever,

Sky High!!. Visited the One World Obsrvatory last year, wow what an experience, having been up the Empire State Building and The Rock, this was by far the best experience with the history of 9/11 and information about the building and completion of the Center it was a must to visit.The views around the skyline of New York were fantastic.Thoroughly recommend a visit here.

Must see amazing... Great views .. great staff to answer ur questions or give u info.. they did a great job from the time u arrive all the way to the top..visualy stunning.. self guided tours.. great job ny...enjoy

Great View and experience.. This is worth a visit. The experience is creative and interesting. The view amazing. Drink a Manhattan cocktail at the top and see the world move!! We didn't have to queue at around 4.30 - the schools had gone back and dusk was a little later. Apparently at dusk it is fuller but I expect very worth while to see the lights come on.

A new"must do" in NYC. Sometimes it's better than you thought it would be. This was one of them. For a start you can knock off a couple of other essentials, the 9/11 memorials and museum. Even the shopping mall at the foot of the tower is spectacular. The ride up in the lift is another extra, as they do a projection on the lift walls which recreates what lower Manhattan looked like through history.Naturally the views are spectacular, and you can get great shots of the Statue of Liberty, Brooklyn Bridge, Empire State etc. The restaurant was good too, and reasonably priced, Co sideline it's location.

Top of the World. We went around 3:45 and the line was long, but it went quickly. It was a bit crowed once we got to the 102nd floor and people tended to stand at the windows and not let others enjoy the view. Prices in the cafe were expensive...$9 for a can of beer. Other than that, the view was nice. Only other "issue" when taking pictures is you get a glare from the windows on the pictures. Beautiful building though. Glad we experienced it.

Ear popping view of NYC. First of all I'm going to say that my jaw actually dropped no less than 4 times. I was that impressed with what I was seeing. Now, let's back up to a few minutes earlier when I waited on (in) line (the queue) to be let in to wait again to buy tickets. I hadn't planned on stopping here so I didn't purchase advance tickets. I was a bit irked at the price of the tickets - $34 PLUS a same day processing fee of $3.00. What??? Someone swiped my card, hit the # of tickets I wanted and handed it to me... $3... in your head add up how much $3 for every transaction for the 3 to 4 clerks -- we're paying their annual income plus others! Needless to say, I felt the admission and fees were way high. However perspective wise - the building is high. Really high. Once you've parted with your $$, you head downstairs for the security check. Everything out of pockets, belt off, hat off. The newer body scan machine is used so it's very quick and easy. Next is the walk toward the elevators - through the Manhattan schist - literally. Very impressive looking - take the time to read the captions projected because it is pretty informative. Next is the elevator. This was the start of several jaw drops for me. The elevator was relatively empty (3 people) and the 3 sides (the 4th being the elevator doors) are all very high definition projectors - floor to ceiling. As the elevator goes up (and later when you come down) there is an amazing presentation of NYC rising. It was incredible. There's a short film with a really amazing ending - another jaw drop here. Next is "forced sales stop #1" where you get your photo taken with guess what as the background. I suppose it's a great momento for a family picture - but I very casually skipped it. From there is "forced sales stop #2" where you're given a sales pitch on why you should rent a $15 IPAD that will show you what everything is. If I hadn't already thought the admission and fee was too much I might have done that. But no way was I parting with another $15. Not only was there a person making the sales pitch - others were circulating among the captive audience with one to show off. From there it was simply looking out over the entire city. It was incredible.

Really well done observatory. We'd already been up in the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock on other trips to NYC. We weren't expecting to be awed by the experience at One World figuring we'd already seen the view. We were wrong. The trip up the elevator and the introduction to the 360 degree views were worth the price of admission. This may have been our favorite of the three.

Very worthwhile. The accomplishments in creating this new building are incredible. 360 degree views, and time at the memorial pools are also a must. My only criticism was the money grab of charging $15 for i pads and the obligatory tourist photo. I don't feel either of those money activities respect the sanctity of the site.

Extremely moving. Such a well designed experience and touching tribute. . Recently visited with a friend during the day. Didn't know what to expect but this experience was well crafted. You got a sense of the gravity of what had been achieved the minute you walked in and it felt quite emotional but part of the experience before the viewing deck was really cleverly done and awe-inspiring. My friend had visited before but didn't tell me what happened and was watching me out of the corner of her eye. I instantly had tears running down my face and she said she had been exactly the same on her visit. The views of the city are fantastic! Great photo opportunities. The exterior of the building is break taking! Such a huge skyscraper but cleverly designed so that its almost invisible. This should definitely be on your must see list when in the city.
Has to be done. A very efficiently run operation gets people in and up to the observation deck. As you can guess, security is tight, but not oppressive. The views on a clear day are amazing

Great views of the city. I really enjoyed the experience of the one world observatory. The elevator ride in both directions is very well done and quite unique. The only thing that stops this getting a top score is that it is a little on the pricey side.

Unbelievable View!. This is an incredible building and the observatory is unreal. We were impressed with the process because they allow people in during scheduled times, which makes the crowd manageable. The elevator ride up is fast and interesting as you see the evolution of the Manhattan area. We ate lunch at a great place on top. Great experience!
Worth every penny. Spectacular view!!! Breathtaking. I went late in the day because I wanted to see the sunset from there. It was unbelievable.

Amazing Views. Some people might consider it a little pricey, but the views are amazing. Photography can be a little tricky due to the large glass windows (there are no outside viewing areas like with Top of the Rock). One tip...don't pay the extra fee for the sunset views, just go up early and stay a while. The only major Con I had, was that the gift shop was outrageously and stupidly expensive (I can't even emphasize how stupid the prices were). I did not see one person buy anything, and they did have some nice items to purchase. I would have even paid tourist prices.
Very Sad. Went to NYC and gotta see and visit the new World Trade Center, but it was kind of sad actually i mean the building is beautiful but the 911 museum and the memorial fountain was sad.

Spectacular views. One of the must does of a trip to New York , you'd be a fool to miss it . A well thought out attraction with simply stunning views , just make sure you go on a clear day . Only slight problem was because your viewing behind glass some of our photos had unwanted reflections on them .

Stunning views. The build up to the view is done very well, starting with the great elevator ride. Great views all around. I would not recommend to pay extra for the I-pad which tells you which buildings you see while pointing at them. Directions were slightly off on the I-pad, which made a bit cumbersome to use and was a bit costly for what it added.
Awesome . A must for everyone who visits NewYork make sure you visit on a sunny clear day and get the best 360 views of New York you'll ever see, worth every dollar

Top of the world. It is well worth the queue to ascend 102 floors and see how Manhattan developed. We went just before sunset and as there was no one hurrying us to move on , had the pleasure of seeing the amazing views in daylight and the picturesque scene as the lights of the city went on. It is possible to eat at the restaurant or snack bar but we thought it was poor value and as you are never far from a decent delicatessen in NY, we waited until we had gone down. Going down in the lift is worth s mention. It is over in 45 seconds and you don't realise you've moved!

NYC From above. Ideal attraction to get a nice view over NYC.I think it is worth to take the option where you go to the 120th Floor as you can notice the difference from the 86th.The only way to get a better view from above is taking a helicopter tour.
That is the must of the city !. That is the must of the city at least the newest must! so maby cost more than $35 but the view is stunning
Amazing. Amazing building, amazing technology. Perfect show in elevator, superb show after elevator, breathtaking view from observatory.

Very expensive but an incredible view!. We enjoyed this but it was very expensive. Had hoped to get a bite to eat at the cafe and then watch the sunset at the observatory level but they stop serving much of the food at 6 and there is no place to sit anyway. A lot of standing and few benches in the observatory. We went when it was not very crowded so the line to get in was not terrible at all. Cannot imagine waiting two hours in the sun just to enter! Worth doing - once- especially since we had the grandkids with us.

Tallest building in NYC. At the observatory, you can see the city from 541 meters high, or 104 floors, so a bit higher than the Empire State, which has 443 meters and102 floors. Practically speaking, if you’ve seen Manhattan from one of them, seeing it from the other is a bit redundant.Other than that, there's places to eat inside, inlcuding a VIP restaurant, a souvenir shop, and after exiting the elevators you will see a short video about Manhattan, which is pretty cool.At the One World Trade Center Observatory, the ticket price depends on the day and time of your visit. The standard ticket is $32 and it can be bought online or on site.

Magnificent!. Undeniably stunning views for as far as the eye can take you! Entry is a bit pricey, especially when there are no markings to tell you what you are seeing. Rather they try to rent you an iPad for another $15 that will give you that information. No lines for us on a Friday early afternoon :)

Nice building but the visit is too commercial . The building work is great and the view worth it but I felt like a sheep as the queue moves from outside the building to the elevator and again when arriving on top of it. Too crowded, not enough explanation, stories, places to rest: go round once and go!
What a view. What a view, just stunning. Ever where you look you see all the great monuments. It's great to start here so you can get the lay of the land before venturing out to explore NEW YORK.

A fantastic view...... There was a commentary that was really interested and conducted in a fantastic maner.I was, however, extremely disappointed that the windows had not been covered with a antireflective shield. By all means you don't get a better place for taking photos of the city. Being unable to take clear pictures doesn't make me want to buy one of their picture books - I'll just visit Empire the new time. And while we are at the windows - they were full of smears from hands, heads etc. Thats not really good enough for what you pay.But the view is phenomenal and the elevator ride excellent so I would recommend anyone to go.

I dreaded going because afraid of heights, I worried about it for months but didn't want to miss it with my family!. I was an incredible experience. There was never a moment I felt the fear or quiziness of heights I dreaded. The elevator has a historical movie of NYC from dirt up, fascinating. When you Step off the elevator which goes 103 floors in 60 seconds, there is an amazing movie, fast paced, exciting, like NYC, and then the wall slides open and you see the city. You go WOW! and it takes your breath away. Please rent the iPad for $15 dollars. It is definitely worth watching what it does. Don't be the least bit nervous, but make sure you go on a Clear Day so you Can See Forever!

Pricey, but nice presentation. This attraction is a bit pricey, but overall, they do a nice job with the presentation. The elevator ride up showed how New York City grew from its initial years as a city in the 1600's to the city it is today. The visuals of people who witnessed 9/11 and were dedicated to bringing this new building to fruition were moving, as was the unveiling of the skyline. However, for the price, I would think that each family/group might be provided with a complimentary tablet showing you the city sights from above, versus paying for one more thing.

Wow!!!!. A wonderful building with a very reasonable priced restaurant at the top which had amazing views of Manhattan & surrounds. It was a bit surreal being on top with the knowledge of what happened 15 years ago & my thoughts were definitely with the victims of the horrendous terrorist attack. I'm an Aussie through & through but the resilience & patriotism of Americans truly rocks!!!!!

Amazing !!. We visited the One World Observatory on September 9th. The Feelings that stirred inside are hard to put into words. Knowing the tragic events that occurred on this ground left my heart heavy but at the same time seeing the tribute that has been built to honor those that lost their life brought joy also. The observation deck gives you wonderful views all the way around and I would recommend it to everyone.

Beautiful. This place should be on everyone's bucket list. It is a beautiful sight to see. From the elevator ride up to the 102nd floor the look out and the photo ops are all magnificent. There are iPad rentals available to help you in all languages enjoy the scenery and sights.

Anniversary Trip. This is a must see for everyone visiting the city. We had the honor of being here on September 11th. I honestly think we could see forever. Such a beautiful view, in every direction.
Visiting family in NYC. Very moving. Brings home the sacrifice made by many and the losses suffered by many. Our visit included the Tower as well as the museum. Plan to spend at least 4 hours.

Great views of the city skyline. We were there in August but there were no lines and few people on the observation deck. You can hardly feel the elevator's ascent--be sure to watch the video on the walls on the way up. At the top you have a 360 degree view of the city. Pretty spectacular. We paid $15 for the IPad to learn more about some sights we were seeing. Great concept but had lots of trouble getting it to stay synced in to our location. Would pass on that additional expense.

Spectacular & Amazing Views of New York City. The views from One World Observatory are breathtaking. There are 360 degree views of the City. I loved looking at the Rooftops of lower Manhattan. The gorgeous view of Midtown is so impressive. I also enjoyed the majestic Brooklyn Bridge from above--it is truly beautiful. On the elevator ride up, they project the history of lower Manhattan on the elevator walls--very impressive. While there is a lot of tourist junk on sale and tickets aren't cheap, you really get a sense of the Island of Manhattan and it will stay with you for a lifetime!
Top of the world. Visited just before sunset to get the daytime and night time views. Unbelievable views of NYC and the memorial gardens. Awesome visit

Expensive. You get a very impressive view of all the 5 boroughs and you can also see NJ and Connecticut on a clear day, but the price to get up there prevented me from paying to see the Ground Zero Museum as well as other attractions in NYC.

Amazing !. I was atop one of the "Twins" in November 2000 and watched at home in England the horror that was 9/11. Going back to the top of the new World Trade Centre was, for me, a show of disgust for terrorism and respect for the victims.
Wow. We've visited New York on several occasions. This was our first visit to OWO - we were not disappointed!
Best view ever. Visited last week. Was not disappointed. Amazing presentation and uninterrupted views of this awesome city. Would highly recommend.

Amazing views, long wait. Even at $37 worth doing this, also when you have been to empire state building. As it is much more south you get a better overall NYC view. Great experience, including a nice suprise in the elevator and when you arrive on the top.Make sure you have some time, there will be a line outside and another two inside, one to get through security and another one for the elevator. Took us over an hour from when we queued to get in the elevator. On the top, another line...Anyway, still worth it, definitely must do.

One word sums it up - wow!. You might think your $35 entrance fee is high - but it'll be worth it. You are whisked up what is one of the fastest elevators in the world, but that's not the half of it. Ringing the top of the elevator walls - and they are deliberately 2 stories high - is a 360-degree moving projection and timeline, taking the city from its foundation to today - you can see each of the many buildings and developments taking place. I could have ridden the elevator itself a dozen times. You exit the elevator to a series of juxtaposed white pillars - different heights and distances forming a solid line, against which are projected sights, scenes, and sounds of NYC today. Just when you start to get a sense of the rhythm and vitality the designers are trying to portray, the walls whisk up and you are standing in front of a towering set of unencumbered windows- the observation windows of One World Trade Center. You make your way across to the 360 degree observation platform down a set of stairs, and you can spend all the time you want looking down at the city and the 20+ miles that surround it. You can rent an innovative iPad self-tour that is its own impressive piece of technology (and it's only $15). There is a snack bar, a nice restaurant, and a gift shop, but none of them are as "in-your-face" nor obligatory as, say, the Empire State Building. When you're finished, you once again board your elevator-come-thrill ride, but this time, it simulates busting out of the side of the building and hurtling itself down to the building's base. I can't think of another observation experience like this, but it will certainly spur similar developments in other cities. Definitely needs to be on your "must-see" list.
Amazing . Everyone should spend time to visit one of my highlight of spending time in New York. We all were humbled by this truly amazing day

Great NYC experience. NYC certainly did this site right. The building itself is breathtaking as it rises 100+ floors straight up with reflective windows. We purchased the priority tickets online to avoid standing in line for hours, and it was a very smart move. There was quite a long line snaked outside around the building when we arrived mid-morning and we walked right in, went thru security, stepped on the elevator, and were in the observatory in less than 5 minutes. (I highly suggest the priority tickets if you are crunched for time.) There are ipads to rent for $15 that you may point out towards the views that indicate what buildings you are viewing. The city below is breathtaking! You can see the Statue of Liberty, Manhattan, the bridges, the rivers, the 9/11 Memorial etc. There is a clear glass portal you may stand or walk on that looks down 100 stories below you, in real time. The observatory is quite spacious and there is room for everyone to get great views. There are restrooms, a restaurant, gift shop and various speakers throughout the 360 degree site. In my opinion, this is a must-see when visiting New York. The views are spectacular. This is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere and is worth every penny.

It's high but it's inside and difficult to photograph well . Having done the Empire State Building before we made straight for 1 World Trade Centre on this visit. Higher must be better, right? Well not exactly. The elevator ride up is indeed spectacular as you pass through a 360 degree digital animation of the evolution of the city. But as if that's not enough when you get to the top you're herded into another space to watch another hype video, this time an overwhelming and ever changing mosaic of scenes from the city with an insistent sound track. At its end the whole wall lifts away to reveal the view and just as you go wow you're moved on again. Round another corridor and you're greeted by someone on a microphone talking insistently at the crowd. By now we were getting quite frustrated as all we wanted was to see the view. When you do finally get into the large observation area it's actually a bit of an anti-climax. Everything has to be looked at through windows which naturally everyone gravitates towards. If you want to take photos it's quite frustrating made worse by greasy smears from many hands and reflections from the bright lighting which really affected our dusk shots. Why they've chosen to light it so brightly I do not know. There was too much Disney hype about this for us and the thing we actually came to see, the view, was difficult to photograph. This is great for kids I have no doubt but if you're after a city view you can take pictures of, go to the Empire State Building outdoor deck. It's much better.

Awe Inspiring. This truly is an awe inspiring place. We visited ground zero very early on when nothing was there, then when the pools were done. Then when the museum was open we visited. To be able to witness this beautiful place take shape and see the hard work of those who built has been an honor. The American spirit is alive here. This isn't just a great view of the city its a testament to the American spirit and how we always dust ourselves off and pick ourselves up after a truly saddening time. If its crowded when you are there please look beyond that and remember why you are there and what happened there.

Amazing views. We visited a week ago and despite having 'Fast Track' passes we queued for about an hour in total. As expected security was like when you go to an airport and this slowed things down. The lift experience was fast and the videos added to the experience. I liked the video presentation and as the screens lifted and you saw the city in front of you it was a definite WOW! moment. Shame the glass wasn't as clean as it could have been as it spoilt a lot of photo opportunities. I would have liked to have seen an open viewing deck or at least gaps in the glass like at the Rockerfeller center. Worth the money for the views though.

Totally Surprised! Hint- pre buy the VIP tickets online. We visited on 9/10 and bought the VIP tickets. I joined the Army in 8/2000 and wanted to take the kids to ground zero again to remember what happened 15 years ago that changed our country. It is a sacred place. The observatory is amazing. It is very very different than the 9/11 memorial and focuses entirely on NYC and is very positive. PRO TIP: Get the VIP tickets to skip the massive line and get your video camera out and film the ride up. Very cool historical surprise. Also the iPad rental with the zoom and view is GPS tuned to your location. It is very clean and well organized and the staff were some of the best. Worth every second. Plan for at least 40 minutes to walk and look.
AMAZING. The whole experience was extraordinary; beautiful building and elevators, and the view. The store is overpriced though.

WOW! Stunning views, great attraction overall. $38/ personWe decided to go here after the 9/11 museum on a whim. We were excited to see what the view was from the top and we were not dissappointed. After getting through security, you are transported to the "foundation" of the building and they really emphasize the rock that the building is sitting on. Once on the elevator to the top, (and it travels FAST), you are presented with a short movie playing on the walls of the elevator of New York and how it grew from the 1600s to today. Once at the top, you are shown another video and after it is over, they open up the wall to reveal the outside. WOW!! From there it is a short walk to the observation deck and it offers stunning 360 degree panoramic views of NYC. On our day, we had about 20 miles of visibility. The ride back down also had another video on the walls of the elevator. Must see attraction!

Wow. An even better presentation than "The Rock" (no clues, I don't want to spoil it).The moto "See forever" is well adopted, the view is stunning. Great cafe at the top and a well stocked souvenir shop with a large assortment of items. I would say it's an amazing statement of defiance of the 9/11 atrocities and I applaud the city for this amazing piece of architecture .

Crowded, herd mentality with great views. This was a mixed bag for me. The ride up was totally entertaining...amazing how fast you go up. The movie before they let you see the view seems like a waste of time. I was there for the view. It's a money making operation, so the "stand here on the x" commands and the "move all the way down to the end" feel like they're herding cattle. To be fair, I was there on 9/10 so maybe it was busier than normal. Go on a day where there are no lines and I'm sure you'll miss all of the things that made my impression suffer.

Great view & Experince. It was very very organized, we didn't have to wait in line. Advice try the restaurant at the roof such delicious drinks and pork ribs appetizer. I am defiantly glad I made it and spent such an awesome time there!!
Stunning views. This was a great experience. With stunning views, it was nice to see the view from lower down the city. The videos they show in the lifts on the way up and down are amazing!

Worth a visit. Went here on a Saturday morning queues were not to big security check before you went in The elevator ride was part the attraction wonderful view from observation floor total cost per person 37 dollars

360 view of NY city. the bottom are the rocks of the 911. the lift to 102 floor is fast and nice. Then - came the showcase before the opening of the window to see view from the floor. Interesting.It's a place to have 360 view of NY city.

Incredible!. To visit this tower on September 10th was very humbling. What a great monument and an amazing achievement, you can see the passion that went in to achieving such an incredible building. We loved every minute of our experience. Ensure you visit the bar and restaurant for a truly wonderful time at the One World Observatory.

The view is good but.... The view is great, but it's indoor behind glass with a dark floor, so trying to get decent pictures isn't particularly good.Given this building was designed partially to accommodate tourists, you'd have thought they would have included an outdoor observation deck where you could enjoy a clear view without horrible, almost dirty looking glass, misting up photos.The grand reveal as you get out of the elevator I found to be an irritation. 60 seconds of stock video with a 10 second reveal on the end. Not great and fairly pointless.But the facilities and tourist queue management are almost first class.

A Wonderful Experience. The visit is very well organized, accommodating huge numbers of people in a very orderly fashion. All who work there, are friendly and helpful. From the ride up to the Observatory and on to presentation which introduces the Observatory, the stage is perfectly set for the experience of the Observatory itself. Once you enter the Observatory every view is stunning and absolutely makes you feel as if you are on top of the world. Took a peek at the Cafe and the Restaurant and both seem terrific. People were certainly enjoying their food. Will definitely make plans to have dinner, next visit. Enjoyed a glass of champagne at the bar, thoroughly enjoying the greatest city in the world and celebrating the wonderful experience of being exactly where I was.

Good . I live in New York city and have seem them all.... One world is a good place to go too.... It's a little expensive but if you have seen this then no need to go to empire state.... One of the 2 is good enough.... As its the same... I feel the view from one world is better than empire state building.... And the best view is actually rocker feller center... As that shows central park whixh looks amazing during fall :)
fantastic. A real unusual experience - combination of real and virtual views. if you visit just one view point in Manhattan, this is the place to go. ,

Overcrowded Tourist Trap. This place was crazy! Awesome engineering and very nice building! Could not help to think does any of that money they raise go to the families of individuals who lost their life on 911. Come see ground zero but pass on this!!!! Empire State Building is way better!!! Just know you are cattle into one video and then into another to get your photo! Don't waste 34.00 go see the Statue of Liberty! Oh yes the glass was dirty and smudged so good luck getting a good photo!!!

Great view. This is a great experience, to see New York from the top of the tallest building in the USA. Frustrating, that they try to sell you a photo, even though you don't want one, then the iPad to explore the view, considering the entrance cost, this seems excessive

Amazing views, haunting experience . We wandered around the 9/11 memorial first, which is incredible for very different reasons. Then we boarded the lift and shot up the 100 or so floors to the One World Observatory. The views are spectacular as you would expect, but for us it was inextricably linked to the 9/11 memorial and you could not help but reflect on what it must have been like for those involved. Worth the money and your time to visit a great spot.

Worth the money, for view and experience. Buy your tickets in the building not from the ticket touts outside. Great views as would be expected. Extremely well organised. Talks from guides within the circular screens every short while. There is the option of an ipad for 15 dollars which tells you what you are seeing when you click on it, but we didnt take the offer. Download your own audio guide and listen to it on your smartphone. Restaurant was really good, unexpectedly good for a tourist attraction. Views spectacular.

Another New York "must see.". Great 360 degree views of NY, NJ, etc. Great place to take photos. Only problem was it's hard to get a really great shot through a window.. Didn't spend a lot of time here, just took photos from all sides. The real star of this attraction in my opinion was the elevator ride....102 floors in 47 seconds. There was a video on three sides of the elevator different for the upward ride and downward. Loved it! Would not have minded doing it again!

What a view. The ride was so quick, it took about 40 seconds to get to the top. Then they have a scene with city view, subway train roaring by, then the unveil, it was breath taking You can rent an audio device that is really worth the $15, they have them in every language.. You get to walk around and put your face right up to the windows and look down at an amazing city. Go on a clear day. I got tickets from Living Social at a discount and didn't have to wait on line. I'm a New Yorker and never get tired of the views, took my binoculars and got to see my building across the river to Brooklyn, awesome must go. Will be taking my friends next time they are in town

Great Experience!. Great views and an amazing elevator ride to the top. We visited back in April and even on a slightly cloudy day it was still breathtaking from the top. A must on a visit to New York!

Great view, windows are annoyingly reflective whilst taking photos.. We went up to the observatory a few days ago. Won't ruin it but the lift ride was an interesting virtual experience in itself (not scary) you only get to see the view once you've arrived at the top when it's revealed by a screen and everyone emits the same audible *GASP*! The actual observatory floor is what you'd expect.. everyone trying to get the same shot from the same area which was a bit annoying. The glass is quite reflective so its quite difficult at times to get a perfectly clear shot. What else can I say, it's an amazing view and worth the visit. Put it in the itinerary!

Very commercialized!. Was very disappointed to see how commercialized they have made this.....like a Disney world experience...was saddened to see them take a monumental time in history and turn it into this. Every stop they try to sell you sonething....was a foggy day and could not see a thing...don't go up if there is fog

A must-do in new york. No matter how touristy it might sound, but given a chance this place is not worth missing owing to its spectacular view of New York. The whole experience of approaching the top of the building is in itself rewarding. *spoiler alert* my best moment was- just after the screening of history of New York after which unexpectedly the screen rose to give way to the most breathtaking view of New York right in front of us! That kinda gave me goose bumps :)

Yes!. Don't want to spoil anything so book and visit - the views are incredible!Very well organised and friendly staff!The elevators are so so so fast! You reach the top in no time at all .....another must do if you are visiting Manhattan!

Spectacular views of downtown, Brooklyn and the harbor entrance, not so much of the rest of Manhattan. You are definitely going to enjoy the spectacular views from the top of WTC One and learn more about NYC, especially since it is not crowded (at least when we were there in August, peak tourist time) and there are knowledgable guides who will offer to help locate and explain what you can see. You can have a meal with views at the snack bar (decent food, I thought) or in the sit-down restaurant, and of course get souvenirs at the gift shop, where the bathrooms are rather connivingly located. I would not recommend getting the $10 ipad they offer you, as the human guides at the top were a better resource for us. The midtown-facing windows are taken up by large displays which are used for for interesting explanatory sessions that take place almost continually. However, these displays obstruct the view of midtown Manhattan from what would be the two best corners to see it from, and many of the sights explained there (the Empire State Building, Broadway, etc) are best seen from observation decks nearer those sights (Top of the Rock or the ESB observatory). The best sights to see from WTC1 are the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, the Hudson River, the Brooklyn Bridge and lower Manhattan. When you are ready to leave, you may be tired of observing, but save some energy for enjoying the video in the down elevator, where you exit the tower, spiral around it and come back in for a landing.

Not to be missed. Awe inspiring, the 60 second lift ride with videos of New York from its beginning to present day playing on the lift walls wow. When the view from the observatory is finaly revealed it takes your breath away. A deeply moving tribute to those poor folk who perished on 9/11. The Americans couldn't have done it better.

Visit. Amazing place with amazing views of the whole city, ongoing video presentations about the history of the build since the tragic events of 9/11. The lift ride itself was an experience travelling at 25mph and a film show all the way. Coffee prices at the top were reasonable considering where you were and admission price was fair. Definitely worth going to when in New York

very well done.. Helpful knowledgable staff, and with wonderful endless views of the area including marine terminals (watched the Queen Mary 2 depart), Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Governor's Island, New Jersey, etc. $15 for the iPad tour enhancement worth the price.

Great Place.!! You need a few hours to enjoy everything.. Everyone should visit this spectacular building. You need at least 3 hours to take advantage of all its offerings. The guides at the various displays are very informative and sometimes funny. You won't believe your eyes when you look out the windows. Restaurant is very good. If you want to see a spectacular sunset, you need to time your visit.
Spectacular view. Nothing to say... Just enjoy the view and discover New York from the sky... Why not 5/5 because it is very expensive for the roof top of a business building.

Breathtaking . First off yes it is a little pricey but if youve already have visited Empire State Building/Top of the Rock then this is worth it. With a different view (from downtown looking north and also seeing the Hudson) this observatory has a 360 view that is stunning. We went right at sunset and zipped through the line. Although it seemed long we got through in less than 20mins. And our line started from outside. Don't forget to check out every side to get the whole fill.

Simply amazing!. You have to go, right at the beginning you already get amazed at the elevator, after that there is a presentation showing NYC from its beginning, I can't say everything without spoiling the next visitor.

Wow. An amazing success story born from such a tragic event. From arrival until departure the observatory had our full attention. The journey 'up' is an extremely innovative way to demonstrate history of the surrounding area. As expected, the views across NY were breathtaking and to have employees talking about NYC was a additional benefit we greatly appreciated. As impressive as our visit was, visiting the WTC was extremely emotional. Like everyone we met, we also paid our respects to those who passed a few short years ago. I recommend you visit. It is truly inspiring.

Emotional and breath-taking views.. For anyone who lived in New York, visited the original trade center or remember the awful Sep 11 day, this place will mean something. It was an emotional experience. What they did with this place was very creative and thoughtful. The entrance was quick and when we got we took the time to read the story and watch all the video, to get the story behind building this monument. The views are amazing. Good experience.
Great experience. Definitely worth doing for the elevator ride and the views across New York and beyond, particularly if it's a clear day.

Expect to pay, and pay, and pay.. The visual experience IS beyond compare. Seeing NYC from that height is a blast (always has been, always will be), but be prepared, it's gonna cost you. If you want to avoid the lines it will cost you $56.00 per ticket. If you want to have a photo souvinier taken of you by one of their photographers add another $10. If you want to use their "One World Explorer" (basically an iPad Rental running a program that identitifes landmarks such as the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building, etc.) that's another $15.00. A t-shirt in the gift shop: $34.95, a 6" resin (that is, plastic) model of the building: 29.95. Total: $94.90 EXCLUDING food. If you plan on feeding anyone in your group, bring along another wad of cash.All of this is totally worth it (it was to me) but just this once. At nearly $100 bucks a pop, and with five nieces in tow, it will be a LONG time before I take them back to see the place. I paid the ticket price (high, but, I figured, it is a unique experience so...) but $10 for a picture? (we took our own for free using iPhones), $15 to see each landmark identified? (again, Google image search and various other apps did the job for free). The elevator ride up, is pretty spectacular but it's over before you can really appreciate it. Once at the top of the building, a lame "See Forever Theatre" presentation is little more than a bunch video clip art of NYC. "Sky Portal" lets you stand on a glass floor and stare down at video screens depicting what the view would be (if there WASN'T a building beneath your feet -- honestly a very creepy thing for most of the adults who -- to a person -- mumbled about "9/11" as the skirted this display). The so-called "City Pulse" experience is a bunch of TV screens arranged in a circle showing more images of NY (all of which pale next to the acutal view out the nearby windows).Yes, it was exciting to see the view again, but the whole experience seemed rather vulgar when every staff person we passed seemed to have their hand out asking us for more money.
outstanding. Went there in januar 2016 with my wife. I would recomend to go there just before the sun is going down. Its worth the money.

Don't miss even after the Empire State building. Visited when my family were shopping on our last day in New York. We had already visited the Empire State Building but the One World Observatory is even better. Views are great and give you a great overview of the harbour, landscape and the Statue of Liberty, ok you are not as near to the buildings in mid town Manhattan as the ESB but you are higher, get free talks on the growth and geography of New York and the experience of getting in is so much easier and more relaxed. Recommended

Highlight!. Buy the tickets online. Figure out when sunset is and get there before to see the view in the light and then in the dark. Truly spectacular! Be patient to find a window spot and then hang for a while. There is a bar up there as well!

A Must Visit!. if you are in NY city for tourism, then this one needs to be there on your to do list. You need to pay an entry fee of $37 for an adult, $35 for Senior and $31 for child. Their website says purchasing it online saves you $3 for a ticket, but in reality you don't since they charge you a processing fee. The only advantage of getting your tickets online is you can skip the line for ticket at the tower. Once you reach the top, the view is from the 102nd floor is amazing! We went there at around 5:30 PM and stayed there until sunset which was again an incredible sight.The place got crowded at around the sunset time. I would recommend going to this place only if the sky is clear, else you would not get to see much. Overall a pleasant trip and I would highly recommend this place for a one time visit!

Views of a lifetime. It all starts with an amazing lift ride. You then have the 360 views of the city "AMAZING"You are at the top of he highest skyscraper in the Northern HemisphereThis should be at the top of your must see list. Try to go for the early tickets, although we were there in August, there were no crowds at all.

Breathtaking views!. Buying your tickets ahead of time and online will save you time and money. The only problem is that the weather isn't always guaranteed. To get the most of your visit, a clear day is essential. On a perfect, cloudless day, you can see as far as 50 miles away! As you begin your visit, you'll take a sky pod to the top. This was probably my favorite part. During the 60 seconds it takes to get to the top, you'll see a time-lapse movie that shows you how the City has changed over the years. Absolutely jaw -dropping! The main observatory has huge panoramic windows that offer the most magnificent views of this bustling city. I was a little disappointed that you needed to rent the Ipads for an extra $15 to enjoy the full interactive experience.If you're not afraid of heights, then don't miss the 14 foot wide disc on the 100th floor. Here you can step on and look down at real-time Manhattan streets and traffic!I would recommend that you buy a "standard" admission ticket. I don't see why you'd spend $20 more per person for priority access.

Too many people, pricey tourist trap!. The view on a beautiful September day was spectacular, HOWEVER it was a challenge just to get up to the windows to view out. Too many people up there at one time, and once at the window people waiting behind you! The pressure sales pitches (which I was prepared for) of renting tablets, photo's etc I walked right past. The souvenirs were priced exorbitantly as well. Many people waiting in line for overcrowded restaurant. $24 hamburger?Why is it $34 (adult) to look out some windows? Sadly we're all still paying for 9/11

A High light of our trip to New York. A must see.. We had a great few hours here. After the sadness and reflective atmosphere of the Twin Towers Memorial, this visit was very exciting.After buying tickets you enter in to room with a large video wall where you can hear people involved in the project to build WT1 giving their stories. Their obvious pride and passion is very moving. Some people strode through on the way to the elevators but I stayed for 30mins and it was well worth it.The elevators are like a 270 degree video screen that gives you a rapid journey through time as you rapidly ascend to the 102 floor, my favourite part of the trip.You then proceed to a viewing gallery where the vistas of New York are revealed. Breath taking height and views.All in all I would highly recommend this trip.

Great view, obviously, but a bit expensive . It's 37 dollars to get to the top, which I found a little bit expensive. There is a bar and a restaurant on the top floor, which was nice, but also a pricey. The visualization in the elevator on the way up was almost the coolest part of the experience!

Amazing and Breathtaking !!. I've seen this place being built over the last few years !! I was totally blown away with the way the visit is present right up to the revelation of the view as the screen rises ... outstanding! Can't recommend this attraction enough .. just a shame it came to be there because of the circumstances of 9/11 ...

Brilliant Views & Bar. I visited recently with my partner and we spent around ~2 hours here in total. The building itself is stunning and the inside is even better, from the fancy lifts to the presentation when you reach the top. We went to the bar and ended up staying for some drinks - I tried four cocktails (all of which were lovely) and my partner tries some of the local beer/ales. The bar is pretty pricey, but this is to be expected for its location. The views from the observatory deck are brilliant and on a clear day you can see for miles! My only criticism is the sales pitch from the staff wanting you to rent a tablet - they approach you and start to chat, and once hooked in to a conversation, try to pressure sale tablet rental on to you. We declined this and don't see the benefit this would have on an otherwise fabulous view and location.

Fantastic views!. When we went we were surprised to find absolutely no queues at all. This was at about 5.30pm. So straight up to the top. The views were amazing. Being behind glass was a bit annoying when trying to take photos, especially with the Suns reflection, but most photos came out well.As we were getting hungry we decided to look at the restaurant menu, which we found very reasonably priced. The restaurant was fairly empty too, so we ate there, with our table overlooking Manhattan. It was fantastic. I'm so pleased we did that.

One World Observatory is a must visit in my opinion. Whilst One world observatory focusses on the view and rebuilding post 9/11 it is difficult not to reflect on the events of that dreadful day and how those trapped so high felt while you are looking out of the windows.It provides 360 degree views stretching as far as 4 states. Obviously the views of the 5 boroughs and the Hudson are insane from this height and location.The 9/11 museum is separate and is located by the reflection pools. The lift up 102 floors takes less than 60 seconds and has a great video on the way up & down.A very affordable and informative experience.

A bit pricey but the view is tremendous. If you book online in advance you can save a few bucks but the trip up 102 floors will still set you back. The trip itself is smooth and fast and once at the top, the views are spectacular. Ideally visit on a clear day.

My favorite "tourist" attraction in NYC!. We have done all of the touristy things on NYC but I went to the top of the One World Observatory and was blown away with how gorgeous the views are. You can see everything and it's great for photo opportunities. Also recommend the restaurant at the top for a nice lunch and a drink or too. You cannot match the view anywhere else in NYC. Also recommend getting the fast pass tickets if you are going on a Saturday since we did not have to wait in line! Wonderful experience during a trip to NY!
Best views of New York. Breathtaking views of the entire NYC area...and educational on how the city has grown through the ears

Great views. Great view of the city from here. Views are great we went to see the sun set. A very busy place so expect a crowd. There is a restaurant that you can sit down eat and look out at the city. It was a bit erie to be up in the tower and realize that many people were there and lost their lives here. Go and enjoy the view and remember the people that died there.

Fabulous view, amazing sunset. The tallest building in the Western Hemisphere provides an incredible view of New York and New Jersey. On a clear day, they said you can see Pennsylvania and Connecticut. We set our tickets for 5 pm entry. This allowed us time to get to the top well before the sun set. The sunset was amazing. A person who works there said the terrific sunset usually lasts about 10 minutes. This evening it lasted for an hour. There are 2 areas where someone provides a talk about a variety of topics dealing with the World Trade Center, or food in New York, or what to see and do in NY. It is well worth listening to the talks to learn more. If you can't stand for long, bring a wheelchair, as there is very little seating available. There are special Ipads available for $15 which show you what is located outside the tower. They aren't calibrated very well, and not nearly enough sites are labeled as to what they are. I paid $15, but I felt it wasn't worth it. Loved the experience, and would definitely do it again. No doubt, the view changes every day.

Great Visit from the ground up to the top. Don't miss this if you are in NYC. The experience starts once you enter the que area for the elevator. Unbelievable view at the top. Make sure to allow plenty of time.

One Visit!. A little bit disappointed with this experience , over hyped, over full and under explained? The viewing areas were too full and even though we had an iPad guide , it was temperamental and therefore we were unsure as to which building or area we were looking at. We took our 3 daughters and to say they were underwhelmed is an understatement. To be honest would rather have gone to the Empire State Building were we could have gone out on the viewing platforms.

Typical Tall Building Experience. The view was amazing (we went on a clear day) but there was nothing to set this apart from other really tall buildings. The one negative is that you must purchase the Observatory Ticket in order to dine in the restaurant at the top -- not true at other tall towers. In Auckland, New Zealand's tower, for example, the restaurant has a dedicated elevator for diners so that they don't have to pay the observation deck fee.
Breathtaking!. This is a must do when in the lower Manhattan area. Such a cool way to experience the city. I want to go back during the evening to see the city from another perspective.
So impressie. The views of the city were spectacular as was the building, It was specially moving seeing the twin tower footprints from above,

Great view but.... You can't fail to be impressed by the view but the experience was not as great as it should be. We booked in advance for the sunset visit. Lots of people were sitting against the windows so it was difficult to get any photos. Standing further back means you get a lot of reflection from the angled glass.There are no seats, not even to have a drink, they obviously discourage lingering.Much had been made of the lift rides but it all happens very fast.I have been to the Empire State building and prefer the opportunity to go outside to view.

Amazing Experience!. We bought our tickets online, which saved us a lot of time. Suggest you buy the flex tickets, so you can visit any time of the day, they're a little bit more expensive, but well worth it. We were at the 9/11 Museum beforehand which took us a bit longer than we expected. Loved the elevator ride up with the transformation of the city and the views were just amazing! They also had these iPads that you could rent for $15 that would give you information about all the different landmarks as you pointed the iPad in that direction. Overall, a really nice experience. Well done!
No better introduction. One of the neatest intros and walk up to an observatory I've ever seen. Fantastic views of the entire city.

A Must on The List. This needs to be booked ahead though you can buy tickets. It is an amazing experience. I won't spoil it but many wow moments. Then you can hire an iPad for $15 that shows you what you are seeing. You can click them for more info. No pressure to leave so you can wander on the observation deck for as long as you want. It is worth visiting Broomfield across the road

Great views of Manhattan but just too much people.. I know. We were there in probably the busiest week-end of all in NYC...labor day week-end.But,I would assume that they limit visitors to give us a good experience ... not the case.The other thing you're assuming is that's a spot to take great pictures of the city,Not the case also: reflections everywhere because you don't have access to an exterior place to stop the reflections.For us, the best views are stil at the Top of the Rock observation deck at Rockefeller Center. You can't have a better place to feel Manhattan from the top of a building.If you're planing to go at World Trade Center...go at the Museum instead: amazing experience!

Do it!!. I was so impressed by this, finally was able to go and I'm so glad I did. If you have to choose one place to go for view of city choose this. Experience was way better than Empire State! I can't wait to take my kids.

Great place to visit. The new world trade center is open to public. Is a great side tour to take. Great view and a lot of info, available. The restaurant at the top is Ok, but if you want to eat there, you still have to pay $42.00 to get there so be ready.

Sunset Pictures ?. I bought tickets for the sunset hour to take pictures of the sunset. That was a mistake. It cost more and they weren't checking entry times, only dates of entry on tickets.
