The film in the elevator ride up was great. They move the lines up and down really efficiently and the crowd spacing was manageable.

Weekday trip. Very excellent views of the City. Best I have seen to date! Took a weekday tour. Booked online for 6:30 PM, walked right in straight to the elevator. Elevator ride was moving (no pun intended). I would do it again absolutely!

Point of interest for NYC visit. Worth the price, excellent 360 view for lots of photos. Our group of 8 spent 2 hours here and we really enjoyed learning more about the building, the area and looking for recognizable points of interest from the top
NY Trip. It would of been nice if they gave you some information about the building, it was like being in a heard of cattle going to the stockyard.

Amazing 360 Views. A must see for any local or tourist.We paid $130 for 4 adults and after a clearing security we proceeded to the lifts to take us up to the Observatory.The lifts are all screens which show the history of the area being developed as you rise to the top.Once at the top - you enter into a small theatre with some more imagery of the development of 1 WTC - with a breathtaking surprise at the end.You are then free to move around the floors taking in the awesome views that exist around and below.There is a souvenir store along with bat and café.A great hour well spent - wasn't too busy when we arrived (1pm) although they were queuing when we left.

Exceeded High Expectations. We visited with our 11 year old grandson. We expected s lot. And One World delivered more than that. What a wonderful experience for young and old alike. We appreciated that the experience was designed to accommodate lots of people - but be leisurely and relaxing.The tickets are sold on a timed entry basis for each day. We highly recommend that you spend a few more bucks and get the Flex Entry VIP ticket. Then you can arrive at anytime during a specific day - and go around all the lines and straight up the elevators 102 stories - in 48 seconds. PS: The food service is excellent.

Worth it. No queues! So it was even better. The View is amazing Just too bad there is no open space... But it was amazing and The View is lovely. We could see The Brooklyn bridge soooo neat! It was worth. Plus they gave us a discount for century 21 .
OMG. this is amazing. do not miss it. we had a fantastic weather day for it - might not be as great on a rainy day.

Fabulous views. We had a lovely visit to One World Observatory. We got VIP skip the line tickets which I thoroughly recommend as the lines were quite long (we were there on a weekday afternoon in July). The elevator ride up and the AV presentation before you get to the top are terrific. The views from the observatory deck are fabulous. We splurged and spent the $15 on the interactive iPad but if I had my time over, I wouldn't bother with it.
Worth it. What a view, organization, service and amazing elevators. A must do in NYC with a family. A tribute to America. Worth the money !

Jaw dropping.. The views are tremendous and the building is stunning. 360 degrees of scenery and whilst at the top you can choose to eat or drink. There is a gift shop at the top, a little pricy but you have to have the souvenir. Don't miss this if you are in NY.

First visit to one world . I was moved by it I'm British but love the USA and I felt it !Big time I went on a Wednesday pm in August and it was expecting huge huge queues like the year before when I went to the Empire StateYou need to see One world and my four year old son seemed to like it No he didn't get the background of course but worth taking him for the views!!Only thing is say is it was a waste of money buying the priority ticketIt was quiet and didn't save us any time at all !

great views if the skys are clear.. Just going up in the elevator was an experience not to be missed but I won't spoil the surprise. I really enjoyed the scenery from the top.I would suggest to everyone to have something to eat before going up, the café/restaurant is a total rip-off. its fast food sold at gourmet prices, pretty shocking.

Amazing..you can see New Jersey from top of this Building!. It's a brilliant experience!...everyone should visit, the lifts are Amazing!!. It has a sit down restaurant & cafe...also a shop to buy your Gifts!...even though it's more expensive,buy tickets inside,as if you buy on line you have to queue outside!......

Moving visit. Such a moving visit, as an ex fire fighter, this was a very emotional tribute to the lives lost and the bravery shown by the firefighters of 911 to see something positive and new and respectful not build directly on top of the the twin towers. Well worth a visit. On the day we arrived visibility was not good and they allowed us to return the following day at no cost. That day the weather was amazing, blue sky full visibility. Would highly recommend!

What a ride, what a view. Going up was a breeze, 102 floors in 50 seconds!The views from the top were gorgeous, it was a clear day and we could see miles and miles of New York. Once you see New York from the top, you have seen all of New York.The food was good too, a drink at the top of the Country!!!A must see if you are in the vicinity, kids would love it, especially the laptops that they give you, science at its best.

Excellent. Awesome experience....My family loved it...You can see whole Manhattan area from top...Amazing views.Elevator too fast too smooth u even not realize you are in elevator..Inside the elevator is LCD covers all 4 sides of elevator. Introduction about One world on 102 floor is amazing...Well design well executed.Must see attraction in New York.

Best to visit before it gets dark! . My friend and arrived to the ticket office at about 7:15pm waited 5 min in then line (no one was there beside a few people) got to see the view in the light of day and in the night! This will probably give you the best value for money as the ticket to most of the city view cost between 40-50$ for an adult.Tip: the building is in the financial area of the city right next to 9/11 memorial and museum, try and do them on the same dayAlso no need to book in advanced.

Sweeping Views Of NYC. Wow! The experience was just awesome. I bought the sunset flex and we reached about 30 minutes before sun down. We stayed until after sunset and that gave us two very different views.Humbling to be at this place. Testament to the resilience of NYC.

Exhilarating, but what's with the carnival barkers?. Check online or with your hotel concierge for discount vouchers and avoid the long lines. The journey begins by going DOWN to a basement level for a bit of orientation and history (a clever way of spacing out the crowds with some educational material thrown in, rather than just a dull switchback line). The elevator ride is a highlight; as you ascend there is an historical 360-degree overview projected onto the walls of the elevator of what you'd see outside as each decade passes, from Precolumbian Native American settlements through the Dutch and English colonial period, and on through to the present day. The ride is fast; faster than I recall from the Twin Towers. Once on top, there is a brief introduction before the curtain is raised, so to speak, and you glimpse the city from from your lofty vantage point. Those in a hurry to get to the view may resent the preliminaries, but these are, I think, thoughtfully done and are a much better way to pass the time than just meandering through a long line. There is ample space in the main viewing area (and the high ceiling adds to the sense of openness); tablet computers are available for visitors with a special app that allows you to hold up the screen to the window and use identify what exactly you are looking down at (again, a great educational tool). There is a smaller viewing area above the main area with cafe; a gift store is located on the primary viewing floor. The staff throughout was very friendly and seemed to actually enjoy being there and helping with questions, etc. One unsuccessful element was a sort of stage set (partially blocking a prime northward view) for a "guide" who gave a (loud) talk about various aspect of the view, the city, and touring the area -- I didn't notice many folks paying attention, despite the (rather forced) enthusiasm of the speakers, and it detracted from the overall experience. A less intrusive approach would be better. Wheelchair or stroller access requires assistance from staff and some behind-the-scenes detours, but it seemed that staff was plentiful and very cheerfully helped out.

Great For Tourists. I purchased the tickets online but could not print - no problem. You just show up atguest services with the confirmation number and they print your tickets for you.Our time slot was 1pm. We got there at 12:45pm on a Monday and were allowed in.There were no large crowds on this day, perhaps because it was overcast and cloudy.The elevator ride takes about 30 seconds and the 360 degree views are nice. But , folks linger around taking selfies and photos and it's hard to get a space. I didn't find the views as breathtaking as the first towers were where you were able to see Central Park.Tourists will love this. But being a New Yorker, it was as expected.

Not worth the money. If you go to the One world observatory make sure you don't get a hand held iPad thingy for $15 it's crap and you don't need it they charge you $15 for it.If you go in the evening make sure you head for the restaurant before 9pm otherwise they stop serving drinks! The tickets for 2 are 68$ plus the tax. Honestly I think Empire State is better value for money and more iconic.

Pricey but probably worth it if you actually get a view. Impressive structure and fast elevator. But I think overpriced for this type of attraction. I advise not buying your tickets in advance unless you are absolutely sure the skies will be clear that day. We were stuck with tickets for a particular day that we bought in advance. The day was 100% cloudy and the whole building was socked in. Since we could not get a refund we rode the elevator up anyways. We literally could see nothing - - it looked like grey soup. We even hung around at the top for an hour or so but nothing cleared. At that time the ticket window said they could switch our tickets to the next day but we were only in the city for one day. Expensive gift shop and food at the top. We will return for the view again some day when we have the schedule flexibility to make sure we can go up on a clear (or at least partly clear) day.
Overpriced . It is what you expect an amazing view but that's it really a elevator ride that's over in seconds a quick 5 min video then on to the viewing areas
Best view of NY . Skip the Empire State Building.... This has the great view & with much less hassle!!!! Location is well situated to including this stop on your way to many landmarks.
Beautiful. The view of the city and beyond is excellent even on a slightly cloudy day. The sunset is beyond spectacular.

Cheaper than the "Top of the Rock" and what a view!. This is all about the experience! From the elevators to the introduction presentation, to the scenic view you get...everything in a modern/classy way...everybody loved it!It is also all about timing...we reserved the 6:45 PM elevator ride (the last one before paying the night premium), had the visit with the remaining daylight, ate at the restaurant (a bit pricey but worth it IMHO)...and then! had the night view as a bonus! Breath taking!

Beautiful view on a clear day!. The elevator alone was worth the trip, you see NYC as it was when the Europeans arrived and as the elevator rises the city rises around you. The view from the top is spectacular. The building is beautiful, I am so glad a huge skyscraper was build to replace the WTC.
Terrible tourist trap!. $47 to take the elevator to the top. Ironic it's called the freedom tower. Trust New Yorkers to cash in on a terrible event. Shameful!

Amazing. We went here on out last day in New York and absolutely loved it. From the lift ride with displays showing you the history of the skyline to the views was outstanding. A cinema experience at the top where you watch a mini film then the screen opens to give your first amazing glimpse of the skyline is impressive. We walked round the whole 360 experience taking numerous photos. Would recommend this to all regardless of age.
The real View!. Fast elevator and a great view! It's a good trip up. Awesome views! Usual gift shop and tourist gotchas, but worth while.
WTC Observatory . Great quick tour with ridiculously amazing views. Only need an hour or two to see everything. We went before the Statue of Liberty tour.

Amazing. Visited the observatory while on vacation in NYC. I found a nice group deal on the website for a family ticket (group of 4) got there at 8pm and oh boy was it amazing! It was not so much a tour but I liked the intro as you passed through the security and down into the lower level. The elevator ride was very smooth and so fast that I didn't even realize that we got up to the 102nd floor in a few seconds! Finally...the views!!!! 360 degrees of NYC! Stunning!! I'd definitely recommend taking a trip to this observatory! It's worth every penny!

Pretty awesome. Just went up with my wife, 3 yo and 3 month old sons. This place was fantastic! The views were great, and the crowd was small (6pm on a Wednesday). The elevator ride up was unique, and once on the observation deck I felt comfortable that I could stay for a while. There was nobody trying to move us along. Of course there were plenty of opportunities to spend money, but the sales people weren't pushy and a simple no was fine. Compared to the CN tower in Toronto and Chicago 360, this place is the tops!

Anniversary Trip. The observatory at One World Trade had a awesome view of NYC.Was a neat experience as you go up the elevator.Don't want to spoil the surprise.You will have to come visit NYC,go up the elevator and see the surprise.Believe you will enjoy the experience of One World Trade.

Great Visit at the Top of NYC. My 8 year old grandson was visiting from South Carolina. He is in love with tall buildings and we did the Empire State Building on his last visit. This for me was a better experience although my wife like the open air of the 88th floor of the Empire State a little better. While I am an NYC resident and clearly remember 9/11, my grandson wasn't even born in 2001. Although they discussed it at his school, he did not really have a good understanding. A walk through the grounds and a stop at the memorial pools gave us a chance to increase his understanding. I will wait until he is older for a 9/11 memorial museum tour.I had purchased standard tickets a few days before for a 1:30 PM admission time. Even though we were early (about 30 minutes), it seemed that as long as we had a ticket the entrance time at the ticket was not relevant. We visited on a Sunday afternoon in the summer and were told to go right in. The only line evident was the one to purchase tickets. Spend as much time as you would like on the walk to the elevators looking at the history of building the new WTC. The elevator ride up was also fascinating as the walls depicted NYC from the 1500' s through 2014. The view from the observation floor was amazing. Floor to ceiling windows will let you see for miles. First time visitors to NYC may want to rent the I Pad viewer for $15 which when aimed out the windows labels all of the major buildings for you.I think we made some good choices. We opted for the standard admission ticket. After our visit, it didn't seem to me that the extra expense for a flex ticket or priority ticket was necessary. We also opted to take public transportation. The E train from Penn Station was quick and an easy walk from the World Trade Center stop to One World. Make sure you leave some time to walk the grounds and stop by the reflecting pools.

One of the better observation deck experiences. From entry to exit, this was one of the better observation deck experiences. We bought tickets on-line for a 1030am slot during busy August. The price is less than the Empire State Building and higher too, value! We bought the regular ticket and waited in short lines that no one noticed. The whole experience seriously starts from the bedrock up with structural, cultural and historical references from the amazing elevator ride, the various "tour guides" available or shut it all out and enjoy the views. "High priced" cafe/restaurant/bar is up top and of course a souvenir shop. Plenty of room and windows to view the city through. No time limit when you get up top. Easy access by all. Allow at least one hour if just viewing. I didn't see a need to purchase the higher end tickets if time is of issue at least when we went. Light security before entering the building and lots of ticket checks till you pass security. All closed in viewing so you only have to worry about the clouds offending your view. I can't wait to take my dad there for his birthday cocktail!

Stunning views of Lower Manhattan. I loved this observatory. I've been to the top of 30 Rock and the Empire State Building. The history of this building, and it's memorial, make it a MUST SEE. I did feel it was not as great of a view as 30 Rock, as you can't see any of central park. The perk is that you're on lower Manhattan, so you can see Brooklyn really well.

Amazing 360 view of New York. Amazing 360 view of New York. It was really worth it. Better than the empire state.I really recommend to go around 30 minutes before sunset and stay there watching also the sunset and then the night. Nobody controls the exit hour so you can stay as long as you want. It's great to watch new york in those 3 different moments.The view is fantastic.The only "but" y that because of the glass of the windows, the pictures sometimes catch some reflections.

Cant beat the view. It can be a little pricey but, what the heck.They've done a fine job with the way they deliver information. Once at the top (for any additional fee of course) you can rent an iPad with augmented reality. That means that no matter what direction you point it in it (even if it's too rainy or foggy to see) it will show what your are looking as if it was a perfectly clear day and it tells you what you are looking at, as inn the names of building, parks, etc... You can touch any of those and it will you give more information on that site, It's really pretty cool. You must make reservation and/or have tickets to got to the deck. ( recommend reservations, that way you can avoid the lines).

Top of World One. At first I wasn't sure whether I wanted to visited this tourist attraction, but after several recommendations from friends I decided to book tickets and go explore. I recommend booking tickets online first as the lines can be long but it's definitely worth a visit and has amazing views of uptown Manhattan including Empire, Top of the Rock, Central Park and Chrysler. The downtown views are pretty spectacular too - great at sunset. NB: they don't allow tripods!

Good view, not long libes. We went there directly Saturday morning, only 20 to get up (waiting , paying, elevator). Good views but bad glas reflexion so not nice to take photo'S. Eating drinking on the top is super exoensive and not worth the money.

Pricey, but a new way to see NYC. We were lucky to go here in June 2015, shortly after the Observatory opened to the public. My girlfriend is from NY and she'd already been up 30 Rockefeller and the Empire State, so she wanted to do something new. Not only does this give a great view all around, but the video in the elevator makes an entertaining ride, plus there's a surprise at the top! It is expensive however, so be sure to check prices.
Amazing Building. We didn't realise this building was just over 1 year old. Its views are gobsmacking to say the least!! A fitting tribute in many ways xx

Go after sunset for smaller lines. Make sure the day you go you can see the top of the building or you may be going for a view of the clouds. You can book online in advance. They already charge a lot and then will try and get more money out of you for pictures and things. Amazing view.

Awesome!. What an experience! Starting in one of the fastest elevators in the world, you go up watching an interesting video on elevator´s walls (yes, al around including doors). Then you get to floor 102 and there´s another video, don´t miss it! Then you get to the observatory, which is a 360° view of the city. I enjoyed every inch of panorama there. Just consider this is a glass closed observatory, different from Empire State Building which is air opened fence closed.

Excellent views. Somewhere for a clear day. Excellent views all around. Not cheap but worth it for the vista. Good audio visual presentation just before you enter the observation area. TIP: When taking photos, watch out for reflections in the glass - depends on the position of the sun. Holding your camera or phone close to glass can usually overcome this.

Ultra modern facility for tourists alike. This tower may not be the tallest in the world, but offers the best view. Leading up to the 102nd floor was quite exciting: the display and presentation. Totally recommend.

Unbelievable Experience!. I can't believe how much more awesome this place was than the Empire State Building observatory. In fact, the two aren't even in the same universe. One World Observatory was simply amazing from the digital video on elevator ride up (you have to see this for yourself) to the actual views to the restaurant and bar. I had a blast. We stayed for more than 2 hours. A must visit for your family!
Unbelievable . Very well done. Worth the price. The restaurant was very nice. You can stay there for hours and look at the view. They try to sell you iPad tour and photos.

Great views-too much commercialism. After paying $32.00 per person to ride the elevator, we were bummed out when we listened to a sales pitch for I-pads to help us identify the buildings we would see, after we left the area which had covered windows so we couldn't see the panoramic views! We finally made it to the uncovered windows and we were amazed! The restaurant at the top is over-priced and our service was bad. The manager came to our table and apologized, but I wouldn't recommend it.

Awesome . No other word can just describe this place. In few seconds you are on the 103 Rd floor. Introduction to the skyline was terrific. We got a device on rent.... to see and locate the landmarks in Newyork. Pointing to all important ones in all four directions.
Amazing Views! . Fast line, quick trip up to the observation area and amazing 360° views! A must for any NYC visit. Also 9/11 museum and memorial in the area plus lots to see in general area.

Highlight of the NYC trip. Well worth the trip. Although the area was packed we were at the top within 20 minutes of joining the back of what looked a long queue.The show in the lift going up and when you get to the top is a brilliant introduction and the you can spend as much time as you like at the top with amazing views.

Amazing!! Very well put together. The entire program was very impressive. Put together nicely. All the video screams were very interesting and entertaining. Our family favorite is the elevator video. Wow!!! I loved it!!! Would love to buy the video!!! The next video out of the elevators left me speechless and i did not expect that (no spoilers)!! I was truly amazed. I didnt like to have to wait and listen to a presentation about renting iPads. Wasted my time. The cafe was nice. The gift shop was so expensive!!!! I wanted a tshirt but not for $40!! I wish it had budget friendly prices.

Out of this World!. From the entrance it is impressive. I purchased our tickets prior to the day. When we arrived we simply went down the escalator then around the corner to the security check. After the check point, we were "welcomed" in different languages to a "tunnel" of videos showing workers of the one world observatory. Then we walked through the bedrock foundations to the elevators. The video in the elevator was awesome! It showed the skyline from when there was nothing but prairie. After exiting the elevator there are restrooms. The woman's restrooms were clean and had fresh flowers. They have an area on the top where you can rent iPads that talk about the skyline etc. However, you can save your money and simply ask any employee and they use their iPads to explain anything. The employees are very knowledgable. We exited and were herded into another room to see another video. It was about NY and then when it was completed the screen went up to reveal the windows and the views. After the "OHs and AHs" we went onto the observatory. They have a real time video on the floor of the street level view. This was neat as you could see little people riding bikes, walking, and NYC traffic. They have a "wheel of NYC" where an employee will talk about NY. There is a restaurant and before you enter the restaurant there is food you can buy and eat on your feet at some tables. Expensive. I tried the grilled cheese which was $10 and a $6 Sweet Sam's Cupcake that looked like a Hostess cupcake. I would skip the grilled cheese as it didn't have enough cheese to the bread ratio. BUT: BUY THE CUPCAKE! Best I ever had!!! For the "gift shop" there is a small area with items to buy. Not much of a good variety. There is also another restroom in that same area. You can also view your pictures beside the gift shop. When you go down the elevator it has a different video. We really enjoyed this attraction.

Best views in the City. Worth seeing, although a little pricey. Take your camera. Chew some gum on the elevator. It goes up/down very fast. Be prepared to go through security. Looks a lot like it does at the airport (except you don't have to take your shoes off). Keep track of kids. It's easy to get separated.

Great Views but Don't Pay for the iPad. The views are a 5, but the price of the tickets makes it a 4. The tricky marketing on the iPad makes this a 3. Go enjoy the views if you have the money for the tickets, but don't pay the extra $15 for the iPad. A total waste.

The most impressive experience ever.. If you love the Big Apple you'll love going up to the top of Freedom Tower, so much to see, so mcuh to feel, so much to remember... and you don't like it (is it possible ?) you'll enjoy the incomparable sense of vertigo, of power and of transparency you get when you are on top the world.

awesome elevator ride. The Elevator ride was my favorite part, it was a really cool experience to see it. The viewing area is nice, all enclosed so always looking through glass, a lot of people up there so hard to get up close without waiting a really long time, but overall it is really neat. If I only did one building I think I would lean toward Empire, but that's just me.

Breathtaking views, but do not expect to take breathtaking pictures. A must for a NYC visitor, interesting, but the old WTC Observation Deck was higher, open-air and way better. Sad memories...It was not crowded when we visited, but I would advise to buy tickets in advance, on the Web page. Look for discounts (Travelzoo, Groupon, etc.) before you commit to a day and time. Show up one hour before sunset to see the city by day and by night, you can stay up there as long as you wish. There is food and a gift shop inside the Observatory.They made it kind of a well-organized theme park experience, helped by amazing technology, very informative, but do not expect to take really great pictures of the breathtaking view, because the double-pane thick windows, full of reflections and fingerprints, will stay in your way. I was expecting, at least, that the light reflections be managed somehow by architectural design, or, at least, a little cleaner windows... The sub-ground level entrance wanted to showcase the bedrock on which the WTC was built, but it proved to be just an ill-inspired plaster rendition of wind-eroded rocks (safety concern?), in any case not a copy of the actual WTC bedrock (which you can actually see in the 9-11 Museum).
Too expensive, mixed feelings. An amazing structure for sure, but all I could think about was the terror of 9-11. Beautiful, sacred ground, sad and amazing all at the same time. Felt surreal.

Blown Away!. I was truly awed by the entire experience! I went around 6 PM on a Monday night and the crowds weren't bad (almost non-existent). The moment you walk in the doors to the moment you walk out was very well planned out. It flowed really smoothly and engaged you every moment (elevators played a scene, a movie was shown at the beginning, and information was everywhere). The views from the observation floor were outstanding. You could literally see everything in front of you. You could see the Statue of Liberty clearly, all of Jersey and beyond, Manhattan's skyline, Queens and Brooklyn, the ocean bordering everywhere, and finally down below you (9/11 memorial). I don't think I've ever had a view like this before from a tall building. Worth every penny and I'd recommend everyone (even locals) to see it at least once!

Bird's eye view. No other skyscraper can beat this building. The fastest elevator ever I had. We can see all the New York City and surrounding states. Very comfort inside the glass covered top floor, 360 degree view. You will feel that you can touch Statue of Liberty. Worth for your money and to keep the memories. In my experience, all other skyscrapers are worthless to see New York. Don't miss the opportunity.

Amazing views. We went at the end of the day (maybe 6:00ish on a Saturday?) and there were almost no lines. But you could see that they had it set up to accommodate a lot of people waiting to get up on the elevators. There was an interesting visual display in the elevator to pass the time as you zip to the top. Once at the top, there is a short digital presentation before they let you loose to check out the views. The views really are incredible. There is a pretty good café with food and beverages.My only downside (why I didn't rate a 5 star) was the fact that everything is enclosed - there are no open-air spaces to let you take unobstructed pictures. So you have to deal with greasy fingerprint stains on the glass in your pics. Also, the downtown location of the building means that you don't really see detailed views of the iconic Central Park.I'm glad that I experienced One World Observatory. But if I had to choose between the views here and at the Empire State Building...I'd go for the Empire State.
The Views!!. You can literally see for almost ever from the 102nd floor observatory! The view is breathtaking!! So is the elevator ride up!! This one is definitely a Must Do!!
So cool. Probably the most impressive things we did in New York.The panorama is splendid and special effects well done.Must do !

A fantastic experience. The One World Observatory is well worth a visit. From the rides up and down in the lift to the fantastic theatrical start of the tour it does not disappoint. We found hiring the ipad that gave information about what we could see was very helpful and added to the experience.

Amazing!. This is truly amazing. Lovely view over Manhattan. Great to be in the highest building, one remarkable in the NY skyline. One slight negative aspect is that you are inside behind glass. The elevator ride is an amazing experience, I could be in there for hours!We booked online which was covenient. Altough no queues when we were there.

A Little Expensive but Fun. We visited on a very clear, beautiful day. We enjoyed our visit, but it is a bit over priced. The elevator ride was the best part. We went early in the day and did not wait, but it did become very crowded, very quickly. We left once we no longer could get near the glass. Overall - it was OK.

Amazing views. This building is superb!!!From the mega fast elevators, to the surprise when you exit the elevator.....the experience is top notch, all 3 of n.y.c. viewing platforms are unique and offer different views,this one is special, particularly given it's position....

Top of list to do!. Don't miss out! Well worth a visit and the money. The views from the top are spectacular. The elevator which getsq you up to the top is great with careens showing how New York has developed. I definitely recommend you to here!

Out of this world. Now that most of the work is done around the World Trade Center in New York, one must go up to the observatory at the top ot the Freedom Tower. Just the fabulous24 second 102 story elevator ride make it worth it. But, the view up top is breathtaking.

If you can afford it.... Amazing view of the lower Manhattan... or the whole island on a very good day. Fastest elevators in the world with a great interactive display. The price of admission is really high but if you can afford it it totally worth it... don't get up if there's no visibility you won't be able to see anything.
Visit. Great views of New York, 102 floors up, can see 360 degrees all round. We had a very clear day so all was good. Advise get ticket before you go and save time do not have to wait in lines

Brilliant views and well laid out. The observation deck was very well organised and had a lot of thought put into it. There were various staff giving very interesting talks about the building, the city, and the views for free once at the top. There was also a cafe and a bar there which were reasonably priced and it was nice to be able to get a drink and sit up there and enjoy the views a bit more without being ripped off.We went up just before lunch time and it was very quiet, not sure if this is usual but might be worth going at a similar time!

Great view!. We booked our tickets in advance. If you have a mastercard you can get 20% off on a Monday. When we got there they said the visibility wasn't great so that is a downside of booking in advance. However by the time we got up there visibility had improved. This is a fairly short activity about an hour or so. You get a 360 degree view which is amazing. There is a cafe and shop at the observatory also.

Amazing- A must do . We have done Top of the Rock and The Empire State Building neither compare to this. It was truly breathtaking. Well organised and informative. Spent a great couple of hours here. I would highly recommend it

Really cool experience. We chose this because we hadn't done it before and it was the same price as the Empire State Building, which we had done many times before. I recommend buying your tickets online to save time waiting in line. You can pick a time and show up for that time. The elevator ride up is innovative and really cool. At the top they have another cool little experience before you go on to the observation deck. You can bypass the "instructions" which is really a ploy to keep you captive while they try to rent you an interactive iPad. They will also almost force you to take a picture which they want to sell you at the bottom. We skipped all the sales pitches and went to the view. It was awesome and much different than the view at either the Empire State or 50 Rock. You really get to see the southern end of the island and all the surrounding area. Other than the sales tactics, they've really done a good job of making this a unique and fun experience.

Awesome. Good experience, it might be expensive but to see nyc from above can be good value. If you have good weather it can improve the experience angel.santin@telmexmail.com we did. I strongly recomend such an experience

Good tour,nice views. Impressively fast elevator and nice views, well explained by the dedicated tablet you can rent. The movie could be improved, as it does not tell so much about the building and its construction.

Amazing.. Views are just stunning. Price is worthy to be considered.I recommend you to buy tickets in advance or you can also buy them for the same day.I think to remember that if you pay with MasterCard you get and extra discount.Just enjoy and see forever.

One World Observatory. I am glad we saw this but once is enough. The views were magnificent for sure and the building and grounds are beautiful. The lines move quickly and in an organized fashion. However, it is quite pricey and then there are several ways that the experience tries to entice you to spend more money. Of course there are photos for a price and a gift shop at the top. When we went it was a very hot summer day and for security reasons were not allowed to bring inner own water - well at the snack bar - it cost 5.00 for a regular size bottle of water. You can see forever, but unless you spend the extra 15.00 to rent an iPad that tells you what you are seeing, you don't really know. So yes, a nice experience but I think it is over priced -

Amazing. From the elevator ride to the observatory it is just amazing and very awe-inspiring. The views are spectacular and people are left to take their time so you can stay as long as you like. It is busy and I would recommend getting tickets in advance - we did this and so glad we did after seeing the queues for on the day tickets. A very fitting tribute to the 9/11 victims and the people of New York.

Drama but needs class. My husband and I went to the top of ONE WORLD (proper name) as that is where we celebrated out wedding 30 years ago. Of course originally it was at the other towers. Needless to say we had a strong emotional attachment to the original World Trade Center. The views are magnificent of course. An interesting elevator ride was appreciated.But, it become just another tourist site when you get there. We so missed the beautiful restaurant that was once a part of the experience that has been replaced by something you can see at any airport. For something so special it stooped to selling overpriced t-shirts and the usual tourist trappings. It was dramatic of course but so very sad.
Amazing & unforgettable !!. This is one thing that we had to do. The elevator ride sets the tone and as you arrive on the observation deck, you are totally amazed. It is incredible and a must see !!

NYC . We visited the Observatory this past trip. We opted for the flex day pass ($60), so we didn't have to show up at a certain time. We headed over around 4:30 and to or surprise, the flex pass also meant VIP lines. So we skipped the wait. I would recommend this to anyone as you do not want to spend your limited time in lines.

Must experience while visiting New York City. This is one of the most incredible sites in the city. It is well worth any wait. The staff are knowledgable and friendly. So much of the history of the building and the city is explained while at the top. Plan to spend several hours just viewing the sites and make sure you purchase the IPad service that is offered.

Visit Top of the Rock instead!. We visited the One World Observatory deck at World trade center and that was waste of money - you are inside with lots of reflections from the windows so quite difficult to see and get good pictures. Also very crowded. We purchased VIP tickets in advance which we recommend if you do want to visit - to bypass all queues - from entry in building until up on the observation deck was a matter of minutes (probably hour or so without VIP pass).We recommend you do the Top of the Rock view instead (Rockefeller Centre) - clear view and open (no windows on the top floor). And if you want the view of downtown from the sea take the free Staten Island Ferry.

Wow, it is something!!. We had first class service from the team at One World. My husband is in a wheelchair and we were treated like first class. That's for starters. The elevator ride was an experience like none other, it wow-Ed me going up and down, awesome!!The view is breathtaking and plenty of room on the observatory deck to roam without bumping into everybody. The gift shop is pricy on some items, others are what you'd expect on a site like that. I think it's a must see. My family had a great time.

Breathtaking views. I went for a trip to New York to visit my friend who lives out there and this was on my bucket list! Seeing the memorial ground zero was historically beautiful. I heard from many people that the views of New York are much better from One World compared to the Rokerfella - I went up the 100 floors and the views were absolutely breathtaking you could see a full 360 degree of New York and I was literally mesmerised. Definitely recommend going in for both views and remembrance

A fitting memorial to those who died.. A very sad place to visit but it's a fitting memorial to those who died on that terrible day. It's great to see the fire fighters who attempted to rescue people being especially honoured.
Simply breathtaking...a must do🇺🇸. It's one amazing place to visit. My husband and I are New Yorkers and visited it today. I've been there before but it was his first time. He was in awe. We ❤️ NYC

Cloudy Day - But Still Worth It. This was an uplifting visit. I loved the 'testimonials' of those who helped build this beautiful building. And the elevator ride up was very well done with the quick history of Manhattan!

The number 1 in my rating of New York's observatory towers. Buy tickets online before to pass by the long queue at the counter! Keep your camera ready when you enter the elevator to take some pictures of the very creative movies they display on the screens at the elevator's walls. And keep your camera ready also after you have left the elevator and have to wait in a line in front of a wall which serves as a screen for a little intro show and then surprisingly opens and gives you free sight to the city below. Even on the two main decks you can take pictures from inside only through the window glass. The ambient is modern and quite noble. There is enough space upstairs so I never had the feeling that it was crowded - a relaxed and comfortable atmosphere. Take the offer to loan a notepad (15 US $ extra charge): It displays the buildings and landmarks you are aiming at and if you touch on a detail it zooms in and displays useful Information about it. There are two giant rings of screens; do not miss the show that one of the very friendly staff members presents there from time to time.

On top of the world! . Once in a lifetime opportunity to see New York City from the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. What an experience. I would definitely do it closer to early evening so you can get both day time and night time views. Also get the IPAD, so you can get the history of all the landmarks.

They did it right!. Even though the reason this exists couldn't be worse, this new tower is definitely worth the trip down and the $37/Adult price. From the moment the elevator begins it's trip up, you know this is going to be an experience. Get your video ready. Than upon exit, there's a little "Disney kind of treat" before you start your Observatory fun. There's plenty of souvenirs, plenty of window space, and a nice place to have something to eat. Even they ride back down is enjoyable. It's similar to the Sears Tower in Chicago as you're inside looking out windows. But there is plenty of room and like my title suggests, all those involved did a really good job of creating a really good experience. One thing I didn't expect, the architects of the building have it looking like different shapes depending on your vantage point.
Wonderful view!. The entrance is very organized, and then when you arrive to the floor 102 for the introductory speech you realize how high you are! Spectacular view from each angle!

Spectacular. Came here on our visit to NYC. The lines moved quickly, and the elevator ride was amazing. When you go in, there are screens all around the elevator and as you go up you can see New York City throughout the years. When you enter there is a brief presentation, you also have the option of renting an iPad for $15 which pretty much describes any building in New York City and gives you a brief history of it. My son wanted it so we rented it. There is a café in the souvenir shop which are a little pricey. The view from the observatory deck is unbelievably breathtaking. If you are in NYC this is a must!

Breathtaking !!!. Oh you just have to visit this amazing building! It's one hell of a ride in the lift to even get to the top but that view!!! Wow!!!!I am very scared of heights and the lift absolutely floored me in a virtual panic attack but I must say it was worth it. Truly beautiful and what an amazing view. Don't go to New York and miss this!! Will definitely do this again next time

Great views; too many huckster moments. Great views. Best elevator ride ever. But the price is high, especially when you are trapped in front of people trying to sell you headphone tours and other things. When very busy up there, you spend a lot of time walking past windows covered with screens so you can't see out. Then finally you arrive at the observation level. Our day was so sunny the outside pictures are great but it shadowed faces inside. Not a complaint; just a fact. Of course there are fools who stand in the window sills for selfies OR stand in front of windows while reading their emails...

Amazing views and incredible elevator!!. Zooming to the top of this building in about a minute is incredible. The elevator does not have any lurching or stomach churning like I imagined it would. The views from the top are good. The men giving the spiels about other historic buildings, etc was enjoyable. I wish there were more places to sit. It was pretty crowded up there when I visited even though it was 7:30 p.m. I have been on top of a skyscraper under construction and it was a scary feeling and I didn't want to walk too close to the edge. This was nothing like that, I felt safe and I enjoyed the experience.
Our visit to One World Observeratory. Took my 6 year old great grandson to visit NYC. This building is amazing, breath-taking and an experience of a life time

Amazing views in a beautiful building. Amazing to see the progress from 9/11 to the new beautiful building of 1 wtc. Amazing views and VERY easy to access. No need to buy express tickets like the Empire State. Bought our tickets on line in advance and got their a bit early and went right in - no waiting, very friendly staff and we went at prime sunset time. Lots of open space and wonderful views. In contrast to other reviews on here I didn't find it overly crowded and we found spots to sit. Nice clean washrooms and lots of helpful staff. Elevator ride was very cool and fast. Reminded us a bit of the Willis Tower in Chicago. I would highly recommend this activity if you like great city views. We have done Top of the Rock and the Empire State building more than once and 1 WTC gives a completely different city view and experience.

Amazing. This is a must see.. Just the path to the elevators is well done and lays the groundwork for what is to come. I don't want to spoil any surprises so won't give details. Let's just say the ride up is like nothing I have ever experienced! And is worth the trip. Then the introduction - 2 min film, well you have to see for yourself. The 360 degree observation deck is breathtaking, the Freedom Tower is the tallest in the Western Hemisphere.

Just wow!. Aside from the amazing view from the observation area, the elevator ride up was incredible. The presentation once off the elevator was also a pleasant surprise although I think they could have refrained from the group sales pitch of trying to get everyone to rent an IPad for viewing the city afterwards.

Great views. We bought tickets right before going inside the 911 museum. They open at 830am and you can pick the specific time when you want to go up to the observatory. There was no wait when we were there yesterday - no wait to buy the tickets (830am) and no wait at noon for the visit. Take time to hear the workers describe what it was like to build One World. The elevators are fast - easy trip to the top. When you get to the top its a little odd - you actually have to go down a level to walk all the way around the observation area. They line you up to take a group photo before you go down a level. (Expensive). We also didn't rent an iPad but many people did - helps you identify what you're seeing as you look out the windows. The views are spectacular - esp of Ellis Island and Liberty Island (Statue of Liberty). Great views of midtown. HOWEVER last summer we went to "Top of the Rock" and I have to say if I was picking between the 2 buildings, I'd do the Rock - primarily because you see all of Manhattan including Central Park. One World had great views except the tall midtown buildings prevent you from seeing anything past that area (no Central Park). Lastly, there was a gentleman providing some history about NewYork - worth listening to if you're interested in learning geographic, demographic details)

It's all about the view. Beautiful day we could see for miles. After getting your entry ticket you go down to go up, when in the elevator don't stand like you normally would facing the doors, turn around they project the NYC skyline through the years as you ride up, a really nice touch. You can rent for 15.00 an IPAD which if you hold to the window it will ID the notable buildings you are gazing down at. The view is, of course incredible. There is also a place to eat & drink if you so chose. Also a place to buy your tchotchkes to take home & there is quite an array. On the elevator ride down there is a sensation of flying over NYC in a helicopter so look to the back.Nicely done, I paid 34.00 for my ticket.

What a view..... We went on a quiet weekday after lunch in Soho - will talk about this later today.Amazing from the minute you walk in the building until you exit. You can see everything from Central Park to the Narrows. From NJ to JFK. Breathtaking....After that go for a walk to and between the 2 pools on the ground (north and south) and stop to think what happened there.
A must do!. If you visit New York and don't do this you are completely mad. I really mean it. A unique view of this awesome city.

Great views, different perspective. OWO had great views and was a great experience overall. The views from here are completely different than what you'll see at Top of the Rock or Empire State. However, unlike either of the other two, at OWO you are completely boxes in by glass. There is no getting around it, so don't expect to get too many great pictures if you're interested in that. Other than that it's a great experience and something that's definitely worth doing while in NYC.

Great views, but.... How can you ever go wrong with the views afforded from the Observatory at the top of One World Trade Center?! The elevator ride is extremely fast and comfortable. After you get to the top they give a brief presentation and offer to rent an iPad to you that will tell you what the points are that you are looking at. It is $15. We rented it but were disappointed with it because quite a few of the things that we were looking at that we wanted to know what they were, weren't included in the landmarks. It's also sketchy when you calibrate it...for instance we were pointing it at the Empire State Building but that building was not in the frame of the iPad. So we re-calibrated it and it was still off. Also, the information it did give on places wasn't as detailed as I was looking for. Personally I just didn't think it was worth more than about $5. The gift shop is very nice and full of neat things, but seemed pretty pricey to me! All that said, I would go back again!

One of a kind experience with Breathtaking views . This was the first time I visited the One World Observatory and all the hype was true. My trip was made with friends who are in NY for the first time and I really wanted for them to take only the best memories of NY and taking them to the observatory was truly an amazing experience. From the elevator experience to the guide who gave information regarding one World Trade Center made this one of the most incredible experiences I have ever had in my amazing city. I really liked he fact that the it's also educational and kids will be in awe of this amazing observatory. One World Observatory is a must do if you love experiencing new things.

Sorry but it was a let down. I was excited to add this to my tourist weekend in Baltimore- especially since I found a Groupon I figured "what the heck?!" Sure it was nice to overlook the waterfront but it was a pretty quick trip to look around from every direction. There was a cool e hi it on 911 and local art on display. I suppose it's something to do but was not an overwhelming memory for my mental scrapbook.

Summer holidays in NYC. Impressive and amazing building inside has a astonishing view.Case you like read the history from what you are looking at and want to stay at least one hour I advice you to rent the iPad. We had a great experience.
What a view!!!. Great experience. Love the 360 degree views with interactive attractions to help educate and appreciate NYC. Nice café to have a bite to eat as well.

Very well done Memorial and Museum .. We were 4 women who had been to Ground Zero during the restoration process many years ago. The completed site is beautiful and touching in so many ways. The museum is so thorough in bringing you back to that fateful day with great tributes to those lost and those who helped. Be sure to visit.

Fast trip to the top. I went to the top of the original buildings in the late nineties and this was an emotional experience for me which I had not expectedThe lifts are really good, the show at the top of the lifts is also brilliant and the viewing decks are big and all round the building, there are also two impressive video circles manned by NY guides which are worth stopping to listen to of you aren't a localThe only slight disappointment that all your photos are through glass there is no outside option like the Rockefeller

Amazing Experience. While planning my families trip to Europe the best flights were through New York. So on the return flight I added a overnight in New York to go see the 911 Memorial and the One World Observatory. Booking my tickets online was easy. You are able to pick your time which makes planning easy. We arrived at the time on the ticket and were quickly whisked into a elevator that began a amazing visual experience. My family has been up the Empire State Building which does provide great views but the One World Observatory provides the views with a whole new and exciting experience. This is a must see for all!
Great view but.... Great views but they've tried to commercialize it too much. They push paying for their iPad with their special app on it. It should be a free app on your phone.

Breath-taking views and a very modern experience from the ground up. We saved our trip to the One World Observatory until our last day, and we were glad we did. It is a different experience to the Empire State building. We pre-booked tickets online, but arrived early and the queues were not to too long.The approach through the underground, looking up through the Occulus, was fantastic. The lifts and views - were excellent. I don't want to spoil any surprises along the way - but if you want to get a good ariel view of NY and beyond, you will not be disappointed.There is also a small cafe and a bar at the observation deck.If I did it again, I would book a time so that we could go up and look around during the day, and then watch night fall.A fantastic experience. I hope you enjoy it.

Great views but no open air outdoor access!. We visited the One World Observatory on a recent trip to New York. We purchased and printed our tickets online beforehand, which avoids the need to queue for tickets when you arrive. It was costly at $37 each.The elevator up is very quick, 102 floors in less than 60 seconds! Whilst in the elevator, you get a 360 virtual look at how Manhattan has developed over time. Once at the top there is a short video before you enter the main observation area. There are iPads available to hire to help identify landmarks, which seemed like an expensive gimmick to be honest.The 360 view was really amazing, you could see for miles! We were lucky that it was a clear and sunny day. However, taking photos wasn't easy given everything is behind glass so reflections everywhere. The glass could also do with a clean, so many finger prints....The lack of outside access to an open air section was the biggest disappointment. I guess I expected the same as at the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock. It would have been much nicer to be able to take photos without reflections. Worth a trip up for the stunning views though.
Views with a WOW. Been up high at other NYC towers and this is the best. Beautiful views of the sea and rivers bordering Manhattan. Very modern and stylish.

Educational tour. I learnt in the observatory that The New York Times made the times square and they made Times Square the actual name TIMES SQUARE. I learnt a lot that i can't even remember what I learnt! It is a nice view from the like 101st floor especially The Empire State Building, actually you had a great view of everything!Hope you enjoyed.
Great views!. Great views of the city, 360 degrees! A little pricy, but it's NYC. I would recommend doing it once.

Great view on the city and Liberty Island. We went up in the morning and the view is quite spectacular. The whole experience is very good and the different parts are well done.They offer a concept with IPads which show you additional information on the view depending where you stand and in which direction you look. This concept is quite unique and a well thought application. Therefore there are no information panels where people queue in front. The observation deck does have a lot space. It is well worth a trip up as it offers a different view than the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock.

Incredible views of New York . Good value, stunning views, the ride to the top was done in seconds with a video wall revealing what Manhattan looked like at certain times of the century. Worth a visit.

Great view. The best elevator ride in New York, then a fantastic view, we visited in the morning so it wasn't very busy, the elevator ride takes you on a historic journey of New York until you reach the top very impressive, highly recommended.

Great views (unless you want to see Central Park. Smooth transition to the observation levels. The elevator ride up is an experience in itself. Trip down is different and good too. Shame about the selling attempt for the iPad device (to give info on what you look out onto). Not many takers at $15. It should be includes in the ticket price. Fantastic 360 views all around albeit through glass. Central Park not visible at all so you'll need to complement this visit with one to Rockerfeller and/or Empire State for that. Some views looking down to street level and into the pools of the twin towers spoiled a bit by by reflections.Over a couple of visits to NYC, I've visited all of the 3 observation sites but if choosing just one of them I would recommend you consider this one though.

A must see. We got lucky and arrived here on a very fine day so we had an outstanding view.The observation deck gives a fantastic 360 degree view and, in my opinion, is the best in New York.There are two restaurants and we ate in the less formal one which was OKWe also hired a $17 iPad based device that gave you some idea of what you were looking at.As I say this is a fantastic view point and worth the $34 fee.

Great view but under a fish tank. Historically, I know this is the most meaningful place for New York City. I know everyone will think this is the best view ever too, situated in downtown. I have been to the Empire State Building and almost twice to the Rockefeller Centre. Both of these attractions were amazing. Unblocked views of the entire Manhattan skyline with an open space. You can experience the natural breeze, soak in the skyline with fresh air. One world observatory is unfortunately glassed up. It is likely to be for security reason, but think of the an avid photographer's nightmare at night ->you will see reflections of myself and everyone else against the glass. I was up from 6.30pm onwards and the sunset created such harsh lighting with reflections that you can hardly take anything without seeing yourself. Truly a bad experience for photographer. The only plus point is that you can take the Statue of Liberty at a much closer range than the other two vantage points.

Stunning, Breath taking views but don't look for a seat. Absolutely stunning, breathtaking views that only one of us was fully able to enjoy as they do not allow for those with medical conditions. They do not offer wheelchairs for use or rent and there are NO SEATS any where along the tour. When the tour ends there are seats on another level. Shame on the designers of this magnificent structure.

This is a breathtaking experince. Amazing how this is organized. It starts with a nice little history show in the elevator and than followed by a movie with a lot of impressions from NYC. The view is unique and it is worth to take a iPad to learn more about the city
Fantastic and reasonably priced. This building will blow your mind. firstly the lift is beyond this world, once you arrive at the top the views are breath taking, we stayed until dark, wow
You must go!!!. The better and most wonderful view of nye!! Find a clear day and have your tickets !!! Astonishing views!!! The elevator : a must!!!!!

Fantastic place to enjoy lunch. Had lunch at One Dine after a 9/11 museum tour. Lunch was excellent and the view is fantastic. Although you have to pay to get up top, lunch was reasonably priced and tasty. Worth it!

A must do while in New York. The visit of the Observatory was worth every penny spent. We arrive to visit at 10ham and this is probably the best time to avoid crowds and line up. We purchase our tickets ahead. Recommend to do so.
Breath Taking. Worth Every Penny!!! It was very nice and the views were spectacular!!! Everyome there was so helpful and full of facts!!!

New York City's View on the World is Back and Better Than Ever!!!. I was so happy to see One World Trade finally open. The experience was well worth the wait. The thrills begin from the moment you step into the elevator. Don't close your eyes you don't want to miss one moment of this moving tribute. Once you arrive at the top of the world the magic continues from the moment the doors open. The views from the top are amazing... especially at sunset. There is even a glass "bottom"platform that allows you to see down to the ground via television screens. There is a restaurant lounge which looks out over the observation deck. We didn't have the pleasure of dining there during this trip, (I think reservations may have been required) however, we plan to next time we visit. Awesome experience! Worth a trip to the Big Apple! Be sure to check the reflecting pools and the 911 Memorial while you're here too. Military and First Responders receive a discounted admission.

The best view in NY. Simply stuning.. This was without question the best thing we did during our 3 day visit to NY. The views are breathtaking, and the iPod that they give you to view the skyline and put names to the buildings is a great idea. Everyone was lovely and helpful.

Phenomenal views of the whole island. We had a clear day which set the stage for amazing views. The height exceeds the Empire State Building so the views are more vast. The viewing area is inside versus outside. The ride to the top is quick. Upon departure of the elevator, a brief introductiory presentation is given before you are released to view at your own pace. There are no time restraints and therebare many employees wandering around to answer questions or help you locate a familiar building. We stopped at the lounge to enjoy an adult beverage and were greeted with friendly staff. Drinks were very expensive and 18% gratuity was automatically added. Our cost was $48 for one mohito and one tequila cocktail. After paying $85 each to get to the top, it seemed a little high. We really enjoyed but it doesn't seem very affordable for a family.

Beautiful views of the city!. The entrance to One World Observatory was awesome and not to be missed. Following and introduction, the view was presented, and it left you speechless. The presenters, who tell you the facts about the building, are friendly and knowledgeable. The patrons (mostly tourists, like myself) are fairly ridiculous. They have a tendency to park in one spot on the viewing level and then call a family meeting. I have no qualms with family meetings, except when it denies the other patrons the ability to enjoy that particular view. There should be some kind of "see the view, take some pictures and move along" line. A little more organization, if you will. I like the pictures and the gift shop :)
Loved It. An experience you need to do. Absolutely amazing. Will definitely be returning. Awesome views of NY.

Everything you hope for. Great experience. Booked on line. Arrived at 9. No queues. The whole experience was excellent... Including the elevators. Views couldn't be betterCoffee was reasonable, croissants were fresh. We spent most of the morning at the top. It was busy be the time we left. It's the second time I have visited New York, but the first with children. This worked really well for them. Book on line. Arrive early. Enjoy!
Good view. Apart from being highest view not much else to do get to stand on glass base imitates looking to the ground which is not accurate
Absolutely must go in NYC. This place offers a privileged view of NYC. Taking pictures thru the thick glass is not the best, but the view is fantastic. The elevator ride is also amazing.

Magnificently architecture blazing building dominating the New York skyline. The new World Trade Center sometimes referred to as the Freedom Tower is a beautifully architecture building and certainly stands out on the Manhattan skyline.The views from the observatory a spectacular and from a different perspective and angle to that of the Empire State Building.The new World Trade Center looks rather spectacular at night time and can certainly be the focus of some great photos.

Money hungry! . We came here on our first time to New York. To pay respect to the people who lost their lives here. The tour was nice, but at every turn, they wanted to make more money off of us. It was sad to see that. After walking around a while, I was thirsty, and they charged $5 for.a bottle of water! Sad, sad, sad!

Terrific experience. We went here spur of the moment and lucked out with no wait. My husband and I hadn't been here since it opened and we weren't sure what to expect. The whole experience was wonderful. The elevator ride up is and experience in itself. You get a 360 virtual look at Manhattan over time. When you step off the elevator there is a short video on a giant wall. Then suddenly the wall lifts and you get a breathtaking sneak peak of the NYC skyline. Then you are off to the observation deck. Visibility was great. We got some great pics all around. Our younger kids had 100 questions about the twin towers and 9/11. I admit I got choked up a little being in that building and that environment. What a great way to honor those lives lost and look toward the future.

Worth a visit!. Visited One World's observatory recently. I do not want to let the surprise out, but the introduction to the observatory was surprising and beautiful! Great experience. You have the opportunity to see New York and New Jersey from high above the sky. The elevator experience was very interactive. Great for families!
360 degree views of New York. high speed elevators take you up 102 floors in less than 60 seconds. Prepare for spectacular views of New York.

Amazing View of the City. First time visitor - purchased our tickets online through Viator and skipped the ticket lines. Ride to the top was great - on the top during your initial briefing they rent ipads with which you can view different directions. The cost is $15. We thought it would be "real-time" views but turns out everything on the ipad is pre-recorded. So it is a little bit of a waste of your money to use it. Better just to view through the glass and take your photos. Overall, it was a good visit, but once is enough. Kind of like, been there, done that sort of thing.

Spectacular Views, Spectacular building, distractions from views all over the observatory floor. The views in this iconic building are spectacular. The person in the circular-structure yelling facts about NYC in front of the prime views of the city... please move. There is sensory overload here, a gift shop, and several snack stations for a half an hour tour. The building is so beautiful and I think the observatory floor could have been made more minimal and focused on the architecture and views rather than information/snacks/gifts about NYC.

A Must Visit. have been visiting New York for a number of years, since 9/11 and watching the construction of this building. Now open it just had to be on the visit list. It did not disappoint. The views are amazing.

Superb experience. . Getting off at the 102nd floor you are met with very friendly staff who try to sell you the use of an iPad to not just sense and identify all the major buildings and bridges but at the press of a button tell you a little history and detail. Amazing and well worth the fifteen extra dollars!!
fun trip to the top. Great toi see and hear all about NYC. well worth the time and cost (minor). yOU CAN SEE FOREVER. line ups were minor here.

Get ready for the lines. 37 dollars per person. I had a New York City Pass so it was free. Long lines so go as early as possible. A nice remembrance of that horrible day that now sets in our hearts. If you can make the effort to go.

Top of the World. If you go to NY you must do this but chose a clear day so you can see all the way to New Jersey and Connecticut. The views are fantastic and its a greta way to get a hang of the geography of NYC
The new WTC at NYC. It is an amazing place where you can see the whole city. I actually liked more the memorial pools on the ground with the names of the people who died there.

Worth the Trip. This is an incredible view of the City and the lines are long, make sure you book weeks ahead of time and not for the faint of heart. Worth it if you can put aside your fear of heights, even if only for a moment!

Not for those scared of heights. Great views of the city and out to the sea and all 5 boroughs that make up NY. We went up in the evening before dusk and then stayed up there until it was dark so we had the best of both views.

Tallest Building in the Western Hemisphere!. This was too cool, and at the same time sad. Going up the building, the elevator is screens all the way around, which is really neat. It shows you the "years" increasing and shows you how the city of New York "grew" in height each year. On the screen in front of me, I saw as we got close to the top, the Twin Towers appear on the screen, and then they just dissolved, disappearing. A very quiet reminder of what happened.At the top it was just wild how far you could see.Wilder, still, was how you can actually feel the building moving. (all skyscrapers have several feet they sway) I've never been that high up in a building that needed to have that type of flex, so it was weird to feel it. It almost felt once in a while like I'd drunk one beer, and just felt a little bit of disorientation. There is a restaurant at the top of the building, so we sat and ate and looked around at New York from 1,700 feet in the air. It was really nice. The food was good. Expensive, yes, but how else could it be with a view like that?

Sunday visit. The new building observatory is amazing. The elevator ride up is fun, with a video showing how the area changed since 1800s. The lines were not long, and it was pretty fun to see the city from above. Job well done.

Exceptional views. Having visited both the Top of the Rock and Empire State building the OWO blows them all away. Booked our tickets online so managed to get to the top far quicker than the TOTR or ESB. Once on the observation deck the views are absolutely outstanding, only hampered due to the clouds but was still amazing.Better to book for quieter times to get a good look out the 360 view :)

Great attraction, lots of great info up there.. Awesome 360 degree views of Manhattan, Brooklyn, and New Jersey ... be sure to get the interactive iPad that tells you what each landmark is. Plus there's a number of information "rings" with info from hosts that help to complete the picture.For now, it's the only way you can stand atop the highest skyscraper in the western hemisphere. Why not, right?

amazing. Ever since the plans were unveiled I had a desire to visit here, its simply amazing , not just the views but the effort that has gone into every aspect of the visitor experience. My tip would be book in advance to avoid the queue's although even then you are in for a little bit of a wait to get to the observation deck. The lifts are quirky to say the least and the unveiling when you arrive is a nice touch. The star as you will expect is the 360 view across NY, anyone who has visited NYC before has already done the Empire & Rockefeller but this gives you a different perspective seeing all the way up town. a must for any visitor

A pretty ‘high’ building with wasted views… and astronomical, tourist-trap prices !!. Well… after waiting many, many months, we finally took the plunge and went up to see the new One World Trade Center. Everyone knows where this is and how to get there, so I won’t get into that. I took up an offer on Living Social for discounted admission ($24/person ~ which is still a lot) and trooped over to the famous landmark, armed with a camera and plans to have a drink at one of the top-level (physically speaking) restaurants in that towering edifice and get some stunning photographs. Thing is, you can’t get into the tower without paying the steep ticket price which starts at $32.00 just to get in the door, even if you were going there to have dinner at one of the high and highly overpriced restaurants/eateries there ~ which is ridiculous and just a way to fleece the public. It’s a shame that the developers and operators of this site where so many innocent people were murdered, should use its infamy to capitalize on and fill their pockets... this is a crass exhibition of unbridled avarice. This place does bring back the views lost when the Twin Towers fell, but other than that, its also a pilgrimage site: my last visit to these rarified environs was in July 2011, just a few weeks before tragedy struck 15 years ago, and seeing that view of downtown New York City and its bridges brought back those memories.While its true that the gimmicky, really fast ride to the “top” in an elevator with LCD screen walls that show changing vistas of the outside as it grew from a jungle into present day New York City are a great idea, and well executed, there isn’t anything else there other than just another tourist trap to fleece the unwary traveler at every turn, from arrival (the photo-stop) till one leaves (the souvenir shop), and the many recordings telling everyone that “you are at the top of the tallest structure in the western hemisphere is highly misleading: first of all, you are not at the top, as the top of the needle or whatever you may call it, which is above the entrance level from the elevators, is not open to the public.To quote from “A glimpse of the world” in the New York Times, 2013 ~ “Heights like these are usually measured with a rubber ruler. But according to the Port Authority, the 102nd or top floor of the observatory is 1,268 feet above the street, making it the third-highest observation deck in the Western Hemisphere. It would rank below the CN Tower in Toronto, at 1,465 feet; the Skydeck at Willis Tower in Chicago, at 1,353 feet; and above the Empire State Building, at 1,224 feet.”And adding a pointy steel-thingy that can’t be inhabited to the rooftop and calling it needle, spire or tower doesn’t increase the height of the building itself, no matter what any Council says... that’s just measuring with a carnival barker’s (aka Donald Trump’s) ruler and shabby posturing.It took them long enough to work through their petty squabbles and get this built, and it shouldn’t be used for their greed. Yes, the views are unparalleled in this area, BUT the internal reflections in the glass, of the lobby lighting and visitors, mars the photographic opportunity completely. What a monumentally foolish choice for glazing ~ what a wasted opportunity….

Amazing views. The views from the observation deck is amazing. The only thing that was a downer was that our group felt like they were always trying to make more money from us. a picture of everyone after you have entered where on the way out they try to sell to you. A IPad to use while looking out at the scenary so you can identify each building you are looking at, an additional cost. On the ride up in the elevator an video surrounds you explaining the progress of the tower over time. Great visual during the ride up and down. Overall a great experience for the views.
The BEST views of the city. Very educational experience, and really breathtaking views of the city. Buy your tickets ahead of time to get through the line, and you'll find it cheaper online.

OWTC - a 21st century tour. Entering the OWO my family and I were looking forward to a typical observatory visit. We left with a far better experience! The view was just the icing on the cake. From the interactive boards to the testimonials of workers, our family was WOW-ed by the sights and sounds of the Center. Excellent experience for all ages!
Very busy and not sure. This was seething and it gave us a high level view of the city but I didn't really enjoy it! Expensive too - go to the 'top of the Rock' instead! Streets ahead!

views were great and respectful. I had visited the world trade center many years ago and was hesitant to return to one world trade, but very happy I did!. From the moment you begin to walk to the elevators it is very well done, with videos of workers of the building speaking and the video before you enter the observatory. It is definitely worth the trip!

Windows are reflecting too much to allow any picture. The view over the city and the bay is simply spectacular, howver, the windows are reflecting so much the inside that it is all but impossible to make pictures. Also, this has been designed as a Disney attraction,mwhich i did not enjoy.

BACK ON TOP. Together with friends and parents we were used to go on WTC on the towers before 9/11. After several years, I had the opportunity to get back on the top, this time on the new building. The vision is incredible and you a get a 360-complete picture of the city.

Great view, but no outdoor access.. The building itself, and the view is really fantastic. The elevator speed was impressive, as was the elevator and intro entertainment too. There were many people up there, but still easy to find places to look outside. Everything was very streamlined and efficient.The lack of outside access was the main disappointment. Having been to both the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock, I love to go outside to really feel the wind, hear the sounds of the city and be able to take photos without reflections. Also, the price was a bit on the expensive side, on the other hand, there was hardly any line any place.
