Best viewed from the outside. We'd decided to visit One World Trade toward the end of a nine-day vacation in New York City, which, in hindsight was a mistake. If I can proffer other travellers one solitary tip, it's to arrange it as close to your arrival in Manhattan as possible. I say this simply because, if the weather isn't optimal, and you need to change your booking because of that, having the maximum number of possible days and timeslots available will likely make the difference between an enjoyable trip and a less-than-enjoyable visit.Our plan was to visit the One World Trade observatory the day before our last day in Manhattan, and that's what we'd booked for. However, between booking and visiting, the weather forecast changed and what had been expected to be brilliant sunshine when we'd booked had changed to rain when the day arrived and we knew when we walked toward the tower that we were going to have to rearrange given that we could only see the lower half of the building as we approached from our hotel in nearby Tribeca. Rearranging was effortless, even if the person who served us was a little disinterested, and we moved our booking to the following day at 0900. As a sidenote, we'd booked for a Friday and ended up visiting on a Saturday, which I think was more expensive, but we still paid Friday prices.The Saturday began with brilliant New York sunshine, and we schelepped down to the line optimistically, only to be told that there was zero visibility from the observatory and that we could rearrange if we wanted. Hence my sagely advice above: by this point we had no more days that we could rearrange this for, and so we just had to suck it up.While it might be the case that our experience was somewhat less impactful because of the lack of visibility, the four of us left feeling a little disappointed by the whole thing. Granted, the elevator to and from the observatory was incredible, but I thought the video pre-show they play once you've walked out of the elevator was a bit weak, and I absolutely loathed the hard sell for the iPad experience that you were then needlessly subjected to. However, I think this may be the only way to access the Jay McInerney-narrated tour, and I'm a massive McInerney fan - but even with that as a draw, I was never going to shell out for it, plus the chatter coming from people's iPads as they walk around the observatory zooming in on landmarks is incredibly irritating.Even with zero visibility, we could make out a dim silhouette of the Empire State Building by the time we left, and we had perfect views of the Financial District, the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges, the Hudson River Park and Tribeca. This was our locale for our trip, so it was, in many ways, nice to see our neighbourhood from an entirely different perspective. We could identify our hotel and many of the buildings around it, and I've no doubt that the cathedral-esque grace of the Woolworth would be breathtaking in a completely new way if the roof hadn't been covered with construction sheeting and scaffold.While it's nice to say we've been up that high, looking back now I'm reminded of the advice that we were given before we booked to visit the observation deck of the Rockefeller Center compared with the Empire State Building back in 2012 - Manhattan is best viewed, not from the highest possible vantage point, but from slightly lower down. That's why, for this reviewer, One World Trade is something best viewed from the outside.

A MUST FOR YOUR NYC TRIP. Spent a great day at 911 memorial. Still after all these years it pains me to see this memorial but with that being said it is a must see for young and old so we will never forget what happened here and to never forget the ones lost on that tragic day. One World Observatory was so awesome. It was a sight to see and how proud to be an American in such a magnificent building. Endless views but the best part was the elevator ride up and down... make sure you have your phone ready to video the trip up and down.

Get up there. We were expecting to like this but we ended up really liking it. Booked ahead, rented the iPad device, and had a light lunch (complete with beer tasting flights) for our group of 6. The elevator ride up is very cool with depiction of what the city buildings looked like throughout NYC history. Yes, its touristy but what a special spot!

Multimedia-enhanced observatory. Happily, OWO now brings to the table of solid NYC observatories a downtown perspective on Manhattan that's coupled with state of the art multimedia usage. Our group was fascinated by the elevator video transformation of NYC (and the swift, smooth ride!). Received optimal explanations of various sights using the One World Explorer that we rented for an additional fee. Definitely worth it!

Pretty cool!. The 48 second ride to the 102 floor was kind of unbelievable. It was a partly cloudy day but there was just enough visibility to still see everything. If it was even little cloudier the $37 ($34 if purchased on line) price tag would not have been worth it. After getting to the observation deck I almost wished I had shelled out the $15 for the iPad to help point out the locations below. Just to be at the top of this architectural wonder and what it stands for was worth it to us.

Its not just an Observatory --- Its a One of a Kind Experience. From the Global Welcome Center to the Sky Pod Elevators to the Observatory itself, its quite the trip. As you take the 60 second ride to the Observatory, you are surrounded by an almost 360º visual changing of Manhattan from the 1500's to the present as you ascend to the top. Once the elevator doors open, you're treated to a two minute visual presentation of New York. Then the screen rises and WOW, you see New York from 100 stories up! You can buy a skip the line ticket on line for around 50 bucks but if you go on a weekday in the morning you probably can get your ticket for around $34 and walk right in. The views are tremendous, the sky portal ho hum, and the iPad interactive introduction to New York for $15 a definite maybe depending upon your knowledge of New York. A definite must see attraction.
A Fitting tribute. Another poignant location to visit & reflect on the events of 9/11.The design is symbolic in representation of the Twin Towers & provides an ample opportunity to reflect.

A Must when visiting New York. Fantastic - a must do as a visitor or resident of NY. We purchased tickets on-line so that we did not have to wait in very long lines to purchase on the day of. We also went with VIP tickets so that we did not have to wait in line for the elevator ride up. It was well worth the extra few dollars. The elevator ride up and down is very cool; very fast (not scary at all) and the inside 'elevator show' is really well done as well as the cinematic show once you step off the elevator. From there, it's all about the 360 views where you can see for miles and miles, plus there are very friendly and very knowledgeable individuals available to ask questions should the need arise. Just Do It!

Astonishing view of NY. The view from the One World Observatory is really a must during a visit in NY, the presentation in the elevator is one of the highest points and the skyline from the city on the top is breathtaking
Top of the world. Went to the Twin Towers hundreds of times in the 80's and now can say that the OWO truely brings back the feeling. Loved it.
Mrs bisignano. Very busy establishment. Best hot dogs and pastrami. So good. I recommend it highly. All food is great. Watch for parking.

Only worth it for the view. Definitely worth one visit just to see Manhattan and beyond from up in the clouds.Try and find a deal to get reduce admission as it is a little over priced for what's on offer. They show you a very brief video and then ask for more $ to get the audio guide.Only reason to visit: Great photo opportunity!

WOW!. Had a lovely glass of champagne on arrival and the video screen that reveals the city is magic! Loved the ipads to tell you what you are looking at. Just one suggestion - dim the lights so that when guests take photos at night, it isn't of the cafe in the background reflected in the glass! This place is a must see - amazing!

Glass reflection ruins view. I was amazed by the view from the top and the pre show was ok. Do not get conned into hiring a tablet they are not worth it. Any photos you want to take will likely be ruined by the glass reflecting the crowds behind you and the corner with the best view had some horrible presentation structure in the way
Top of the world. Fantastic view, well worth the $$$$ A MUST DO, even if it's just the observation deck. The food was Good & the sunset even better!

Better than other observatory views!. If you're debating on Empire State Building, Rockefeller, or One World Observatory views, definitely go with this one. You can get the tickets cheaper online by shopping around. I think we saved $20 this way. There are security check points, but they were a breeze. ***Make sure you have your camera out on video for the elevator rides up and down. There are three different floors. One has an incredibly expensive restaurant and snack bar so I don't recommend those. Also, we went at 7pm to get views of the sunset over the city. The view was great, some of the pictures came out less so. The sunset reflected on the windows and casted some shadows over buildings.
Well worth the money. Amazing opportunity to see NYC and get a small touch of what happened on 911. The story is amazing and the view is spectacular.

Amazingly high and unforgettable sight . Wonderful experience , deeply moving too, considering I had visited the twins towers in 1992. When I was on top of the new One World Tower, I though to myself , these Americans are a great people after all. Nobody will never bend them!!!

A "must see" when in nyc. I visited the one world observatory twice in my recent NYC visit. This is now a "must see" for tourists. Apart from the obvious historical significance , the views from the observatory are spectacular.Wait times were minimal.Highly recommend

Great Views. Expensive, but the elevator ride and reveal at the top are very well done. The views are fantastic.We arrived so that we would be there for the sunset, and could see the city lights as well.

360 and amazing views. There were no lines when we got there, the fee was a bit expensive for an ex-New Yorker, but had to do it as a tourist now. The elevator was great, less than a minute to the top, without the usual jarring movement. It was nice how the displays showed both height and the floor numbers as we went up. The initial intro was pretty nice, the curtains going up to show a view. We did not sign up for the tablet guide and went about looking at familiar places in NYC. Only thing I did not like was the glare from the windows - can't really get a crisp picture with my phone. But I was really surprised to see the growth of NYC and even across the river in NJ. Overall, it was a memorable experience.
Incredible Experience!!!. Wow!!! See the entire city!!! A 360 view so you can miss anything. A must do when you are in New York City. So much history observed for a cost of $32 a person!!!

An Experience Not To Miss. An experience not to miss. If you book online you can avoid the crazy lines for ticket purchase in the lobby. Ticket price is very cheap for the experience you get! Staff are very friendly and helpful. The elevator only takes 48 seconds and the ride is quite spectacular on ascent and descent, I will not spoil it for you. Once you get to the top you go through a short cinematic experience, after that you are brought to an area where they try to sell you a fancy looking iPad that just tells you what each area of the city are when you point to iPad in the direction of them, its overpriced at $15 for what you get, that is the one of two bad points I have for this Observatory. The views are spectacular on a clear day, you can see out as far as JFK Airport and can get great photo opportunities. You can spend as little or as long as you want up there, with the restaurant being within the observatory area as well, however, I have heard it is a little expensive and of low quality. Overall - I would highly recommend you visiting the One World Observatory, even if you don't like heights.
Amazing!. This was an amazing experience! We purchased the 8:00 p.m. tickets and were up to the top just in time to watch the sunset on Manhattan. Highly recommend to anyone!
A View Not Worth the Steep Price. For $34 per person this is a steep price to pay for a view of NYC. Guest Service staff not nice when my ticket wouldn't open up on my phone. Not worth the trip!!
Extraordinary!. My husband and I had drinks at dusk and the view will take you breath away. We stayed until the sun went down and the lights of the city came alive.

Fantastic . The experience starts from the minute one arrives at the newly built underground train station. Costs £37 to reach to the top. The elevator takes people from level zero to 102 in just under 60 seconds. Apparently they travel at a speed of 24 miles per hour, as fast as Usain Bolt. Fantastic views from the observatory on the 100th floor. One gets free wifi too! Thoroughly recommend it

Worth Going up. I think its worth going up to the Observatory. You get to see NY skyline from a different and beautiful angle. Also a must going to the memorial paying respect to those that died tragically in 9/11. I think the building also symbolize that Americans can rise from the ashes and they will never be defeated by those who are against freedom and democracy. Definitely worth visiting.

Don't leave town without trying. Oh my! I've visited the shard, I've done the at the top experience in Dubai and dine at the top of the revolving restaurant in Sydney but this was by far one of the most memorable and fabulous must do experiences! From the clever lift ride show to the curtain rising on the Manhattan view I was blown away by the details. I was also pleasantly surprised by the dining options at the top and unplanned decided to take advantage. I can't recommended it highly enough, upon entering the restaurant and asking for a table for one I half expected to be ushered to a spot a the back of the restaurant away from any view, but instead was given a seat with the best view of the city, I casually ordered the French onion soup and the calamari, both very responsibly priced. The food was simply exquisite, the best onion soup I've ever tried, so much so I recommended to the table next to me and they too were blown away. All washed down with a glass of bubbles made for The most excellent way to see New York. I booked to visit at 7pm and decided to go up despite a thunderstorm over the area reducing visibility to 5 miles and I'm so glad I did as the show from the storm was awesome and you are able to stay at the top until closing at 10pm, taking in the sunset which was visible as the storm cleared. If your deliberating visiting one world or thinking should I do rockerfella or Empire State or one world, I personally would say why queue for hours for a lift at the empire or go to the viewing deck only at rockerfella, when you can dine, digest the view and enjoy the hospitality and the show on offer for at one world. Book now!

Breathless! Speechless!. This place is simply unbelievable! Every step brings a surprise you would've never imagine. From the technology in the elevators, to the outstanding views of the city. The regular entrance costs about US$37 , which I think was a good price for the experience. It was also very accessible for strollers and wheelchairs. 100% recomended.

Amazing!!! . This is the kind the place that you will remember your whole life. An excellent experience. All the staff were kind and helpful. No inconvenience with the stroller. There are designated access for wheelchair/strollers. The designers of this attraction thought in every detail. The money spent worth it. If you have to decide between this observatory and the one in empire state building, choose one world observatory. There were a lot of people but the space is appropriate to keep every one apart and the elevators are running always. There are 2 types of tickets. Buy the regular one, because is the same ride with both tickets (I did not understand the need of 2 types) and you will save some money.

Breathtaking and awe-inspiring. While in NYC for a teaching academy I knew I wouldn't have a lot of time for sightseeing but I wanted to go to the top of at least one skyscraper. There was no doubt in my mind that One World Observatory was the place to go. (although the Empire State Building was very tempting!) I did not regret my decision! It is the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere, so I was sold! I went on a Wednesday afternoon and did not wait in line much. I loved the elevator ride up as well as the history of NYC. The views from the top were beyond what I imagined. I wish there was an outdoor observatory but I can understand why it's enclosed. I could see for miles and was fortunate it was a beautiful clear day. The people who worked there were very friendly and one even gave me directions to Times Square. I did spend way too much money at the gift shop but they have some excellent souvenirs! I would definitely go back again during my next trip to NYC. (whenever that may be!)
Great family time at One World Observatory. We visited the 9/11 memorial and than the One World Observatory. The view from up there is amazing ! Rent the iPad for touring the area.
Top of New York . I was undecided where to go between Empire State Building and freedom tower finally I think I chose the best and newest view you could ever have I paid 37 dollars an it's worth it
A must see. One of my favorite attractions in NYC. View are breathtaking and a very short wait. Great experience- a must see,
Wow.. Really impressive building, as you go up to the top you realize how crazy it is that men work this high up. Beautiful from the inside and out.

Great views!. My husband and I enjoyed the marvelous 360 views from the top. It took 40 seconds to get to the top with spectacular videos in the elevator. Definitely a must see when visiting New York!

Because it is there..... We visited One World Observatory because it is there, sort of felt an obligation to go. Because it is glass and mirrors, it reflects the sky around it and blends in magically. The elevator ride is memorable; so clever to move from beginning to end. And if you are anticipating a reference to 9-11, don't look for it here. WT1 is about the present, not the past. It is also about selling you stuff. The commercial aspect of it sort of diminishes whatever meditation you might have stored away for the event. I much preferred Rockefeller's top view to this one.

Really good experience (could be improved). We traveled over from the UK and booked ahead to save time and this worked well for us. We arrived at 7pm and went straight through to the elevators - make sure you face the walls and not the door. Arriving at the top we did not bother with the hire of an iPad, we simply enjoyed the spectacular views, watching the sunset. Once you are up there you can stay as long as you like until closing time so no pressure.The food and drink selection was poor. The dining area is a real waste and badly laid out. We were offered a seat at the bar looking at the wall of drinks. The designers could learn from the Fernsehturm in Berlin about laying out a dining/bar area.The views are partly obscured by the reflections on the glass and some of the window panels are irregular making the taking of photos a bit hard.The souvenir area is a waste of valuable space and could be better placed at the exit as most museums do.All in all a really good experience but not 5 stars

Sunset treat and better than Empire State. Very slick with a fantastic view. In fact nothing prepared you for standing outside and looking up. It disappears like part of the Imperial Battle Fleet. We booked using MasterCard (saves money esp for the peak time using their promo). No problems re queues. The lift up us an awesome NY timeline. The way down is like the Great Glass Elevator. They have mini iPads where you can zoom in on views. Ok but about £10 a spin so one per large family enough as you'll spend plenty long enough up top. There's a good cocktail lounge with views for the romantic and separately a cafe next door with hot chocolate. Sunset is a great time to go as you get the best of both worlds. See my review of the Empire State to compare. In my book if you have to do one of the two do this. The ESB looks dated, rather than classic, in comparison. (Didn't do the Rockefeller though). Memorable stuff.

Amazing. We had already done the Empire State Building but decided to do this too. If you get the chance then you should. What absolute amazing views very well organised. For $15 you can rent a tour guide iPad which shows you all the main building where they are and you can even take a virtual tour.

Extraordinary. The experience begins well with timed visits, so the wait is not bad. the walk through the foundation is interesting. the elevator ride is great! and then the views! so many wonderful things to see and all in a great setting with soaring windows and some glass floors as well. Enjoy!
Mussst. Wonderful breathtaking place where you can have a panoramic full view of the big apple, definitely recommend it to everyone

High price tag. We wanted to visit One World Observatory but as this was not included in our City Pass we thought we would just drop by and see how much the admission was.At $34 per person we felt this was a high price tag just to go up high and view the skyline. As we had already gone up The Empire State and The Rockafeller we had already viewed the city from up high.Maybe on our next visit...................
The new view. New tower has been erected on Ground Zero area where you can lift up around 111 floors to see an astonishing 360 degrees overview of NYC. So a new must!
Manhattan Skyline is something. It offers a different view than the Empire State Building and much closer to the bay area. Please visit during twilight time and you can see the beautiful sunset!!

Wow!. The best place to see New York! A fab surprise before you go to the observation deck too which I won't ruin for anyone wanting to visit. Fantastic views of the city, could have spent hours up here. There is also a large store and places to eat and drink.
What a View. Best view in New York City. Well worth visiting. I have now visited all the observatories in NYC and if I had to pick just one to visit this would be the one.

Stunning view. The whole experience is very technology based which is interesting and I guess it makes this observation building different to the two others in NYC. There were no queues and we went in about 30 minutes earlier than our pre-booked time slot. The lifts are interesting as is the mini show at the top which I won't spoil for others. The views are stunning and we did hire an IPad as my partner really wanted one. I did feel it was pushed a little on people. We were here for around 45 minutes but did enjoy the experience overall.

Spectacular views . We went up the high speed elevator just after 7pm and experienced the most amazing sunset and views while we ate supper in the restaurant, and we were lucky to have had a window location .The food was very good,and just being in such a beautiful building with stunning panoramas was a wonderful experience .The gift shop had a fantastic selection of souvenirs .I highly recommend the visit to the top to everyone .I really liked the history of the build and what obstacles they dealt with and hearing the pride from all those who had anything to do with the construction of the tower -was touching and powerful !

Stunning. From the beautiful marble greeting of the escalators that lead you to the ticketing to the animations of the elevators that take you to the top, no detail has been left out. I am so afraid of heights and initially got nervous in the elevator, but the thought of the amazing women and men who had made this unusual experience possible gave me the positive vibes I needed to be so calm and eager to view the city from the top. After the tour you can exit though the new transit hub. It is ethereal, yet so existential.

Marvelous Views. Having been to the top of one one of the twin towers we visited the resurrected tower. Marvelous views starting with the video in the elevator as you go up. I missed being able to go outside at the top but appreciate the security issues.Good lunch with a great view. The elevator video on the way down is magnificent but I will not reveal the surprise..A must see

Great For Fam!. I am pleased at the accomplishment. I came here with my family while here on holiday and enjoyed myself. The elevator ride to and from the observatory was awesome. The history you will learn on an elevator ride...it was cool! And it didn't seem as though we went up 100 floors that fast and smooth! We went at night and it was a slight overcast but, we enjoyed it and it was no one there. It's better than being crowded with people. The employees are super nice and courteous, I almost felt like I was at a Disney park lol.Great informative things to listen and learn. And a great place to take the kids. That elevator ride is history itself. It shows the development underground up and through the years and centuries! We all enjoyed it and the little one enjoyed running around free being we were like the only ones to be in there that evening.Nice place to stop if you're visiting or even if you're from here. You'll be amazed at how much you will learn and how much you will enjoy yourself. I recommend going in the evening because when we went it was no one there.

Must see in NYC. One of the best views of NYC 360 degrees . We went in near dusk ,smaller lines and saw both day and night time views. With kids recommend the iPad purchase it gives the names of all the bridges and the landmarks The elevator ride is cool and the idea is wonderful . Staff is helpful and would recommend this as a must see.Tad expensive
A cut above . Very informative in addition to great views. Tour guides make presentations about the city and answer questions from the guests
Amazing View 1WTC. We visited the observatory of the One World Trade Center. It was amazing. The views were spectacular. We went at sunset! So beautiful! A must see while in NY!

Highest view of the city. I was in the original World Trade Center observatory, and the view from the top of this one is just as good. The elevator ride is fast (60 seconds). At the top there is area couple brief presentations (skip the presentation that tries to get you to lease you an iPad for $15 if you want), then you are free to explore the two story observatory which contains a gift shop, snack bar and restaurant. Unlike the other two observatories in NY (Rockefeller Center and the Empire State) this one is indoors. That is one of the downsides as you can get a lot of glare from the windows that might interfere with the "perfect shot" you are looking for with your phone. The other downside is with the position of the windows in the structure, if you are looking for a good picture of uptown Manhattan or the Brooklyn bridge, that can be a challenge, but it is doable.Wait times were not too bad, perhaps 15 minutes (I went mid-morning). Security was airport style, nothing too difficult. They have some guides at the top that give interesting lectures, and for first-time visitors to New York you can learn some facts about the building and the city in general. The views are very nice, and while it is a bit pricey, I found it worth it to say I have done it once. Highly recommend it.Tip: While there are certainly other things that should garner your attention first in the World Trade Center area (Memorial first, museum second, then the observatory), after you come back down from the observatory ask for directions to the Oculus. While not quite finished, it is open to the public to see now. It is the new World Trade Center transportation hub which is breathtaking inside. Once you see it, you will think Grand Central Station is small! Highly recommended to go see the Oculus, and it is free!
Top of the world Ma!. One World Observatory provides absolutely unrivalled views of the New York area and entertains you while doing it.

amazing views to forever. It was my second visit to WTC #1 and it was still a fantastic opportunity to see the layout of the island of new york. Make sure to purchase a ticket that gives you "jump to the front of the line" access to elevators which take you to the top. No need to fear heights as you travel to the top of WTC #1 in elevator.Take time to read the notes on photographs of construction workers who helped to build WTC #1--very moving. This is definitely a "must see" for visitors to NYC. Suggestion for great visit: Go in the morning when the air is still cool and if it's a clear day you can see forever and you can take wonderful photos of NYC buildings.

Great View- Big price tag. The views can not be beat.Unfortunately, the price of the exhibit can make visiting with large families prohibited. As a New Yorker, I felt compelled to support the Observatory. I visited with 7 people. It is a very humbling experience. There were lots of selfie sticks and huge lines with timed tickets to get in.

Nice friendly staff . Happy the way the staff treated me and we're very helpful, it's a must see and with the second tower near completion it will be good to see the skyline south of the river, good views across NYC visit the memorial too...

High view but others are better . We went to the Observatory but didn't think it was worth it since we've done the others in past tips like Top of the Rock and Empire State. The difference here is that you are indoors, unlike the others which could be a reason to select this one over Top of the Rock. The elevator ride was really cool but other than that it was ok.

Views are Incredible!. It almost feels like a theme park when you first walk in. You walk through all the details about the prior WTCs and the current one. The elevator up is pretty awesome, but makes you a little dizzy with the animations that are going on inside. Once up and finally through to the observation deck, you can see so much, especially on a clear day! It was a lot of fun. The only down side is the pricing. So make sure you at least get a Groupon if it's offered! You don't need too much time for this attraction-an hour or two is probably more than plenty!

Amazing view and excellent presentation. I thought I was just going to this place to get a good view of New York but what experienced was just amazing. The presentation of the FOREVER video ended in just the most wonderful way. I highly recommend this , especially to those going to New York for the first time.

Amazing views of NYC. We went here as part of a tour. We had a pre-approved time slot so the line was not long, pretty much no wait to get to the elevator. We also noticed a VIP Queue - so there must be an option for that when lines are long. The elevator ride up was impressive. As the elevator rose they had a 360 degree video panorama that showed NYC evolving from the 1500's to present. The ride itself was less than 30 seconds from ground level to the 102d floor! Once at the top you can get a professional photo done ($20) or skip that and walk down to the 101st floor where you can see 360 degree views of NYC and NJ. Very breathtaking and you can take some great photos. They also offer a tablet PC ($15 rental) that you can point at buildings and find out info about them. You can take your time on the 101st floor and they also have a café. The elevator ride down was also 30 seconds or less. All in all very cool experience.

I can see for .... feet and feet.. So you prepurchases tickets online and you are given an exact time to arrive, and should an afternoon thunderstorm roll in and completely engulf your view, you are simply out of luck. It then becomes a wonderful $70 (for 2) elevator ride. Such is life.

Nothing compares. The building, the displays, the history lesson all a magnificent tribute to the recovery after 9/11. Don't miss. Also a great experience for a teen born after the attacks. Very helpful staff throughout. One small down side - save the $15 bucks for the iPad they want you to rent. It doesn't work nearly as well as it's claimed to.
Iconic Visit....a place to remember. My wife and I visited this place in April 2016 and it was a cold day. Having got to the top the views were fantastic.

FANTASTIC BUILDING. This is definitely a must see building. The 360 degree views of New York are phenomenal. There are queues so I would recommend going early morning to try and avoid this. I wont spoil it but the lift up to the top is something else!

Amazing view, large 360 degree viewing area. Absolutely a must-visit-again! Relatively long queues, but efficiently and definetly worth waiting for. Cool elevator with a twist :-) Excellent area for view the whole city 360 degrees, spacious. A must-do-when-in-NY!
The highest view of NYC. From this amazing point you have a 360° view. You can see all the boroughs of NYC, all the bridges, avenue and the Statue of Liberty.The place to go for great pictures

Amazing view of the city. The observatory was possibly the highlight of my trip to NYC. Although I was somewhat surprised that there was not more mention of the lives lost on 9 11! I know this is not the museum but because this building was built due to the destruction of the World Trade Center, I thought there would be a little more about the victims. The Observatory offers wonderful views, including the Statue of Liberty & Ellis Island! I highly recommend you take this tour! It is a little pricey, but VERY much worth the cost!

Mind blowing . It is a little expensive but it is well worth the money. The experience is mind blowing, from the lift to the opening of the curtains and the view of over Manhattan. It is a place where you can stay and just watch the scenery

It is all about the view. As the song goes "on a clear day you can see forever" and from the vantage point at the top of this building it is true. Try to buy your tickets online and avoid the initial crowds. There is also a small discount for doing so. You get a brief history on the way to the elevators that will whisk you to the 103 floor. The short ride (45 seconds) is entertaining as there is a projection on the elevator walls that shows the city skyline changing from the 1920s to the present. You would think the elevator has a glass window. When you get to the top the view is spectacular with floor to ceiling glass walls. There is a bar and restaurant at this level. It is a bit pricy as you would imagine but you enjoy an unprecidented view. A short flight of stairs takes you down to the prime viewing area where you can walk 360 degrees around. You can spend as much time as you want. There is a short demonstration you can take or leave and there were a few building experts roaming around to answer questions. A souvenir shop is also located on this level. When you are done it is back down the elevator with another presentation on the walls. Before you know it you are back on the ground floor. Did not even pop an ear drum on either the up or down it was so smooth. It was not cheap($36 for adults) but how often to you get a view of one of the great cities of the world from this vantage point?

I can see for miles and miles and miles and miles. Cool experience, especially the elevator ride. Could be better with reduced crowds, but if you get your tickets for early entry you can avoid most of the rush. 360 degree views of NYC and beyond.

Incredible Views and Great Restaurant. We decided to do this last minute and walked right up on a Saturday at lunch time with less than a 5 minute wait. Everything from the elevator ride to the opening video to the iPad self guided tour was extremely well done. We also made lunch reservations about 1 hour before we ate and were seated right away with a breath taking view of the city. The food was excellent and not overly priced considering! Highly recommend this to everyone!

Great views. The views from the observatory are just great. As the observation deck is very spacious with windows from floor to ceiling you have perfect unobstructed views over manhattan and other boroughs of New York. It's quite pricy (around USD 30 each) but in my view worth the expense. In combination with the impressive 9/11 memorial a good way to spend a few hours.
A must see. Beatuful setting. Pricey admission for a family but a must see. Restaurant had surprisingly good food for a tourist attraction.
The greatest views. The views of the greatest City in the World are here!Don't miss it! Renting the iPad for $15. was a great idea for the teens we took with us.

Really beautiful view. This is a really great site to see, but be prepared, it is busy. I felt like I was in line more than anything and the cost was pretty steep too. Maybe go earlier in the day to avoid this. It is orchestrated from the start from the ride up in the elevator, the introduction video and introduction to the iPads (more money). It spreads across a couple of floors, 100 - 102 for the viewing areas. I preferred the Willis Tower or John Hancock 360 in Chicago over these, but if in New York only, give it a view.

Add to your must do list!. Our family of 4 really enjoyed our visit to the One World Observatory. It wasn't complete the last time we were in NYC so we did the Empire State Building that trip. It's a toss up which I prefer more after going up to the top of One World. The Empire State Building offers an open air experience which is pretty neat. One World does not. That said, the admission price and lines were less for One World and we really enjoyed it. The use of various technology from start to finish was impressive. The elevator ride up was super cool!!! They also offer iPad curators for $15 that our whole family enjoyed. At first I thought it was a gimmick, but decided to try one and am so glad we did. As you hold it up and pan an area, it highlights many attractions/buildings/neighborhood areas and some you can zoom in on and it gives you a bird's eye view of it. Really cool technology and we learned about a few new things and added a few items to our must do list this trip.Overall, I'd add this to your list of must do's the next time you visit NYC!

Great views from Lower Manhattan. Great views of the city and harbor. The elevator on the way up shows you a historical skyline of New York up to the present day. Once up in the observatory you can walk around and have views of the harbor, New Jersey, and up into Manhattan. They have iPads you can rent for $15 that give you info on what you are seeing out each window and it has links to click on to give you more information on certain landmarks.
Expensive but very nice. Expensive but very nice view of all downtown, incredible view of Brooklyn bridge and all the city. very fast elevator amazing!
WOW!. Best elevator EVER! Best views EVER! This is a must see if you visit NYC. There are no other views like it in the city.

We beat the crowds. We booked on-line the night before for 9 people and a 1 year old child. We booked for 12:15 pm. The flow to get into the building was good. The staff were helpful. We arrived around 11:50 am on a weekday in July 2016 and there were basically no lines. There is a security checkpoint kind of like the airport, not as bad. The interesting facts in the rocks is nice and the entry point video is cool. We rented one iPad for the group and not sure we found it to be all that helpful and a bit frustrating to understand. The views were great, bathrooms were clean. The elevator is surprisingly fast and involves entertainment as well. Nice. There are presentations in the observatory if you want to learn about the view highlights. Length of your visit could be 1 hour or easily up to 3 hours if you listen to everything.

All You Need to Know about the Freedom Tower. I've been living in NYC for over 20yrs and lived through 9/11. Did not want to go, however my brother from Chicago wanted to go and I was very hesitant on going. I was impressed with how smoothly the tour went. I purchased a 10am tour and boy am I glad I did. The earlier you can get in, the better. There was no waiting in lines and the staff was very organized in direction you where to go. It definitely gets crowded after noon but GET YOUR TICKETS for anything before 10am.

Not your typical skyscraper observatory. It's not just a nice view, it's an experience. From the moment you enter the building you get a similar feeling to being in a theme park. There is an exhibition about the history of the building and then during the ride in the lift you can see how the New York skyline evolved. It's is all very impressive and totally worth the visit as you can actually learn quite a bit about the city. The view naturally is simply breathtaking. We went at sunset and absolutely loved it.
Awesome!!!!. The view was extraordinary! We thought the elevator was going to be a little adventurous but you hardly can tell that you are moving. It is worth the trip up to the top of the world.
awesome!!. Don't want to say too much about this visit because it is so much more than the best view of NYC. Several surprises await all visitors. My #1 destination when in the city!!

Wow. Let me start with price, It is overpriced, no question about that but once you are done with the tour you just don't think about it anymore, its a great experience and been able to visit one of the best building in modern history Is just amazing, the view, the elevator ride, they definitely did it right, would I go back, NO this is just once in your lifetime, just my opinion....

Simply fantastic. Once in the elevator surprises are starting.. once in the observatory the pre entrance is amazing, you can see a video that ends with the opening of the curtains showing the beauty of New York buildings. I was speechles....

Superb view and lovely bar . My Friend and I visited this amazing replacement for the twin towers in December and were amazed by the experience. Not only is the building amazing but the views are totally jaw dropping.The only issue I had was the cleanliness of the glass as a lot of my photos look awful due to this :-(We then had a few drinks at the bar at the top of the tower and were pleasantly surprised by the friendliness of the staff and quality of the drinks and service.Highly recommended trip if your in this amazing city

A New York must see!. The observatory is a great addition to the to do list of any tourist. Stunning views of the skyline with an iPad option that allows guests to zoom in on landmarks. My favorite was the elevator ride to the top. Very smooth and fast, you are completely distracted by the full size monitors on the walls showing you the timeline of New York City from prior to settlement through today. A brief glimpse of the original towers as you realize their short lifespan from the 1600's until now. We went around 5pm for around $37 per person but the price goes up for sunset at 7pm. We ate at the restaurant which seems like it would be a tourist trap but the food was unexpectedly good although over priced. A great way to relax even if just for a cocktail at the bar. The only drawback was the loudspeaker on the floor beneath the restaurant of the guide giving a tour.

Do It!. At first, I thought that that the price to ascend was exploitative! But my companion said,"Come on. Let's do it!" Thank God we did.This is not a tourist attraction. It's an emotionally uplifting experience. I felt more at one with the victims while looking straight down on the memorial plaza and prayed for them and thanked them. I shed tears of exhilaration at their triumph over tragedy.Their spirits are with you throughout the visit. I hope you can share this awesome trip to the top.Do it!

Top of the World, Ma!. See New York and Jersey from fifteen floors higher than on the flattened World Trade Center. It costs $37, $35 for geezers like us. That's one expensive view but worth doing once. We went on a Saturday in July, the highest season you can find. So the line was looong. We skipped it to walk around the area and have lunch. Before leaving, we check the line again, and, lo, it had vanished almost. So up we went. (Note that if you pay with a credit card, you jump the line inside the lobby.) I thought there would be a crowded space at the top where we would be herded quickly through. Wrong. There is a spacious circular observation deck where you can spend as much time as you like. There is also a cafe. Nothing is cheap. The prices are as high as your perch. Floor-to-ceiling windows provide a spectacular view in all directions year round (weather permitting, of course). There will be days when you can be lost in the fog of a cloud, but you'll know that simply by looking for the top of the building. If you can't see it, don't go up. In a nice touch (literally), before you enter an elevator to ascend to the observatory, you get to see the Manhattan schist bedrock that holds up all the skyscrapers of the city. At the top, there are people who explain some of what you see. That is worth it for tourists who don't know the area. If you're a local, you can skip that and just drink in the view.

Disappointing. Went here with a 10-year old. I was warned by a New Yorker friend that it's overrated and that she didn't really like it. And, boy, she's right. I thought the observation deck's too high that it just looks like you're on an airplane. Also, the queue was disappointingly long. We're scheduled to enter at 5 pm and we only got in at 6:30 pm.

Great visit top of the city. This is a must see fir NYC. They did such a fabulous job with the 9/11 memorial and the observatory is a class act. Spend the money and go to the top. The elevator ride is a treat of its own. We had a party of 8 with 4 adults and 4 kids ranging from 11 to 17. This was the highlight of our day and all loved this stop and sight. Some people just walk around but we say go all the way up, you will not be disappointed.

Amazing Experience. From your trip up the elevator to wondering around the looking 360 degrees over Manhattan, Ellis Island, New Jersey the rest of New York. Worth the money and time. We bought advanced tickets that guaranteed getting up the elevator at a certain time...that being said on this weekday in early May you didn't need to pay the extra price - there was a very short line up - likely long line ups during peek season or maybe weekends though.

Bringing Back the Best View. In building this fantastic building, the architect has given us back the view that's been missing since 2001. And the view from THIS building is far better than what we had at the World Trade Center. Even as you take in the view, however, the fact that others saw this same vista on 9/11 is ever-present.From the much-talked-about elevator ride that displays, in less than a minute, how Manhattan Island began and grew, to the step into the observatory, the experience is unique. When you look down on the rooftops of all of the other buildings, nearby and farther away, you clearly see what a marvel this structure is. What engineering and architecture! It's a fitting place for such a grand building!There are just a few things that might be reconsidered: 1) The lame, lame, slideshow that you're forced to watch could be dropped completely and we'd be none the worse for it. I suspect this is some type of "entertainment" while you wait to get into the observatory but it's just not necessary; and 2) The commercial pitch to rent an iPad. Granted, the iPad gives you more information but the few people I saw trying to use it, it seemed that it was an impediment to the actual view. It would be better if they just added a guide along the bottom of the windows, pointing out which buildings you're looking at and what's in the distance. Maybe the iPads just need more work but I say low-tech would work just fine. 3) There was some person talking about the area -- it sounded like a TV show host. Since I didn't pay attention, I'm not sure what they are doing there but it's some type of presentation. Why that is necessary is beyond me!There's one more thing that might bother some who get dizzy easily: The elevator ride down shows buildings swirling around you as if you're going down a drain -- but they swirl first one direction and then in the opposite direction. It's a short ride but could bother some -- just so you know.The cost might seem prohibitive but this experience is incomparable. If you spring for the annual pass, you get a couple of guest passes, which would be a nice treat for friends or relatives.This should be on everyone's "must see" list for NYC

Brilliant!. Great experience at the one world observatory - we have been at various times since 9/11 - soon after, again when the fountains were complete since and now to the observatory - GO - no spoilers re the lift experience! Brilliant

Amazing View. My family visited here on 23 Jul and it was an amazingly beautiful, sunny day (AKA very, very hot!!!), so the views from the top of the World Trade Center were truly incredible. I paid extra for an anytime VIP visit, mostly due to it being Sat and their website showed a lot of times were already fully booked. When we arrived, just before 10am, the lines were small and we quickly got to the top of the tower. Not sure the extra expense was worth it, but It is NYC, so everything is expensive! For us as a once in a lifetime experience, we loved it!

Tallest building in western hemisphere. The building is the tallest in the western hemisphere. Elevators are very fast going up. If you are afraid of heights, don't go up. Views are great. Don't expect to buy anything to eat or drink. I attempted the buy a gatorade but it was $6 so I put it back. Plan on spending some time on various levels to get some good pictures.

Spectacular view but something missing.... . We had bought priority tickets and that worked out very well. We didn't have to stand in line!The Forever Theater was a great start and the view spectacular. We also had the iPad view which I can recommend! You can read a lot about all the sites you can view through the iPad but I really missed some information about OWO. If you visit the Empire State Building you get a lot of history. You don't get that at OWO.

Impressive. This is an impressive NYC stop and absolutely worth experiencing the hope it represents. Once you get to the top, there is a presentation which is a sales pitch for a $20 "viewfinder", if you know the skyline fairly well feel free to bypass. Otherwise, pick up a skyline guide from the Rock for $4. The tableside dining restaurant is similar to a midtown dinner, but worth dining "on top of NYC." No reservations needed. The other option is to bypass the tables and have a drink at the bar.

Spectacular!. Everything was spectacular from the high speed elevator with images of buildings of NY's landscape and explaining how high up you are going. It felt like we were in a futuristic space ship like the Star Trek Enterprise. Then, along the walls are videos explaining how One World Tower was built as well as another video of NY and when panels where the movie clip was showing lift up you get a peek at a spectacular view of the city. Thereafter there are huge windows where you can see different sides of the city and take pictures. The restaurant also has views you can look at while eating or drinking really pricey items like a croissant and a small bottle of juice for $11.98. There is a pricey gift store with t-shirts for $34.95 for adults and onesies for babies for $24.95. I wish they also had a 4 D movie of NY and the observatory like "the ride" at the Empire State building.

Just breath taking. I recently went to One World Observatory and it was just outstanding. I would change how many people can be on the elevator for people who have motion sickness. But the view was simply amazing. There is plenty of space for everyone to take pictures. The gift shop was a bit small but had beautiful pieces. Me and my bf decided we were gonna have dinner upstairs but the table we had was right next to balcony where downstairs they were talking about one world and it was pretty loud that we couldnt hear eachother speak. We asked to be moved to a booth further away but was told that it was reserved for guest who made reservations. So we decided to leave and just got nasty looks by the waitresses. Other than that the observatory was amazing and will hopefully be planning a future trip.

Great view but overpriced experience. We visited the observatory during the week, around 3pm, so it was not at all crowded, which was nice. The views were wonderful but at $37 per person this was a high priced experience. In retrospect, we should have dined or had a drink in the restaurant at the top of Rockefeller Center and enjoyed the view for free!

You can see the curvature of the earth. Look North to the George Washington Bridge, East into Long Island, South (Statue of Liberty) and well beyond even New Jersey. The ride up in the elevator is a "trip" itself. Not inexpensive and if your a tourist in NYC you know almost nothing is.

Visit only after being to Top of the Rock and Empire State. If you have done most of the touristic stuff in New York city, then you can go here. The building os very modern, neat and the attractions (videos and media) are very technological. The view from above is nice, but you cannot go outside. Also, you don't have the view from Central Park that you see from the top of the Rock and Empire State Building, and also the view of the city from Empire State is better.For me it was good but I was not impressed.

Awesome views with a historical perspective. One visits the observatory for the views but also provided is an interesting historical perspective on the development of Manhattan. My friend and I found it very educational. There is also discussion of the "outer" boroughs and some of their highlights. All in all well done. Not nealry as crowded at the top as one may think.

Great view of NYC. This is the place to see the iconic Empire State Building! A tremendous view and well worth experiencing. It is the new, modern building that rivals the Empire State as an observatory!

Another Great Site in the Big Apple. From the damage done in 2001, it would never be known. Yes, there is lots of construction going on for new buildings and renovations for some of the old. As one of the sayings stated, "we may have been down; but we will carry on." A must see for all ages.

Great views. Had a great time checking out the 360 degree view of NY. I would recommend ordering tickets on line so you can skip the ticket line. I would also recommend getting the One World Explorer iPad, even just one for your group. It added a lot to our experience.I have no recommendation for parking nearby, it cost a fortune. Take public transportation?

Inspiring, impressive and ... expensive!. And it is exactly that: inspiring, impressive and very expensive. But absolutely beautiful and unmissable! Get the lifts and less than one minute after you will have reached floor 102! Amazing ride! Everything goes smoothly and carefully planned to catch your attention and dollars, pretty much on Walt Disney Orlando parks' style. Firstly, you'll buy your same day ticket (USD37.00 or USD35.00 for senior citizens) on ground floor, then you'll ride the lifts up to floor 102, where they'll try to rent you tablets (USD15.00) explaining the breathtaking views. On floor 101, a food hall and an opportunity of taking pictures with professional photographers (more USD). One floor down, the 100th, and the awesome "One World Observatory" with jaw dropping 360º views of New York City! And, finally, a big gift shop! It is easily reachable by subway (Line R) at Cortlandt Street Station. Combine your visit with stops at nearby Ground Zero Museum and Memorial, Brookfield Place (a fantastic mall by Hudson River) and Century 21 (a high-end off-price department store). Enjoy!
vacation 2016. Beautiful experience. Great way to see NYC. We also had a light lunch in the restaurant...delicious broccoli and cheese soup.

Beautifl views on a reclaimed site. Sixty seconds in the Freedom Tower elevator gets you to the top of the tallest building in New York. Designed in a circular pathway, take in all the sites of Manhattan, the waterways and beyond. Reserve ahead for tickets/times to avoid long lines. Worth the trip.

Amazing view!!!. If u wana see an amazing view dont miss that one!U maybe gona miss the central park,but i think it stil worth it!It cost 37 dollars,but u will never forget that!Check out my pics and you will see why i chose that one instead of rockefeller or empire st.b.
Great view .... Spectacular views of NYC (and New Jersey). Stopped here after visiting the 9/11 Memorial and Museum. $15 to rent an iPad to identify landmarks was a bit cheesy for my taste.

great city overview. lets start with the elevator ride- you can see youtube videos and hear about it, but there is no comparison to actually feeling it, the elevator ride is an adventure by itself.that said, the view is just amazing, and the double decker observatory is well worth the high price, you dont just see the city, there are actually stuff to do up there, employee presentation,restaurant and more. if you have to choose one skyscraper and cant visit the other high-rated one, this is the one to pick.one star down for the price.

Must Do!. And yet one more reason to visit the area of the 911 tragedy..... This is a "must do" when visiting NYC. Not only do you travel up an elevator that takes you from the year 1500 to the present in a matter of seconds, once you reach the top, it is spectacular! The views are breathtaking and it's a 1st class attraction all way round. We opted for the VIP tickets which just saves a bit of time waiting in lines, though I don't think those lines looked all that long, so you may be just fine with the regular admission. But do go, it's worth it!
The view was unbelievable. Bought tickets at the door and went up almost immediately. Spent about 1 1/2 hours just looking at the view from everywhere. Loved it!

Amazing view. My wife and I bought tickets after visiting the 9/ 11 memorial and museum next door. The views at the top were amazing even though it was an overcast day. Very enjoyable and highly recommend.

Incredible!!!. This was amazing. It was great from all aspects. I was able to bring my kids to something that was similar to me visiting the Twin Trade towers as a kid. I was able to show them and teach them about what happened. The presentation, elevator, and staff were top notch. I would do this over and over before I went back to the Empire State Building ever again. Great Job. The only negative was the bill was a little high for the drinks we had.

Pricey, but worth it for a tourist visit. The elevator shows you NYC being built on the way up and back down. Honestly, I loved the elevator show so much I wish it was longer. Observation deck is completely enclosed and gives you a 360 view of the city. Breathtaking views make it worth the $35 price tag. It's definitely worth it if you're visiting the city and won't get a chance to see the skyline in another way.

Tall, impressive, expensive. I found the price of 75 dollars for two people a bit steep. I also thought the building from the outside was extremely impressive, but the inside left my wanting more. The elevator ride shows the changes of the city from thousands of years ago until today, which was very cool, but also extremely fast. It was over before we knew it. The views were nice, but I personally enjoyed the view from Top of the Rock much more. Go here if you want a good view of lower manhattan, (it is the tallest building in the western hemisphere we were told) and you are able to see 60,000 buildings below you. Not enough places to sit, if you wanted to take a break, and the souvenirs were very pricey in my opinion. It is a very pretty building though.

Very impressive. The lift is one of the best bits! Be ready, it is a journey through the ages looking at the fields around New York and the buildings as they were built. The descent was like a ride, flying down the outside of the building and interweaving through all the others. Fabulous! Good cafe and usual gift shop and photos taken as well as information centre st the top.

A mouth dropping view of NYC!. My wife and I brought tickets on a whim while in NYC for our anniversary. Tickets are not cheap..about $34 for an adult. This is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere..at 1,776 feet! The views are amazing and be prepared for a longer then usual elevator ride! Definitely worth seeing while in NYC if you don't mind paying $34 a person!

Great Views. Although the day was rainy and dreary, the views were still pretty amazing from the 100-102 floors. The walking path to the elevators was excellent. Super quick elevator ride. The opening "scene" is a little much for the senses because you are so close to the video, but it's worth it in the end. We had lunch reservations at ONE and was delicious. They aren't stingy on the liquor in the drinks.
Don't Miss It!. The most inspiring attraction we visited. Reserve an early time to avoid crowds and have unobstructed views.

A view that goes on forever!. Amazing place to visit. We booked for 7 pm and managed to stay during sunset. We also used our mastercard to get VIP entry - don't forget to do so. Plan to eat elsewhere as the food and drink costs are very high. The elevator ride is fantastic with a video timeline of NYC as you travel upwards. The 'reveal' of the view is breathtaking and then you're free to go around and around taking in the skyline. My bigget criticism would be the dirty handprints all over the windows and the reflections on the glass of the metal 'skyline' at the base of the windows. These made taking photos very difficult in some places. Other than that, it is worth the money for the incredible vista spread in front of (and below!) you. I'm scared of heights and was concerned whether I'd cope but had no problem with this at all.
What a view!. We went up to the top and had drinks! Drinks were very good, but very expensive of course. Views are beautiful. The short elevator ride up 102 floors was entertaining!!
Wow. This is amazing! If you visit New York make sure you visit the Observatory! You will never see anything like it.

Fantastic overview and great experience. I've been at all "Highpoints of NYC" before but this one is really special not only about the view it's even more the experience and starts and ends with the animated displays in the elivator. Try it!

Highly recommended. I first came here in June and have been back twice already to bring friends and enjoy the sunset. The view from the 100th floor is simply amazing and in summer a beautiful sunset is worth-waiting for. I love the view of the bridges too. My friends love it too, some have been there a few times too. Those who came for the first time were equally impressed and likely to go back.

Great visit. I visited Empire State Building in 2010 and fell in love with the view. This time I wanted to show my kids the view and chose the highest building in the US. The access was fast as we had a scheduled time slot. The view was great but the reflection from the Windows made it hard to take good photos. The kids really loved the rented iPads that gave information about the sights.

Good views and well presented, but extremely busy. Currently the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere so the views are spectacular, we went at night and you can see the entire city lit up. My only problem is it's more salesy that the other tall buildings and extremely busy, that's why the top of the rock beats it for me.My camera is a bit rubbish at night so the pictures don't do it justice.

No lines, elevator ride is awesome. We came here at 6:00pm and there were no lines for tickets or elevator which was quite the opposite to the Empire State Building. The elevator ride up was quite the experience, great story and visuals! Can't believe how fast it goes! The view is breathtaking but the one downside is that there is not an outdoor observation area so your pictures will get a glare from the windows. Highly recommend!
Breathtaking. A beautiful tribute to the victims of 9/11 on the ground and breathtaking views from the observatory. The whole experience is wonderful

Overpriced!!!. I will say the views, the movies, the narrations are outstanding and breathtaking. Given it is a new attraction, I chose to pay the $50 for priority tickets..... What a let down..... Not worth the money at all!!!We were able to view a video twice, but not ride the elevator again. The gift shop occupied half the floor blocking valuable walking space. It's filled with overpriced trinkets not worth the price tag. We were offered an iPad for an additional fee, which is unnecessary. All you have to do is Google and interactive map of NYC and you'll have the same information and description with the added bonus that it's free.Go but don't pay the priority pass not worth the extra $20 per person. No long lines etc.....
very well done . nice visit lots lots lots of emotion prepare to cry long visit but you don't feel it very cold insidelots of walking nice films very nice museum

Massive new sky scraper to replace the "Twin Towers" destroyed on 911.. The visit is well worth doing & the lift to the top is quick & your ears will "Pop". The views are stunning of Manhattan and the Hudson & East rivers.
Great view. Fast elevators . Great view. It's a good destination when I'm NYC. Nearby are many restaurants, Hudson River park, south street seaport. Check it out

Breathtaking views of Manhattan. The whole experience was amazing. The building is just mesmerising when you look up at it from outside, a magnificent building standing tall and proud. A journey from when you first walk in, going through the cavelike area with the holograms of the people that reacted and built this building and listening to how passionate they were about building it and what it stands for. The ride in the lift, as quick as it is it's still an experience seeing the landscapes as its travelling up to the top.One at the top the views are spectacular and you really get to see Manhattan in all its glory, you can see the city for miles and from every angle. A great place for photos.The freedom tower is an experience you must have when visiting NYC.

Knockout Views. If you go to Century 21 you can get a 20% discount card for the observatory. I shop at Century's often so my husband & I decided to go to the observatory. The views are spectacular and that's about it. It's expensive, it's crowded and it's filled with overpriced tchotchke booths and bottles $5 water. If it's a beautiful clear day and you've never seen the city from a cat bird's seat you might not mind getting overcharged but rest assured I will never go back even with friends from out of town.

A must-see in New York. I've been traveling to NY for many years with family, friends, and for school/work, so I've slowly stopped going to some of the more touristy attractions, but I must say -- this is something everyone has to see. The staff is knowledgeable and extremely well-organized, your experience is not rushed at all, and the set-up is great for any age. I'd recommend purchasing tickets online ahead of time, as this will save you time in lines. The 360 views are incredible, and the iPad experience is great if you're unfamiliar with the city or are interested in more of a museum-like experience with some historical background and city-planning information on some of the larger buildings you'll see. What a great experience!

The best of all the skyscrapers. This skyscraper tops the lot. No queues if you go mid morning. It's absolutely stunning and very informative. Hire the I pad they offer out to spot the skyline worth the cost ( do one per family)

Quite awesome. Well worth the trip. Definitely purchase the express tix. Don't bother with renting their iPads to show you the interest points. You can do that on your own phone.Besides, you are going for the view.

Disgustingly overpriced…. The view’s spectacular. But $37 is a sickening amount of money to pay for the (30 minute) privilege.This is a brand new attraction so there was all the scope in the world to add loads of value with museum exhibits and interesting, fun, exciting tourist extras. And there is next to none of that.It’s a captive audience – everyone wants to go up tall buildings in New York and this is the newest and tallest of them all – so, I suppose, good on them for giving visitors as little as possible for such a high ticket price.But shame on them, too.NOTE: Within a few days of arriving back in London I had dinner at the Darwin Brasserie in the Sky Garden at 20 ‘the Walkie Talkie’ Fenchurch Street.The view from the Sky Garden is stunning – not as high but every bit as epic and interesting as OWO – and I learned while there that people can visit… for free.
Amazing. We weren't sure what to expect we had never been before. The building itself is beautiful. Then the presentation begins all I can say is I got goosies it was breathtaking!!!!

Superb Views. Definitely worth visiting. Stunning views over the city. We were lucky enough to go when there wasn't a queue. Security was quick and then it was onto the experience. There is a nice cafe area up the top. This became my favourite observation deck in the city for the views it provided. I would go back.
Breathtaking. The experience is engineered to a tee, and the views are breathtaking. The long line moves fast and the experience is definitely worth the 32 dollar price tag.

Impressive. Great visit, expensive but worth it. Great 360 views. Bit disappointed that after paying for tickets we were asked to pay an extra $15 for an iPad viewer to explain the some of the buildings, would have liked to see more talks or guides for the price.
Unforgettable. The whole experience is great. From the lift to the top, opens up, then it becomes something for Star Trek, the screen drops and wow!

Modern and Stylish View of NYC!. The experience is stylish and catered to impress its visitor! You can tell the building is very new and well taken care of. Be wary of up-selling once you get to the observation deck. It gets very crowded during busy times. Nice view. Clean. Picturesque.

Amazing Attraction. This is a truly remarkable experience. We visited on a Friday morning in the summer. The wait was very minimal. The elevator ride up is amazing. Patrons can watch screens that show how the city progressed-and how the building progressed as well. The ride up to floor 100 takes just 60 seconds!The video prelude is awesome, too. I won't give it away-just wait until the end.Of course, the views are out-of-this-world. You can see the magnificent city for miles! Enjoy every angle from every window.This is a must-see while in New York-for Americans or anyone else in the world. Price: $34 a person (non-VIP).Enjoy.
A must see/do. Views are incredible and the dining ONE Dine is exceptional.The management team at ONE Dine and the staff is terrific!

Amazing place for pictures!!. This was one a great experience. We had our hotel buy the tickets for us a day ahead of time and thank goodness we did. We got to by pass the lines and that made it a quick nice trip without taking up the whole day. They do a video on a screen and afterwards the screen lifts up and your looking out at the most beautiful view you have ever seen. Really cool how they present it! The pictures and the experience was very memorable! Highly recommended! A good experience for the whole family!

The Freedom Tower Experience. A must visit!...from the moment you enter , down the escalator through a cavelike walkway with Holograms of some of the builders who are sharing their experiences, also the glass elevator with the ancient landscape of NYC & as it takes you up in 60 Sec. You see the transformation from past to present! Is amazing, then you walk into another dark room and as you're standing in line facing a rock like walk with twinkling lights and you here a welcoming voice of what you're about to encounter...and I cant tell you the rest!???? HAHAHA Just pay & go see it for yourselves!!! B-)

Quite nice. We visited this newly bulit scyscraper to see NYC from a different place. It was not bad but Top of the Rock was much better. The entry show here is quite impressive - you go up with a fast lift and they pull a kind of curtain up at the end and you see the city.
Mind blowing views. I have been to the observation deck in the tallest building in the world (Burj Khalifa) but the views from One World Observatory were second to none

Beautiful view, but little else. We missed the opportunity to go up to the observation deck of the World Trade Center in July 2001; we were not going to make the same mistake this time. The new building and memorial are magnificent. The tower soars into the air as a proud symbol of American know-how. The high-speed elevators take you up to the 102nd floor in just a few seconds, while you are distracted with a video that makes it appear you are looking out over Manhattan. The introduction to the observation deck is dramatic and the 360 degree view on a clear day is magnificent! The food court is quite modest, considering the volume of visitors and the offerings, acceptable but not great. Avoid the iPAD being offered as a guide to what you see. It is minimally informative, unless you know absolutely nothing about the city. In addition, it keeps re-setting, so you need to fiddle with it continuously to bring it back to the view you are looking at. The gift shop detracts from the spiritual meaning of this monument, which shold be a memorial to the fallen, and not an opportunity for the greedy.

Free!!!. If you don't want to pay for the cost of going to see the Statue of Liberty, you must take advantage of this free ferry ride. It passes right in front of Liberty. You can take a round trip ride just for fun & it's well-worth the wait. I always enjoy taking ferries and free is even better.
Great!. Beautiful...loved the video clips at the beginning...the views and the building are stunning....well worth it.

Great Experience. If visiting NYC I would highly recommend visiting One World Observatory. You can buy tickets on site but would recommend buying them online in advance. The line got long very fast with individuals that did not have reserved tickets. Great experience, won't get in detail due to not wanting to ruin the experience for someone that has never been.
Expensive but nice. You can buy the cheaper ticket after 7.45 pm as sunset is at 20.25 in July. Real nice to see the sunset price way too high.

Warning: Its so damn high, you may break your neck !!. OMG, this is like top of the world. I have never seen a concrete structure so tall. You should definitely go to observatory. The prices are pretty steep i.e. $37 pp plus taxes. You can get $3 off if you buy tickets online. Other than the price its a treat. So damn high. You get a breathtaking view of the city. On a clear day you can see 40 miles in any direction. Unfortunately, I went on a day when there was zero visibility so could not see anything. Take something to eat or drink coz once you go up the prices of the food drinks also go through the roof. Enjoy & feel the clouds.

On Top of the One World. Enjoyed our visit here. Essentially you are just getting into a lift and going to the top of a very tall building, however the view from the top is amazing. 360 degree view, far and wide from the south of Manhattan.Plus the lifts have video screens in the walls, floor and ceiling, they do a nifty presentation on the way up and a different one on the way down.

As Beautiful as I hoped it would Be!!!. There was no wait with our reservation time....the staff directed us to the areas we needed to move along to. And everything was so beautifully done. Particularly lovely was the moment you see the outside after the 3 min. presentation!! We loved it. It actually was so pretty a tear came to my eye.

What a way to see NY!. Took my niece instead of Empire State building. It was fantastic! Organized, efficient, interesting, state of the art, beautiful, safe, quick etc! Saved us about 3 hrs compares to the ESB wait! WHAT A VIEW. Do this.

breathtaking. The views are literally better than anything i could imagine. going at sunset to see the city change from day to night is totally worth it. The only thing i do not enjoy are the crowds. Some people are very pushy and there were lots of teenagers doing time elapsed video. Cool for them but the would stake out a window and set up shop for forever and it made it hard to go around and find space. I am still glad i went and would totally recommend it.

Stunning views just like the old WTC. The last time we visited New York was just after 9/11 so we had to go to the top of the new building. Views stunning as before except there is no outdoor viewing point meaning photos have reflections of other people on them. The film shows in the lift in both directions were interesting as was the first 'reveal' of the view.

On top of the western world. One of New York City's newer attractions, the almost two year old observatory is a must see. Currently the tallest building in the western hemisphere and sixth tallest in the world, the trade centre should be on everyone's travel list when visiting NYC.Before entering the centre, do take time to look at the memorial fountains in the footprints of the old twin towers, which show the names of those who so tragically lost their lives. Although tinged with sadness, this has become a calm, poignant memorandum to that day in September and well worth a look.I pre-booked the observatory tour online (that morning) to get tickets at a set time – around 45 mins before sundown for us. There was a special 'Date Night' on offer which included two glasses of prosecco and chocolate truffles to share along with the regular tickets. This was perfect as it was my wife's birthday and a great added extra.We arrived at around 6.30pm, spent time around the memorial fountains and then headed into the trade centre making sure we had enough time to meet our time slot. There were no queues and we went through the obligatory photo shoot to get to the elevator. This was something else. The 40 second ear-popping ride was really smooth. The elevator had large LCD screens showing the construction timeline of the city around us, shooting forwards in time as we reached the top floors. I thought that was a really nice touch and probably one of the best elevator rides available and a great introduction to what was to come.We were gathered behind a viewing rail to what looked like a giant wall which then opened up to show the amazing view outside. We were so high up, looking out over this extraordinary panorama. It was amazing. Afterwards, we took a short escalator ride up another level to where we sat down at the bar area for our free drinks and truffles. They had ran out of those but the nice lady behind the bar fetched us a good-sized piece of chocolate cake to share! We then sipped prosecco, watching the sun going down over New Jersey.
