First of all, I'm going to refer to it as the 'Freedom Tower' because that was it's first name and that is what most New Yorkers call it and I feel they should have kept the name in the spirit of something new rather than changing it back to 'One World Trade Center' apparently for 'business reasons' Yes, it's expensive, yes there are queue's and yes, plenty of opportunity to spend even more money on all the incidentals (Ipad tour info, photo's, upgrade, etc etc) The thing is, you're only here once and the overall experience will stay with you forever. It's a fabulously impressive building and the views are breathtaking. They should have built two!!. We loved it and well worth the cost.

The View. The view is just stunning, be sure to go up on a clear day to see as far as possible. The elevator ride is amazing with NYC history in just one minute, wish I could see it again online! Well organized staff.

Spectacular view . Take the 7 o clock slot to go up as it will give u a chance to enjoy both day and dusk view from the top. New York starts to light up around 8 ..before which you can simply enjoy the sunset views of NY. Sun rays falling on water makes it all the more magnificent. The entry was very smooth. The lift takes you to 102nd floor in around 12 seconds which is amazing. The I pad device that they will persuade u to rent does not have a lot of significance unless u are really interested in the history of all the buildings in NY. The experience was unique and worth the money.

Fantastic experience . Well worth a visit, although a bit pricey at $37 each, it offers much more than the Empire State Building and the Top of the Rock. It has now been crossed off my bucket list, so glad to have done it.

Alright but pricey. Went up just before sunset during their prime time pricing as we wanted to see the city lights. Great views from the top but as you are inside looking through glass there is challenges taking pictures. There is glare from the glass and so many hand prints and smudges on the glass. Neat to see but if you are doing only one observation deck, go to the Top of the Rock.

Emotion Filled....Excellently executed . Having grown up in NJ, I had many fond memories of the Towers and still can't get those iconic images out of my head. One World is beautifully done and is a wonderful experience. The elevator ride was awesome. They have iPads for rent to get a detailed narrative of the sites you can see. Picture packages to take home. If you are short on time make VIP reservations online. You get to skip the line. You get extra prints in your picture package if you do the online reservations. The infinity pools outside are beautiful and memorialize those lost. The winged sculpture is iconic and is forever etched in my mind.

Very beautiful views. Oppoortunities to surrender money around every corner.. Buy a ticket. Check. Do you want to not wait in a line? Buy an upgrade. Check. Take a photo. Do you want to buy it? Turn over more money. Check. Want to eat? There is a restaurant with good food and very high prices. Turn over more money. Check. Souvenir shop with overpriced stuff. Turn over more money. check. Do you want to use an IPAD that shows you what buildings you are looking at as you are looking? turn over more money. check. Be prepared to burn through some money if you do everything offered there. In actuality, it was a good visit. They are more organized now than when they first opened. There are spectacular views of the city and surrounding areas. If you are taking photos, bring your off camera flash. The lighting is at least 2-3 stops difference between indoors and the city. Without a good flash, you will either have a photo of the city with silhouettes or good photos of people with a completely blown out background where the city should be.
Family Vacation. The view was great, but the observatory was overcrowded. We went at sunset, so that was probably not the best time to go. The staff were not very friendly.

Beautiful excellent views and the building is beautiful.. Not cheap to go up. Its beautiful. The views are breathtaking. The design of the building is really awesome. Its pricy to eat up there. Its very interesting and the staff is very knowledgeable and friendly.
Unbelievable presentation & view!. The elevator ride to the top and view is intense. Skip the lines and buy the anytime/express pass. You have a walk around 360 degree view of the city.
Breathtaking 360 Views of NYC!. This is a must see! Enjoyed every minute listening to NYC history. The 360 degree views of NYC is simply breathtaking on a clear day,

Well organised, interesting for some, truly emotional for others. Priority Pass vs. General Admission? We paid for Priority Pass, but on that day it was not needed. However, I can imagine, like others have said, it would be worth the money to avoid the lines. Oddly, the highlight might be the introduction video and the lift ride up to the observatory. A time line of the building of Manhattan from the 1600s to date 'evolves' as the lift goes up. I wish we had the option of going up multiple times! The view is great, of course. It is very well organised. Everyone says so many things in NYC are a "must", but this IS a must. BTW, I ate at the One World Observatory and have written a separate review. The restaurant was very good as well. Overall, what a good experience.
see forEver !!1. this is a must visit , not to misss . I m in awe of this place .. the history behind and the way they have build it now to being the best in the zone .

Top Of The World. We had pre booked a priority ticket for a set admission time so there was no hassle and no wait to get into an elevator. The ride up is quite an experience in itself, the inside of the elevator has images projected onto it to give the impression of a view out that not only changes with height but also has a chronological scale to give you an idea of the development of the area over the past century.It wasn't that crowded at 11am, even on a sunny day so it was easy to get a view in all directions without too much of a wait. Spectacular vistas in all directions which give you an idea of the scale of Manhattan Island and New York Harbour. Well worth the cost and the time if you are in NYC.

Very beautiful view of NY and lot of history. Be prepared to fight the crowd. I highly recommend using the APPLIE IPAD add on, as it a great way to view points of interest and learn about places and get close up and detailed views.You may also want to consider paying extra for Priority admission.

Truly amazing experience - not to be missed. As strange as it may seem, we did not plan to or really realise you could go to the top of the one of the WTC buildings. We had a full day planned and were walking to somewhere else when we passed by the front, saw the queue and anyway there we were 15 minutes later 102 floors up, $64 poorer but ecstatic. The day was stunning, beautiful warm, blue sky which of course meant stunning views.Spending maybe an hour or more up the top, after an amazing lift ride to the top of course just wandering around taking loads of pictures.Lovely little place to eat and shop up there too and the staff were excellent.Well worth a trip and the money spent, one of the highlights of our trip.Have an amazing time
Spectacular. Great (indoor) observation deck, + so much more...spectacular multimedia elevator show(!)...knowledgeable and friendly guides...reasonable wait...

Fantastic!. They've really done a marvelous job here...the views are, as you would expect, fantastic but so are the facilities. The process of buying tickets isn't too bad and you can splurge for "no line" access for a few more $$$.

Take my breath away. Everyone should experience the new Freedom Tower! The elevator ride up was the fastest ever. Only knew we were moving when our ears popped as we ascended. There is a cool video history that plays on the walls of the elevator. Views are unmatched.There's really nothing more to say.

Great view. Worth visiting, great view of New York City. Not too expensive compared to other places in NYC. Incredible view of everything around it, full 360 view with plenty of room. Went late afternoon. Everyone in family enjoyed it.

Out of this world experience. Wow, what an experience. The elevator experience is like wow, awesome. The video on the wall screen is fantastic & once we reach on top, we get to watch a short video and when the screen went up, wow, what a magnificent sight. The view on top was magnificent. Definately recommended

great 360 degree view along with sunset.. elevator ride was fun.. go for it..!!. first thing first.. avoid taking tickets online for 7-8 pm.. we booked tickets for 7 PM and from 715/730/745/8 PM, it was $5 more. so better book for 7 PM, be there until sunset and enjoy both evening and night time at the observatory.the tour starts with elevator ride, but before entering into it, it feels like you are at down below to foundation, they made like this and its good to know how these rocks helped to build WTC again.so coming to the elevator, the whole ride completed in 50 odd seconds.Wowww..!! and screen in elevator starts film which shows how NYC rises since the 1600s to till now. (best part of tour for me)then crew in the start will give you a short presentation about new york and after that when screen lift up and you see the NYC view, amazing feeling. they offer the tablet for $15 to know the all iconic building/places/park. it has inbuilt app in it and it will end your curiosity like what is that building, where is Chrysler building. so if you have a group, you can take it.and yes great sunset view. from the high rise building, it was y first experience.I had been to empire top deck so the comparison will come of course.Personally, I liked empire more as it was in midtown and you can see up/down town both. but from OWO, you can see manhattan outlines and midtown.still, fabulous experience.

Staff need an attitude adjustment. First time to visit the world trade center monument. Very beautiful but the staff at the observatory were rude and not helpful. The security around the water fall could not provide any information about the history of the twin towers. They were only able to speak there native tongue (we spoke English). We even asked someone if they enjoyed their job and they said no. So sad and disrespectful to this monumental place.

Top of the World. This is all inside and there's a lot going on. People talking about what you're seeing. Enjoyed the views. Not a lot of waiting and it starts with a interesting introduction (don't want to spoil this for anyone).

One of the Best Days Spent Being A Tourist. Went to the World Trade with m my daughter and granddaughter. They went to the museum which I passed on, having experienced 9/11, I opted to stay in the outside area. It is very well kept, clean and inviting. I spent a pleasant time around the reflecting pools and just relaxing. We then went to the building and up in the elevator, which in itself is an exhilarating experience. It was a lot like the virtual ride at Disney!! The observation floor was absolutely amazing, I cant begin to described the magnificence of the views. We just went around and around picking out various areas of the city.This was worth every penny and we are going to do it again this time at twilight
Take the Fastest Lift in the World. Wow just seconds to travel to the 102nd floor and you don't even know it! But the view from the top is to die for, well worth a visit.

A wow moment that will take you breath away. I've been up The Rock and The Empire State Building and both are awesome - but the view from the observation deck and what the whole building means and why it is there will take your breath away. A moment I will never forget - seeing that view for the first time. A must do!

What a view!. Very fascinating elevator ride up. Once you get to the top, you see a short video presentation and at the end, the screen goes up and you see outside. Breathtaking and somewhat emotional! Very good presentations by individuals.

Pricey entry just for the view . The views from the 101 floor are amazing don't get me wrong however I was expecting some part of the short film to explain the history of the area/memorial info or even the process of building the highest building in NYC. Instead the short 5 minute film was just fancy pictures and graphics on the screen. You get a 360 view of the city and have the option of purchasing an iPad like device to explain all of the main infrastructure. I have also been to top of the Rock and that is just as good (and outdoors) so in my opinion you do not need to do both. It was about the same price as well around $35 USA per person.

No better place to watch a sunset than this observatory!. Just by entering the elevator you know this is one of a kind experience! A beautiful building that allows you to get the best of Manhattan. I loved it!
great views and fun elevator ride. Great city views from the observatory. Fast elevator ride up is fun and informative. Not sure its worth the money though.
Only 102 floors - wow!!. The whole experience is incredible especially when they are telling you about it and then the screen lifts and there is Manhattan in front of and below you.

Incredible Views. This observatory offers a 360 degree view of the city. As the elevators take you to the 101st floor, the walls of the elevator project a video of the landscape of the city through the years dating back to the 1600's.

Sometimes its all about the Money$$. We had family in town and wanted them to enjoy the fireworks, so we paid $ 740 dollars to view the firework from the top of the tower. What I didn't know as I ordered my tickets, was that there was a VIP ticket at $ 325 dollars per person and that was all that mattered to 1 World.First, we were treated like livestock kept waiting till the last minute to enter the tower while the VIP's were treated like kings.The promised food was a joke the soft pretzels were hard since they were still frozen. the Hot Dogs with ALL the traditional fixings was only mustard. Oh, there was a bag of chips. Only a few small tables and chairs so there was no place to put down your drink, which made eating not fun. For Sure, not worth the price.$$ When the Fireworks did start they didn't even turn on the music that synchronized with the show. It was not a very happy 4th of July
ONE WORLD FOREVER. This is the most spectacular view anywhere. Their saying "One World Forever: is absolutely true.....
You must do this!. After our tour we stopped in the bar for a drink. The views are amazing and the service is great. I would recommend this for a relaxing break before finishing the tour.

Beware!! Families get ripped off.... We passed OWO later in the day and as all the ticket booth were open with absolutely nobody around, we decided it would be the ideal opportunity to purchase our tickets for the following day (a Tuesday) thus avoiding the infamous queues. We were not particularly fussed as to what time, so we picked 1.30pm and paid $136. You can imagine our annoyance when we discovered, later that day, that we could have had a Family Package for $105!! This made my blood boil as none of the ticket staff offered this package to us or made any suggestions to us to get our tickets at this price or if the Family Package came with any restrictions. They simply charged us for 4 standard tickets without asking us any questions. Not one of them was under any pressure with queues of people waiting in line behind us. When we arrived the following day, there was no customer service desk to be found and the feeling of being completely ripped off was fresh in my mind. However, we did our best to not let this cloud our judgement of the tour itself. We hired one iPad ($15) and shared it between us and this worked really well. The highlight for me was in the See Forever Theatre. I do not want to spoil it for you but all I will do is suggest that you have your recording devices at the ready.The staff at the City Pulse were charming and very helpful. One lady recommended a few places nearby where we could get the best hot dogs.The experience itself was most enjoyable and I would definitely recommend a visit. The only reason I have rated this as average is because we got ripped off, otherwise it would have been an excellent.

Great entertainment and view. I didn't pre-book any tickets, I guess I was lucky as there was no que iby the end of the afternoon. From the moment you get in the elevator until the moment you enter the observation deck, it's great entertainment. At the observation deck, the 360 degree view of the city takes over. The tickets are expensive, but it was worth it. I have an incedible fear of heights, but as you stay inside behind glass, it was doable.
Cool. Took the trip to the top. Elevator ride was so cool and the city is beautiful at night from that height. Statue of Liberty in the distance. Go at night.

Sacred and Scarey. This is a very high building that is exquisite and serine but I felt quite scared to be there. On the other hand when your number is up that is it and I did not stay long I just loved the view and hen it ended

Totally amazing views. In all honesty I didn't have this o my list of must sees while in NYC, however the group I was traveling with really wanted to do it so I went along. I'm so glad I did, the view was simply amazing, I would recommend that you visit on a clear day, you can see everything for miles. It made me very emotional too, I kept thinking about the lives lost on 9/11 and how it must have felt to be In a building of that height on that day and it being the reason the new building was erected. Well worth a visit

Awesome Adventure ... One World is a full around viewing experience that starts in your elevator. From a 3 D viewing as the walls of the elevator change as you go higher showing NY in the past till present. Once at the Top you can eat , look out on any side with up to the glass experience and buy gifts. Well worth it .

Amazing views of the city. Visited in July on a Tuesday before 2pm. So there were smaller queues. By the time we came out, queues were longer. Ticket costs slightly higher if purchased at the tower itself. Best to buy online, but there is entry time restriction per ticket. The elevator to the observatory takes you through the journey of New York's history. The views from the 100 + floors are beautiful.

Fantastic views. The One world observatory was brilliant.. I went a little later in the day (arrived about 1630), which was perfect as the crowds are starting to settle a bit, though still waited for about 35 mins to get into the lift. There is a moving video wall from the people who built the new tower, and then some information about it.The lift is amazing- I won't say anything more to not spoil it, but it like a potted history of NYC. Then there is another short video with an incredible ending. The viewing deck is just after that, where you can see the most fabulous views of the city (though we were blessed with a clear, sunny day). I would plan to spend a good hour up there taking in the views. Definitely worth a visit!

Must do at night. Didn't know what to expect or what was actually in the building. Once through security the ride to the top was very quick. Had booked the Flexi ticket which was worth it so not restricted to an allotted time - especially if you do the 9/11 museum first and overrun as we did. The "special effect" was very impressive. Wont tell so not to spoil! Go at night for the extra special wow factor.

Awesome view and great Cocktails!. The Elevator traveled 100 floors in about 47 seconds and had a nice multimedia experience. The views were great, the hosts were all very nice and informative. The bar at the top was very nice!
Tear jerker. Thoughtful, sensitive and with wow factor. Don't miss it! Book tickets for a set time but no hurry once you have reached the top.

Great....BUT...VERY VERY EXPENSIVE. This gets three stars because of the price. Its well done, figure to allocate about an hour based on line length.Positives - great views - Manhattan and BrooklynNegatives - Expensive. figure $75 for two adults. If you want the guided tablet to identify the buildings thats another $15 when you get to the top.Crowded. Everyone wants pictures of course.The windows need cleaning for optimal pictures.Now day/night combo ticket at least I didnt see.Night time is more expensive than daytime.If you want high building overviews of NYC you have three choices:One WorldEmpire State Building Top of the Rock.If you can live with one either go with One World for the uptown view or top of the Rock with the South view of Manhattan.When you do the Statue of Liberty or walk the Brooklyn Bridge you will get the great lower manhattan perspective with One World at the centerpiece.

Loved the views. Some people said they didn't like the enclosure of the observatory. We didn't mind it. It was beautiful. We came during the day on a very clear day and were able to see everything. Highly recommend!

Landmark Attraction. Our first post 9/11 visit to One World Trade Observatory. Thrilling, amazing, educational, emotional. From the moment you enter your experience begins even before you board the elevator. This is no mere elevator though, it actually is a historical visual educational experience from the bedrock below to top of the World. I will not reveal all we experienced during our ride as it would spoil the great surprises in store. Once arriving to the observatory the view is a jaw dropping experience filled with delight and amazement. Having visited what was "Windows" in the past I will say that is was a bit emotional for us all. Overall we where very glad to be there and all of the staff members where inviting and eager to answer any questions. To me though it felt more like a Disney World attraction than a ride up in an elevator to look at the view.Disney World is known for it's exceptional everything and a visit to One World Observatory is nothing less.

A must see!. This is really so well done! The staff is not only knowledgeable and friendly, but you can see they are really proud and enthusiastic to work here. There are so many special details all around you and the views are amazing! It was wonderful to see so many different people visiting the One World Observatory. This should definitely be on everyone's itinerary to visit when they are in New York City. This is such a special tribute to those who lost their lives on 9/11 as well as their families and the city!

Good but not the best views. Visited April on a very clear day, the views are amazing however the reflection from the glass on the photos meant that the best photos are to be had at the Rockafella Centre :) Worth the visit tho :)

New amazing "must to see" in Manhattan. There are three essential observation decks in New Your, Rockefeller Center - the rock, Empire State Building and new One World observation. One World is the highest one and provides unique experience and view that is not available from others. If you have time for one deck, go to this one. Little bit. More expensive than others, but for good reason.

It was pretty well organized. Views are beautiful.. We went there on the 4th of July. There were some crowd, but the folks who handle the event is well organized. The elevator ride is very fast. Wish it has windows to see outside. Overall a very good experience.

Amazing views, learned a lot. Buy tickets in advance. We didn't do the priority tickets but it wasn't busy the day we went - I have heard from some people that the priority tickets are worth it so depending on the day and time you're going, plan accordingly. Priority tickets will bump you to the front of the line so if you think it'll be busy, get them. When we went it was raining so there was limited visibility however we did catch a rainbow (see photo). Before we entered, the gentleman did tell us that it is limited visibility and we could either choose to go up today or come back tomorrow. After the rain, it cleared up and you can see pretty far. The elevator ride up is great - hopefully you don't get sick but the best view is to stand with your back to the elevator doors so you can see all 3 sides of the elevator. If you'd like to see the city from all sides, this would definitely be the place to do it.

Can't believe my anxiety didn't get the best of me . I was somewhat concerned to go up so high. The line took a little longer then I was comfortable with. However the elevator ride was quick and the video on the walls took the attention away from how fast and high we were going. It was very pretty just a little overpriced .... Then again I didn't look for discounts so I blame myself for that.

Just fantastic. Very well done - an amazing view! It is one place to definitely visit in NYC - you won't be disappointed .The guides were very knowledgeable, make use of them - and the coffee shops at the top are well worth popping into!This is a very sympathetic monument for the twin towers !
Amusement. The journey begins from the base of the tower. Very entertaining from the beginning to the top end:) with a surprising amusement in the middle!

Amazing view if you don't mind the glare!. Firstly - get there early to avoid queues! We rocked up at opening time & walked straight in. The lift takes you to the top in no time at all with cool video screens floor to ceiling on all sides (have a good watch on the way down, my partner thought it was brilliant but I was too busy trying to get my phone to record & missed it). Once at the top you are in for a treat - we visited our first morning so it was really our first look at the skyline & what an introduction it was! Don't want to spoil it for anyone who doesn't know what happens but believe me it is awesome. Then you are free to wander around the observation decks, all internal so photos all have an annoying glare. The iPad you can hire is pretty cool, it helps you figure out what you are looking at. The snack bar/cafe place wasn't up to much - as I mentioned we were there for opening time & wanted to grab breakfast at the top but they didn't have any bagels left (don't know who ate them since we were so early!) & no seats, just lean to bench things. There is a proper restaurant too but think it may only do lunch & dinner.

Amazing Views, disappointing dining. First the good; the views are amazing and that's what we came for. Yes, as others have mentioned, pass on the iPads as it's a quirky experience at best. The idea behind the iPads is to point our what you're looking at but it's a poor experience. Asking someone is more productive. But again, the views are amazing and why you should go!BUT, the dining experience put a bit of a damper on the visit. It was truly disappointing given it would be so easy to improve and, if not make memorable at least not detract from the whole experience. What's the problem? Well first I should should mention there are 3 options for dining but you need reservations for "One Dine", the top shelf facility. We didn't want that but still expected a decent lunch so that left us "One Cafe" or "One Mix. Issues:1) My wife uses a wheelchair so although "One Cafe" fare looked good there are no chairs and high bar-type standing tables. So my wife would have had to eat her lunch from her lap. Not good. So we "chose" One Mix but..2) Service was slow despite plenty of staff and we waited and waited for our food, though others ordered the same meals and were served first. I asked about this but our waitress indicated the kitchen was behind, but again, others around us ordered the exact same meals and were served before us. Not good.3) The food was pricy and nothing special. Yes, I didn't go there for the food but again, so easy to improve upon.4) There's plenty of room but it's poorly used. We had to actually have 2 people at the bar pick up and move their chairs so we could get out the only exit from the dining area. Really? My wife's wheelchair is not that big - a travel model even. Again not good.So while the views are great as you would expect whoever is managing the dining operations should be ashamed. Such a great venue and yet such poor execution.

One world observatory. Nice view depending on weather, They told us the weather and expected view before they excepted our ticket. There was no tour per se and renting a tablet for $15 to share was an option. We could hold the tablet up to the window and see more detail on all specific buildings. If you're not familiar with the buildings it wasn't easy determine what they were without the tablet.

"360 views ". We paid for priority tickets which actually if you visit early on a Sunday we found we needn't have bothered. We had a clear day which meant the views are amazing. We paid for the iPad for our son but as the staff are really informative we probably shouldn't have bothered. From start to finish I guess it was about an hour and half, including taking time at the top for drinks.

One World Observatory. This is a great scenery to see all over New York. i was there when the weather was fantastic. the ride with the elevator is an experience in itself. getting out of the elevator, and seeing the view from the 100th floor is just FANTASTIC!!if you would pick only one building to view NYC from up above, i would recommend you choose this one.

Panoramic view but Overpriced . From the moment I entered in line to buy ticket I felt like a victim for exploitation. Every stop is being used as opportunities to get people to spend money beyond just entry ticket. The elevator ride was entertaining and the view breadth taking. Everything is controlled in the environment. I do think visitors should consider to visit either Empire or this one if necessary.

Best Tall Building Experience I've Had. In lots of cities it's a common attraction to go to the top of one of the tallest buildings and look around. We enjoy the view and the marvel of the building itself. But, for me, it can sometimes feel anti-climactic. I paid a lot of money, stood in long lines just to spend 15-30 minutes walking around a crowded areas looking at the view. It's always a spectacular view, but somehow I still feel like "that's it?".My experience at One World Observatory was the best I've had. On a later trip I went to the Empire State Building and was disappointed and wished I'd come back here instead. OWO made the whole experience more entertaining. Even the final point where you are looking around at the view is a richer experience.There are lots of interesting moments along the way to the top, and at the top the area is spacious and modern and comfortable. Also, you can rent a tablet that helps point out landmarks you are looking at and gives you some information and history about those landmarks.As always, it's recommended to buy your tickets in advance. Even if it's just buying them that morning online for a set time that day.

The highest point of New York. We made reservation through the official web site where someone can find many offers and we took the family offer for 4 persons. We made our reservations days before to ensure entrance and we were very lucky to have a great weather - sunny day on our visit. The views were exellent, to go up you have to be on time in order to pass the securuty controll so its better to arrive earlier and the staff will tell you when to enter. We came 30 min earlier and as we waited we spent some time taking pictures and looking up. The best thing is when you arrive with the super cool and fast elevator to the top and the "curtain" opens and you see all the Manhatan greatness infront of you. Incredible!!! At the exit you can buy a picture of you which can also be downloaded to your computer.

Well worth the $32 we spent on each ticket. The entrance price is not cheap, but I felt it was well worth my money.Not only do you get to enjoy the endless vistas from the top of the observatory.Along the way to the top, all kinds of things are added for an extra special experience.I enjoyed my visit tremendously.

Amazing experience. You must go to this! Buy tickets online to bypass lines at the observatory itself, which will save you a lot of time.You first go through the bedrock of NYC while watching a video of the observatory and how it was built. You take an elevator ride from the ground level (which is where the bedrock is) up to the 102nd floor, while watching a video on the elevator walls of the NYC skyline and how it's changed over the years. I was so busy watching it on the other sides that I missed the twin towers going up and coming down. On the top floor, you watch a video on NYC life and then the screen raises up to reveal the current city. You then go down a couple of floors to the actual observatory, where you have a 360 view of the city.

Meh.. Don't be a sucker like me. Don't get the Ipad, unless you really, really dont know a thing about NYC. The info is not that "historical" and it didnt always line up with where we were standing. It was frustrating to use and we felt limited.We had priority tix, which bumped us to the head of the line. Being July 4th weekend, I was very grateful, it was still very crowded and noisy.As other reviewers mention, The elevator ride would be spectacular if you could see it in a packed car and/or had time to take in the images.Having been to the WTC observation deck and Empire State, I was just not that impressed. I wish I could say I was for the ticket price.The view of the memorial is amazing but the north tower site is unable to be viewed.

Not for the faint of heart.. You'll feel all the emotions. You'll be terrified as you're about to get in the elevator to go to the top. You'll be sad. You'll feel a little guilty for even taking all those Instagram pics of the same view thousands of people saw before they died. But you ultimately will be glad you went.
Nice tech . The elevators and pre show were great. So much more advanced than the Empire State. The restaurant was very good. They should not charge you to go to top if you eat at the restaurant

Getting re-acquainted with the WTC. Last time I was here was 8 weeks before 9/11 and one can imagine the emotions flooding in. The visitor experience has been well organised and based around the terrible events and the subsequent rebuild. I went early in the morning 9:15 am to avoid queues building. Tickets are around $33 and seniors (over 60s) pay $30, incl. tax. The elevator has large video screens showing the build process whilst climbing to floor 102Here you find a small guided audio-visual exhibition, as well as a snackbar, restaurant and a gift shop. A coffee is $5, which IMHO is a bit steep!!!!Outside the amazing views lay Manhattan and surrounding areas open to your gaze. It never surprises to amaze me and is a MUST for any first-time visitor to the Big Apple. Overall, a truly great tourist attraction. Recommended A*

The view of Manhattan is absolutely breathtaking . If you are going to New York City visiting the One World Observatory is a must. The view of the city is absolutely breathtaking. Get your ticket/s online to avoid the long line. It is worth it. The first time I visited the lines were so long I turned back. The elevator ride to the viewing deck on the scenic elevator is amazing. On arrival to the viewing deck they give a visual film presentation of Manhattan and they sell you this iPod device for $15 which comes in different languages. When you hold the device against the window it identifies what you are viewing and tells you it's significance. Make sure that when you pay for this device you test it before proceeding to the viewing deck to avoid being irritated of getting the wrong device. I ordered one in English and asked if it was in English when they handed it over to me in the counter and they said it was only to discover it was in Spanish (Grrrr!). In spite of the hitch the view was simply amazing. This is a must visit when going to Ground Zero.

3 days in New York . One World amazing structure disappointing experience . This is costly visit if you are a family unit . Yes the view on a clear day spectacular but they experience is very commercial and over controlled . You go up quickly in elevator which has TV screens all round you . When you get out you are forced to watch a presentation before the wall lifts the view is before . Be warned after this you are herded into an area for an obligatory photo , I tried to forgo, this by walking round the rear of the are but was told not to nicely that I shouldn't . Far to commercial . Sadly not good experience . Try top of the rock instead.

Great views, layout could be improved. For views of lower Manhattan, Liberty Island, Ellis Island etc there is nowhere better to go. Whilst in Midtown, I prefer Top of the Rock over the ESB, the One World Observatory can't be beaten for this area of Manhattan. So, that's the views out of the way. Understandably, the One World Observatory is busy a lot of the time and there are a couple of areas in which the layout could be greatly improved to aid guest flow around the attraction.After going up in the lift (in which the AV is excellent), you enter a small movie theatre experience, however, once the film has been shown, the assembled people are then expected to exit via a bottleneck that is not very conducive to efficient guest flow. It's also counter-intuitive as those who are furthest to the right (where the exit is) have to move to the left first before then moving back to the right to exit. After the cinema experience, you enter another room where the team try and sell you the hire of an iPad to provide further insight as to the views, and again, after this area, there is a bottleneck for everyone to move through before reaching the observatory itself. It's definitely worth a visit because the views are unrivalled, but they could certainly do with a few changes to the flow of guests through the attraction itself. I'd also suggest a few more areas for people to sit too.

An incredible view of NYC. The view on a clear day is simply amazing. I would recommend that you get there early. Lines can get long. It is a fun activity for the family and has a "futuristic look" to the ride to floor 100. It obviously can be done in tandem with the visit to the 9/11 Memorial. Its a little pricey, but a visit to the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere is worth it. Looking down on helicopters is a wierd sensation!

One World Onservatory. Its difficult to put into words how One World makes you feel. The views are amazing, the building incredible and the legacy is forever. Please add this to your "must go" list when visiting New York City. We found it breath taking and heart warming.

Breathtaking view of manhattan. The observatory on the topmost floor has used technology to transport you to the places you are viewing. You can hire an ipad which is programmed in such a way that when you look at a certain building you get all the details. amazing. The elevator to the top is also quite thrilling

Great views, high cost. Impressive high-rise and the views are stunning. Elevators are super-fast and with innovative "illustration" as one travels to the top. It is a bit expensive though (more than 30 USD) and done in less than an hour.

You gotta do it! We suggest VIP tickets for busy weekend visits. . It's the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere and the top floor is open to the public. Why wouldn't you go see it? It's super cool. Here is a tip. We bought the VIP tickets which allowed us to by pass all these hundreds of people in line ahead of us. The VIP tickets were $56.00 and well worth it. We went on a busy Saturday morning and walked right past all these folks in line and jumped right on the elevator. During the week it might not be too busy but when we went there must have been 500 people in line.

Awesome view!. In town for the weekend and this was on our 'to do' list. Husband got the Priority tickets ahead of time so we didn't have to wait in line. It was very busy on that floor. It was a quick trip up and down.

Yearly visit . The World Observatory was absolutely outstanding. The elevator ride and the film that was shown while riding up and down was so great and honored those who lost their lives in 911. The place is a great contribution to those who died. The view was great.

Family Vacation to the South East . This whole area is amazing. So much emotion felt. Remembering that day like it was yesterday. The memorial is amazing and shows we will never forget all those lives lost.

It's very tall... and that's about it. . Visited at 10am on a weekday so it was really quiet which was good. Meant no queue getting the the lifts and we went straight up. View is amazing and you can see for miles although its a little worrying when you realise helicopters are flying below the level you're stood on. What I didn't like and what lost points is the " theatre" In the lifts... a short video showing new york being built through the ages. Fine. .. but 45 seconds in a lift isn't long to take that in. Once at the top you then watch some " random scenes of new york" played on a screen which then moves away to dramatically reveal the view. Yawn. I don't want to see ground level shots of taxis and buildings. It was all very irrelevant. Then you're ushered away from the view to a room where they try and upsell you to rent an ipad with info about the view. We'd pre ordered one anyway but the price was the same and we still had to stand through the sales spiel before we could go anywhere. Once we had it it was mostly a pain in the rear as it was heavy and cumbersome, however if this is your first viewing it may come in handy to spot what's what. Some of the best views were totally obscured by more stands with people waffling on about the view. Again. So the view pointing directly towards central park and the rockafella centre etc was captured from one side rather than front on because they had stupid stands in the way. Please please. Just let people see the view and stop with all the extra junk. Overall the view from the top of the rock may be lower down... but damn. I enjoyed it more. We were left to our own devices there and didn't have to sit through what felt like loads of rubbish to see it.
Wow. I have not been back since I was a responder at Ground Zero in October of 2001. It has changed so much... so many new buildings. I was moved by the memorial.

Utterly astonishing. When visiting Manhattan this is one "attraction" you can't afford to miss. It's exceptional right from the start. The elevator ride, both up and down, is unique. I won't spoil it for you. The view from the observation deck is breathtaking, On a clear day you can see Washington (joking, but it feels like you should). The interactve ipads are very good and there are plenty of friendly staff on hand to answer any questions you might have. It's really weird to be looking down on the sight seeing helicopter tours.

Not Free but Dramatic. Pros: Dramatic sweeping views of New York, 47 second, super speed elevator with fantastic video surround presentation, convenient to the 9/11 memorial site.Cons: Tourist trap ambiance, you must pay $47/adult (some package deals with other attractions give you dollars off) and run the gauntlet of the photographers taking/selling you pictures, the hawkers of the $15 Tablet app to help you find and interpret the landmarks, and giant souvenir stand.Tips: we went at nightfall, no line, actually had the elevator ride to ourselves. It was more difficult to take pictures through the glass due to the bright lights of the souvenir stand (created unwanted reflections). You can get food at the top if you want. Expect to spend about an hour at the top plus your line time.Overall: If you like this type of top of the world views or have this attraction as part of a package ticket, by all means see it!
you can see forever!. Visit the 9/11 memorial and the museum, then go to One World Observatory! It will give you chills! Amazing job! Well Done! Makes you proud to be an American!

Awesome view - best sunset over a city. I was advised by a friend that this is an awesome place to go to... He rated this above Empire Estate Observatory. I went there just around the sunset and was fun to see all the architectures from up there - including the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge. The best part was the sunset, I have never seen a better sunset over the backdrop of a city. It was great! The sun down and being towered by tall buildings. You don't get to spend too much time once it gets dark as it closes down pretty soon enough after the sunset. But whatever time I spent after the sunset was spent looking at great lighting across the city. The bridges particularly look marvelous.If you are not a history buff and want to avoid museums, this would be a great place to go to.

It's True - On a Clear Day, You Can See Forever. My advice is check the weather forecast for the next day, and then buy your tickets. You want to make sure to get as much of this experience as possible, and with clouds and fog in the forecast, it wouldn't be quite the same. On a clear day, you can truly see forever. It's so peaceful at the top. And getting there is quite an experience; the walk to the elevator and the elevator ride itself are very informative. Once at the top, you're given the opportunity for $5 to rent a One World Explorer iPad to take a virtual tour of New York and it's iconic landmarks. I thought it was worth it, since this was my first visit to NY. All in all, I highly recommend, and the $30 price tag for the tickets is worth it.

An uplifting experience. This is an uplifting experience in every way. The views on a clear day - as we experienced it - were breathtaking and lifted the spirit after the solemnity of the 9/11 memorial. Stunningly well executed and well worth the extra few dollars to jump the queue.

Fantastic views. Been here twice now. Always quick and not waiting in queues for too long.Going up in the lift I tried to keep my eyes open as you travel so fast.The whole lift changes through time as you get higher which is interesting to see.You then go into a room for the view revealed. You can then grab a tablet which i think there was a small charge for and as you point it around the 360 room you can find interesting facts about what you are looking at. There is also a restaurant, bar and food places open. We had the flat bread pizza and it was amazing. Best pizza ever. Would go back here just for the pizza.

Very Well Done. The Observatory is now open to the public and very well done. It does not dwell on the 911 events at all, it is a proud display of New York's building talent. Obviously it has a spectacular view, the elevator ride was interesting and a very fast ascent. There are a lot of employees around to answer questions and they have a tablet for rent that has a great app on it to identify any building and give plenty of facts. There is a large gift shop and an expensive café.

A must see for anyone visiting NYC for the first time. One World has 360 views, and on a sunny, cloudless day, you can see the whole city. There are also lots of activities going on in the observatory such as live presentations about the city. The only downside is that the observatory is entirely indoors, so you have to take your pictures behind glass. I recommend going early in the morning to avoid crowds.

Great views, but sightly expensive . If you are looking to get a great 360 degree view of the tri state area from 100 stories above lower Manhattan, then this will do it. Tickets are on the expensive side, approx. $35 for adults and $25 for kids 12 and under. I bought tickets on the day of my visit on line. Ticks on line are $3 less but they charge you a $3 service charge per ticket. Therefore, no real savings. Line to grab the elevator was short and minimal wait time, a few minutes. The ride up to the observation deck was amazing. I will not ruin the surprise, but be prepared to view images on all 4 walls of the elevator while riding to the top.?Very cool! Once up on top, a short video presentation and then one other surprise, also very cool. Once up on top, you will have great views of nj, lower Manhattan, mid town, Brooklyn and queens. No views of Central Park. One negative, the observation area is totally enclosed, unlike the Empire State Building, which offers an outdoor viewing area. Overall, a must visit if you re looking to see NYC from above.

A view of New York City that is unparalleled!. We ordered vip, fast pass tickets, enabling us to avoid the lines and walk right into the elevators. The elevators present a history of New York city's skyline showing inhabitants how things have changed. The view is enhanced by interactive iPads that you can rent for $15 which will tell you what landmarks you are seeing. We did not rent the iPads and just soaked in the incredible views which were truly breathtaking. It's a definite must see that is truly astounding.

An absolute must. This is an absolute must for visitors to NYC. On a clear day the views are nothing short of spectacular. Four states are visible. Everything is well paced and staged. Even the elevator ride up and down was spectacular. Definitely worth the time and ticket price.

Views. Great trip well worth a visit, but a bit pricey for a family, the lift experience is very clever, as is the lobby when you alight the lifts, we visited in the evening and the lights around Manhattan were a sight to behold

A speedy visit to tick off another attraction. Paid express at 11.45 am, there was no need as thmuch queue was minimal, enjoyed the while think despite the usual commercial "photo shoot". Quite a lot of people up there but plenty of opportunity to take in the amazing views .On exiting, the queues were longer and express ticket would have been useful, never mind what's done is done!

Top of the world views!. Worth the cost see the views of the city and beyond. We pre-purchased tickets through a tour of the 9/11 Memorial and visited at about 5 pm. Elevator ride was an unexpected visual surprise of historical information. Although there were quite a few people, observatory didn't seem too crowded. Plenty of space to move around. The views were spectacular......especially with the clear day. Make sure you visit the restaurant bar for a memorable drink. (They have food available as well.) If you can time it, I'm sure the sunset is a spectacular sight. Wish we had made time to see both Observatory and Museum, but we definitely made time to visit the Reflection Pools to offer our respect to the 9-11 victims. Make this a definite visit.

THE best view in town !!!. Visited today and have to say this was our best attraction all weekA brilliant place. The views (on a nice day) were sensational........quite frankly breathtaking and it is just awesomeThat's the word !!! The whole thing is very slick and the attraction hosts very friendly and helpfulThe theatrical way they take you through the attraction is brilliant tooSimply a MUST VISIT
Even the elevator was amazing!. The Observatory is a must-see. All of the employees were friendly and did a great job. . I want to go again just to see the walls of the elevator!

Open late, great views. Finding ourselves in the area we called in to see the memorial and decided to continue into the observatory. Need to go through airport style security before accessing upper levels but worth it. Wonderful views of Manhattan skyline and identification made easier with a rented tablet to point out and explain features. Probably better in the day when buildings are identifiable and cafe is open but still enjoyable. Open fairly late so good for an evening activity when others have finished .

Very impressed! . We bought the priority tickets for the ride up, and I would say it's worth the extra money. We skipped queues at the security checks and elevators, I don't know how much time we saved exactly but I'd guess at least 30-45 mins. Without spoiling anything, the experience starts in the elevator! Once at the top, there is lots of space to wander around, the guides are very friendly and knowledgable. I'd highly recommend renting the iPads so you can get an idea of what your looking at. Highly recommend this to anyone.

Must visit . The new One World Observatory is an amazing building We had pre booked tickets before leaving the UK and went straight in avoiding the queue building up outside Once through all the tight security ( very reassuring ) you enter a corridor which tells the story of it from the workers point of view The lift up is amazing - tells the story of NY over the years and how it was built Before you know it your up on the deck where the views are to die for Make sure you go on a clear day There's the inevitable souvenir shop as in all museums but some goods are reasonably priced If you are only going to visit one building in NY then it has to be this one It dwarfs Empire State and Top of the Rock
One World Observatory . This is my new favourite place to visit, 360° views of this wonderful city, excellent elevator ride too.

great for families. Best time to go is weekday mornings and afternoons, because the crowds are not bad. Kids 5 and under are free, but **NOTE: you need to stop at guest services to get an admission ticket for any kids 5 and under - everyone needs a ticket to get in. It's really an amazing view, and any and all ages will enjoy it. The kids loved seeing the Statue of Liberty. You can spend as much time at the observatory as you want. There is an option to rent an iPad for $15 that will identify everything you look at through the windows, but I don't think this is worth the money.

Amazing experience. Was reluctant to go but decided at the last minute to take my 9 yr old son. It was a very cloudy day and they warned us that there is zero visibility at the bottom before we bought our ticket. Since it was our last day in NYC I didn't care and wanted to have this experience. Last time I skipped the experience I missed out and never got a chance to see the Twin Towers.That said, I don't want to take away the surprise from future visitors so here are a few tips:1. If there is 0 visibility the day you visit, you can still go and get a few peeks if the clouds are moving but best of all the crowds were minimal. We went on a Tuesday afternoon around 5pm and we ran straight to elevator and the whole observation deck had MAYBE 50 people including staff. It was extremely peaceful if you are looking for a more meditative experience rather than viewing all of the skyscrapers.2. Eat before you go. They have food up there (sandwiches, pizza, coffee, etc) but of course very expensive. 3. If anyone in your party has motion sickness or afraid of heights, bring a plastic puke bag. None provided in elevator. I do not advice if anyone has a strong fear of heights. The observatory is enclosed but to pay that much money and have a strong fear may not be worth it. 4. I suspect the best time to go is after 5 pm, Monday - Thursday since all of the workers and early day tourists are gone.5. I can't speak to buying your tickets online but if you are on a tight schedule and have to plan, just know there is a chance of 0 visibility. They will exchange your tickets for another day at the counter.

Must see for all ages. Breathing!!!
Great for all ages !!
It's best to book in advance. It's a great view all times of the day. From sunrise to sunset. Make it a stop at least once a year

Beautiful view!!. Beautiful view, but they need to clean the windows more often you can see the finger prints all over the windows and is hard to take good pictures. Book the late one so you can stay for the sunset and the lights of the city when it gets dark. You will see the three day, sunset and night.

Amazing place to see. it will take 25$ to go observation 102 floor( when u enter in to the list all three side LED display will start. after reaching top you will see entire new york citi and Manhattan, Statue of Liberty
Full of Surprises. Kinda of expensive but worth it. Surprises around every corner and a spectacular view. This is a must

Amazing Views!. I knew this was a must on our first trip to NYC. I thought it was very cool. As everyone says the elevator ride is neat, but they pack you in pretty tight, so you have to really look to get the full effect. Of course, once up at the top the views are amazing. My husband purchased the use of the tablet which shows you what you are looking at when you point it in a direction. They have speakers who are great and you learn alot, yet they are entertaining. My only complaint is the price. I feel it is a little high. especially for a family of four.

The best view yet!!. Loved the view of the whole city and the elevator is too fast the observatory is got you can eat lunch upstairs. What's funny is that when you get their tablet it causes $15 to borrow from them

What an elevator ride!. I know, you go up to look at the city, but the ride up is a stunning piece of technical wizardry. New York grows as you climb and the images are pixel-perfect. View from the top was great....but it was the elevator ride that really blew my mind. Wonder if I could book a ticket just for that?
Summer visit. I was there last December in foggy cloud days I saw nothing today with the clear summer sky I could see New York from the highest floor It is a great building from all aspects

Wonderful View. It is really worth a trip to the Observatory. Interesting short program on the buildings construction, followed by free time to walk around the top of the tower and take in stunning views of the city and the area. We also ate at the restaurant, food was good, view was even better! Great way to see the city.

The best skyline View . Fantastic view of the skyline of New York and more, We went at sunset time and it was absolutely astonishing the view and colours.The time you are there really takes you back to what happened that day. Very emotional

NOT TO BE MISSED. Preferably, visit early in the week when there are less crowds/visitors. On a clear day, you can see for "miles" and the views are magnificent! We visited on a Monday and was able to buy tickets immediately, no wait lines, and go up the smooth elevator. You will visit two floors, so take your time & enjoy. You can "rent" in Ipad that can identify what you are looking at. There are also "very nice docents" that can help and answer questions. Souvenirs are a bit expensive, but some are nice. There are a very few places (benches) to sit. The "cafe" is small but has nice items. The "sit-down" restaurant is not very large, but overall the prices are not that bad for NYC. When you are ready to leave, go down the elevator and visit the "new building". I think it is called the "Occulus" that looks like a "dove with the wings open". This is the new "large & beautiful underground train/subway terminal" with high-end stores coming soon! Will certainly go back next time we visit NY/NJ.

Sometimes the USA gets it right. We visited today with relatives from Italy. We went to show them but we were just as impressed. Very powerful reminder of what happened that day but in a very peaceful way. The tower experience is dramatic on the way up while you're up there and on the elevator ride down. Don't come to NY and not go there.

Great view. Very clever elevator ride up to the observatory and stunning views of Downtown Manhattan await you at the top. If you're looking for overall views of the city then the Empire State Building or Rockefeller Ctr would be a better option - or visit them all if your budget allows!

Not a bad view. The trip on the elevator up was very cool. As it ascends to the observation deck it travels forward in time from the native americans to the present. The view up top was good and had great interactive features.
Amazing views. The pod up to the 102nd floor takes just 37 seconds and views from the top are awesome. Well worth a visit when in New York.

Amazing. This was absolutely terrifying for me, but I fought the fear and went up anyway. It was a beautiful sunny day and we could see for miles and miles. So awesome and amazing. I don't think I would want to go up there again, but I'm glad I did it once. I think this has to be a sunny day activity, so you can fully experience the views, but that's just my opinion.

Truly Amazing!. This was a great adventure. I have been to other observatories and sky decks before, but this one was truly magnificient. Maybe because once you got up to the top it was such a magnificient view. The elevator ride up was fast with an interesting little twist. So great! Once you got up to the top there is a hallway you go down, that was probably the biggest disappointment. You are so ready for those views and as you are walking down the hall they have the windows all covered up. But they didn't disappoint once you got into the main area which is more than one story. They is a beautiful gift shop, restaurant, snack shop and bar. Awesome place, you go down an escalator to get to the views and they do not disappoint. There are people there who give very interesting observations on what this area used to be as compared to what it is today. Very knowledgeable . The lady that did the presentation for us had a PHd in Art History. She knew her stuff. And it was interesting in that you wanted to watch her. Beautiful building A must see!
Awesome!. Having been fortunate to have travelled to the top of the Twin Tower a number of years ago it was an emotional return! Well done New York!!!

Wow. This is a must see if visiting the city. A great experience ! The elevator ride provides a history of NYC in video form from the 1500s to present day. A good distraction from the awesome speed the ride gets you to the 102nd floor

Going Home. Since 9/11, I just couldn't bring myself to go and see Ground Zero, so I put it in the back of my head, for future reference. Years later, My cousin and I went to the site, when the infinity pool with all the names lost in the horror. It was sold, crisp, and silent. No where else, could you hear a needle drop in the middle of Manhattan.Last year the tower was opened and my cousins and I went, a long long line, but we had tickets for a time frame, and went up 103 floors in 43 seconds, we walked out on the top floor to shades hiding all the windows, until all the people holding the time frame we had. Again,silence, until the shades dropped and there was Brooklyn, Manhattan, the Bronx, New Jersey, Queens at our finger tips. The first emotion was to look at the city I grew up in, worked, played and then came tears. You never forget how we got to this place and the meaning of it. The view is spectacular, 360 degrees, and a 'AH' moments when you saw all the areas around the One World Conservatory. I will be taking my husband in August, once is never enough and as a New Yorker and country, WE SHOULD NEVER FORGET WHAT HAPPENED ON THIS SPOT

Breathtaking views!. This is a must visit when in New York! The views are breathtaking. The story is amazing. Watch the 3 minute video. It brings tears to your eyes as you watch the story behind the building. This is truly an American staple.

Cannot beat the views . Great way to kick off our short NYC trip! We opted for the single day flex ticket since we really didn't have much time to waste but knew what day we could go. That was definitely expensive but it allowed us to go right in without any hassle or waiting. Also paid for the tablet add on that identified everything we were viewing which I would suggest getting.

Wow . Beautiful building We had dinner on the 101st floor not cheap but worth it for the views Elevator up is something else very clever but remember if you book restaurant you still have to pay $30 each to get up there !

Great view of the city but not sure it's worth the price. Like most things in New York this is a pricey attraction. It cost around $50 AUD per person which might not sound too bad but other than a great view of the city and surrounds you don't get anything much for your money. They will try to sell you an iPad guide for an extra $15US. It would have been much better if this was included in your ticket price
The best observatory. The higgest building allowing visitors to take many amazing pictures. Fantastic view from the top, the best!

A Beautiful Replacement for the World Trade Center. Wow, do they know how to market things - we chose the priority access, but we went really early on a Saturday, so there was practically no queue so we could have saved a bit, had we gone later it would have been worth it, however at the observatory level we ended up in with the crowds. The elevator journey was really clever and then the initial presentation was fantastic. Standing so close to it though made it difficult to view properly.It got busy very quickly, but not so much that we couldn't get to the windows to take some fabulous photos. Also make sure you watch the presenter in "the Buzz" SO clever and informative! We had some breakfast, it was very nice, if a little pricey, but we were very grateful that they had some nice hot food as well as the sweet stuff! The souvenirs were vast, and they certainly know how to charge for those!! It was a great morning out and would highly recommend it.

There are better views from the centre of Manahatton. The One World Observatory is at the Downtown end of Manhattan. The Empire State Building and the Rockefeller Centre are in Midtown and give all round views of the City.

tis' awesome!. We bought tickets for a Fri.online and didn't have to wait more than 15 min. in line, but it was worth it. I don't know if they give military discounts, which we learned are an option for many places. The 82 second ride was like nothing you've experienced before. No stomach lurch when you stop and the view! They have an IPad that you can use that will tell you what building you are looking at, which was very helpful. Worth the price of admission.

Extraordinary views!!!. It's a bit expensive, and reminded me of being at Disney World, but riding the fastest elevator in the world to the top of a 100+ story building can't be all bad. The presentation on the way up was cool and the views like nothing else around. I could have done without all the extras (pictures for sale, gift shop, etc...) but it was a fun time.

Expensive and gimmicky!. I'd much rather admission price was less than the expensive $37 and cut the gimmicks. In particular the video show where the screen rises to reveal the view, and the circular video display. Great view from the top though, and of course a real credit to the people of New York to have this brand new building.

Unbelievable building and views. We have been to New York 3 times and been up most of the tall buildings that give great views of Manhattan, this one is an amazing experience. Great views, great restaurant also.

Spectacular!. One cannot describe this experience. Unbelievable views! Just go see for yourself! They also have a cool museum store and also take your photo with the skyline in the background. There is a charge for the photo if you choose to get a copy.
New giant. To me the best alternative to the Empie and Top of the Rock. Enjoy unique sightseeing and take amazing pictures (if you succeed leaving selfie-junkies out of your viewfinder's frame).

Trip to the top of new york. Amazing build up. The elevator up sets the tone on the way up! Feel your eyes popping as you go!They have a sort of cinematic type show before letting you through to the 360 degree view room. That's excellent.As you go through they try to sell you some iPad type thing for $15 which shows you which landmark are in your view but if you don't want it you don't have to watch the presentation just fire down the stairs to the view.Unhindered views all around, breathtaking.The shop offers a good selection of memorabilia aswell which is great for gifts. Not too dear either.All and all a fantastic must do experience!!
Emotional. All I can say for this one is WOW! Such an emotional visit but definitely one you have to do! the atmosphere around this place is so special and a feeling a will never get again.

Photography from Deck is terrible. Went to take images from the observation deck. Paid full ticket price (32 dollars for a Senior) and then had to pay another 3 dollar ticket processing fee! Duh why? Elevator ride was interesting as was arrival show.They tried to get us all to rent out an ipad to show the landmarks as you pan round. "like "Sky Guide" app just less cool" for 15 dollars a pad. As a result of this marketing strategy they have not put any info boards up in the actual observation deck. So it is a "pay or guess" system.I have been fortunate enough to have visited most of the "tall observation" decks around the world to take images and without a doubt this is the worse for reflections. From the fancy metal strips around the bottom of the panes to general reflections up the length of them the reflections are very intrusive. Mr World Trade Centre CEO, just pick up the phone to the designer and tell them that they have plain got it wrong.And at the time of my visit (13.00 approx) a lot of the windows had smears and other grubby marks across them that also messed up photo's. The windows had not been cleaned recently, this was not just visitors poking them that morning.Interesting views, just don't go expecting to get photographic "keepers". Manhattan skylines with a trail of sneakers across the middle are sad!
Wow. Went up the lift took 4minutes approx with a journey never to be forgotten at the top 360 deg view make sure you go on a very clear day to get the best views

Well done. You have to purchase timed tickets and it worked out great. No lines. Went straight through security and to the observation level. It's very well designed and the entrance to the observatory is dramatic and breathtaking. Once you've done it, though it's probably not worth a second trip, but a must do at least once.The push an iPad rental for a tour when you get the the top. I didn't do it and it's probably not necessary if you know the area.
Amazing views. On a clear day, amazing views.Nothing to do there other than the vista.On a rainy day, it would be a colossal waste of money.

Disappointed, very commercialized, no mention of 9/11. I have to say, the 9/11 tragedy deeply affected the majority of Americans whether physically or psychologically. We had visited Ground Zero in 2008, the Memorial Pools in 2012 as well as The George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum in Dallas in 2013. So this year, we felt a trip to NYC would not be complete without the experience of seeing a newly built One World Observatory. How disappointed we were to be subjected to the commercialization of the tour! We were expected to move into a photo-taking area to buy souvenir photos at the end, subjected to an uninspiring film about about NYC and the new building addition to NYC, offered a $15 rental of an iPad to review attractions as seen from the top deck, a restaurant, and of course, the gift shop. Not one mention was made of September 9, 2001. Meanwhile, we had purchased priority tickets online in advance, just knowing there would be long lines in June. What a waste of extra dollars spent not to mention the high cost of the lowest priced ticket; there were no lines! Okay, the view of NYC was spectacular on a clear sunny day, but don't expect that clarity every time. The only impressive thing about our visit was the EXIT where we viewed the uncompleted concourses of the building which will have shops and restaurants; it is a very magical design of white contemporary architecture. Plus, a new subway stop inside will be most convenient for workers and tourists alike. In summary, if you have money to burn and simply have nothing else to do in all of NYC, go ahead and waste your time at this attraction. Otherwise, love NY in so many other ways!

Worth the money. The sight is worth the entrance fees.
Awesome 360 view; light lunch at the restaurant, food pretty good!
The elevator ride is fast and interesting!

Impressive. The most technology advanced building that I have ever been into. I work in construction. The elevators are just amazing and so are the views :). The tickets are not cheap - for me and my 12 year daughter it was $68.00. However it was worth it and experience you will never forget.
Wow a must see. Its more then going to the top to see the view of new York city I cant give it away but you will enjoy going to the top

Interesting. Booked this in advance to tie with a 911 Museum visit. Arrived and went in straight away, no queues – this may have been due to the fact many were coming back another day as staff said zero visibility a the top due to the awful weather. We didn’t have the time to return another day so went for it.It was steadily busy at the top and we could move around easily. The views were still great – 360 degree all over the city. Whilst would get a better view on a clearer day it still gave a great overall view all around. There are facts and stories to read around and just being at the top of the Iconic tower built to replace the World trade Centre was incredible feeling. Would tie in with a visit to the 911 museum.

Amazing views - and very slick marketing. Stunning panoramic of NYC, Jersey City and parts beyond. We went on a day with 5 mile visibility - and it was great. Be prepared to shell out extras if you want to know what you are looking at - they offer an interactive screen that you can rent - but no descriptions on the walls, so if you are new to the area, you won't know what you are looking at. Despite being funnelled through a picture taking experience and having to leave via the gift shop, and the steep admission price ($34 per adult), it was a great experience

For a first time NYC visitor, not as cool as ESB. I have been to six different continents, but barely went to New York City for the first time last month. That being said, it allowed for an objective point of view when comparing experiences with One World and the Empire State Building.While high tech (and a cool elevator ride, you'll know it when you ride it), One World lacked the same impact that the Empire State Building had on me. I think what contributed was the inability to go outside and feel the wind in your hair and on your face. That, and the well-oiled tourism moneymaking machine these vista points have become. ESB was bad enough, but One World has it down pat. It's actually faster to buy something from the gift shop to effectively jump the queue on the way back down. The views are great, but enclosed in glass (not as cool).I did appreciate the assigned visiting times. Definitely pre-order to save time.

Amazing views.. This is one of those places that you really are not glad that you are there but you ARE glad. We lost thousands of lives. The views are fabulous and it is a beautiful monument. It is worth going all the way up. Spend some time there. It is a beautiful place.

Pretty cool. Nice experience. Fast elevators. Amazing views. Lots of staff in the observation area to answer questions. We rented an interactive tablet that was supposed to tell you about the landmarks you were seeing. Not worth it to us as we couldn't get it to work.

Has nothing to do with ground zero. Maybe we assumed too much, but this observatory has really nothing to do with ground zero. You could barely see the memorials from up above. It is more of a panaromic view of the city and skyline which is beautiful, but just has nothing to do with ground zero. Keeping that in mind, the views are great. We skipped the $15 iPad rental and felt fine with what we saw. Good to do, but we wouldn't need to do it again.

I took my niece there and she loved it. I had to entertain my 12 year old niece who was visiting from argentina and New York seemed to be a tough place for me... An adult with no experience with kids... Or Tweens. This turned out to be one of her favorite parts of the trip. The views are spectacular, the elevator ride up not to be missed ... Complete with digital screens for walls that take you through a spectacular ride through the history of New York as you go up to the observatory floorOnce there... The staff is so cheerful and informative giving you lots of snippets of facts and trivia about New York. This turned out to be my favorite viewing experience in New York City when compared with the Rockefeller and Empire State

102 stories in 45 seconds. Large observation decks on multiple levels at the top, along with gift shop (of course), bar and restaurant. I went without a ticket or advance reservation on a Saturday afternoon. I could not figure out how to buy a ticket to display on my iPhone. That does not appear to be an option. (And I keep my boarding passes on my iWatch!) Total time from end of the line to the top, 30 minutes, which was not bad.Fairly clear day, so you can see quite a piece. For $15 more you can rent an iPad which has great interactive features. That's especially useful if you are not from New York.The elevators show a film on three walls on the ascent and descent. About $35. More if you go at twilight. More if you rent iPad. You only need one for a group, and they make that clear. Pictures available, along with food, drink and souvenirs.Easy to get to on mass transit. Parking at that end of Manhattan requires a loan application, an 800+ FICO, and references.

Fun and Informative (including elevator ride up). We went early on a Sunday morning in the middle of the summer, and there really wasn't much of a line. We did not need reservations. We just walked up and bought our tickets. You then go downstairs to go through security. After going through security and metal detectors, you weave through what is supposed to look like bedrock. You can tell this is done for when there is a very long line. Thankfully we just walked through. Then, you get to the elevator, and there are guides to get the right number of people on the elevators. Once inside, it's a very cool 360 degree view as you go up of the city being built up around you. It's fun! Once at the top, you have to listen to a short speech about the benefits of buying an iPad. We half considered it, but then we weren't in the mood to wait to buy the iPad. After that, they practically force you to have your souvenir photo taken for purchase later. THEN, you're almost there -- to the overlook. They have a lovely little cafe up there. There were two areas where guides were talking about famous New York sights. We were a family -- all adults. We had a nice time walking around the observatory and spotting what we recognized. I live here in NYC, so I have an advantage of knowing more streets and buildings than many visitors. Definitely recommended for anyone and everyone -- visitors and locals.

Very nice 360 degree enclosed view of the Tri-State area.. We purchased the priority tickets to avoid waiting on line, but at noon on a Tuesday in June, there was no wait and would not have needed the priority tickets. The entire experience is well-designed and first class. It is expensive, but you have to resign yourself to spending some money on a New York visit. The weather was very clear and we could see a great distance. There are plenty of guides to answer questions, or you can pay extra to rent a fancy tablet-computer guide. The building is across the street from the WTC Memorial and 9-11 Museum, so there is a lot to do if you want to spend several hours.
