The queue to the right is marked VIP which is available for an up-charge that is a time saver but a potentially off-putting one. The amount of time you can expect to save will depend on how many people are waiting in the standard ticket queue. Once beyond security, visitors move onward to the passageways that lead to the elevators. Here is where the tedium begins. The passageways are lined in a fake decorative bedrock that is supposed to mimic the bedrock of Manhattan. As the WTC site is on landfill, this is at a minimum misleading. There are video presentations where you will hear stories from the construction workers, some intentionally sentimental. I would have preferred to see a presentation on the process of getting to the executed architectural design. Another video presentation that shows how the WTC view has changed over the years from past to present is on the elevator walls. This is spectacular. When you finally arrive you will be asked to wait. Again. For another video presentation. At this point I wondered if I would ever see the view that I paid for. This presentation had nothing to do with the WTC. It would have seemed a more relevant thing to show to tourists waiting to board a double-decker bus that would take them to see... tourist spots. That final presentation ends in walls moving to reveal the view.The view is fantastic. You won't be disappointed. I resented the process to get to see it. I can't imagine locals will feel differently. I witnessed a few kids having meltdowns and adult tourists loosing their patience.I compared this observation deck to the one at the previous tower as I took in the view. It is completely different. The building is different. The view is different. The city is now different (than it was in 2001). This observation deck, similar to the characterization of today's Times Square - has been Disney-fied.

Amazing!. Worth every penny. They did a great job with this observatory. We lucked out and didn't have to wait in line. Be careful what time you go because it looks like you can be stuck in line for a very long line. I went with two small children and they enjoyed everything. We ended up eating at the restaurant on top, the food was good but the restaurant was not kid friendly. I will definite skip the restaurant in the future if I have my kids with me.

The tallest building in the western hemisphere lives up to the hype. As a "New Yorker", I have mixed emotions about doing the "touristy" stuff like going up to the top of the Empire State building or visiting the Statue of Liberty, so I've been putting off visiting One World Observatory, despite waking up to a view of One World Trade every morning. But a few weeks ago, I found myself waking up extra early with nothing to do, so I decided to stop by and check it out. Lucky for me, I got there at 9:30am on a particularly cold Saturday so there was absolutely no line, all the more reason to go in. And I'm so glad I did. The experience is so much more than just views of Manhattan, which can be stunning on a clear day, or even a gloomy day like that Saturday. I did not know what to expect so I was pleasantly surprised with all the history and visuals leading up to the ascent to the 102nd floor. Everything about the building and the experience feels sleek and modern and beautiful. The images flashing through the screens, the clean lines and architecture, the colors, it makes you feel like you're seeing something new and almost space-like. At one moment I even felt like I was in Disneyland visiting Epcot Center! It was truly awe inspiring. Also, for those who may be uneasy about going up that many flights, the elevator ride is quick and painless. You barely even feel like you're moving and you're entertained the whole way up with images that flash on the sides of the elevator. The entire experience is fantastic, and well worth the $30 bucks (for adults). One thing I would recommend is getting there early so you can move around freely and get better views. I don't know how my experience would have changed had I been forced to enjoy it with a "million" other people at the same time!
don't waste your time. spent 2 hours to take a 20 minute elevator ride to the top. took way too long to get on - even with pre paid tickets

Breathtaking. I'm not one to be easily impressed, let alone have my breath taken away, but that's exactly what happened when I first saw the views from the observation deck on top of One World Trade. The views were incredible and the knowledge of the staff presenting was impeccable - brilliant!

OOh what a view!. My husband took me here the day it opened actually before it opened to the public. We got some preview tickets. Love how they started from ground Zero and goes right up to the top the stories in the elevator - a must do for tourists - and be mesmerized by the view!

The most incredible views of NYC!. As soon as you enter you are able to see how many people have visited and where guests have visited from. There is a behind the scenes look at how the building was constructed before you enter the elevators. The elevators are an attraction in and of themseleves. As you ascend up to the One World Observatory you enjoy a 360 degree timelapse of the city's progression over the past 100 years. On exiting there is a short introduction before the blinds raise and expose one of the most impressive views of the city. There are also restaurants and interactive displays for guests to enjoy.

Great trip for the entire family!. We are a family of 5, kids 14, 12 and 8 years old. I have to say the experience was so enjoyable. The managing group has done everything to make this tour - a journey, an experience, not just a quick view of the city. We so appreciated the tunnel video experience at the base of the building, and the elevator ride up was remarkable. The kids enjoyed the transformation of the city, and the build at the end. The views are of course magnificent. I highly recommend getting the iPad for the complete experience. We only purchased one and shared it, which was plenty. We spent 2 hours up there, I could have stayed longer. The space at the top lends itself to lingering and spending time. We had a snack the restaurant which looked amazing and we only peeked in, as we had other dinner plans.I rarely write a review like this but felt compelled to. I would highly recommend this for any age group or family dynamic, it was that good!

Nice view, bit tacky.. Of course the view is nice, especially on a really cold day, we could see well into the Atlantic Ocean. But we can get this view from other tall buildings in Manhattan or from an airplane,. We went for our 6yr old son, he was impressed to be so high up and to be able to see a few buildings that he was familiar with. The restaurant at the top is a nice way to extend the time there without wading through crowds. Yes overpriced, but the chicken wings were very tasty. We do get herded around the observatory part, and there are a few sales pitches, one for a tablet, and one for a picture which they take without even asking. The glass floor, looking down to the street was tacky, it didn't look real. For someone who enjoys architecture and history this may make a nice stop for a couple hours, otherwise I think there are cheaper options that are just as enjoyable.
America Well Done. What a building, what a monument. Those who created the building should be proud of themselves. Anyone who visits New York must visit. Breath taking

Wow what a place and an amazing view. We hadn't booked this in advance and purchased tickets on the day, it was an organised system and we was soon heading up in the very odd lifts that have screens on all walls showing a show as you went up the lift.The views are very good although people tend to sit on the edge which makes it difficult to get close to get the good photos, From the tower you get a good view of all of the landmarks in new York.We preferred this view to any other in new York that we done.

Overall, good experience! Beautiful views of NY.. We booked tickets online for 5:15 pm on Friday, Feb. 12. We arrived, went right in, through security, and headed to elevators. There were no lines. We were able to go in within 5 minutes. We went to see the sun setting and to view the lights coming on all over the city. It was a beautiful view!! We paid $15 for the interactive ipad, but I would not recommend. Although it looked cool, I did not think it enhanced our visit and we didn't think it was worth the money. We had no issues with getting down in the elevators as others did. We loved our experience and had nothing negative to say. When we went to the Empire State Building a few years ago, it was over 1 1/2 hour wait in long lines and up small stairwells. We also had to wait to leave. It dampened our experience there. We did not have the same experience here. Others have stated they encountered long lines or complained it was cloudy which I would imagine would make the visit negative. Ours was great and I would highly recommend a visit to One World Observatory.

Beautiful Views, beware of what time you go. The ride up was amazing and slightly emotional. Great opening presentation once you reach the top. Lots of beautiful views! Some areas were a little tight for viewing, the bar/restaurant a neat idea but the food court area seemed out of place. Be aware of when you go We went at the beginning of January around 3:00pm and the sun was directly in our eyes so the view of the Statue of Liberty was not the greatest.Overall a unforgettable experience and the buildings architecture amazing.

Great experience. Outstanding morning spent here , the entire set up first class especially the history of the city. The view as expected was out of this world as we had a clear day. A big well done to all the staff who were all very helpful.

Awesome attraction. Done both the museum and memorial before. This time around our son talk us into visiting this new attraction. In short it was one of the highlights of this Valentine's weekend getaway. The elevators by themselves is a very well stage attraction. Get your cameras ready. We did it twice! The view from the observatory was unbelievable, with a bright sunny day. Not to be missed in your visit to NYC.

Birds eye view. Visited with husband and 16 yr old niece. Paid for priority access because I thought you had to stand outside and it was 7 degrees the day we went! Fortunately (and sensibly) they moved lines indoors- but I was still grateful to be able to rockstar passed the queue (probably saved an hour of time which was worth it for us) Cool elevator ride up, but IMO it went TOO fast- you couldn't take it all in. The big view reveal at the top "holding" area was exciting. We went just before sunset to experience the view in day light and as the lights of Manhattan began to twinkle! Coupled our visit with Lady Liberty/Ellis Island, lunch at the historic (and tasty) Fraunces Tavern, and a far too brief walk around the memorial fountains (again 7 degrees) for a nice day in lower Manhattan!

Awesome! . We pre-booked our tickets for this and were not waiting very long on arrival. Wow! The Americans know how to do things with style! The sky pod lift took 60 seconds to get right to the top and the images in the lift are amazing!When you get to the top and the view is unveiled people literally gasped it was so breathtaking! I had goosebumps! Great views and we got some fab pictures.Do not miss an opportunity to experience this!

Breath taking.. I was informed that it was a 'zero visibility' day when I visited...which meant it was a little cloudy and over cast...but decided to still go up. The show inside the lift as it rises is amazing and, yes, you do feel your ears pop with the speed!!There is a show at the top, which is a build-up to the big reveal (I won't spoil it too much!) It was quiet when I visited and I was able to sit and watch the clouds clear to reveal a beautiful New York day! It provides you with an amazing view and is fantastic for getting your bearings in New York...and for you to realise just how far you walk!!The only down side/negative was the 'cafe' at the top. Coffee and a cake were expensive ($16) and were of a poor standard. Save your cash and buy a souvenir instead!

Stunning way to view NYC. $29 per person allows you to access the viewing decks after a short introductory presentation. This is well worth doing, the lift journeys are even interesting (and fast)!The views are spectacular, viewed on a clear day some stunning photos are possible even on a camera phone. There's a restaurant, cafe area and bar and of course a souvenir shop and official photo opportunity. The 360deg floor to ceiling windows mean those photo opportunities are in abundance. We arrived about 09.30 on Friday and queues were light.

Wow, what a view. Well it really is worth doing.First visit since 911. The view is stunning, was lucky it was a nice day.My only criticism was that it's all enclosed, of course a function of the shape of the building, but for me being out in the air would have been nice

Worth the visit! Absolutely a gorgeous view and modern feel.. We chose to visit OWO instead of the ESB and found it to be more modern and offered gorgeous views. There were some people who provided information about the various areas within the NY Skyline. Highly recommend!
Spectacular views. Do not miss this building spectacular views from the top spent a little extra for fast track tickets and was worth it

Bad design and logistics... almost not worth the view. You can get fantastic views from a number of buildings in NYC. I was excited to see and experience this but left very disappointed. I think this *COULD* be great with some changes.- First off, we purchased tickets for 5:45pm. You would think that they would only allow a limited number of people per time slot and that there shouldn't be a long line since everyone reserves a time. We had to wait in line over an hour just to get to the elevators. - The elevator ride up is pretty cool with video screens that look like glass overlooking NYC as it changes from past to present. It's over quickly and you get ushered into a long room with a video screen. After waiting so long to get to the top I really didn't want to watch any digital content on any screens. I'm there for the view! They play some silly video with images of NY which I can see at ground level so that was pointless and boring. Then the screen lifts up to reveal windows and you get your first view (finally!). 3 seconds later the screen lowers and you get to go to the next area.- This next area isn't the Observatory. It's a cafe where you can eat/drink. You are sort of far from the glass windows so you can't really see that well out. You have to go down a flight of stairs and FINALLY get to the observatory.- The view is great from there but the center is filled with a gift shop which I thought was really tacky. I mean normally you get forced to walk through a gift shop on the way out of an attraction, not in the middle of it.- We walked around looking at the skyline from different vantage points until we came to what should be the best sight of all. Looking straight up Long Island. It would be great to get close to the glass and take in that sight from the best angle. Unfortunately, they put this stupid video screen display thing right there and you can't get up close to the windows right there!! Of all the places to put that stupid thing!! They should move that to the gift shop area and move the gift shop downstairs.- Finally after feeling bit cheated out of our money, we went to leave. There was a huge line to get on the elevators to go down. That took another 20 min. When we got up to the elevators, we noticed one wasn't working. The lady said that one is only for special events or something. - Finally to add insult to injury, when we got off the elevator to leave, there wasn't a single person on line to go up. Not 1. Anyone could have just walked in and hopped on an elevator with no wait. Did they only sell tickets with 1 times slot!??Obviously the view is pretty amazing and there's special significance to the Freedom Tower and the ground it stands on. If they could just make some changes to the logistics of getting up there and the layout of floors (like leave the freaking windows un-obstructed!!), it would be a fantastic experience.

All you do is wait in lines. This was the biggest waste of my time. I had an amazing experience at the 9/11 Memorial and Museum, so I wanted to go up One World Trade. They make you purchase the ticket for a specific time, so I figured it would move quickly. I went after peak time and the employee I asked said it would take "about 10 minutes" to get up the elevators. After standing in line for 30 minutes, I finally got in the elevator (which were really cool).Then they make you stand in another line for 5 minutes to force you to watch their video, which alright, but not worth it. Then they make you stand in another line for 5 minutes to take stupid pictures in front of a blue screen.By the time I got to the view, I was pissed, sick and tired of being there, and running late to make it to my later plans. I ended up missing a Broadway show. Then the line to get back down took an additional 20 minutes. Basically, I stood in lines for over 60 minutes, after waiting 3 hours to go at my designated time slot. Some of those lines were unnecessary. Had I known that it would take that long, I would have never gone, but the indication from employees is that it would take less time. Further, the view isn't NEARLY as good the Empire State Building or 30 Rock, which are both a lot easier to get to. That said, this is one of the coolest buildings I've ever seen. I recommend going to it, just don't pay the money and the time to go to the top. TOTALLY not worth it.

Great views, horrible wait. I am not sure what was the point of buying advance tickets for a particular time and then not being able to get to the observatory until one and a half hours later. We purposely scheduled a time when we could view the sunset, but due to the length of the lines were not able to. Tickets should state that there will be a long wait and not a print a time on it. But despite that, the view was everything you could want. However be prepared to wait and if you want the sunset get there hours in advance.

Amazing views. Whilst in New York we decided to give this a go and popped along expecting to have to queue. We arrived and pretty much went straight up. The journey through the building to the lifts was like an Alton towers ride... Music and displays keeping you occupied if there was a queue. Once in the lift the 45 second ride was made amazing by the video projected onto the walls of the lift. Upon exit there was a short video and then the view was revealed which was breath taking. The views from the observation deck are amazing. We went mid morning and we're lucky enough to have great weather and at one point we were higher than the pleasure helicopters!Dinner was a bit prices but you expect that.Overall a brilliant few hours and thoroughly recommended

ok. well, the admission fee kind of expensieve and the view was alright , when you done empire state and the Rock, you will just have enough .. i would rather walk around the memorial ground , but well, its kind of experience

A great experience. Its a great experience. An amazing view. This is something that you have to do if you are in NY. The only bad thing was the long line, we have to wait more than 2 hours to go up. I know it was a long weekend.

Awesome view of Manhattan. Buy your tickets online so you can avoid the long line. Of course there's a security check, but it's quite swift. The elevator brings you in a mere 45-50 secs to the 102nd floor (about). After a short presentation you'll have a fantastic 360 degree view of Manhattan, Staten Island, New Jersey, Brooklyn, etc. Pro's: short line (compared to the Empire State Building), amazing view. Con's: It's all inside (could be a pro as well). Tip: come early so you're not crowded behind the windows.

Worth it for the view. We stumbled upon this attraction by chance. We went downtown for the 9-11 memorial, but getting out of the taxi, we were at the entrance to this observatory. It turned out to be one of the highlights of our stay in New York. As we didn't have much time in the city, we couldn't go to Statue of Liberty and many other sights. But going up the observatory, we managed to catch most sights (at a distance). We were lucky to be able to appreciate them under the glorious weather on a cold February morning but staying warm and comfortable indoors. Should also pay $15 extra for the iPad which gives more details about the landmarks around.

Wonderful view and a great experience. This is another one of those things in NYC that you have to do at least once! It was a great experience. I saw some complaints on posts about the lines, we did spring for the extra $ for the VIP line and by the time we left I was surprised more people were not doing that. The lines were very long. That being said they do seem to keep things moving. The views are amazing as is the information provided by the friendly guides that are there. we did not get the iPad that would help you identify the buildings but watching people with them I would say it is probably worth the $15. Even if you don't have a ton of time pay and skip the lines this is worth it.

Don't miss this!. Booked at WTC1 on Valentine's Day busy but still only an hours wait. A very slick operation. The queues move quickly once you are in and the security is well managed and very impressive. Much tighter than some airports. As you walk through to the elevators the electronic screens give snapshot information from people who have been involved in the construction. The ride up is fantastic and seems so quick. When you come out a screen is raised and you get your first glimpse of the view. Amazing. After that you are free to spend as long as you want there. We did have an iPad which was useful as we didn't know all of the landmarks. We did have a beautiful sunny day so the view was outstanding but we would still say this is an attraction not to miss.

A must see stop. We had advanced reservation for a school group and while our views were obscured due to an overcast day, no doubt the view must be amazing when it is clear and sunny. Even though mother nature didn't cooperate, the elevator ride up and down with the wrap around screen was almost worth the price of admission itself. And once we were up at the observation deck there was a very helpful young lady sharing tons of trivia and facts about the city with our kids. Definitely will have to visit again when the sun is shining more :)

Stunning Views.... but. Architecturally One World Trade Center is a bit of a cop out. It's too utilitarian. In my opinion they could have and should have made a statement with 1WTC. Look at buildings like The Petronas Towers / The Shard / The Burj Khalifa that are unique and memorable. 1WTC looks like another office building.However once you step inside the elevator things start to look up. When you reach the top be prepared to be in awe after watching the presentation on the staggered screen. The views from the observation deck are amazing. Looking down you can't but think of the poor souls that lost their lives almost 15 years ago.All in all though another must see place on your visit to the Big Apple

You really must visit here!. Visiting the observatory is a gamble in the winter. If the weather is bad there is zero visibility and you have to come back another day. If you get a clear day though, the views around Manhattan are incredible. It's a full 360 degree tour with some interesting feature points and information provided as you walk around. I visited at sunset and got some absolutely amazing pictures but I am sure it would be perfect at any other time too.

Time to Wait INFORMATION was nonexistent.. The information regarding your time to wait was terrible. The staff had no clue how long it would take to get up to the top based on your location in line. Once you proceeded through security, there was an additional line that went through some faux granite. It is hard to believe that an attraction of this magnitude would be so poorly operated. Don't misunderstand this review as a complaint on how long it took to get to the top, the staff have no control on how many chose to visit the attraction on a given day. The review is based upon the lack of training the staff has on advising visitors how long of a wait can be anticipated. The actual observation was fantastic, but due to the limited amount of time we had to enjoy it was somewhat disappointing.

Great view from the observatory, but stay away from the restaurant!. My wife and I visited the One World Observatory and booked the restaurant for lunch. While the Observatory itself and the amazing views are well worth the trip, I recommend staying away from the restaurant. Although the waiter was friendly and helpful, the food was mediocre at best. Definitely highly overpriced... The pasta I ordered was cold and it was a rather small portion. Nothing to rave about. Somewhat a pity because it would have made for an excellent visit if it wasn't for the restaurant.

American Obligation. The view of the area was incredible - arguably the best in Manhattan. The building was state of the art. The attraction was professionally and efficiently run. I think every American should visit this as a response to those who believe the American spirit can be destroyed. It was breathtaking.

Good, if you know what you're looking at. We took visiting parents here and it was a good overall experience. The ride up was engaging and informative, and the journey to the top was reminiscent of amusement park queues. Once at the top of the observatory, you get panoramic views in an enclosed setting. Definitely some great views and I enjoyed pointing out areas that we could make out.

February visit. Overall very disappointing. Long line - waited for over an hour and a half. Some of the videos and the elevator were very well done. We booked for 5:00 p.m. to catch the sunset. But what good was that....with the delay we got to the top around 7:00, just in time to see....darkness.

Breathtaking Views. This was one of the most amazing experiences I had while visiting New York. It was worth the $32 dollars and I would recommend it to anyone. They also have a restaurant inside and a gift shop to purchase souvenirs. It was one experience I wont ever forget and I enjoyed it very much.

Have to do it at least once..... I was going to skip the $15 for the I-Pad tutorial....Went back around 15 min. later and got one....I thought it was worth it, without it you just wander around not really knowing what is what unless you are a local..... It was also worth 10 min. to sit and listen to the live presentation-City Scape, I think....

Awesome observatory. This observatory is very well done! It offers a 360 degree view of NYC from lower Manhattan. You won't feel crowded by other people, as there is ample room to walk around and take your time seeing everything. There is even a cafe where you can grab a bite to eat. If you're looking for any type of 9/11 mentions, you won't really find it here. You can see the original footprints of the twin towers and there is a memorial museum nearby. Other than that this is purely a way to see for miles from 102 stories up. PS Right now, there's a discount for Mastercard holders on Mondays.

Amazing!. To write a review would ruin the experience I think, so instead, all I can say is that if you are on a trip to New York, you really won't be disappointed with a visit to here. A 360o panoramic view from 1783 feet up. The elevator ride up alone is an experience. Just go. You'll be glad you did.

Amazing view! . Amazing view of NY! Even better because everything is indoors (unlike at the Empire State), which is a plus because it is winter when we visited. My 4 year old daughter loved it and was so interested in what she saw. She thinks that the elevators were so cool too!

Fantastic. We booked the date night offer which included prosecco and chocolate truffles. Was great visit, hardly any queue, visited around 5pm which meant we got to see the sunset, and after our drinks in the bar area got to then see the city lit up at night. All this following seeing the memorial area. Well worth a visit.
Amazing. Amazing from start to finish, from the elevator ride to the best most amazing views of Manhattan and the surrounding Burroughs. If you only visit one place on your trip make it this!
Nyc vaca. Was quite amazing going up and down in the elevator. Beautiful sites once you get to the top. You can see everything for miles. Elevator took seconds to climb over 100 stories

A View To Your Heart. Bought our tickets on line ahead of time..No Waiting in lines..Went in February during the "quiet" tourist season. Had 4 PM "elevator" ride scheduled..So much more...Fastest, highest, non stop ride..With cool info graphics and pics on elevator walls about NYC and the WTC..Made the ride smooth for those that get nervous..Once up to the sky top, the 360 views were just crazy beautiful. We did late day to see the day views and watch the sun set. Passionate tour guides man stations around the view floor and share lots of cool and interesting facts about...well...everything, the city, the sites, the building, the recovery..While no one actually goes in to detail about those bastards that attacked the Trade Center, you can not and should not forget,why this new building is here in the first place., We stayed for about an hour and 15 min then headed up stairs to the restaurant. Pretty cool having dinner on the 115 th floor, watching the sunset, having a glass of wine and sharing history with your kids. From great tragedy comes great courage. One should always remember, especially international visitors, that this building is a big FU to the cowards that knocked down the old ones.
Awful. Staff badly misrepresented the time it would take to get through the lines. Worse than Disney. Claustrophobic circuitous route through faux granite took forever to navigate.

So much better than the Empire State building. We bought tickets on my phone 5 minutes before we walked over to the hotel. Did not wait even a minute to go up. No lines and so perfect. Watch the elevator walls as you go up. The movie before you go in was super cool for the kids. Definitely get the iPad for $15. Super great to point to landmarks and see a quick video about it. We spent a lot of time up top walking around and watching the videos with our 7, 8 and 13 year olds.Ate lunch in the quick cafe. FYI - only tables no chairs

The Most Outstanding View of Manhattan. A tribute for the twins and an outstanding and memorable view of Manhattan. you can see the statue of liberty, elly island, and see and incredible perspective of Manhattan skyline.

Amazing. The views take your breath away. From the time you walk in the lifts to the time you leave you will be amazed. The whole experience is breathtaking. I also ate in the restaurant whilst watching the sunset over Manhattan. The food was fairly priced and good quality. The staff are friendly. It is definitely a must if you are visiting New York. I also took the chance to visit the 9/11 Museum. It is heartbreaking to see pictures of all those that lost their lives but it is also very peaceful. I would recommend visiting this as well

Great views, but could be a better experience.. This is the observatory everyone has been waiting for, but did it live up to the hype?The observatory has its own entry on the West Street side of the building. Tickets can be purchased inside, or you can buy them in advance online. Entries are timed every 15 minutes, but you can stay as long as you want once inside. Tickets are $32 each.You initially take an escalator down to the main entrance where they'll scan your ticket and you will have to go through a security checkpoint similar to TSA at the airport, but you get to keep your shoes on. Just beyond security is a huge wall map with ever-changing stats on the amount of visitors and miles travelled to get there, as well as a live indicator of where those entering hail from. From there you walk through a corridor of stone acknowledging the bedrock of the building's foundation. There are some factoids projected on some of the rocks, but they only stay on for a little while, then fade away. That's fine if you're waiting in a long slow line, but not when it's moving quickly (as ours was). If you stop to wait for it to appear again you hold up the whole line.Next, you're directed into your elevator to take you to the observatory. Three of the elevator's walls are floor to ceiling monitors that show a digital depiction of the evolution of the neighboring area. This is well done, but the elevator ride is just too quick to truly appreciate it. Stepping off the elevator you are guided to a narrow but wide corridor where a brief welcome video is projected on the wall. At the end of it the wall lifts up in sections to reveal the view of the city below.Your next stop is going to be a sales pitch that you're stuck listening to. They have iPads you can rent for $15.00 that are calibrated with the view from wherever you're standing and you can learn more about items in that view by touching them on the screen. It's pretty clever and can be useful if you're not familiar with New York City.Now you finally get to go to the 360 degree observation deck view, but not without taking the obligatory picture-for-purchase first.The views are amazing, including several states, 8 bridges and almost all of Manhattan. It seemed a little hazy when we went, but "...on a clear day you can see forever...". It's a bit surreal when you think about just how high in the air you are.At the north and south sides there are rings of 'City Pulse' television monitors (that kind of resemble a stargate). Employees will periodically do presentations within these rings discussing some of what you're seeing. Somewhat interesting.One big negative when taking photos is that there is often a reflection and/or glare in the windows, so frame your shots accordingly.There's an elevated platform called a "Skyportal" where you stand on a glass floor over support beams with more television monitors underneath with a video of the traffic below. Unfortunately, it's just a video and isn't even remotely comparable to the Willis Tower Skydeck in Chicago.There's a restaurant and café up one floor where you can grab a quick snack or a nice, sit-down meal. Expect to pay higher prices than normal because you're a captive audience with one of the best views in town.Of course, there's a gift shop with expectedly overpriced souvenirs you'll pass through before you can head back down so be prepared.The elevator ride down has more cool images on the walls, but the ride is just too quick.Having also been to the Empire State Building as well as Top of the Rock (Rockefeller Center), I was a bit disappointed here. The other two have quite a bit of information about their construction and history, as well as outdoor observation decks, but this does not. I think most of that is reserved for the 9/11 memorial and museum (both must-dos). Also, if you have to choose between only one of the three, ask yourself what you want to see and experience. This is the most expensive of the three and, because you're standing in the Freedom Tower, you won't be able to get a picture of the Freedom Tower in the skyline.

Amazing Views. Rising like a phoenix, One World Observatory-World Trade Center, is a fitting memorial and reminder of 9/11. The views are 360 degrees and amazing. Make sure to buy your tickets online before you get there so that you don't have to wait in a line.

Brilliant experience, and a great view of NYC. We have done Top of the Rock on a previous visit and so wanted to try this, am so glad I did as it was a really great view of NYC and so different from the TOTR. Great, friendly staff, interesting facts, and opportunity for some fab pics.

Worth a visit, but not comparable to Empire State Building. The opening of the One World Observatory was much awaited, but now that it has opened, it leaves a bit to be desired. Obviously, being close to the southern tip of Manhattan, there are many sites that can be seen here much better than from either Empire State Building or the Top of the Rock; the entire New York Harbor can be seen splendidly, as can the Statue of Liberty, Ellis lsland, Staten lsland, the Verrazano Narrows Bridge, South Brooklyn, and Jersey City, New Jersey. Lower Manhattan is seen in great detail. lt is on the 102nd floor, compared to the 86th floor for the main observation deck in ESB (where access to the 102nd floor can be gained for a separate, additional fee), and the 70th at TotR. But the view is seen through thick reflecting glass windows, which a bit hampers visibility, while the two others are outside. Moreover, admittance is according to a time slot given on payment of the entry ticket, like in the Top of the Rock, and this time slot can be even three hours from payment time; paying even a much higher entry fee on top of the already high fee - basically, a bribe - enables speeded-up entry. This stands in stark contrast to Empire State Building, where first come is first served; both times that this reviewer was there in the last few years - on beautiful days in August and in September, the height of the tourist season - he accessed the observatory within 40 minutes. After 85 years, ESB is still the best observation place in New York City; but the OWO is worth a visit at least once.

Amazing memorial . This was humbling. The One World Trade Center is a beautiful building. I stood in awe in front of it and between the two memorials where the World Trade Centers used to stand...just couldn't imagine being there when they fell. I tried to picture the chaos, the heartache, the bravery and it really was overwhelming.

Awesome!!. Absolutely amazing, a must do in New York. We went in February and booked our ticket to enter at 14.00, absolutely no queue at all. When you get to the observatory use in conjunction with Google maps to help you get your bearings.

Best View of NYC!. This is by far the best view of the city. You have a 360 degree view from the deck and you can see all the best sights of New York City from here.The view is just simply breathtaking, and no words can describe it.This is a must for any visit to the Big Apple.Little tip: Make sure you have the video recorder ready for the elevator/lift, both going up and down. Secondly, get your camera ready for when you first get onto the observation deck and the show completes.

Awesome view from the south over Manhattan. The elevator ride up and down is awesome! It takes only about a minute to go up an down, and even if you are afraid of elevators, the big screens around you will make time fly even faster.On the way up the history of New York is shown in a time lapse until the door opens in 2015. On the way down it looked like the construction of One World Center. Incredible. The view is breathtaking! We went up at night and had a lovely time taking pictures of New Work at night.

THE PRINCE of NEW YORK CITY. 104 floors, 541 meters high and 3.9 billion dollars. The One World Trade Center is the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere and the 4th in the world. Built next to Twin Towers area, it's the new icon and pride of New York City. It's height in feet is 1776, the same number than the signature year of the United States Declaration of Independence. Atop the One World Observatory offers amazing views from the 102 floor for 32$.

Good view. There were no queues when I visited here 9am on a weekday in January, was not too impressed when I got short changed of $10 at the ticket desk, but luckily I noticed and pointed it out. Good views on a clear day but the glass has reflections on it which may impair photos. Also not many people here when I visited. Best to visit on a clear day!

highest point. We had decided that this was a definite being the highest point in New York. We had booked online and had priority tickets which meant no queuing and also gave us priority for getting into the lifts which was definitely worth it. The lift is the beginning of a great experience, everything is well organised.Great surprise at the top reveals a truly incredible view of New York. We went in the evening to see the city at night chose dusk to dark really beautiful !There are bits to do up there as well, question and answer area, gift shop and it is quite spacious

The Rising - an awesome experience. Visited New York in December 2009 & went to the Twin Towers site which was then a hole in the ground to pay our respects. In January 2016 we returned and as Bruce Springsteen said "come on up for the Rising....". We arrived at the One World Tower one hour before our designated time slot, spoke to the guides who said to go right in. After moving quickly through the security area we were ushered into a lift and sent hurtling up to the observatory. The lift experience is amazing as was the whole time spent at the observatory level. It was a beautiful day and we had fantastic views of Manhattan & beyond; the staff were so helpful and one lovely lady staff member even took photos of me and my wife. We've been up the Empire State Building & The Rockefeller Tower on previous visits to NYC and they were fantastic experiences but they are nothing compared to the One World Observatory - even the return journey down in the lift was amazing.

Amazing Experience, must see!!. We did the One World Observatory tour - "See Forever", and I must say it's great.I would recommend this to anyone who visits New York.It's affordable and is organised incredibly well, giving good detail of the building and its design and the views are cool, you see Manhattan from Downtown, which is brilliant.Must see

Amazing views and interesting presentation of how the New York Skyline came to be. The view was the top was amazing, but I think I was most impressed by the elevator ride to the top. Be sure to pay attention on the ride up. And once you get up there, be sure to see all sides because the view from each side of the building is different. You can really take in all of the landmarks we all know from the city. One other cool feature is the camera that points straight down so you can see what is happening below you - don't miss it!

Great views. We have seen the tower being built over the years and it great to finally get to go up to the observatory. The views are great. There is a gift shop and periodic talks on the tower and its surroundings. The cost was $29 each, you can also hire an ipad to explain what sights are visible. Have your cameras ready when you first get in the lift to go up, and back down. The walls of the lift are actually video screens. Cover your eyes if you don't like heights ! Well worth a visit.

Awe Inspiring. You cannot visit New York without taking a trip up One World. It was the most wonderful experience of our stay. Rising from the grounds of where The World Trade Centres stood, it is a very emotional testimony to how NYC recovered and triumphed over the evil that took place on 911. You will be moved to tears watching the video clips of the 100s of workers who participated in the build and the explanation of the proud story of how they overcame hurricanes, floods and all sorts to create this incredible structure. And then there's the views! Wow! The best part is you can stay up there as long as you like and the 360 degree viewing deck offers every aspect of NYC - truly awe inspiring. Don't miss out.

very expensive -- there are cheaper options. Long lines, expensive tickets and not that great. the views were nice, of course, but there was none of the charm that you get from the Empire State Building. I'd skip it.

the best views in the city. We had a last minute trip to NYC and i wanted to see the skyline. As this new building is the highest, it was my obvious choice. the weather was great, clear but very cold. There was a 2 hour queue outside but i'd prepaid and booked our slot so we went right in. I strongly suggest you do this, its an extra $20 each I think but since you want to cram as much into your time here as possible (there is so much to do) that i think its worth it. Also the door where you queue is in the shade so it was very, very cold there. The security is good too with the standard airport metal detectors so we felt very safe. There are lots of branded merchandise for you to buy and a cafe at the top but we didn't stay long enough to go there.
Fantastic view!. We were there at night, and we had a very nice view of New York, you saw all the lights and it was awesome!

Worth the money, amazing elevator and view!. We enjoyed this a loot, watching all the way around NYC. Nice staff. A must in NYC! Not over crowded. - No place to sit to have coffee just standing by the tables, the restaurant was really expensive.

The classic 'tall building viewing platform' reinvented. One World Observatory is now a must-see if you're going to New York according to the advertising blurb, but it's hard to disagree with that: its builders have taken the traditional viewing platform and brought it right into the 21st century with a clever use of technology.Worth saying we didn't pre-purchase tickets or spend a long time in line waiting for one - and this was 11am on a Saturday morning - so don't feel compelled to committing yourself to a day/time in advance then finding out the weather's rubbish and compromising your view, and tickets aren't transferable.People with vertigo/a fear of heights shouldn't be deterred from going up the building: you don't see the outside world during the astonisingly fast lift ride to the top (with a digitally-animated history of the New York skyline playing around the elevator's four walls instead). This was nothing compared to the attraction's pre-show, however, which I won't ruin - suffice to say, tech is used here to create a dramatic reveal that had several people in our group gasp in amazement.The observatory itself is a full 360-degree viewing platform, and very, very spacious - meaning you're never pressed up against the glass or without a decent vantage point. Not many people in our group spent the $15 on the tablets to pick out landmarks on the horizon; to be honest, the guides giving presentations at regular intervals on the viewing platform were happy to field any questions.Once you're done at the top, it's straight back down with another lift show; not quite as impressive as the ride up but different nonetheless.This is a great attraction, and a real boost to the New York tourist offering - while tickets are not cheap at $32 each, it's definitely worth a visit.

Great views from lower Manhattan. The elevator ride to the top is fast and also shows cool images on the walls. I won't spoil it, but right after the introductory movie, something cool happens! A circular observation deck offers views in every direction, especially good for the lower Manhattan sites. We rented the iPad ($15) and it names all of the major sites that you'll see, plus offers video of some of them. Pretty cool. Pick a time that you want to visit & purchase tickets ahead of time. Lines were long to get in (on a Sunday morning) & it's also more expensive.

NYC at its Finest, Breathtaking!. A native NY'er, I have gone twice, once in the day, once at sundown, friend visiting from Lithuania, and son. You can see it all, 360 view from the 102nd floor. A view of NYC multiple Boroughs and New Jersey the Atlantic Ocean, Ny Harbor looks amazing with Lady Liberty and if you go a at sundown the View over NJ is breathtaking. This building is a modern Marvel and the story told and you begin your journey through the bedrock is educational and a testament to the resilience of NY'ers and Americans alike. The view of Downtown alone with make your visit worth while!. The Elevator Ride, amazing video history lesson, must see!

Amazing attraction with a sympathetic slant. The last time we were in New York, we made the point to visit ground zero. Broke our hearts having been working for a company with business links to numerous companies in the Twin Towers. Returned to Manhattan in November 2015 and for a long overdue visit. Thoughts we should take in the World Trade Centre. What a visit, what an attraction and hats off to all those who have created such a marvel with enormous sympathy. The whole visit was a delight from start to finish. Take in the bar. Awesome service and views that take your breath away. Tip: pay a little more for the VIP ticket.

The view and the history of the building were wonderful. My son and I went on a clear Sat afternoon it was inspirational and fantastic! We had lunch at One dine and the food, service and magnifcent veiw just could not be matched.

If you chose only one tall building to go up, make it this one!. Not only do you have the best views through a full unobstructed glass observation deck but you also have the emotional experience of the history of the site.there is a restaurant and café to keep you comfortable because you will be here for at least an hour or two. I would recommend the ipad interactive experience. They were doing two for one at $15 when we were there.Tip.. pick clear day and go up either side of sunset.

Marketed place but others are better. Proximity of water and bridges gives a perfect mood especially when night is on. Even the view was great, especiially when we were there - right before sunset, during sunset and after it, I was previously at Empire State Building and Top of the Rock and real feeling of air and no glass between you and landscape give more excitement. In my case all those marketing issues - show etc was unnecessary because I would more love those 10 minutes view of NY and NJ in sunlight. And without reservation we could not get the table at restaurant on top.

The best Observatory in New York. We've been in February, so we did not have to wait long time in the Que.Yet it seems they are well organize to handle large amount of visitors. At the cashier they informed us about visibility conditions so we could decide wether to enter or not.The experience starts at the elevator with the video that scans the history of NY, it continues with short impressive show at the entrance theater. Then The view is magnificent.Highly recommended.

Top of the World--Done Right!. Start to finish, this is an awesome family experience. Awesome 360 degree views of NYC, Hudson River, iconic sites (Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, ferries, lower Manhattan neighborhoods, and of course the Skyportal with it's virtual view of the busy streets below. The 47 second elevator ride is unforgettable. The available video viewer is a good value and very helpful to identify and zoom in and learn more about important sights all around you. Lots to see and do 102 floors above the street plus reasonably priced food options and a souvenir shop. The staff is friendly and helpful. Definite must-see when in NYC.

Mesmerizing!. Nothing I can write can do it justice. It is an engineering marvel. A magnificent edifice. I highly recommend a visit to the One World Observatory. It is an experience you will not forget. Breathtaking.

Obviously a great view, but ruined a bit by gimmicks. I went for the view of New York which I got, but found the gimmicks there a bit annoying. Too many touristy and expensive things people were trying to sell..

Didn't expected it to be so "Wow". 1992 I visited the World Trade Center. Could the One World be as good or maybe better? It was such a touching experience to be there. its an amazing, well done adventure. The view was spectacular, the media show in the elevator excellent. Loved it! its a "must do", while visiting NY
Very well done. This was exceptionally well done and worth a visit if in the area. A lot of thought obviously went into the observatory.

Ignore the unorganised queues views worth it. Although we had booked, they were running late , for the Americans it was very unorganised . However once in the views from the top were stunning . The restaurant at the top was lovely . Great to see the sunset as we had Dinner

Stunning all round views. Do not visit NYC without taking a trip up the one world observatory. Everything from the high speed lift which has a display showing the development of the city from the first settlers to present day as you rise to the fab views that greet you after the reveal.

Amazing experience. Visited here in February. We had done both the Empire State and the Rockerfeller centre so we were not sure what we would gain from this experience. How wrong our expectations were. The experience was amazing and I won't spoil it for those that haven't been but it is well worth doing. We booked tickets for 4.30 ish so that we could get the best of both day light, then as the sun set over the Hudson river we watched the dramatic changing sky. We then sat sipping Prosecco in the bar watching New York bathed in light. It was magical.

Best view in NYC. I was really looking forward to this and it didn't disappoint. It feels like you're higher than you are and the view is just amazing. They also give you a tablet to carry round with you that identifies historical land marks and points of interest as you walk around. Worth the extra money. Can't remember how much it was though. Little cafe and a bar/restaurant up there too. The elevator ride up is good too!

Amazing use of technology. There was no queue and going through security was easy and then the technology starts. The elevators travel at 23 miles an hour and the walls become a screen showing the history and height of buildings as your ears pop. Then you line up to enter a corridor with an amazing montage of New York and then the screens rise and you are just staring right over the city of New York. The viewing deck is 360 degrees and although they offer an interactive ipad rental for $15 you don't really need it. Just ask one of the helpful staff members. It isn't sentimental or poignant that is all in the Museum to 9/11 but why are the souvenirs so outrageously priced. It just isn't necessary and virtually nobody was leaving with having purchased from the store. So glad we did it even at the rather expensive $32 per adult. There is a beautiful looking restaurant but didn't investigate the prices but if you have the time there isn't a rush to enjoy the experience.

GREAT VALUE. Visited on a Beautiful sunny Sunday in February! Went early ish about 10am , no queue, it's all very well thought out and is a pleasurable experience ! There is a cafe and restaurant if you go a bit later ask about lunch you don't always need a reservation, check around for all inc ticket prices it is included in some bus / boat tours ! 102 floors in under 60 secs is amazing !!
The Reason We Came To NYC. Thankfully our wait in line wasn't too long. However the wait is very much worth it when you get to the top. The views are spectacular.

Great observatory where you can see all of New York, and most of New Jersey.. The One World is a terrific experience. From the time you get onto the elevator until the time you get off, this is a great experience. The only reason I did not rate it a "5" is that it is very commercialized and they tend to "sell"in several different areas.

Good - It's a new one on the check list. I wouldn't go here again, but it's been a good few years since I've been to New York and so this is a new check mark on the 'things to do'.It's good to go, but probably wouldn't bother again. On a good day it's great to view of the city from a different view of the Rock or the Empire.Price not too bad. The three of us stayed to have a bite to eat and a drink. Impressed that the prices were not a rip off levels.

Impressive organisation of visitors!. We booked this as part of our visit to New York and bought tickets before we went. We had a time on the, and found the organising of the queues was very well executed. The views from the top of the building are amazing and we had superb weather so could see for miles. Well worth visiting and a beautiful building.

Get drinks at the bar, sit down and enjoy the view!. This was the third of the three buildings we went up and very different to the Empire State and Top of the Rock. We did various other things there, such as the seeing the 9/11 Memorial and taking the Tribute Tour, so it wasn't just the tower. We booked in advance and were given a time slot but changed it without any fuss from the ticket office staff, when the weather wasn’t looking good. There's still quite a bit under construction around the Trade Centre but One World Trade Center is complete and very impressive. A very fast elevator takes you to the top, where you can walk all the way around and get some fantastic views. Not as good as the other two tall buildings for photographs, as you have to take through the glass (there's no outdoor deck) and it's difficult to avoid reflections. There are staff who are doing talks and presentations you can watch/ listen to and you can stay up there in relative comfort for some time. What we liked though was going into the Bar/ Dining Room (you should book if you want to eat but it won't be cheap), ordering drinks and watching the sunset. Very civilized! Recommended.

Fantastic views. From the min u walk in til u leave it's just such a beautiful place. All staff are super friendly. Only annoying thing was the buggy situation having to put it down in the lifts. But understandable. My kids loved the lift amazing to see it all over the years where it started to now. Fantastic. We had no idea what was going to happen next whilst in the theatre room. We were gob smacked when the blinds opened. Breathtaking. Wish I filmed it. And next time I'm gonna go to the front n film it lol. Was a great surprise. As we had a buggy a lovely gentleman took us to a staff lift bless his heart. And also took us to get out photos taken no queues. We felt like VIP. We really appreciate that. With two young kids u know how it can be in queues. The views are insane here. Can't wait to return. Defo one of my favourites things to do in NYC. See u in December.
just amazing. out of all the sky scrappers that we went to the top of this is the best- the lift is amazing- the views are spectacular

Sight seeing.. Oh this was the most amazing sight to see from going up in the lift to the sights of New York from above. We were lucky to see the sun setting from here. A beautiful sight. Worth the price..words arent enough to describe this experieance.

Brilliant visit. Amazing. The views are spectacular. The ride to the top fabulous. We have been to the Empire State and Top of the Rock. All amazing views but One World is different. It's much more relaxed, it's warm and cozy. A restaurant and coffee shop to relax in. Interesting talks going on. We spent over 2 hours there and would love to go back

Great 360 degree views. Great experience at One World Observatory. We hired the tablets to identify the areas viewed but I don't think they were really necessary. You can walk round the full 360 degrees so you can see in every direction.Just to add, the memorial waterfalls outside are very tastefully done....very poignant.

Outstanding view. It was a great experience but a little pricey, especially for a family. Then they wanted another $15 to use the pad for an explanation of the different buildings. We listened to the young men who gave a narrAtive about differEnt sections of the city.

Great view plus best elevator experience. We were there on Sunday in January and it was not overcrowded so you don't need to book it in advance. Good time is to be there for sunset and then stay for dark.The elevator up to the view offer truly amazing and previously unseen experience. Enjoy the view of NY in time from different perspective...In the restaurant upwards, definitely try the Bronx Brewery Beer, I consider it one of the best local beers.

Great View of NYC!. Loved my visit to the top of One World Observatory! Great views of Manhattan. The elevator ride was entertaining, emotion to know we can rebuild, so proud of New York for this accomplishment.
A fantastic point to view almost the hole city.. A must to visit point. You have the opportunity to visit also the simulator, wich is an experience on its own.

Wow. Having already been previously to Empire State Building and Top of the Rock, my son and I decided to go to one world observatory this trip to NY. We decided to follow others' advice about going near sunset which turned out to be a great choice. We reserved on line without any difficulty choosing 30 min before sunset. Compared to the other choices, it was reasonably priced. Anyway, we arrived on an overcast day approximately five minutes before our scheduled time. We quickly went through security and onto the elevator for a fast, neat ride to the top. The neatest thing about the observation deck particularly compared to the other viewing attractions is that it was spacious, relaxed...you didn't feel like lemmings packed in to the area. Other than not being able to see Central Park, the view was better than the others because there were fewer competing buildings and you can easily see the different neighborhoods and connections to the city. They also had guides who gave you interesting tidbits on NY. We did not rent the iPad's per the other recommendations of previous travelers. Might not be a bad idea if you had never been to NYC.It was particularly neat to see NYC before the daylight left and then to see it after the light was gone and the city lights emerged. We never felt rushed and there were plenty of places to comfortably sit. We were able to see NYC in two completely different worlds for only one price. Would definitely return and my highest recommendation for this attraction

Great Experience at One World Observatory. The experience my wife and I had at the One World Observatory - World Trade Center was excellent. You can eventually see the entire city of New York. The only problem we had was that as you try to record a scene or scenes with your video camera due to the sun's reflections you often get a reflection of yourself or others. The only other issue I feel should be discussed is the cost for souvenirs. Too expensive.

Outstanding Attraction. Bought the Day Flex priority VIP expedited tickets but because it was off-season, didn't really need them as the line was short or pretty much non-existent. But the experience was so worth it! The main observatory was amazing and offers stunning views of the entire city and beyond. Easy to photograph views without the glare that we experienced at the Top of the Rock. The One World Explorer was also incredible---it was an iPad companion that brought up-close in an interactive sight and sound experience the specific view or site that you are currently exploring.

Omg amazeballs . We visited yesterday and we were absolutely blown away! The staff are all incredible, professional and super chirpy, really made the experience for us. Great job and a fantastic thing to see.
See it on a sunny day!. We were fortunate to have a sunny afternoon when we visited. Spectacular views. Loved the elevator ride! What an introduction to the views!
Wow!. This is a real wow-experience. I don't want to ruin the experience by explaining it to anyone, but I truly recommend everyone t go here at least one time in your life. Really cool!
no 1.. A super experience, the view is amazing, you just want to spend hours there to admire the view and all the people walking below.

Top of the world. The view are amazing. They say in clear days you can see as far as Connecticut (I don't think so but it's a nice idea) and if you have some time to spend in the observatory you can listen to the stories the guides are telling out loud (each one has different stories about the history of New York city so it is a great experience over all.

Wow. This is an absolute must if you come to NYC.The views are just amazing and they've really made it an experience to visit. You get much more for your money than just the views. Shops, restaurants and live speakers are all at the top. You could spend a few hours here easily! DO THIS NOW IF YOU ARE IN NYC!

Triumphant and Inspired. We visited the New WTC to open the door to a new experience although bittersweet we felt triumphant and inspired. The staff were amazing, the VIP pass was worth the $$ and the complex amazing. Definitely a New York must see.

Not to be missed!. Four of us visited One World Observatory on the 4th February, we would like to urge anyone who visits New York to make sure they take the trip up to the observation deck, it's a must! We have visited wonders of this world and been up many buildings and seen many views but this experience is by far the best of our lives. It's certainly on another level, the technology and the views are like nothing you have ever seen before and of course the emotion of what One World Trade Centre stands for. This along with the 9/11 Memorial can be a life changing experience.Please don't miss this it is breathtaking!
The view. If you like great views it's a must. 102 floors up ear popping so go for it. The lift ride is pretty cool on its own.

Brilliantly amazing views. Well worth a visit as you get to see the city, and further a field so clearly - only go if the weather is clear. You start in the basement surrounded by the rock that makes part of the foundations. Lifts take you to 102nd floor where you watch a 2 minute video, watch out for the subway train, it made me jump. Then out to see the views. You are forced through a photo wall where staff take pictures of you that you can buy later, don't bother just take a selfie. You can also rent an iPad which will talk you though the top skyline buildings. The views are brilliant and there is no limit to how long you can spend up there. The lift up and down is also a treat. Make sure you have plenty of memory on your camera.

Very well done. We had tickets booked 6 months in advance but when the day came around you could barely see the tops of buildings. When we got to the Observatory the guides informed us we could switch our tickets for another day as the visibility was set at zero. We saw some people go up but we're very glad we waited. The museum at the start is very interesting and the way the view is presented to you at first is beautiful.

WOW. What a view not to be missed. A must on your visit we had no queues went before 10am The reveal is amazing there is a cafe. There lots of benches to sit and enjoy the view lifts are smooth and quick

Blown away by the initial observation deck presentation!. We loved the One World Observatory. The Initial video presentation is out of this world and a lot of thought and work has gone into making this observation deck the best in the world. Highly recommend this attraction

Top of the World!. Having visited the Empire State Building and the Top of the Rock at the Rockefeller Centre, we decided to visit here last of all and this was by far the most impressive. Transported in an elevator 102 floors up in less than a minute we were wisked up to firstly view a presentation about the construction of the new tower before entering the observation deck which was quite simply breathtaking.We visited during the daytime. It was a clear day and the views were stunning and looking down 100+ floors down at the cars below was incredible! The observation deck covered every angle of the City and I would run out of superlatives to describe this attraction! Definitely worth a visit....I could've stayed there all day!!!

You have to see this!!!! (even if you've lived in NY all your life). My son and his girlfriend came in from North Carolina and we wanted to do something special. We thought about going to the NY to see the sights. My husband had been getting these pop-ups about OWTC and I was devastated that I had never been to visit the Twin towers. * we purchased a family package for $99.00 for 4 of us* We traveled in on the LIRR and then the E train down town and walked 2 city blocks. The view was breath taking from the outside. This Building is spectacular!!! Until you have seen it in person. You don't what you are missing! There are surprises that make you feel so lucky that you have made this trip!!! Don't miss this!!!

Now the highest view in the land. I was happy to be able to watch them place the top spire on this building (from the Empire State Building) in 2013 and now it is open. You start out below ground, reading some history and watching vignettes of workers talking about the building then you walk through bedrock to get to more video and then the elevator. The elevator ride (look for it on YouTube) is worth the price of admission right there. You are brought up to the top where you can rent an iPad with an interactive map of what you are seeing out the windows. There is also access to an eatery up there. As they say, on a clear day you can see forever. It is a bit disappointing that you cannot go outside like you can on the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center, but don't let that deter you.

Fantastic. We were excited and attend the first day of opening. The One World Observatory is a beautiful building. The elevator up to the 100th floor, went super fast. A thrill for all of us. The views from the top is stunning. It was a clear evening and you could see all over NY and NJ. Beautiful sunset. Must make sure to purchase way in advance. Staff very helpful and friendly.

First day open. We were able to pre book tickets from the UK, but we still had along wait outside, however it was well worth it. Even the lift is an experience. But the view is amazing. and that's not the end of it you get a full package. Food and Shops, and some history too

Long time coming. I went up here with my daughter in January. I paid the expedited fee and that was dramatic. They really do rush you past quite a few cues. It is just as you might expect. A world class tourist attraction. Personally, I'm a tourist of the entire world. I live fourty minutes away but I am committed to enjoying every worthy spot I can reach. I certainly feel lucky to experience this beautiful setting. I put us there right before sunset on a clear cold day. The restaurant this time is a bit less ostentatious than Windows on the World was. There is a great bar up there and the kitchen for the restaurant is feeding the bar as of when I went. Amazing sunset. Great views of the avenues headed north. Times Square is easily identifiable once the sun goes down. Dig deep, spend some money! It's a one in a million event so make it memorable!

Amazing multimedia experience and view!. It is our first visit to the new world trade centre and we certainly greately enjoyed this experience as it is a great combination of technology and an astonishing 360 view, that allows anyone to appreciate NYC in a whole new and innovative way. It is certainly worth a visit!

A beautiful day. Went in December to see the view and to eat at One Dine - which we had to make reservations one month in advance - you must have first purchased tickets - So went with husband daughter and her friend. Well it was a cloudy day - and you were told in advance there were no views and can reschedule tickets. We decided to go ahead - the elevator ride in itself is a show - and its fast. because there is no view - you can rent an ipad for about 10.00 and it will show you what you are missing. There is a person who gives a description of nyc and it was interesting. I saw nothing but clouds- I will say that if you are scared of heights this may not be good for you. I was not great - but all i saw was clouds. So we went to the restaurant - If the view had been clear - it would have been magnificient. We went for experience. Food was expensive - but was not bad. french fries, steak, soup. We had a good time. Definitely something to be seen and experienced if you can.

Amazing views of Manhattan but why make it an attraction?. If you are in New York you should pay to go up in the One World Observatory even though I wasn't too impressed. I don't like way it has been turned into an attraction with a "presentation" to start with and the following up-sell of renting a tablet to tell you about the buildings for an additional $15. It is expensive as it is. Don't fall for it.The video in the elevator was a nice idea but too short. Even if you know about it and are prepared to watch it, it goes by pretty quickly. Would have loved to have it repeated in a "dark room" or something where you could stay as long as you like.Of course many photo opportunities of Manhattan Midtown and the surrounding Jersey City and Brooklyn. Not to bothersome that everything is behind glass windows. Interestingly, since One World Trade Center is a beautiful building from the outside, it might be better to go up one of the other towers like Empire or Rockefeller.The best thing of the whole experience was a guy called Fountaine that did a too short presentation overview of New York and what is happening as his job after actually being retired. Give that guy a 30 minutes show to tell you everything about New York and I'd gladly pay the full amount only for that!

Brilliant view! Beautiful Building!. Very much enjoyed visitng the new World Trade Center. We went up to the top before visiting the 9/11 Museum and Ground Zero.The view is phenomenal and you get a full 360 view, seeing the Hudson River, Statue of Liberty, Brooklyn Bridge, and over to the boroughs and the Mmanhattan Skyline from downtown angle.I would definitely like to to do this again, but maybe do at nighttime next time, as seen in the afternoon this time. Would recommend to anyone.
wow. well what can you say to this, what a way to commemorate such a tragic event 911, this has to be seen to believe, the views are second to no

Although Pricey A Must Do in NYC. So I like everyone else originally gawked at the $32 admission fee for this venue, but believe me when I saw that $32 was worth it. I was a little bit worried when I bought my ticket because they said there was limited visibility because of the weather. I was pleasantly surprised upon arriving at the observatory that it was quite clear. You can purchase a tablet to view the sites for $15 or just enjoy the view on your own. There's also a restaurant and gift shop in the observatory as well. Overall this was a great experience the only problem is with some of the windows there's a glare so you get your reflection in your pictures. However if you're just visiting, staying for a while, or a native New Yorker I highly recommend doing this at least once in your life.

Great views. Really enjoyed the experience at One World. We visited on a Sunday morning in late January and walked right in. Staff was helpful. The elevator ride to the top was probably my favorite. Views from the platform were breathtaking.

Amazing. Based on where this is, we had visited the museum and decided to go to One World Observatory. This is a must and is amazing, the views are breathtaking and well worth the dollars spent, you get to see New York the other way round from the more traditional towers

Must see. There are a couple of observatories in the city now and we chose this one and were not disappointed. It was designed really well! We did get the extra tablet with information but could probably just listen to the info people as they were very entertaining and full of details. I cannot rate this any higher!Make sure you book tickets online in advance so you don't have to wait around to buy tickets.

Great views of NYC. As a native New Yorker I was hesitant to indulge in a NYC tourist attraction. This was one of the most rewarding experiences I have experienced. The elevator ride was very well done. The scenes depicting New York through time was entertaining and amazing to see how the landscape of NYC has evolved. Upon arriving at the top you are led into a viewing area where a short film of New York City life is shown on a panoramic screen. Then the view takes over. It is great locating all the different landmarks of the city. If you are not familiar with the city there are iPad devices which you can rent that will show you different landmarks and a brief explanation about them. The staff is very knowledgeable and great at answering your questions about the views and different information of structures with a little history thrown in.It was an enjoyable time and I will definitely go back.

Davies family holiday 2016. Myself, my wife & our daughters visited the 9/11 memorial & the One World Observatory & we can honestly say it was a moving & awesome experience! The new observational deck on the 102nd floor is a view that simply just can't be missed by any visitor to the city of New York. Great memories, thank you Manhattan....

Very glamorous. A great view.. While they sell the tickets in specific time slots, if it is a relatively slow day, they will just let you in even if you are early. Once you have passed the airport style security, you get to go up in these swanky elevators where the walls show you sort of a time lapse view of the area.I haven't experienced this anywhere else before. Once at the top, you can rent an iPad which points out all the landmarks and gives snippets of information about them. On a clear day the views are brilliant. Go around dusk so that you can see the city lights come up. There is ample space to sit and take in the view. They do not rush you out, so you can take your time.

looking around doesn't cost anything?. Never have been at the old WTC observation decks ,so I went to see this view out as the building itself is much better looking than the destroyed towers.The elevator ride is super quick and the view is great especially if you are from Awshucks, Kansas and have never seen anything larger than a silo.The price is ridiculous though for the attraction.I figure it could cost almost $200 for a family of four to visit this with the admission costs, souvenirs and a refreshment at the top.

Excellent experience well worth the money. Great experience going up lift like a fairground ride also coming down have video ready. And actually been up there with the high tech way you are shown everything is great.

Amazing best observatory ever. An absolute must we have watched this building go up over the past few years so couldn't wait to book the observatory visit.Don't want to spoil anything but the lift to the top is unbelievable then the small film show before you enter the full viewing are will take your breathe away. I will be going again for sure.

Amazing.... This is such a great building. One of my favorite to look at I have ever seen.It is a very emotional place, with ground zero right below so its great to see what New York did by building this. It shows true community which I have never seen anywhere else. The building is truly magnificent and it was a total pleasure to visit and go up to the top. There are no bad points. excellent value too. It really is a must when visiting NYC. Soak up the view and the emotions. We have extended our vacation to Orlando later in the year just so we can bring our daughter to this building.
