We had to walk around past tall windows with shades, (WHY??), while folks were having photos taken in front of a fake screen of NYC, still keeping me from the views!!!Finally we got to where we wanted to be, in front of the tall windows with spectacular views of the city!! Well worth it. You are certainly not rushed to leave, and the elevator ride down is entertaining too. The staff were friendly, but there is room for improvement there.I personally would not use the ipad, maybe it's a good tool, but I find the folks that used them were always in the way, stopping short, and standing if front of a window with their head down blocking the view for everyone else.Well worth the visit, but try to go mid-week to avoid crowds.
Wonderful experience!. We were a party of 7 touring NYC. We had 5 teenage boys with us. The One World Observatory was a hit with us all! It is a must see!

Stunning views friendly staff.. We decided to visit during the evening to see the city in lights, as a result we missed the crowds. The cost at the time was $32 which is much cheaper than the Empire State Building. The lift journey was excellent the whole of the interior was a video screen showing the buildings construction floor buy floor, a nice detail. You enter a walkway with various video projections of individuals sharing their stories of the tragedy and of the new building and its construction. You then enter a room where you watch a short video. I will not spoil the ending. The views are amazing and take your breath away. At an additional cost of $15 you can have an interactive audio tour on an IPad. Expensive but it does help you to identify the buildings and give you some historical context. Staff are helpful and friendly and offer interactive talks at various points around the viewing deck.

Wait for clear weather!. Long lines even with a reservation. Plan on 1 hour from the your appointment to actually reach the front of the final line. Well worth the wait if the weather is clear. But in all fairness they did tell us we would not be able to see a thing! They even gave us the opportunity to change our tickets but this was our last day in NY. The elevator up is positively impressive - you don't feel a thing and it's quicker than you think possible. We had lunch in the Dining room instead of the cafe and that was well worth the experience. Food and service were terrific. But once again . . . an even better experience if you can see the view. It was a cloudy and rainy day for us. We'll go back when we return to catch the view.

Do not buy your tickes in advance. Bought tickets days in advance; visibility zero; exchanged tickets for another day in advance, came back that day; visibility zero a second time. Was told while looking to exchange tickets that visibility was improving. It wasn't and there is zero reason to go unless it is a clear day.  In fact, it makes no sense to buy tickets until the morning of the day you want to go. You will still have advance tickets. If for any reason you cannot get tickets, no worries; go to Top of the Rock or Empire State observatory. They are all the same.

Spectacular views - come early on a clear day. The spectacular views are the best and only reason for going up to the One World Observatory. They are the best views from anywhere in Manhattan and they are well worth it, if you: - Come early on a clear day. Coming early (before 10 am) means much less waiting in line, and there will not be a crowd of people blocking your view from the windows. And a clear day is a must: there is not much of a view otherwise and this place is not worth the cost if there is no view.  - Bring a soft lens cleaning cloth to clean the windows when you want to take a picture. There is no outside location so pictures can only be taken through the windows. To avoid reflections, clean the section of window through which you want to take a picture, put your camera lens against the window and then take a picture. If an outside observation deck is what you want, go to ' top of the rock' at Rockefeller Center. - Buy tickets on-line, preferably using a discount coupon - Do not mind the in-your-face sales pitches for souvenirs or ' One World Explorer' device. Frankly, at USD 32 ticket price levels these devices should be included in the fee.

go here first and you won't to Emoire state or The Rock!. This is the new building at the 9/11 site . The whole experience is excellent and the views from the observatory and breathtaking - you can see over the who;e of Manhattan. Once you have been up here anywhere else is going to be second rate -- probably even the helicopter rides that fly lower than this building! They do an introductory talk then open the blinds to reveal the whole of Manhattan laid out in front of you -- stunning. You get an iPod that shows the buildings etc as you walk around so you know what you are looking at.

Amazing view and very well organized. We had family from LA visiting for the holidays and we went on New Year's Eve. The lines were running a about half hour late which would not be a big deal in warmer weather but it was a nippy day day despite the warmer than average weather. The elevators both going up and coming down are amazing. The views are incredible! Our family enjoyed this a great deal. Just be prepared for standing in line longer than the your entry time would indicate and there are only a few places to sit in the observatory. Though I would recommend public transportation there was a garage on Albany St that had a coupon online.
Amazing... Breathtaking... Incredible. No words can express the view. And have your video ready to go on the elevator ride up and down... just Breathtaking!

Book online or in advance!!. We made the mistake of not being organised to book online. Rocked up at midday on the first sunny day of our trip, only to find that there were no available tickets until, that evening. As we were in New York for a limited time we had no choice but to go up on a day with zero visibility!! The elevator ride, interesting presentations and friendly staff (one of whom gave us some great recommendations for visiting Brooklyn after) made the experience JUST about worthwhile!

Worst organization ever in the US. The lines are not clear, there's a lot of people waiting to get inside as if it were a rock concert.The views are wonderful but the lightning inside the building doesn't let you take a single picture without seeing a reflexion on the window, no matter what time of the day you go. NOT COMING BACK FOR SURE.

Spectacular Views. The views from the top of the WTC are amazing and are a must visit location if your are in NYC. We panned our trip for a Monday and got tickets in advance And Mondays appear to be Mastercard Monday so you do get VIP treatment which means you are on a different line (quicker). You schedule your arrival and are also in a different line when you enter the building. Food and beverages are available but pricey. And there are a huge variety of souvenirs. We also planned out day to arrive an hour before sunset so we had both day and evening views of the city and harbor. A wonderful experience.

Impressive. This was a great experience. We went here after spending time in the 9/11 Museum and it was a lovely way of "looking to the future" so to speak and shows how far New York has come. Do not miss the lifts and the surprise which awaits you at the top especially if you like to film things - have a camera ready. Very impressive views at this indoor observatory - the SOL, Brooklyn Bridge, ESB etc with great guides offering advice on what you can see - no need to spend the $15 on the Ipad. We also bought the commemorative pins they have. We thought it was probably the best observatory and we didnt have a problem with glare through the windows when taking pictures as some people have mentioned.

long wait.. We have purchased tickets for 2.30 pm. Once you get to the entrance it is chaotic scene, with lot of different lines, but no signs for anything, and very few staff. They were half an hour behind schedule, and would not let us get in line for our scheduled time. After coming back, we were ushered in one of the three lines for 2.30 pm tickets. The girl that manged these lines, would only let one of them move until they were totally empty, while people in the third line were waiting in the cold for more than 60 minutes. The staff and managers are unable to organize the place. Totally unacceptable for the price.Visited January 2016

Beautiful views but long lines. We went to visit on January 2nd. Our time to visit was at 3pm and the website asked us to be there 15 min earlier. When we got there, there was a huge crowd. No one was in line. There was no one to help. When we finally found someone to help us, he told us that the 2:30 group wasn't even inside yet. He told us to come back later. We waited for about 45 min to get inside. It was very cold and difficult to wait with kids. The observatory itself is beautiful. The views are breathtaking. But they need to organize the lines and learn how to handle crowds better.

Amazing, a must see! That's coming from a native New Yorker!. Let me start off by saying that my husband and I are native New Yorkers. In saying that, we aren't easily impressed. Well, we were impressed. We purchased tickets online the night before and got to the site about 20 minutes early. Very well organized and we were! We were awed by the views of our beautiful city. All of the staff were accommodating and knowledgable about the observatory. I myself was a first responder with the NYPD, so I am personally appreciative of the beautiful job that has been done to recreate what once was, but above and beyond my expectations. Great addition to a great city

Badly organized, and not enough real value. Admittedly we went on a peak attendance date, but given that tickets are handed out in timed slots and do sell out, I doubt the volume was much higher than normal. The lines outside were TERRIBLY managed. It was basically a mob of people edging to get in, with no announcements or attempts to organize. By the time my kids and I got inside, we were tired, cold, and completely not in a frame of mind to enjoy the experience. There was only very cursory educational/background provided - we would have been much more interested in the overall history of the area than in just the building of the tower. The short video was not even meant to be educational or informational. The walk-in voices installation could not be digested it as you moved through so fast. The elevator time-lapse was the most interesting part - but it went by FAR too fast to appreciate or even see it, plus it was blocked by the crowded elevator. I hoped we would see it on the way down again, but no. Upstairs was an expensive cafe ($8 for a croissant?) and views that are almost too distant to be of interest. Go to the Empire State Building instead to really appreciate the city.

Top of the World Ma!. We loved our visit to the One World observatory so much we went back a second time.This time we went at twilight, and the view was magical. I am amazed at the complaints about sales pitches. We never felt forced to stay. They were informative and short, and we loved the iPad. It added so much to our views. The gift shop had lots of affordable things that made great presents for friends. Sure it is commercialized but what isn't these days. Disney set the stage decades ago, My advice, stop complaining and GO!! Don't buy the extras if you can't or don't want them. But you will be missing something. Buy your tickets on-line and pick a non-peak time (mid-afternoon?). This is a fantastic experience, especially for Americans who suffered through the horrors of 9/11. It is totally upbeat and a great technology showpiece. GO!

Very Commercial!. Expensive and when you are taken up to the top you are let off on a floor that has a restaurant. Then you get to go one floor down and are solicited to purchase a tablet to take along on your visit. Then one more floor down is the observatory where there is a gift shop. My advice is to do this during the day, we went at night to see the city and while some spots were ok to take pictures, other areas had glare from all the lights of an exhibit and the gift shop. Daytime would be ideal to do this. I was kind of disappointed at all the sell, sell, sell that was crammed down our throats as we did the tour. Not my favorite attraction in NYC.

Friendly staff inside, staff so great on the line outside. We had purchased tickets in advance in hopes of avoiding lines. Turned out to be an overcast day with zero visibility so of course that was disappointing. One World staff certainly has no control over weather and visibility, but staff outside building could have been more clear and helpful about rescheduling process. Sounded to us that the only choice we had was to go up and see nothing or wait in a huge line to change in tickets for another day. As we were all from out of town, we couldn't change tickets and predict a day and time when we'd be in nyc again. Like others, I resented the sales pitch for iPad, we paid a lot for entry and I'd prefer staff to spend more time telling us about building, ground zero, etc. than trying to get more money from us. I did think the tour was well done as far the inside entrance, the elevators, the bits of information shared. We will go back again some day when it's a clear day. It must be amazing.

Well done! Great views!. Booked timed ticket and glad we did. We were there the week after Christmas and Manhattan was extremely crowded. With a timed ticket there was no real wait. The observation floors were incredible as was the ride In the elevator up. You do get a sensation of movement while in the top of the building. The live docents give some good info and trivia on the city and answer questions. Picked this over Empire State Building thinking this would be better than the Empire State Building since it was newer exhibits.

A little over priced to be treated like a sardine. Since One World Trade Centre opened, my partner & I have wanted to go visit the site. We absolutely loved the 9/11 Museum as we thought it was such a just tribute, so thought that One WTC would be such a powerful observatory to compete with Empire State and the Rock. We purchased our tickets online with priority entry and OMG I am so glad that we did. We probably skipped approximately 2 hours worth of lines. The elevator ride & the presentation up the top (sorry, I won't give away any surprises) was amazing with the visual displays. I do find it a little unfortunate that the staff have to cram everyone in like sardines as it makes seeing the visual effects so much harder to see and get the full experience. They need not be so greedy for ticket sales and allow people to get a enjoyable and less crowded experience. The view up the top isn't bad. They were good views, however I did tend to prefer the experiences at it's competition uptown. Also, the pricing to go up is probably a little over the top. But if you still want to go up, please pay more for the priority access.

Sobering yet beautiful views.. We visited the tower on Monday, December 28.2015. My husband purchased the Sunset Flex tickets @ $59 each. This was a good choice on a cold, windy and crowded day as we entered with "priority expedited entry". We were able to experience the views before and after sunset. The first thing you think of are the many victims of 9/11 that once stood very close to where you are now standing. Sobering to say the least. As you look out and down from the east side of the tower, you can see the north and south memorial pools..

Long queues, blocked views and sales, sales sales. I have to say that once you do make it to the observation deck and people move from the window - why do some think it's acceptable to make camp at the foot of them??- the view is pretty impressive.However, after being heckled for a photo and a sales pitch for an ipad device and queuing from beginning to end, the price of $32 is not justifiable I'm afraid.

Spectacular view. We'll run service. . The view is worth every penny. We arrived at 9:00 am and were able to get on the elevator by 9:30. It is very well run with the assigned times. The elevator ride alone is amazing. It's a 360 movie and is the fastest elevator!

360 degree views. If you are in NYC, you will probably go to the 9/11 memorial. This is a great add on to that experience as the views are phenomenal. You can spend a lot of time up there...just taking it all in. I give it 4/5 (not 5/5) just because you can a better view of the Manhattan skyline at Top of the Rock. If you have to choose between the two because of time or finances, I recommend Top of the Rock. But if you can go to both....it is worth it.

Wow - what a great experience!. Our extended family had a great time touring One World Observatory. We ordered tickets online and got in fairly quickly. Note: if you have tickets, go the left front of the building and find One World people at the time you are scheduled. The experience and the view was just fantastic and you can stay at the top as long as you like.

BUY TICKETS ON-LINE. The reason I did 4 not 5 stars is the wait.... We went on New Years Day... Be kind to yourself and don't go on holidays....:).....tickets were for 4:45, got into bldg at 6p.... But much easier to buy online... If you can afford , do an express ticket as no or limited waiting... Now the great part... Very moving to be there... Great views and memorial very well done... It is a happy and sad place at same time... Sad for the obvious reasons and happy for thePerseverance of the American people and the people of NYC. Would recommend and return

Overpriced, unorganized tourist trap. We have purchased tickets for 1.45 pm. Once you get to the entrance it is chaotic scene, with lot of different lines, but no signs for anything, and very few staff. They were half an hour behind schedule, and would not let us get in line for our scheduled time. After coming back, we were ushered in one of the three lines for 1.45 pm tickets. The guy that manged these lines, would only let two of them move until they were totally empty, while people in the third line were waiting in the cold for more than 20 minutes. The staff and managers are extremely rude and unable to organize the place. Totally unacceptable for the high price of the tickets. Another NYC tourist trap. You can get decent view of New York City from any high rise office building in lower Manhattan, no need to be subjected to insults from impolite staff for that price.

Nice View with Heavy-Handed Sale Pitches. I bought tickets online, adding the slight premium for Priority access because on New Years Eve, I assumed it could get busy. Yes, the tickets are not inexpensive but it is a unique experience and I will tell you that the priority access is worth the extra.I understand that the observation deck is still relatively new and they are probably working out some kinks. Be prepared to be confused at the entrance. The signage is poor and you will be stuck scratching your head - especially if you pre-purchased priority access tickets. Just ask the employees that you see; they are helpful and should guide you. Again, inside the lower level queuing area, there is a lack of signage so you may find it confusing where to go if you have premium tickets. I saw so many confused people both outside and inside, not sure where they were supposed to go.In an effort to keep people flowing, they fill each elevator to the max. While this is generally acceptable and not too uncomfortable, it ruins the theatrics of the elevator ride. There are high-res LED screens on the walls to give you an animated experience as you ride up and down - but when packed full, it's hard to really experience it optimally. It's a short ride though, so I took it in stride. It's not the way the designers envisioned people would experience the video presentation, but it's what it is.Generally, the theatrics of the experience is well designed, from the initial trek to the elevators and ride up, to the initial reveal of the view. After that reveal, be prepared for the worst part of the experience... the heavy-handed sale pitches.The initial "tease" reveal gives you about 1 minute to take in the magnificent views, before they hide it and usher you into a second room. All guests are forced into a room at the top where all views are blocked - so your attention is on the sales people. You cannot leave the room until their sales pitch is over. In this room, they try to get you to spend another $15 for an iPad rental with unique app. Yes, the app looks to be well designed and useful for those that don't know the city or want to really dig into what they are seeing, but not everyone wants it. Honestly, they SHOULD be trying to sell this in the queue lines downstairs or at a kiosk on the observation deck level - NOT by forcing it down your throat as they do now.It's not over folks, the next sales pitch is around the corner. After their first sales pitch is over, they allow you to travel down one floor and funnel you single file in front of a huge LED screen where photographers try to snap shots of you and your group (to sell you later downstairs). After you get past this second gate of sales hell, you can then pick up some overpriced food at the dining area or head down one more level to the main observation level. The main observation deck is well done. It is open and easy to navigate around. Be prepared to wait your turn at most of the windows because there are a lot of people - but hey, that's expected for something like this. They also have two presentation areas where very knowledgable and friendly speakers will give you cool and informational introductions to a variety of topics (Brooklyn Bridge, 9/11 plaza, etc). I believe the topics rotate every 30 minutes or so. Generally, the experience is positive and the attraction has been designed well. The only frustrating parts are the lack of signage/way-finding at the bottom and the heavy-handed forced sales pitches at the top.

Incredible views, incredible lines. The views from the Observatory are fantastic but, the problem is actually getting space close to the windows to absorb the views. Unfortunately, the advent of the "selfie" now means that people are in place for an inordinate amount of time, trying to get the perfect shot. If they are not happy with the photo that they have taken, they regroup and try again. This can happen several times which means that the line to access a window can be five or six people deep. Having said this, when you can get to the windows, the views are absolutely stunning, even on a slightly overcast day, and it is fun trying to pick out various neighborhoods and landmarks.Definitely a worthwhile visit.

Atmospheric & Breathtaking. Worth the visit just for the lift journey alone! We visited when it was very cloudy and were immediately offered to change our date as zero visibility. We did change but sadly still had zero visibility (offered to change again) HOWEVER was absolutely still worth the trip and will definitely be returning with the hope of a better view next time.

Not worth time or money. The overcrowded conditions make it difficult to enjoy oneself. Lines for everything was long especially for restrooms.Everything is not only overpriced ( ie. Poland Spring water for $5 ) but there's every effort to sell you something else ie. screen rentals, photos.

Best Experience Ever. This place is incredible after watching videos about it I finally got to visit with my friend the other day and I was astonished by the construction and craft of the building. The elevator part was especially my favorite. The presentation is on of a kind New York has nothing comparable to this building its one of a kind. I advise anyone who has time to go there make sure you purchase tickets online because they sell out pretty fast
a new place after WTC. not so great about the place but observatory is ok. u cannot see manhattan from here but rest of the city and its amazing see my pictures

Spectacular Indoor Views of Manhatten from One World Observatory!. This new attraction in Manhattan is definitely an must-visit experience when you visit New York City. It's the perfect place to start for new visitors to orientate themselves in NYC. In addition to the 360 uninterrupted views of New York City, there's plenty of attractions on across the 2 levels of viewing decks. A few important tips. 1. Make sure you book in advance and select your preferred time to visit to minimise queuing on the day. 2. Visit during late afternoon (i.e. 3pm) so you can enjoy both day and nigh time view of the city. Get a spot in the observatory restaurant and grab a coffee/tea/snack and watch the sunset.

Enjoyable but get a priority pass. Having seen most of the landmarks in NYC, this new icon was a must on our bucket list. We were not disappointed. With priority queue jump tickets, we were at the top of the tower within 15 minutes. The elevator ride is fab (video display as you go up). The views at the top are fantastic with 360 degree views of NYC. There is the usual merchandise on sale and also for $15, you can borrow an ipad showing you the different buildings in NYC as a virtual display.Only downside is the glass windows sometimes show a glare when taking photographs. There are plenty of toilets and a well priced restaurant.

Long lines, terrible staff, unimpressive view. We had tickets for the 4:30 entry into the observatory because we wanted to see all of NYC while it was light outside/sunset time. We arrived 15 minutes early as indicated on the ticket. When we got there, flustered staff who had no idea what was going on told us we couldn't get in line because the line was only for 4 o'clock tickets. At this point it was already 4:15. Us, and hundreds of other visitors were stuck outside in the freezing cold waiting to be told where to go for over an hour before we were escorted into the proper line. It was now 5:30, and we were just now getting in LINE! The entire time we had been waiting out in freezing cold conditions with wind off the hudson that we didn't dress for cause the tickets said 4:30! Once we got inside and past the other lines, and up to the top of the elevator, you wait some more. Theres a cheesy movie they make you watch. Then after the movie, you are escorted to a sales pitch where they try to sell you an iPad. Skipping that, you finally get to the observatory where it's full of hundreds of people blocking the windows. Of course by this time it was night, and we didn't get the experience we had paid for! As we went to exit, there was a 30 MINUTE LINE TO EXIT. Total in waiting we probably waited 2 hours for this unbelievably underwhelming experience. I complained to customer service on the way out and we were given a refund no questions asked. The management at One World needs to step things up if they want to provide an experience that is actually enjoyable and worth the $32 entrance fee.

1776 feet of magnificent views!. Worth every one of the $32 we spent for each of us. There are some great surprises on this tour so I won't ruin the suspense by telling you...just go! 100 times better than the in-your-face Empire State Building tour and much more organized. Pick a time online and book in advance. Show up a little early (our subway was diverted over the Brooklyn Bridge so we were a little late). Staff were friendly and genuinely good-natured at every turn. The presentations were sharp and engaging. The snacks were a little pricey, but on par with NYC standards. Pick the best weather day of your visit and make this a priority! Our teenagers loved it and my wife and I agreed that this made the short list of must do's in New York!

Spend the extra money for the express ticket. Avoid the lines. Feel like a star.. I'm not a big fan of heights, but for some reason the observatory on the 102nd floor did not bother me at all. It might have been the amazing views along the entire 360 degree circle. The guides make informative and entertaining presentations to highlight different parts of the view. The "bird's eye" view gives you a unique appreciation for the entirety of the island.
I've been twice . Once solo then had to bring the fam back to look at it. Really neat. High tech observatory. Lots of photo ops while you're walking around the top. Lots of history in the bottom.
Stunning!. This is a must do when visiting New York! Get your tickets early because they sell out on same day. By far, the best observatory in all of NYC.

Worth it! Go!!. Amazing views. Get your tickets on line with assigned time and avoid lines at the Center. Wasn't crowded and the flow of people traffic was managed really really well. Very much worth it. You can get iPads at the top to show you the landmarks and tell you all about them. Kids loved that. Cafe at the top had better food than the limited menu at the restaurant but still great food. Well worth the trip.

Beautiful view! . First of all, the view is absolutely beautiful and definitely worth paying for! 4 stars are for the view! Hopefully they'll sort out the teething problems of the queuing system, stop all the gimmicks like the photos/iPads and just let people look at the view.If you get motion sickness don't go!! I do and was extremely ill going up and down in the lift. Fast moving video/fast lift = very sick, then you watch another video before you can view. By this point I was extremely unwell and had to eat/sit. Sadly there was nowhere to sit in the restaurant and a member of staff told me I couldn't sit anywhere! So after about 5 mins I was too unwell and had to leave. Such a pity. I must mention the young member of staff who took charge in the outside queue and made it orderly and less chaotic! He took so much initiative and sorted it out all on his own! Well done! In summary, go visit and if you have motion sickness go to Rockefeller instead as I was fine there! :)

Visit no matter what the weather!. We went up on what was an extremely cloudy day, so our view was... well inside a cloud! It was a shame we didn't get to experience it with our own eyes! however, they have these brilliant little interactive tablets which align with the view so we could use a little imagination and facts to see what we beyond the cloud! Staff are amazing, so so friendly and the bar, while a little pricey, is wonderfully stocked and located. And of course, it was an honour just to have the chance to make a journey to the top of the new One World Trade!

Very well managed on your part. This is a first class experience. From the amazing (and fast!!) elevator ride, to the very helpful and polite staff, to the amazing view ... it was all great.Suggestion - Not quite sure how you might best manage this, but it felt like there were too many intermediate stages in anticipation of getting to the actual view. When we arrived at the actual observatory, it was like, FINALLY!

Even with zero visibility!!!. Zero visibilty at the beginning. Minutes later the fog open up giving us the chance of a great view, not 100% but something. It was great!Elevator to the observatory is pretty fast, you may feel dizzy for a few seconds but wonderful. You go in and while going up, there is like a view of what is outside, the higher you go, the higher the feeling and the view! Is just amazing!!! Staff is great and very well organized! There is a cafeteria and also outlets where you can charge your phone. That happened to me!!! Gift store too. Once inside you can stay as long as you want.Before passing through the security area and scanning our tickets, they gave us the chance of changing the date due to zero visibility. That was nice! But we stayed and anyway it was worth it. I may have to return? Yes! Absolutely. I wanna see the whole view with a clear sky! Pictures show from almost nothing to some view. Just being that high and being able to see something was great!

They do a good job letting you know zero visabilit6. We had to go on cloudy day so we didn't see forever we saw some in between clouds. On a plus lots of people chose not to go so crowds were minimal as we're lines. We sat at the bar a bit pricey but the bartender and all the staff were very nice. Store was way overpriced. Elevator ride was awesome wish it lasted longer. If you can go on a clear day I imagine it is great.
Great experience. It was amazing how you can see all New York city up there. Even if you are solo or with friends or family your will enjoy a great view of the big apple!

Excellent views. We booked to go up at night time, the views were excellent, but there is a lot of light pollution from inside the observation deck making photography hard without getting reflections off the glass, it could do with dark areas to allow photos of the views

Fantastic!. Even with zero visibility the whole experience was amazing. The outside pools are beautiful. Inside the information and the presentation are so well done. A low visibility day meant shorter lines. The ipad experience is also worth the money. Great for families and kids!

view even more amazing than I thought it would be. I'm not a fan of heights, so my kids had to cajole me to go up in the elevator to One World Observatory. I'm so glad I did! The elevator ride is quick and not scary at all. Once you are at the top, you are shuttled a bit from place to place until at last you have the opportunity to explore the Observatory on your own. The view is spectacular. Like the Grand Canyon, I think it's difficult to over-state how amazing it is. The Brooklyn Bridge, the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, the Empire State Building, and all of Manhattan and Brooklyn laid out below you. Definitely get tickets in advance on line - this will save you lots of hassle.

Great views, crowds, over-managed. Well, the views from the top are obviously unique and arguably worth the $30/head entry fee. Entry is every 15 mins. Arrive 15mins before your allotted time and you are led into a queue that enters the building on your time slot. You then descend to the basement where you have airport style security and we queued for another 15 mins or so.The ride up takes 27 seconds in the lift and there is something very neat in the lift which I won't spoil for you.At the top there is a brief video that is rather senseless. They then lead you to another short presentation where they try and rent you an iPad that explains the remote views for another $15Once inside you can walk around all sides of the building. The views are impressive. They advertise what seems to be a glass platform to look down to ground level but that's a con as it is basically TV screens over a fake glass floor that give the impression of you standing on a glass 100 stories up. Very poor i.m.o.Most annoying is that they have placed presentation booths in the two best viewing spots where inane presenters try to be funny. This dumbs down the whole experience. Another 10 min queue for the ride down. All in all something worth doing but the over engineered, dumbed down approach with the fake glass floor, annoying crowd control measures and presentations takes two stars away for me.

If it say zero visibility don't do it! . We went on a cloudy day- had already changed dates once and this was or last chance to go up. Could not be more disappointed- could see absolutely nothing . Don't take a chance a go up- waste of money. This is the view all round.

Poorly executed. Lots of up-selling. Do Top of the Rock instead.. It is a great view, but you can get a great view from cheaper, more easily accessible places and learn tons more (such as Top of the Rock and tour). The restaurant has a very limited menu and way over-priced. There is NO PLACE TO SIT in the cafe?! The vibe is "give us more money and get out fast."

Fantastic. Absolutely loved going up the new Trade Center. The lift to the top is even pretty impressive right away. The observatory is made up of 3 floors with a restaurant/cafe and shop. There is plenty of room to see the views and move about and you can see for miles and miles. I recommend going to the cafe eating area, as it has an opening where you can look over the observation floors below with the views out the window as a backdrop, I personally found it pretty impressive.

Buy the VIP Priority ticket.. We promised ourselves that this time when we were in NY we would go up and see the view from the WTC. Booking online is a real bonus and we also decided to pay the extra money to get priority access. Money well spent! It was $54 each but it was worth it. We printed our tickets off at home too.The queues for the observatory were very long, but with the VIP ticket we were up at the top looking out over the city within less than 10 minutes. From entering, security and waiting for the elevator it was seamless. The top is breathtaking, amazing views as you would expect. However you are being constantly bombarded with people trying to up sell the experience. Photos, souvenirs and an iPad to view stuff on. If you are like us and just want to see, enjoy and go then just walk on!
Amazing Views. Superb views from the top of One World Trade Observatory. I would recommend this to anyone. The lift up is amazing as well.
Fabulous views. A must see on a clear day, there was enough security to get us through the lines. It was a little similar to a Disney ride, with the music and anticipation until we zoomed to the top.

Excellent Food and Drinks on Top of the World.... We were at the observatory on Christmas Day when the visibility was zero, so we decided to wait a bit to see if the clouds would start to disperse, and in the meantime decided to grab a bite at the restaurant. Wendy was our server and she was amazing. We stayed for food and one, two, three... drinks and the clouds did part enough for us to see the spire of the Empire State Building. The ambiance was super, the staff was great, and the food was simple and most excellent, but quite expensive. But what else would you expect there?

Top of the world, Ma (almost). There's not a whole heap to do at the 9/11 memorial site at the moment so a trip up One World seemed like a good idea. And it was. It may be higher than the Empire State but it lacks the pizzaz - none the less it gives a different view of the city taking in all of Manhattan when you face north as well as good views over Brooklyn, Queens and Jersey. The cafe was fine and quiet - a good spot to get away from the crowds on the viewing floor. Probably the highlight was the elevator ride on the way up with a brilliant animation of New York from foundation to the present passing the two minute trip spectacularly. We queued for a total of twenty minutes to half an hour in the middle of the day, so I don't know if it's important to book ahead.

On top of the One World. Timed tour is easy to arrange online. Price is reasonable. No paper tickets are needed. Just show the bar code of your ticket sent to your phone. The tour is organized well so it took me about one hour from the time I got there to the time I left the building. That is very efficient. It's on a fully enclosed floor through glass windows. The view is spectacular.
Great and different views of NYC. This gives you a different perspective then either the Empire State or Top of the Rock. Enjoyed the whole time up there.

Christmas holiday visit.. Booked tickets from the UK. Pretty easy. Luckily visited on first day of holiday which was bright and sunny. Amazing experience for kids and adults alike. Lifts up and down are brilliant. Staff all friendly. Would definitely recommend it. Good value compared to some other attractions.

Fantastic. Well we went up world trade one fantastic experience and tribute to those lost in the 9/11 tradegyGreat staff very helpful and knowledgeable Souvenirs expensive Would recommend you experience this highlight of NYC

You need to see this one!. Great view! Cafe if you want to grab a bite, too. Only downfall was you have to wait in line and can't go to the restroom until you go through the security line. Typically airport security, strollers allowed, which was great for us with a 17 month old.
The pick of the views. If you are only going to do one tower view, do this one. I've been up the Rockerfeller and Empire State and this tops them by a mile.

Fab-u-lous. Wow! Amazing! Do it!This is a must-do if you're in New York.I went up the original world trade centre back in 1989, have been up the Empire State and Top of the Rock. Top of the Rock is great because you're out doors and there's no pillars obstructing your view but for sheer magnitude, one world observatory is brilliant. The trip in the lift and the big reveal bizarrely made me feel quite emotional. We visited mid December so no worries re queues and had pre- booked for a date when the weather forecast was good. The weather was fabulous which was a relief as I don't think you get a refund on pre-booked tickets if the weather is poor.

Breathtaking. Went Christmas week and was told by people that you needed a reservation that get to the top. Not so on this day. On the elevator within 15 minutes (Slight security check) and whisked to the top. 1,200 ft. in 1 minute. Interesting "view" on the way up. Video of virtual NYC. Girl at ticket booth was the ONLY one who was less than friendly. Not unfriendly, just that we had to ask for brochure, ask for directions etc. After that, just the best young folks from start to finish. DON'T MISS IT !!!

The Best Spot to See NYC. The Observatory on the top of the One World Trade Center building is accessed by an elevator whose walls show the history of New York City as you ascend. At the top, you can walk around to get a panoramic view of the city or use the many tools to see and understand near and distant landmarks. Based on our what we saw, we've identified numerous NYC places that we plan to visit in the future.
Brilliant, must do on a visit to NYC. This is a brilliant must see on any visit to NYC, it's high tech and informative. Highly recommended

Amazing fast ride to the top, excellent view!. What a thrill, the elevators are really great and take you up in about 40sec. Feels like flying in a plane! Once above after the short introduction movie the screens go up and give a first glimps of the view. Breathtaking experience!! Also easy to change bookings, we had fog on our planned day, reschuled to next day easily.

Buying tickets in advance isn't always a good thing.... Unfortunately, we purchased our Flex Pass for admission prior to traveling to the city (which was highly recommended by friends that had visited before). The day we had a pass for was rainy and foggy with ZERO visibility. They did offer to let us use it another day, but we were only in the city one more day and weather forecast was same. I think in the case of a pre-purchase, a refund or credit should be available. As a family of five, we paid $162.50 for an elevator ride. Very disappointed. They offered to let us rent a tablet at the top which shows what we would have seen without the fog - really?

Incredibly Amazing doesn't even cover it. The views are incredible. Definitely book in advance to get the tour. So worth it. Be sure to spend time on the viewing floors (enclosed). But also spend time in the surrounding areas they've kept the foot prints of the old buildings and made a memorial from them. It's amazing what's been done in place of what was. I'm sure it's hard to visit for many but try to take in the beauty.

One World Observatory....Beyond Belief!!!!. We have been avid NYC visitors for over 30 years. We have seen and done it all for sure. But if you do nothing else on your next trip (or even your first visit) to the Big Apple, make plans to see the One World Observatory. No spoiler here, but they have thought of every detail to make your experience one of the most memorable in your lifetime (including the elevator ride up). We splurged for the Priority Tickets which allows you and your group to skip all lines and head straight to the top at your specified time. The 360 degree views of Manhattan and the burrows are simply breathtaking. Your family and friends will thank you for this incredible journey to the top of the world.

Christmas Day at One World Observatory. We had booked tickets online for Christmas Day evening. When we arrived, there was zero visibility but we went up anyway as the tickets were non-refundable. There were no queues and we got straight up. The lift ride up and short show at the top were very cool and gave this an exciting difference to Empire State and Rockefeller. Thankfully the clouds cleared once we were up there and we had great views. I liked that you could see the Statue of Liberty clearly. We had a bottle of house wine in the bar upstairs which was very reasonably priced.
Breathtaking!. Definitely a MUST on your itinerary. We bought tickets there & everything went fast. The ride to top was awesome!

A Wonderful Experience!!!!. This was my second time to visit the One World Observatory - the first time was with 200 8th graders and this time just my family. Both times the interactions with staff were very good. Both times the views were spectacular - this time just a bit calmer. I purchased these tickets on line and everything went smoothly. We had a 9:45 AM entrance but were allowed to enter earlier. The elevator ride is phenomenal. And I love the See Forever theater - it just brings so much happiness to be up there and seeing "forever". I had purchased the I-Pod. This was wonderful for our family because we took the time to hear about the various locations, etc. (With the school group - not so much - they did not have the patience for it). We spent about 2 hours up there and had good experiences - all the way around .

Missing salt!. We visited 12/28, we arrived 6pm, we couldn't book in advance since you need to specify the date and time that you will be arriving in, with unpredictable weather this is close to impossible, it was foggy most of previous days in our visit so we didn't risk. The bad news is when we arrived the next available entrance was 8:30pm (only 1.5 hour before closing), but we decide to go ahead and book since that was our last day. after paying close ~$68, we passed security line which was too long, we passed VOICES AND FOUNDATIONS since we have only ~1 hour left, SKY POD ELEVATORS was cool but we were disappointed that it wasn't real, we thought we will see the city from outside but it was movie type, SEE FOREVER THEATER was very nice and the moment when it goes up and you see the real city is amazing. Now that small thing that greatly annoyed us is before you enter the main MAIN OBSERVATORY they show a demo of device that you held in your hand to identify the buildings you see, it was very cool demo but they asked for another $15 for it, come on we already paid that much, small things that like missing salt after 3 hours cooking! SKY PORTAL was another disappoint thing as is was faked.Still the view was amazing but do not expect more than that. Prices at the store was a joke but tourist of course keep buying!

Amazing. The whole experience was amazing, really well organised to get in with good security. Lift ride up was so good u needed to see it more than once! Then a small presentation then blinds up - amazing, brought tears to my eyes. Have an iPad - good value 15 dollars. Then it was just views after views, so good. We then ate at the restaurant, best food ever with the best ever view.

Customer Service. I tried to order 2 "priority" tickets for Saturday, December 26. The web-site said, "turn on your printer, make sure there is paper in the printer, and click PRINT to print your tickets." I did this and nothing happened. The web page went back to the home page and nothing printed. I did this again and the same thing happened. I called the tech help number and they said, "refresh your browser." At some point, I checked my email account and found that I had somehow got billed for 6 tickets. The visit was great, however, when I called to get a refund, I got a real run-around. I was told this was my fault and there was no refund. The agent admitted that this is a common problem, duplicate orders, however, I would have to pay for 6 tickets. Since I ordered the tickets on American Express, I called American Express and I am disputing the 4 tickets that I did not want. The customer service here was worse that what I usually get at Lowe's Hardware where the Lowe's employees usually run from you if you have a question. In other words, HORRIBLE!!!

Christmas in NY. This has to be one of the best "tourist" attractions I have ever visited. I purchased VIP tickets online in advance and it was well worth the extra money. Our scheduled entry time was 9:15am and we were granted entry at 8:50. No lines; no waiting. Staff was friendly and helpful. Views of New York were magnificent. My son rented the iPad for $15 (which I thought was too much at first) that identified the sites around the city. This was extremely helpful especially if you are not familiar with NY. I will definitely return.

In a word - GO!. Great experience and so well organised.We turned up the first day and there was zero visibility so they offered to replace the tickets and we returned the next day.The line moved very swiftly the observatory is excellent and it really is a must if you are in the area.

Weather did not cooperate with my visit; beware of collector's pin. If there weather was good and you didn't purchase anything, this would receive at least 4 stars if not 5. I would have rated this higher, but since there was zero visibility and I had an issue with the gift shop purchase, I couldn't go higher. The staff went out of there way to make sure I know of the zero visibility, to the point that I would respond as a greet that yes, I knew the weather was bad. I'm sure they get lots of complaints about the weather, so I do not fault them for that. If our trip had allowed more time, we could have changed the date, but we didn't have that option.My negative experience was with the gift shop. I purchased the limited edition collector's online when I purchased the tickets. However, when I went to collect them the sales person told me they were out of stock and had 2016 pins ready to go out and the pins on the rack were not the same limited edition pins. After some internal confusion and not finding any 2015 pins in the pack room, I was instead provided two $9.95 pins off the rack, instead of the two $12 limited edition pins I ordered.Also, the 3-coin collector's set I purchased had evidence of prior handling that I discovered after returning home. Not a huge issue as it is on the back of the coin, but there are blemishes that appear to be caused by handling with dirty or oily fingers.

Highlight for me. I purchased weekend flex passes for my family of 5 (incl 3 teen boys) for this past weekend. When we arrived on Sunday there was NO visibility and guest services quickly extended our tickets for use the next day. The next day was clear! The flex pass was expensive - but amazingly quick and efficient. I felt guilty passing all the people in line. We did not wait for anything - the entrance, the security, the elevator. My boys enjoyed the view - I'm not sure $90 worth. But I was thrilled. I had dinners at Windows on the World and stayed at the Marriott in the Twin Towers - as recently as 2 weeks prior to 9/11. I was so happy to share this experience on top of the Freedom Tower with my boys, for whom 9/11 isn't as prominent a memory as it is for me and my husband. I was disappointed that there were NO books about the Freedom Tower history - or history of the site - or the Freedom Tower construction - or souvenir book - or any brochure. But I would highly recommend the experience.

No refund. the building is impressive and i am sure that the view should be fantastic BUT i do not certain things with the Americans. I booked an appointment as it was requested, we paid more than 120 euros in tickets to admire the view and the visibility was zero. They should refund our money and not tell us to book another date and hour. We are tourists with limited days of visiting NYC and is not possible to change everything. We did the tour (it was our last day in NYC) but disappointing ...

One World....WOW. Visited after touring the 9/11 Memorial & Museum & found One World Trade Center to be a perfect complement. The 9/11 Museum is amazing and a very real reminder of the devastation of that day - but One World shows the triumph & determination of the WTC complex. Amazing views, starting with the elevator ride showing the development of NYC over time. Allow yourself time to take in the story tellers giving descriptions & tips about different parts of the city....neighborhoods, arts, commerce, etc. Like any good tourist trap, they do try to sell you on the rental of an iPad that will pinpoint various buildings & points of interest, along with photo op - as soon as you get off the elevator. Easy enough to skip if not interested.
Site to visit. Choose a sunny day, lift 100 floors in 0 sec. Views 360 and amazing. Great place to visit. You are issued a timed slot due to being very busy..

Amazing View. We had prebooked our visit, on a Holiday Lights and Champagne Nights package. We were booked for 4pm on the 26th December, and the hope was to see New York in daylight and at night. We arrived at 3:40, and got straight in. The wait in the security line wasn't too bad, and we were able to get to the observatory while it was still daylight outside. Without question, the views are amazing, and although the weather wasn't the best, all the key landmarks were very clear.On our package, we had a glass of champagne each, which we had to go to the ONE mix restaurant. While there, we also ordered a Beer, and Coke, which I thought was reasonable priced. The only gripe I had, there was a lack of seating in the restaurant, and we felt like vultures waiting for somebody to leave the bar.Only 2 complaints, unlike Top of the Rock, and Empire State, you can't go outside, which means any photos you take, have a glare, or reflection on, and once you get the top, is there really the need for the video, and sales job, trying to get you buy the Ipad add on.

Awful view and no refund?. We paid 38 dollars per person for a 47 seconds elevator ride... Zero visibility , all white Windows and no refund? They can't even offer you a decent movie explaining how the tower was built? Some history or other interesting topic? An exchange does not do you any good when you are in NY for a short time like most out of town visitors...

What a view!. Excellent 360 degree view of Manhattan and surrounding boroughs.We went to the restaurant and a beer cost me $12....!!!Queue was very long on 26th December but it did move quickly. The WOW moment's are the elevator and the "reveal".

Horrible during bad weather also very congested with people and impossible to take photos. The observation deck/floor is not photo friendly. It is impossible to take photos unless you have an expensive camera due to the way the windows are. One thing that made me and will make you frustrated is the point that people are sleeping, napping, resting and blocking windows by sitting in the windows texting, talking, playing games. The people are not even looking out the windows. There should be a time limit of hogging up a window ledge/sill. Note, there is no outside terrace,balcony therefore you are boxed in. I would only go if you are the first 100 people in the building, you have quality cameras and lighting and weather is perfect otherwise you will feel that you wasted 90 minutes of your life. The gift shop is huge but the pricing is reflects truce retail markups. $200 jackets, sweat tops etc.

Too much drama !. If you haven't visit a tall building it's a must in NY but this specific attraction can be so much more. It's nice but on your way to the top the elevator is too fast so you can't see the movie and then you just go up and down. At the end they're trying to sell another attraction - iPad - why not including everything in the expensive ticket? $32 just to enter and then if you want to watch the view in an iPad - another $15

Incredible Views!. It's amazing and you will be proud to have visited the tower. You have to go through some serious security but they are the best. My husband left his wallet behind in the security vin and when we went to the 911 Memorial Museum and went to pay we realized he didn't have it. He thought it was stolen and I decided to go back to see if by any chance he left it and sure enough security had it in an envelope with his name. As soon as they asked me his name and said they had it I was surprised by the wonderful people that work there. Enough on the employees, those views...amazing. Anywhere you walk you will see forever. Try to go when it's sunny for the best pictures. We paid extra for the virtual ipad to see what we were looking at but I don't think it's really worth the additional $15.

What a view. The whole experience was amazing. The lift in itself told a great story of the location and was brilliant with the audio visual interaction of the lift - you simply cannot explain how good it is by words - you need to visit.The view on the top was simply stunning as well, and you get a brilliant view of the whole Harbour area from the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty and round to the view north up Manhattan.We visited around 9am and my suggestion would be to visit early as will get busy. Over priced coffee and cakes mind!!

Amazing building, terrible execution by company running observatory.. The building is stunning and sturdy.If you are even remotely claustrophobic, avoid at all costs. You go up to the top and are forced to watch a really long video before they allow you to go through a series of bottle necks to where you can finally relax and enjoy the view.Just an FYI, I have done the Sears Tower Observatory, John Hancock Tower Observatory, Tapai 101, several in Tokyo, several more in HK, and LOVED every one of those.

Not worth. Have visited Empire State and rockefeller before. Arrived here with higher expectations. The view is not so amazing. The glass windows are not made of non reflection glasses. So all the photos taken had reflections.

Purchase tickets in advance!! . This is a nice place to look out and see New York, but it is very crowded with a lot of people. Which was likely due to it being after a holiday. Make sure you purchase tickets ahead of time because they sell out really quickly. They have a VIP option that will get you in quicker so you you don't have to wait outside. The only complaint is that it makes it seem like there is an app for your iPad to go along with the observation but you have to get one from the top of the deck. The elevator is a nice and smooth ride with a nice mini movie while you are going up.

Hustled at 102 Stories. At One World Observatory, you're hustled, hassled and overall robbed, to hand over your cash more than you are on Canal Street. And this is disappointing. As a New Yorker, I expected a more respectful tone from the Observatory. For 180 degrees, you're staring straight down into the memorial pools -- a beautiful, solemn view. One that certainly should be enjoyed without two booming employees projecting pointless facts & selling the city like hotcakes into loudspeakers. Let the view speak for itself. They shuffle you from a beautiful introductory room with an incredible reveal (one that provides a chill and teary eyes for those who truly love the city) to another where they gather you 'round to rip you off for futuristic iPad panoramic technology. The idea is inventive and helpful for those new to the big apple. But couldn't it just come as a free app for your iPhone rather than ransacking excited tourists' wallets for $15 a pop? Because your $32 ticket x the size of your party just wasn't enough. This is startling especially as the first thing you see after passing through the metal detectors is a digital screen projecting the volume of tourists since its opening this 2015. Some 850,000+ on December 26. You do the math.It's not just the pointless priority ticket option (if you can spare 10 minutes, save yourself $20 and go with the general pass), gift shop that takes up too much space on the 100th floor and overpriced iPads, there is even an obnoxious sell for a professional photo op. They're willing to try to get you to buy anything. You've been herded here and there, and with tight security procedures (expected & understood), you're brainwashed to follow any employee in a blue shirt because you just want to see that damn view already.Yes, the view is other worldly. The facility is gorgeous, sleek and innovative. The design is a spectacle. And I still can't stop thinking about the big reveal. They nail it on the head in terms of showcasing the view. But all the constant, pushy "buy this, buy that" is seriously disheartening. This place should be a celebration of the beautiful city and a reminder of the important, historical soil we're standing on. Not an obnoxious auction with the "ultimate experience" going to the highest bidder.

Not Worth the Cost. Maybe it was the time of day or because we were there in December, but it was a waste of money to pay extra to cut in line. There was no line. Basically, we paid $65 per person to ride an elevator up 102 stories. We arrive on the 102th floor and they want us to see a presentation. It wasn't a presentation- they were trying to sell iPad tours. The view was great, but not worth $65. You received nothing else for the money. Then paid $16 for a pretzel, a small bottled water and a root beer. Wish we had skipped this site.

Incredible view. The view at the observatory is amazing. It truly is a 360 degree view. You can see the Statue of Liberty, bridges, the Empire State Building and all of New York. Worth the trip to see it. Reserve your tickets early!

A-maz-ing!. We were lucky enough to visit on a clear day and the views were stunning. We've visited the Empire State and the Rock and think that this is also a must. They all have such different views. Like the advert says, you really can see forever from up here. Well worth a visit.
Very bad. Didnt like it not worth the money, waste of time and dont go in evening at all. i feel U get a better view from empire state bldg.

Awesome!. Having been to the Twin Towers prior to 9/11, this visit was a special one for me. The observation deck has the same gorgeous views of all of the Burroughs as well as a fantastic downward view of the memorial pools. I would recommend to visit this at night or at sunset.

Amazing 360 degree views!!!. We visited the Freedom Tower for something to do while in NYC. We waited in line for maybe 30 minutes for reg $30 pp tickets, then another 20 minutes through security. You move through this hallway of video screens telling the story and history of the tower, which is very interesting and compelling. The next step is the elevator to the 101st floor (50 seconds to the top). More videos about the city life in NYC, then the screens are lifted and opened to this amazing view overlooking the Big Apple. The whole floor was dedicated as an observatory area. iPads are rented for $15 to give more info on highlight aspects of the city...I rented it, but only used it a few time...may be worth it to do once. There is also a restaurant if you are hungry. I highly recommend this experience for anyone visiting New York City.

I hope your not afraid of hightes!. With a exceptionally speedy elevator this place puts you on the top - literally. As the elevator moves its way up it shows you the history of NYC. That's just the elevator. If you want to know more you'll have to visit.

Top of the world!!. The views are amazing, it reminded me of the Twin towers when I went as a kid and how exciting it was to see the city from a different perspective! Definitely a place to go when you're in NYC!

Too many people at the same time!. We purchase tickets online for a dedicated time slot which really did not provide any great benefit, other than not having to purchase tickets at the entrance.Elevator ride was great. Staff were great; helpful, informative and had a fun attitude.On a real downside though...they just allowed way TOO MANY people in the observatory area, making it difficult to have easy access to any given view or take decent pictures. This complaint seemed to be the general consensus from other visitors.Many people just parked and sat themselves down in from of the windows for a long period of time. In end the overall experience was a let down as the main reason for going, was to enjoy the view.If they correct this, we would give 5 stars!

Aggressive Salesman. From beginning to end, stopped twice without choice so I cold be sold things. The presenters in the viewing area are like circus barkers giving useless information and seriously reducing the pleasure of the view..

Awesome!!. Seeing the building at first and we were awestruck - amazing looking thing and bl**dy high!! Would highly recommend buying the 'premium' ticket as we did and don't have to queue at all, outside or at security.Had no idea what to expect and even the lift was fab.... The little intro was amazing (I won't spoil anything by telling what happens) and then the views were awesome Definitely recommend more than the Empire State and I loved that too!
Anazing experience. Amazing views, good price, would reccommend going early as it does get busy. The lift experience is also amazing it feels so real. 100% would go again.

107 stories high isn't for everyone. If you don't like heights, then don't bother. It gives a great 360 degree view but dependent on the visibility. This should be done before going to the 9/11 museum.

Stunning view. Amazing 360 degree view of nyc and especially beautiful at night. Difficult to take photos with glare on the Windows but the view was amazing. Make sure you check tombs visibility before you go.
Amazing views. Wow...what amazing views!!! Wonderful views, so much to take in. A must see while visiting New York.

Make One World Observatory your first choice. When visiting NYC, you have three main choices on buildings to go up in: One World Trade Center, Rockefeller Center and the Empire State Building. Based on our experience on while on vacation in December, One World was the best and we visited all three observatories. Top of the Rock is very good and a close second to One World and Empire was a distant third. We originally had tickets to One World Observatory (OWO) on Christmas morning. Thanks to some unseasonably warm weather, the trade center was completely fogged in and had zero visibility. OWO gave us the option of going up or exchanging our tickets for another time and/or day. Classy move. We decided to try again the next day at 10AM and it was clear as a bell. Based on our experience on a Saturday, we got there about 9:45 and breezed right in with no wait. When we left closer to noon, there was quite a line. Your tickets are timed, so I don't know how bad the wait is, but I am assured it was longer than ours. Everything about OWO is well planned, starting with a high tech elevator ride and a video presentation at the top that when it is over opens into an jaw dropping view. From their you go up to the observatory and can spend as long as you want to looking at the city views. You can rent an iPad that is programmed to show you all the things you are looking at interactively ($15 extra), and they have docents giving talks and answering questions the whole time. There is a bar/cafe and a concession area up top next to the gift shop so you can have a drink in the tallest building in the western hemisphere. There is much more room to get around in OWO versus ESB, and you don't feel like you are fighting for window space. There is no outside viewing at OWO (there was at the Twin Tower) as there is with ESB, but that really didn't detract from the experience. If I only had time or money to do one building, it would definitely be OWO. Combined with the 9/11 memorial, it can make for an emotional experience.

Stunning View of Manhattan and The Rivers. Thw One World Observatory experience begins with your approach as you pass the 9/11 Memorials and the new construction surrounding the site. It was easy to order tickets just a couple of hours in advance. When we arrived about 15 minutes early, we simply waited for our tour time to be called. If you find yourself confused with all of the crowds just ask the very helpful attendants for help and directions. Videos presented during elevator rides up and down gave interesting context to the setting and history of One World and Manhattan. The stunning view at the top, once you get past the rather relentless merchandising, was well worth the ticket cost. We just ignored the extras, enjoyed the fantastic view, and stayed I as long as we wanted.

America the great!. We visited WTC and 911 memorial on Christmas Day. Visibility was zero. But it was great experience watching clouds surrounding observatory. One time we saw Tip of Empire State came out of clouds. It was amazing. The staff was friendly and very helpful. The journey to the elevator , movie and entire ride is awesome. My prayers for who lost their lives and my salute to those heroes who rebuild this land mak. I will defiantly visit again and I will recommend everyone should do so.Vijay christian.
Must visit when you are in New York. It was a bit chaotic going in as lines were long and we had to wait in the cold. But the views from the observatory was worth the wait.

Zero visibility. Zero value.. When arrived we were told the visibility is Zero.... we were given two choices: (i) wait in a line for over an hour to change the ticket for another date, or (ii) use the current ticket and go up to see nothing... we used option (ii) since we had a very busy schedule and could not waste over an hour in the line just to decide on another date which we could not commit for in any case. So we ended up with going up and seeing nothing... a waste of money and time... I'd expect that if the visibility is Zero, allow people to rebook their visit again via the web, and not force them to either (i) waste their time in standing on the long line for changing the ticket for an unknown date, or (ii) go up, just to get further disappointed and waste this money.

DO NOT PRE BOOK TICKETS!!. DO NOT PRE BOOK TICKETS!! We bought tickets the day before to save time. The next day we arrived at the OneWorld Trade Center, fog prevented us from going up to the observation deck. We tried to get a refund for the tickets, but OneWorld Trade Center don't do refunds. They do however, exchange for another day. As we were flying home the day after, this was not possible for us. We now have some cards that we can use in a years time!! We don't plan to come back to New York in the next year though!!It does clearly say in the t&c's that a no refund shall be given, this is displayed on the back of the NON REFUNDABLE TICKET!! So you have to buy the ticket, in order to read the t&c's!! I'm not aware of US laws, but I know in the UK this would be illegal let alone immoral. I'm sure it would be a lovely and exciting experience on the observation deck, it's a shame myself and girlfriend will not get the privilege we paid for. Very disappointed!

Don't buy tickets in advance. Bought tickets several weeks ahead of time. BAD mistake. The tower was socked in with fog and zero visibility. Only option iwas to change ticket for different day but with limited time in Ny this was not an option. Threw away $65. They try to upsell once you ride the elevator up.  On the bright side, the pools are inspiring in any weather.

Best view in Manhattan. On previous trips to New York I've been to Top of the Rock and up to the Empire State observation deck and this is better than either. If you have the chance, aim to go up around an hour before sunset and then wait and watch as the city lights up beneath you.
Fun experiance. This is a really cool place to visit. Everything work nice and easy.You don't have to spend alot of time in lines as in Empire State, and the view is out of this world-

Great views of New York. We booked this online so did not have to wait long to get the lifts to the top are very fast and are great , once you reach the top floors the views over New York are amazing and you can see a very long way there is also a bar and a coffee shop a must place to visit when in New York

Amazing experience. Of course we happened to head up to the top of the world on the one day with zero visibility. However, the day was not lost as the staff at the venue were friendly and warm. The restaurant/bar at the top looked like a great spot for a special romantic dinner. (Maybe next time!) My favorite part was the elevator ride up which showed you how NYC evolved over the years. I look forward ot my next visit when I may actually be able to see the city from above!

Don't rent the iPad. This was a fun adventure. Very well organized for elevator use, access and entrance and exit. It was not all that crowded but there was some jostling for the better views. I felt the iPad was not worth the rental. Your smartphone could do just as well. It was definitely and upsell. Be sure to take time to explore around the center itself. Lots of fun shops.

Amazing!. I loved the One World Tower and would highly reccomend if visiting NYC. The attraction is fantastic, modern and very interactive. I will definitely be back! (If you have a MasterCard you can gain a discount by booking in advance online)
best ever views of NYC.. From the lift to the 102 floor ~ well what can I say? Scared of heights but I managed no bother, well worth it!

Spectacular views. This observatory is fantastic, we had expedited entry on Christmas Eve . The iPad that can be purchased for $15 is very informative of everything you are viewing especially great for children! We went in for 3 pm and stayed till dusk watching a magical dusk appear as the sun was setting. Superb views across the boroughs and NJ.

Good views. We booked ahead and got lucky with the weather. It was stunning. The views are stunning, we saw sunset, unfortunately it seemed several hundred other people saw it at the same time. It was rammed full. Rammed.There is a bar, toilets, and guys doing lectures. The lift ride to the top is very fast and entertaining. Usual airport style security before you get in and this was the disappointmen, the security staff are not the highest paid and the quality reflects this, as the tray containing my camera was sent flying down the rollers I got the dirtiest look from the gum chewing half wit as I voiced a complaint.All in all, good to do, nice to say I've been up. For me, not as good or as sophisticated as Top of the Rock.
Bring your checkbook and your camera. I hesitated to pay this much ($32 per person) but in the end the views were so amazing and entertaining I would have to say it is worth it.

Beautiful view of NY and NJ. The elevator going up begins with the early life of NYC to present just goes so fast to top. The view from s spectacular we had a beautiful sunny day. They take photo can purchase it and go on net to download it. We bought 2 , one with day background and the other sun set same picture just changed the back ground,
Breathtaking . Amazing views of Manhattan and beyond. Not to be missed. The elevator ride is quick, but you're kept distracted by the video around the walls

Definitely great views, not sure the VIP ticket is worth it however.. My wife and I visited here December 24th. We purchased the VIP tickets in advance fearing we would have to wait in line a long time since it was during the holidays. I detest waiting in lines so I paid the $130 plus dollars for two tickets. However, when we arrived shortly before noon, the lines were not that long for the regular priced ticket holders. Of course, this could change on any given day. It may be better to check things out the day you want to go to see how long the lines are for regular tickets rather than purchasing the purchasing the higher priced tickets online. The view was great even though it was getting to be very foggy. We dined at the fine dining restaurant for lunch. The menu is limited. I only had a hamburger. My wife had a shrimp salad. We had a couple of craft beers and it was all very good. The service was excellent and we were seated facing out towards to city. Awesome lunch time view. I definitely recommend the experience. As with many tourist attractions they try and sell you on purchasing photographs of your group imaged in front of the new World Trade Center. Most of these are pretty lame but since we didn't look too bad in the photograph, we bought one. It will probably go in the drawer back home with all of the other staged photos we have taken over the years but if my grandchildren happen to find them 20 years from now, they will have to say Paw Paw and Mom Maw didn't look too bad. We opted not to get the Ipad's I didn't see much value in this option as I was just interested in having a spectacular view of the city, away from the crowd in the Observatory, while having a nice lunch and a couple of beers. I got just what I wanted. It was definitely one of the best lunch time views I have experienced.
Annual celebration . What an awesome view and the info provided is outstanding From the elevator ride to the top to the restaurant - highly recommend
WOW. this is a must!! The views from the top are just breath taking and the lift is an experience in itself.

Pretty Cool. The elevator ride surprised me with how quickly it went up that many floors! I've heard the view from the top is great on clear day. It was a bit cloudy when we were there unfortunately. We bought our tickets ahead of time, so we were going no matter what. We ate at the casual restaurant. The food was good, but expensive and the view was amazing. A soft drink was $5 plus tax. Yikes! A few things I didn't like. I felt like we waited in line to then wait in another line to then wait in another line to then wait in a group while they tried to sell us the Ipad program, and then FINALLY we were able to get to what we paid for. I also bought a pin when I made my reservation, but when I got to NYC I saw there were coupons all over for a free pin with your tickets. So that was a little annoying. And the last thing that really upset me was I reserved tickets for 4:00 so that we could see the sunset and see the skyline at night. I paid for them in advance. Then shortly before we were supposed to leave I get an email telling me that "due to an unexpected event" they will close at 1:00. I had to reschedule my time to 11AM. They didn't offer any compensation, explanations, or seem to even care. I feel like we were sold out to a higher bidder as I'm assuming the "unexpected event" was a private party. They could have at least given me my pin for free!

Very well done. The tour was very efficient--we were never stuck waiting around--which was great because our group of 6 consisted of 3 teenagers and one 9 year old! The elevator ride was SO cool and FAST! We couldn't believe how fast it was!! There was a great presentation when we got to the top, and then we were left to our own devices to take in the view and get great pictures! We went at night and the view was gorgeous. I definitely would recommend it and I want to go back and see it during the day as well! Totally worth it!
