It was a several minuted wait to queue to get a view without someone in front of you, a wait which was repeated every time you moved. Just too crowded up there.3) Tiny bar: We tried to go for a drink in the bar after our visit. We were four, but it was a long wait, and they seemed completely unprepared for how to manage a groups waiting to go and get a drink. Another symptom of too many people up there at any one time, but the bar could do with being twice the size.

Incredible views. The priority admission was well worth the price. We did not have to wait in lines and were able to get to the top quickly. The views are unlike anything that you can see from anywhere else in NYC!

A great experience!. We visited this on a Sunday and it wasn't as busy as we suggested. They have done a lot to make you feel really special and make it a great experience to remember for a very long time. We will come back in a few years when a few of the buildings in the same area are finished. Looking forward to it!

Very Expensive and WAY OVER COMMERCIALIZED. Too much emphasis on selling - audio/ipad a total rip off; too much space for souvenirs, too much emphasis by employees on commercial aspect.Empire state or top of the rock are better deals and less tacky. "Restaurant" food is so overpriced and barely average quality.

Simply lovely.. We were so grateful to have the opportunity to visit these special grounds. Its a must stop for anyone in visiting NYC. Once in the observatory, which is a fast elevator ride, we had amazing 360 views of the city, and opportunity to rent an ipad that had limited information about some visible sites. There were no crowds and no wait at the 9:pm ticket time. We also found that there is a lovely presenter on the observation deck to answer questions and talk you through the views. Wish I had known that before I rented the so-so IPad. The one upsetting issue was a very intimate couple cuddled up to the windows. I feel like this is still a place of reflection and that behavior might be discouraged somehow.

Thanksgiving 2015. This was a truly moving experience. While we were visiting our son in NYC we booked a visit to the freedom tower. From beginning to end it was an experience from great emotional sadness to beauty. The minute you enter you will experience the real experience and emotion from the folks that built the expansive tower. The views in itself are incredible; I imagined the people up there on that day in September, it was a difficult journey. We reserved, priority, our tickets for 3:45 and stayed for the sunset. It was a gorgeous day in the city and the sun set was spectacular! I would definately recommend reserving tickets as the line was very long the day we visited. A must see in NYC.

Stunning views from a stunning location. This is a new must-do for NYC visitors. We were fortunte to do this visit on a sunny and clear fall day and we were lucky to go at a time where the crowds were minimal. Fantatic views in all directions - but the thing we remember most was the unique elevator ride to the top in less than a minute. Do this first then go to the 9-11 Museum to complete your visit to this sacred site.

As good as a Disney ride!. I am in awe of how incredibly well done the One World Observatory experience is put together! The elevator ride is so much fun, the views from the top are phenomenal but the highlight for me was the presentation before we went into the observatory. I was totally teary eyed when it was over. I wanted to see it again and again! Wish that was possible. The new World Trade center experiences are a tribute to the fallen, to the human spirit and to America! Thank you for an amazing time touching the heavens.

Breathtaking views. The view is absolutely incredible! However, a few things to note;*queueing system is disorganized and confusing,*be prepared for a long wait *a lot of cheesy stuff along the way*the view is from an enclosed floor so it's hard to get good pictures without smudges from dirty fingers on the glass/glare from the glass.

THIS IS A MUST SEE. 102 Floors in less the a minute, what a ride. The view is the nicest in New York, you see for miles. It is good to make reservation in advance. The restaurant bar is very pricy, 2 beers and 2 glass of wine close to $100....

Nice View But Thats It. Like every other review says. . nice view, and it is. My issues was with all the other hoops they make you jump through before letting you to the observation deck. A line outside to get in the building. A line inside to go though security. Then, a line weaving you through fake rocks and TV screens with stories from contractors who built the building. Then, a line into the elevator. Then, another line at the top leading you into a theater for a video presentation. An hour after you first entered the building, you are finally able to reach the observation deck. The view is nice and it would be nice to get up to the windows except for the dopes blocking them. You see, all along the bottoms of the windows they have the HVAC vents. People use these vents as benchs and they will sit there all day on their phones texting, checking e-mails and playing games. They could care less you might want to get up to the window to look out or take pictures because they are texting the person sitting right next to them. If you must go spend the extra cash and purchase the Priority tickets and save yourself a bunch of time.

Just wow. You cannot go to New York without doing this.. You can just see for miles totally amazed.. All staff so helpful food and drink on the top and there's nothing at all you cant see.. My husband is scared of heights but this is something he wanted to did and he's so glad he did

Amazing Views, Touching rememberances.. Absolutely MUST do this! The height is manageable even for those who have fears of heights. The Elevator ride is SURPRING - wait for it! Views of the City then and now, absolutely enriching!

Great view with hidden extras. This attraction overs wonderful views of NYC. It was cheapened when we were held for a few minutes while staff informed us there were tablets that you could use to find out what you were looking at but that you had to rent them fro $15. This was a tad annoying when you have to pay quite an amount for admission

Amazing Views. Well organized entrance, friendly staff and fabulous views. However, it's arranged to maximize, maximize, maximize upselling of tours, food and souvenirs. The smallest picture book offered is $99.99. Nuff said.If you suffer from claustrophobia, the entrance portion of the exhibit might be too restrictive for you. Call ahead to see if they can accommodate you via a different route.

Mind Blowing . Being so high and looking down on the helicopters flying below is freaky and special. The view is wonderful but unless you're a local I would recommend paying the extra and getting the iPad interactive guide. We were pressed for time and spent the extra to get the VIP experience. It was worth every $ to not stand in line. The elevator ride up is so fast and with little feeling of motion it's hard to comprehend you are so high until the doors open and you see the actual view for the first time.

best view of new york. the views from the observatory were amazing and the drinks were also very nice. the elevator ride going up and down were also a very nice experience. this was an overall great tourist attraction!

An Amazing Heart-filled Experience. The entire process of visiting the One World Observatory was classy, informative, and spectacular. I brought my family from California anticipating that this observation would be special and indeed, it was beyond my expectations. The information provided on the lower level gallery-type, museum walk was an excellent segue to getting on the high-speed elevators to the 106th floor. When we exited, the suspense continued when a group of us watched a video against a wall that had the shape of buildings. This wall raised up and revealed the spectacular view. It was like being in an airplane but the viewer is in control of how long they can view along a 360 degree opportunity. It was very peaceful and made you wonder many things such as the beauty of this planet, the amazing people who were involved in bringing this to fruition, and the peacefulness of simply watching boats and ships move along the waterways. It is something that many should experience. Being that I am originally from NY and visited the previous twin towers as a youth, this visit had a personal, emotional impact that centered on not allowing a tragic event to prevent one from rebuilding and moving forward.

Stunning view with an emotional message.. A must see for any visitor to NYC. Worth the $$ to go to the top. Be prepared for waiting in line to go up the elevator. The prices in the gift shop at the top were very high, but you are a captive audience. Stunning views as I said.

Worth the money. The lift ride to the viewing floor is incredible, moreover the views from the 360 tower are amazing. Even with a fear of heights, it's worth a view. On a Saturday morning, we found the security quick and simple, with buying tickets and getting to the lift taking less than 20 minutes

NYC must see. I was so impressed with the relatively new One World Observatory. We had tickets for 9AM which I think was an excellent choice as it seemed to be more crowded when we left. The line moved smoothly and we did not wait long. The staff was really warm, organized and welcoming and one even offered his jacket for my niece while she was waiting in line. The whole presentation, the build up to the top was beautifully done, informative, tugged at the heart while not being cloying. The elevator ride takes you through the years from ground level to the top which takes the sting out of such a quick ride to the top and is really brilliant. Once to the top the views are incredible. There were lots of people yet I never felt it was too crowded. Unlike my trip to the Empire State Building I was able to see well, no pushing, lots of chance to stand at the windows and marvel. There were two really wonderful presenters who talked about the cities history and attractions and gave helpful tips. You can rent, for 15.00, an IPAD that is interactive and assists you in locating and reading about the buildings you see. We rented one for our group of 5 and while I didn't use it much my 8 year old niece did and I think it was worth it. The elevators were really not crowded. Overall I was just really impressed and felt that it was a highlight of my trip and reasonably priced. It turned out to be gorgeous weather for a late November day and a walk along the river by the tower made it all perfect.

Awesome. This must be one of the great new experiences in Manhattan. We were there on a brilliant sunny day in November. The views are just mindblowwing as nw York is laid out below. The theatre of your elevator ride to the top and the short 'formal' introduction whets the appetite before the magnificence of the view captivates you. Try and get a clear day. Well worth the effort

Security and windows, and discounts. The Security made me feel like I was at the airport. Emptying out my pockets I didn't mind. But why did I have to remove my belt off my pants. If I had beeped going through the door metal detector. They could have just used some kind of wand metal detector to see where it was coming from. And the window viewing was ok but I prefer an outside viewing like at "Top Of The Rock" or the Empire State Building. Here you get a lot of window glare and reflection. They should have made an Outdoor viewing area. I've lived and worked as a NYPD cop my whole life. I even worked down at Ground Zero 6 days after 911. You think you would had some kind of discount for the fireman and cops and their families for those who worked down at GZ
Awesome view.. Arrive early if you don't want to have to wait to enter. We arrived at 10:40am and were able to enter upon arrival. By the time we left, there was a line to enter.

Awesome overview of city. So much easier than Empire State building and what a view. Got there by 9:30 for our 10 tour time and got right in. Was able to wander around view floor for as long as we wanted to. Love the interactive iPad to learn more about everything you see.

Spectacular Views - Great Elevator Ride. Let's face it ... it is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere ... so you have to check it out !! The best part was the "surround video" elevator ride. It was like time-traveling on the way up. And like a helicopter ride on the way down. (The elevator ride was my favorite part.) I was very fortunate to go on a slow day and therefore did not have to wait. Tickets are expensive at $32 per person. The observation deck has spectacular views. Unfortunately so many inconsiderate tourists decide to sit on the ledge around the perimeter windows as they play on their smart phones, it makes it hard to see out of the observation windows. Go on a clear day to see the best views.

Reach for the stars. Excellent views but is quite expensive. There is a cafe at the top which was nice. Staff are nice and helpful. You can borrow an iPad which helps you look at landmarks. This an additional $15 at the top.

A building with a view. We have visited NYC many times and were fortunate enough to go to the observatory in the World Trade Centre just a year before the awful events there. The views at the time were unparalleled, so we were really keen on this trip, the first for 10 years, to see how it's shiny replacement would stand up.I booked online tickets in advance, the standard $32 ones after having read tips on TA, left it until the last moment having checked out the weather forecast to try to get the clearest day possible on our stay. We were lucky, not a cloud in the sky, and after the elevator trip up (recommend having your video ready) we were shown through to another room which ended in a real spectacle, I won't spoil it, before being shown through to the observatory.The views, as you would expect, were stunning. Our tickets were timed for 3:15, there were no queues to get in, no hanging around but as per another reviewers comments, I chose this time as sunset was due just after 4:30 so we stayed not only to get the daytime shots, but also to watch the stunning sunset, just beyond the Statue of Liberty. This is a great tip (thank you reviewer) as you could purchase sunset tickets in advance but these were significantly more expensive.We left before full darkness, so got no nighttime shots, but there was no time limit to how long you stayed so could if one felt inclined, perhaps grab a coffee and bit to eat in the cafe first?!For the regular standard price tickets, I thought it was good value for money, although I don't think I would have apaid for the sunset, nighttime or expedited ones, or perhaps we were just lucky at the time of year we visited.

Not to be missed on a clear day. We walked from Little Italy on a clear brisk morning after a stormy night. We bought tickets on line for the first elevator time 9 am. The view from the circular observatory is.obviously unique qnd the friendly knowledgable guides are a bonus feature

Born from tragedy, this is an amazing place to go.. It was always my intention to visit the sight of the horrific attack in 2001. I have always wanted to pay my respects and finally go to do so in Nov 2015. I had seen that the One World Tower was a tourist attraction for its observatory before flying out but felt that it wouldn't compare to the Empire State or Top of the Rock, so we discounted it from our plans.How wrong we were!!!We hadn't intended visiting the tower but so glad we did. It's a little cliché at the beginning with some typical American flair as you work your way through to the lifts. Then the lifts themselves are something else and a ride all of their own. I wont spoil it but they are fantastic and very swiftly get you to the top. At the top there is some more glitz and flair which, when taken in context of what happened, I think every New Yorker has the right to be proud of their resilience and accomplishments since 2001. After this and the revealing of the view the rest of the time you are left to your own devices to wander around a 360 degree utterly amazing view of New York. They even have a café up there so you can chill with a coffee and enjoy the views.Having done the Empire State building on this trip too I would definitely recommend this to everyone. We were very lucky with almost no queue and when we came out the queue had grown quite a bit more but still worth it.The value is excellent too and over half the cost of Empire State and significantly more organised. So glad we did it and would recommend to anyone. Just make sure the weather is OK as the view probably wont be so good in bad weather.

Disappointed. Pre bought tickets. Visited with our son who was on crutches. Stood in queue outside at allocated time. Took 20 minutes to get into building. Down stairs to security. Took 15 minutes to get through security. Took 20 minutes to get to elevator. Forced to watch video for 5 minutes. Forced to listen to iPad sales pitch for 5 minutes. Eventually get to see great views marred by dirty glass and reflections. Gallery shopping area crams space. 2 NYC tourist guide locations block best views north and south. Cafe has poor quality expensive food and stand up eating only - our son was given a chair but his head was below the bar table height so had too eat off his lap. Worst skyscraper observation experience on the planet.

Amazing views 360. Really fast ride in the elevator, your ears pop. Amazing views from the sky to all New York city buildings (360 experience). You get nice pictures but in some areas you get to much light reflection from the windows.Son enjoyed the I pad experience, you can tap on the screen to learn about the things in NY and their history.

Just okay. Very busy and long process to get in.. The process just to get into the Observatory is complicated. First you buy tickets (for a specific time), then you line up outside and wait for your time. Then back inside and down stairs for another long line through security. There are no signs or commentary about what to expect. The elevator ride up is the best part. Very cool video showing the changing landscape is shown the entire way up. Once upstairs, it wasn't anything special. I've been to a lot of very tall buildings (CN Tower, Eiffel Tower, others in Vegas etc) and the One World Observatory was not nearly as special as I expected. The process for getting up there took longer than my wife and I actually stayed up.

amazing views. we visited 10 am monday morning and went straight in, just one other couple in the lift.(big, big lines of people as we left) listening to the testimonials of those involved before going up was quite emotional, after travelling in the fastest ever lift the views as expected take your breath away. Handy tip ....book monday on a mastercard and get a discount!

Super views. Admission charge is $32 each but we found we could spend as long as we wanted in the viewing gallery. Luckily we didn't have to queue for long at the entrance as we went in the evening. The staff are friendly and freely give information about the sites in Manhattan. The building is truly amazing and the lift (elevator) popped everyone's ears because of the speed of assent and descent. Would love to go back.

Interesting and great views. Very interesting and put together nicely, the only downside here is that its over priced to buy gifts etc making money out of something which in a perfect world should never of existed is quite off putting especially at the foot of the tower are the memorial pools, still at least I can say we've done it.

Tourist trap, incredibly disappointing . I'm 33 years old, I've lived in NYC since 2004 and have visited most of the major tourist attractions in the city. With family in town, I brought them to see the new One World Observatory. The experience started off promising, but was largely disappointing. After a length security screening process (understandably), that was more thorough than most airports I've visited, you then pass through a bedrock-surrounding passage to the elevator bank. You are presented with various facts about the building and the construction process, as well as testimonials from some of those involved in the creation of it, which is fascinating and builds your excitement. It has a very Disney-esqe feel for a queue. The elevator ride to the top is exhilarating and well done. Then you are corralled into a room and see a presentation with fantastic imagery of NYC with an eye-opening surprise glimpse at the end. Up to that point, I was starting to feel that the $30+ that we paid for our tickets may have been justifiable. From there, the experience greatly diminished. At this point, everyone is anxious to see the views and instead of permitting this, the staff practically forces you to take a picture in front of a green screen (that, given the price, there is no chance you will buy) and then tries to pitch you to rent an iPad that points out all the popular attractions for an additional $15. You then need to bypass the restaurant and souvenir shop before you can finally approach the unpolished and heavily smudged glass to take in the "360 views". It is hardly fair to call this a 360 view (as they advertise), given that at 2 strategic viewpoints they have placed these circular monitor structures that make it impossible to actually take in the view behind them. Also, most glaringly (and unexpected for many), there is no outdoor platform to take in the view. This stands in stark contrast to the two other most well-known observatories in the city, the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock, both of which have outdoor platforms. As well as in contrast to the previous World Trade Center which included an outdoor observatory platform. This was perhaps the biggest disappointment for many, including me. Ultimately, I was left with a feel that my beloved Yankees (which own One World Observatory) had done everything they could to squeeze every last dime out of the tourists and locals alike, that pay tribute to and take in the views from the location where New York has strived to overcome the greatest attack this nation ever faced.

So nice to be able to experience this view once again!. What a treat to finally be able to go up to One World Observatory to get the birdseye view of NYC. They really did an exceptional job with planning for getting so many people up to the observatory quickly. It's also spacious once you arrive so plenty of room for lots of people to walk around and enjoy the view from every angle.My only negative is for the visitors. I was surprised (shouldn't have been the way society has become!) at how many people decided to just lounge in front of the windows with the best view so they could keep their heads buried in their iPhones rather than enjoying the view, or more importantly, letting others enjoy the view. It is my hope that One World Observatory will eventually place signs on the areas in front of each window to not permit sitting.

Wow. . What a view! Amazingly fast and joyful ride to the 102 floor. (Hint:No nausea experienced). Elevator is a different experience going up, and going down on the entertainment. Amazing views as you walk down on the 100 floor. Go!

Best View in New York. What an experience starting with the visual history in the lift, continues with a fantastic audio visual introduction with a jaw dropping finale. The not to be missed views from the platform are the best you can get of New York without flying in a helicopter.
WOW. Fantastic views of NYC. Very worth it. 360 degree view. Breathtaking. With every minute of it. Book ahead, print your receipt and you're ready.

Great view of Manhattan. Got VIP tickets and no waiting , got straight in ! We arrived right when the sun was setting down. Saw Manhattan light up ! Excellent view. Now I had my GoPro and set it up close the the windows and shoot one picture every 5 secs .. got a nice time lapse clips... just one thing if you plan to do this get a cupboard around the GoPro to avoid getting back light on the pictures. Nice experience top place to visit in New York (do not forget to go to ESB and top of the rocks)Also when you arrive at the top and get out of the lift (there is a nice projection while you go up) there is another space where you wait and a short movie on NY is played get you camera (video) ready there is a big surprise !

One World Trade Center in the Fall. . We enjoyed looking around from 100+ stories. Granddaughter like the I pad experience. Lunch was good up there also. We walked around and looked in all directions. Certain areas were a little crowded but still enjoyable. I miss being able to go outside like you could at the other trade center.

Fantastic building. Fantastic building with fantastic views all round. Does not seem too busy and we were there at 6pm. Amazing to look down at the footprints of where the twin towers were. A must if your visiting NYC.

Its worth the trip. The view is just amazing! I came the night before Thanksgiving and it was quiet. The views are just breathtaking. You could see the whole city and all the way out to the far reaches of New Jersey and out to Coney Island. Nice to do once while you are in New York CIty. Avoid the VERY overpriced gift shops and picture taking that they want to do for you.

Do It At Least Once.... The elevator ride up could be interesting if they put the action above head level - can't see anything with people in the elevator. I was complaining in line (to my fellow traveler) about having to watch the movie before you get to go into the observatory (I usually wish you could skip all of that at places). The end of the movie is pretty awesome. If you go, you'll know what I'm talking about (no spoilers!). Views are great - as expected. But, I don't think I ever need to do it again. I prefer ESB and 30 Rock over WTC actually.If you can afford it, splurge for the anytime tickets, which automatically allow you to skip the lines.

Nice view but bad for photography.... I'd still recommend going to the observatory for the views but the reflection off the glass was a bit annoying. I loved being able to see all of Manhattan, New Jersey and the rest of the boroughs! The views truly are breathtaking! Definitely worth the money. I went right as the sun was setting so I got some day and night pictures.

Overpriced and over rated. I expected to see more. Extremely long line ups. Very over priced. You rushed in in groups based on the time on your ticket. Go through security check just like immigration. Go through some dark tunnels without tour guide listening to a video that repeats itself every 2-5 minutes. Take a fast lift to over 100 floor to see what I went there for requires me to rent their tablets to see the pic. Shops has items with one world name on items. There was a restaurant there too. I didn't eat there it was too expensive.

Great views of the city. We visited with our friends in mid November. The whole experience is great from the lift journey to the top followed by the short film when you get to the top. The views are breath taking and give another perspective of the city compared to the empire and rock observation decks. There were no queues we bought our tickets on the day and were straight in and straight up to the top. A must visit.

Amazing Views. An excellent experience end to end, starting from the videos on the elevator, the videos on the "wall" and when the screen goes up and you see all the skyline is something awesome. Nevertheless, in my opinion, Top of the Rock has the best views in NY, this is something really amazing.

Amazing view, unfriendly organization . Well the view is just awesome, so you want to go up. But be prepared for standing in line for tickets, standing in line for the elevators, security check, standing in line for mandatory presentation, standing in line for mandatory picture taking and a small presentation about the tablet viewing service they got.

It's a long way up. Wow! What an incredible job they've done on this new building and it sure is a ling way up.Similarly priced to the Rockefeller Center but 30 extra stories. And everything was easier and quicker than the Top of the Rock. The queues moved quicker, security was easier and quicker and the lift to the top was quicker too.And the views are just amazing! You really are on top of the world when you visit the One World Observatory.Definitely worth a visit, I would go again without hesitation

A must do!!🗽🗽🗽. This was an amazing experience the lift ride alone was amazing and so fast!! The show before the screen disappears was fab and the views all around were just breath taking- we paid for the use of the iPad which you can aim at your surroundings and you can zoom into with a commentary - loved it loved it!!

Don't waiste your money go to the Empire State Building instead. If you want to fell like you are going to be sold something ever other minute this is the place for you. After going up the elevator which was one of the best parts of the "tour". you get to stand a watch a film which shows shots of NYC. When the movie is done the screen goes up for literally about 1 minute and you get a nice view. Then you get herded into a large room all the windows are covered on purpose so you have no view. They try to rent you Ipads. . Then you go up one floor where they ask how many people are in your party and take your picture in front of a blue screen. So they can sell you a picture later. Then you have to either go through or around a cafeteria so yo can finally get a view. The is of course the gift shop. When we got down stairs My wife and I went to customer service to complain about constantly being marketed to . His deck is attached to the people selling the photos. Literally with in 5 steps from his desk in side the building there are people giving you a "gift" , which is a discount coupon to a clothing store.There is no mention of 9/11. There is no reverence at all for the space. See the 9/11 memorial out side .

Good, but.... ... a bit over-commercialized and the windows reflect so much that almost every photo has some other person or the metal from the vents below the windows in it. For better photos, go to Top of the Rock.

Epic!. This was our highlight on our second time in NYC. We had heard good things from a friend - but truly wasn't expecting it to be as amazing as it was! We pre-booked VIP tickets & they were more than worth their money!The technology is outstanding! I have an inner-ear condition & worried I would be affected by the lift - you do go up to the top in about a minute, but it is so good - I hardly felt like we moved.You arrive into a dark room and watch a mini video clip & then they lift the screen & you see Manhattan behind - truly amazing. I was so overwhelmed! We hired the use of the ipad & it's well worth it. You learn lots from it while getting some epic photo's!Staff all lovely too! Go!!!

Just amazing. Everything was amazing about this building - it is absolutely gorgeous. My friend and I ended up buying tickets online in advanced - you have to select the day you want to go and you pick a certain time to go as well. We got to bypass the ticket line (which wasn't that busy when we passed by) and went straight to the entrance to go up to the observation deck. Once you enter, you get a quick history of New York. The elevator ride up is so cool - monitors showing you going higher up in the air, and showing how New York has evolved and changed throughout the years. Once you get to the top, you're shuffled off into an area where you go through more videos showing again how New York has changed but the really cool part is when those monitors move up and you see the skyline. Absolutely gorgeous. My friend who lives in New York and was playing tourist with me, was almost in tears. They do sell those little self-guided headsets for you to use. I ended up not investing in it. We went earlier in the day, so it the place wasn't overly crowded, so getting to a window to look out a the view wasn't too bad of a wait. So overall - buy tickets online/in advance, go earlier in the day to try to beat the crowd, and you have to go through security so make sure to not bring a gigantic purse.

An experience I will always remember. I highly recommend a visit to One World Observatory - World Trade Center. I will never forget the experience. Everyone responsible for creating and maintaining this experience is to be commended. The technical expertise and artistic vision behind this endeavor speak to the American spirit. Everything is flawlessly executed, and you will be awed.

Fantastic views no rush. We have been to the top of buildings before and they seem to pack you in like cattle then rush you round and out. Not here! It was easy to book a time slot and then were allowed as long as we wanted to walk round and enjoy the 360 views, there is even a cafe up there. The views were amazing, being down town the only view you didn't get was of Central Park. We had a really clear day and could see for miles, you must go up this building if no other.

Amazing View. I didn't plan my visit to One World Observatory. I was staying nearby and walked over early one morning. I had a short wait but the line moved quickly. The tour begins as you head down to the bedrock level. Videos offer portrayals of the many people who helped "create" this magnificent structure. Elevators whisk you to the top. The panoramic view is breath-taking.

Absolutely fantastic. We came from the Brookfield Place and took the brand new underpass! What an experience: all brand new, clean and extremely well designed. You feel like on another planet. The pre-booked tickets worked extremely well. We were there 20 minutes too early but they just let us pass. The elevator is a box with TV-screens and gives you an exciting Manhattan time machine through the centuries. the sightseeing is very impressive. Soon I will have lunch there and will write a review as well.
Unbeatable view. The building itself is really nice, great design. Inside it is also very nice, with a lot of marble and very spacy. The elevators are an attracktion an sich and the view is great.

Pretty amazing. I bought the tickets online, it saves alot of time, the elevator is amazing, the movie is great. The observatory is indoors and you can see 360º of Manhattan on glass, it is a better experience that the Empire State and tied with Top Of The Rock

Between this and the empire state the views are awesome. Visiting New York for a long weekend we are taking in several sites and this was one we liked. Between this and the Empire State Building, Awesome views.

If only the weather had been better!. What an amazing building! Everything was exciting from entering the lift to arriving at the top of the building. The only downside for us was the poor weather, but no one can control that!

The Best Views Go On Forever. A must! Very good value only $32. Expect this whole experience from arrival to departure an hour. They dont explain there are a few treats before you shoot up into the sky. Once at the top you want to have a latte and croissant (at least... or a beer) and just take your time, taking it all in. It is awesome. Looking straight down into the 9-11 Memoral is very emotional. Pay your Respects and go.

Fantastic experience. Having been to the observatory at the WTC, I wanted to go and experience this new tower. It was a great experience. The staff are pleasant, particularly the young guy when you step out of the lift!! He had a great sense of humour. Once up there, you can spend as much, or as little time as you please looking around. There is a small cafe/restaurant and a souvenir shop too. Well worth s visit

Absolutely spectacular. What an incredible experience. Something I will never ever forget for as long as I live. It's hard to pick out ONE highlight from my week in NYC, but if you pushed me, this might really be the one. Seeing the Statue of Liberty from the top of One World Trade Centre was a profoundly moving experience. A stunning feat of engineering, and an emphatically defiant statement to the people who did what they did a decade and a half ago.

Breathtaking view. Admission is rather expensive, but basically coincides with the prices of other observatories. In the case of One World, the observatory have been designed from the start of construction of the building, this allowed him to make it comfortable and organized. However, I never understood why they put a device in front of the glass with the best angle into the city. Please notice: the staff was so rude in the lobby.

Annual Family Trip. Great views - not too crowded. Ride up is neat and fast! Be careful if you get motion sick - when we got off the elevator it was like being on a boat! It was very warm in the there even tho it was cool outside. Great views and a wonderful way to see the city .
Thoroughly Enjoyed this.. Brilliant views - fast lift. can use interactive viewer when at the top which helps point out buildings and places. Fab views of the Hudson and all over.

Most amazing view EVER. This is the city's best view, period. It was a very well run observatory. You could see beyond far. I could have stayed all day long and admired the view. It's something that can't be put into words.

World one Tower. Despite the circumstances this was built, Totally impressed with this building ,Recomend pre book saves time.What impressed me was that when you get in the lift ( which I think takes 45 seconds to go 104 floors)Also in the lift you have a 360 degrees fil of New York thru the ages absolutely brilliant.Well worth it

Amazing Experience. Wow, wow, wow. The views are wonderful and the floor to ceiling windows do the cityscape justice. So many wonderful photo opportunities but take some time put down your camera and phone and just enjoy

Don't miss it. What a wonderful memorable experience. From the man on the ground at the reception taking our entrance fee to the staff at the top, everyone was pleasant, helpful and very patient.We went about 10am and there was no queue. It's well worth renting the 15 dollar piece of kit ( ipad type tablet )that allows you to see all around Manhattan and names most of the buildings. We passed ours on to a couple as we left who hadn't rented one.That is perfectly acceptable with the centre.I don't want to describe the experience in detail , as that would spoil it for your visit. For me, the Freedom tower was the most memorable part of my New York trip.
Best Views by Far!. Absolutely amazing views of everything. I definitely recommend going here over the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock, if you can only choose one. Worth the money!

Breath taking. We pre booked our tickets and it was well worth doing so, we got fast tracked so no queuing the lift takes 60 seconds from bottom to top and make sure that when you enter the lift have your back to the doors so you can both watch and video the story shown on the back wall of the lift as you go up. Once out and before you go out to the views you have a 5 minute presentation along a wall and then what happens takes your breath away ( not going to say what happens as would hate to ruin the surprise) once out the views are breath taking and on a sunny day you can see for miles . This trip is worth every dollar

A "must see " in Manhattan. Simply a great experience. Wonderful staff who keep the crowds moving .They have it down to a science . We had 3:00 tickets and they took us right on time . The elevator ride up was very cool and during the ride to the 102nd floor they showed a timeline of New York dating back hundreds of years .The presentation upstairs was well done. The view was great and we happened to be there on a very clear day. A bargain at 32.00.

Amazing views. We got there about 10.30 on a Sunday and only waited about 5 minutes to buy tickets there. The day before the queue was nearer an hour at 4. Would be worth to buy online as you get an allocated time to go in. Once in security was very good. Nice walk through with lots of info on the building. Once up the views were mind blowing well worth the money. We went on clear day and could see 20-30 miles. It was also nice that you could spend as long as you wanted up there, did not feel rushed in any way.Only down side was that they wanted to charge an additional $15 for an iPad to show the landmarks. Would have been nice to have this included in the price. But we declined and it did not spoil the enjoyment. Also they have guides walking about to answer any questions. Overall a highlight of the trip

Awesome views of New York City & surrounding boroughs. Not to be missed! Book online if you can before you go taking into account the local weather forecast. We booked the week before we traveled and the forecast was "spot on"-not a cloud in the sky which was not bad for a November day.We got priority access tickets which probably weren't needed at this time of year but would recommend for busy holiday times. Lift (elevator) to the observation floor was very quick but interesting computer generated visuals on way up and down. The views were awesome (a word we picked up in NYC). Plenty of photo opportunities. Nice loos!! Refreshments available and good gift shop. Prices to suit all budgets for gifts and food.

A Wonderful Adventure. There are no words to describe what a beautiful sight this is. My family and I had a wonderful time. There was no waiting in lines, the security was fabulous, and the views were out of this world. We especially liked the first part when you got of the incredible elevator ride.We had our daughter in the first World Trade Center and this time she along with her children and husband were just as amazed. The pictures that we took will be life long memories.The tour guides at the top were very informative, knowledgeable and extremely friendly.I highly recommend visiting the One World Observatory
new WTC Observatory no good view.. The big glass wall generated lots of reflection at night. no good for photography at all. won't visit it unless they build an open view area.

Fantastic view of New York. My husband, daughter, and her boyfriend visited One World Observatory on Saturday. It was the 2nd visit for my daughter and I, and the first visit for my husband and daughters boyfriend. The views are amazing...well worth the time and effort to visit. We purchased our tickets online for a 4pm enter so that we could watch the sun set over the city. It was a clear day and watching the sunset from the observatory was fantastic. Visiting One World Observatory is well worth the money...DO IT!

Great Views!. The new observatory is a great place to take you family. Order your tickets in advance if you're sure the weather will be clear. Food is availabel for snack and a restaurant serves food. You still need a ticket to the top to go to retsuarant. There are two levels at the top. 360 degree view from the top. There is a gift shop (of course!). Elevator ride up is kind of cool. Stop by the 9/11 Museum next door.

Breathtaking view of the Manhattan Skyline. The One World Observatory is a Fantastic experience for all travellers to New York City. The views are sensational with the introductory experience of the elevator ride & screen show preparing you for the vistas that really capture the full visual essence of Manhattan & the surrounding boroughs. I took the Downtown E subway making access to the One World Observatory a breeze. Great experience and one to treasure. All observatories are different, but this one certainly captures the essence of New York.
Amazing views. Breathtaking views of an amazing city, elevators to the top are a bit interesting if your not good with heights or lifts but worth it for the views
Surreal. So high that I didn't feel like the things I was looking out at were real. The elevator ride on the way down made me feel like I was in Charile & the Chocolate Factory

A bird's eye view of the city. We visited on a Sunday morning at about 9:30, which turned out to be a good time to go. There was no line at all and as it was a clear day, we had a great view of the city. After exiting the elevators on the observation deck, I took up the offer of renting out an iPad for $15 that matched the view to what I was seeing outside. It had audio narratives of the various sites in the line of sight. The views from the observatory do not disappoint. The only kind of negative thing about the visit was the elevator ride. They show a 360 degree CGI experience. Going up to the top, the show was cool, though on the descent, I thought they were getting a little over the top with the special effects.
amazing views. Well worth the money. We arrived at 10 am and this seems a good time as not too busy, it was getting busy when we were leaving.

Put on your definite list of things/places to do!. This is well worth the money; what an amazing building with the most wonderous panoramic views over New York. The lift to the top is something else - don't worry about leaving your stomach on the ground floor - its a really smooth lift to the top in such a short time.We loved it!

Very well done--excellent staff. I would recommend buying your tickets online in advance, no matter when you plan on going. The elevator ride to the observatory is so smooth, you can't really even tell you're moving. The short film at the top is good--wait for the end of it! So amazing and unexpected!!!!!! You can spend as much time there as you want. I think hubby and I spent about an hour. Amazing views from all sides--take lots of pictures and hope for a clear day. Great experience! It's right next to the 9/11 Museum and Memorial, so if you're doing those, spend another hour and do this, too.

Expensive and disappointing. Very expensive entry fee ($32 per adult) and pretty rude staff (although it is New York I suppose). Impressive elevator ride up to the 102nd floor and the 360 degree views are lovely, no doubt, but there is no real sense of height as everything is behind glass. Some good photo opportunities but, again, they look a bit naff with glass reflections in every picture. Doesn't compare to the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock.

Good for kids, not afterwork drinks. Went after work to meet up with some business partners, so I wasn't very interested in the museum or the exhibit that accompanied the $36 elevator ride up to the observation deck. The elevator ride through time was pretty cool, but again, would have been nice to have an option for people who just want to dine or grab drinks up there without having to pay for a tourist attraction.View is incredible though, worth it if you haven't been to the Top of the Rock or Empire State observation decks. But in my opinion, you see one you see them all.

Make sure to pick a clear day. A fantastic view when weather permits. It IS worth it, but don't take the iPAD - it doesn't add much to your visit and will steal andother 15 bucks from your wallet. Try to get there early to avoid long lines.

Wow. Don't miss going up to the One World Observatory on a visit to NYC. The views are amazing and I'd definitely recommend going for a drink in the bar on the 102 floor. There's no need to book the staff are very friendly. Would didn't eat by the food looked and smelt great. We went up around 3pm and spent about 2hours there, watched the sun set and the lights of the city come on. Magical!

Disappointing!. When you reach the top of the building, you get a 3 minute presentation and then they open the curtain to reveal a wonderful view!! BUT, they then lower the curtain and make you go to a lower level!! You are then subjected to a sales pitch (hard pressed) to rent a viewer that is not necessary. The actual viewing area is lower than the initial one and you do notice a difference. The refreshment/restuarant area has super expensive items as does the gift shop. I was disappointed and wish we could have just stayed on the top level and looked around. The price tag was high and not worth it.

Amazing views. Wasn't sure if it would be worth paying the money to go up, but it was well worth it. Amazing views of the entire city. I stayed about two hours and easily could have stayed another hour if I were alone. I went a few hours after the 9/11 museum. May be a good idea to go in the later afternoon and wait for sundown to also take in the beautiful skyline lights. The elevators are really cool, like a Disneyland experience with changing screens depicting the changes in landscape over the decades. I get motion sickness so I had to close my eyes, but I loved it until my stomach started turning!
Nice view. View is very nice (specially at night) but for those who have been to Top of The Rock before, nothing beats that! One World is nice too tho.
Great views!. Get fantastic photos of NYC - Brooklyn Bridge, Statue of Liberty, Empire State Building, etc. The elevator is amazingly fast and smooth

A wonderful experience on a clear day. My wife and I went to see this attraction late in the afternoon on a clear day. The elevator experience to the top - 102 floors- is amazing. It shows a video of NYC from its beginning as grassland through the early settlement, development of buildings to skyscrapers ending in the present day. Once at the top you are guided downstairs to the discovery level - floor 100 that gives a 360 degree view of the city. We had a really amazing view of the sun setting and the many landmarks. An exciting experience well worth the $32 entrance fee, $30 for seniors

Ok views. We had the tickets where you didn't have to specify a time, personally i found the tickets very overpriced. Also when you go up there is an iPad that you rent for $15 to show you what buildings you are looking at - we both agreed we thought it was a waste of money. The views are ok but i think there are better views of NY (particularly from the rooftop of Z Hotel in Queens, the promenade at DUMBO in Brooklyn and the Strand Hotel in NYC which are all free).

Majestic views. It is very expensive ($32 per adult), but it is really impressive. The faces and voices of the builders are meeting you at the entrance. Then you will ride a magic elevator which will take you to 100th floor in 60 seconds. During that time you will see pictures of changing and rising Manhattan from 17th century to modern times. Then you will see a movie about New York - just wait to the end to be really impressed. I had tears in my eyes. And of course the main part is observatory itself. The views are majestic. However there are no pictures with marks like: 1 - Empire State Building, 2 - Rockefeller Plaza, 3 - Brooklyn Bridge, etc. For the money you already spent you can expect it! You would be only offered to rent an I-Pad with information for additional $15. You cannot go outside, and there are no place to sit except windowsills. Keep in mind that it is difficult to take good pictures through the glass. You would be able to listen to some presentations about New York. We listened to one presentation about New York cheese cake and New York pizza, which was OK, and another presentation about building of Freedom tower, which was interesting. Overall going to Freedom Tower was a very rewarding experience.

Not as good as the Empire State Building. Fantastic views but its all behind glass so doesn't have the impact of the ESB. Still well worth a visit though (get your video cameras ready for the lift ride up)

Amazing . Been twice and both times it's been amazing. Offers different views of New York than the Rockefeller and Empire State and is much more of a spectacle. Spacious, friendly staff and well worth the money. If you're going to go to one observatory deck in New York make it this one

Superb views. This is really worth doing. The views are breathtaking - in some ways better than the old twin towers as there isn't a second tower to occlude part of the vista. The ride up in the lift is clever as the whole of the wall is a screen which shows the historical development of Manhattan as you rise. It is astonishingly quick, quiet and smooth too.

Amazing views!. Spent a few hours there and I had a hard time leaving it. Take your time to visit this if you are in NYC . Loved the pictures they got and had to buy them. Day time and night time in the background makes great pictures , nice memories!

Great Views. What a fabulous structure, I was so pleased we visited this place, well worth going to and a must do place to visit. 360 degrees views from 100 - 102 floors. They have done a brilliant of job with this structure.

Amazing view!. COST$32 eachLENGTH OF TRIPAs long as you like!! Security didn't take long to get through and once you're up on the 100th floor you can stay as long as you want! There's restaurants at the level too so you won't be hungry!You go to floor 102 in a lift which is fast but also has TV screens all around which project the history of Manhattan. So amazing, especially when you get to the top and shows the construction of the new Center. On a clear day, amazing view. To see the whole of Manhattan and its sister boroughs was great!

It's up there. As part of our visit to New York City we stopped in at the one world observatory. The ride in the elevator was worth the price of admission. Both going up and going down there is an immersive experience while you travel the 102 floors to the top.We rented the immersive iPad experience for $15 and it really helped to put names to many of the places we were looking at on the observatory floor.

One Feels Safe & Secure Viewing from One World Observatory.  There are various ticket checking and body scanning areas as one queues up to ascend to OWO....One World Observatory. With its one hundred-two floors. it is the tallest building in the western hemisphere. Speed and clever photos are the hallmarks of the many elevators which zip up to the top in sixty seconds, and there are video displays on the elevator walls of a timeline of NYC area from decades past to the present. The photos speed by as quickly as the elevator ascends (almost to the point ) I thought: ” What was that building I just saw added to the time-line city environs?”The observatory is built that so one circles around and down to the 101st floor, a mezzanine. There on the 101st are restaurants ; one for eating standing up (at the ONE MIX)  or seated dining (at the ONE DINE) and then visitors circle down to the 100th floor for long viewing, and watching and listening to a lecturer discussing One World (OWO) and NYC.The highlights of my visit to the observatory are: viewing" below and beyond" and dining at ONE. In advance I bought on line standard admission timed tickets, and yes, there is a  discount for seniors. I knew my/our day was tightly scheduled so the timed morning tickets really helped us without waiting in the outside queue. Once inside the foyer we used the circled queue to go through security which is as extensive as at airports. We felt safe, and knew not to take backpacks nor bottles of liquid (water is allowed) into One World. (There are guidelines for what is permitted to be carried in OWO on the observatory website.)All elevators zoom up to the 102nd floor where the experience begins, and one winds down a floor to the observation deck. Since we had lunch reservations we were lead down backstairs to the mezzanine area, and we were seated at ONE DINE, the fine dining restaurant with fantastic panorama views of NYC. The service was excellent, the views unparalleled, and the food* and its presentations were non pareil. We leisurely dined, viewed, and rested!* For dessert we shared the three layers of chocolate cake, chocolate mouse, and chocolate creme topped with chocolate ganache and homemade salted caramel ice cream.After sitting and dining at ONE DINE , we were recharged from our commute into the City, and the emotional visit to the impressive 9/11 Memorial and Museum. We walked part of the “High Line” up to Midtown, and “charged” through many shops for already we had (to paraphrase the program Heroes): “Seen NYC, Seen the World!”

beautiful tribute. We were not sure after seeing the twin towers built in the 70's and then 9/11 if we wanted to go it took awhile but was well worth it. The entire 9/11 campus is beautiful if you go wald over to the firehouse right across the street, the memorial to FDNY is touching tribute to the 343

Absolutely fantastic!. So glad we chose to visit here instead of Empire State, it's cheaper and the experience is brilliant. We went in late on Friday and booked tickets for the Saturday morning and therefore completely avoided all queuing! We went up at 11am, very organised and quick security process. The lift ride is great and there are some super surprises in store! We paid the extra $15 for the augmented reality ipad. You hold it up to the view and learn about the different sites. Great for us as it was my first time in NY. Wouldn't bother if you already know what everything is. We had no problem finding space for pictures and walked around the 360 degree observatory twice before heading back down. It was a beautifully clear day and we got some great pictures.

Amazing.. There's not much to say here but wow ! Simply amazing... A full 360 degrees view of the city ! And surrounding area's we visited during the day and wouldn't hesitate to visit again during the night ! This is something not to miss

Long que but worth it!. We arrived at 1.30 and booked tickets for 2.30 and were told to arrive at 2.15 which we did. By 2.30 we just got through the door but had to do security and get in the que for the lift which we didnt get into by 3.15.Eventually when you get up you are escorted into a room that shows a short movie and from there you expect to go into the view but unfortunately they take you into a shop sort of thing and try to sell you a virtual ipad tour.Eventually you get to see the view, which of course is worth it!

There are no words!. There are no words to describe the beauty of this place. It is breath taking. It is expensive however super worth it. I suffer a bit of vertigo but I couldn't not go. I was right is A M A Z I N G

Amazing Views. While a little pricey, the views are amazing from the top. Crowd control ensures that there is just enough people inside so one can enjoy the views. Before heading up there, one walks through a maze with information on how the building was constructed.There is also the option to rent a tablet for $15. It acts as a GPS and gives information to certain landmarks and buildings around the island as you see them from the observatory. One can stay as little or long as they want depending on how much information they want to read from the tablet.Having been to the Empire State Building, I prefer the views from here.

Awe!. Words cannot describe this. It is so well done. The One World Observatory experience is not to be forgotten. Skies were clear and beautiful on the day I went, but honestly, I think the view would still be extraordinary no matter what the weather. When I return to NYC, it will be at the top of my list of things to do!

Top of the World. This is a value for your buck stop. It was well worth the $32 price of admission. After you go through the standard these days security checkpoints you slowly venture towards your elevator ride to the top. The elevator is probably nothing like you've ever experienced before. Three sides of the elevator are screens which provide the illusion that you are taking a glass elevator ride all the way to the 102nd floor. Eager to get to the spectacular views you wait in a line to enter a theater of all things. Initially frustrated by this you enter an area with a screen in front of you where the video talks briefly about NYC and just when you think let's get on with this the screens slowly rise to reveal the city views below. What a great idea to introduce you to the view. Then you're set free to explore in 360 views of the city. There are several places to grab food or drink there. We had lunch and the prices were reasonable given the location. We even got to witness a wedding proposal which elated the crowd. It would be a neat place to pop the question. When you're ready to leave you have the same unique 60 second video elevator ride to the bottom.

The views are breathtaking. What a view. Everything worked like clockwork. It was very easy from getting our tickets, getting through security and finally the elevator. It's unbelievable once you get up there. You see for miles. Worth every penny

amazing building. My wife and I took our 7 year old to the Freedom Tower on Veterans Day. When we arrived the visibility was near zero at the top. We decided to go up anyway and have lunch. During a very nice lunch in the sit down restaurant the skies cleared and we were treated to amazing 360 degree views

Good because of what it is and where it is but..... Glad we decided to go to the top because of what and where this is but we were disappointed by this.9/11 memorial was superb so decided to do this also. At 34 dollars each, it isn't cheap but a great surprise awaits inside at the top and when you ride the elevators.At the top, they took us through a sales pitch where you can use an iPad that points out the locations you can see but at 15 dollars, this is extortion. Staff were ok but not overly helpful and overall, apart from what and where this is I found it pretty poor.Empire State Building and top of the rock far better and staff much nicer.Glad we did it but wouldn't return.....

Just opened this year and worth every penny.. You take a fast elevator to the top and get a short video at the same time. Another video when you get off the elevator and then the VIEW. No need to say anything else.

On a clear day you can see forever!!. This is something you'll want to do once but it is pricey. And during the summer, definitely get your tickets in advance. As mentioned by others, the ride on the elevator alone is an excellent technique of showing you the passage of time - and buildings. Well done! And of course, the view is "knock your socks off beautiful". I paid an additional $15 for the ipad that identifies specific buildings and gives you a close-up view of a smaller number of buildings. I thought that I could tap any building and it would identify it but guess that technology isn't here yet. Instead, it just identifies the bridges and most well-known buildings. Wouldn't bother if I'd known that. And don't bother w/ the cafe - ridiculous prices and it doesn't give you any better views. So just walk around and enjoy the show - there are so many great buildings to see and it gives you a great overview of the terrain for miles and miles - if it's a clear day!

Fancy athmosphere but not what I have expected. I visited New york for the second time and decided to go to the One Worls Trade Center to go up to the Observatory.The elevator is made out of TV screens and there is kind of a journey through the development of New York on display. After reaching the top there is a small show in the "Theater" and then the canvas Screen goes up and you see through floor length windows over New york. You then can make a circle around the storey. there is a gift shop etc but I think its pretty sad, that it is all inside and that you cannot go to a terrace or similar because on pictures you always have the reflection in the windows.As far as I can remeber the ticket we bought in advance on the internet was about 30 USD and I wouldn't have bought it, if I knew how it was before.

Great View to blasting New York. Look for a sunny day and buy some tickets for Sunset (recommend Sun Flex Tickets = you pay just some more USD, and get in in few minutes). The view from the top is just great and when the sun comes down, houses are shining red. Awesome !!!! just do it
Amazing. The entire experience was awesome. They make mundane things like elevator rides interesting. I regret not renting the tablet.

Great views and trendy. Perhaps we didn't go about seeing it the right way, but I expected to feel more of a connection to the events of 9/11 at the Freedom Tower. Of course the architecture and technology was awesome. Coupled with the views this is unbeatable. I was just expecting a bit of different experience.

Great view, nice video / techy education while you are waiting. On the day we visited it was very busy, so it took about 50 mins to actually get to the lift but the view was amazing and there is lots of education and things to keep you occupied during the wait. The main room is contained within glass fyi for photo ops!

Breathtaking!!!. Smooth entry, no queues. Entered the lift and suddenly you were on the move! Amazing journey to the top and soooo quick. A quick story about New York through the years and then the revelation.....the view- spectacular, emotional, surreal, awesome...all if the above and more. Very informative, no time limits you can just take in the atmosphere at your leisure. A great opportunit for some wonderful photos. We were lucky to be there at sunset, what a setting.There is a restaurant and a souvenir shop although quite prices for some things. So glad we did it on 16th Nov as weather was superb and visibility excellent. Highly recommend.
amazing building!. it is not cheap, $32 usd per person to go up, but it is worth it. Just the elevator experience is worth that.The views are amazing

Great views but very busy. We booked tickets online as soon as we arrived in NYC. It's not cheap but it's something you have to do! Cool elevator ride to the top very quick and 360 views. On arrival from the elevators there's a huge TV screen showing NY life then it lifts and you see the view. Quite welldone. You can wander around yourself and observe the views and there is guides giving free talks as well if that's your thing. It gets really busy so book in advance if you can as there is queues upon entry as airport type security in place. We went just before sunset which I highly recommend. The souvenir shop is a bit tacky in my opinion and vastly overpriced!

Wow. Just wow!. On a clear day...Having been to the Top of the Rock on a previous visit, we debated whether to go to the Empire State Building of the One World Observatory - we are so glad we chose this. The theatre presentation after the (extremely well done) elevator ride was a spectacular highlight (no spoilers!), but the view is simply stunning. 360 degrees of views to the horizon and, a good view of the Empire State Building as well! What more could one want.

Too long queues. Queue in front of building, queue before security, queue before lifts, long video projects, one floor down to the restaurant and finaly one floor down to the observatory... About 1 hour!

Best view point. After visiting Empire state and Top of the Rock this is the best! such and amazing view and the memorial was amazing!!! We stopped at the restaurant and the food and service was incredible! Would visit again.
Extraordinary place. I used to dance every week at Windows on World. It was just magnificent. Too bad now is gone but I am glad I visited often because now I can't.

Fantastic. They have done this very well! Less expensive that the Empire State Building entrance fee!. Very interesting elevator ride to the top. Free talks at the top from knowledgable people. 360 degree views of the city. Try to go on a clear day.

Trult the top of the world. Spontaneous visit to this incredible location in early November and very glad we decided to go! Our hotel in FiDi had an incredible view of the Freedom Tower and late one Friday we crossed the island and stood briefly in line just before dusk and had a wonderful visit to the top of the world ! The staff is amazing and they young people make everyone feel welcome and the wait seems brief ! I am told if you buy your ticket on line or on your phone it is even quicker. The building is amazing and the elevator incredibly unique. The two observation levels at the top are in describable and worth the $32 admission fee. There are great restaurants I am told as well but we only went for the 360 degree view and the experience. The ground zero area is a must for all visitors to the city even of one does not go to the tower or the museum.

Spectacular views of the city and more!. This observation site on hallowed ground is pretty tastefully done, although the souvenir shops off the observation deck seemed to me a bit out of place, as were the upbeat presentations of the views by the energetic young folks who sounded a shade too much like game show barkers. Having said that, the testimony of those who worked on the building is very moving, and the views themselves are incredible. The price is not cheap, but judging from the crowds, there are many who will pay it. The view of the Statue of Liberty and nearby Ellis Island is, in fact, priceless.

Breath taking views. We bought our tickets before flying to the states and chose a ticket that allowed us to go anytime on a given day with priority to avoid the queues. We deliberately chose to go around 4.30 to enjoy the views in daylight, but stayed for the sun setting to see the city at night too. Incredible and speechless. Great avoiding the lengthy queues too.

Dont eat there.. Ingrid will tell you the table you ask for is reserved even tho is not, i will never eat there again , is very very loud too , you looking for a nice sunset romantic dinner, NO not here ,not this place .
Best View in the City!. This was a cool experience going to the top of the tallest building in the United states. You have a 360 degree view of NYC and it is amazing, a must do!

Awesome views on a clear autumn night. We stopped by on a Friday evening and learned that the last tour had closed, so we came back for the 7:15 (last available) tour on a Sunday night. There were zero lines or wait times, and only handful of other tourists, which was wonderful.The views were amazing on a clear, cold evening.I wish, I wish that on the observation level there weren't any ambient lights in the room at night. I was traveling with $5k in camera bodies and fast lenses, and couldn't get a decent photo unless my glass was touching the windows. I get that people would fall and sue in the dark, but still, a guy can dream.Ticket prices seemed fair. I was irked that they tried to be sneaky and upsell the iPad observer system once we arrived - the Empire State Building offered handheld video / audio tours for free.

View is Great Service Poor. We booked our table via Open Table, arriving 5mins promptly prior to the booking we were shown directly to our table.However it was here where the wheels fell off. It was some 20 minutes before a server attended our table.Firstly we ordered some cocktails and then took a few minutes to decide on apetizer and main course.It would happen that our Apetizer arrived well before our Cocktails, to the degree we hadn't finished them before our Main Meal arrived.Our bottle of wine was presented well in advance of our main arriving, however it was well below room temperature and was not enjoyed to its full, as we were still finishing our cocktail with the main.We were sat above the North section of presentation area, of the floor below, therefore the acoustics from the noise below made it almost impossible to hold a conversation without shouting to each other.The Ribeye was very tasty and the chosen wine too. But given the delays in initial service we were quite disgusted service charge was already applied to our bill. Clearly this explains the steady service, as there is no need to rush if you are guaranteed 18% no matter how you perform..The only person on the ball was the water guy!

Glad we went. Visiting here was a last minute decision. We didn't have tickets and were not going to go if the line was too long. But they said maybe a 20 minute wait (Monday at noon). So while we waited in the outside line we purchased tickets online with our phone for the next tour. By the time we reached the front of the line -which moved quickly and was about a 20 min wait- we had our tickets and were directed downstairs and through the tunnel like entrance to the elevators and were up to the observation deck in about 30 min from when we decided to visit. We felt the introduction to the view was a bit melodramatic. We then had a forced plug for the iPad locator which my friend decided to pay for. It was somewhat helpful, but not great. Then finally we were led down more stairs where we were finally at the observation level on the 100th Floor, 1250 ft high. We loved the views and spent over an hour or more enjoying all the different vistas. Downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn are easily seen. The harbor, Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Governors Island are also great from here. Off in the distance is Staten Island, Verrazano Bridge, and Midtown. The Palisades are barely visible, but on a clear day like we had you can follow the path of the Hudson River north to them. I'm glad we went, it was a great day to enjoy the views of Lower Manhattan.
Great views , helpful staff . Amazing views from the observatory . All indoors so for me not as good as the top of the rock or ESB but still worth a look . Very little queuing too.
Fantastic Views!. This is a must see. The elevator ride alone is worth the time and money. 360 degree views from the top are incredible.

Well worth the trek down to the south end of Manhattan Island. We are fortunate enough to have been on the roof of the old Twin Towers and have been keen to revisit, pay our respects and just see what has been done.Firstly, there are some magic moments after you get off the lift and before you are set loose viewing. I am not going to spoil that with a reveal for readers here but it just about brought a tear to a 57 year old tough guy's eyes!!If you are not interested in the statutory photo opp or optional ipad guide, walk through the queues for those and get viewing. There are lots of informative and happy staff to answer questions and the floor to ceiling view leads to uninterrupted views for 360 degrees.
Loved it. Loved it, amazing views and technologies embedded in the experience – COOLMust see and the dining experience is SUPER

Fantastic view and experience. Extremely friendly and helpful staff that makes the experience fantstic. The view is absolutely splendid. Go for a cocktail in the bar to extend the stay and take in the view even more.

One world Trade Centre NY. Just got back from a fantastic trip to NY,One World is everything they said it would be.its a memorial that looks to the future.and takes the memories of those that lost there lives with you,The whole area is beautiful well done to New York.its still a work in progress,make sure you pre book to avoid the long long line waiting to get in.

Afterdark view from the Observatory - simply marvelous !. We had booked a timed reservation for 5:15 PM; with the thought of covering both the sunset and the Afterdark view. We ran late by 10 minutes (it turned out not to be a big deal); and the staff personnel directed us to the proper line promptly.The ascend to the Observatory was a quick 70 seconds duration in elevator; during this period elevator turns into a mini home-theater and plays a fun animated video. This was definitely a unique and enjoyable ride. View from the Observatory was phenomenal. We could spot the main attractions\buildings of NYC and appreciate the elevation we were in - with helicopters flying below eye-level. This place is definitely worth a visit and rest assured that your folks will enjoy for sure.

A site to remember. It was so much more than I expected. To see all of those names that line the great expanse of water made me appreciate all that I have and all that was lost that day. It is really something everyone should try and see. Very specail

You have to experience it to believe it. We visited the newly opened Observatory three days after it opened in May 2015. the staff was already well trained and efficient, the Elevator ride to the top deck is fantastic with the Historical screen presentation in the elevator, the tickets are time delayed so it wasn't crowded upstairs, the views are incredible, we plan on going back to see the city at night. There is airport level security so be ready going in, and there's a gift shop on the deck also.

Very moving, and worth every penny for the view. Words can't describe the importantly of this building to NYC, and for America for that matter. The entrance to the building takes you through a very moving tribute of those that died on 9/11 - but also those that helped rebuild. The elevator ride is amazing with how they have the walls be screens and show the history of NYC. And of course the views at the top are incredible.

Great view... Terrible service and not as 'open to all ages' as it claims. I live just outside NYC, and over the years have visited most of the big tourist attractions, the ones similar to the One World Observatory are, of course, Empire State and Rockefeller... Both of which give a far better overall experience and service.I visited One World Observatory with my grandmother on a cold day in November, by cold I mean 35f/3c with a biting wind. My grandmother had flown over from the UK to visit me and NYC.Our tickets were for 4:30pm, and said that we should arrive 15 mins early. So, we arrived at about 4:10pm only to see a long queue OUTSIDE the building. I thought 'ah they must be people waiting the buy tickets, we have tickets for 4:30 so we may be able to go straight in near that time'. I was mistaken. Upon enquiringly with the staff outside I was told that we would have to sit and wait outside and that the wait would be 'long' as it was by now 4:20pm and the 4pm queue had not even started moving yet.Now, whoever designed the entry system for this place has clearly never witnessed a New York Winter... I know of no other attraction like this in NYC where you are made to queue OUTSIDE.Now, if it was just myself and my girlfriend visiting, though I would have still been a little perturbed by having to queue in the cold until 5pm when we had tickets for 4:30pm, I would not have minded so much... But I had with me my 86 year old grandmother, who is not the steadiest on her feet and walks with a wheeled stroller... She too was made to queue OUTSIDE in the cold, nowhere for her to sit, no shelter. I repeatedly asked the staff if there was somewhere she could wait inside, but the response was negative (not just in wording, the staff did not seem to care at all).When we finally did get inside, it was clear that there was plenty of queuing space inside, but clearly they had decided that it was better to let their customers suffer in the cold.We then eventually got up to the observatory, and yes, of course the views are fantastic, but again, there was nowhere at all to sit down, we decided to get a hot drink in the cafe at the top, upon getting there it was clear that there was still nowhere to sit... And I don't just mean no free seats... I mean no seats whatsoever... Some tables, but no chairs/benches. I asked a staff member up there if they had any seats that my grandmother could sit on (by now she had been standing for the best part of an hour and a half, and at 86 that is not civilised)... The response to that question was a look of incredulity and 'I'll have to ask the supervisor'...
