So, a few minutes later a lady that I presume to be the supervisor appeared, was informed by the other staff member of our request and headed off in to the main restaurant, we assumed to fetch a chair... We assumed wrong, we did not see her again.The website says it's an attraction for people of all ages and caters for the disabled... That is simply not true... If you are elderly or slightly less a led then this is not the place for you to visit.Not only was the weather cold on our visit, but the attitude and greeting from most of the staff was cold too.All in all, well below par for a NYC attraction... Whoever is in charge here please visit the Empire State and Rockefeller centre to see how to do it properly, and put up some form of shelter for those queuing outside (or, even better, let people queue INSIDE).All in all, great views, but an underwhelming experience.

One World Observatory, NY. We just came back from New York and our vist was primarly to visit the One world Obsevatrly - World Trade Center. I very succintly, I must say it is Awesome! If you are heading to the Big Apple you must rise to the occasion, 100 floors up over Manhattan. the views are breathtaking. Introductory film they show you is really great. The employee's that work there are really awesome too. Very friendly and helpful. Buy your tickets in advance to avoid the lines. You will have a great experience as we did.

By far the best views of the city. I was excited to visit One World Observatory and I wasn't disappointed. The technology, the viewing deck and the facilities are brilliant. The time spent at the Empire State Building is basically a lot of queuing and fighting to get a good photo along with 900 other people. One World Observatory has floor to ceiling Windows for 360 degree views. Well worth the visit. The photo opportunities are endless and the views are breathtaking. My favourite viewing platform of the city. Cafe was a little overpriced, but that is to be expected. Staff are friendly and informative. There is plenty to do and see, well worth the money.

The view is the last thing they sell. Go inside to buy tickets to go outside to wait to go inside. In a traffic pattern that has different streams of people crossing over each other (by the top of the escalators) with no signage or direction.Then, after security (which I understand is necessary), behold... a fake plastic version of the Manhattan schist bedrock they pretend to line the "tunnel" (cattle trough) with. Why bother? I'm certain there was plenty of real Manhattan bedrock around. It's as fake as the Hershey chocolate "tour."The displays on the elevator ride were inspired and well done. Credit where it's due for that.Okay, we're at the top of the building. Time to look at the views, right?No. The uppermost public floor is given over to a nonsense video project and guys hawking iPads.Down one floor. To the views? No, to the restaurant.Down one floor more.Finally: After the badly managed traffic, after a battalion of GED types using the authority of their blue polo shirts to boss you around, after the fake rock, after the video tease, after the appeal to eat overpriced food and drink, they deign to let you see what you came for -- the view. By this point I was relieved it actually happened. I thought I was just going to get cattle-chuted into another door marked "This Way to the Great Egress."I wish the people who ran this concession had designed it around the actual view, instead of treating the view as an afterthought. Everything leading up to it was a nuisance. Most of that nuisance was clearly pointless, unless you're a tourist concession trying to justify its existence.There are acres of floor space one level below the entrance, where they line people up for security. The "waiting to wait" lines could be moved there from the sidewalk. The gift shop could be moved there from the observatory floor.Please rework this so people "experience" less of your concession company and more of the view of New York City. I'm sorry it's the one part of this you can't take credit for. But it isn't about you.

Spectacular. Our first visit, the whole experience was just awesome the views are spectacular and the whole atmosphere from the moment you enter is one of reflection and triumph over adversity. Suggest visiting early in the day as the queues can be long
Excellent observatory!. Excellent observatory!Booked tickets online to avoid more waiting, great views, especially at dusk.
Amazing view!. It's definitely worth paying a visit. The elevator ride was extremely entertaining and surprisingly short. I couldn't get enough of the view. A must see in NY!

CROWDED!!. I must have gone at a bad time because it was incredibly crowded and the wait was almost not worth the experience. We had tickets for 2:30, we got there around 2:15 and didn't get to the top until almost 4. The line was so slow and that was even after going through security! I have to admit that once we got to the top, I was so frustrated, I almost didn't enjoy it as much as I probably should have. The views were amazing but that was it, there really was nothing else to do. There was a small restaurant which you needed reservations for and there was a concession stand like place, but that was it. If you plan to go in the afternoon, don't plan anything else for the day because this will take forever!

Brave act oF America stand in front of world. That is what makes a nation grest. Even after demishing the twin towers by air attack by terrorists , IS stood together and faced the situation. This tower is show of strength of America. Great and just the tallest tower.One sees the Newyirk from all,angles in this observatory I think this is just a great observatoty to be seen by every individula visiting Newyork

Amazing and Wonderful!. Having grown up in New Jersey, I have always been a fan of New York City. I have not lived in the NYC area for many years, so coming back to visit and to experience the One World Observatory was thrilling. Even though there were many people there enjoying the experience with us, it was very well organized and there was no feeling of it being crowded. The thought that went into the presentation was amazing. We paid the $15 for the computer that was used for identifying sites from the observatory and learning about what we were looking at. I was so moved by the building of this structure and the innovativeness of how the elevators worked and the beauty of the building. There were employees who were available for answering questions. They are extremely knowledgeable and helpful. If you have never been to New York City, I suggest your first stop be One World Observatory. You'll get the most wonderful 360-degree view of the city. Don't miss it! It really is thrilling!

Spectacular views even if raining, a must place to visit. We went as a family of four (all adults), on a part cloudy afternoon with high possibility of rain. We decided to give it a try, and it was definitely worth it.When you buy online, you have to give an estimated time of arrival. We printed our own tickets at home, and we went through the entrance with very little waiting time.We went through a bag search and scan, then went to the line for the elevator.There were people trying to rent you an ipad, to get better grasp of what you would see on the top, and also you can choose to buy an upper floor ticket that costs extra.We decided it was not worth it and stuck to the cost for the original ticket. We don't regret it. There are also people prssing you to take pictures that will cost you so much more, but they are with bacground photos, not the real thing so we decided to bypass that, since we had our own cameras.The line went quick.mthe elevators are amazing!!To go up 100+ floors in under a minute without feeling the push (just a little pop in the ears as we were going up, but nothing to worry about, just less pressure), and we were greeted at the top with some small and quick documentaris about the construction of the building.Then the drapes or screen opened to reveal a view of NYC and sourroundings!!WOW, that's what I can say about the views.SPECTACULAR views. We stayed there for about two and a half hours enjoying the different views. You can go around the 360°. Lots of pictures. The windows were sufficiently clean to take great photos, but in some cases the reflection of the inside lights was an unwanted element in the pictures.At on time one side of the tower it was being pounded with rain and the other side was clear, a wonderful spectacle. And because of the hight of the tower and some low clouds, we could se them at level, impressive.No seats to rest if you get tired. You must seat at a slightly higher edge near the windows, but you might get some hight dizziness from being too close to the edge.Things at the gift shop, we found too expensive, but we just didn't feel it was worth to spend many dollars on things that in a few weeks would be stashed in the closet.Great experience, will go again next time I visit NYC

Must do in your lifetime!. I was unfortunate enough to miss the original twin towers. However, I made sure to visit this one, and it was quite the experience. The elevator ride to the top was incredible as you watch the landscape change throughout history, very cool. Once at the top, I started to get a little light headed, I guess being 1,776 feet up does that. But the views are amazing up there of the entire city. Would be very cool to watch the Fourth of July Fireworks from there. Make sure to check this place out when visiting NYC.

Cheesy . Cheesy, cheesy, cheesy! The views are great but the atmosphere is that of a theme park. If you're a tourist you may not mind it, but if you're a local, you will not be happy. In addition to being shuttled around like we were on line at Disney World, we made the mistake of eating at One Dine, the only restaurant there that takes reservations. It is open on one side and overhangs the floor below where the loud and hideous City Pulse takes place. It looks like the wheel of fortune with pictures moving about and has a live moderator droning on. I can't decide if that was the worst part of the experience or the ridiculous movie they make you watch at one point during the shuttling around. Then again, there was the picture they take of your group (against a fake backdrop) as you enter and the sales pitch to rent an iPad telling you what you'll be seeing -- like I said, cheesy, cheesy, cheesy!! Come on, folks, this is NYC, gimme a break!!!

Amazing Experience!. This was a great experience! I have visited the memorial a few times and was looking forward to the opening of the observatory. It did not disappoint and was well worth the wait. Great views, beautiful building, and state of the art technology. It's important to remember the events of 9/11 and this building is a strong representation of what NYC stands for and their tenacity to rebuild and offer something great to the citizens of the planet.

Not to be missed.. Amazing views make the entry cost worth every cent. The experience at sunset is very special, but don't pay the special (more expensive) sunset admission fee, just book a standard entry at the appropriate time.

The view was nice. I paid extra for the flex pay which worked out because the train was late. The only benefit to paying extra is you get to cut the initial line. For every other aspect you are one of the crowd. If you are not tall, your view will be blocked in the elevator because it is packed with people. The presentation is good but if you are up front your too close and if you're not up front your view may be blocked. The Sky view is great but there is a constant flow of people lingering in front of the windows. If you're not in the right place on the elevator ride down you will either be too close to really see what you're looking at or your view is blocked because the elevator is packed with people. Last, I purchase the photography add on. The back drop is a green screen so the fake buildings came through our heads and bodies and the see forever photography employees didn't seem to know what they were doing. When I gave them the prepaid receipt because I purchased it online, they didn't know what it was and ended up not giving me what I purchased. It was so chaotic that ?I didn't realize it until I left.

$32 per person! Okay for a one off! Very Sad too..1st Class Views!. Booked in advance, so we skipped silly dragging queues. We were shuttled quickly to a walkway presentation about the Tower, then we walked into a lift and went High, High, High! At the top was a lovely presentation and amazing views! You can't go outside like the World Trade Centre Tower back in the nineties, but it has two floors! And the best time to go is when the sun sets!..Tranquil and romantic, Be wary that the Tower does sway - but not very noticeable! It was daunting to go up at first, as 911 was such as sad day..My thoughts and prayers go out to all. Do the Tower I say!

Magnificent. This is a great tour for visitors of NYC! A great high tech way to spend an hour or so especially at night. We had family visiting from another State and this is an easy and impressive stop to make their visit memorable.

Out of the World Experience. Entry fee around $30. But worth seeing. 102 floors. Elevator takes 55 seconds. When you climb up the elevator, the elevator wall projects the images of NY city - how it transformed over centuries. The observation deck offers panoramic view of the city including Statue of Liberty. Located adjacent to 9/11 memorial. Best time to visit is night time.

Incredible view of the city at night. We visited the freedom Tower in a crisp fall evening in New York. We took the opportunity to go to the observation lounge which offers you a combination of cocktails like bites and spectacular views of the city. The drinks are OK but the food is decent but the views are absolutely worth the wait

not to be missed. this is not a cheap spot but to me really worth every penny. If you are lucky enough and in town during a nice day, I really suggest you to not loose the opportunity this place has to offer. The view from up there is just marvelous, your eyes going 360° around NYC and the suburbs. A souvenir you will take home forever.

Amazing. Visited New York previously and been up Empire State Building. Decided would visit One World Tower.  Amazing. Trip in the elevator gives a overview of the history. You understand the height against other towers. We visited at 18.00 light were on over NYC. The first view takes your breath away. If you are visiting New York this is a must see.

Terrific experience.. We had booked tickets for late afternoon on 9th October so that we could see the transition from daytime through dusk to evening as the lights come on. As we were walking around looking at the pools before our allocated time we were caught in a sudden thunderstorm. We were soaked but nevertheless turned up for our visit. At the ticket office we were advised that the clouds were so low that there were no views and did we want to postpone our visit. Of course, we accepted. I hesitantly asked whether 11.00 the next morning was available and was told that it would be ok. I was surprised knowing how busy it was likely to be on a Saturday. We were most grateful. The point of this review is to thank the amazing staff for their helpfulness which applies throughout the attraction. The views are, of course, wonderful and we were blessed with a clear, sunny day.

Amazing elevator ride, views for ever. Do it. The elevator ride to the top is worth it to see the New York skyline change over the decades. The views from the top of Manhattan, Brooklyn, New Jersey and beyond are phenomenal.

Graphic presentation right before the observatory is icing on the cake.. Standing on the top floor of the 5th tallest skyscraper in the world is an experience in itself but the icing on the cake is the interactive graphic presentation shown right before they let you go inside the observation deck. I would have paid the entire entry fees ($32) just to watch that presentation. There were lot of loud “Oooooo…..s” and “Wows!” from the audience when the presentation ended. Needless to say that the view from the top is amazing. So much so that then and there I called up my family in India and told them where I was. It’s a moment to see the assortment of lights beaming from other skyscrapers and tiny buildings placed neatly on the Cartesian plane of Manhattan Island.I would recommend to visit One World Trade Centre at night for 2 reasons – no crowd (we had tried coming here in the afternoon but there was an hour long queue to get to the top floor) and the view at night is awe-inspiring. If you are visiting NYC then you might get stuck in deciding which skyscraper to visit – WTC, Empire State Building or Rockefeller Centre. I am guessing that the view from the top is almost similar in all three of them but WTC would get my vote because of their graphic presentation and the high speed elevator which was so fast that it made our ears pop.

Book ahead to avoid having to wait for entry. Amazing views that you cannot get anywhere else in the city. We went up on a very clear day where you could see for over 10 miles. Expect lots of queuing though.Staff are very knowledgeable and helpful.It is fully accessible and a wheelchair user could manage very well alone.
amasing place. Cannot miss going to this place, Views were tremendous spent a long time up here admiring the views can see for 41 miles and it was a clear day

Nothing Short of Spectacular. Not to be missed while in New York. Pay your respects at the 9/11 memorial and marvel at the spectacle that has risen out of the tragedy of 9/11. Optimizing the spirit of New York and America, the entire complex is a testament to those who died and shouts out that we will not allow acts of terror to demoralize and defeat the ideals of freedom and democracy that the USA stands for. Well-managed, I secured a timed ticket in advance allowing me to plan my day accordingly. Note, though, that it still took 30 minutes to get to the top even though all was on time. I planned to get there so it was still light and would transition to dark. With that in mind time your ticket for 1 hour prior to sunset, minimum, and you should have more daylight to marvel. And marvel you will at the greatest skyline in the world. Even NJ was awesome. So plan ahead and have a great time!!

Great views. After coming out of Ground Zero, this was very uplifting to be able to go in here and see the videos of the building and opening of the new trade centre before going up to the observatory tower. Views were awesome and plenty of room to move around and see from different windows.

Stunning View. I had read if you're u can't see the top there is no point in visiting and because you need to book ahead I chose the flexi ticket ok it is more expensive but you can visit with in the week chosen. The view is stunning, lift whisk you to the top, you step outside and stand at a rail while scenes of New York move across screens, then the screens drop, wow!! The following day we couldn't see the top I would have hated to have tickets for then. Book the flexi ticket well worth the extra cost.

Amazing!!!. This is done so well. We had no wait to get in and were swiftly in the special effects lift, the welcome to the observatory is greAt. The staff were very friendly on arrival. I would say pay the $15 extra and get the iPad guide, this really enhanced our trip. There are staff giving talks frequently to give more information too. As it was my partners 40th we had a celebratory drink in the One bar which even though it was busy and overcast we still has great views. Drinks were more reasonable thAn expected. You can stay up for as long as you want and go freely between the restaurant and observation floor. The bar was busy but no one was in any rush to get us out and reuse our seats. Love this whole trip!

Nice view of south Manhatten. The total experience is great, the elevator ride just took less then one minute, but shows how NY changed in time.Only the windows aren't very good to make photos, it's kind of mirror.

A new must do when visiting New York.. Beautifully done this is well worth a visit. Best to visit on a clear day and do get the explanation of all the sights. Plenty of room if you go early in the morning, would probably be best to avoid afternoons.

Beautiful building!. I know NY is full of skyscrapers, but this is seriously another one you do need to add on the list to go up to! The view is just amazing from the top, it offers a different perspective from the Empire and the Top of the Rock.You are up at the top in no time at all, you are then taken into a room where a film of NY is played and then it concludes in a great way! You will have to go to see what I mean!The queues were non existent for once which was a blessed relief as they are so bad over there now. I had gone for the early slot which I would recommend and it wasn't too busy at the top which meant you had easy access to any view at any part of the tower.It is also known as the Freedom Tower as people were getting confused when we were using One World!

The best skyscraper view in ny. The view is spectacular. It is the highest spot in the city so you don't have buildings that disturb you.We bought the tickets online and until November 25 you save 10% with the promo code C21OWO.All the views are through windows, and you don't feel the wind like in top of the rock, also pictures you take have reflected lights of the observatory. I went at 6pm and I could watch the city with sunlight, at the night and the whole sunset.If you are in NY this is a must.

The most amazing views of New York. The top of one world trade centre is amazing with incredible 360 views of New York and its surrounding areas you can 'see forever'. Make sure to go on a clear day and enjoy it from the moment you go through the security checks to when you arrive back on solid ground!

Great view over Manhatten. We went to the observatory at dusk, it was a special time watching the sun go down and the city light up.The city takes on a different feel in the dark, watching the buildings come to life, and the reds lights of the traffic!There was no rush, you can take all the time you want up there with being pressured to move on. The elevator trip is a rush also!

Once you see one, you've seen them all.... What was impressive was how fast the elevators wre and - you didn't feel anything.The video visuals were impressive - but they advertise on their website that you can walk on a glass platform and look straight down to the street...Well - guess again. It's projected onto panels under your feet. The real thing is out the window! What they project is not realistic...They don't tell you anywhere about advance Observatory purchase procedure. 1. Do you go to the ticket office and check in?2. Do you go directly to the Observatory?3. If you buy a time slot and can't make it - what happens.Here are the answers you won't find anywhere:1. Do not check in. 2. Go directly to the Observatory line.3. As long as the time is not earlier than you bought, go directly to the Observatory.Would I go again?nooooooooooooo............

Woah, just spectacular. My husband and I visited NYC as a birthday present to ourselves and made our first stop the Observation Deck. Thankfully someone warned me to BUY TICKETS IN ADVANCE. The whole experience was great, very well done. If you can, go a little before sunset so you can see the views in the light and then wait for a spectacular sunset and see the city with the lights on.

Empire State Building has serious competition here. Having visited the ES building a number of times, I would say that the One World Ob. has probably better all-round vistas especially as you're so close to the waterfront. Book online for an early slot as it makes the experience that bit more seamless....skip the "pay for your special photo" option as it's a little too artificial....worth hiring their iPad option at $15 as it knows what direction you're looking and labels/describes the key landmarks in your line of sight...pretty cool. Highly recommend this slick operation.
View is spectacular, tallest building in the West. Amazing views, forget going up the empire state building or rockefeller, this is the one you have to do.

One amazing elevator ride. We're New Yorkers, so naturally we don't visit things like the WTC.But relatives arrived, so felt we should tag along.The views are, as expected, spectacular.But the elevator ride and video preview before entering the observation area are imaginative and extremely well done.

It was nice. The elevator ride up was pretty good, but you see a film going up, it's not an exterior elevator where you look out. While that would be pretty fascinating, I would expect many people would not be able to tolerate the sensory overload. You kind of get the feeling that your at Disney, because they are trying to sell you something the whole time. The $15.00 interactive tablet view finder is worth the expense because it identifies most of the interesting buildings you see. The floor panel video special effect thing was pretty lame. I rate it as average because it isn't really anything more than going up real high and looking out over the city. Granted, there are only 3 places the average person can do that, and it needs to be done, but I didn't find anything special here.

Spectacular. Wow. The lift to the top is amazing and when you leave the lift, the description by staff is excellent, I'm not saying anything more otherwise it would be spoilt for your visit. The views are out of this world and you just get the feeling of hope and a bright future.

My top NYC recommendation. If you only do one thing in your visit come to the WTC. Views are unbelievable, you are literally at the same height or higher than the helicopters. If you avoid the up sells the ticket price is worth every penny.

Excellent views-dirty Windows . We purchased the day flex tickets and it was well worth it. We jumped right to the front of the queues on the way up the building, however, it is very disappointing that you do not get the same privileges on the way down the tower, and as seen as we had paid a lot more than other guests, we feel that priority should be given to day flex customers on the way down the tower to. The views from the tower were amazing!!! As expected, but the Windows were not clean!!!!! Most of our pictures and video footage of the views are ruined due to the smeary Windows. We found this very disappointing. The gift shop offered a very limited choice but we felt items were very overpriced. Would still recommend a visit.

Well worth a visit. Having visited the empire state and top of the rock on previous trips to NYC I had always wanted to see if the one world observatory was any different. I can happily say I was impressed with our visit. We went at about 4pm which was quiet so no queue. The lift to the top was quick and worth having your camera out for The views were amazing with a full 360 view of nyc and due to the time we got to see NYC in daylight , sunset and lit up at night. Of the 3 trips the view was easily the best

Amazing sunset!. Fantastic experience. Views to remember- sunset option was brilliant!Good surprises awaiting you in lift and at top!!!Little too much selling- hire ipads for visual tour and external brands linked to, in staff speeches.Bar needs pre-booking but cafe available for all.Too many kids on my visit, but all in all fantastic experience!
YOU HAVE TO DO THIS!. The views from the observatory are just awesome as you are the highest up. The lift only takes literally 20 seconds for 100 odd floors - mental!

Windows on the World post 9/11 a Heartfelt View in the Past Present and the Forever. it is October 20 , 2015 and I decided to take my daughter Eva for her birthday On top of the world and back on memories lane for me,........ It is her birthday she is 17 today , it has been more than 14 years for me since the tragic unconceivable September 11 attacks . I celebrated my 40th birthday at WoW restaurant then and as we both go up in 60 seconds to the 102th floor I cannot help but think back and remember.... The views are breathtaking and the new windows offer a similar vista on the world below on the Big Apple with all its transformations and up in the Heavens where the souls of our human family members ascended . The One World Tower is a heartfelt experience to see at least ,Once, in your life for it is and will remain Forever part of our History Past Present and Future. PascalPicks
Best thing ever. I have no words to describe this, from the moment you board the elevator it is amazing, forever teatre is the best and the views of the city are wonderfull
Amazing views!. So glad we decided to do this! Amazing views and the elevator is awesome! Wish we could have seen Central Park, but other than that we loved it.

Great views . Beautiful views of the city even when the visibility is about 5 miles. Be sure to go during the week when the lines are aren't that long. Be sure to bring a good camera cause you will be able to capture such amazing photos.
Well worth a visit. Amazing view. Restaurant was an added plus not to mention the food was good. The elevator ride was super quick. We made reservations so we did not wait in line too long.

Nothing Special. Went inside thinking the view would be amazing, and had an amazing elevator ride up. Once you get up there, there is a small presentation and then.... THE VIEW! If you've seen other views, even the Empire State, you'll realize that this is nothing special. You are wayyy too down south to see Manhattan well.Too expensive of what it is!

Great visit to the top - read if you have any fears about going up!. My husband and I brought our kids here on Veteran's Day. Once we arrived, they were able to take us a little earlier than our scheduled time so that was a good start. We were warned that visibility was a bit limited and were told we could exchange our tickets for a rain check if we wanted to go up on a cloudless day. We chose to go up. I was VERY nervous about the elevator ride up and last minute, as the elevator doors opened, said I wouldn't go up and my husband could take the kids. Two staff came right over to talk to me. They explained exactly what would happen, asked me what my fears were, and started to talk me down. Then one of the staff a female (I'm so upset I didn't get her name - she was awesome) requested an elevator for me and my family only so that I wouldn't be embarrassed if I started to panic. She rode the elevator with me. Told me she would bring me right back down if I panicked. Once we were at the top, she asked if I needed her to stay with me a bit and made sure I was OK. I was FINE :).Despite the fact that my fears got the best of me, the staff were so kind and caring and went beyond what they needed to do. My fear was completely irrational but they never made me feel like I was being ridiculous. They could have simply let me walk away and I would have missed a great experience with my family. I came down about an hour later to see the same female staff member who gave me a thumbs up and noted that I was even smiling. I'm very thankful to her.Smoothest elevator ride ever. Couldn't believe it. And the views at the top were spectacular. Kids really enjoyed the elevator "movie" and pointing out landmarks in NY and NJ. I would go again.

Well done.. We didn't realize the observatory was open for viewing until the day before we had to leave NY, so I snagged early morning tickets. We left midtown and arrived in the Financial District via subway during the morning rush to work--that was interesting and something to experience in and of itself. The clouds were low that morning and the staff at the WTC warned us that viewing would be limited. We weren't there for yet another view, so we continued with the visit. It's a beautiful building inside and out. The elevator to the top (and back down) is a chronological visual journey, that offers a bit of context on the development of NYC. At the top, there is a snack bar, if you really need a cup of coffee while you're there. Seating looked limited, as there were many people standing. That day, I suspect so many people got snacks while waiting for the clouds to burn off--I heard people complaining about the costs. We had the windows to ourselves. Insulated by thick white clouds, we shared a powerful moment; reflecting on the existence of that new building and what it meant. I imagine the view was pretty amazing, too, once the clouds were gone. But we had already returned to the ground and made our way to the reflecting pools. It is definitely worth a visit, regardless of your motivations for visiting.

Worth it.. Went early in the morning, no queues, no screaming school kids, must admit wasn't really bothered about going here, have been up the iconic Empire State and Top of the Rock, so didn't really think this could match them, wrong, absolutely stunning views, would recommend it to anyone, but go early!
MUST DO.. The BEST! 360 degree view of NYC. What a view, what a show from the elevator going up and coming down!

Oustanding views. Coped easily with the crowds.. We had not pre booked for this visit and joined the queues which did not seem too long. Moved along very smoothly and after passing through security too the smooth lifts to the observation areas. The views were outstanding , obviously very dependant on weather, we were lucky as it was a clear sunny day. There are 2 observation floors and we were surprised that there was no time limit for the visit and yet there was no problem whatsoever with overcrowding. I guess they track how many elevators have taken visitors up and govern numbers this way. There is a food outlet and an extensive souvenir shop at the top.

Fantastic Experience, Quick yet Amazing. I would not hesitate to do it again. The views were breathtaking, and the buildup to seeing them was amazing. I also appreciated the fact that they took us through the history and future of New York's skyline.

Fantastic experience and very well organised. We had a brilliant visit on a very clear October day, the view is just stunning and so different to Top of the Rock or Empire State.Booking online is very easy, we checked the weather forecast and booked a couple of days in advance. Went at 10.30am on a Monday morning and although it was during the UK school holidays it wasn't very busy. Very, very efficient entry process with just a minute or two to wait before getting into the elevator. We spent about an hour and a half admiring the view before settling down for lunch in the restaurant. There is a cafe too which look pleasant but we were keen to sit down to eat and enjoy the view for a little longer. The food and service were great too.Altogether a fantastic experience, I would thoroughly recommend as long as you go on a clear day.
Absolutely worth visiting. Buy tickets in advance and take time for the visit. Stunning views and a great experience. There is also a very nice restaurant for lunch or drinks.
Beautiful view with surprises. A visit to remember at all times the terrorist attack, but also surprises with good special effects and with a wonderful view.

Amazing views of NYC. What an amazing job NYC has done at creating this fabulous observation deck. 360 degrees views of the entire city. We spent a couple of hours up there - could never sick of the view. Only disappointment was the prices being charged at the cafe. We were going to enjoy the views over afternoon tea but changed our minds when we saw the prices.

A great panorama. This is something that you simply have to do, if only to get a feel for how the whole city fits together. Not disappointing but for my money the Empire State is still the more impressive experience

Fabulous!. This was our third tall building (after The Rockafella and Empire) and was the most enjoyable. Slick presentation, no queue around 4.00pm, especially the lift experience (you're there in no time!). We did upgrade to have the ipad which was helpful and fun. Suggest not pre booking as checking out weather for clear day is a must!

Fabulous Views. This is a must do while in New York. Yes, they do try to hold people up to take photos but you can bypass all of that by saying you don't want a photo. Our tickets were purchased early with a timed admittance. Our first stop was the bar to get a glass of wine - be sure to ask them to put it in a plastic cup. Then we were free to wander and observe. We timed our visit so that we were able to view a truly spectacular sunset. Every view from any spot was amazing but that sunset has really stayed in my mind.
Great to visit. This is fantastic.Great videos at the start, very touching to watch A really quick elevator ride to the top and the views are really good

Perfect birthday lunch. My first trip to OWO....and only a clearer day would have made it better. Great food at OneDine and wonderful 3-4 hour experience at the Memorial and Observatory. Not 100% sure the Experience iPad rental is necessary, but we all had fun!

If you only do ONE thing in NYC, this is it, but they SPOIL IT trying to "sell" photos. Honestly - this was awesome! I'd choose this over the ESB any day...We went early in the morning, so no need to get the "fast pass" (and pay the extra $$$ for it). Walked in, paid, walked through the exhibits, got on the elevator and Wowwwwww! The elevators are AMAZING and I wish I could ride them over and over to watch the changing scenes on each wall. Check YouTube for a video of the elevators!When you get off the elevator, you're put into a queue for the "movie" they want you to watch. It's scenes of New York and it's a bit overwhelming, but then the wall where they're showing the movie raises up and suddenly you're looking out of the 102nd floor, to the South. Their hashtag #seeforever is so aptly chosen!After that moving experience, you're herded in front of a green screen to have your photo taken, then rushed to stand in front of a counter where the charismatic and engaging young folks try to get you to buy the use of an iPad for $15. After that, you're allowed to wander freely. There is a restaurant, but we didn't eat there.There are also a couple of other exhibits where Ted-talk-esque presentations are going on, but I ignored them.The views are magnificent, especially when you can look straight down and see the south reflecting pool...The gift shop is full of WAY overpriced (even by NYC standards) junk. The cheapest t-shirt is $34, so I bought our traditional "souvenir" - a magnet ($8). You can stay as long as you like, and the view is unobstructed from any angle.
Top of world ma. Fantastic well thought out attraction can't comment any further don't want to spoil what awaits. But you must remember to respect the victims of 9/11 when visiting this area

BEST VIEW OF NYC. A fantastic panoramic view of the city with great knowledgeable staff who offer guidance during your visit. Don't bother going anywhere else for a view this is the new place to be and an incredible feeling to stand in the new tower. 10 out of 10.

A grand view from the top of the world!. The World Trade Center is both very moving and informative...a "bucket list" kind of experience. Seeing the Memorial pools/water features gives one a quiet reflection of the evil in this world which could try to justify such terror. KUDOS to the security force on hand, one of whom was quick to inform a group of bicyclists to move their equipment from where they had leaned them against the stones engraved with the names of those who had perished on 9/11. Going to the top of 1 WTC provide a spectacular view and the technology of a hand held screen which oriented as one pointed it with a "zoom" and explanation capability was well worth the $15 required.
Amazing!. We had a bit of a wait to buy tickets and decided to pay the extra to get admittance straight away. From the lift ride to the top, the digital film and the view this is well worth a visit.

spectacular. I loved this place! It was buzzing with positive vibes. The amazing story of its construction was a fitting tribute to its predecessor. Don't want to give a spoiler but there is a surprise on the tour which took my breath away.

Breathtaking Experience. I lived in New York and I have traveled many times and this was the new attraction and you will not be dissapointed . they did a great job . the view is fantastic as is the whole experience and the building

Best place for a work event! Incredible experience. The elevator ride up and down are amazing and out of this world. The view is also incredible. I would definitely return. It's such a unique opportunity. It is super organized and the staff is very professional and friendly.you won't regret this trip.
Wow!. Definitely a must! Take your time, enjoy it, take pictures, look around, get a hot dog, just do it, views are amazing!

Awsome Viel. The view from the observation deck was amazing! There were no long lineups the day we went and we did not have to wait for tickets. To see the city from that high up was spectacular. Would definitely recommend this as a "must see" when in NYC.

It will blow your senses. Best experience ever! No better view in town. You will reach the 102nd floor in lest than 48 sec. You will see the history of WTC through the years in a short film projected in the walls inside the lift-elevator and then..... the magic

Great Sights!. We went at the end of the afternoon so we could watch the skyline in daylight and at night. Great views!The ride in the elevator is quite fast! Try not to stand too close to one wall on your way up/down because you won't have a good view of the video on the walls.The place is great except that it is completely inside and thus this makes photography difficult because of reflections off the windows.

Best views of the city. Well worth a visit. The views are outstanding. We were lucky enough to go on a clear sunny day. The staff were helpful. You have to pay an extra $15 to get an interactive iPad which tells you what you are viewing from the Windows.

Put this on your Must Do in NYC! Don't forget your selfie stick!. Incredible views of an incredible city! We booked in advance with part of the Memorial tour, which I would recommend as the line can be quite long. Having booked in advance we we let in at our designated time and didn't need to stand in the long lines. After going through security as quick elevator ride brings you to the observation deck. After a short video to enhance the suspense, the windows open and WOW! Right when you exit to the observation deck they have the touristy green screen photo op - if you're not interested in the photo, pass this by - especially if you're able to take decent selfies!

MUST DO in NYC. This is probably the most well done attraction of this sort in the USA. The views are unreal but the whole experience to so excellent. Go late in the afternoon so you can stay for the sunset. Drinks are pricey in the bar but the view is worth a million dollars as the sun sets. The ride to the top is so cool and there is a big surprise. Just an excellent, excellent experience that you will not forget. Take binoculars, too.

Stunning views!. Had a great experience recently from the customer service to the amazing views of the City, absolutely breathtaking. It is worth the visit to this remarkable building that still shows original parts of the Twin Towers.

First class syscaper. Security is very tight as expected but entire experience was well worth the money. ?Views are spectacular and you do not feel rushed at all. Was treated very well by staff as we had or 1 year old daughter with us.
New Trade Center. A must see. Lift goes up 102 floors in 45 seconds. Good food on top floor while taking in the view . In the clouds on a misty day so make sure its clear skies

Must see!. This is a must see when you visit NY, the new freedom tower has been done so well, in a tasteful and respectful way concentrating on the future and what the tower represents - Freedom!As the tallest building in the U.S. and the 4th tallest in the world it's absolutely worth going up... Enjoy!!!

great views, bad experience. The view is obviously incredible. Went there around 4:30pm and saw New York by day and night. The experience however was poor. First, when you arrive they hold people for a few minutes to try to sell a guide, then there is a huge line for that mandatory picture most people don't buy. And the worst of all is that, because it lacks seating places, people sit by the Window just to rest, talk or check their mobiles, staying on the way of those who want to see the views and take pictures.

Freedom Tower. 1776 feet tall at the 102 floor. Elevator takes only 60 seconds to ascend or descend. Walk the perimeter and see all the boroughs of NYC on a clear day as well as NJ. Get exposed to a time line of NYC as well as the progress of construction. Staff is very helpful. Prices for beverages at top are outrageous.
A must do!!. This only opened in July, but I would recommend it to everyone. Even the lift journey up and down are exciting and entertaining.

Incredible‼️ . This attraction is called "See forever". This is exactly how it feels. The 360 view of Manhattan is perfect. This building is so high that it feels like the others around are low but of course it is not true. The elevator ride is magnificent‼️ thank you!

Wowwwwwww. One word to describe it WOW - the lift reaches the 102nd floor in 45 seconds . The views are breathtaking, we visited early morning and the weather was fantastic could not have picked a better day. A must do on your itinerary to NY
Spectacular. The views are worth the cost of admission!! I was very impressed with the observatory. Buy tickets in advance to avoid the line to purchase.

Awe-inspiring. Phenomenal building, love how the architects incorporated the essence of the original towers. Elevator ride's surprise digital show was outstanding -wish the ride up lasted longer the visuals were so fantastic. The presentation at the top before you go out to the observatory was awe-inspiring. The entire crowd gasped at the end. Won't say more so as not to spoil the surprise for new visitors. Would love to have both on dvd. Oh, and the views are stunning too. Absolutely a must-see and well worth the admission price. Buy online to avoid the ticket line.

On a clear day you can see forever--well, nearly.. This is not *the* place to see all of NYC at your feet (the Empire State Bldg is, well, antiquated). You can walk entirely around the viewing area for a 360* experience. The food options are pricey and not all that great, but a glass of expensive wine at sunset might be in order. You should get your tickets in advance online to save some time. Even at that you'll have to wait in line to get to the elevators. The trip up is *almost* worth the price of admission (almost, since it's a pretty pricey venue). If you must choose between One World Observatory and the 911 Museum, in my opinion, this is the MUCH better option (enjoy the memorial pools and leave it at that for 911).

Tearjerking. You really need to do this, absolutely awesome. 103 floors above Manhattan there's a short film show of NYC life and then wait for it, it will bring a lump to your throat and a tear to your eye.

Wow! Just WOW!. Whole experience was amazing. Video footage of work involved and views of people involved was informative and moving. Trip up in the lift was super speedy. Be prepared for ears popping. I would recommend you video the changing 'scenery' in the lift on the way up as it shows how the skyline has changed over the years. But it is over with too quickly to appreciate it. Was so pleased we could watch it again later. View from the top is totally amazing. No rushing - we stayed for a long time and left when we were ready to. Sunny day when we went, so that made it even better. Whole place is clean and welcoming. Guides avaiable if you need to ask anything. Brilliant.

Seamless, friendly, well-produced. I visit New York 2-3 times a year, and had this on my list to do. Arriving on a crisp fall weekend, I knew the view would be great.I went on a Sunday at 3:45 pre-booked, and experienced none of the lines some are complaining about. The queue staff were all friendly and interactive, seemed to genuinely be having a good time.I don't want to give too much away, but the elevator ride and the presentation immediately at the top were fantastic.There were, of course many opportunities to spend more money (green screen photos, tablet viewing guides, etc) but I didn't feel any of it forced on me.The sky portal was a neat idea, but the screens really weren't projecting in the afternoon light, and hard to see.It got a bit more crowded as we approached the 4:45 sunset, but I still didn't have any trouble snagging some good photos.People have complained that there is nowhere to sit, but I'm not sure why this is an issue. You go up, see what you want, and go back down.Elevator to get back down was a tad hard to find, but all it took was a loop around the core. Maybe a minute wait to get on it then.All in all, well worth it for anyone new to the city or old pros. If you're new, the tablet viewer might be worth it. If you know your stuff, it's fun trying to pick out where everything is.

Speachless. It may not seem a lot at first, since there are many other observatories in NYC, but the work and effort put in to all of what the attraction consist it's worth the money. I had the sunset entry pass and honestly it left me speechless. For us whom lost someone close to us in 9/11, seeing this marvelous achievement and that first impression in the see forever theater is just plain wonderful.

Almost top of the world . I visited the original world trade centre so just had to go and visit this one. Before you go up make sure you have a look around the memorial fountains very subtle and thought provoking. The observatory itself was very good and when we went 11am on a Friday it was pretty quiet, (unlike the empire state building which is great but a little crazy). There is a short presentation before you get to the actual observatory which is pretty cool and the lifts, or elevators for USA readers, are extremely quick with a little show for the trip.
Spectacular!. Best view ever, a must in NYC! Have a beer and enjoy. Excellent organization and the elevator make the different.

Glad we went!. We went to the 9/11 Memorial Museum last Summer, but I don't think the Observatory was open yet. So this Fall when we returned to NYC, we decided to got to the Observatory, and I'm glad we did. The elevator is amazing, and the views are unforgettable.
Breath taking.. AMAZING views of New York and the entire area, you can see for miles!Favourite memory of New York...

Amazing views. Great views wow see forever is the tag line and that is correct wow , there is a lot of stories and history here and it is interactive and informative , my tip is to go early in the day we went at 9.30am and there was virtually no que

Excellent. This was the highlight of my trip to NYC We had to purchase tickets and it was worth itl The elevator ride took us to the top 90 seconds. the view was incredible. How sad that it had to be built after what took place on 9/11.

Don't Miss This View. WOW, what a great view. Everything is inside, roomy, dry and warm. You can skip the Empire State Building with its' long line and crowded outside observation deck, this new observation area is even better then the old WTC. There is food available, but it is very expensive. It is worth the money and for this great view. The area around the two pools is now free and beautiful with the green grass and developing trees providing shade.

If you do one tower, do this one. Wow! Just Wow! Had I of gone up this tower first, I would not have felt the need to do any others.It was so well organised and you had plenty of time and space to view the entire 360 degree observatory, and the views are just incredible, breathtaking and moving. You can see everything in every direction that you ever needed to see!!! I wont spoil the surprise when you go up in the lift, or the surprise when you first exit the lift, as I was glad I didnt know about these, but wow - you will be amazed, blown away and probably quite emotional!This tower is the tower to do. Do not miss it.

"Observatory". The building is beautiful! It is a must see - agree with others that it is pricey - we did not buy the xpress passes but I did purchase on line for an alloted time. We arrived 15 minutes ahead of time as they recommend but still ended up waiting 1/2 hour to get in. I think alot of people buy the xpress entry pass so they don't have to wait and that screws timing up for others that have "allloted" times - I could not swallow the extra $25 just to get in early - although it does get you through security without standing in line. The secutiry line was about 10 minutes long but it moved along quickly. The staff is a pretty well oiled machine. Once you are up there - after a quick little movie - you are in. I rented the ipad which I thought was a waste because it is a tape - not really showing real time and thought was pretty goofy. No seating unless you want to dine. All in all you are paying for a observatory - lot's of people taking pictures and once you see North, South, Each and West - that's it. Visit time depends on how long you want to stand. Hour max and they really don't even give you much information on the building at all. I learned more about the Freedom Building on the cruise around Manhattan.

Observations from a native New Yorker. Yes, the admission price is relatively high, but it didn't deter us. This is New York City after all. The opportunity to gaze out on the splendid view we remembered from Windows on the World was worth the price. And yes, the view is still spectacular, but the arduous journey to actually seeing the view is something we certainly didn't expect.Prepare to be herded through a security checkpoint (staffed by incredibly polite, excellent attendants I might add) and then through a darkened hall of video wall presentations, then into a Coney Island-esque recreation of the underpinnings of the building complete with faux bedrock and a concrete pillar made of fiberglass. Then it's off to the elevator ride.The video presentation during the ride is wonderful, though too fast--if you can see over the heads of the other people packed in, that is. You finally arrive at the top... but it will be quite some time before you can actually see the view you came for. More lines, another video wall presentation, and two forced sales pitches to purchase photos of you and your companions superimposed on a background image of NYC--not even the real view mind you--followed by a very long pitch to rent a tablet viewer. Given the dollar's value being what it is these days, international visitors may think nothing of spending $15 for a rental gadget to identify the sights, but when I say "no thanks", I don't expect an over-zealous salesperson to argue with me.Finally, through the sales hurdles, you arrive at the observation deck to see what you came for...but only when you can break through the crowds of visitors. There are no benches or seating areas, so prepare for crowds of people jostling for position, some navigating bulky baby strollers, others huddled on the small window ledges taking a rest. Unfortunately, many of the the wondrous views are marred by reflections from the lights of the gift shop, making your photo taking a challenge.New York City's skyline is, and always will be the star of the show, but the One World Observatory experience was simply a profit-centered carnival side show that fails miserably in doing justice to our great City.

MAKE THIS A MUST!!!!! . An absolute must, if you do nothing else in NYC, make this a priority, the views are breathtaking. Despite the bad reviews, my experience demonstrated a well organised process. There are options to purchase tickets online before arrival, you can also pay extra for express tickets on arrival, to avoid the lines. We had neither for our tour, and probably waited 30 minutes to get to the viewing platform at 3pm on a Saturday afternoon. Some Tips: There is an additional $15 dollar charge per iPad, which allows to use an app that's helps you identify exactly which buildings your looking at from the viewing platform. Worth every cent. When you enter the elevator, turn and face the glass, as the lifts close the glass around you becomes digital screens, get your cameras ready to video. There is a self service cafe at the top, that serves the basics, but behind that is a restaurant & cocktail bar. To dine in the restaurant you would need to book in advance of your tour ticket. The cocktail bar is roped off, which makes it appear that it's a VIP area. It's not, anyone can have a drink at the bar, drinks are pricey, but they do taste sweeter whilst you take in the spectacular views, it's worth paying out for at least one! In total we spent around 2hrs 30 mins at the One World Observatory.

A Meaningful View. Walking through the halls of this beautiful building, we had chills running up our spines. One cannot ignore the love that went into the construction of this project. The observatory was absolutely breathtaking however be prepared to pay the pricey $32 USD for entry. Definitely worth it!

Amazing view from the top. We got the express pass, which helped us in bypassing a big queue. The observatory offers stunning view of New York skyline. Infact skyline New York, New Jersey . Unfortunately it was a overcast day but still offered us with great views.

A Must See. A fantastic Observatory. Great from start to finish. Line went down quite quickly — we were there on a Monday morning. A lot more people in the Line when we came out. Fantastic views from the 102nd floor. Elevator takes less than a minute to whisk you there. Moving film before getting into the elevator.

Breath-taking!. I am a New Yorker and it was a breath-taking experience. What an amazing place. Tourist or not, I would recommend everyone take a day and spend a bit of time to do this. Buy your tickets on line and skip the wait. The workers inside were polite and accommodating. It was a great experience!!!

So much more than just amazing views!. As someone who lives in New York City, I don't typically visit many of the tourist attractions here (unfortunately!). However, I am SO glad I made it to the One World Observatory. The whole experience was a blast. Kudos to whoever led the creative direction and design here, because the attention to detail is 100%! Without spoiling the surprises for anyone, I must say the elevator ride and the intro presentation were my favorite parts... and that's before you even get to see the amazing views!! :) As for the views, definitely great - we went on a pretty cloudy day and you could still see extremely far. Highly recommend for those travelling in town AND those that live here!

World Trade Centre should be #1 of things to do in NYC. You start your experience travelling through time on the journey up in the elevator! Then one of the most amazing things happen at the start of your tour, which I'm not going to spoil for anyone! The views are so amazing especially on a bright sunny day which we were fortunate to experience. Yes there is a bit of "mirror" glare on the glass but you can't have a regular window pane in a building that tall! We found all the staff in the building to be helpful and friendly. We had our lunch in the restaurant and the food was tasty & not as expensive as we thought it would be. You could spend an entire day at the top of this beautifully designed building, which overlooks the Ground Zero footprint waterfall memorial gardens, on returning to the ground floor you again get an amazing experience on the elevator down. You can then visit the Ground Zero Memorial, while there just take a look back up to the top of the WTC to get a feel for how high up you've just been. Above all enjoy the whole experience.

Amazing view. Its a must to be seen while visiting New York. Incredible the lift experience! Love the device you can rent out for showing all the different buildings and places of interest, just point at a building and it tells you what it is and a bit about it.
Great place to visit.. Great place to visit and have a great view of NY and the boroughs and NJ. It is pricey but the experience is unique.

Amazing View!. The views are amazing and it's a really fun trip to the top. I'll agree with others that the reflection from the gift shop reflects at night, which is a little annoying. We got the sunset flex pass, but considering the steps to get to the top (security, elevator line, mini flick before you enter), I'd almost go up at like 4 to make sure you're up there as the sun goes down.

Fun to visit - on a clear day you CAN see forever . Buy tickets online to skip lines. The priority passes worth the extra$ if you are tight on time. If you have kids the iPad augmented reality gizmos are a lot of fun -$15 for one can be used by a whole family and adds to the experience.
Beautiful. I had never been to NY and this is a must see. You truly see the entire city. Took my family there and it was amazing.

Worth it for the view alone. I wanted to show my respects at WTC and decided on a whim to go up the new One World Observatory. The mini tour is a bit cheesy but the place is well staffed and supported and honestly you only really need the view.The lifts are astonishing, cool multimedia experience but the speed they get you to the top is something else, especially as you don't really feel as though you're moving that quickly.View is matchless for NY I'd say

Dinning on top of the world!. We were so happy to be able to have a simple light meal and drinks after taking pictures on a beautiful clear day out all the windows from one world observatory! Then as it got darker we got a totally different perspective on NY city at night, what a treat! Our waiter and the manager were very attentive and pleasant people to talk to, which made our visit even better, so much so that we went back for dinner again the next evening after going to the 9/11 memorial. It was a rainy day so there would be no view but we didn't care because the food and people are so nice! Thank you again for making our time in NY city so special!
Ok. If you have been up tall places in London, will fell same, not cheap,but got to do it if in New York

wow. The one world observatory is amazing! the view is just breath taking and the entrance is perfect. A beautiful tribute to what once stood there! I was abit confused as to where the restaurant was but this wasn't a problem as there is a food market place across the road and the steak is amazing!

Hearded like cattle.. Of course the view is fabulous! But the organisation is demeaning! They heard you like cattle, and make you wait for their ridiculous theatrical presentation just to get another $15 to rent you a tour device. Can't skip it, you are told to stand right where they point you, and you have no voice, just like cattle.... very unpleasant!!!

Expensive but worth doing. It was unfortunately a rainy, cloudy day for us but the views were still worth it. What impressed me most was they warned us before going up and were willing to change our reservation to any day so we'd have a better experience. We were limited and couldn't change but how often do you get that kind of consideration? This is another place in NYC (like the 9/11 Memorial Museum) where I strongly suggest booking ahead. We ended up doing a flex pass which allowed us to arrive at any time on our reserved day and bypass the lines. As many have said, the ride up is dramatic and fun. If you can, start a video when the elevator takes off and at least capture the narrative if the crowd is too big to get good video.

No exception for lack of visibility. unfortunately we want when it tower was surrounded by clouds and raining. Visibility was zero initially and them slightly cleared to see the buildings next to us within a mile. The guys at the top told me i should check with customer service downstairs for a rain-check and when came down, i was told i had 'some visibility' but not 'great visibility'. I don't think i has paid for 'some viability' did i?
Amazing views of fantastic city.. This was a great opportunity to view the city at night. Stunning skyline, we went just as it was getting dark wonderful to see the different buildings lit up.

Fantastic views. We booked this trip to the observatory online and were speedily shown through the crowds to the elevators up. What an experience. Be ready or you'll miss it. We wanted to go down and do it again! The views from the top are amazing albeit by the time we reached the bar for a cocktail overlooking the city, the tower was covered in cloud and we couldn't see a thing! Food looked great and on a clear day it would be a real treat to eat up so high with such great views.
A real eye opener. Fantastic... You go up in the really fast lift & have a little talk by the guide & then the curtains open & the view is breathtaking. Really well worth it.

Awsome and spectacular . Was there with friends. It was flawless despite a lot of visitors. We bought tickets on site and choose to go there in the evening since we went to Empire State Building during the day.Everything is well prepared and executed. It starts with the elevator where you get a unique experience both visually and in the gut...First stop is mindblowing and I could not have been more surprised and yet impressed. We had a beer in the restaurant, a bit expensive but worth its money. When the sun had set and the evening had come I would have wanted less light cause it was hard to get a good picture because of the reflections in the windows. But I have such nice memories from it.Go there! For all the reasons you can find but most of all to honour those who passed away 9/11.
Fabulous. Loved this. A great surprise right at the start, which unfortunately I can't tell you about as it would spoil it. Great views, well worth the money.

Finally, fourteen years later. True disclosure: I once worked on the 96th floor of World Trade Center II. No, I was not there on THAT day, but I was there in the aftermath and watched for months the ruins of the towers no longer there and thought about the people I knew who were no longer there… As result, it took me fourteen years to be able to bring myself back to the site. For all these years, every time I find myself in the area, I would do my best to avoid approaching the site, still remembering the messages and photos posted all along Broadway: people looking for other people, relatives, friends, anybody, anything.  To make a long story short, I finally decided to approach on a recent Friday. That’s when I found that there was no more lobby you can walk in and shop and browse, entrance to the new WTC 1 is highly secured and the Path train has nothing but scurrying crowds of commuters. But then, they had built the Observation Deck and I decided to visit. The line for tickets was very short (5 minutes or so). Cost $32/person or $54 “Priority” which will allow you a quicker admission. I am sure there are days when it pays to go Priority. You buy your tickets, go through Security and after another short wait at the elevators (spectacular!) you are up for orientation. The elevators in the old building were different: they went very fast, then pushed the “brakes” and slowed for getting off. To get to the 96th Floor I had to change two elevators. Not these beauties: they use some new technology which flawlessly and gracefully took us to the 102th floor and we did not even feel the elevation. The first level is orientation where there is a short video presentation (I found it un-watchable, the huge screen is too close for comfort and the content is of very limited interest). After some more peddling (an old Yankee tradition) when they try to sell you photos and rent you tablets, you are finally let loose to circle the glass windows and enjoy/photograph the most fabulous views in our great City. Neither the Rockefeller Center (separate review) nor the Empire State Building (separate review) come close to what you can see from here. I cannot help it but think about the people who came to work in Windows on the World (the restaurant on top) on that fatal 9/11 not knowing that this is the last day they’d be seeing those views… or seeing anything, period.  The glass windows are reasonably clean, so you can take pictures quite comfortably, I cannot describe the views for you, you’ll have to see them to believe them. The “Eye” dares you to step on a transparent panel where you can see the cars moving down on the street... I look at the couples all around and think of all the images I saw after 9/11 of couples holding hands while jumping from atop one of the Towers, preferring this to death from burning... A couple of digital presentation panels each with a human interpreter, covering different boroughs/features/sites of NYC and a gift shop complete your visit. Oh, and if you are hungry, there is a restaurant, I did not go there. No appetite. On the way down I realize that this enterprise provides employment to a large number of people in positions that do not need extensive training.  For movie lovers: a variety of movies were shot in the old WTC:Three days of the Condor , Rollover, Trading Places, Escape from New York etc., but my preferred one is Dino de Laurentis’ King Kong (1976) in which the WTC (new and sexy) won over the Empire State Building for shooting location. The Empire State Building, quite annoyed by this, staged people dressed like apes to demonstrate around the WTC. Getting King Kong from Hollywood to the WTC was another story: the monster model was dismantled to pieces, loaded in special trucks with KING KONG painted on their sides and transported to NYC while press releases kept the public informed of the important event…5,000 extras were needed and the production company invited the public to the WTC Plaza on the nights of June 21-22-23, 1976. Thousands of New Yorkers showed up and King Kong got its crowd scenes: for three days the Great Ape was the city’s brightest star. Jessica Lange was almost lost in its shadow. Yep, that’s how she started. The new WTC 1 is not on the site of the original tower, that one is reserved for the Memorial park & Museum. My bravery did not extend to visiting those. I find it very bad taste to make money from those tragic days and events.

not the best view of manhattan. the best view is from top of the rock or empire state. The position of the building does not give any interesting view, with the exception of the brooklin bridge.It is too expensive for what gives, and then when you are up they try to sell you an ipad running a specific application ...

Spectacular!!. Went to the top of this spectacular building and of the views were amazing. The building is sleek and ultra modern and the high speed elevator alone was worth the trip. I can't say enough good thing about this visit and will definitely return again.

commerialsed dissappointment - Highlight was Lift ride up. This review is purely for the tower and not any of the surrounding areas or memorials. The lift ride upto the observation deck was brilliant but sadly, apart from the view, was the best part of the attraction. I would have liked to see more of this type of information throughout the visit. We found it too commercialised, and almost forgot the reason why it is there and was built. The views are fantastic, but unlike the Empire State Building, there is no external observation deck so all our photos had reflections from the glass. There is a presentation first but there was no information, just random videos of a typical day in NY, people skateboarding, having a coffee etc. Then we were asked to attend another “presentation”, which we thought would give us some information in relation to the tower, but this was to try to sell us renting of Ipads for information whist on the observation deck, which was very disappointing. There was a coffee shop, souvenir shop and info points on the observation deck, again commercialised and no one to actually ask any questions to regarding the building. I do not want to sound disrespectful but if you are looking to view NY from a high level I would choose the Empire State Building over Freedom Tower every time. And again would like to say this is in regards to the Tower only and not direct surrounding areas. Very disappointed and come away from the tower with knowing nothing more but a see a nice view.

Incredible views!. We had a short stay in NYC so opted for this over alternatives and it was incredible. The digital video screens around the experience are amazing and make the transition to the view much easier (I was slightly panicked at the height beforehand!). Definitely recommend this and it's the same price as the Empire State Building or Rockefeller but we had no wait at all - a huge relief!

A definite destination when visiting the city. We were lucky to be in NYC on a weekday and get there at 9 am so there was no line. In a few minutes we were on top and had a great view of the city. The tour in and the elevator ride is also worth the visit.

Awesome. I went there on the off chance and was really surprised that I hardly had to queue to get in. The lift ride was the best I have ever had and then when you arrive at the viewing platform the views are spectacular. Definitely a must go to place.

Awesome.... Like all the places you've dreamed about going that seems so far away in the distance this is a moment you won't want to miss. A Humbling experience because what it means to be there, as one reflects on the significance of all that is there, standing at that location.

Wonderful views as expected. It's $32 to go up to the observation deck. And the views are certainly of value. However then when you get up there, you get given a hard sell to hire an iPad to tell you all about the views, which is a great idea but when you've already spent a lot of money you expect to get it included, especially as when you get through to the deck as there are no signs or boards explaining the views. Which again for the price there should be. Loved the views, they could just try a bit harder giving people value for money, rather than the hard sell which includes the vast shop and resturant

Wow!!. This was by far and away the easiest tall building experience we had in the city. As with most NYC attractions be prepared for airport style security, however this was friendly and efficient.The elevator itself is an experience, taking you up to the 101st floor win a matter of seconds whilst you watch the manhattan skyline grow around you.Step out of the elevator into a long gallery style room....I shall say nothing else about this as I don't want to ruin the surprise.The observation areas themselves are simply stunning. Floor to ceiling windows, interactive areas and lots of staff on hand to answer any questions. The gift shop is the usual overpriced stuff! The bar is very expensive but the view whilst having a cold beer was worth it!!A must do!!

Spectacular Metropolitan Area Views. It's a little pricey, but it's the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere and the third tallest in the world. It's touristy, but especially on a clear day it's views are spectacular. Forget the Empire State building and Rockefeller Center and go for the highest vantage point to get an aerial city view.
First time. . Amazing view! You will not be disappointed. Recommend purchasing tickets online to avoid the line that wrapped around the building.

Gotta do it. Pay the extra for the express visit. It's worth the immediate access and avoiding the lines. I didn't get the ipad rental and was able to equally enjoy the views and exhibits. I went for the sunset and night fall. Just didn't want to leave...

Amazing sights. You feel like you are on top of the world. The COOLEST, and I mean BEST elevator ride I have ever had in my life to the top of "One World Observatory". A scenic history of Manhatten surrounds you when you ascend to the top. Then in the 360 degree observatory , everything is visable. We even went on a cloudy day, and could see for miles. History and sights everywhere. I could stay there for hours. Cameras a must, Handicap accesable. The staff were absolutely the VERY BEST, thank you "Victor". Many restaurants around the area, and a nice place to visit with the reflecting pools right next door.

Views are magnificent. This is opposite the 9/11 museum and well worth a visit. You can book in advance but we wanted to be sure that the views would be great so needed a clear day. We went on spec and only queued for 15 minutes. Even though I haven't got a great head for heights coped fine and would of hated to of missed the fantastic 360 degree views. We paid extra for the iPad style view guide and this helped us understand the local geography and key sights.

WOW! What a great place! Definitely worth it!. Everything good that's been said or written is true! This is NOT to be missed!! Buy timed tickets beforehand. I had read many reviews, so I knew what to expect. The lines moved quickly. The young workers are outgoing and confident- a bit assertive and overly friendly, but that's their job. The lead up in elevator and the NYC movie before the curtain goes up are all high quality, and- knowing the drill- I had my video aimed at the family members for their reactions when seeing the view for the first time. An unforgettable extra piece was going before sunset- seeing the sun go down in a fiery red blaze miles into the distance over New Jersey was very special. I'm so happy that I took my whole family to experience this!

Expensive views.. Yes, the views are amazing from the 360 degree wrap around gallery, so it is worth visiting. However it does cost $32. They then try to sell you lots of extras 'to enhance your visit'. Firstly the loan of an iPad for $15 to zoom in on whatever building you are looking at. The cafe and restaurant are grossly overpriced as is the merchandise in the shop. On exiting they try to get another $25 for a photo they take of you on entry, with a superimposed cheesy backdrop of the tower. They don't say why they are taking the photo, only that they have to take a photo of everyone, so it could be for security. No information at all on the design or construction of the building, or even who the architect was.Tip. Go early, before 10am. Easy to book a timed ticket on line for the same day and no queues.

Awesome. This is at the top of One World Trade Centre and is officially the highest building in America and the views when we visited on a clear day were amazing but do book in advance as the queue was rather long and do not rely on tickets on the phone as there is no reception within the building

Worth the trip - amazing view. having talked to some New York locals who were less than keen on the prospect of a new tower, I believe they are missing out on the effect the building has - it dominates the sky line from every angle and is run quite well. Brasserie is amazing - looking out over the city
Love the new building. The views are spectacular. Had lunch and a Manhattan at the rooftop restaurant. Pricey but very good.
