To do!. We bought our tickets online, so very easy.What a wonderfull view of 360°. Arriving on top is so spectacular!You must do this while visiting NY.

Fantastic experience, unparallelled. The view, the food, the engineering, the media experience.. The view is unbelievable. I've been there in the spring and the fall, on a sunny day and a cloudy day; I want to go back at night and at sunrise. There are some very unique experiences to enjoy. I have been to the observation deck of the Burj Kalifa in Dubai, a building twice as high as this; however, the view of lower Manhattan, the lower Hudson River, the New Jersey gentrified area, the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Staten Island, Brooklyn and the East River, Brooklyn Bridge, is unparalleled. You can see the United Nations, Empire State and other building landmarks. It was more impressive (perhaps because I'm American) than to me than the Burj Kalifa. I recommend anyone who goes to New York to experience the One World Observation deck. Buy your tickets online, pick the day and time, early is better but in New York, its often cloudy until later in the afternoon. The ride up the elevator is in itself, incredible because to the century long time-lapse video image of the development of Manhattan, and there are other surprising multi-media presentations, I won't "spoil" it for you, go and be surprised yourself. The restaurant is great, the café is amazing, delicious, top quality. Expect to pay more than elsewhere, but I was very happy to pay more, have great food and drink, while looking over the city. This is no Dallas Tower, or Toronto, nor Space Needle, this is more, totally breathtaking. I've only been there twice, but I expect to return again and again.I want to add one more detail. They will rent to you a tablet kind of gadget that is amazing. You point it out the window, it will identify the buildings and landmarks you see around the 360 degree view. That's not all, you tap the screen on some object which is identified, such as Coney Island. Within seconds you visually "fly" to that location, maybe at three times the speed of sound, then land right at the spot. Its much more than Google Street view. Actually, as an engineer, I'm still trying to figure out how it works. It is worth the $15.00 USD.

Much better than the Empire State Building. The place is very well organized. The views are incredible. The only complaint I have is that the place is entirely inhospitable to physically handicapped people as myself. It's accommodating to those in wheelchairs but has no where to rest for those of us who use canes or crutches.

Amazing views. No hard sells!. Great views all around Manhattan and well beyond - including Statue of Liberty, Empire State, Brooklyn Bridge, etc. Wasn't too crowded when we went so easy to get to windows and move around with buggy - staff also very helpful in directing us to avoid stairs/ elevators. Lift going up is good - projects a wrap around history of the area as you ascend; for best view, get into lift last and stand with your back to the doors!

A great Experience.. The One World Observatory has only been open to the public since September, however I feel that it will give the Empire State a run for its money. The afternoon we visited the queue was quite short and we were able to gain entry in no more than half an hour, once you get through security, you enter a tunnel, which takes you through solid rock, you then realise that these are the foundations the Observatory is built on, lots of Manhattan is solid rock. The lift is one of those super duper ones that makes your ears pop and you arrive on the 102nd floor, before your tummy has left the basement! Adults are charged $32. Seniors $30 not sure about children as we had none in our party. The Lift doors open and you enter what I can only call a "waiting area", I believe there may be 2 or 3 Lifts, within seconds the waiting area is full of people, the blank wall in front of you puts on a movie show with voice over, all to do with New York, this does not last for more than 3 minutes or so, then the wall lifts, there were simultaneous gasps and clapping from the people watching ( I won't spoil the surprise) you are then taken to another area for a quick chat and a sales opportunity, from there you go down a floor to a 360 degree observation deck and gift shop. As you would expect beautiful views over the 9/11 Memorial,there is also the new building structure which is being erected across the road, which to me looks like a bird in flight with its wings extended, I believe this will be a beautiful thing when its finished. When you come down in the lift you again have a very brief visual tour of new York by way of cinema and a voice over, all in all a great experience. If you visit here, you may not want to visit the iconic Empire State, as once you have seen New York from the 102nd Floor of one building it all looks the same but from another angle!

No vale la pena / A waste of money. La vista es increible, pero es imposible sacar buenas fotografías. Al ser un espacio completamente cerrado con vidrios no se pueden sacar fotos sin reflejos y ademas los vidrios estan sucios debido a la cantidad de gente que se apoya. Mucho mejor subir al Empire State. The view is great, but is almost impossible to take good pictures. Since the observatory is fully closed with glass taking a photo without a reflection is not possible. The windows aren't clean due to all the people putting their hands on them. The Empire State observatory it's much better.

Great View . . . Nothing Else. You go in an elevator to the observatory and the elevator was amazing. There are tv screens that show you through time what the area looked like. It was very interesting. Then you get to the top and you just look out the windows and see New York. It was nice but I really don't think it should've been $32 per person. There was nothing to do up there. You circle the observatory once and you're done.

Great. Really good if you have already visit Empire State and Rockerfella. The visual display in lifts and when first arriving were fantastic. Tried to sale the use of an iPad to show names of buildings for $15. Cafe was expensive but probably to be expected. Approx double the price. Booked on online which worked out well.

Worth The Ride Up !!!. Words can not express how amazing, beautiful and well designed the new World Observatory is. The best advice I can give is to go "Early" ! You can buy your tickets on line before you arrive. You select a date and time of arrival. By coming early you avoid all the lines and crowds. Our ticket time was for 10:00am on a Thursday. When we arrived we just walked up to the front entrance and showed our tickets, no line, no waiting !! :-) We were directed to the entrance/display area where you see the bedrock of the building and a display of monitors with videos of the workers who built the tower. Once you get on the elevator, you see the most wonderful video displayed on the whole interior wall of the elevator. Amazing!! Once you arrive on the 102 floor, you are directed to an area, where you see another video with many NY vistas. I will not tell you what happens when the video is over. All I can say is WOW!!! Again, go early, because you seem to have the whole floor to yourself, and no one is blocking your view. By the time we were finished looking at all the sights, it was about 11:00am and the place was becoming very crowded. The earlier the better!!!

Fantastic!. If you go to New York, you must go to the top of 1 or 2 of their tall buildings....It was a tough call whether to do 'Top of the Rock' or the Freedom Tower...but this experience was tremendous. Brilliant 360 degree views....maybe time your visit around sunset and catch the day/night views. And the building itself is spectacular. I really debated whether it would be worth $32 just to go up to the 102nd floor for a few pictures....yes, it is!

Great view. That's it.. Look, it's new, it's high, it's panoramic. However, it's indoors, it's crowded, and you better be prepared to queue, queue, and queue some more!There are plenty of negative reviews around visibility, but my biggest issue is the queue to leave the place. Simply do the math:1) You book a 15 minute time slot to enter the observatory.2) You spend more than 15 minutes in the observatory.Assuming a constant influx of people, this means that there will always be an overlap of people in the observatory. As such, the queue to leave the place is simply insane. It nearly wrapped around the *entire* observatory, meaning that it would take at least one hour to exit. This is not acceptable, and poor logistics.That said, the view is amazing. It's indoors only, refreshment prices are extortionate, and it has airport-esque security. Top of the Rock is probably better.
Great views!. We loved the elevator ride to the top with the history of New York being shown on the elevator walls. Great idea. The views are truly breathtaking. Definitely worth a visit!!
Definitively amazing. I recommend going in the late afternoon to see NYC lighting and sunset. The look and incredible, but not to see the north side of Manhathan, such as Central Park

Breathtaking view. A great experience! It starts in the hall and goes on in the elevator. When you arrive at the 102th floor you get an amazing videocompilation of the city and it ends in a breathtaking climax.... The view behind the windows all around the building after that is endless fantastic...

Oct Day time visit - Great Views for a Sunny day!. The One World Observatory was a great experience and the views from the top were great. Lovely view of Manhattan and the skyscrapers towards time Square.Prices at cafe are dear, but not everyday you can eat at such altitude, so not bad for some snacks.

Nice views but did we miss something?. I agree completely with the previous reviewer - spend your $$ at the fantastic 9/11 museum next door. Although the views are very good, the information was sparse to say the least. Did we miss an exhibit somewhere explaining the building itself? Maybe we did. Also, we got the iPAds, but there could have been a lot more info about more buildings - especially those visible from the top. It was very basic and simplistic.

A must see place in New York City... . Spectacular 360 degree view from the tallest building of western hemisphere... With 104 floors, it truly gives an amazing view of New York City and the neighborhood... Its a guided tour which reflected the resilience of the city with which it has emerged after 9/11... Totally worth the money and time...
Awesome. We got in the elevator doors closed.. They opened and we were on top. You don"t even feel it. What a view

Best views of the city. The recently opened One world observatory offers the best views of the city as well as some great technology giving information on New Yorks places of interest. Would recomend.

The view is breathtakingly gorgeous!. We had booked a Sunset pass for $59, this allowed expedited entry any time between 4pm and 7pm. Entry was very quick, which was good as the queue was long. I don't want to reveal too much about the trip to the top and the brief show in the room at the top as it would spoil the excitement. The view was amazing! We watched the lights come on as it got darker and it was quite magical seeing the Empire State light up.We made use of the cafe facility which offered a fair choice of sandwiches, cookies and drinks, however there was no seating in the area, only high tables to stand next to.Gift shop has large range of items, but is quite pricey.Cheaper tickets are available and it is not covered by the New York Pass.

Amazing experience. The lift to the top is an experience in itself, then the great reveal when you get to the top makes this a very well orchestrated experience. You must either do this or the top of the rock but you get great views over the sea from here.

Took my breath away. We arrived early afternoon & there was no queue so were able to go straight to the elevators. Yes it's expensive to go up but a must thing to do. The gentleman at the elevator was very informative & answered a couple of my questions.The lift ride takes you to the top in 60 seconds, make sure you watch the video as you ride the elevator. You then go in to another waiting area & watch another video & like the other reviewer I don't want to say anything about this as it will spoil it but OMG I was blown away.The views are fantastic & I listened to a lady giving a talk about the Brooklyn Bridge which was very interesting.I would definitely recommend this attraction though whilst walking around ground zero & the reflection waterfalls I did feel emotional & very moved & in a little way it did feel very strange going up One World & I think once you have been there you will understand how I felt.Enjoy

Amazing Views, but that's about it.. The 360 degree views of NYC were incredible, but it stopped there. Little info on the new building itself. Tourist trap in every way. $6 for a bottle of water at the top. Save your $$ and go to the 9/11 museum next door.

Stunning trip. We took our 3 kids on MasterCard Monday ( you get a discount online) Be aware there is no wifi outside this attraction so make sure you download pictures of tickets before you make the trip!The long line of visitors is effectively and efficiently managed Even the elevator ride was interesting !The view is quite breathtaking
October - end of day visit. Superb views over NYC. Best time to visit is sunset but get there 20 minutes or so beforehand to see NYC in daylight and then evening/night

Breathtaking. The presentation of this attraction was truly breath-taking. The lift journey to the top and the panoramic video presentation, truly took my breath away. What can I say about the views, spectacular!I also had the opportunity to dine at the top of 1WT and the food was exceptional. Having visited a number of places in NYC, my visit to this venue was one that I will never forget.Food, drink and friendly service, all to a very high standard. My recommendations would be to purchase the VIP ticket which allows open access to the venue on the day of your booking. You gain immediate access and have an expedited route to the top.
Best views in New York. They've done a fantastic job, won't tell you too much or it will spoil it! Views are fantastic! Lift takes you to the top in 60 seconds, a must do in NYC

Incredible views. I must admit, it was emotionally difficult to enter this building and to go to the observation deck. Having been to the top of the original twin towers, it was hard. A reminder of what once was and is no longer because of an act of terror. That said, there is an amazing video that you watch during your elevator ride and up and down. Great technology and graphic. The price is quite high, but we felt the need to go

Incredible views and incredibly long lines. This was my third visit to the World Trade Center site but my first visit to the One World Observatory. The lines were very very long. My suggestion is that if you are planning to visit the observatory buy your tickets online. If you do not, this will simply add yet another line that you must wait in. Once you have tickets, either bought online or you waited in the "purcahse tickets" line at the observatory itself, pay attention to your scheduled tour time and I suggest not arriving any earlier than the scheduled 15 minute window for arrival. Example, your your starts at 3:30, you may enter the first line at 3:15. No earlier. Once through this line you will then be herded to a security line. Somewhat like the TSA lines at the airport. After this line you enter into another waiting area except this area, which is another line, has stuff for you to watch and things to look at and read. Upon making your way through all the lines the experience begins with the elevator ride. Wow! What an experience. When you get off the elevator you will be corralled into a holding area to watch a video. If you are short like I, try to get up front otherwise you won't see anything. I'm not trying to be ugly but there was a guy on crutches, not in a cast or a boot, no visible injury, he was just walking with crutches and he was a tall guy. The lady herding people called him out and put him and his party up front. Well he ended up in front of me with severa of his friends. I saw nothing during this part of the tour. I'm 5'2 and this guy was probably 6'2. He could have stood in the back of the room and been just fine. Anyway, after the short film is over the screen raises really fast and you get your first glimpse at the view of the city. You can briefly enjoy the view as people exit this room. From here you are moved into another area where you may pick up and iPad if you paid for one. This iPad will adjust to your position within the observatory and will point out what buildings you may be looking at as well as other points of interest. Its kinda a neat little extra. This views from up here are amazing and if you have yet to see the Statue of Liberty or Ellis Island, well you can see them from here. While the views are incredible I believe this is one of those things I would probably only pay to do once. Unless I'm visiting the city with someone who's never been up in the observatory before.

This is a must. I think the elevator is one of the best parts of this attraction, amazing view, but after paying 32 dollars per person once you're up there they'll try to rent a you a very cool screen so you know what you're are looking at.
Amazing View. The observatory is definitely a must-see when you are in New York City! Spectacular view, nice introduction - it is its money worth.

By far the best tourist attraction in the world. These types of observatory places exist everywhere.. However, when it is the jaw dropping skyscrapers of NYC, it becomes something extraordinary. It is worth a go even for the elevator ride only. Makes you want to cry after seing the memorial.. The staff is extraordinarily friendly and proud of what they have there. Don't think that it will be a half an hour thing that you only take pictures and leave.. One can spend more than one hour admiring the view from up there. Just buy your tickets online in advance to beat the queue.

Lots of tourists but its a must visit in NY. First time to visit.... got lost in few turns. The sound of the waterfall makes the bustling area peaceful in a different way. Such a heartwarming way to remember the departed.

Well worth a visit. We were deciding between Empire State and here. So pleased we went with this location. It was emotional, moving and spectacular. Great views are an option at many attractions but what you get here is so much more. We didn't know what to expect but we're so impressed and moved by the emotion and the experience. Highly recommended.

Stunning views over city and into the distance. We visited on a Sunday in fine weather in early October. Only a 5 minute queue for access in the public Lin and we actually were quicker than some who want through the VIP line.The experience is worthwhile, great elevator ride with visual display of NYC from first settlers to today. Once up top you can stay as long as you like moving around for great scenery and photos.There are food and liquor outlets available as well as a tourist shop.Well worth the ticket price.

Top of the World!. Incredible experience!! The elevator ride to the top is amazing- there is a 'surprise view' as you ride to the top but I don't want to spoil it for you. All the people working there were VERY nice and helpful. Two tips : buy your tickets in advance and get the 'fast pass' (it's worth the money!) and plan to have lunch (or dinner) in the restaurant.

Staff ruined the experience. Location, location! This was expensive and I would say this is one of those attractions you do once just to say you did it. Purchase your tickets online! It saves you time. Everything here is a wait. Wait to buy tickets, wait to get in, wait to go through security, wait to get on elevator, wait to go through sales presentation, wait to take pictures, wait to look outside windows. Get the theme? The employees here are way uptight. They're so uptight that they ruined the experience and the "moment." They're just there to herd people. No smiles, not polite but not rude either. It's very sterile. The most annoying thing is that they pack you in like sardines for everything. Especially to try to sell you the I-pad experience. Most places just let you walk to the floor of the observatory and let you explore. Here, you feel like they are holding you upside down and shaking every penny out of your pocket before you can go to that floor. The most impressive was the elevator ride. Hopefully someone from management reads this and things change. Take a class at "Disney" and let people feel the moment!

Long lines. Pre-purchased tickets for 6PM intending to see sunset, but didn't count on lines. We felt like cattle being herded into the slaughterhouse. First a line to go through security and the security person was rude. I understand the need to be firm and direct, but there is no need to be a horses butt. Then another line to get on the elevator. Finally at the observation level and we were herded into a room where souvenir pictures and some sort of ipad were being hustled. Finally at the observation deck (about 10 minuets after sunset) and we were able to see lower Manhattan, Brooklyn, and New Jersey. Planned on eating but casual food looked like mediocre deli food and would have had to eat stranding up. Finally, when ready to leave, another interminable line to get on elevator. If I had to do over would have gone to Empire State Building for better view of Manhattan, the buildings, and Central Park.

breathtaking. The views are breathtaking. It took no time at all to get to the observation floor, but we did buy express tickets, for any day during the week of our stay, I think they are worth every penny
A must. Brilliant views, great journey up and down in the lifts. Little queuing. Restaurant available and gift shop.

3rd highest skyscraper in the world. The lift ride is an experience all of its own. Fabulous view from the top and although there are IPads available for an extra $15 dollars to tell you what you are looking at, we found you didn't really need these. Definitely worth doing, the best moment is possibly at the end of the film they show you..... I won't tell you as it spoils the surprise.

Love the Elevators. We had not planned to go up to the observation deck at WTC, but after seeing the memorial we wandered over to the building and there was no line in front. After asking, we found we could just buy tickets and go up. The tickets are a little pricey at $32 but we went because we did not have to wait.You walk through a bit of an underground display before getting to the elevators. We had perhaps a 5 minute wait to get onboard, and the attendant says make sure to look out the elevator. What happens in the minute or so it takes to go up is you see how Manhattan developed from green forests to concrete towers....it was very cool. I wanted to go down and up again just to watch it.They show you a tablet when you get to the top that you can hold up and it instantly points out all of the landmarks you see with more details available with a click. I thought the tablet would be free....a great tool and deal. But there was a charge and most people did not go for it. We picked on up and it was fun for a bit, but I soon found the tablet always showed the south view no matter which direction I held it. Perhaps worth the money....hard to say.The views were great. Liberty Island one way and all of Manhattan the other. Unfortunately with the Ground Zero memorial right at the base of the building it is hard to get a good look at it from above.The elevator ride down had a different display on the windows....equally fun to watch but different than going up. Always try to be on the outside of the elevator when you board.The WTC area is about a 10 minute walk from the nearest subway station. There was a lot of construction in the area so it was not always obvious the best way to walk.

Slightly disappointing. Although the the trade centre is an impressive building, I was left slightly disappointed by the observatory. The views are amazing but as its floor to ceiling glass, the lights inside reflect and make it near impossible to take good pictures of the view. For that reason, top of the rock, and Empire State are better to take pics but. One world trade centre is an experience and I'm glad I went.

Great views of NYC but takes a lot of time. Coming from Toronto where we have one of the tallest free standing stuctures with 360 views, its hard not to compare the experience. The building is beautiful and the views at the top are impressive. However there's too much "production" added to what should just be a very simple elevator ride and access to views. Its an expensive attraction ($32/person) and there are long waits to get up but, more importantly, the day we were there it was 45 minutes to get back down. So its a lot of time spent to get the views.

Stunning Views. We went to One World Observatory after previously going to Top of the Rock and Empire State Building, in that order.Well we got the order right.Let's be frank, the history and interior design probably gives ESB the "nod" over the other two, but the views are simply stunning from OWO.I do not know if there could be much to gain from paying the extra for the "express" tour, we did seem to get up to the observation point very quickly anyway - perhaps it just misses/shortens the "hardsell" for the tablet viewing aid.Anyway, it is a different experience to the others with the "reveal", but well worth the effort and dollars.Cafeteria on the top, although as you can imagine quite expensive - cake was very good, and what a place to take a few moments to enjoy the views.

Part two of two; 9/11 Museum and One World Trade Centre. After the sombre experience of the 9/11 Museum, it seemed appropriate to look to the future and go to the top of the tallest building in the Americas. Suffice to say it definitely didn't disappoint; not only are the views spectacular and largely unobstructed (we were especially lucky with a deep-red sunset over New Jersey) but the observatory itself is aesthetically well designed, with a restaurant, cafe and pleasant mood lighting. The elevator to the top includes a projected animation detailing a time-lapse of the city over the last 1000 years or so, followed by a dramatic reveal of the view over the city. The guides are are polite and helpful (though the info iPad describing the landmarks of the city is pretty overpriced at $15). Just like the 9/11 memorial, I would thoroughly recommend this for any trip to New York and would definitely recommend that people do it in conjunction with the museum and memorial below.

Go at Night. The view is amazing and is a must see at night.Have your camera ready to take a photo(with out flash) once the first video is finished playing. The only downfall is that it felt like I was at a carnival, with people trying to sell you things.

A room with a view. This is the latest high level viewing site of NYC. We accessed the site just pre sunset. Note it can take up to an hour to actually get access to the viewing level. At this stage closing time was 8pm and if you wish to dine you do need to be seated by about 6pm. Drinks need to be ordered by 7pm. The view of the lights of NYC and the surrounding boroughs is outstanding and is from the lower (southern end) of Manhattan. If you stay until close to closing time the crowds have mainly disappeared and you can take a leisurely last walk around the viewing floor.

You need to visit this place!. The views are 360 degrees of amazing, "see forever" visuals. The best time to visit is just before sunset. You will see the views in daylight, during the orange/blue hues of the setting sun and then at night. It is the best of three worlds.

One world. Well worth the $32 charge. We were fortunate on the day that there were no lines so didnt need to avail of the priority line. 42 seconds from ground level to floor 102 in the amazing elevator. A terrific experience. Great cocktails in the bar, good food too, well priced and decent portions

Great view . We were really looking forward to the elevators, but found that because too many people were in there, it made it harder to see the changing scenes through the years. The view from the top was worth seeing.

Spectacular View. The View from the Observatory was Breathtaking. Was pleasantly surprised how good the food was . Thought the prices where reasonable for the quality of the food. The wait staff was excellent. Would go back in a second. I would like to see a discounted ticket to get up to the restaurant instead of paying full price to get in.

MUST DO. We had already done both Rockefeller and Empire state observatory so my boyfriend wasn't sure about doing another one but we both agreed once we finished this one that it was well worth our time. Amazing elevator rides with neat videos and just a great display of the city. Can't beat this view, by far the best.

Great views of the city. We decided to go to the One World Observatory as it's cheaper than the Empire State Building and when you buy the tickets online, it has designated entrance time so that you can avoid the queue. We were half hour early and were allowed in early. We really enjoyed the 'Sky Pod Elevators' and 'See Forever Theater'. I highly recommend getting the 'One World Explorer iPad' in order to learn more about the iconic landmarks nearby. Unfortunately it cost another $15 for the iPad but was worth it.

My most moving experience.. I visited the World Trade Centre and observion deck in 1984. I was overawed at that experience and today I could not believe my feelings as I ascended to the Observation Deck of One World Observatory. What a magnificent experience!

Well worth a visit. We prebooked this the day before visiting so didn't have to wait long. Yes there's a queue for security, but it's there for everyone''s benefit and safety so no problem there. A little bit of a sales pitch and photos going on, but just grin and bear it. Once you've passed that, you can spend as much time on the observation deck as you like. We got lucky with weather - a stunning clear day with blue skies. The views were fantastic, taking in New Jersey, Staten Island, Liberty Island, Brooklyn etc, as well as Lower Manhattan. Overall a great way to see the city and the price is about on par with The Shard in London, so it's all good for me. It's a special experience and an iconic building.

Great views!. When my husband suggested we go to the One World Observatory at World Trade Center, I was agreeable, but not particularly excited. What's so great about being up high and looking down? We've already been to the top of the Empire State Building and the Top of the Rock, after all. But I went ahead and purchased the tickets online for the following day, choosing the Twilight Flex option, which allowed us to enter (without standing in line!) any time from 4-7pm. It cost more, but we were hedging our bets, as we weren't sure what time we could get there. And are we glad we did! In the end, we arrived just before 4pm, and found the many entrance points/lines confusing and not so well marked. But we asked an employee, who looked at our tickets and immediately shepherded us right to the front door, bypassing the whole scene outside. From that point, all along the way, employees helpfully greeted and guided us. The elevator ride up was very cool, less than one minute in length, and featuring a display on the evolution of NYC. Upon reaching the upper levels, we enjoyed the dramatic "big reveal" of the view. We spent about 1 1/2 hours circling the viewing area, as my husband took photos of the city from every angle. He was in his glory, and I found it surprisingly entertaining as well. Besides the incredible views, I enjoyed checking out the plentiful gift shop area, watched a wedding in progress, met some nice tourists, and listened to a very funny tour guide/comedian give a spiel about NYC. The only disappointment was the food situation. We had planned to eat at the cafe, but changed our minds when we discovered that there was no seating around the tables--everyone was standing. We looked at the menu for the upscale restaurant option, but it didn't interest us. After leaving the observatory, we ended up at a neighborhood sports bar for supper, but we would have happily paid the inflated prices for food at One World Observatory if there had been seating and an attractive menu. All in all, it was great fun, and the staff is particularly friendly and welcoming. If you enjoy heights, I would definitely recommend a trip to the top.

Spectacular . We visited on Friday, October 30 at noon. It was a beautiful sunny day, so I knew the views would be fantastic. We entered One World Trade after a very poignant visit to the 9/11 Museum and Memorial. I am grateful for paying the extra for the Priority tickets, because we avoided very long lines in doing so. We were able to go right to the express elevator to the top. The elevator ride was by far the coolest I have ever experienced. We exited the elevator into a dark room and were treated to a multi sensory experience that culminated in a quick view of the surrounding area. This was very nice. The only drawback to the visit was a choke point sales presentation of an overpriced iPad rental to show landmarks around the region. For people who wanted to use it, I think this was fine, but it was impossible to proceed to the restaurant or the observation deck on the levels below because of all the people waiting for the sales pitch to finish. I hope this is re-thought by the management. I understand the need for generating revenue, but by then, I had already paid enough. We ate at the restaurant which I will review later, and then proceeded to the observation deck to explore The region from such a great vantage point. From views of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge to the full length of Manhattan, the sites were spectacular. There were lots of selections in the gift shop as well. We then queued up for the trip down in the fantastic elevator, and exited the building. Overall, it was a fantastic experience if you are willing and able to pay the price of admission.

Wow! Just wow!. This is truly a magnificent experience. The views are 360 and undisturbed by fences, barriers etc that you find at TOTR or ESB. I'd recommend buying tickets online on the day you plan to visit. They are in 15 minute intervals and mean you avoid the que when you get there. The lines to the lift moved along well and the 60 second lift was amazing with the graphics. Truly impressive views and a piece of genuine history and importance.

New York at your Feet. The long waiting line can be avoided by ordering your tickets online - this saved us a lot of time. We didn't prebook the tickets (didn't know what time we would arrive) but did order them online once we saw the snaking lines. It's best to do this activity on a good weather day (this could include snow if it's not coming down too fast). Rain might not be such a good thing.The introduction to the observatory is terrific - one is surrounded by the granite that allows New York's skyscrapers. Even better is the elevator ride to the top - and grounded in historical views (i.e., at the beginning is the city as it looked before humans built their structures). As you quickly rise, you see the city unfolding over the last couple of hundred years. I wish there were a way to purchase this timeline - a great way to appreciate our quest for domination over nature in our structures.The view is just beautiful - you can rent a tablet that allows you to identify the buildings at your feet. We bypassed that - my husband is from NYC so I had a personal guide to do the IDing for me.If you don't know the city, it can be overwhelming at first, but you can take in the panoramic view as long as you want.

Expensive, but worth it. We deliberated for a while, but then decided to go for it. Glad we did. We booked online and were able to use the free internet in the building lobby to access our tickets. Great views.

Evening with the clouds. Go for it..highly recommendedWe went on a weekday so there was no que at all, the lift ride to the 100th floor is an unbelievable experience and the graphics are simply superb..the video before you get to the observatory is mind blowing and beautifully done. The observatory provides unbeatable view of the city..

Rip off and overrated. We had a mindset of enjoying good panoramic views while learning more about the WTC history and acquiring Good knowledge of the previous and current building in our recent trip to this place. Overall, There weren't much useful information for charging usd 32 per person plus furthermore you were asked to rent an iPad for additional usd15 to learn slightly more about the key buildings from the device. It's the tallest building in NYC and yes, period. You could see Brooklyn/Manhattan bridge and downtown pretty clearly but I would recommend go to Empire State Building or Rock. Center if you are seeking a mid town /more concrete jungle view. Overall an expensive and disappointing experience.

amazing view. We arrived around midday on a Friday and queued for around 20 mins for tickets so not so bad. Long line at security then another long line to the elevators. But they do entertain you along the wait, with very good videos and large screens with some inspiring clips. The elevator ride is very cool. I am usually a bit queezie with simulators but this was fine for me, it's very quick. The 'reveal' is cool, but we did get a bit frustrated with being constantly hearded along and just wanted to get to the observatory. Which once there was truly spectacular. You can linger as long as you want once up there and take your time to take in the views from all angles. Well worth the ticket price in my opinion.

Top of the world, ma!. A bit pricey but worth it for the amazing 360 views and the rocket like elevator.....you'll never know you travelled that high that fast. Don't leave without remembering why this building is here - pay your respects at the 9/11 memorial.
Great experience. Definatly top 1 on our touristy stuff todo list. The elevator "show" was amazing and the views wonderful. Lovad everything about the visit.

What a view!!!!. The tour is really good and has amazing surprises before getting in the observation deck.It is not one of the cheapest things to do while in Manhattan but, if possible, the view worth it.For the travellers that are going to New York City for the first time it also helps to localize where are the buildings and places they would like to visit.

I just want to look out the window. I like to go up in things. Eiffel Tower, Tokyo Tower, Q1, whatever. So I was pretty excited to get up here since it's pretty new. I just wanted to look out the window, but first you have to sit through a movie with a big reveal at the end, listen to a big spiel where they try to rent you iPads for $15, get your photo taken, etc. You're all taken up as a group. It's kind of annoying, throughout this whole process the windows are all covered/screened. Then you go by the restaurant, then you're led down to the viewing platform. The view is amazing. However, the interior design of the building is very white and light colored which means the windows have terrible glare. It was difficult to take a picture without getting the reflection of my shirt in it. Most places I've gone up to have dark interiors that discourage glare. The best windows (directly north, for example) have little stands in front of them with a multimedia display and you're not allowed to go look out of those windows directly. The view was amazing. However, all the other stuff involved was a hassle. It was expensive and I'd recommend Top of the Rock instead.

The best way to see the NY skyline. We contemplated going up the Empire State to see the skyline, but after seeing the cost decided to go on the subway and down to One World Observatory. I recall it being approx $25 each and we spent a good hour in there taking in the amazing sights and taking a million photos!Thoroughly recommend, you can see much much more from the observatory than the empire state

WOW. Keep your camera on from the minute you step in the lift as going up to the 102nd floor is an experience in itself, I won't spoil the surprise but keep the camera ready too as you watch the video screens before you go through to the main viewing area.

Great views but rest of experience was a mess.. We booked the 6:00 p.m. tour on a Friday evening. Perfect weather day. Impressive elevator ride with none of the usual OMG feelings in an elevator that goes that high that fast. The graphics in the elevator provide a distraction, but they are not very good. Once off the elevator, you are subjected to at least 10 minutes of photo taking and product hawking that is VERY annoying. If you charge me $32 to enter, give me the tools you have available to make it enjoyable. There is no denying that the view is unbelievable, but the crowd management (or lack thereof) is so overwhelming that you just want to leave. Management needs to have staff spend more time pulling teenagers editing 1200 photos of the same view away from the windows, instead of having staff hawking tacky photos of fake backgrounds. If you go, please remember: Do your social media somewhere else, not while sitting in the window box blocking other people from enjoying the attraction. Very disappointing attraction. Attraction managment need to work harder at making the actual attraction better for all attendees by reducing the sales events at the beginning and providing much needed crowd control around the windows.

"I Can See for Miles and Miles, I can See for miles and miles and miles......". Visited here in the late afternoon into the evening. So it was dusk into night. The ride up the elevator was unique as there were TVs surrounding the walls which play a video of Manhattan through the years, til you got to the top. What views at the top, all the way around. We got to see a Cruise Ship heading out to sea, with all the cameras flashing as it went by the tower. Kinda funny. There was a restaurant and gift store up top as well but a bit pricy. My wife and I got some great pictures of the rivers, Empire State building, the Statue of Liberty and all around town. It was a nice visit. Everyone should see this sight at least once in their lifetime.

Amazing view. Great view of the city. We were lucky to be there on the sunny day. It took us 40 minutes to get to observatory deck, one line to get tickets then another line to an elevator, but it was worth the wait.

Excellent view of manhattan and tri-state area (if weather permits). Top view from Manhattan and NYC. Great view. Price is a bit high (32$ single adult). And you have to add an extra 15$ if you want to get a tablet with augmented view of the city (no really necessary, if you know the surroundings a bit IMHO).The elevator are great, with the VR view of manhattan expanding. But I think the "see forever" pitch is cheesy. View is great, but not improved here over what you can see from any other high rise in the city. The 360° view is indoor only.

Great views but you're behind glass.... We pre-booked this and got the priority tickets so saved on a fair bit of queuing, which is always good.There is a strong emphasis on quality service from the happy staff from start to finish although having paid $90+ I didn't feel the need to fork out a further $15 for an informative iPad.The views are amazing as you're 102 floors up above the streets of Manhattan although as you are behind glass it will be hard to get that perfect photo.There are plenty of small presentations from enthusiastic staff talking about the city NYC they love with a passion and these are very informative.The other major downside of this attraction to Top of the Rock is the sheer numbers they allow up at any one time meaning you'll need a fair bit of patience to get some window space to take in the views and get that photo.Good but not great and I would choose Top of the Rock over this if you had one choice.

Great experience. Booked our time for 5pm to see the sunset. The checking in and elevator went smoothly and we enjoyed the express film in the elevator. Once at the top the views of New York are amazing, and we had a wonderful sunset.

A great attraction. Having visited the Twin Towers back inthe 70's we were excited to try thi new attraction. Also the tragedy of 9/11 put this experience into perspective. The "ride". Starts with a presentation as youwalk through going fromsecturity to the lifts. The ride up to the 104th floor takes 60 seconds, and with a virtual presentation on the inside walls of the car this for us was a high point of the visit. The view of course is amazing. A great day out for the family

Wow views. We do this viewing during the day and the Empire State at night. Much easier to access than Empire State with fewer queues and in some ways better views. Outside area of the ice rink interesting too.
Wow OWO.. Cheaper than the Rock and a bit higher. Total 360 views over the whole area. It's great that you can just truth up with little waiting or queuing, but it was a week day.

Moving Experience. I found this to be a truly moving experience.The panoramic views are fantastic but are behind glass (unlike the Empire State Building).The lift to the 102 floor only takes 60 seconds and is an experience it its self.I would definitely recommend a visit.

Worth the trip but get there early. I was skeptical about this attraction after hearing about the long lines and big crowds, but it did not disappoint. We got there early and there was no line for tickets or the elevator. By the time we left, though, the observation area was becoming crowded and it was harder to get near a window to take photos.

Twilight viewing. We chose the twilight viewing and we were not disappointed the views are spectacular. Save you money on not doing the helicopter flight this is just amazing and the views can not be described

Utterly amazing . For $32 this is an amazing experience. The views are spectacular much better than Empire State.The tour part was really enjoyable and then the viewing area just immense. You can see for miles!Get the iPad interactive tour guide it's only an extra $15 but it was so useful as it showed all things you were looking at. It told you all the history of the Manhattan skyline. Allow yourself a good couple of hours to fully experience this.I'd also recommend the food in the cafe with fantastic views all around.Absolutely do this if you are in New York.
Nice vue. Its not the most amazing vue of NY and i don't find the bulding especially beautiful. But they made a good work with the presentation and the vue is still amazing

Useless set-up of screens right in front of the best window.. There is a completely usless set-up of screens called City Pulse right in front of the North window (views directly over Empire State building)If you are willing to take a decent picture from the north side of manhattan, good luck with avoiding that screen-monster and it's belt barriers, plus the reflexes of those many screens on the windows (while visiting after sunset).Don't undestand, how they dared to ruin what's for sure the best view of Manhattan!

Great views. New place to visit for great views and they do not dissapoint. Book tickets or go early to miss the lines. The lead up is a bit over done and the cafe is super expensive. But the view is stunning.

Awesome views, but a pricey. If you want 360 degree views from 100 stories high, and don't mind paying the price, then this is worth it. The views on a clear day are absolutely terrific. You can see all of NYC from Midtown to Downtown, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island, New Jersey, the Hudson and East Rivers. it is really amazing. My recommendation is to get your tickets online ahead of time, so all you have to do is show up 15 minutes before you designated time and get in line. there are specific lines set up, about four of them, which are separated out by times. You show up and tell them what time you have and they direct you to that line. You really don't wait too long to get in the building.You will have to go through an airport type security line with whole body scanners and xray machines. The elevator ride up is amazing. The inside walls of the elevator are actually full height monitors. While you are riding up, they display NYC starting back from the early 1900s and show you how all the buildings came to be over the years. It is really cool. The ride takes probably less than a minute to get up to the top. Once there, you start on the 103 floor and work your way down. They try to sell you this pitch about something. We just passed by without stopping and went down to the 102nd floor. There is a restaurant. You head down to the 101st floor to get to the views. They are amazing. The floor is very crowded, so getting up to the glass may take a few minutes, but be patient and you will get the view you want. The cost was around $26/person, with some discounts for seniors and children. A bit pricey for a few minutes of looking out the window, but I would still recommend if you like this kind of thing.

This is a must do. The set up is amazing done as only America could do it. It takes ages to get anywhere as you go through long queues and pass through heaps of exhibits. Be aware of long queues and allow much more time. Well with seeing.

Upsell with a view. It's a good view. I guess I prefer the option of having the open air. The glass impedes pictures at night. I could also do without the upswell to upgrade to an iPad, or souvenir photos, etc. I still prefer top of the rock I suppose.

Wow. My wife and myself were at the twin towers the night before 9/11, so this visit was both sad and happy, Our grandchildren have not stopped talking about the views from the 140th floor , the lift descends to ground level in 19 seconds

Great views.. Do not go expecting to eat in the café. The coffee is 5.00 and not good. There are no chairs to sit in (I can only imagine they don't want people staying along time). They want to sell/rent to you 1.) a cheesy photo 2.) an ipad that shows you landmarks as you direct it/point it around the city. It really didn't work that well for us and a lot of the buildings we were wondering about were not considered 'landmarks' 3.) gifts from the gift shop where the bathrooms were conveniently located so you could buy gifts. I didn't like the fact that they make you wait to see all the views until you have heard about their Ipad/tablet to rent and taken the photo. I have already paid to go up, I should be able to decide if I want the photo and want to listen to the spill about the tablet/Ipad for rent.

Breathtaking and tastefull. This is a must visit if you are in New York and makes the Empire State building seem dated. It is modern and high tech but fundamentally the views are breathtaking. You have 360 deg views over the south end of Manhattan including the Statue of Liberty and being at the top of this iconic new building in New York is something very special. Right next to the 9/11 memorial and memorial fountains make it top of your list and you must be without feeling if you are not affected by a visit to the One World Observatory and the immediate vicinity. Our 2 sons (13 & 15) said this was the best thing we did whilst in New York and we did a lot so great for all the family.

Best elevator ride ever!. The 360 view from the observatory is awesome, but I've seen the skyline before from The Empire State building. I loved the journey on the elevator. It was very creative and makes the experience even better. The observatory itself was big and roomy. Great job.

possible the most impressive Tower to climb. The brand new 'Single Tower' at One World Trade Center the "Freedom Tower" isthe highest of all the SkyScrapers you can climb in the N.Y.. The quick entry and fast climb is efficient. The most impressive, apart from the obvious View at the very Top, is the introduction at the Top as well as the fashinating Buildingprogress display that runs in the rapid Elevators. The easy access to the 360 degree super View from above is stunning. Thats all Folks !

The View Blows Away all other Buildings in NYC. This place was amazing. It had just opened, but we were able to get in no problem. We did use our smartphone tosee available spots and purchase tickets, to avoid lines. We had gotten the City Pass and were sticking to entertainment included in that, but this was a splurge and worth every penny. The views are amazing. When the elevator opened its doors up top, it literally took my breath away. Loved the time-lapse history of NYC movie that showed as we sped skyward. This is a wonderful attraction.

Only need to do it once. The building is amazing and the process getting in was well organized. When you get to the top I would suggest taking the time to settle in. People are very excited and can get pushy. I walked around once just to take it in. Then went back around. If you are from the area, you will probably love getting the iPad and seeing everything in the area. The downside is lots of people camp out on the window ledges so you are looking over people to the views and take pictures. I did it to cross if off my list. I wouldn't go back.

Amazing!. I'm so happy we did this, it was absolutely amazing! Beautiful 360 views of Manhattan and surrounding states. Well worth the price! The only down side is that you're hearded into a cafe area before you actually see the observatory. Don't feel like you need to purchase anything, it's was overpriced!

Absolutely stunning experience. The visit far exceeded our expectations. We had pre-booked our tickets and were amazed how quickly we passed through the entrance and security. There was very little queuing for the lifts and the experience on the observatory floor was simply breathtaking. Staff were friendly, helpful and informative and there was no rush to move people through their visit. The cafe was a little on the expensive side but this did not detract from the amazing experience. If you have the opportunity - go!

Brilliant 360 degree views. After the disappointment of Empire State Building (ESB) I was unsure what to expect from the One World Observatory. However from the entrance line to the build up of when you reach the observatory, was highly organised and modern. Even though you're not outdoors, you can still take great photos with the Manhattan skyline in the background and you don't need to worry about the outdoor weather when visiting this landmark.It was also great to see outside the North and South pool sites which are in memory of where the Twin Towers once stood. Everything has been done in a respectful manner and you don't get hounded by ticket agents like you do outside of ESB. With this venue now open ESB has a lot of updating to do to continue to compete as an attraction.

Gorgeous Views. Don't buy your tickets ahead of time because you only want to go up to the top on a clear day, then buy them on your phone because the lines are horrendous! You can spend a lot of time at the top because presenters have interesting information to offer. We also had a light lunch in the cafe which was reasonably priced in terms of New York.

Things you need to know. Lets start with buying your ticket. If you buy your ticket on line you must be committed to a specific date and time. I hope it's not raining, snowing or there is too much fog. It's better to check the weather forecast first. Maybe buy only a day ahead of your visit. If you buy the ticket on your cell phone they can scan your cell phone and no need to print it out. There are multiple tiers of tickets. You can risk trying to get a same day ticket. Trying to get a Friday-Sunday ticket is of course your highest risk. Tickets are $32 per person.The entrance is located on west street. It's here that you show your ticket. You could try to purchase your ticket on your cell phone while waiting in line. Next you are herded downstairs to a security checkpoint. It's a full body scan. You do not have to take your shoes off. No food or drinks and like airport security no liquids. From here you go down a hallway lined with bedrock. At the end of the hallway you are again herded into one of many elevators for the trip up.The elevator ride is quick. and needs to be because there are 104 stories. The observation deck is on the 192 floor. I've been to the Pearl Tower in Shanghai, China and in both cases my ears popped and I could not really feel the speed. The sides of the elevator are LCD screens and as you go up the history of NYC is told. The city rises up as you go up. It's spectacular.Once on top you are in a long hall and lined up behind a giant screen. A short video gives you information about NYC, how many visitors and where they came from.. The screen lifts and you are presented with a spectacular view. Pictures do not do justice to the view. It has to be seen. The observation deck is all enclosed behind glass. No outside observation deck. It's a 360 view as you walk in a circle. lots of glare and reflection but you can find free areas. The sun side is really difficult for photos. My suggestion is that 1 hour before sunset is an ideal time to go preferably Mon-Thursday. Since you can stay on top as long as you want, you get day and night pictures. There are bathrooms, a few seats to sit and rest, gift shop and a restaurant directly below. The restaurant sells hot dogs for $7 and beer for $12. This should give you an idea about meal prices. They also have a Sky Portal. On the elevator down a different video is shown in the elevator. In the 16 acre World Trade Center site you have the two twin tower fountains, 9/11 memorial museum and One World Trade Center with the observation deck. You can find a virtual tour online.

Breathtaking views . Was fortunate to visit on a quiet day, so no queuing. Elevator ride up brilliantly done, and stunning views of Manhattan from the top. Bit too much effort to sell you photos etc. but well worth the money for the views alone.

OMG. Will never forget this experience . It was breathtaking , brought tears to our eyes when we looked out for the first time from the 102nd floor over the city,it was totally amazing . The weather was beautiful while we were there and it was spectacular . A memory we will carry with us forever , and to walk around the memorial and read all the names of all the people who lost their lives there . Very sad , but a beautiful memorial in their honour . A must see for everyone who visits N.Y.

Shoddy Design and Consumerism Ruin The Experience. So to begin with- let's talk ticket levels- having been at the top of the Empire State Building at Sunset I thought just how beautiful it would be to experience this building at the most beautiful time of day. For $20 more you can get a "sunset flex" ticket, or you can just do the smart thing and consult a farmer's almanac to find out when sunset will be- this quick google will save you money. It was my boyfriend's first trip to NYC and he was particularly looking forward to this experience for photography alone. The way the gift shop is placed in the center of the observation decks, the closer it gets to night time and beyond, it just reflects in the windows... all my photos have floating merch above the Manhattan view- just what you would want right? Moreover, as others have said, there is NO WHERE to sit and because of this people tend to sit on the ledge of the windows- no one polices this so people who aren't even looking out the window are just hogging up what little space there is to look out. It was just so so so disappointing. The "See Forever Theater" is a joke.... seriously we were laughing at how pointless and bad it was. There was so much potential and it was all ruined by a gift shop and not hiring enough staff. It's a waste of everyone's time and money. You're better off going to ESB by far.... I mean unless you want floating exit signs and tshirts in all your photos....
One amazing place. Truly the only thing i want to say is this should be on everyones todo list while in New York it is truly an amazing place. The elevator ride alone is worth the price of admission

What a great tour guide . I have just been to New York for a week. Decided to do a one world observatory walking tour. What can I say Mike M was Such a great tour guide. He made the tour very enjoyable. The pace was good his knowledge was excellent. His enthusiasm made the tour a very enjoyable experience. My advice take the tour with Mike M
Wonderful, impressive.... In my opinion, it is the best way of having a NYC panorama.I adored it !! The experience starts with the elevator. I do not explain it... it is better to live it yourself.

Amazing views, but busy. A very organised process of moving people around within their time slots. Views are amazing and we were very lucky to have a clear blue sky on our visit. We went at 2pm and it was very busy. You can however stay as long as you like. I personally preferred The Rock as you can go outside and I think this adds to the experience.

Breathtaking views.. The lift(elevator) is just the start of it. At the top you stand behind a rail and wait for a screen to be drawn back. You will not be disappointed. The first sight takes your breath away. One floor below is a cafeteria,( nowhere to sit) and below that a 360° view of the city. Worth every cent. But take a moment and reflect on why this is now there. Along with the Ground Zero memorial, it is a very humbling experience.

Outsanding views (and, in my opinion, much nicer than the Empire State Building). Because of the significance of this building, the outstanding 360 degree views (up to ~40 miles on the clearest of days), the clean and comfortable observation area, and very friendly staff, it would be hard to give this attraction anything but an excellent rating (even for the $32 per adult ticket, which does seem a little steep). In contrast, the Empire State Building -- while iconic and historic -- is not as clean and comfortable, the visit is more rushed and "mechanical", there is sometimes pressure to buy unneeded add-ons to tickets, the views (to me) are not as nice, and the observation area is considerably smaller (although outside, whereas One World is all inside). If you only can do one of these two, my vote is strongly in favor of One World Observatory.

Best views of the City... well worth the money. We stumbled upon the One World Observatory by accident while waiting to go to 9/11 memorial.... What a find!It was one of the highlights of our holiday. There was an employee who gave information and talk on how it was built and surrounding area which was fascinating. Not usually my cup of tea to stand listening to someone talk about a building but considering where I was standing it was surreal.

Great idea gone wrong. Awesome ride up and awesome view, too bad the whole thing is over and over commercialized to the effect of ruining the experience. Top of the Rock beats the World One experience hands down.

Set up like a tourist trap...worth the eventual views?. The process to get from the entrance to the 100th floor observatory is like going through an endless tourist trap with line ups at each step. Too many stops to persuade you to buy something you don't need. The views of New York at the top are amazing, but not sure if it is worth the hassle.Unfortunately, to dine in one of the restaurants at One World, you have to go through all of this first, and you are required to join the mob to get back to ground level.
Excellent Observatory. Great views of NYC. Line up to get up was only about 15 minutes. Elevator ride up is really impressive, as is the video and wall opening at the top to reveal the views.

One world is amazing. This is really one of the most amazing trips to the top of a building in the world. I'm sure others will follow but right now this one is beyond amazing. The elevator ride is a definite do over. My favorite part of this is the ride up and down. It was comfortable up top as far as crowds. There was a small period of time when the line to get onto the elevator down was pretty long but it was because of a large group. We waited for about ten minutes and it once again changed to no line at all. The windows are huge floor to ceiling. The views are spectacular for lower Manhattan. You still need to go to top of the rock to make your birds eye view of NYC.

Highest building I have visited. Over 100 stories,this amazing structure is a must visit if in NewYork area.Views are stunning in every direction.Food,washrooms,gifts,history are all abundant.Personable staff to help...bring your camera.911 Memorial is next door,and cabs easy to obtain outside.Best building I think to see the skyline of NY.

Breathtaking. Highly recommended, don't be put off by the queues they go down very quickly as they are a well oiled machine and get you in much quicker than you expect. Online booking is recommended. The views at the top are stunning, seeing the 2 pools below is amazing and the glass floor where you can see the street below is so cool! Lots of information about the building of it and the original towers and the lift ride itself is an experience of it's own. Will definitely do it all again next time we are in NYC.

Tallest Freedom Tower. One world trade center in lower Manhattan with 94 floorsStarted construction in 2006 and completed in 2014.The height is 541m(with peak height 546m).This is very close to 9/11 site and must visit&admire the architecture.

Amazing views of Manhattan and surroundings. We were lucky the day we went up. It was a crystal clear day and could the views were amazing. With binoculars we could even see planes take off from Kennedy.Make sue to buy your tickets online to avoid standing in line. Everything was very well organized and even with going through security we were in the elevator in 15min.The elevator rides up and down are extraordinary. The screens inside the elevator on the way up show the history of Manhattan, which is great.
Amazing.. I won't give much of the details away as spoiler but if you thought the Empire state bldg was awesome, wait till you see this.

Excellent View but overpriced!!!. The security is similar to airport security and makes you feel safe but does it really necessitate such a high cost to view the city? It was $38 just for the observatory and another $30 for the museum. Wow! Really? The cost for a bottle of water was ridiculous!! I thought $2 on the street was ridiculous for a no name bottle of water. They had the same brand for twice the price. Real crazy. The views are phenomenal so if you are a photographer and want excellent pictures, it is worth the money.

Be ready for the prelim jostle to see a jewel. The getting there is a bit of a gauntlet, long lines despite reserved times, tight tight tight security, claustrophobic prelim video at elevator exit, and wait in line to get a photo taken (whether or not you want one). Grumpy staff seems like visitors are an inconvenient imposition on their day. When the cattle call ends, the views will amaze.

Magical. Opened May 29, 2015, you start on the ground floor watching very clever videos of some of those involved with 9/11. Then you walk some more and see the foundation that NYC was built on. You then zoom up 102 floors in 60 seconds. The elevator show going up and down is very special and best to be surprised. Once on top of the world, there are two decks for observation, snack bar, restaurant, gift shop and you can spend as much time as you wish. Allow 30 minutes for a great experience. For $15 you can rent a locator iPod that shows you NYC landmarks. $32 admission is worth it and then you can walk over to the Memorial afterwards. We went on a Saturday morning and it was not busy. Enjoy.

Wow. The most stunning views of the city, it's not cheap but remember you're probably never do this again! Understandably the security levels are quite high but that is very reassuring  The gift shop is not cheap but you will not find these merchandise anywhere else. So when in town give it a look

Great View of the City. The elevator ride was cool. They had a short video clip, but I went up to see the city on top. You see Jersey and then the other side. I think Empire State has a better view because it's in the middle of Manhattan. $32 each to go up there.

Fabulous!!!. This a a must for anyone wanting to see an overview of the city! It is not bad for people with an aversion to heights because of the way it is arranged. There is no outdoor viewing and you can see a lot without going very close to the window, if you would like.There is food available along with extra tours, but unnecessary to see everything.

Just Amazing. I went here by myself and it was pretty fun not only because I like tall buildings but also because of other things there are along the way up that make the experience really cool. I don't want to spoil it but I can tell you it is more than just coming to a really tall building to see the city from above. You learn about how it was built, about it meaning, and also about New York City. Shouldn't take more than 2 hrs if you buy your ticket in advance, which i highly recommend.

It's all about the view!. A must for visitors to NYC and residents too. The entire procedure is well organized. Tickets are available in advance designating a time for the viewing. Consequently, the lines move quickly.The ascension in the elevator takes but 90 seconds. Not long enough to take in the Manhattan timeline which is flashed on the walls of the elevator. I would love to have more time to study the depiction of the growth of Manhattan Island. Otherwise, the viewing at the top was magnificent. Those familiar with New York City will enjoy identifying the different sites. The Empire State Building is a stick out as are the bridges connecting Manhattan with the boroughs. We were even able to focus on our cruise ship docked in the Hudson River. The Statue of Liberty is easy to spot as are the ferries shuffling back and forth to and from Staten Island. Tours are available, but the signs and tablets posted are a wealth of information. Pick a clear day for maximum visibility.

Worthwhile place to visit. The elevator ride is cool and takes only seconds to get up to the observatory. Once inside the observatory the views are the best. Floor to ceiling windows and have a drink at the bar to fully enjoy the experience. Prices are to be expected considering where you are.
NY shows new perspectives!. With reservation and pre-paid tickets the entrance was efficient. The visit is a show and we felt on top of the world!

Great views. The views were spectacular, you could see all around New York City, every thing is perfectly detailed up to the lifts that showed what floor you were on and the evolution of the building.Great experience, definitely would to it again.

A must see. As this had only just opened we had to go. 102 flights up we could see helicopters flying below us! The information said you could see the curvature of the earth .... but I'm not sure. Well organised but we didn't have advance tickets so had quite a queue.

WOW!! Amazing views... This is an amazing beautiful building on this sacred ground. The building is stunning from all angles. The views at the top are so impressive. Please visit if you haven't and are in NYC. Go on a clear day and you can see amazing sites. You don't need tickets in advance we waited maybe 5-10 min to enter. JUST GO...

Incredible views. My husband and I wanted to go to the world trade center memorial but when we got to the site we decided to go up to the observatory instead. It was beautiful. 360 degree views of New York city and beyond. There is a wonderful restaurant there too and of course a gift store. The elevator ride up is very entertaining as well. Worth the price!

W-O-W!!!. W-O-W!!! This is so impressive. The view is like being in a helicopter. Also the story you get as you go through 'the experience' is fabulous. The pride of the people working on the tower. This is a tower to the pride of being America and all that America can achieve.

Amazing Views of the City. What amazing views! All around, it gives you an incredible overview of the layout of the city from that end of town. From the video on the elevator ride to the intro story to the building of One World Trade Center, it was a great visit! Highly recommend getting tickets online as the lines even in late October 2015 can get long. .

surprising element. Went up to One World Observatory on a clear day and the view is amazing! The staff are much more friendly at the site compared to Statue of Liberty. Well worth going up for the view. The lift going up to the viewing deck is really really quick. Unbelievably quick! There is a 'surprise' element to it as well....(I won't spoil it).There is a lot of space to move around the observation floor.

Excellent view. If visiting this attraction i would advise booking a ticket online to avoid a long wait in a lengthy queue. Once inside the building getting to the observation deck was quite quick, my ears popped twice in the lift which had a very good video of the early years of New York transitioning to present day with the skyline. The view was absolutely stunning on a bright sunny afternoon like today was. After viewing we went into the bar for a drink which had as you would expect was spectacular looking north. The only downside to having a drink in the bar was the fact that within the bill the gratuity of 18.5% was included wether or not the customer received a good service. This is a must visit when in New York

The One World Observatoy. The One World Observatory is something you should not miss. After taking an incredibly quiet elevator ride to the top of the Freedom Tower, complete with a visual story of how New York City evolved over the years, you come to a 360 degree view of NYC, with all the skyscrapers, bridges, waterways, etc. We went there mid-afternoon on a week day and waited on line for tickets (not a bad wait). You can also buy tickets on-line.

Expensive festival of tackiness. In the old days, going to the top of the old WTC used to be a trip to Windows on the World hag a cocktail looking at the great view. It is now an endless trip of trying to sell you franchised rubbish. Still a great view, be a very tacky experience in American cosmmeriist excess. Only go if you can't getnup the Empire State Building.q

Well Worth It!. Outstanding views, and particularly nice that they off non-glare for all the photography buff. I've been to the top of the Empire State Building, the Top of the Rock, and stood on top of the WTC 2 weeks before 9/11, so this was a very memorable visit, on an October day with blue sky and sun the same as on that terribly, tragic day. Magnificent views which result in magnificent shots and memories. I think what impressed me the most was the excellent organization, so while there were hordes of people including school groups, you never felt crowded or rushed, and going through security, while thorough, was easy. We booked our tickets online and chose 11:00 am as the time of our visit. I won't spoil the exciting elevator ride or its climax at the end, however we spent about an hour just looking and snapping pics. A memorable experience!

Best Experience. Anybody visiting New York has to experience this. One of the best views I've seen in my life up to yet.The whole tour is an amazing experience. We had some drinks in the bar on the top floor which was awesome and the bartender was really friendly. You've got to see this!!!Drinks weren't cheap, but we expected this.

Do this first!!!!. I suggest doing this attraction first. It gives you a sense of the entire City and allows you to gain information of all the attractions you may want to do. The staff here is SUPER friendly!!!!!! The technology is perfect. Have your camera ready the moment you step into the elevator and record...coolest thing ever! Go first thing in the morning so you don't have to fight people for views. Spare about 1-1.5hrs. For this attraction. Worth the money!

Great View! Great Lines!. The view at the top is fabulous! It is very nice but it is rather costly and is too commercialized. If you like to move from line-to-line, this is a great attraction. We had tickets for 1:45 and were told we would be up in a few minutes. It took over an hour as I guess there were privileged tickets that allowed people to jump to the front of the line. And they try to rent you an iPad for $15 dollar more after the $32 fee (plus tax). Of course, they took your picture also for you to purchase. From our experience, you should dedicate at least two hours of time as it is 75 minutes in lines to get up and 15 minutes in lines to get down. Again, it is a super view!

Amazing. A spectacular view of NYC and beyond. It is best to go on a clear day as you can see for miles. You can hire a hand held tablet which can zoom in to landmarks in the city and beyond. Very impressive a must see attraction.

One amazing place!. The World Trade Center "Freedom Tower" is an amazing sight that dominates the NY City skyline. It is even more majestic that its original counterpart, and is visible from most sides. I loved the clean, mirror-like finish on the sides that spike up to towering heights from the streets below. It adds the exclamation mark onto photos of the Manhattan skyline...majestic!

It doesn't get any better than this. Born and raised in NYC, I didn't think that I could still be wowed by any of the city's attractions- until I visited this. It's an experience like no other. It's unlike any other high-rise observation deck experience and it's a testament to human ingenuity. The best way to describe it is that the view from here is like the breathtaking view from a place without having to worry about losing it when the plane files past it. No other view from a skyscraper in the city allows you to go right up to the glass and look down. It's truly something to experience, even if the cost will set you back quite a bit.

Great Views and Imaginative Elevator ride. Although you have to watch quickly, the elevator ride to the top shows the history of New York in 60 seconds. The views ar3e fantastic and on a clear day, late in the afternoon you can see the shadow of the building crossing the East River and extending into Williamsburg. Late afternoon is best for photography.
great views. had a great time there. amazing views very organized. didn't have to wait a long time. the grounds were done very tastefully.

Best view on big apple. We booked our day-ticket online from germany.Because we had a priority-ticket we could avoid a long waiting period.Way to the top is enormous quick.On the platform you have an excellent view over the town.We think a visit of this spot is a must.

Amazing!. From the first few steps inside, to the amazingly cool elevator ride, to the short film before you enter, everything is spectacular. Although it really hits home for anyone who lived here through 9/11, the lasting memories of all those brave souls who died that day, this is an amazing tribute to their spirit.
