breathtaking view of the pools. I was disappointed there wasn't an outdoor viewing area, still, it's the WTC and a must see. Seeing the footprints of the original towers was breathtaking. Careful, if you go after dark it is beautiful, but photos through the glass capture a great deal of glare and reflection. I don't know if it would be different during the day. There's also a number of up sells along the way (photo, explorer tablet thingy, etc.) It was still a once in a lifetime opportunity I'm glad I did. Oh, the elevator is super fast and awesome.

Great way to see NYC!. We went on a Sunday morning, no crowd. The entire tour from the time we walked up to the end was fast! You can spend as much time as you want up there. The interactive IPADS you can rent for $15.00 are great. You just hold it up to what you are looking at and it tells you what you are seeing and any information about it. The views are 45 miles around. The tour guides are helpful and willing to answer questions. There is a gift shop and cafe

Up-sell, up-sell, up-sell!. Once we got to the actual observatory, yes - the views were incredible. However, it was getting there that was the issue. First, we booked tickets for 1:30, and arrived a few minutes early. Then, we stood in line. Finally got to go inside around 1:50. So, 20 minutes standing outside isn't bad, but it might be in January! So, they were a little behind, but not terrible. Short lines for security and the elevators - those were not a problem at all. Then they get you to the top. You wait while other groups to arrive, then they put you all in this room where you see a video presentation, and then SURPRISE! The video screens lift up and there's the view! Except then they go back down about 15 seconds later. JK on the awesome view, guys! Then they herd you all into another room. In this room, they try to get you to pay MORE for an iPad thing that can tell you what the buildings you're looking at. The kicker is that in this room, the windows are covered. As in, you COULD have the view, but they don't want you to be distracted while they sell you stuff, so they cover them. Finally you are allowed to take an escalator down to the observatory, but by that time we had such a bad taste in our mouths from all the blatant money-grubbing that it was hard to shake off at first. Oh, and don't worry. There's a cafe and gift shop up there, too. In case you'd like to spend more money...So, yes. The views are awesome. But given that you're already paying a bunch of money for the privilege of looking through the windows, it's really annoying how long it takes you to get a chance to do just that.

The best views, crowded and too many bells and whistles. Because my time was somewhat limited, I took an express ticket (cost is about double, approx 54 US) which takes you to the observatory deck in a few minutes.The elevator is great not only because of its stunning speed but also because it projects the scenery of Manhattan on the walls showing the development during the past four centuries. Once out of the elevator you first have to see a short audiovisual show which is pretty good and then the curtains (literally) are raised and you get a glimpse of the view. Great you would think, but then you are led to a photo shoot (which you can skip), some more explanation, while all the windows are sealed. If you want to move on to the observatory deck you have to walk directly to the escalator one floor down to finally enjoy the views. Quite busy with people trying to take dozens of selfies while blocking the views. But OK, be patient and enjoy the moment. Surely worth the visit!

Poor.... The One World Trade Center Building is a very bad architectural building. It's a shame that so many money was wasted in such a poor tower... Much more design intelligence and creativeness should have been required for those making this in such a special place. The ascensor experience is interesting and, off course, any view from that height would be fantastic in any city. However, the observation experience at night is very bad. As it happens in the inside of the building, all the interior lights of the space and the shops reflect in the windows... My tour lasted only 5 minutes. I don't care about the videos, the shops, the photo-guys, the coffe places.... A terrace for really engaging the city would be enough. If you have to choose, go definitely up to the top of the other buildings, like Empire and Rock.

Incredible scenery. The observation deck gives you incredible 360 degree views of New York City. The $32 entrance may seem steep; however it is well worth the experience and the ability to see the resilience that Americans have to overcome adversity. The elevator ride up to the 102nd floor is an experience in itself.

Impossible to book with UK credit cards. The concierge at my hotel tried, I tried; we tried visa and corporate Amex; the concierge even rang them --- but "computer say "no"".Ridiculous - we have had no trouble booking other attractions etc.
Greatest view in NY. Again, a must see in NY. Very fast elevator to the top. There, 360 view. We can stay as much time as we want.

Incredible 360 degree view. Expensive, but worth doing once to see NYC and surroundings. We had a rare clear day, so our view was amazing. We rented the tablet with building locator, but were not impressed with lack of information. The staff were a lot of fun. They really tried to get us excited about this building (maybe because they were all new on the job). We went end of August during dinner, but before sunset crowd arrived. We had a short wait in line, but it looks like one day lines might be way too long to bother.

Truly amazing. We visited on a perfect autumn afternoon, bright sunshine, blue skies and you really could see forever we have visited Top of the Rock and Empire State on a previous trip but for me this is the best.

Sky High. Simply a brilliant experience – well done, masterful technology and some of the most welcoming staff we have met (except for some of the security staff – why do men associate ‘security’ with ‘moody’?) The lift / elevator experience is exhilarating (unless you are scared of heights as I am!). All in all, a fantastic visit, but guys, $5 for a bottle of water…really? Skyhighway robbery!
Best View Ever. You won't find better views of NYC. But it was crowded and a bit of zoo. The cafe line took forever to get through. Cool iPad rental available for $$.

This is so well done; so much more than the view. Of course the views are breathtaking; but the elevator ride up is unbelievably unique (I am not going to be a spoiler) as is the intro film and the guides and lecturers provided. I took two out of town friends and I enjoyed it as much as they did and I have lived in NYC for over 30 years.

What a view. An excellent experience with marvellous views across New York. Note for the nervous (like my wife) the lifts take only 42 seconds and are very smooth. She actually enjoyed the whole visit despite her dislike for heights. The staff were very pleasant and helpful.

see the world from one world observatory. Absolutely beautiful, the one minute flight to the top is a trip though time. The views from the top are stunning, I think they said you can see three states, the Statue of Liberty all the boroughs of New York, and 7 bridges. It's interactive with the purchase of an iPad, point and pick out a building and you can read all about it. A must see for all skyscraper lovers.

Over produced and over priced. All I really wanted to do is ride to the stop and see the New York skyline. But, I had to endure endless lines walking through "bedrock" upon which the structure was founded with a few tidbits of history and lots of personal anecdotes from people who worked on the site. one might think once none got on the elevator one would go to the observation platform but no. One is taken 1 level above the observation deck for a multimedia production introducing one to the skyline. All I wanted to do was just see it. Of all the things we did in NYC this ranked lowest.

Worth the $32, considering you can spend near-unlimited time up there. Spectacular panoramic views over not just Manhattan, but all of New York City and its outskirts.As others have said, if you want to be able to pick out specific buildings, you need to hire an iPad at a cost (we didn't) - but you should be able to pick out the majority of the city's sights with your own eyes, without paying this extra cost!The dollar price is well worth it, at $32 it's cheaper than, say, The Shard in London or the Burj Khalifa in Dubai - and in my opinion offers better views of a better city!We were blessed to have visited on a very clear and bright day, with a dazzling 360-degree view. There was practically no queue either outside or inside the building, so we were up in the sky in under 10 minutes.The one downside is that because the OWO is deep downtown, your view of Central Park and other NYC green space is of course blocked by the skyscrapers of midtown/Times Square. For a better view of ALL of Manhattan, you'd need to consider the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock instead.Well worth the money, considering you can hang around for as long as you want, once you're up at the top.

A must see while visiting the Big Apple. The drama of the elevator ride up to the 102nd floor and the entry into the top observation is breath-taking and very memorable. The downside is the myriad of selling moments - a photo op in front of this bad large image of NY, a $15 opportunity to rent an IPAD - all of which takes you away from the sunset you should be seeing. Stop marketing to us! Let us enjoy the view! Worth the visit!

From the ashes. I have been on the observation deck at world trade several times. This was my first visit since the completion of Freedom Tower. The first thing to consider here is where you are. There are places around the world that are considered holy sites. Lower Manhattan is the holiest site of all and it is paramount due to its modern connotations. Modern science tells us that 1% of DNA separates us, alters our appearance, makes us unique.. ONE percent! We are far more alike then we are different. If you do not agree that we are brothers and sisters in science then here, on this site where over 2700 people from over 80 nations representing all religions, languages, cultures and walks of life perished together, make us brothers and sisters in blood."The tree of liberty must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants." - Thomas JeffersonAs you walk the grounds consider them, consider that we ALL OF US are the same. Tolerance and understanding is the path to peace.As you ascend to the 102nd floor and finally look out over New York and New Jersey ponder where we have been and where we should be going.Breathtaking viewsover selling of pictures and trinkets by staffThe most important historical site of modern times

Absolutely Stunning!. I found the entire experience experience to be well-orchestrated. I purchased the regular timed-entry ticket, showed up early as recommended, and was admitted early. I do recommend going in the morning for the most relaxing visit. Once you are up there you can stay as long as you want, so it does gets gradually more crowded as the day progresses, although I think the average visit time is between 1 and 2 hours. I won't give away the surprise experience that occurs just before one is admitted to the observatory, but I can pretty much guarantee it is an experience you will never forget!

Best Views In New York. Nothing will ever replace the twin towers but the One World Trade Center is a fitting replacement! A stunning building!$32 to get to the observation deck and worth every penny. The journey starts as soon as you get in the lift, all i will say is make sure you have your camera ready! You shoot up 102 floors in about seconds (your ears will pop), one out the lift you are shown a simulation so its like you a flying through New York and then the screens raise and wow! What a view! You then walk around the whole observation deck and the views are breathe taking! It is truly something you have to experience whilst in NY!There is a cafe and restaurant at the top of the tower to. we opted to have a sit down lunch in the restaurant with the stunning views as a back drop! As you can imagine it is not cheap, we shared a few starters and 2 drinks and it came to $117 but you cant knock the quality of the food!On getting back down to ground level, upon leaving your a given a little gift card for C21 which is nice, cant complain with money of shopping!Overall, amazing experience!

Awesome !. From the moment you step into the elevator to go up at incredible speed....not so you notice though....this is an amazing experience. The graphics are vibrant and exciting giving an outline of the growth of New York. When you step out into the first observation area another audio visual display covers the wall showing NYC as it is today. The views are amazing...in fact quite surreal. We were booked at 5.30pm to see the sunset and watch the City light up. (If you are a MasterCard holder don't forget your card for priority access which cuts down on queuing!) Having said that, queues moved quickly. Food and drink not cheap, but hey, it is a captive audience,

on top of NYC. From the observatory you get an amazing view of NYC. The whole site is extremely well run and well presented, but there were a few things that annoyed me. For one, it is relatively expensive $32/person and for another, once up there they are looking for other ways to take your money. One particularly annoying feature is their oneworld Ipad accessory which they push you to rent. That really didn't bother me, but it did bother me that there are no maps below any of the observatory windows and no indication for any of the sites you are viewing so that it makes it hard to know where to look if you don't rent the iPad . But other than that, I enoyed the site, the view and even the elevator ride up - which offers a short video of NYC.

Spectacular. We booked the timed ticket so that we had immediate access to entry. We were whisked by the fast lift to the viewing platform. Possibly the best city views available l have seen in any city. Modern facilities, well run, friendly staff and easy to get to.

Great place to visit. Great views! Good food and drinks too.. Outstanding views of NYC area. We spent a couple of hours here enjoying the breathtaking views. We also had drinks and appetizers. You can order these and enjoy while sitting along a long bar at the observatory windows taking it all in. We spent a couple of hours at the observatory and enjoyed every minute of it!

Too much expensive but a nice view. I think is too much money for an observatory (32$) and if you want the ipad experience is more 15$, the ipad is for you point from the observatory and know the name of the buildings that you are seeing

Awesome!! A must!. We visited Top of the Rock and Empire on our trip. What set One World apart besides the height was the Ipad. They have Ipads that you can use for a small $15 fee. When you hold the Ipad up to the city it will name the buildings, and other things that you are looking at. It would even give you a brief history of some of the things in your view, for example a quick history of Cony Island.

A REAL PROOF OF HOW GREAT AMERICA IS. On my understanding there is no any other people in the world like Americans.Only them can overcome a threaten like they had on 09/11.On being there you can see all the greatness of this country.You have to be there to feel the emotion that touch every one who knew the saga of September 11.This new skyscraper is the real proof of the power and greatness of America.

One World Observatory- World Trade Center. The view is stunning and well worth the fee. We enjoyed the 360 degree viewing experience. I must admit that I by error stated we visited the top of the rock observatory when it was actually the One World Observatory that we visited.

Too Commercial for me but Worthwhile. We visited in October 2015 after spending the afternoon at the 911 museum. It was a sharp contrast to the memorial. One world building has a Disney land approach to the views of lady liberty and lower Manhatten. After opening in May to massive fanfare, the $30+ tickets are just the tip of the iceberg as far as the price paid for the view. Pictures, food et etc. are all available for purchase. Clearly, the foundation needs money to operate the building. The 55 second elevator ride was incredible and the best part of the experience. Crowds are to be expected but the experience pales in comparison to the observation deck once available at the WTC - South Tower. Good effort to reinforce the resilience of the people of the USA and NYC.

Great views but.... Stunning building and amazing view. The "but" is due to the attempts to get yet more money from customers when at the Observatory. On exiting the lift a short film is shown and the doors then opened to a room where you are subjected to a sales pitch. Yes, they will tell you what you can see from the Observatory via a tablet device for a whopping $15. We decided against this and were disappointed that there is no signage giving information eg building names etc. Two of the corners are blocked for a strange performance where a visitor guide gives information about the City. Few showed any interest in this patronising performance.
Worth checking off the bucket list.. Went on an overcast drizzly day. Had no wait and stayed up there a little more than an hour. Cheaper than a plane or helicopter ride and worth doing once.
to the top of the world. We had an enjoyable visit no lines...thankfully but a little expensive just to see a view..mind you it was an experience that I would not have missed.

Unparalleled, Memorable Views. I remember standing atop the World Trade Center towers in September 1999, as a little lad. At the time, the adrenaline was pumping; I had a fear of heights which has been overcome in 2005. As I witnessed the events of September 11, from a television in school, I cried. The building I had visited exactly two years ago was crumpled. But I came here once in June, and decided to come back. The views remind me of the glorious twin towers. Unparalleled, you truly do see forever.

Views. Pricey, but worth it for the views. The whole experience is well organised and ran smoothly. The views are spectacular although photo opportunities are spoilt a little by glass, covered in fingerprints and head prints at eye level. The elevator ride is awesome, both up and down.
It is one of ten places in NY what you must to visit. It is one of ten places in NY what you must to visit. The best view on Low Manhattan, Brookline and bridge to Brookline.

Amazing. The views are absolutely amazing. We had timed tickets and we're through shortly before our time. The video on the journey up is great as well. Shop and food in the observatory seemed expensive.

Expansive vistas on a clear day. Atop the tallest building in the western hemisphere. Highest observatory in lower Manhattan, at floors 100-102 of One World Trade Center. It one-ups the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center observation decks. Clear views in all directions (weather permitting, of course). Gift shop, restaurant and restrooms. The elevator to the top (“Sky Pod”) is really fast. An Apple View (tablet) is available at extra charge which lets you point at a cityscape and identify buildings by name. Entry is by blocks of time. Do get your tickets in advance through the web site to avoid delays in entry.

Must Visit - Awesome Views. Well worth the visit and plan on spending an hour or so taking in the views from the top. Suggest making reservations on line to avoid the long waiting lines. Great for the whole family.

Surprisingly good food in an amazing setting. The view is breathtaking, worth every dollar of the price to get to the 100th floor of this amazing building. But, after the lines (buy your tickets in advance) and the astonishingly quick elevator ride (complete with historical graphics showing the city's development) you might recall that you are hungry, or thirsty. If that's the case, visit the restaurant. Good beer, great snacks in a relaxed but grown up atmosphere. Service was helpful and timely, the food was very good (we had lighter plates) and the view is unmatched. More than worth a visit and a very pleasant interlude during your sight seeing day.

This is Worth Visiting for the Views. We brought our British friends who were visiting here. Not sure I would have gone otherwise since I used to work at World Trade Center and have seen the views many times, but the place is too painful to visit on my own. I must say it is much improved from the original structure although the view is the same. However, the elevator ride is so much better! No more popping of the ears. They show you the progression and development of the area on a screen as you climb the 100 floors in a quick 60 seconds. Don't look at your phone or talk to your neighbor or you may miss the entire show. Then as you reach the top, they lift the screen to see the entire real view. Very dramatic. FYI, they do not show you the same view on the way down. The coffee shop is very expensive, $6 for a cappuccino, but a nice place to enjoy the view away from the crowds. Make sure you walk around the 360 room. I actually did not make it all the way around as I got stuck in the NJ views. Also better to go up on a nice day. We had awesome weather and visibility was more than 20 miles!

FANTASTIC . Totally amazed. Definitely hire the $15 iPads if like me you're not familiar with many of the buildings. I was entertained for well over an hour! We went into the restaurant and sat down for drinks - they let you sit at the bar for drinks, which was lovely with the views. A *must see*

Room with a view. My visit was a little overshadowed by memories of my previous most memorable trip to the observatory in one of the original World Trade Center towers in 1998. This new observatory is slick and new and has the views but I don't think it was very well thought out. All of the Windows have ledges that have slats that appear to be vents and people sit and stand on them. If they are vents, won't debris from their shoes fall in there? And when people are sitting there, you can't get very close to look down from the Windows at the sites below.

Great Views At An Iconic Spot--Will Be Emotional For Some. One World Observatory offers spectacular views, as did the old World Trade Tower's Windows of the World. There was way too much time spent on getting visitors to rent iPads. The elevator rides were great but fast. Take in the exhibits as best you can going up and down. For those of us who visited the old towers (I took students there every year for over 30 years), there were several painful moments. I imagined people jumping when I looked out in one direction, and in looking down at the memorial. If 9/11 is too close to you, you may want to wait longer....
museum and fountains. We were enthralled and yet saddened by the exhibits at the museum and thought the fountains were so moving and touching

Well designed observatory. My husband booked observatory tickets without my knowing. I will preface this by saying that I'm not a big fan of observatories. You go to the top, and you're able to see everything, and that's about it.I will say that the presentation in how to get to the observatory is well designed and aesthetically pleasing, and is somewhat similar to the layout at the Burj Khalifa in Dubai I went to earlier in the year.What can I say, observatories just aren't my bag. But I'm giving it a positive rating because of how well everything in the observatory was done:- Walking through the "faux" bedrock- The elevator giving you a visual as you rise to the top- The personalization of all the individuals that worked on the building- And the quality of the view itself (you truly can see all of NYC, the boroughs, and beyond)To me, it seems a bit pricey for what it is, but if you enjoy this kind of thing, you'll love it!
Great view. Nice restaurant.. The fast elevator ride show the city start to grow as you near the top. Then the doors open to a view of NYC. Very well done. Great view. Nice restaurant.

102 floors up. The new modern alternative to the Empire State building for views of Manhatten opened early 2015. Slick and up to date presentation with video walls telling the story of the building then you get in the lift and you get a projected image of the history of NewYork before you reach the 102nd floor. A stunning entrance then greets you to the observation deck. Not open like ESB but visually brilliant

Some problems. This is something I woud do again, but....you have to buy an observatory ticket to eat at the restaurant. I would go back to dine again because the food was good, but not worth another $15 a head once you've seen the view. They also had a very loud program going on just below the balcony where we were seated...VERY loud. Totally ruined the ambience and dining experience. On the bright side, the servers were very nice and the food was delicious. But they need to think a few things through if they want repeat diners.

One World Observatory. The Observatory was very impressive, displays were great and the best view in the world. Our plan was to visit Observatory, have a bite to eat in Café, then go to Museum. Were very disappointed to find that the Café had no seating so opted for a drink at the bar in the dining room, head to Museum and we pleased to find a local pub nearby for food which turned out to be great. Would suggest that the website be more clear regarding the accommodations in the Cafe

Breathtaking views!. Tip. If you haven't pre-booked get there early. No time limit once you're in......a good two hours is enough unless dining in the restaurant. Coffee shop is pricey -$6 for a muffin or a coffee.Magnificent views 360deg. $33 for adults and $30 for seniors.

Awesome view, but make sure the weather is good. The view from the top of the observation deck is stunning, there is no other way to describe it. However, the rest of the visit is a little on the disappointing side.I would strongly recommend anyone to buy the Expedited package, it may be an additional $20 per person but the lines can be horrendous trying to get in to the building, then again through security and then to the lifts. The expedited packages let you bypass all of the lines and get straight on the next lift.The lift itself is brilliant, showing the story of NYC changing over the past centuries until you get to the summit and the present day, it is very smooth and you don't even feel like you are moving (very much/fast).At When at the top there is the typical hard sell of the panoramic video devices, and etc, before you get into the observatory, but this can be bypassed. I do think that at $54 a ticket that this should be included. The bars and restaurants at the top are also a little pricey - $5 for a (cold) drip coffee is extortionate. We did try to visit the bar for a hard drink but were told that it was by reservation only that day - nice to be made aware. There is the obligatory gift shop with over priced stuff on sale. The staff on the observatory floor are very helpful, showing you lots of hidden stories and gems of Manhattan, the rest of NYC and Jersey However the really poor part was the time that it took us to get down, almost an hour spent in line waiting for the lifts to take us down - mainly due to the shear number of people and a lack of direction from staff.In all it was a fantastic experience, especially as we visited at sunset, so got to see day, dusk and evening, and pretty good value on the whole.

Commercial but impressive. Very commercial but well run and amazing views, the views would obviously be better on a clear day. Photography can be awkward as there is lot of glass and reflections.There is no premium areas and your tickets give you access to all round views. Seemed a bit commercial but worth it to see the south of the island. Overall I preferred the rock for photography and location even though it is smaller.

Birthday Trip. This wasn't part of the New York pass but we decided to check it out anyway & it is AMAZING. Just to get great photos from the top is so worth the fee to get in. They put a big effort into this place and it shows!

Views everywhere. This tower gives great views of downtown, Liberty island, and Brooklyn. You can see forever. Buy your tickets online and book your time to save a half hour plus wait in line. Dont spend the $15 to get the ipad when you get to the top, its not worth it.

So cool. The really got this right. Very hip, modern experience plus the view is obviously incredible. The ride up the elevator may be our favorite portion so be ready with your video camera as we were not!

go when it's a clear day. if you go on a clear day you can see 3 states. go early. if you have questions, make sure to ask the 2 people at the designated spots, the rest of the employees aren't very helpful. the I-pad map/features thing that they try to upgrade you to doesn't show you everything, just hi-lights. so, if you're curious about buildings that aren't on the display you have to try & find someone who can answer. save your money, you probably already know what/where everything is anyway.
Excellent view. We went to the to of the new higher tower in Manhattan. The elevator is really fast and show to us the history of manhattan

Breathtaking . We went here with my family for the first time and it was just breathtaking. It's definitely not heap but it worth the money. Everything is high end and nice. From the entrance to the elevator to the video you watch. You will not regret going to this. I have been there a second time since August.

AMAZING!!!!!. I can't really say much because I don't want to spoil that Experience for others. I can say it was a well thought experience. We were up there for 2 hours and never felt like we had to leave. Everyone was just having a Awesome time. We had drinks and food at the Restaurant. Took many many pictures. I recommend it to Everyone. I will tell you this.You get to the 102 floor in seconds. One Elevator straight up. Oh and it was Emotional but not in a negative way. Every video was positive. I Loved it and will do it again. Price wise was great also. We were Blessed with a Clear day In the Sky!!!!

Super view of Manhatten.. We went to the top of the one world tower. Superb views of the whole of the island. The lifts were amazing - I won't spoil the surprise!! The only minor issue was the food in the restaurant was expensive. The was a cafe style part but there were only tables with no chairs, which meant that you could not be there very long. After walking miles a sit down was required so we ended up in the restaurant paying over $80 for 4 bowls of soup and 4 drinks. Still great experience overall.

Stunning view but can the sales pitch.. Visited on a fairly quiet Sunday around midday. Security check was quick and we had a short wait for the elevator. Really cool show on the way up so be good to get in on a quiet day so you aren't too squashed to see it.Once up to the top the pre show was clever and prepared you for the stunning views.I HATED that they herded you into an area to hear a sales pitch on the iPad hire felt very cheap and nasty as well as a bit off considering why such a building now exists. PLEASE PLEASE GET RID OF THIS. Reminded me of the guys in Times Square trying to hand you those "free" CDs. We just got out as soon as we could.Views stunning and we were lucky to catch one of the guides doing a talk on the building and some fun facts about NYC. Overall it was good to go and see it but a bit sad as well as it shouldn't be there.We booked a timed ticket but if the weather has been cloudy no refund / alternate time is available so that would have been disappointing if the weather had been bad.

One World 360. There's a fantastic view, New York 360, from the observatory and the video during down lift is amazing. Besides that there's a device showing every important point of the city as Statue of Liberty, for example.

Amazing. Views are fantastic. Only two comments - why was there a man at the top of the building promoting pizzas (so random and out of place), also difficult to take photos with the lighting. It would be great to have the correct lighting so that the people in the photos are not dark - it was impossible to get the lighting balance right so my photos show my friends in darkness with the view behind. Also, the building inside is so sterile and bland, pity to have missed a chance to make a statement about the city (or anything).

One world. I very much enjoyed visiting this site. The elevator ride to the top is fantastic and clever. The view is breath taking. An iPad is offered to help highlight the points of interest. A bit pricy, but well worth it if you have the time.

Combination of river and city views. Went there at 9AM - so we were the first visitors that day.The views were amazing! it was really nice that everything is so new and high tech - such as the extremely quick elevator.we used it as a starting point to a walk in the financial district, chinatown, and SOHO

Amazing views, Great experience!. Visited the new One World observatory at the end of September. This new tower, opened to the public at May 2015, was one of the most exciting attractions in our NYC visit.The whole experience is very impressive - from the entrance to the observatory, through the elevators, and of course the wonderful views from the top.Recommended to visit on clear sky days.The entrance fee is not cheap - cost us 32 dollars per person - but for us it was worthwhile!

A show instead of a great experience. When you buy timed tickets online you don't have to wait in line to get in.We were there for the view, but it took a long time to get there! The elevator ride was great with a media show that showed how Manhattan has grown over the years.When getting out on the 100th floor you had to watch another media show before the curtains went up and you got a glimpse of the view. Then you went in to the next room where you had to spend a couple om minutes while a guy tried to rent you an IPad that could guide you. 15 dollars to rent an IPad!!! No thanks.Finally we were there where we could enjoy the views - and they were beautiful. But the reflections from the windows made it almost impossible to take good photos. In the corners where the best views are they have made some kind of media show (again), so you couldn't go there.All in all it is too much a show. The views are so great so you don't need all this stuff. You also pass by some photographers who want to take the perfect overpriced tourist photo.For 32 dollars it is too much a circus instead of a good experience.

Great View! Very well done!. I took my children, and we loved this experience. The building is state of the art, and the visit to the observatory is really well done. We booked on line ahead of time, and had no problems. We went in the late afternoon and stayed to watch the sunset. It was glorious!

Toss up. Had to make a decision about whether we did this or the Empire State and listening to advice from others, came down on this side of this. Very painless as not that terribly many people in queue, indeed the guy beside us had paid 20 dollars extra to be in priority queue. Waste of money at this date at this time. It's all very flash and orchestrated, but the real star of the show remains that stunning view!
Excellent experience. A must when in NY. The views are amazing and the whole thing is well done. A drink at the top is lovely especially at dusk.
Great views. Trip up and down in the lift very well put together. Spectacular 360 degree views, well worth the price. Pre- booked the tickets so walked straight in.

Highlight of our trip. We booked this before we left as we wanted to be there fairly early and it was cheaper online. We saw the memorial first, which was very moving, and then walked over to the entrance and got in earlier than we had booked as there weren't many people around. The elevator was very fast and only took about 50 seconds. When we got to the top, there was a short introduction and then, wow, the whole of Manhatten was revealed. We spent about an hour looking from different sides, and, luckily, it was a clear, sunny day.Also you can hire ipads which tell you about what you are seeing, plus guides who are very helpful. Absolutely worth going to so, if you're going to New York, don't miss this. We went on the subway and it was very easy to find.

Great views, too much selling the experience. It's the 5th highest building in the western hemisphere apparently so just take me to the top and let me look out the windows. They spent far too much time selling the "experience" and doing CGI stuff, along with trying to get you to rent an ipad. All you want to do is look at the city and take in the views - which when you finally get to do so is really good. However wouldn't go again, would return to the Empire State building, still the king of buildings and viewing platforms.

Very touching scene indeed. We visited the One World Trade Centre and it was a very moving and emotional site to see the memorial with so many names inscribed on it.. It takes you back to those times when the building collapsed due to terror attack for no fault of. common office going citizens.. Can never forget this trip in my life and I came back home feeling sad and upset... Kudos to all the families of the victims for putting up such a brave act and accepting the reality.. The new One world trade centre building looks awesome and it was a very memorable trip for me and family...

amazing. what more can you say, it is a truly humbling and awe inspiring experience to visit this place, so much has come from such much pain here, but the resilience of the new york people to compete against the odds and say "look what we've done" it is so inspirational, the building is huge and the architecture is fantastic

Tallest in Western Hemisphere. 1 World Trade center is tallest building in the western hemisphere and 5th in world. Come up after 9/11 and named as Freedom Tower initially. Now Officially the 1WTC. I am not sure whether it is open to public but is visible from 9/11 memorial and good to look at.

Best view of NYC. The spectacle begins in the elevator ride up to the observation deck - don't face the doors or you'll miss the show. These folks have taken some tips from Disney World in their effects and presentations. However, human special effects can't compare with the 360 degree view. We were fortunate to visit on a clear sunny day, so we could see all of NYC and a good chunk of NJ. Best bet is to buy your tickets in advance and arrive shortly before your scheduled admission time.
Breathtaking. A breathtaking work of art that is visible from many locations in Manhatten, New Jersey etc...a must see.
Great time!. Great views at night! Kind of expensive...the elevator trips are really cool. Not for those with fear of heights though...

Unforgettable Views. We visited here on our first day. We had arrived late the previous evening & had seen nothing of New York. What an amazing introduction to this magnificent & proud city. I cried when the windows opened at the top. Great little lift ride to the top then a great little presentation & a dramatic reveal of the view we were about to see. Moving & dramatic. If u visit one tower while you're in the city, make sure it's this one. The best experience ever with views to really write home about!

Worth every penny. Awesome everything. . This is so well done. We have been up in top of the rock and the Empire State Building. This is the winner. First, it's brand new and shiny and It has the latest technology. The 60 second elevator ride up is a giant led TV that shows a cool movie about how the landscape has changed over the last 100 years. Yep. All that in 60 seconds. And that's just the ride up. The entire elevator is the tv screen. It's awesome. You arrive quickly at the top and have a few minutes of an annoying sales presentation on their $15 iPad upgrade. It didn't last long. My advice: decide ahead of time if you want to rent their iPad for $15 and grab it, if not, move on to the view. The view is awesome!! You feel like you can "see forever". It was a clear day. We could see citi field all the way in flushing! The Empire State Building is gorgeous. It's nice to see the island and you can really begin to appreciate the number of tall structures and bridges. The only thing you really cannot see is Central Park. There are too many tall buildings. If that is important to you, then pick top of the rock. This is the best Ariel view of lady liberty (unless you did a helicopter and got a little closer). There is a "city portal" where you can see the street below in real-time. It looks like a glass window, but it is really more LED TVs with a real-time camera. Impressive everything. Even the ride down in the elevator was exhilarating.

Spectacular View. We booked our time in advance to ride to the observation tower. From ground level to the 102nd floor. Videos are shown on the walls of the elevator on the history of New York so you do not notice. Has to be the best view from all of the choices in New York. We were fortunate it was a beautiful clear day and you could see for miles. Recommend it be done at the same day as the 9/11 Museum and Memorial

Stunning attraction and staff. Booked tickets for this attraction through a company and with a bit of a mix up didn't receive the tickets through to down load onto my phone.I attended at the attraction and found the staff couldn't do enough to assist me,especially a member of staff called Kyle G who was stationed at the front door.I couldn't thank him enough for being helpful and friendly.HE is a real asset to the companyWith assistance also from the public information team who contacted the ticket company for me I finally got my tickets The views were stunning from the top

Amazing Views. As you might expect, amazing views from the top. Paid for the "Priority Access" and it was worth not having to wait in any lines. They could do without the hard sell on the iPad rental to "enhance" your experience and the forced official photo (of which we quickly opted out of)...but I get the crowd control value of it. Only disappointments were the lack of an outdoor observation deck, and the "Sky Portal" (nothing more than a video feed under your feet).Of the three major observation decks in the city (To of the Rock and Empire State Building being the other two), this one is most spectacular as you might expect. But, if I only could choose one I would pick the Top of the Rock first. The Empire State Building and Top of the Rock have the added thrill of an outdoor component.
Very nice view of the City. Well done for crowd control. Great 360 degree view of New York and New Jersey. Glad we were able to go

Beautiful architecture. This is a beautiful architectural building dedicated to 911 and also for working in plus having tower 123 by it makes it extra special and to see how much time it took to build
WALKING TOUR WITH ANNE OF VIATOR.COM. ANNE did a great job through the tour adding many details and experiences unknown to us beforehand. She guided us to find a friends name on the South pool.

You Really Can See Forever!. After spending the morning at the very powerful September 11 Museum, a trip to the One World Observatory was the perfect way to see how NYC has bounced back. You can feel the optimism and I've never been so proud to be a New Yorker and an American. It's expensive, but well worth the visit.
Trip to the Observatory Deck. You MUST do this in NYC. Amazing and powerful. The video in the elevator to the top and from the top to the ground is incredible. And the views are obviously unmatched.

Stunning Views. If this is your first trip to New York, then this is the place for absolutely stunning views.There is no time limit on your visit and no rushing around by visitors.The queuing and security search area have no public toilets available until you clear security, this took us over 45 minutes, so go prepared!The detailed timeline presentation in the lifts is well presented, but appears to be over too soon, you need to have your camera/video ready from the outset.I am still unsure if this attraction was a little overpriced or did the views make up for the entry fee....
Just amazing..... Hard to put this into words. A view to remember. Fantastic experience well organised. Even the lift ride is brilliant.
Beautiful. We did not go inside, but we saw the exterior from about every angle, except from above, and it is fabulous

Great experience and stunning views of not only Manhattan. The experience is very different from the 2 other viewing platforms. There is more information provided by the staff presentation is you want to listen in. The biggest difference is still the sight as you can look the other way at Uptown Manhattan and you can see all the way to JFK, Brooklyn and New Jersey and the beaches on Long Island.

What an amazing view!. A gorgeous building, very modern and futuristic. I particularly loved the elevator ride up the top and also the theatrical movie about New York which was really unexpected! Friendly and knowledgable staff is a HUGE plus.

Beautiful view.. I have never seen anything like this before. My first trip to NY loved being able to see the entire city in one stop. Not crowded, timed tickets really helps with that, we were able to see everything and did not feel rushed.

Definitely a unique experience, marvelous presentation. First of all the reason they had to build this building after 9/11 is still unsettling. With that said they did a marvelous job recreating the old 107 floor observatory. The entire staff working there was super friendly. Like Disney word friendly, something you just don't see in NY. The experience builds you up for the view and has really intense technology in the elevator and on the floor to add to the experience. The drawbacks are timed entry and crowds. The timed entry is annoying since you have to commit an exact time when you are coming and even with that its still pretty darn crowded when trying to get to a window to look at. We allotted 1h 15 mins which was not enough time if you wanted to casually look around because you burn through almost 30 mins going up and down waiting in lines. Website I think recommended 45- 1 hour , which is too little.

Excellent views . I knew that I wanted to visit one of the high observation points but could decide between here, the rock and empire state. In the end I opted for one world trade centre and am glad I did. The views up manhattan to midtown are great, as well as beyond. The only down side was the 'marketing walk' to reach the viewing level. You Frist have to listen to a sales pitch for some ipads that give you details of building you can see, then trail around and past the restaurant before getting down to the viewing level. Queue looked long but moved extremely quickly. The lifts only take a minute in each direction and probably fit 20-30 people.

Wow, stunning views and a memorable "reveal". Visited on a sunny morning in October, bright blue skies. No lines so straight up in the lift, which had a great story of NY playing out as you travelled upwards. A short presentation, followed by a brilliant and moving "reveal" of the views. Bright and airy viewing area, not too busy so you could get close to the windows at every point and see 360 degrees

Must See!. We were walking past the observatory after visiting the 9-11 Memorial and decided to go in. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I was very glad we stopped.The whole experience is very well done. Lots of computer technology enhance the experience and it feels very new and exciting. Kids will love this experience and it is accommodating for all ages.Good dose of history, but not overwhelming because of the presentation.All of the presenters were extremely friendly and willing to talk and answer questions.I don't want to give away any of the surprises, but highly recommend this attraction!

Amazing View!. What a view. See the city from the top! Amazing and right next to the memorial of the twin towers. An honor to be able to experience it. My only complaint was the lack of customer service or rather patience that I could see toward other guests and us by staff members. When someone asked, "this way is the exit?" and was answered with, "that's what I said," was rude and not called for. Left us feeling as if we were unwelcome. The only staff that seemed nice and attentive was those that promoted the iPad map. The others made it feel like a ride at Disneyland and it's so much more than that. I hope they can find out how to bring respect throughout especially since the building represents so much.

Great view but pricy and chaotic . I've been to other observatories and this one takes the cake. However- I wish there was an outdoor deck, and there wasn't an extra fee for the viewfinder. I feel like it should just be an app on your phone when you visit that you can use if you want. I also wish we can view our photo taken at home to purchase since ours "was not ready yet" when we left. Other than that I loved the big reveal and would go back!

An Over-produced Experience. The problem with the new One World Observatory is that it is way over-produced. First, they made everyone wait outside before entering the building...on the day I went it was very windy and probably 45degF outside...very cold to be making people wait outside. Once we finally got inside, there was lots of open space inside where people could have been allowed to wait...not sure why they make everyone wait outside. Once you finally get inside and get through security, you start off in the basement of the building in a tunnel whose walls are fake rock (seriously...if you tap them they sound hollow), and that's supposed to illustrate how the foundation of the building has been securely built into the ground. Then, you take an elevator up to the top. The elevator has no views. Instead, its walls have an elaborate illustrated depiction that show visually how the city of new York has changed from its founding in the 1600's to present day. Kind of cool, but frankly unnecessary if you just paid $32 cause you were only interested in seeing the view at the top. Then, once you get to the top, they make you stand in front of a large wall onto which they project a movie that shows a lot of views of people and places in the city...it's pretty much just like some montage that an NYU film student probably made. Then, the wall onto which movie was projected actually lifts up and exposes the view. But, you still can't take it in. Instead, you are ushered into a room next door where they give you a sales pitch to rent for $15 a tablet that you can point at any building in the city and it will tell you what that building is. Then, you are forced to take a photograph with the people in your party so that they can try to sell it to you as you leave. After all that is done, then finally you can take time to walk around the windows and enjoy the view. It's a lot to go through if really you just wanted to be able to take a few photos from the top. I've been to the Sears Tower in Chicago, and it's a much simpler and enjoyable experience: buy your tickets, take the elevator to the top, get off and take pictures of the view. Enough said.

Absolutely awesome.. Amazing experience from the on line timed entry ticket, free WiFi and no queue's to the incredible views. The high tech experience from start to finish was totally impressive. Didn't do the other towers so nothing to compare them to, but we were glad we chose One World, as it was an unforgettable experience.

Museum well worth it!. You could easily spend hours here. We bought our tickets ahead of time and it still takes awhile to get inside. Lots of people trying to get in. You really need to be there 30 minutes at least before your tour begins. We just bought access to museum and walked around ourselves. It wasn't too crowded inside and lots to see!

Great View from an Iconic Building. As a New Yorker who visited the twin towers, I had to visit to see the views again. We visited on Saturday night around 6pm and although we purchased tickets on-line, there were only about 20 people on line waiting for tickets. Yes, the elevator is unique in that full wall screens on 3 sides replicate the view as you ascend the building. And you are taken into a room where there is a short multimedia display about New York before the screens are lifted to show the real view of New York through the windows. The views are incredible from the 100th floor, where you can see from all sides of the building. The problem is that people sit at the bottom of the window sill and it's a little awkward to take photos with people sitting below you. The other thing is that there is glare in the photos from the interior lights. My wife and I like taking photos so this was a disappointment. We stayed until they kicked us out at 8pm, but around 7:45pm, most of the people left and you can get a window pane for yourself and take photos. You can get good photos of the view but it's tough get one with someone in the photo due to the glare. Not like the Top of the Rock, where you can go outside and get great photos without glare. If you must choose between the Empire State Building, the Top of the Rock and here, I would suggest choosing between those two.

A magnificent experience out of a tragic event!. Just approaching the building brings a flood of emotion for me. I watched the building of the original Twin Towers and watched the horror of 9/11. We have been to the Reflection Pools and the Museum. This is a different experience. In some ways almost Disney-esque. The tribute that the individuals that actually worked on the project to rebuild gave is profound for many other reasons. The trip in the elevator going up and the mystery of what is behind the glass and the presentation is a bit suspenseful and entertaining. Once they raise the window coverings and you experience the 360 degree views, you stop in your tracks. We bought timed tickets for 5 PM so that we could witness the 6:13 PM sunset on October 16h, so it is wise to do your homework if you want that experience. It was crowded, but not so much that you can't walk around and get good photos. You do have to be patient and wait to get close enough to the windows for the optimal view. It is worth it. The merchandising is what does not appeal to me. The taking of your picture when you enter the zone so that they can ultimately try to sell you a picture as you exit at street level is a bit hokey. There is food, but not a very large area or a big assortment. The Gift Shop is precariously located in the middle of the Observation area and can get congested. And the things I looked at were extremely expensive. They do have devices to rent that are pretty cool if you want explanations of what you are looking at. And there is very knowledgeable personnel to help with questions and explanations of what you can see from this high up, but they are fielding a lot of questions, so don't count on them for long.Overall, I look forward to a return trip.

Amazing view. Booked our tickets in advance - turned up on the day with no queues (no visibility). We were advised to change our tickets for another day free of charge.Second time round was perfect. We arrived at 6:15 for our booking at 6:30. We walked past all of the queueing with our pre-booked tickets and straight to the security.Security is high for obvious reasons - still moved through quickly but thoroughly checked. The experience is perfect - if you take the time to stop you can learn about some of the history and hard work that has gone into this building. The 360 view was amazing - because we arrived around 6:30 we were able to see all of new york fading away into city lights with the sun setting over the skyline.If you're interested in this tour & another tour or attraction such as top of the rock or a bus tour etc...i would suggest booking with citypass.com or smart destinations. This enables you to create your own package or choose a package (gives you additional discount). Definitely take your camera for the views!

Must Visit at least once. A phenomena view , 360 degrees, on a clear day you can see 40 miles. Sit at the bar for a nice NY State micro brew, $12. Had a baco burger, very good.Worth the $32 elevator ride once.
World trade centre restaurant . The restaurant in floor 101 is absolutely terrible. Totally inedible. An insult to its predecessor in the old building.
A Must See!. One World Trade Centre and the two reflections pools are a must see when in New York. We found the visit very moving and were reminded of the impact of 9/11 on the world.

Fantastic experience. Being a New Yorker and having been through the events of 9/11 ... always have mixed feelings about One World Trade Center and not re-building the Twin Towers. I'll say this, they did a great job with this building. It tells the story of the site's past and it's present. The observatory is state of the art. Sweeping views of the city and surrounding area. State of the art technology showcasing what you see and identifying every building for you so you know what you're seeing (amazing). Ate at their formal restaurant at the top and food was declasses, service excellent. It's smaller than what you expect within the restaurant ... but the floor space of the observatory itself is large and handles the crowds well. One drawback ... no where to sit so people sit on the window ledges and block the views. They need to correct that problem ASAP.

I live in NYC & it was worth the $32 ticket. Unlike anything else, timed it so we'd get the daytime, sunset & the lights coming on at night. Beautiful. They don't rush you out so we stayed for and hour and a half. Buy tickets online and print them and your wait time will be pretty quick. I took my best friend for her 1st trip to see the city and I will do it again for any other visitors....

Incredible from the first step.... From the moment you walk into the building and make your way to the elavators, it is an amazing experience. Hearing the iron workers talk about much it meant to them to be a part of the construction was emotional. Then you have that incredible elevator ride 104 stories up. But, the view. What a view. I could have spent hours just gazing out. Well, done, OWO, well done.

Worth the Ascent, good value. We went up first thing in the morning, and it was very quiet, easily got tickets, and went up, some great features and surprises and the views are breathtaking, only thing at that time is the sun was lowish and so it was difficult to view certain sides of the tower, midday would be better, but of course that is when most people go !!

Spectacular!. My advice is to skip the Top of the Rock and the Empire State Building and go straight to One World Observatory. You'll save a lot of money and the views at One World blows away the other two. We visited on Friday, October 16 at 11 AM and all the lines were short. We purchased the Flex Pass allowing us to go at any time that day. The Flex pass also allowed us to bypass the lines and go straight into the elevator, although with the short lines we wouldn't have waited long anyway. The view from the top is beyond spectacular, and was well worth the price.

Birthday trip with granddaughter. The new One World building is spectacular!! We took our granddaughter to NYC for her 10th birthday. Everything leading up to the Observatory was great...even the elevator ride up! We had lunch (a tad pricey) in the cafeteria style restaurant, with gorgeous views. The observatory level has plenty of room for all visitors!

"Stunning" reveal for a "pretty good" view. I've lived in NYC for 14 years, and I've been to the Empire State Building, Top of the Rock, and many, many other, lesser building tops. One World Observatory is impressive. It's, you know, really high in the air. But it's not as amazing as I'd hoped. The view of Manhattan is great. The view of Queens and Brooklyn is very good. The view of Jersey City and Hoboken is great. But even on a clear day, while you can see a long way, there's no guide or reference for what you're looking at. You can rent the One World Explorer (an iPad) one which your view is explained, but it's an additional $15 on top of tickets that start at $30.
Best view in the world. It was very busy on a Saturday afternoon, but very well organized. I would go back & I live in NY! You could literally see forever.

Breathtaking views. The first time I was at the One World Observatory it was on a foggy June Sunday, so I could not enjoy it. But last week's visit was on a cloudless day, so we could have magnificent and breathtaking views of Manhattan, Brooklyn and New Jersey. Definitively, a must see location! One tip: Check the weather forecast when planning your visit there.

What a view!. The One World Observatory totally lives up to the expectations! It all starts with the elevator ride where you are taken from history to today...once up, you'll get to see another fantastic video before you are released into the observatory...what a view! Please choose a clear day in order to enjoy the views best!

New wine, closed bottle. Hi, signed up for this visit during my family NYC break. Having done the Empire state and Rockefeller in previous visits, this was a new attraction. Everything was smooth, tickets and the trip to the top. At the top, I expected a lot more info (Yes, there were paid ipads to rent, but wasn't too keen). There were a couple of interactive demos/news, but the wait was long. One big dissapointment was the fully-walled experience. Having been to the rock a few years ago, I was hoping there will be some element of open-air views. Totally glassed in, it was good to view when you could peek beyond the shoulders :) Would I go back again? I'd recommend the Rock for those doing eeney-meeney-miney....

There Is No View Like It. The wait was not small, the orice was not cheap, the attempt to sting you some more once you are in the attraction is high. Having said all of that the elevator ride is truly amazing with an LCD on three sizes showing the building of New York on the way up and showing a New York fly by on the way down. I ate at the restaurant and if it wasn't for the food I would say don't bother.

Excellent View!. The whole package works - 360 view, highest building in the city, and nice entertaiment videos.I had to make a choice on visiting one observatory only and I was very happy with this! I travelled with someone who went to Empire State and Top of the Rock and was also very satistified with OWO

Great on a fine clear day. We had pre booked and expected to access the observatory on time as it was emphasised that we should arrive 15 minutes before. We waited over that time in the cold but fine and clear weather. There was a queue for booking tickets and this moved quickly while we were waiting and most people seemed to be able to book a time slot close to the time they arrived. The lift up is interesting but be sure to have aids to help with the ear popping! It takes 60 seconds for a hundred floors! There is a display on the way up and down but the highlight are the views. We were very lucky with a clear crisp day, but it could have been so different. Advise you to pick the weather, queue up for your time slot and enjoy!

Great to see . It was good to see how well NYC recovered from such a horrible tragedy. The memorial was tastefully done. The building is just amazing. Even the ride up the elevators was interesting. The lines to get in we're very long. I highly recommend buying tickets online and paying for priority entry. You will be glad you did.

Amazing!. We were there on a very clear sunny day. Could see forever. Would not go if it's very cloudy or rainy. Did rent one of the view finder screens. Not so impressed with that. Enjoyed the city circle. Very informative

You'll be amazed!. I was fortunate to go in June and told myself I had to come back with my husband. We visited last week and it was once again, amazing. If you love the Manhattan skyline and want to marvel at a 360 degree view in every direction.....don't miss this. Staff, gift shop and organization details are superb. Recommend going early in the morning to avoid crowds. I think the view would still be good if it's raining.....food adequate, plenty of selections for a light cold or hot snack.

Best view of Manhattan. You will not forget this attraction. The queue is very quickly processed, the whole experience from the elevator up through to the observation deck is nicely choreographed. Its like a Disney ride, but real. You can see the entire island and all bridges.

A One Time Visit is a Must While in NYC. Everyone needs to visit the 9-11 museum and take a trip to the top of One World at least once in their lifetime while in NYC. One World is very organized as opposed to the older Empire State Bldg tour. We paid for the guaranteed time tickets and were at the top within 10 minutes of getting to the location. The view on top on the day we went was spectacular, because we had a rare event, a clear sunny day in NYC. We went early morning (9am) and though it was not very busy, taking pictures while facing the still rising sun meant the pics would not be their best. On the plus side, there were fewer people there and you could take your time and see all around. There is an eatery there as well that might be interesting for a future visit. We took about 1 hour from start to finish.

Amazing view on a clear day, just working out some of the initial kinks. We enjoyed our visit to the One World Observatory on a beautiful fall day. We had booked our tickets in advance and were up at the top within just a few minutes, much faster even than to the Top of the Rock. We ate lunch and cocktails in the restaurant on the top, and everything tasted great. The servers were very friendly but the service itself was spotty. We waited for menus for about ten minutes, and our cocktails/drinks actually came after the food.Really my only real complaint is that there is nowhere to sit down up top, apart from on the ledge in front of the windows. This meant that it wasn't very crowded when we visited, but about 30% of the view was blocked by people sitting on the raised ledge and plaiyng on their phones with their backs to the windows, not even looking out. I am only 5'2'', so it was annoying that I couldn't really enjoy the view over the people sitting around. The space lends itself to hanging out and enjoying the vibe, but there is nowhere to do that. Otherwise, this attraction was really well planned and enjoyable.
Top of NewYork. Well, first of all it was difficult to go there. Could it replace The Twin Towers ? No ...it is not the same, and have a look .. it's great
Dream tour holiday . It was absolutely awesome. Would highly recommend. All the family young and old would love it. Definitely would recommend
Amazing experience. If you need to go one sightseeing place in NY, I would choose this. Amazingly done everything from the elevator back to ground. Really great experience. Choose bright day!
Never forget. Something to remember a tragic event, only saw it from a distance. Wish we had more time to take a closer look, planning another trip to New York. Make sure to see it up close then.

Great views! . My 9 year old loves skyscrapers and wanted so badly to visit the Freedom Tower. We were not disappointed! Yes, it's a bit pricey, but where else can you get a view like this?!? I suggest buying tickets online ahead of time to avoid the lines.

Wonderful replacement but the old one still in my memory. One World Trade Center is a great replacement for something we will never forget and always will be in our hearts. As of today, It is the highest building in USA but you never know how ling it will be. I live close to the area and go more often to enjoy the process and the hard work to fill up this place with great building and parks.

Avoid this building. 32$ wasted, people impolite stand and remain close to the Windows with no staff intervention to guarantee respect of common rules.Impossible to take photo for the reasons above.100 times better the ESB.

Iconic. It's not often one sees an icon in the making, quite literally. this is the case here. Holds an important place in many hearts, worth checking out, and on days when you walk by without a thought, stop anyway. Give a thought.
Commemorate our country's Worst Disaster. The shear emotional reactions to the Trade Center and museum bring you to the realization that our country is stringer than ever before.

Chaotic; Too Many People. After viewing the 911 museum, we decided to go to the observatory which is a few hundred years away. We got into the premium line by paying with Mastercard, but at that time of the day (about 6 pm), there wasn't much of an advantage. The observatory is on Floor #100, and it was crammed with people, especially those who were sitting on the side under the windows, making it very difficult to get any decent pictures. In fact, it was impossible to get a decent picture because of the glare caused by our flash against the windows. Definitely not worth the $32/PP pricetag.
Amazing view on a clear day. We pre purchased our tickets on line. Agree with the FAQ of the website and 30-45 min is enough to see the amazing views from the top.

Amazing views. The wait was not that bad even though we had not booked tickets in advance. The views were absolutely stunning. It was just really annoying that people sat at the edge all the way around so it was really hard to get to the windows to take a picture or enjoy the view.
Worth it maybe. If you want to be at the top of a building, go for it. And, be prepared to pay extra for the iPad which tells you what you are looking at.

crowded and pricey.. nice if you have never been in a high rise but nothing over the top. crowded and pricey.. nice if you have never been in a high rise but nothing over the top. try and pre book. You can actually do this on line or on your smart phone. It will shorten the wait time.

Obnoxious... But nice viewe. Terrible example of ultra tourist nastiness. Poorly organized on entry to sending customers down escalator towards a non-moving crowd. Nearly caused an accident. Then line and after line and people trying to sell you pictures and iPad view accompaniments. And at the top people FaceTime'ing, selfie sticking, being loud and annoying. All for $120 for 4 people.Why, of why, are there people obscuring the view with pointless talks about basic New York facts? Most are well know to Americans or lost of overseas visitors.Still, the views are nice and unparalleled. Maybe try and come Monday morning at 9am to reduce the annoyance.

WTC Sky High Bar. We are visiting NYC from L.A., and of course we wanted to see the WTC observatory. Breathtaking views and very friendly staff! We had to have some cocktails at the sky bar there! Most amazing tasting cocktails! Matthew was our bartender, and he did a fabulous job. We ordered the shrimp salad....the shrimp was a little overcooked, but not a deal breaker. Nonetheless, Matthew told Carlos, the bar manager, and he not only took it off our bill, but gave us two complimentary rounds of drinks!! That's like $80 worth of drinks! Carlos took time to chat with us...we had an amazing time, and Matthew and Carlos went above and beyond! Totally impressive. When in NYC, we will definitely go back! Thanks guys

Was Disappointed. Too much commercialism. Everywhere you turned there was something for sale. Tickets are pricey and you are given a time to enter. View from top spectacular on a clear day, but would not repeat.

Incredible views. I would highly recommend this observatory at night (after the Empire State Building during the day). Obviously there are always going to be incredible views but we went after dark and the extra peace and quiet you get when it's past all the crowds goes nicely with the implicit serenity you get at night.

World's highest Disneyland ride. That's tongue-in-cheek. It was a wonderful experience, well worth the price, and we were not disappointed at all by skipping the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock. See my slightly longer review of this attraction, posted erroneously to One World Trade Center.

World's highest Disneyland ride. That's tongue-in-cheek, but there is too much flavor of a theme park ride - and upselling - to getting people to the observation deck. I suppose some of that is necessary just to move people and keep admission at $30.But the views are stunning! The perspective from Lower Manhattan covers more of the city, as you can look right down into the Hudson and East Rivers, as well as seeing the Midtown skyline. We were there at 10:30-11am on a bright sunny day. There was a lot of glare on some sides of the deck, but that is to be expected. I can't give photography tips, but the light and time of day may be something to consider.This was the only observation deck attraction we took in this trip, and it was well worth the money. We don't feel we missed anything from the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock.
Amazing building . Had a great time. This building is simply amazing. Booked our visit for 10 am to miss the crowds. Went straight up with no problems with crowds or queuing.

Best High Rise I've been too!. This building is amazing! Even the arrival to the highest floor is like a show, wont spoil the surprise, but its breathtaking. We had booked timed tickets and the weather was quite poor but we had the tickets so up we went, we were told there would only be a 3 mile view, but within minutes the view cleared and we had a full amazing view. We thought this beat both the ESB and TOTR and comparing to the Shard in London was far better. Is thats because its so new, i dont know, but we loved it and would highly recommend.

An October visit. Alot of hype and build up for an elevator ride, kinda a waste of my standing and walking. The views are splendid; I've been to mountain tops, so everything in perspectives. We ordered drinks at the bar also, mediocre therein. They on't stock Weller's bourbon, had only "heard of it"... kinda like saying they're on top of the World (Trade) but we've heard what a aircraft carrier landing and take-off is like, we've heard what a hot air balloon ride in Colorado is like, and we've heard of what it's like to stand on a mountain peak. Also, the Bellini I ordered was flat out WRONG... I should have gone behind the bard and shown the team what real drinks are and how to make 'em ... overall? nice experience, but I wouldn't waste my time and $ a 2nd time

Get the flex day ticket. I bought the flex day ticket because I wasn't sure how long we would take to go through the WTC Museum, we got the VIP treatment, skipped the long, long line and got straight to the top. Pay the extra money, skip the lines so you get to see more things on your trip. It was an awesome view, the elevator ride was the best!

.....see forever.......so true. It was a beautiful blue thursday. The lift to the top is worth the money, its an amazing way of entertaining you on the few seconds it takes to get to the top. I will not give away other experiences up top, the surprise is so much better. The views are beauitful. There are two talks on either side of the obs deck, interesting. However I won the keep your hands up to find the person who had travelled the farthest.....AUSTRALIA...i won....no prize just the 20 hour flight home....I was visiting the museum after this and sadly my mind went to the poor souls above the impact zones, as I gazed down.....unimaginable

47 Seconds To Reach The Sky. Even though we joined the que it moved very quickly, very smooth entranced to the lift. The lift was so quick and the passage to the little talk went well. What I did not like was the following, The person was giving a talk on how great the little I pad was, you just pressed the icon and it would zoom into the building / bridge telling you all about it. Then they proceeded to tell you how much it would cost. So it was a sales talk. Other than that the view was fantastic, we went up about an hour before sunset so we seen two viewes, the first one was so clear and sunny we could see for miles, then we watched the sun set followed by lots of buildings and bridges lighting up. Could not fault the experience. Glad we went up.
Views incredible. It was very emotional at the top where I stood 35 years ago in the old towersThe views are stunning and the wait short
Those views!!!!!!!!. I went to the top if the WTC 35 years ago and this was very emotional return Fabulous building and great views well done

Still in Tears. Still in tears about what took place on 9/11 the hurt is still there but they will build again,bigger and better. when I looked at all of the names of the people that lost their lives i pray that their families find some type of comfort. I even saw a woman's name and her unborn child. It is so worth the drive, train, taxi cab to this place. It is a beautiful must see place. You cannot come to New York and not visit this place. I had a great time in New York.

Spectacular views and worth the price.. $32 each takes you up the elevator which has video on the walls on the way up and down that are worth the price on their own. Then at the 102nd floor Observatory, after a brief intro, you are free to view till you wish to go back down. The two floors of floor to ceiling glass walls let you see up Manhattan and the G. W bridge, across to Brooklyn or NJ, out the harbor and Liberty & the Verrazano bridge, or nearly straight down on the Battery! It was busy but not crowded and you can shop for momentos or eat at the restaurant while you view. There was very little waiting in line going up or down and the 9/11 memorial and museum are both close by. They obviously planned on an efficient Observatory from the beginning of building design. Very highly recommended!

Spectacular views. We saw this when visiting the 911 memorial and decided to take a look. Wow the views are truly spectacular york photos look like you must have taken them from a helicopter! The 'reveal' moment is very good also.

Wow, what a place. I Dont really like heights but i was glad i did it, The experience is truelly out of this world, & Pay for the ipad viewer it really helps point out what you are looking at. The staff were excellent so friendly & Helpful

What a view and experience!. You start at street level, go down stairs into the footing of the old world trade center and take the fastest elevator you have ever ridden to floor 102. The video screens in the elevator blew my mind, you gotta see the city change as you ride up. The top floors are all for viewing, casual food is available at the top, I did not eat there so I won't rate the food or choices. The views are amazing, your right above the 911 Memorial, we went at night, soo much to see! Last ride up is 7:15 pm, you can avoid the lines by buying tickets online. Closes at 8 pm.

Great Views/Good Food. Worth the price of standard admission with a reserved time. The wait in line outside was not bad on a sunny day. I wonder what happens during rainy or cold weather.
