You do have to submit to a full security inspection when you enter the building, same as the 9/11 museum. The elevator ride was very fast and displayed a timeline of NYC. We decided on having lunch in the restaurant and only had to wait 20 minutes on a Saturday afternoon. We sat at the bar, turned around and enjoyed the view towards mid-town Manhattan. The hamburgers and service were both good, and the prices not too bad considering where you are eating. Tables had a wonderful view.
Well worth it. A great way to see New York - and the opening movie ends in a great surprise. Highly recommend buying a ticket online because it means you go straight in and don't have to line up.

Views Amazing , the preamble not great!. We bought a priority ticket we had to wait in line with every one don't know why I spent extra money for nothing, Long wait after security for elevators, then once off the elevators you have to stand like a fool for the staff to unveil the window. After that they ask you to stand around while they try to sell you an ipad to use during your visit. Hard to get to a window since people will sit at the edge for a long time.

Don't miss it. Wow, after Manhattan from Empire State Building and Top of the Rock you see Manhattan somehow "on the water". The lift with NYC pictures, you get over and after a brief explanation they open the courtain... And you stop breathing!!!! A sort of show very well organized and the view is simply FANTASTIC. We were there around noon next time we'll try sunset/evening. All the bridges are under your feet, I can't even explain and describe this spectacular place

On a Clear Day. You can see breathtaking views of NJ, Brooklyn, the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, and the East & West sides. But if you live in the NY area and/or may have been at the Towers, the $30 fee might not be worth it unless you have an out of town guest.

Amazing views. The Freedom Tower is well worth a visit. The views, 360 degrees, around the city are amazing. Worth paying the extra for VIP entrance to avoid the queues and for the iPad experience - which zooms you to all the favourite attractions ( one per party would suffice). One of the highlights of our visit.

Has an unexpected wow factor. I wanted to visit this to compare with the twin towers and I think this gives you a modern interpretation of the views. I enjoyed going up in the lift as there's screens showing you what it's like to experience going up in the world. The montage of New York life was colourful and interesting, more so when the curtains lifted and it revealed the view of NYC. It made me gasp and say wow! - not easy for someone who has seen NYC numerous times. It's quite a spacious floor though it does get crammed with people at the windows taking photos. If there's one sky view I would recommend over the other ones,it'll be this one.

Best view of New York. Access is a bit of an annoying process and its dearer than other options. USP is a tablet with an application which identifies all the major landmarks - costs an extra $15 but is probably worth it. Views are more extensive than alternatives though there are no outside terraces. We got a good understanding of the overall geography of New York

Great views of the 1776 feet building. Wonder why they decided on 1776??. How can you not resist taking a few photos of One World Trade Centre when you visit the Ground Zero memorial? Stunning architecture and very modern looking. Well worth taking a few moments to reflect.. I visited during Easter of 2014
Stunning. This was a fantastic experience from start to finish. A very professional set up and what views at the top, just stunning. Don't miss this on your trip.

Excellent Views. Going up this magnificent building was money well spent. We all loved it. The whole experience is managed professionally and the views are spectacular.Would recommend this as a must do in NYC

wow...... totally amazing to stand here and see what has been achieved in the face or evil, this amazing building stands as a symbol that they won't be beaten by these terrorists and that the city has bounced back harder, it is such a shame that so many lost their lives here
aksinottawa. Defiance is how we viewed this new office building. It is worth wandering around its shadow, camera in hand, before or after visiting the nearby 9/11 memorial.
Beautiful View. Worth the price. See all of NYC in one place. Strict security. Beautiful views from the top. Absolutely breath taking!

Beautiful View at the Top. Security here is tight, as it should be. Great elevator ride to the observatory. When they open up the curtains for you to see the view it is breath taking. Great two floors of observatory and a 360 degree view as you walk around. Good gift shop too.
Truly Spectacular!. This is a must! Pay the price to go to the top! You will not be disappointed. I am still in awe over the massiveness of this structure.

How can you not visit ?. This is not a cheap ticket. While most people breeze through the walk to the elevators, the stories told are well worth slowing down to check out. The elevator ride is another look at new technology and the "theatre" does a good job at building excitement. CityPulse is an interesting up to the minute live presentation...with truly lively presenter. Yes the observation deck is commercialized with photo stops and a sales pitch for the see forever IPad. But it's all part of the NYC experience. Restaurant pricing is crazy even by NYC standards, but you pay for the view. Will do again to experience the night view.

Great if you can afford it. This attraction is pretty expansive - 34$ per person, but if you don't mind paying it, you're in to a treat! This observatory has an amazing view of the entire city that you can't get from anywhere else (the view is from the 100th floor).

Sweet views from the top.. After being up on Top of the Rock we had to do One World Trade also. There is nothing quite like standing next to floor to ceiling windows and staring straight down from over 100 stories up. Went at night and as expected the views were tremendous. Wish they had a map of what you were looking at, would have made the experience even better. Buy tickets ahead of time on the internet and go with anytime of day choice for flexibility of schedule.

"Not a complete trip to NYC unless you visit One World Trade Center". The outside memorials will take your breath away and the OWTC reaches into the blue sky and above the other buildings. Take your cell phone with a pair of ear buds to listen to a narration of the 9-11 story inside. You can download a free app with pictures and descriptions of what you're about to see.When my wife & I entered, we were speechless, the very quiet atmosphere and sincere facial expressions says it all. This horrible 9-11 attack is our Pearl Harbor.We'll never forget this experience and the very brave victims, and first responders who risked their lives for others they did not even know.

Not worth the money until they fix their wait/line/overbooking isues. I bought tickets for 6 friends in from out of town who were excited to go to the Observatory. We bought timed tickets for 315p on a Saturday afternoon - got there 15 minutes early - and it was chaotic with no one clearly helping helping you get in the proper line. We stood where they told us to and waited for someone to get us - but turns out no one comes to the area where they had us gather. we overheard someone say 'the 315s are lining up" so we then lined up. We waited in lines for over an hour and 15 minutes before we even got to the top. I have been to numerous attractions like this - Empire State, Sears Tower, etc. And know there will always be some sort of wait. But this was the worst And we were outside for a good chunk of it with no shade. For most of the wait there is nothing to see or do. We were so late we could only stay at the top for 10 minutes then had to get to an early dinner reservation. For the amount they charge $32 plus tax - it should be a) more organized and b) less overbooked. There were just too many people there. I strongly recommend you wait until they iron out some of the kinks.

What A Wonderful View!. Towering at 1776 feet, One World Trade Center is a sight to behold. As we entered the building to go up to the observatory we were given the option of the fast pass lane - it cost nearly twice as much and wasn't worth it. We paid the regular ticket price. The elevator up to the top is an experience in and of itself. It takes you through the history of the city as you go up and you"ll watch the city being built to its present state including One World Trade on the elevator walls. Beautiful! Once you reach the top you will be given the opportunity to rent an ipad which will teach you about what you are seeing - point at an area and it will tell you what landmarks are in your view. We passed. The views are amazing - a full 360. We also grabbed a cup of coffee at the cafe at the top, it was great. They have drinks, food, pastries, etc. Expensive though. All in all, we're so glad we did this. Worth it.
One World Trade Centre. A moving experience, many people standing in respectful silence, the new Trade Centre rising Phoenix like looks surprisingly beautiful close up and the

Beautiful and Heartwarming. It is very heartwarming to see the determination of a city and a nation represented in the building of this beautiful tower. It's a magnificent building and, as it casts a shadow over the 9/11 Memorial site, it seems most befitting. If you have time, you can go up to the observation deck as well.

Must See. Yes, everyone should go here. But I suggest you do it when you are not rushed and when you have lots of time to take it all in. Well, really it takes more than one trip. However, I can assure you that you will come away emotionally drained!
Awesome!. The tallest building in the hemisphere. A MUST while in New York. The views are incredible, the presentation at the beginning is great, definitely the highlight of my trip to the City!

long lines not very organized. we purchased tickets ahead of our visit to NY we had a 2:15 time. We waited in line for 1 hour finally we rode the escalator down into another line waiting to get through security another 30 minute wait. After security we were in another line waiting for the elevator another 30 minutes. We finally got to the top the view is breathtaking but they try to sell you an Ipad for $15.00 to explain what you are seeing then they try to take your picture not sure what that cost then you are left on your own. The food and water are ridiculous expensive water is $5.00 for a small bottle. Would not recommend this to anyone. Bridgeville,DE

Beautiful place. I booked the elevator ride to the top on-line and you can chose a time to go up. I booked 5:30 pm, hoping to catch the sunset and the lights coming on in the city. Perfect! We got on at 5:30 and were whisked to the top. Wonderful views of the city and also views of the reflecting pools below where the twin towers stood before 9-11. It reminded you why you were in this place. Nice restaurant and bar up top. Be sure to make a reservation if you want to eat there. We were able to grab seats at the bar and view the sights.

Good View but .............................. Even if you have purchased your tickets ahead of time you will wait in multiple long lines before you get to enjoy the view. Your viewing will be delayed while they try to up sell you on several gimmicks. If you are not bothered by this then go for it, but if you just want to get to the viewing area, you will be annoyed. This is overly commercialized.

sightseeing. we went to NY too see all the sites, we enjoyed each and everyone of them, there are lots of restaurants everywhere we went , however hard for my daughter to really fine Vegetarian... lots of shops to go to , something on every corner
Observatory is very cool. The elevator is the best part of going up to the top of one world trade. It's a time lapse of NYC. Really cool fast elevator. Kids will think this is cool.

Great expirience. In the observatory, there are some folks offering a sightseeing iPad. I didn't purchase that, but I could notice the personal is very nice. One of them provided detailed orientation when I was trying to stop Wall St. Bring binoculars, telephoto. Also, try to get the first bracket in the morning (9am or before). At 10am the observatory gets crowdy and it complicates taking good pictures with out bombing your photos.

Awesome!. A must tour if you go to New York, this tour was well worth the small fee to visit. The elevator ride up was worth it on its own, that was the fastest ride up elevator in my life, I won't ruin it for you but you will get to experience it if you go. The views are amazing and the introduction is amazing!
World Trade Center. Solemn, moving. A Must see in America!! Purchase your tickets in advance to guarantee your timely admission, Give yourself2 - 4 hours.

One of the best!. This will not disappoint! The view is incredible! Everything had been thought through from the moment you enter the building to the moment you leave. The sky pods transport you through time, the theater was my favourite part, the ending was spectacular! You can't miss this!

A great and moving experience. From the One World Observatory the view of New York City is absolutely fabulous. But more importantly it's a very moving experience when we have a look over the Memorial and think about all the innocent people who died during the nine eleven attack.By visiting the One World Trade Center and the Museum I do believe that it's a way for us to pay homage to all these people

Amazing Views and Experience a must on anyones visit to NY. The views from this observation deck is fantastic and the elevator ride with the video was pretty neat. We bought our tickets online which I would recommend to avoid long lines to get tickets at the attraction. The only drawback is you have to pick a time you're going to be there. Which wasn't bad at all. We got there 15 mins. before our scheduled time and got right in once we found the line for ticket holders. The building is beautiful and you get a complete 360-degree view of Manhattan. Note: this even can get crowded so to avoid this arrive either super early or later in the day.
Wonderful view from of the entire City and beyond.. We visited the One World Trade Center on a beautiful day. Can see for many miles in all directions. Breath taking and magnificent.

Didn't know what to expect. I went to OWO because the last time I was in NYC I got to see the twin towers so I thought that this could be cool. I went with my family ($160), it was at night time and raining a little bit. There were no lines, the attendants were nice and up we went. The elevator ride was fast and smooth, the interior of the tower was almost empty and we had plenty of space to move around, the view was breath-taking. If you are going to OWO, go at least 2 hours before closing. We went on the last elevator and we were rushed around as they were closing. I'm happy I went because I got to see the memorials from up there but the price is definitely a bit too high. This is a "one visit" must do. Was I the only one thinking that the building was moving?

Worth the wait. Visited at peak time and waited about 30 mins in the queue to buy tickets to return in another 30 mins.I expected to wait so wasn't surprised, but could have booked online to ease the waiting time. On entering went through security quickly,and entered the lift which has a quick presentation on the way up.Short introduction at the top, and then WOW .Absolutely fantastic views.Really helpful and informative staff.The only draw back is that there are no seats on the viewing floor,not even in the coffee bar. All that said well worth doing.

No words can describe....... If you have visited or not visited NY before 9/11, it doesn't matter. NY has created an atmosphere of love and rememberance. This building is beautiful and fun. Taking the elevator to the 102nd floor is fun but if you have motion sickness, stand by the elevator doors. Its amazing how they have created a 'vision' in the elevator. Once to the top, amazing things happen. Then you are lead to the viewing area. You can rent an ipad to help with the view of NY or you can just ask the people working. The view is spectactular. Have fun....worth the money spent!

Great view on NYC. Another point of view on New York City from the One World Observatory at the top of the One World Trade Center, the new tower of New York. fantastic experience the ride in the elevator to reach the top and great idea the Observatory Theatre. It definitely Worths the price of the ticket.

Fantastic Views........But. We booked times tickets for 3pm so arrived 15 mins early as advised. We still had to queue to enter the building. After entering the building we proceeded downstairs to enter the foyer area where we queues again to go through the usual security check. The line was long but moved reasonably quickly. After security we then entered a underground area and 3 queue area. We weaved through what seemed to be a never ending maze of rocks before reaching the elevators. The elevator ride was fantastic. The walls showed the evolution and growth of Manhattan and was one of the memorable features of the experience. Look for it on YouTube to see what I mean. After the elevators we the queues yet again in a corridor. Everyone was wondering what was going on. After about 5-10 Minster doors opened and we stood facing a wall. Shortly after a short film played before revealing the stunning view looking north. The wall then closed. This gave a brief look at what was to come. After this we were then hoarded into a room where we were encouraged to buy an iPad type tour of the skyline which would point out points of interest. I think it was $15. By this time we just wanted to see the view and I don't think many, if any, took up the iPad tour viewer. We then finally entered the observatory. The views are beyond fantastic and pictures do not do it justice, this is not helped though by taking pictures behind glass with reflection (see my pics) and when sunny (like it was) the reflections are terrible and some pictures were horribly dark. Where the sun wasn't shining on the building the pictures where better but again reflection was a problem. In summery the queuing is beyond monotonous and I even mentioned it to one of the staff who just laughed. The need to sell you extras is not needed as most people should know the most famous buildings. But the views are FANTASTIC, just don't expect great pictures when the suns out.

Slick and soulless. Building looks good from a distance, with clouds and sky refelction giving it a changing and at times ethereal appearance. But once you get up close the Center is strangely lacklustre and graceless. The observation deck visit is not cheap and it's tained by an over-the-top commercial presentation. The viewing area is completely enclosed, unlike its Empire State building counterpart and this distracts considerably from the experience. Eveything seems plasticiised and commercialized. Avoid - see the Empie State building instead
Best elevator ride, ever, animation to 102nd floor. I enjoyed the new feel to what I miss most (the twin towers outdoor terrasse). Great animation, visualization and view.

Definitely worth a visit!. The One World Observatory offers a spectacular 360 degree view of the city and the harbour. I'd recommend a visit in the late afternoon / early evening visit to also to see the city light up after sunset. And be prepared for a truly remarkable elevator ride!
Best view in the city. You can't beat this view, plan at least 2 hours and take a train to the tower. very busy somewhat crowded but a great time.

Great view.. Just like the other nearly 1million who had visited before me, visiting the new World Trade Center was a must-do experience. We got there early enough in the morning that there was nearly no line. we walked right in.There is a security check pretty much identical to the TSA checks we are all used to by now. Going to the top costs $32 per person. But it costs the same for the Empire State. you are directed along a path with photos and testimonials from the workers and designers of the towers. Then you go through a corridor with fake rock walls to get to the elevators. The rock is supposed to remind you that this is the strongest building ever made. Getting to the top was quick. The elevators are the fastest I have ever seen. less than a minute to get to the top. Going early in the AM is great except you are looking into the sun and some views are tough to photograph. there are a couple restaurants and a gift shop up at the top. Both are somewhat pricey which is to be expected considering where you are. $35 t shirts and $8 magnets are the order of the day! There were guys at the observatory floor who would give little spiels about New York or some current event. It was interesting to listen to them.It wasn't too crowded when we were there. I spent maybe an hour or so up there. You never get tired of the view. They had a deal where you can rent an Ipad which has an interactive display which will tell you what you are looking at which might have been a good idea. I think it cost about $15 or so. This is a great attraction. Don't miss the memorial and museum at the base of the tower.

Don't miss this...awesome!!. Totally awesome experience seeing NYC from the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. The 9/11 memorial museum is a very sobering experience, but also well worth seeing!

Don't miss this...awesome!!. Totally awesome experience seeing NYC from the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. The 9/11 memorial museum is a very sobering experience, but also well worth seeing!

You can't miss this Experience!. The place is amazing from start to finish,We bought fast tracked tickets, and they are worth it,Amazing building from the ground up, and experience you must have while in NYC, The views are spectacular, A tip go up early while it's still light, and just sit in the bar and watch the the sun go down and Nyc takes on an amazing light show. Enough said don't want to give too many spoilers way!!
Great experience. If you have been to the Empire State Building, you shouldn't miss the view from One World Trade Center.Senior discount available.

OMG!!!. Don't miss this! We bought our tickets in advance for the first group at 9am Saturday morning. The visitor centre is well laid out and you move fairly quickly through security. I don't want to "spoil" the experience but our group applauded before we even got to the viewing areas. Well worth the time.

Worth the long wait in lines. We went on Columbus Day weekend and the crowds were huge. It took a long time to get to the observation tower but the views were definitely worth it. Go during the week if possible.

You will not be disappointed great experience. Third visit to NYC, first time in 2003 when we visited ground zero. Brilliant to see the new Freedom Tower. The whole visit to the Observation Tower was perfect, I hate to say it but 'so' American, if you are going to do it do it right. The 9/11 memorial is also just right, so many visitors and everyone is so respectful of where we are and what happened here.
Standing tall once again.. It is quite elating that we can resolve that good will prevail over evil. The tower is an encouragement that we can rise again come what may.
Rebirth rising to the sky. Was overwhelmed by the tasteful presentation of the new venue at One World. Very pricey which I'm afraid may exclude many.

Nice Take-in, But Very Expensive. One World Trade Center Observatory is a fun take-in, but it is very expensive. At $32 per person, it's worth doing once, but I probably won't repeat. The iPad feature is an additional $15. Although I don't think everybody in the family needs one, it might be worth the $15 to have one iPad for the whole party. We did not get the iPad, but in hindsight, I wouldn't have minded learning more about what I was looking at. The best part of the entire experience is probably the elevator ride on the way up. The inside walls of the elevator are all LCD screens, except for the door. It's pretty cool to watch the LCD screens simulate the construction that has gone on over the years outside, as a timeline shows along with the video. It's also very moving to see a picture of The Twin Towers, which then disappear as the timeline gets to 2001. At the top, it's pretty crowded, but you can still get over to some window space fairly easily. Bring a good camera. There were plenty of selfie sticks on display. What was probably just as impressive as the view from the top, was the view from the bottom, outside of the building looking straight up. The way the building was designed, as you stare up at the top from the bottom, it looks like the building rises and converges into a single point as it approaches the heavens. The building design may look a little strange from far away, but as you stare at the top from the bottom, you can appreciate why they designed it the way that they did. And that view is free.

You can see forever!. When we arrived at the observation area, someone asked the guide, "Is this it?" He said, "Yes, that elevator ride and this view is what you just paid $32 for!" In many respects, that is it. It's an interesting elevator ride (a short video history of the building in the area of the tower) and incredible views. But that is it. One can rent an ipad to get more geographical markers, but it's really just about being able to see for miles. It's definitely a bird's-eye view of the city and environs. It's the kind of thing that's good to do one time.

Concrete Jungle Wow!!!. Top of the Rock was epic but this was just insane!! You see everything almost it's overwhelming the view! From the lady in green to Brooklyn bridge to the Empire State you see it all and it is simply amazing! One of the best things we have ever seen!!

Disney couldn't do it better.. The elevator ride alone is almost worth the price of admission with its audio-visual show on the walls. Then there's the next A-V show with the big reveal prior to getting to the observation deck.We had a superbly clear day (we're originally from NYC, so I know whereof I speak). I must have told 50 people this was as clear a day as could be. Needless to say, the view is spectacular.This wasn't on our list to do as my wife and I had been to Windows on the World and the original WTC several times and didn't really want to relive 911 vicariously. But the couple we were with had never been to NY and they prevailed. We are glad they did - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Amazing Building. This is an amazing building and the story in this area alone makes it something special. We've been to New York several times in the past five years and have seen this building be constructed. It is a symbol of hope for us all. When the sun shines on it it appears to display a cross in the center, not sure if this is by design or happenstance, but either way, it's awesome.
Amazing views. Sat right next to the 9/11 Memorial, truly beautiful part of downtown New York, the Tower is a must see whilst there, the views are breathtaking!
great view. very good view on.Manhattan,recommended the best I have ever seen. it is worth standing at the long line

outstanding view. This observatory costs $32 per adult. We didn't pre-purchase tickets because we went on a Tuesday. There was a short line for tickets and a short line for the elevators. We were at the top within 20 minutes of arriving. The view is panoramic. It was slightly overcast but the view was clear for miles. They have ipads that can be rented for another $15 each that identify and describe the buildings if you're not familiar with them. There was plenty of window space for viewing. The elevators are fast but they hold about 15 people so you don't really get to see the history on the way up or down. We had a draught beer with a marvelous view of the Hudson. The beer was $12.69 with a gratuity added but it was the novelty of the view that made it worth it.
a sad history. I remember this pace from the past now it has a sad history, but you can go and see the placefrom central park you can walk like 45 minutes or maybe better take the metro

So good can't be missed!. Went here last week with my best friend and had an amazing time. Elevator ride up is amazing as is the video reveal at the top! Spent about an hour here had so much fun. Food is expensive though, paid $2 for a banana and $6 for a bottle of iced tea but definitely can't be missed. The 9/11 memorial is free now as well so can do both at the same time which was great. Definitely recommended, will be going back every time I'm in NY!

Visit to One World Trade. Excellent visit and very helpful staff. The view is spectacular and well worth the fee. Do book online in advance to jump to lines. Very well laid out interior and highly recommended.

Up, up, up to the Observation Deck (105th). Buy tickets in advance for a specific loading time. We missed our time because of subway repairs, and we were hustled down the quick line and got right in - though much later. We went after the 911 Museum and just at sunset. The west view was golden; the other views were watching the city lights come up. Fast, comfortable ride up and down with a surprising add-on in the elevator. Lots of people, big crowds, but manageable.

Sight seeing. What a magnificent view across Manhattan, the waiting time was really short to get into the observatory and within 15 mins of arriving at the building we were at the top. The views were fabulous, obviously we went on a clear day, you are able to walk around the entire floor taking pictures and looking for the landmarks that you know, the lift is amazing you don't feel any movement it is so smooth, just your ears start popping as you get towards the top. Well worth a visit.

One World Observatory @ WTC is a Must See. Well done. Views, elevator ride sets the stage. Legends provides the food service and it is good. Allow 2 + hours for a nice pace. Do explore the whole complex as there is a much to experience.

Great view, but it doesn't come cheap. I can't say anything bad about the One World Observatory; it was exactly as promised and expected. I just think paying over $30 for a view is overpriced. I don't think my visit to NYC would have been diminished in any way if we had left this off the itinerary.

Feeling on top of the world. Get your ticket printed ahead of time. Line moved fast. I experienced everything you could do. The elevator and the view reveal was a great way to build up your anticipation. Go on a clear day.The restaurant was excellent. The building is beautiful.

Breathtaking View!. The views on the sunny, blue-sky day were fantastic! You can truly see for miles, and the views looking down are IMAX-like visions. Although crowded, there was ample room to get up against the glass on all sides of the observatory and snap great photos/videos. And, just when you thought it was over, the elevator ride down was incredible. Make sure you have your phone cam ready. The staff was very pleasant, and the narrations about the views was tastefully done and very informative. This is the new must-do in NYC.

Worth it!. I probably picked a bad day to go because it was incredibly busy. We went on the Saturday of Columbus Day weekend. Our 3:30 tickets didn't allow us to get into the door until after 4:30. After going inside you still have to wait in a line for the metal detectors and for the elevators. Overall, it was totally worth the wait!I could have stood and listened to the men and women who contributed to the building of the One World Trade Center for hours. The elevator was amazing and the view from the top was more than you could ever dream!I would go so far to say that I would spend $50 to do this again. It says a lot about a place when you truly feel like it was money well spent. (Tickets are only $32) The only suggestion I have is that if you're with someone who cannot stand for a long time, you may consider spending the extra money to get the express VIP tickets. Don't go to NYC and miss out on this attraction, you must go!We Remember!

Takes your breath away. The moment I saw the tower I was amazed! A very busy day. The pools make one step back in time, reflect and be thankful. Did not take her tour lines were very long. One cannot go to NYC and not take all of this in.

Wow !. Hard to believe the lift gets you to the top in less than 45 seconds ! There is a film shown all round the lift on your way up so you are paying attention to that and not really noticing that your ears are popping - then you all stand in a viewing area and more images are flashed across screen then the screens lift to reveal the most stunning view - we could really see for miles !
A highlight on a sombre day. After visiting Ground Zero you feel very flat so to then go up One World Trade Center and see the stunning view is a way to end the day on a high.

Great view, but pricey. I loved the view. Get your tickets ahead of time and go early in the morning to avoid the lines. The iPad tour is expensive. I liked it, but because of the crowds, I couldn't get up to the window and use it like I wanted to. If you get one, just get one per party.

Not Good For Photos. If you want to take pictures of the city this is NOT the place to go. This is a tourist attraction. It is overpriced, way too crowded, and the windows are covered in fingerprints, smudges, and glare. I found it frustrating to be pushed and shoved as you work your way to a spot at the window to see the view. Buy tickets online for a timed entry but be prepared to wait in line an additional 45 minutes or more beyond your time slot (at least true on the weekend and at sunset). You will have a far better picture-taking experience at Top of the Rock Observation Deck where you don't have to take photos through glass.
Nice to look down on Empire State Buiilding.. We went on a bad day because of weather but still really nice attraction. Very easy to maneuver around and the entrance through below ground wonderful.

Great View, Terrible Wait. I came here with a group of seven. We had a scheduled visit to the Observatory for 3:00 PM on Saturday. At 3:30, they were letting the 2:45 PM group in. Needless to say, the lines were very long and the staff in charge of regulating the flow of people seemed very confused and disorganized. It's probably not nearly as bad during the week, but on the Saturday of Columbus Day weekend, it was insanity. Even after getting into the building, we waited in multiple lines until we got to the top.The view at the top was absolutely stunning. I definitely would recommend going, but not on a Saturday. It's something you should save for the end of your day, because waiting to get to the top is a real possibility, and you don't want to feel rushed when you finally get up there.

Lovely view of the city. This was a little confusing to me as we did it last minute without researching - it is NOT in any way connected to or related to the twin towers or the 9/11 memorial or museum. All it is is a ride way up high to have a 360 view of the city. Still pretty cool. You can rent an interactive map which will identify whatever it is you are looking at. We did not rent one but did creep on a few people who did - a nice luxury but not worth the $15 they charge. Took us 25 minutes to exit the building. There was a super long line to get on the elevators. Moved along nicely but if you are in a hurry to get to your next event plan accordingly!
Amazing. I have left a seperate review for the view on the observatory section. This building is a triumph and an amazing addition to the skyline.

Best view in NYC. Absolutely breathtaking there are no words to convey. Don't choose an overcast day in case clouds spoil it. The elevator has an excellent presentation on the way up. The manner in which the view is presented is stunning and spend a good bit of time wandering through the observatory drinking it all in. The bar is nice also and you can sit with a drink- the view doesn't get boring. Book in advance and go early to beat the biggest crowd.

A Deep and Moving Place. The building is quite beautiful and a tribute to the twin towers that were attacked by terrorists on September 11, 2001. The reflecting pools on the spots where the towers stood pay a quite and dignified homage to those that lost their lives on that horrible day.

See the World. Excellent, money well spent. You can see forever. If I had to find one fault it would be that you seem disconnected from the world trade center site and reflecting pools. But the views are amazing.. Buy the express pass.

Great concept, great view. We visited the observatory the second day after its opening and it was stunning. The elevator rides up and down are spectacular and the view is amazing. You have to get tickets for a certain point of time otherwise the tickets get pretty expensive. Overall it was amazing to see what they have built since 2001.

Great View if the weather is good.. We bought advance tickets and we were glad we did because of the crowds but I guess you are chancing it for the view from the top. We did have great visibility so it made it all the more worthwhile. I agree with others that the elevator ride is fantastic as is the movie. Take your time getting to the elevator as the narrative from the workers involved with construction is very moving. We were in the World Trade Windows of the World building four months before 9/11 and you could not help but be aware of planes flying into LaGuardia or JFK as you roamed the 360 degree view. Still pretty awesome.

Amazing WTC one. We joined our tripp to the WTC One world observatory very much! The tripp with the fast elevator and the opening of the wall after the informationshow was great! The view over the city is awesome.
A truly must!. Absolutely stunning 360 view of Manhattan and the area around. The elavator to the observatory is a experience itself. Kind of expensive.

Freedom Tower Observatory. We had bought the priority tickets for this trip and it was well worth the extra money. It was great to bypass the lines and get to the views fairly quickly. The elevator ride up was wonderful with seeing NYC from the very beginning to now. The movie and the surprise view was an added bonus. The views were spectacular. I would recommend seeing it later in the day, the sunset is just gorgeous. The only glitch in this trip was the wait at the bottom. It was chaotic to say the least. There were no distinct areas for regular ticket holders and priority tickets holders. People who wanted to buy tickets had to go through the cordoned off area to the inside. There should maybe be a separate door for just people going in to buy tickets. There should be 2 cordoned off areas, one for regular ticket holders and one for priority tickets as it was very confusing as to where to go and stand while waiting. Other than that the experience itself was worth it and I would definitely do it again.

Overpriced tourist trap. First there's the ticket-buying process: base adult price of $32 and a dozen more expensive flavors of tickets so they can start sucking more money out of you right away: pay more if you don't know what time of day you'll arrive; pay more if you don't want to wait in line; etc.Then it's an interminable series of lines. A line outside; a line inside; a line to go through airport-style security; a line to go up the elevator. Self-congratulatory videos accompany your wait.Then a single redeeming quality: floor-to-ceiling video screens in the elevator with a cool simulated time-lapse of New York's development.Next: more waiting! This time for some glorified advertisement for New York on poorly projection-mapped screens that open ceremoniously for your first taste of the view.BUT THEN! You're herded into another corral by some suspiciously friendly folks who start giving a presentation...oh wait, they're trying to rent you a tablet ($15?) that points out landmarks and such. You're being forced to wait even longer so they can sell you some piece of junk. This was infuriating. Fortunately, you don't actually need to stand for any of this; you can just keep going. Once we realized this, most of the crowd left with us.Then the obligatory stand-in-front-of-green-screen-for-your-overpriced-souvenir-photo, which actually isn't obligatory if you stay to the left and forcefully deny the direction of the photographers. Don't give them the satisfaction.Finally you can go down to the observation level and check out the view. It's great, obviously, but you're inside the whole time and bright lights from various useless attractions created a fair amount of glare for our twilight visit.But before you go: another line!!! This time for the elevator down. Ours stretched halfway around the observation level; took about 15 minutes just to get out of the place.My recommendation: any tall building in New York will have a great view. Find something less expensive, pretentious, and insulting to your intelligence.

A New York must do. WOW - I pre booked & as soon as I arrived, I went straight in. No waiting.The pre tour experience is very good - i won't spoil it.The views are amazing. For me better than Empire state or Topof the rock.

One WTC Observatory ~ Splendid. Every step of the way, this new venue will take your breath away. Know that the elevator ride will be awesome, going through all the development since the 1600's Views from the top are sweet. Food service provided by Legends is solid and a good value.

Absolutely brilliant. Booked tickets online before our holiday but still had to queue for a while to get in as it was so busy. But well worth the wait with a great video going up in the lift and the big reveal when you get up there. The views are fantastic. well worth the visit.

So unorganzied!. Ok wow where to begin. I'll start off by saying they sell timed tickets, and suggest you arrive 15 minutes prior to that time. Simple enough. Upon arriving at the suggested 15 minutes early, there was nothing but chaos and people all over the sidewalk, most having no idea where to go at all, Fighting through the crowd to try and find an employee, once I found one I was told they were just lining up people with tickets from an hour before our time, so we were in for a long wait! Once in the building, it was a pretty quick move to get to the top. The elevator ride is cool with the video that plays. Once at the top, the views are certainly amazing, as good as it gets. The downside, unlike the Empire State Building, the entire observatory is enclosed. This makes it hard to get a good picture, ad the glass reflects all inside light, and the number of fingerprints all over the glass from people that can't keeps their hand off for whatever reason. ESB is better because you are outside, so you get the sounds of the city as well, which just adds to the experience. The staff at One World are pretty clueless as well. I asked about 10 members the same question, and pretty much got a different answer from each one. Cashiers at the souvenir store seemed that they would rather be anywhere but there as well. Overall I was disappointed in my visit here, unlikely I'd go back. ESB is a far better experience, and stays open later as well.

Surprisingly amazing!!!. This is a place for a great view of the city, I purchased the tickets with a time window and didn't have to wait in line when we get there. Very organized, courteous employees.

See Forever, It's True. Incredible views of the city and environs, even w/iPad option (upcharge, $14, I think) that delineates what you are seeing. Travel up in elevator 102 stories and as you go up, you can see video of the city's architectural landscape evolving. Start w/entering granite bedrock of New York, like walking into a cave but excellent and truly brilliant use of natural materials and an intro to the experience. Expensive; basic pass all you need; I bought $52 one, and wasn't worth it. Crowded, but what isn't that's spectacular.

Disappointing. No didn't enjoy this much. We felt like we were being herded around the whole time, the observatory is soul-less and unwelcoming, and far too busy. And yes the view is amazing but looking at it through not particularly clean windows felt so sterile after the wonderful experience of the Empire State. Actually the best bit of this visit was the lift up which has a wonderful 'story' as you travel upwards.

On a clear day you could see forever. The entire tour experience was impressive, I thought I was in Disney World or the Universal Studio. The journey was absolutely an enjoyment. And the view was just spectacular!!!One thing though, I wouldn't dine up there as there no quality in either experience or taste.
Unbelievable!. The views from the One World Observatory is unbelievable!!! You can see the whole Manhattan from the top! Plus the Statute of Liberty!! 360 degree view is breathtaking!

Breathtaking!!!. We had a little more time before we left the city and decided to see if we could get in to One World Observatory. It was early Monday morning and we walked right up and bought tickets and went right in. Score!! The elevator ride is worth the price of admission. So well done!! Sorry for all the exclamation marks but I truly had a good experience. The movie is great as well as the grand finale. We did buy the IPad for further information but we are pretty familiar with the area and the landmarks so we probably should have skipped that purchase. Besides if you have any questions just ask the staff. They were super friendly and extremely knowledgeable.
Awesome. Excellent way to see everything in the city. Worth the money and time. Very friendly and informative.
Fantastic views!. A great elevator ride starts off your 360 degree New York experience! Enjoyed the time spent there...

Beautiful building, beautiful views, poor organization.. The experience itself is nice. The lead up, not so much. Expect to be delayed, but get there early. We bought tickets for a 6:30pm slot, and arrived at about 5:45pm. They still had people in line outside the building for the 5:30 slot, and there was no organization for people outside to know where they should wait, or what time slot was being admitted when. It took myself and some other visitors talking to a supervisor to get someone to come outside and try and separate the people waiting into groups based on their time slots. With all of the money they put into that building, all they'd really need are some "now serving" signs over the lines, telling people which line to get into for their time slot. That would really simplify things.
Must do !. I simply had to do this one.It is breath taking and cannot be described - amazing.Gives a very different perspective to the Rock and Empire State due to location.Very well done as well.

Better than the Empire State. After a poignant visit to the 9/11 memorial we spend a great 90 minutes at One World Observatory. What a view. Clear 360 view of NYC with great views down to Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty. Must do activity but book you tickets beforehand as its easy to do and really speeds up your access and avoid the queues. Great experience

Overbooked! . This was a disappointing wait. More than an hour past our scheduled time. RUDE staff smarted off "what do you expect on a Holiday weekend?" Really? Columbus Day?? Numerous Lines to get in. Not just outside. Plus lines to get out. It's a good view. People camp out in the window sill (not even looking out) because there's nowhere else to sit. Hard to get an open window. The line to get back on the hop-on bus was well over an hour wait. We had to find another way back- after paying $50 to get there. That's my next review!
Well worth the visit. Clever imagery and informative facts in the start up presentation, the viewing area is well appointed and the views are stunning.

Just AMAZING. What I can say is just: Go There. The ticket is worth each dollar.Incredible emotions, from the elevator to the observatory, the real Phoenix of the USA. Unique goosebumps and view on the memorial. To do, to do, to do!

View & experience is amazing, lines are terrible. Clearly a popular attraction to visit in NYC these days so it's likely to be on your must-do list. But there are some things worth knowing before you go.The lines are long - even with timed entry tickets (at a starting rate of $32 for adults.) Buy tickets online before you go to cut out 1 line to wait in. We had timed ticket for 3:15 on a Saturday. We hadn't gotten to the elevators by 4:15. There is a line outside the building that they put you in based on your timed (every 15 min) ticket. You wait there for some time (for us 30+ mins) outside - so be prepared for the weather. Then you get inside - don't get excited yet. There's still a long way to go. You go down an escalator and then get in line for the security check point. After security there is a very long line for the elevators -- you're channeled here in your timed group. The area where you wait for the elevators includes some good video content on the building of the tower. Then it moves into a narrow area of fake granite to show the bedrock of Manhattan. This area could be claustrophobic for some. The content is good - but the line is long and crowded. They have not figured out how Disney world tricks you into not realizing you are in line.Finally you get to the elevators (note more than an hour for our experience on a Fall Saturday.) The elevator ride up is cool -there's a video graphic reel that shows NYC growing over time as your ascend. Close your eyes or look at the door if motion bothers you.When you reach the top, guess what there is another line. To get into the preview area - another good video graphic thing but you're anxious to see the real view. After the video intro you exit to an area where they pitch hard selling you photos and hand held devices for more info (read - another money maker for them). Finally you get to go down a flight to the 360 observation deck. Where you can battle your way to the windows through the 100's of other people to get a view. The views are amazing. You want to see this. Just be prepared for a long wait. And a lot of "buy more" opportunities. And did I mentioned there is a line to get the elevators down. Really.There did appear to be a way to skip some of the lines - if I did it again I would gladly spring the extra $$ for the VIP entry. Same crowds at the top - but you skip some of the lines on the ground.Who ever is running the observation deck is clearly trying to pump too many people through each hour. They need to cut ticket sales back so if you buy a 3:15 ticket you are let into security at 3:15. It's not that difficult to figure out how many people can fit in the 4 small elevators and how many times they can go up and down in a hour. That should be the max sales. Clearly it isn't. If you go. Go early in the day. And/or buy the express ticket.

An amazing evening on an amazing trip. My wife and I came to New York for an Anniversary weekend. We went to the World trade center museum followed by going up the World one Observatory. Both are amazing, located next to each other, and bookends to the 9/11 events. Buy tickets in advance if possible and be prepared to wait in line. It wasn't very busy when we went and had a 45 min-1 hr wait in lines before going up. Views were amazing as expected, food and drinks are outrageous so bring a water bottle. You will go through airport style security so plan appropriately. We tried for sunset but got to the top a little after dark. An overall great time although the reflection from the glass for night pics was a little annoying.

Must visit. Great experience from start to finish.. Breathtaking views. $32 admission for an adult. Worth it. Beautiful building and the whole experience has been planned well to make it special. Visit even if you have done Empire State Building and/or Top of the Rock. It offers something different and more symbolic

Must visit. Views are unreal. Go on a clear day.. Having visited Top of the Rock and the Empire State Building on previous visits to New York we weren't expecting much different from 1 WTC. We were wrong. From the moment you purchase your ticket ($32 for an adult but worth it) you are taken into the interactive experience. You hear stories from the people that helped build 1WTC and start to realise what it symbolises to those people and to the people of NYC and the USA. The lift to the top is also special showing how NYC has changed over time. The views at the top are so clear and breathtaking it looks like a photograph. We visited around 6.30pm and the sun was setting making it more beautiful. It was very busy but still enjoyable.

Great views but prepare for tourist trap experiences. The views are stunning but it takes almost an hour from security to get to the real views. Prepare to stand around for a while if you buy standard admission. Also prepare to be sold on photos and iPads with informational software. It just feels inorganic from the start which is a shame since the world trade center should be a show of resilience and awe not sales and gimmick.
Great New site!. Fantastic trip to an amazing building. Pre buy your tickets to avoid the queues. Views were wonderful from the top and the elevator ride was great!
Breathtaking!!!!!. We chose the perfect crystal clear day and we could see forever! Beautiful building. Wonderful coffee stop. Interesting presentations. Don't miss it.

Best Views Of NYC. This is probably the number one attraction in NY. Opened in July, it offers 360 degree views of Manhattan, The Hudson and New Jersey.I highly recommend priority tickets as lines just to access the building can reach over an hour and a half. After you enter the building you are directed towards one of 4 elevators.As the elevator goes up you see the New York skyline being built over the years with a quick glimpse of the former WTC. After you exit the elevator you enter a theater playing a short 2-3minute movie called the Spirit of New York. The screens lift up and you see all of Manhattan in it's glory with mesmerizing music. This brought a tear to my eye.There is truly nothing like this in New York, even the world. Many think to go up the Empire State or the Rockefeller Center but from this building you get views of both.It is a must do if you're visiting New York.

Great spot! Great atmosphere! Go at sunset.. We were visiting New York with the Citypass so we were not planning to go to the WTC. However, we went to the 9/11 memorial on 9/11/2015 and after the visit we decided to go to the top of the biggest tower in NYC. Fee is 32$ but we felt that our money was well worthed! Excellent atmosphere up there and magical sights at sunset. Much better than Top of The Rock or Empire State.

This Blows - major tourist trap!. It sucks @$32 per. It's mobbed withh tourists, packed in 3 deep at the windows. You cant get decent pics, and there is only one deck to see anything, and nothing outside for the public. Original Twin Towers blows it away, so doesnCN Tower in Toronto, and Empire State Bldg.

never forget. I was here when it was all normal in late 80's and stayed at the Marriot Hotel, I never could have imagined as a teenager what would happen at this location. A classmate of mine in high school was killed in the tower collapse as he worked there. I was hoping to find his name around the reflecting pools and I did after checking both of them. We were showing another couple NYC sights for the first time and had other plans so we didn't see everything or spend all the time we could have. The crowds here with their camera phones, especially younger ones, are really irritating blocking the names and thinking they are special visiting this location like it's just another attraction. I hate that this thing has to exist and it's taken me a long time to make it here and see it. I think a lot of people not from the tri-state area have no idea how local people feel about this area. Several sad names mentioning women who died along with their unborn child. There is still a lot of construction in this area and it takes a long time to figure your way here from Penn Station, especially with all kinds of weekend subway schedule changes. I like what they've done with the space.

Too high of an expectation?. Having been to many observatories before I was actually a little disappointed. The best part is the forever theater. Observatory was small, and for being such a new build, not as well laid out as others. There's no question about the view, but the view is already there, and the observatory should be built to enhance the experience. Despite requiring timed tickets, it was still way too crowded, with almost every window occupied.Free upgrade with MC to VIP, which was not that much quicker at 11AM on Sunday morning, but by the time we left at 12 noon, it looked to be very useful. Still, would've expected VIP pass to include a little more than just getting past the security line, especially if you have to pay for it.
Freedom tower. This is spectacular and worth every cent of the $32 to get in. You have a time slot for your visit yet may stay a while brilliant !!

Moving. Definitely worth a visit. The fountains in the main plaza are beautiful and the whole seen is very moving. Free to walk around.Museum inside is well done although I found one section had too many scenes that no-one will ever forget and don't need to see again on a running loop. But that is only one section.
Great views and experience . The new World Trade Center is a great way to experience NYC. From the amazing video in the quick elevator ride to the 102nd floor to the beautiful 360 degrees views.

WOW. I think this was probably the highlight of our trip. The views are incredible and they have a fantastic way of revealing the first aspect to you. The lift to the top shows a video of New York through the ages as the city is built up and is really interesting.
Brilliant building. Impressive building, close to ground zero obviously, very busy area but is a must see, good location to Battery park too.

Best view of New York And more............ You can see New York and much more,you are on the 104th floor ,it's really unbelievable what you can see, hard to describe, a must see, great restaurants up there to enjoy .

Cracking view, awful queuing. If you love queuing, you're in luck here. We queued for a cheeky half an hour outside the building. Following this there was another 15 minute queue to get to the security scanners. Then another 10 minute queue to get into the elevators. Another queue to get to the observation deck of about 5 minutes. We then had to have a photograph taken, before we could go and look at the view, so we could buy a rubbish blue screen photo for a massively inflated price. Brilliant. The view from the observation deck was breathtaking, but was ruined by the endless queuing. The elevators are very cool as the y whisk you all the way up in under a minute and there's a great historical video of the city in the lift as you go up.A further 20 minutes of queuing was enjoyed to get into the lift to go down again.In summary, well over an hour of queuing with a decent lift ride and great view of the city. Plan for plenty of time...
One Worls Observatory. I have no words that can describe the view from the 102nd floor. There is a 360 degree view of NY City. Mesmerising. It costs 32 dollars but believe me it's worth every dollar.

DO NOT MISS THIS! It's a LIFETIME EXPERIENCE!. Seriously. This is phenomenal! Pay the money and go to the top. We went midweek and there was not a huge crowd. There is good crowd control techniques within so it won't be too boring if you do have to wait. They line the halls with movies, and interactive things. Get on the elevator- and i won't ruin the experience, but be ready for a treat! There is another introductory movie at the top- WATCH it-truly WORTH IT! Then behold the height sights of your life! And another surprise on the elevator down. My husband is terrified of heights, and he even felt so comfortable up top that he sat by the window and took photos. Go and do this!!

New York World Trade Center now open!. You MUST experience this as a part of your NY experience!!Go on a clear day. Views of the entire city are spectacular....though you don't go outside any more.....and there is no time pressure... Do it leisurely, even have lunch if you like.There are a number of options to enhance your experience too, including iPads to highlight the views.Cost for access is about $35, but you can advance to front of the waiting line for $20 additional fee....its worth it! We happened to be there when they welcomed 1,000,000th visitor in the space of just a few months!

Overpriced - better views available from Empire State Building. Great lift though!. As this was my 4th visit to New York I'd already done most of the main attractions. We visited the 9/11 museum last year which was outstanding and as the One World Observatory had just opened we decided to give it a go.Obviously this is a very important building and visiting it in itself is very moving but speaking purely in terms of views I think the Empire State Building is superior as you get to see upper and Lower Manhattan including Central park whereas here you only get a view of Brooklyn/Lower Manhattan. Also as it's completely enclosed it doesn't feel as exciting as the Empire State building and you can't take good photos as your reflection in the window shows. There were also loads of people sat in the windows looking at their phones which was annoying as it obscures the view for other people. Would be good if there were benches or chairs away from the window so people who need to can rest.The best bit by far is the lift, now that is an experience - I won't spoil the surprise. Didn't appreciate the hard sell of the Tablet experience, I'm not even sure what it was but after paying $32 each to get in I wasn't parting with anymore cash. People were walking around with the tablets with the volume ridiculously loud as well which was annoying. Getting out of the observation deck was an ordeal, the exit should be signposted more clearly. Funnily enough I kept ending up by the cafe...I wonder if that is intentional?My advice if you're choosing between here, the Empire State Building and Rockerfeller centre is to choose from the 2 latter options as the view is better. The 9/11 museum and memorial are excellent though, a very moving tribute to those who died and I would definitely recommend a visit to both.Anyone wanting a hearty deli lunch after should head over to Stage Door which is excellent.

Outstanding 360 degree of NYC. Very moving experience to visit this building. The views from the observation deck are outstanding and you can rent an iPod that allows you to zoom in to and explain the sights you are seeing. It is 15.00 but you really need only 1 for your group. We also had a light bite and drink in the restaurant. It was fairly priced and the views from the restaurant are outstanding.

Amazing . Our visit to One World Trade Center was unforgettable! From the moment you are in the elevator on your way up until you ride the elevator down it is simply breathtaking! I really can't describe it. You have to see it for yourself if possible! Once you get to the top of the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere you have a 360° view of Manhattan Island!

Newest, tallest building in NYC, a must visit. When I visited One World Trade Centre had not long opened, lots of locals were checking it out. I went up in early evening and positioned myself to capture sunset and the city lights of NY & NJ which I can highly recommend.Make sure you have your video camera on in the lifts and pay close attention- the lift going up showed how NYC skyline had changed over time. Was fascinating.Also, this has to be the best spot to truly understand the scale of the Twin Towers, when you look down from One World Trade Centre you can see the memorial pools, especially lit up a night in the footprint of the foundations of each Twin Tower.I went up after my trip through the 9/11 Museum. A good way to end the day.

Worth the Cost. The Observatory Deck is so worth the $32. The elevator ride is a fun surprise showing the progression of NYC from back when it was just farm land. The 360 view of NYC can't be beat. It is beautiful. The attraction is very well done.

Great views. My husband and I took the elevator up to the 102nd floor after visiting the 9/11 Memorial. It was very impressive even if the rain did impede the view. The observation deck gives a 360° view of area – New Jersey, Manhattan, Brooklyn…then we had a relaxing bite and some cold beers while looking out from the top of the One World (a welcome break).

Great experience!. Bought the priority entrance tickets to this fantastic observatory. Well worth it, what a view! Views!! And the restaurant was just fine and delicious, we stopped for a drink and a light meal.Not to be missed.

Not just a view but an experience. Went to One World Observatory in October 2015. I recommend buying tickets ahead of time and taking at least 2 hours to experience... Keep in mind that this is an experience, not just a view from the top of a building.. From the ride up in the high tech elevators to what you get at the top of the viewing area.. I won't give details of what your going to experience, keeping it a surprise, but keep in mind you will be taken back by what they did with this experience!
Fitting tribute. Eerily amazing and peaceful. Loved the Memorial Pools and park that has been built where the towers once stood

Well worth the wait!. We visited the Observatory a few days after it opened to the public. We booked online that morning and found space. The queuing system was good, tho still a 45 min wait to get to the lift. It's a really informative and exciting experience - not just a viewing de k, like the Empire State is, but it includes a visual history of New York and the opportunity to stay up there for a long time! We took 6 kids aged 3-9 up with us, and they were mesmerised as the view is through floor to ceiling windows. We thought it was the best $20 we spent all holiday!

Cracking, but not open views. The good -Superb views around all of ManhattanFantastic liftAmazing reveal at the end of part 1 of the experienceLovely wide floor space on the observation deck Very pleasant staffSeemed pretty quiet on your visit - Monday early afternoon - no trouble getting to the windows, just a short wait for one or two popular spotsOnce in the queue (see below) it moved through fairly quicklyThe not so good -There are several different queues outside the building. We'd bought tickets with timed entry and it wasn't obvious which queue we should be in. After asking, we were supposed to be in a queue that was not signed so we wouldn't have known without askingBecause the deck is enclosed, you don't feel as connected to the outside world as you do at, say, the Empire State BuildingUbiquitous security - I understand why it's done, but it does get tiresome after a whileGlass windows mean that it's more difficult to get phots without reflections - I was wearing a striped dress and in a good 50% of the photos, my dress was visible. It's not impossible thoughOverall -Thoroughly modern version of an observation deck. Great views, helpful staff, very spacious.We didn't eat there and didn't hire the tablet so can't comment on those

See For Miles and Miles. Interesting elevator ride up to the observation deck and spectacular views in all directions. We did not have advance tickets and were able to go up after just a short wait on line during early afternoon on a Thursday in September.

Spectacular views - well worth the price. Attraction is well run and your experience begins when you walk in the door. Elevator not only takes you to the top, but shows the changing face of NYC through present day. Of course the views are spectacular. You can take as much time as you like to enjoy without being rushed and enjoy a cocktail at the top of the world. Was there during the day and looking forward to seeing at night on my next trip. Well worth the money.
A MUST SEE. Whole area is an experience . From the reflections ponds to the incredible view and introduction. Helpful staff and snack area.

Awesome.. We didn't have to queue for more than ten minutes today. The tour starts with a security check on the lower level, a walk through the bedrock with information captions projected onto the bedrock. We then ascended in the lift for 38 seconds. The panels of the lift depicted the progress over the years. Out of the lift we stood side by side with about 30 people. We saw a visual display depicted of outside and then the wall lifted and we saw the real view. It was breathtaking. Next we were ushered through to an area with outside views where we were invited to buy time on an orientated iPad. $15. Worth it cause you could tap on certain landmarks and zoom in for an audio/visual history. Next we went downstairs to the real 360* visual. Well worth the visit. Awesome. The whole experience is well planned and an extremely good experience. We stopped at one of the restaurants for a quick bite to eat. Typical USA fast food. Staff extremely helpful.Restrooms excellent.

Amazing view but a touch too commercial for my taste. After visiting the memorial it seemed rude not to give the newest addition to NYs skyline a look. For a Sunday afternoon I was pleasently surprised that the queue wasn't bigger-20 minutes and we were going through the airport style security. I would assume the priority tickets would help if you are restricted to weekend only visiting.The staff were nonchalant and rude, but this is the typical jobsworth style at Manhatten tourist destinations. It is too commercialised and they evidently want to fleece you for every buck. You've already paid $32, get to the top and they almost coersively go on the hard sell for the interactive Ipads. Use your eyes those are free, if you have been organised you will already have a guide book on NY which can give you exactly the same information for free.Thankfully it wasn't to busy, but at times you struggle to see the highlights. It doesn't have the wow factor of the Empire State building as there isn't an open viewing deck-they have missed a trick here. Still an amazing building with great views, drop your prices and teach your staff some manners!

Don't miss it. This is a first class tour, starting with the elevator ride to the views from the top. We bought our tickets on line, which was easy, and opted to rent the computer viewing tablet on site that gave a brief history and location of buildings we could see from the top. It did not dissapoint!

Wowezers!!!. 102 stories up!!! Truthfully, I had reservations going up the elevator. Well, it was nothing to be concerned about at all. Less than a minute long and you re there. On top of that you don't wven feel that you've gone up 102 floors high. See forever is an understatement! The views....WOW!!!
Awesome. Highly recommended. Superb view, all NYC and powerful inspiring overview of ground zero... A must in NYC

A Must See If Visiting The Big Apple. We did the tour and also visited the 911 museum. A page in the history of our country that should never be forgotten. Definitely a must do if you are a visitor of NYC. They did a beautiful job with this tragic happening.
Nice and amazing. Amazing and nice wiew. Cooool lift, and a nice place to go for everyone. This is the best wiew in New Yourk now. It's so special to be close to the sea, and 1000 feet up.

Nice place but not the best observatory in NYC. It's modern and it looks different from the other observatories only because it's newer. Doesn't have an outside deck and everything is indoor. The building itself is impressive and the views are "okay" I gave it only 3 stars because the views aren't that great compared to rocker-feller center or Empire State Building but it's a must do because of how new it is..elevator was also move but it's only about a minute ride up..I would suggest other buildings or observatories if u want a nicer view

WHAT'S WITH THE MISERABLE REVIEWS?. I can't believe some people. There are some unjustified bad reviews of this experience. Most are aimed at the "rip-off" cost of admission. $64 for me and Beverley. We paid more than that for a cab ride from hell the day before. Now THAT'S exploitation! From the moment we got in line, the staff were courteous and friendly. The elevator ride itself was worth the entrance fee alone. Totally unexpected. Tip..... get your camera out before you get in. You'll miss it if you don't. Then there is another graphics show that has a twist.One of the major gripes is the supposed hard sell of the interactive tablet. Rubbish. It is a short presentation that the majority of people don't choose to go with. We did and for $15 it is worth doing. We stayed in the tower a lot longer by having the tablet, thus getting more value for money from the experience. It is a bit tricky to get used to but once you crack it you'll be like a kid with a new toy.The actual viewing area is very much like the Hancock Tower in Chicago. The only dissapointment for me was the glass floor portal. I had thought it was actually a view beneath your feet to the ground. It's not. It is a projection image. Whines about the photo thing are also misplaced. There isn't an attraction in the world that doesn't try to sell you a photo memento of your visit. Just say "no thanks" next time. You won't be tarred and feathered. Honest. A great experience that will become a must do thing - if not THE must do thing - when visiting NY city.

The best view ever!!!!. We have been to New York many times in the past 50 years, and the Freedom Tower Observation deck is the most amazing sight we've see- such incredible views! We can't wait to go back!
Bird's Eye View. The Observation Tower gives a phenomenal 360 view of New York. We had a clear day, so the views were perfect. It's a long wait and very pricey but worth visiting once.
Great view would you believe?!. Outstanding - a must see. The experience is put together well and is not tacky. The lift ride is really well designed

A unique and powerful experience. A unique and powerful experience. The view from the observatory seems unending and the historic view of the changes in the NYC skyline as the elevator whisks to the top in under one minute is unique. The tour is well organized but looses no chance to build revenue. The powerful experience is the memory of the last view of so many who tragically died in the vicious, terrorist attack.
Beautiful and Tranquil. Such a beautiful monument. So well thought out and simple.You must visit when in NYC.Very sobering

A must for New York Travelers. Emotional but a must for those who experienced 911 in any way.The Memorial pools are great reminders of those who died on that day. We must never forget all those who lost their lives on that fateful morning. The World trade center also lost lives a few years before in the underground parking area. Those lives are also remembered at the memorial.

Awe Inspiring!. Lighting fast elevator glides you up to the 102nd floor. Elevator ride shows a trip through time in Manhattan through a computer simulated animation. One you arrive at the top there is a spectacular 360 view to behold. Unlike the old World Trade Center there is no access to the outside roof. This is an indoor experience. Take as long as you like to enjoy the view. Just wish the visibility was better the day I visited, but a storm was rolling in. In any event it is a must see!

Best view of NYC, with a great (short) introductory show. This is not your standard high city observatory like the Sears Tower or the Eiffel Tower. The elevators have large media screens on the inside with something special, and as you arrive at the top, there is a brief show that is very well done. The observatory is 360, but inside. It still allows for the best views of NYC.

new beginnings. tower 1 world trade stands as tall as the original twin towers, and looks down on the two memorial fountains. it's actually the 3rd tower built at the site, and work is still going on around it. be prepared to queue for the observation floor!

Quite expensive but visitors want to do it.. As others have said this attraction can be very busy and if possible it is worth trying to buy tickets in advance (even on the day of your visit if you are flexible). We went when the attraction opened and the observation deck was quite quiet at first but filled up later. The views are stunning as you would expect but depending on the time of day of your visit photos aren't always easy to take as there can be a lot of reflection off the glass. The talks done by the Ambassadors are interesting and pitched at everyone so are enjoyable. I did find that the souvenirs on offer were poor quality and found that graphics on T-shirts etc left a lot to be desired and was really surprised at the lack of good postcards/books showing views from the deck - as they have one of the world's best skylines around them to use. I marked the attraction as average due to cost(quite high), waiting times being long on popular days and the "hard sell" of I-pads to hire for a guide.

Top 3 in NYC!. Do not miss this while you're in NYC! The observatory is incredibly well done. Everything from the initial reception to the elevator ride to the amenities at the top was one of a kind. I believe this is now the highest observatory in the city and the views are stunning. Come for the scenery, but stay for the interactive presentations, eat-in restaurant and bar, and overall atmosphere. Military in uniform get free entrance; not in uniform receive a small discount on admission. Highly recommended!

The higher the better. The observation deck is 102 stories and 1248 feet above the ground. You get to look down on the Empire State building. But it does cost $30 for a senior citizen and a little more if not discounted.
Beautiful. This building was built so beautifully, especially with the 9/11 attacks and the nearby memorial in mind. It is overwhelming to be near, and definitely adds to the NY skyline
Beautiful views. The views were beautiful. There was a nice restaurant at the top were we had a drink and appetizers.

Not to be missed!. I'm still in awe of my visit to the One World Observatory. Knew I would love it but didn't expect to love it as much. Don't want to say too much as it would spoil the experience but the organisation and surprises are definitely worth the money!

A credit to the people of NYC... Amazing. Simply stunning and amazing. The views are spectacular and the experience is spot on. The efforts by everyone involved is second to none.......If you are going to NYC then don't miss the opportunity. The journey to the top and back in the lift are out of this world.....
Very moving and well done. What can you do with a disaster memorial.Well the Americans did it well and should be proud of the effort and thought what must have gone into the planning.
Great views at the One World Observatory.. We really loved the 360 degree views of NYC! It is an excellent way to see the city. Beautiful views!
