Neatless to say from the moment you get on the elevator is like you are entering a time machine and you want to see more as the buildings fly infront of your eyes . Also the short film on the 102 floor and the sudden drop of the shutters SIMPLY MAGNIFICENT . just to let u know that we visited end of July around 18.00 and the waiting time was less than 10 minutes

Don't miss One World Trade Center!. WOW! I visited the 9/11 Museum last year and it was exactly as I expected, truly a memorial to that day and the lives lost. The One World Trade Center is exactly the opposite. It's the epitome of the joy saluting our ability to overcome. The elevator ride alone is worth the price of admission. And the view is AMAZING!
Great view!. Stunning view. Must see attraction in NYC. The coolest part is the elevator keep your eyes open since is a fast trip.

Una experiencia inolvidable. Subir al One World Observatory is really a unique experience. Not only because the view is stunning and uplifting (literally) but because it is a true sample of how America constantly rebuilds itself, remembers and pays tribute to the past.Wonderful!!!

Una experiencia inolvidable. Subir al One World Observatory is really a unique experience. Not only because the view is stunning and uplifting (literally) but because it is a true sample of how America constantly rebuilds itself, remembers and pays tribute to the past.
Wonderful!!!

Amazing!. When I had friends visit from SoCal I thought it was about time I experience the observatory. Well - I shouldn't have waited so long! Great views! Souvenirs all over priced but what can you do. We bought the anytime ticket vs the designated time and it's so worth it. No waiting in line. It was very crowded (being August) - we got there noonish. Get there early!

What a view!. This is the place where we went, not the review I did for the Top of the Rock. THIS is the building where you book your tickets on your phone for the next available tour when you are standing there, get in line and they get you inside in less than 15 minutes. You shoot up 102 floors in 52 seconds on your elevator ride. The view from the top is compared to no other, at least not from a building! Put this place on your bucket list!!!
Impressive. A massive amount of information as to how it was built. Great views from the top. This is another "must see"
Great Views. Brilliant views of the whole city, the lift up was really good. We went just before sunset which meant we got to see the city on both sides!

Beautiful but pricy. Must do! We took the elevator all the way to the top. The elevator ride was incredible, I won't say anything because I don't want to ruin the surprise. The only downfall I found it a little pricy considering the only thing included was an elevator ride up and a view but closed up. And then they try and sell you even more stuff once you get to the top.
NYC Visit. Worth the time not the money, but the view is spectacular. Be sure to go on a clear day so you can enjoy the view.
NYC. Over priced and unbelievably noisy. The view is spectacular but that is all I can say nice about this adventure. Exprss ticket good for going up but not down. Eat elsewhere!
Amazing!. Amazing experience, the observatory is very well set up! Different view of Manhattan from the one you get from the top of the rock, or the Empire State building.

That's high. Like every attraction (or almost) this one costs a fair bit. The elevator taking you to level 102 is amazing as you are surrounded by screens that display the evolution of NYC from a greenfield to what it is now (and beyond if my memory serves me right) as you get higher. Once you're up there the views are stunning.
Worth a visit. A beautiful building with magnificent view - I think the staff could be a bit more welcoming. Worth a visit

Fab views - poor staff. The views are fantastic from the 100th floor - great fast trip up in the life very scenic and interesting. Staff were a bit abrupt and the cafe does not have any seating I think they want you to pay more and go in the restaurant and when the till wouldnt work they didnt explain or speak to you they just talked amongst themselves, which I found rude. You can pay extra for a i-pad that gives you more info about your view, it would have been nice to have some of this just dotted about for information if you didnt want to pay the extra. The t

Excellent!. Great experience from check in to the "big reveal" at the top. Good crowd control, multimedia production values on elevator ride to the top, dramatic build up to the magnificent view. We took two friends from Europe and they were really impressed. Hint: if you are going to visit the 9/11 Museum do so BEFORE the Observatory. This way you have an uplifting experience after the somewhat depressing experience of the Museum.
New York. All surrounding area of tower is a definite thing to see. Go to see the museum as it's the best thing you could visit when you are in New York

The views are outstanding. We ordered a flexible day pass in advance which got us round all the queues and straight into the lift. The lift itself is a very clever experience and you do not realise how quickly you are going. The transition is very clever to which literally lifts the curtain on what you are going to see. The views are spectacular but we were there on a clear sunny day.
Great view. While the observatory is a little touristy, the elevator wide was cool and the view was great. It was bittersweet, but worth the visit.

We truly enjoyed the experience and thank all who made it possible. Humbling and awe inspiring are the two words I can find to describe the experience. We walked to the Freedom tower from Washington Square Park. The anticipation grows as you navigate the city's many micro neighborhoods on your way to that part of downtown and American history. Trying lying on one of the granite benches at the base of the tower and just look up towards the top. It is a phenomenal architectural achievement. Watching the clouds drift by in the background of the building is tranquil. Watching the occasional jetliner departing LGA fly over is unnerving and begs the questions we all think about concerning those who lost their lives on this very site. One World trade Center is an emotional experience -- one in which the visitor can be overwhelmed by the many feelings this sight stimulates.All-in-all, the Freedom Tower and associated 9/11 memorial(s) is an important experience that every American should have the opportunity to visit. While the tour inside the building is great, one can easily enjoy this attraction without spending a dime!

Wow!!!. We were warned before visiting to book online to save any hassle with q's. This was great advice. We went online in a coffee shop whilst walking the Highline, and booked & paid for the experience later that afternoon. When we arrived at the tower a little earlier than our allocated slot, we simply showed our email barcoded tickets and were allowed to go straight through.You get a really nice welcome and the intro tour/experience on the ground floor/basement is a great celebration of what has been achieved here.You are then taken up in a lift to the top floors. The lift is an amazing part of this experience but I won't ay any more to save the surprises both here and with the film you see at the top.You are then free to wander and view from the top floors - and what a view this is. It must be the best views of New York City in New York City.Well worth a visit!!!

Awesome view of the city!. I loved the view from One World Observatory. What a great way to see the city. At $32.00, some would say it's pricey but it's the same price as the Empire State Bldg. and just $2.00 more than the Top of the Rock. Each has their good points. For views of Central Park, Top of the Rock can't be beat but the views of Lower Manhattan including the Statue of Liberty, the Brooklyn Bridge, the 9/11 reflecting pools, etc. are great here. I definitely recommend experiencing this new attraction. We went just as the sun was setting and it was beautiful.

Face it . . . this is one touristy thing you HAVE to do.. So well done from start to finish. The trip to the top is almost as fascinating as the stunning view you have once you arrive. The staff keeps the line moving quickly and everyone was extremely friendly and helpful. Please don't read too much about the experience if it's your first visit because there's an awesome surprise that's part of it . . . I only took one of my three children on my most recent trip and haven't even told the other two about the surprise in case we get another chance to visit. It's THAT good.

Beautiful view of NYC!. Get priority tickets to skip a good portion of the lines. We went on September 12th and we missed half the lines by having priority tickets. The one thing I recommend to the people who work there is to have someone permanently staffed just after the priority ticket ends. We ended up in a line and wasn't sure if we were required to stand there or if we should have continued farther up, but no one was around to ask. You rise very quickly in the elevator, which shows you the views of NYC as it was being built starting in the 1800's until today. Pay attention to the screen on the right which shows the twin towers going up and then coming down. No one mentioned it to us beforehand so I missed it. I overheard someone else pointing it out, but the picture change by the time I turned my head. They take you too the top, which is not where you can see out. I'm not sure why that is as there are windows all around, but blocked with panels. I'm not sure why they force you down a level to go to the conservatory. They have tablets you can rent for $15 that shows you places in the distance and some information about them, which is nice. Make sure you go up on a nice day if possible so you have a better view. The area is beautiful. I took pictures with my iPhone and they were okay. Sometimes I got a reflection on the window of people standing close so it's tricky to get a great picture, but it is possible.

Has the WOW factor. Just expected to go to the top and look out on the Statue of Liberty and Manhattan - it was so much more with interesting visual displays upon entry, a gasping surprise one minute after alighting the elevator [not saying what] , the view from the top, good information guides and an exhilarating trip down to ground level in the elevator. Would recommend this visit having been up the Empire State, Shard [London].Question I asked no one could find the answer - 'how thick is the glass?'The only downside as in many visits elsewhere are the photographers trying to get you to buy a picture of your visit

Do not skip this one!. One WTC is absolutely stunning, every picture you take there and in the vicinity will look like you are a professional photographer truly. The ground around One WTC is the WTC memorial which is a ambient park, which is lovely to walk through. I didn't go up the One WTC, so I can't give good recommendations, but if you're willing to go up multiple skyscrapers this should be one of them. If you're on a tight budget than I would recommend the Top of the Rock (Rockefeller skyscraper)

Wow! A must do on an NYC visit.. The lines are long, the wait is tedious, the experience is tremendous. You go through airport style security and then you wait for a 60 second elevator ride to the 103rd floor with a simulated video. As you exit, you are led into a small theater for a media presentation that ends with a spectacular view of the city. Then you are marketed for an free I-pad which is helpful if you want to identify the sites down below and have not been to NYC, then you are led to a place where your photo is taken in front of a simulated cityscape and which you can purchase on your way out, and then finally, you get to view the magnificent sights! Whew! But the wait is worth it all. There is also a cafeteria and a bar and a dining room; and, of course, there is a gift shop. Go! It is an experience that should be on everyone's bucket list. But get tickets on-line first to assure entry and avoid an even longer line or disappointment at being turned back at the door.

Epic. Loved visiting the One World Trade Center. There was a very sad atmosphere about and you can't help think about the thousands of people that last their lives not far away, but the building is epic. Not gonna lie, it was quite scary being at the top, it almost felt like the tower was moving from side to side. Definitely worth doing as a one off
Great 360 Degree View of NYC. Yes, you get a great 360 degree view of NYC, but it is now inside views only. No outside viewing platform.

Great View of NYC. We didn't pre-book, so joined the queue for tickets and was surprised at how quickly it moved. We were at the ticket counter within 10 minutes and got tickets for a slot in just over an hour. Perfect timing, as we visited the memorial next door.The lifts up are really fast and show a film on the lift walls of NYC growing through the ages. First up you are crammed into a long narrow room for a cheesy film, which at the end they lift the screen for your first view of NYC, They also have a cafeteria, which is super pricey.You then have free time to stroll around the observation deck, which is inside. It provides excellent 360 degree view of the city.The lifts down are equally as fast. Definitely worth the tour.
Amewone. Really worth the price, the elevator it´s so nice, unique experience. What a view!!! I went in the sunset and was supper.

Excellent view to the whole city. This is probably one of the best ways to view the NY skyline. The observatory is located at the southernmost part of Manhattan and offers a 360 degrees view to Downtown, Midtown, Financial district, Brooklyn bridge, Jersey, and Ellis Island.There is a nice show in the elevator showing the history and progress of New York. Inside there a shop where you can buy magnets, clothes and other merchandise. Buy tickets online to avoid long queue. All in all wonderful experience.

Attractive building!. The building itself is very attractive. But the circular "crown" and tranmission tower on top are ugly and don't match the rest of the building. Looks like the project ran out of money in the final stage of construction. A real pity for NY and the country.... reflects the decline of the U.S., as if we can't afford to do things first class anymore.

awesome view, but shady place. its nice to see the memorial and the new building..... but it is an odd site. the whole time people were preaching about 9/11 being fake and also hasidic jews had some sort of perimeter set up with no agenda other then staring people down...weird.

Great view to see The Empire State Building. It is amazing alternative to observe the famous building of NYC - The Empire State. It is great and different view of the city. However, the best view in my opinion is from The Top of Rock, that we can see many famous building including the One World Trade Tower. From this Observatry is possible to overlook The Liberty Statue, The Brookling Bridge and all the South of Manhattan and New Jersey Ilands. And be prepared to record the film, to go up and down on the elevator.
The best view in the city.. A great new and positive attraction on the site of such tragedy. Good tour guide and views. Visit the Amish market just round the corner for the best deli in NYC

WTC. There are no words to describe the grandeur of One world trade center and the memorials. I didnt go through the museum, but just standing by the two memorials was so surreal. It is a must if you are vacationing in the city.

Very nice but not as good as the old WTC. Went here a month ago before visiting the 9/11 Museum. I'd buy your tickets in advance as it will minimize the time you spend in line.The presentation is nicely done and while the views are spectacular - I miss the old outside experience unobstructed by windows - you get better pictures that way anyways.I'd ignore buying trip add-ins, such as the portable guide that ID's buildings - just not worth it. For sure though take advantage of the people guides as they are more than happy to answer any questions you might have.

A must see for NYC. We booked ahead and got a convenient time slot, and I'd recommend this. Fast track also made everything a lot easier. It's a bit Disney on the way in and you're forced to watch a cheesy film. The lift ride up us SO fast... A little too fast and gave me motion sickness for the rest of my visit. The views are worth the price, queues and hassle. Once up on the observation area it didn't feel crowded and we had a very pleasant time. Stunning views and I personally preferred the experience and views here to the Empire state building.

Best of the attractions. Wow what a building and view. Out of the Empire State and the rock this is the one that we liked best. Totally blew us away from getting in the lift to seeing the view. If you can only do one atteaction this has to be the one.

Spectacular views. Been to other observation points like the top of the rock before but this place gets the best views of NYC hands down. Depending on the day and time, you could pretty much walk in and get a ticket and be in the elevator in 5 minutes which is convenient. The elevator ride and the reveal if the view are spectacular. But I felt the place is too commercial, and is lacking some good linking to the events of 9/11.

Views to rival any other building in NYC. This had only just opened when we visited but found the whole experience from booking the tickets to leaving after the visit very slick, smooth and professional. The views were amazing and there were lots of staff on sight to talk to. You could pay an additional fee for renting a ipad which detail each of the buildings and a little background which my son found fascinating. Only gripe was that they said an hour would be ample time to take it all in - it really wasn't and wish we had not be so time constrained.

Very quiet and solemn. Thousands of people paying their respects.people laying flowers on lost ones names on names. I am not quite sure what the huge white thing is they are building. Obviously something to do with9/11

Our visit to NYC. Disappointed! The evening we went was cloudy, raining and low clouding prevented us from being able to see anything. By the time we made it through all their presentations and picture taking we were unable to celebrate my brother-in-laws birthday because they were closing earl, 8:00 pm. The winter hours are now in affect so before going up to this event, check weather and closing hours.

Great views, don't understand ticket times, a bit commercial and crowded.. I don't understand purchasing tickets online at a particular time. We were visiting for the first time, and thought we should purchase tickets in advance. Which based on the long line outside was the right thing to do. If you buy tickets online, go right down to the entrance. What I don't understand is why they sell tickets in time blocks. When we got there we just walked right into the line, and the process started. It was 10:30 and we had purchased tickets for 11:15. I never once heard them call out times, nor did it seem to matter what time I purchased tickets for.SO (for those on a time schedule)... once you clear security it takes a good 30 minutes before your gazing upon the city. There is a line downstairs to get into the elevator, (the elevator rides takes less than 1 minute 'amazing'), then there is a short presentation, then there is a sales pitch for the ipad explorer ($15 i think) (it helps you figure out what your looking at) (we didn't purchase one), then another sales pitch for pictures.... AND then finally you are released into the observatory. 360 degree of views, AWESOME views of the city. The observatory is behind glass. no worries about weather,etc.The observatory was very crowed this particular day (and i believe this was a typical day), everyone taking selfies of themselves and conversing about the views. Some areas, particularly those facing uptown, were very crowded. You find yourself planning and plotting how to get up to the glass for a good view as you work around the observatory. Leaving is very quick... short line, quickly downstairs, and out you go.We spent about an one and a half hours gazing. SO the Total visit time was 2 hours... If you didn't purchase tickets beforehand, you better add another 30 minutes. One final note... if you buy tickets for a certain time, thinking that is when you are going to enter the elevator, then plan again.

Wow. Anyone who does not take time to do this needs to think again. The cost is resonnable and the views are out of this world and please have a drink and watch the sun set its well worth the cost NY at its best.

Exciting!!!. I went with my mom, who is afraid of heights (VERY surprised she suggested it), and we were both pleasantly surprised. Needless to say, the views were outstanding!!! The day was clear and we could see forever. The were alot of people, but we had NO problem at all getting around to view the sights. Before leaving we stopped at the gift shop and the selection of memorabilia was vast and affordable. Very humbling experience and it was probably the highlight of our visit to NYC.

Good views. Great views and staff were friendly and funny.Great views but unlike the Rockefella centre you are inside and pretty much just that one level. I enjoyed it but if I had to choose between the two I would choose the Rockefella.But in saying that, there is a history behind this building.Go early as it starts getting busy with tourists.

Endless views from new heights. Great value, small queue. Exhibits really nicely done and some great people working here that always makes things more fun! The "reveal" was great and the Citypulse gizmo and insights were informative and very cool. But the views, wow! The scale blows your mind. Plenty to see. Not too crowded, nicely done.

Must Do Experience. We arrived early for our pre booked entry to the Observatory. Although we were not kept waiting, it did seem as though those that just "rolled up" gained entry quicker than we did on our timed ticket. That aside I thought the experience was well thought out and organised. The journey to the elevator and the journey to the top provided the context for the experience and the final reveal was well set up and stunning. We did not opt to use the iPad as we had visited New York several times before and knew what we were looking at. The views from the Top are wonderful, even on a slightly gloomy day. Beware of the "selfie" generation whose quest for the perfect pictures of themselves tends to be at the expense of their fellow citizens who would also like to take a photo - but are not so obsessed with being in that picture. Patience is required. Thought the merchandise and cafe prices were a little on the high side - but that's life! A "must do" when in NYC.
Great views. Good views of NY. Went at night so lights were stunning. No really long queues so good to go at night.
Good views.. Went up at night so view was really good with My being all lit up. Hardly any queues until you want to come down.
LOOK UP TO THE SKY. Looks so big, it's in the heart of Manhattan, again: unfortunately there was no chance to get inside and on the top.
One World Trade Center. Much better experience than the Empire State building. Great view and relatively easy access to go up.
Best views in NY!. You want views, and 360d views you will get them here from the 102nd floor, simply amazing and breath taking. Much better than Top of the Rock.

The best observatory experience ever!!. The whole experience brings the observatory thing to another level. They were very fortunate in conceiving an attraction that touches the 9/11 subject without making it all about it and, therefore, giving it a merry, optimistic vibe. Afterall, the memorials are downstairs and they are great and solemn as they should be. We loved the elevators with the city building history and the nyc movie and curtains upstairs. Finally, the views are breathtaking. It is a little expensive, though, and you should book it online in advance.

Stunning ews!. From the one tower you have stunning views: the brooklyn bridge, the 9/11 memorial pools, the empire state building, etc. A must go to complete your visit to NYC. I recommend to buy tickets up front and choose a time just before sunset. If the weather turns out bad, they offer to replace the tickets for ones for another day, so don't worry.

go elsewhere for a view of NYC. My brother and mom-in-law took the ride up and were very disappointed. There were high-pressure sales pitches applied from step one (including some kind of "mandatory" photo which you could buy afterwards, gee thanks), the film was cheesy, and there was no explanation of the link to 9/11 events. They felt the commercialism cheapened the experience, and would not recommend it.

WOW don't miss this !!!!. Just visited the new tower. I was a regular visitor to the Twin Towers and was compelled to visit this new attraction and wasn't disappointed. Won't spoil the start but it's AMAZING.
1World Trade Center. This was done so professionally and the views are unbelievable. It was interesting to hear the history, what New York was like long ago and now. Get your tickets in advance.
Incredible view. We really enjoyed our trip to the top of One World Trade Center, the tallest building in the western hemisphere. The view was incredible! The only drawback was the price.

Incredible, Breathtaking Views. We get to One World and see a huge line up, however we see uniformed folks waving us over, they said do you want a specific time to go up to the observatory? We said no, can we go now? She said, yes, go through the lobby doors and you can go right up. We paid and the made our way to the elevators which is a real treat to see going up. You go up incredibly fast for how high you are going. The observation deck's and views are incredible, they have hosts telling historical stories about NYC too.

Emotional. Amazing place to visit, and the north and South pools are a sight to behold. Very emotional and overwhelming to be in such an iconic place. We went up the observation deck in the new tower, which was absolutely fantastic. We got many pictures of the sights of Manhattan and thoroughly enjoyed sitting in the bar having a drink whilst taking it all in. The lift going up is an experience to be had alone and the organisers definitely know how to take your breath away once at the top!!! It was extremely reasonable too, we paid $34 per person and it was one of our fave things to do whilst in New York. Worth every single penny to day you've done it!!

Expensive but worth it for the view. It's just awesome. Up to the 102nd floor, a fantastic surprise that will leave you gasping and then down to the 100th for a 360-degree view of the city, Statue of Liberty and beyond.

Loved it!!!. We visited this after the 9/11 museum and it turned a somber day into an amazing one. The lift is super quick and the views are amazing. Go for lunch when you get to the top, well worth it!!!!

ABSOLUTELY. Breathtaking! Be prepared to be emotional moved. And the view from the observation deck is the BEST in the world! Don't bother the rent the hand held ipads, they don't really work. But the snack shop has really good food at a reasonable price.

Awe Inspiring. If in New York you really HAVE to take the tour. A 10:00 am reservation on the 9th of September proved to be a good time. No waiting at all, we were whisked to the elevator to take us to the observation floor. The sixty second ascent gives you a through the ages development of NYC in surround type viewing on the screens/ walls of the elevator. Stepping out to the 360 degree 100th floor is like nothing you probably have ever experienced. Just looking at the city and surrounding areas from that vantage point is surreal. A short presentation by one of the staff filled us in on some interesting facts, but the view is what its all about. Just being at the scene of the tragic events that happened there left me a lump in my throat. Its something all persons should experience in their life time.

Put this high up on your things to do in New York list. I don't like heights, but was not effected at all by this trip. We booked priority tickets which I would recommend to save queueing. From the experience of the lifts to the amazing views at the top, this has to be one of the things to do during a visit to New York.

Stunning views, great experience. . We did the Empire State last year, which was great so we wanted to do One World this time. The key difference here is that the observatory was designed as part of the building rather than an add on later. We booked in advance and went straight in. Very efficient organisation and a smooth experience. Very friendly and helpful staff. The trip up in the lift is great. It doesn't really feel like it is moving and the incredible film show on the walls is really impressive. The observatory floors themselves are spacious and relaxed. The hand held device that helps identify what you can see isn't essential but it's a fun gadget and really good if you aren't familiar with the city landmarks. We went on a rainy day so we didn't get the most impressive views possible but it was still great. It's amazing being amongst the clouds and we just needed to move round to find the clear views as the clouds moved. We were up there for over an hour and really enjoyed it. The refreshments are a little disorganised but I'm guessing they will sort that out. To be honest, unless you are dying of thirst there isn't any need to spend your time getting a drink. Have one before you go up, the rest rooms are A-grade! The gift shop is nice, with some really good, high quality souvenirs and reasonably priced. We really enjoyed it, as did my parents. We would definitely recommend it and go again

Must see. The Views are incredible and its not at all crowded,definitely my favourite stop in New York this time,could have stayed up there for ever.Staff were all friendly with special mentions to the 2 guys after the elevator before seeing the views. Great experience
The new focus of the skyline. Wonderful outline from all over new York and one of the last things you see if leaving on the Queen Mary. Fits right in to the splendour of Manhattan.

48 seconds to the top!. 48 seconds from ground floor to top is an amazing ride with videos showing the changing skyline over the years. While it seems a bit odd to then exit into a wide standing theater space, you find out why after a short movie: the grand reveal of the skyline! Wow! You can then explore and roam at your leisure around the two floors that look in every direction. To avoid long waits, purchase premium access tickets online and skip all the queues. It's expensive, but on busy weekends, you will save hours of wait time.
Fantastic view and nice restaurant at the top. I much preferred this to Top of the Rock as there was minimal queuing and there was a nice restaurant at the top to enjoy the fantastic views.

Eh. The idea of going to the observatory is better than the experience. They let way too many people in at once so it's pretty crowded and hard to see out of the windows. We went at night but the reflection from the lights in the building hinder views and you can't get any decent pictures. They take you photo when you enter but it's so disorganized when you go to view and pick up your order. The observatory is entirely enclosed so you'd be better off going to other tall buildings for better views and pictures.

A bit disappointed. Coming to New York, we were really surprised to find out that the No. 1 World Trade Centre building was opened to the public. A worker outside told us how amazing it was so we decided to try it out the next day. I was really disappointed once we got to the top at how shambolic the whole organisation of it was and how it lacked any elegance. It was so touristy and a bit cheap looking inside. There were no outside open air views (unlike the Empire State Building) and before we got in I didn't like the disorganisation with people pushing the queue to get in. People were sitting all around the edge of the windows that you couldn't even take in the view.It didn't help that the staff were shouting away and not really paying attention to what was happening just trying to squash in as many people as they could in one go.The worst part was the cheesy tourist movie played, before they revealed the actual 'view'. We squashed along a row to view the movie and it didn't even have anything to do with the erection of the building itself, it was just scenes shot around New York?I was all dressed up ready for a posh meal in the lovely restaurant that was promised after, but that didn't live up to expectation and you didn't get a further spectacular view...it was already what you had shimmied past other tourist to try and take in before. There was a cheap food/canteen style restaurant and it was separated by a curtain to the more posher restaurant. After much debate with the two staff at the desk we managed to get to the more 'sophisticated' side but it wasn't that much better apart from there was a bar and a more expensive menu. The posh expensive food did actually taste quite nice but they were small portions. A shame they didn't do the restaurant up a bit nicer as I thought the exclusivity of it would have made it a popular romantic choice of restaurant. It was not the best place I had been to eat on my holiday and the Empire State building really does top the view of No 1. Sorry to be so harsh just being honest!

Amazing building -showing New York city as one of the 7 man made wonders of the world. Spectacular views. 90 degrees and clear skys on the day we visited (couple of days before 9/11/2015) meant we could see forever. The building moves/sways which is a little spooky but you soon get use to it! You get to see New York in all it's glory, and in my view the city in it's entirety is one of the seven man made wonders of the world.

Well worth doing. This was a visit I wanted to do on our second visit to NYC. On our previous visit we'd gone up the Empire State building and the new WTC was not yet complete. The trip up is quite a show with plenty of information and build up. The observatory itself, obviously, has fantastic views, although the day we went up it was a drab, wet morning. This causes problems for getting decent photos because of poor visibility, but you also get rain drops on the windows. Maybe as a result of this, there were fewer people going up so the crowds weren't too bad, but I'd definitely recommend booking in advance and going early. I didn't go for the iPad extra (which you are offered at the top) or the standard attraction photo (which is taken at the top and offered to you at the bottom) - I can see the benefits of the iPad if you want to learn more about the buildings, but for me I just wanted to see the view and take a few photos.

A good Job. My kids went and therefore I can only say what they said - they did not book in advance and did not have to wait in line which is great. They are mid teens and described clearly what they learned about 9/11 there so they have done a good job in memorializing those who were in the twin towers.
The Trade Center is Back and better.. Just to see what has arisen from the ashes is beyond description. It is amazing to view the USA resilience. What a spectacular place and the most wonderful view.
Amazing constructrion. An amazing construction well wort viewing and a visit especially in the absence of the twin towers of the World Trade Center

Don't go anywhere else for views of Manhattan!. If you are visiting New York don't bother doing the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock, come to here. The views are far superior and the entry price much cheaper. Out of the skyline, it is always One World that sticks out, high above everything else. The whole experience was great, barely any queueing and interactive parts to the visit were fantastic.Highly recommended!
need to see. Unbelievable and worth the visit. Gives you goosebumps just being there. 107 floors above ground level

Emotional Experience!. This is by far one of the hardest places I've ever visited....It is emotional and heart wrenching, but one of the best museums I've ever been to. When you go be prepared to feel many different emotions. All I can say is I am so glad I finally went. It's very hard to describe how you can feel so sad and so proud at the same time. You feel closer to people you never met and mourn for all the families who lost so much. I feel better that I went because I will never forget all those lives that were changed in a minute and I honored them by going there. It is a must see!

You must visit this observatory!. We went on a fairly overcast and rainy day, and the ticket booth advised that our view would be obstructed by clouds. We decided to take a chance and go up. The elevator ride is amazing ( but I won't spoil it for you)! We got to the observation deck, and the clouds came and went, so we really enjoyed the views. We did rent an Apple IPad which offered mini videos of numerous famous and popular sites around NYC (cost $15, we shared one IPad among our party of 3 people). The admission for adults is $32/person, but we thought it was worth every penny. Make this one of your first stops, as the view really gives you an idea of where all the city highlights are at.

Eh...just OK. . First of all, let me say the view from the top is amazing! That being said, it's one big sales pitch. From the moment you get off the elevator they are trying to get you to rent an iPad. Then at various stations throughout the observatory, there are more people trying to sell you things. One person was even talking about discounted Broadway tickets. If I wanted that I would go to Times Square. I would say just go to Top of the Rock. You will see a great view without the sales pitches.

Awesome Eye on the City. After the unique lift ride the unveiling of the view is awesome. Although unlike the Empire State there are no outside viewing areas, it is still a fantastic place to visit with stunning views.
Awesome and sad. A must visit so we never forget the reach of terrorism. The view is awesome, the museum a must do,very thorough account of that day
Tower one revisited. Do yourself a favour and go up the new tower to view New York City and Manhattan. The experience is well worth the trip

Smooth entry and circulation. The view gives good sense of Manhattan and the surrounding bodies of water. It was a little hazy during our visit but still worth it. The iPad option (for a fee) allowed us to identify buildings. The cafe and bar had great sandwiches and very good servers.

Memorable, but some flaws. Booked for a 9am visit, arrived in plenty of time but queuing system was very unclear with no-one to ask. Very quick security check. 45 second lift journey where they showed an interesting video of New York through the ages, but lift was so packed was difficult to see properly. You were then led to viewing area, with another video and then shutters lifted to reveal view - which was amazing. Guides offered an I-Pad tour for 15$, didn't take up offer. 360 degree views and when we were there it was not particularly busy, so no jostling for space to take photos. My big issue was the reflection from glass spoiling a lot of my photos

A Must Visit. This is a must visit for any New York itinerary. This is my second visit in two months. Recommendations; go online and purchase your tickets at "One World Observatory" with the appointment time of your eventual arrival. It is honored, quick and easy. No waiting in line.

Great view with better than expected food.. The view of course is why one would dine here but the food was surprisingly good too. We sat at a table near a window and the view was breathtaking. There is a limited menu but what we had was very good.

Breathtaking experience. The queue to enter the building seemed a little disorganised and as though there wasnt enough workers to co-ordinate.The lift was a great sensory experience and when the view from the observation deck was unveiled it literally took my breath away. We went up at 7.30pm and to see the city at sunset was beautiful, we stayed up there while it turned dark and spent a long time soaking up the views - beautiful.

Wonderful experience. Get your camera ready before you get in the elevator (lift) as the observatory experience starts the minute the doors slide closed! The views are amazing. You are offered the option of hiring an interactive iPad which tells you about the landmarks, but we chose to simply enjoy the views. We opted for the Priority Pass entry as I was concerned about lining up in the hot weather. It's sometimes hard to work out if paying more is worth it so my advice is if you don't mind standing in lines and you aren't time poor, just opt for General Admission. Lines for general admission start forming about 20 minutes before the timed-entry you have booked for (attendants won't let you into the line early). Priority Pass lets you in about 5 minutes before the rest of the people in your timeslot (maybe 100 or more?) which means no standing in line and an easy pass through security screening and up the elevators. All the people in your timeslot eventually end up at the top to view a multi media presentation before moving en masse through to the viewing area.

The Best View of NY!!. We visited the newly opened 1 WTC in July this year. The whole experience was beyond awesome. Considering Empire State Building was the other option to get a beautiful view of NY - THIS BEATS IT ALL! Must See, Must go up - Skip Empire state- Go here!

Take a moment. This is one place we wanted to visit I won't say a lot about it I'll let you make your own mind up about it,all I will say is when your there if your like us and I guess everyone else that visits there just take a minute or 2 to think about what happened there.
Tall and nice building. One of the best building in NYC. Visible from a long distance and it is a landmark to the city.Looks equally great at night.

Moving. More than I thought. . I wasn't sure what to expect when i visited. But the depth of the emotions you feel as you walk down further and pass over the displays and reflect on what transpired had much more impact on me than I was expecting. I spent 4hrs here and could have spent all day easily. So much to see and reflect upon. Over my 11 days in NYC this was the one thing out of all I'd recommend people go and visit.

Must see!. Well worth the ticket price. An incomparable experience!! We didn't have to wait long and the guides up top were knowledgeable and friendly. Ben and Fontaine took the time to visit with us and answer questions. All NYC visitors and residents need to experience this'

Fantastic view. Beware of the sales pitch.. I visited the One World Observatory on Labor Day weekend. I expected it to be busy so I bought tickets online. The tickets are timed and we arrived 30 minutes before and were able to get in line. The staff was friendly and gave great directions. We walked in to the building at our assigned time but it still took almost 30 minutes before we got to the view.  To get to the elevators you must travel through a fake bedrock tunnel as they describe the solid stone which they excavated to build the building. Interesting, but very cheesy. The elevator experience was worth the price. The walls of the elevator are digital screens which show New York City growing from a small village to a major city. The presentation lasts the 60 seconds it takes to get to the 103rd floor.  Once you get out of the elevator there is more waiting before you're guided into a theater for another multimedia presentation. Finally, you get a teaser view out the windows. From there, you move onto the sales pitches. First, you're lined up and encouraged to rent an iPad for $15 that will "enhance" your experience. Feel free to just walk past and continue on. Even then, you still can't get to the windows. You have to wait for the usual green-screen photo opportunity of you and your family. Feel free to bypass that, too.  After taking an elevator down one level, you're finally free to view the entire city from the top of the building. The views are spectacular and on a clear day you can see forever. Strangely, the direct North view to the Manhattan skyline is blocked by a multimedia presentation and person giving information.  After all of that, you're free to wander, eat, and shop. The elevator experience down is even better than the one going up.

Breathtaking views of New York city. If you like to watch the New York city skyline, this is the best place to do it. You can watch the cool, tall buildings and other structures of New York from the highest point in New York. You could plan a trip in the evening to see both the daytime and night time views of the city. Really cool.

Average. Fun way to spend the afternoon, but definitely an anticlimax if you've already been up the Empire State Building. You can't go outside at the observation point, you can only stand next to the windows which is disappointing. The video clips prior to the observation deck were interesting and the guides at the top floor are great.

Beautiful but Sad . It's a beautiful building but sad for all the live that where lost on 09/11/2001. It make you cry when u see it, know that so many lives where lost on that day. If ur in New York City go and see the new World Trade Center.

Bit like a cattle mart. The views were great and the building was a marvel but I spent half my time being shuttled from one queue/holding pen to another, which was very, very annoying. Probably wouldn't got back on that account. Souvenirs were very expensive. Top of the Rock was much better.

Awesome. Definitely worth the money going up to the 102nd floor. The view is 360 degrees awe inspiring . Staff is at hand to answer any questions you might have . There is a cafe and a restaurant there too, but we did not try it since you were only able to sit down if you ordered a full lunch.
Holy Cow!. Having been to the Empire State Building, I wasn't expecting all that much. The multi-media show that led to the screens being raised to unveil the view was fantastic.
Get with the New York pass!. Wouldn't allow us to enter using our New York pass, which was extremely disappointing given we made the trip especially to do this.
Spectacular Views. Great views, brought back memories from out tower but time moves on...I bought an open pass which was more expensive but allowed me to go up anytime and bypass the queues

The Best View. This place has to be the best place out there for the NYC view. Make sure your phones are fully charged because you would want to capture the 360 deg view. A nice camera would be ideal for this place :)

ON TOP OF THE WORLD!. We'll, not really. Not the highest place in the world, but a triumph over tragedy in New York. Best time to book it--1/2 hour before sunset. Go around the deck & see sunset. Then go get a drink & appetizer in the nice (--not cafeteria) section/lounge (tater tots were good). I said "a" drink, because they are PRICEY--but it is New York. Relax for awhile & take in the view as New York switches from daytime to night time, with its accompanying light show. There are some neat high tech gizmos you may want to try. My favorite is the scenes of the history of New York in one minute on the panels of the elevator going up. Zooms up so quickly & quietly that you will not notice that you are moving.

great views, weird atmosphere. after five queues and $32 per adult you exit the elevator on 102nd floor where a timelapse video of manhattan's development is shown before the curtains rise and unveil stunning views of manhattan, making people cheer in awe. you then descend to a floor with 360 degree panoramic windows that allow you to take in the whole city and neighbouring borroughs (on clear days i guess). so yes, the views are great but if you are just a little sensitive to atmospheres and energies, you can't help but feel a little creeped out remembering the terrible events that have taken place here which is why i personally would recommend visiting Rockefeller Tower's Top of the Rock observation deck because they have an outdoor observatory deck overlooking central park and manhattan and the whole atmosphere is more fun.

Amazing. This is a breathtaking building and the views are just as good. This has now got to be the best viewing platform in Manhattan taking over from the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock. The only issue is the steep $15 charge (additional to your ticket) to rent an iPad to show you what buildings you are looking at as you move around the building. Please note that this optional extra is sold to you once you get to the top of the building and NOT offered as part of the ticketing structure. Maybe if the charge wouldn't have been so steep or included as a package at the ticket office I may have opted for this. Nevertheless the view is still amazing!
A must do. Omg....what an amazing experience, breath taking views, tour is put together very well. Bar and restraunt are very nice although quite expensive.

One World Observatory: on top of the world Ma!. Went around Labor Day weekend on a Sunday. The 32 dollar entrance fee (discounts available for seniors and children) can be paid on line to save time. We booked the 3p time block and the queue was fast once you go in through the dedicated entrance. Expect to have your personal bags inspected. No food or open container is allowed because there's a restaurant at the observatory. You get to wind down to the basement or bedrock to board the state of the art elevator. Each car can hold ten to fifteen passengers. The opposite walls are lined with HD TV panels which together simulate the outside changing views at each timeline. The high speed elevator whisk you in around a minute. You hardly ever notice it.From the 102 floor you get to a chamber where they project multimedia presentations of New York City. When it ends, well you just get chills as they unveil the vista. Then your free to roam about the perimeter with your camera, binoculars, and friends. What ever you do don't go alone. It's fun with a group and families.Protip: get zoom binoculars that can take pictures. You can see Newark planes take off or cruise ships dock at the piers.

Choose a fine afternoon for great views.. Visited last Thursday at around 4pm. Didn't book ahead as we weren't sure when we would get around to visiting, with so much to see on our first visit to NYC. No queue! Straight in and onto the lift with ease. The ascent to the top in under 60 secs was amazing with visual displays around the inside of the elevator as we rose - all the more enjoyable as the elevator was far from packed. Views from the top were fantastic - no need to pay the extra 15 dollars for an iPad to spot the sights if you have got the feel of New York for a few days. Good and gift shop expensive but no obligation to buy. Good experience. Recommend not booking at this time of year and just choosing a fine day, later in the day, as this worked well for us.
Stands out!!!. Beautifully built, specially looks spectacular at night. Didn't go up as the tickets were too expensive and had already gone up on empire state to see the skyline.

Fabulour lofty experience.. Well worth it. Wonderful experience riding up to the 102nd-floor observatory. A real thrill. Weather permitting, go at dusk, see the sun set, linger for the Manhattan lights to start turning on. Great show.

We got engaged on the 101st floor!. I had hoped for a blue sky day and my wish came true. It was a truly unforgettable experience asking Anne to marry me while overlooking the city I was born in and love so much. Big surprise was an incredible crowd who warmed our hearts with love as they cheered our special moment :)

A must-see. No doubt about it!. You should get tickets online. They are timed tickets so there is never a huge line to get in. Very orderly and moves quickly through security. The elevator ride alone could be a reason for visiting; a 30 second (or so) ride 103 floors up while projections fill all four sides depicting the changing landscape over 200 or so years in all for directions. Amazing!!! Then you get to the top and the elevator doors open where you watch a brief and nicely editing montage video of scenery of "New York." When that ends the curtain rises and the "real" New York view is revealed. The 360 degree walk-around floor allows you to see off in every direction and over the memory pools of the memorial. It took over 10 years but it's a remarkable tribute -- both inside and out.

Well worth visiting. Amazing a must visit, thought provoking and uplifting at the same time. A real life Phoenix rising from the ashes and a testing to the people who lost their lives on 911, the emergency services involved on that fateful day and the city of NY. Much respect.

Awesome design -fitting for its legacy!. This place is pretty breath - taking I must say! From the elevator only taking 4 seconds and the video experience in the elevator alone was stunning!Once up their the views are incredible all around in every directions and this guy doing the city buzz experience was great too.$32 but money well spent!

Beautiful building. Loved this building although I didn't go up. It has a nice view from the Empire State building (another expensive-yet-must visit). You can see the sky reflected in the whole building

45 seconds from ground floor to the 102nd floor. We went down to ground zero to visit this beautiful building. We started with a 2 minute video presentation and then we walked around seeing a 360 degree view of the view. It was a very special place to visit
Sooo Tall!. One World Trade Center is the hallmark of downtown NYC. I haven't been in the building since it opened for viewings however I have heard from friends that the views are also amazing.

For a family to expensive to go up. Standing in front of One WTC I was deeply impressed by the magnitude and beauty of it. Impressed by the next door amazing monument and museum dedicated to the fallen and the heroes. Unfortunately to go up one has to pay a fortune. Knowing this will only last a few minutes it is too expensive. Why don't they sell familytickets?

Booked tickets online, no queuing, very enjoyable.. Nearest train stops for this attraction are: World Trade Centre E, Cortlandt St R, or PATH train line if you are coming from New Jersey.I booked our tickets online using Mastercard Priceless Cities discount offer. We arrived and were sent straight down the escalators and into security, very quick and efficient – no queueing at all for us. It said on our online booking that we needed to print out the tickets, but after checking this is actually incorrect. If you can load them on a mobile device, they can scan them straight off of the screen.Security was quick and easy and the lift journey to the top was very quick! We went at 7pm hoping to get views of a nice sunset. I was not disappointed with the views and managed to get some great photos. I was slightly disappointed at the number of smears on the glass from tourists. They would have done well to have someone cleaning the windows more regularly. There were regular speakers talking from the south point of the viewing deck. It was very interesting hearing what they had to say about the city, the views and the history.The observatory was not too crowded when we visited, and we got good opportunity to view all sides of the city. There was quite a large queue to go back down (similar to The Shard, London, or the Eiffel Tower, Paris – if you have been, you know what I mean), but it was quickly and efficiently managed. It is a family friendly attraction, I would certainly visit again. Closely located to the 911 Museum which I would highly recommend visiting.

beautiful experience. This was beautiful experience. It was my first time after 9/11. Made me sad just walking around this area. The flowers around the names and everybody with the same look like just remembering everything. But would have not skip the tour. Just love to see how everything looks now. Looking from down up looks like a triangle building nice effect it has.

STUNNING. This was one of our main highlights of our new york trip. What a veiw, fantistic lift up to the observatory, the job done here, as well as the museum,is a real testament to those who were so brutally murdered on that day.The whole experience will live long in the memory.Dont pass this by on your new york trip underr any circumstances!!
Modern to the Max!. The area surrounding One World Observatory is solemn. The tower itself is a work of art. The views are magnificent. Food and drink at the top are expensive!

Top of the Workd. Well worth the price to see the views of the city and beyond. On a clear day you can literally see forever. The elevator ride is smooth and extremely quick with no sense of movement. Allow at least 30 minutes or more to see all there is from the observatory level.

Great alternative to ESB. Outstanding experience and views to match...great to get a different perspective on Manhattan & surrounding boroughs than from the traditional midtown venues. You don't go outside as you do at the ESB but the more spacious environment makes for an altogether more pleasurable experience. Great map of world on entry that shows from where each new visitor is from when tickets are scanned...just a shame you can't see you own entry as part of the process.Will definitely return.

Creative exhibit in the elevators and a great view of lower Manhattan. The building itself is stunning from the outside. The elevator takes 50 seconds to go up 100 floors and there is a really creative interactive display in the elevator, both on the way up and on the way down. There are great views of Ellis Island and the Brooklyn Bridge and the Empire State Building, but you can't see Central Park from this location. It was difficult taking photos of the views from the windows because all the windows are grubby and smeared, and there are reflections from all the tourists inside the building onto the glass.
One World Trade Centre Memorial. Very moving and emotional visit at the One World Trade Centre...I was very moved when I saw the names of those who lost their lives on that fateful day...

Give it a miss. Same price & similar height to the magnificent queen of the Skyscrapers - The Empire State Building. But that's where the similarity ends. Your view is from behind glass so expect your reflection in photos. And that's if you can get close to the windows past all the visitors sitting on the aircon grills taking advantage of free wifi to catch up on Facebook. Oh, and unlike ESB, who give them for free, you have to pay $15 extra for an electronic guide. If you already have ESB & TOTR covered on your NY city pass then truly do not bother with One World...
Best view of Manhattan!. Best view in town of Manhattan and surrounds!!! You're on the 102nd floor with unobstructed views of NYC!!

Well worth your time. The experience begins when you walk up to the building due to its size and the work sill going on around it. Without giving anything away the ride up and down to get to the observation deck is all part of the experience. I did not pay to rent an I pad that would identify landmarks you were looking at out the window. If I were to do it again I think I would take advantage of that. Enjoy the experience and remember what took place there.

A beautiful place. Booked tickets for 11am and took the subway from Times Square to chambers street. A very easy route and only took 5 minutes.We came last year to the 911 memorial and really wanted to see this this year. Directions to the world trade centre took you down to the trains and we were a little confused, but we did get to see inside the new centre which looks amazing. Finally found the entrance and was directed up the escalators and outside to wait to be called ! When we were waiting we realised we didn't need to go inside or follow the signs at all as we were right back where we started !! Think the signs need to be corrected. Unless they want you to see the new building!?!Once in you walk about the bottom section watching a film which is really interesting. Then you take a lift up to the observation deck which takes 60 seconds! Whilst in the lift and film is played which is brilliant .!I won't give it all away but it's pretty amazing. The views are awesome and I found it quite emotional too. Sadly it was a bit hazy so the views were not that great but it was still an amazing experience and had to be done.

Fabulous views. We decided to visit here as on previous visits to New York we have been to the Top of the Rock and the Empire State Building, so we decided this time to visit One World Trade Centre, you walk through an area that has a film of people saying how they felt working on the construction etc. Then you go up in the lift to the 102nd floor, as you ascend in about 60 seconds it shows you how New York has evolved over the years all around you.Once you reach the 102nd floor you watch a montage of New York and it's people, then the screen shoots up and you have a wonderful view of Manhattan. You then go down to the observatory on the 100th floor which gives you 360 degree views.There is a cafe and gift shop at the top, plenty of space to move around, all staff very pleasant, we visited on a Tuesday at about 6.15pm and we walked straight in, no wait.Definitely well worth a visit.

Wonderful Experience. Everyone who goes to NYC needs to visit the World Trade Center Memorial. We did not visit the museum, but only spent time honoring the victims by walking around the memorials and quietly contemplating the magnitude of this event. It is an amazing tribute to the many who were effected. There are so many locals around to share stories. We took a Bike tour here through Bike n Roll. Our guide Bob was wonderful in sharing his thoughts and knowledge. Would recommend it!

Wow! This amazing building gives you a view of New York City like nothing else. From the outside this is an impressive building but wait till you are at the top. The elevator ride is smooth and has awesome views of New York City projected on screens around each side of the elevator. As you ascend each level you see corresponding views of the surrounding area. Once off the elevator you are taken into a room where once again the technology is amazing with views of the city. Finally the projected views disappear and you are looking at the expanse of the city in real time. Amazing! The site allows you to walk 360 degrees around to see all that New York offers but seen from the tallest building. There are knowledgeable staff available in this area should you have questions about what you are seeing. This floor also has a small gift shop. The ride down is even more exciting, taking seconds to descend. A must see and a tribute to New Yorkers.

Best Skyline View in Manhattan.. This may be my new favorite place to see the city from above. Very high tech and the lines go fast! Be sure to check out the 9/11 museum and memorial while you're there!

On top of the world!. My girlfriend, some friends and I went on a clear Sunday afternoon. We showed up around 2:15 and had tickets for 2pm, so we stood in the stand-by line for a little bit, but were inside quickly enough. When you first go in, you actually go down 1-2 stories to get through security.The fun begins right with the elevators going up. On the 3 non-door walls of the elevator are big displays. As you go up, they play a CGI time-lapse of the view around Manhattan and the surrounding area. Your ears will pop since you're going up ~1000 ft in about 60 seconds. Then you are ushered in to another long room with more displays. A 2 minute or so collage plays showing different aspects of NYC, and at the end there is quite the finale (I don't want to ruin in for people who don't know what it is).You end up going down 1 floor to do the actual walking around, but the views are spectacular! There are big direction letters in the group to give you some orientation (N, E, S, W). The circular displays were acting up when we visited, so they probably have some bugs to work out, but the idea is neat. It was fun to watch planes and helicopters flying below you since you're so high up. You can see everything from the Statue of Liberty to the Empire State building and the surrounding tri-state area.A lot of the gift shop stuff is over-priced but worth looking at to see if anything catches your eye. The food at the cafe was over-priced as well but was to be expected ($5 for a bottle of water). The food quality however was good, and had a decent variety of offerings.Although you have to enter at a certain time, you are not required to leave at a certain time. We spent around 2 hours wandering around and eating, but when we were leaving our keepsake photo wasn't ready (it was digital, not sure of the hold up). We spent about another 10 minutes waiting for them to try to get our photo (the couple we went with didn't have to wait at all). Even with the wait, they would not reduce the price at all, and we didn't like the photo itself, so we opted to not buy it.

Awesome. Really glad I pre booked the tickets and paid a little extra so that we could go any time on a set day. Having the tickets in advance meant we could bypass the long queues and go straight to the elevators. There is a small film show with an awesome end ( I won't spoil it) and then you go down to the 102 floor for the panoramic views of the NYC skyline. I hired two of the interactive IPads that were supposed to give you info on what you was actually looking at at any given time. However, these didn't work properly and had to keep being recalibrate. I wouldn't bother with those if I ever went again.

Great City Views. This is new as of 2015. Great city views of New York. There's also an tablet that is available for a fee that allows you to pinpoint many buildings. There's a gift shop, bar and café inside also.

Go up the Freedom Tower. The Freedom Tower was inaugurated May, 29, 2015 and It is a beautiful experience. Even at the moment you step on the elevator, you know it's worth the money. Best place to admire New York City.
Moving place. The developers worked really hard to bring buildings back to the sight of a huge tragedy. Thinking about all of the people there is an emotional thing. Bring tissues.

One World Trade. Wow! What a view from the top, once you get through the "Disney" type hype it was great and we were lucky enough to be there on a non busy day, walked right in. How Manhattan is growing and you can really see it from the "top of the world"!

Amazing Views, Unbelievable!. One World Observatory was easily the highlight of our NYC trip. The elevator up to the observatory was awesome, as you were surrounded by screens that displayed a virtual timeline of the NYC skyline. Once you get to the top, prepare to be amazed! We got there right when the sun was coming down, and it was simply breathtaking! To see all of the recognizable NYC landmarks from such an elevation was awe inspiring.

very emotional. i was in the World Trade center in July of 2001. Went to the observation deck......seen people working in the Kiosks there. Going back was something I had to do.....knowing most of those people I saw working that day were dead. I said my prayers for them when i went to the Memorial.

Beautiful views - go on a clear day. It's a bit expensive, but you got to go. It's completely touristy, too. I would suggest you do the 9/11 Memorial Museum first. It a bit of a production to actually get to the windows to view the city.

Well worth the price. My wife and I left the 911 Museum and walked next door to One World. We purchased our tickets ahead of time which allowed us to walk right in, no waiting. I would recommend this, especially on weekends. The visibility, the afternoon we were there, was around 12 miles so we got a good view of NYC. It is an impressive view plus the ride up the elevator and the presentation when you arrive at the observatory add to the experience. We didn't, but you can rent a tablet in the observatory to assist you in identifying buildings, bridges, islands, etc. I think the cost was $15. We wanted to take the subway, for $2.75, the E line will drop you off a couple blocks from the building. One World and the 911 Museum are a "Must See".

A little expensive for the experience, but still nice. Waiting in the ridiculously long line outside in the summer heat was enough to make me want to turn away, but I'm glad we stayed. We had purchased tickets in advance, but it still took a while to get up to the top. Once you get in the elevator, be prepared for a wonderful surprise! It's a time lapse of the development of Manhattan, and it was VERY cool! Once you get to the top, grab lunch at the sit down restaurant if you get a chance. I never got to experience Windows On The World, so I wanted to get as close as I could to that experience. It's a little pricey, but the food and service was great! The observatory is all indoors, but it has a nice atmosphere. I wish it were a little more interactive (because the elevator was the coolest thing ever!), but overall, the view was obviously spectacular and we really enjoyed the experience.

Breathtaking!. We had planned to visit the reflecting pools but arrived early enough to avoid the line up to the One Observatory. It was spectacular. Breath-taking views of the city and a testament to the resilience of the American people.
Amazing, very sentimental. Go to New York, you cannot miss this experience no poignant. Not as quiet as Inwas told it would be, but still very respectful.
Can see forever. Went at night beautiful views would love to do again during the day. Bought advance tickets made access simple not much waiting.

Only average. This is a stunning building to look at from the outside but I wouldn't choose to visit again. We booked tickets online well in advance as our youngest son wanted to visit the tallest building in New York. We arrived on time and had to queue outside in the blazing sun with no shade. We then had to queue again once inside and to be honest by the time we got to the top of the building we were extremely fed up and just wanted to get out, for which we again had to queue. The view is no different than from any other skyscraper and I would choose the Empire State anytime, particularly as all photos had to be taken through glass, unlike the Empire State were you are outside. In addition two soft drinks and two waters at the top of the building were $20+. Not something we would choose to repeat.
Magnificent building and view. The elevator ride is just beautiful and when when you reach the top you can see the city from all sides words can't describe the venue must be seen.

One and done.. I'm going to make this short because it's a special place but these things need to be addressed:-horrible line organization outside-lack of security for anyone going up-the process takes way too long even if you pre-booked your time-they're too busy trying to sell you stuff, like it's Disney World or something-too many lines, one after another after another We did it, but I'd never do it again. Fortunately, you're able to go back down whenever you're ready. I only lasted 10 minutes, it's a pretty view but chaotic and unsettling.
Touching. Considering all the History involved it's a must. The attraction itself is very well planned. and the first stage of the visit has an unforgetable grand finale.

'We're running 30 minutes late'. Do Top of the Rock instead. The tower is beautiful, and the view really is unbeatable. But the experience is disappointing. We bought our tickets online, which saved no time, because there is no wait at the box office. We arrived 30 minutes early with nowhere to wait — you only start lining up when your time is called. And as they were about 45 minutes late, we were just standing around for more than an hour. It's another 15-30 minutes before you get inside the elevator, so now we've been here a bit under two hours just standing in line. Meanwhile, anyone who arrived late got pushed right to the front of the line. So the lesson is, buy your tickets for early, then show up whenever. The elevator is a very cool ride up, but you are forced to sit through a Disneyfied video with a cheesy 'a-ha!' moment at the end before you can see the view. The glass is filthy with fingerprints. And, to top it off, they block your cell service once you enter the tower. The only way to text, share photos, whatever, is by paying $20 for a wireless pass, as though the tickets aren't overpriced as is. And expect long lines getting out. Do Top of the Rock instead.

Fabulous. A must if visiting New York ,fabulous views and great experience .From entering the lifts ,with a projected film on the way up to stepping out of the lift and watching a short film before the views are revealed found the whole experience amazing.The staff at the top are very helpful and a good talk was given by a lady and man that was very interesting (although not compulsory ) and gave a good insight into the different areas of New York .

A totally new experience from the other 2. In 2009, we did the Top of the Rock and Empire State Building. This time around, we swapped out the former for One World Observatory instead. We pre-booked for Wednesday morning and made our way there on the Subway from our hotel near Times Square. The nearest subway stop was Cortlandt Street, however because of the different entrances to the station, it was a bit difficult to find at first (but not as hard as finding the Transit Museum in Brooklyn). Once through security, there is a large screen that shows how many visitors are showing up at One World Observatory that day, how many international, which international country the most visitors are coming from, etc. Then you pass through an area on the foundations the center is built upon. Next is the simulated elevator ride up (going up, it recreates the formation of Manhattan from when the island was nothing but greenery whereas going down, it represents a spiral down from the top of the tower and back into the base and starting point). Beyond the elevator is a short presentation (mostly just showing parts of New York) that opens and reveals the view. Then you exit out to the main deck. Don't bother about the virtual iPad that they were selling since not only is the fee steep, but also it is better to just focus on the actual view rather than the virtual one on the screen (which there were lots of people using) unless you are a first time visitor to New York. Anyways, the views are quite different than the ones from Top of the Rock and Empire State Building since you are a lot closer to the water. You have views looking down on the Statue of Liberty, Jersey City, the Fulton area (around City Hall) and lower Manhattan and in addition to having the Empire State Building in the view, all three of the major airports are also visible from this deck. Viewing over Manhattan Harbor, all of the boat and ferry traffic and numerous helicopters can be seen down below along with the cruise ships (Queen Mary 2 was in port at Brooklyn that day) and the cargo ships that come in and out. All of the bridges are clearly visible from this deck (though the Queensborough Bridge is only partially visible to the north. Other than the views, there is also the SkyPortal which is a virtual screen (similar to a glass floor) that has an aerial view of the traffic that is moving down below. After the observation deck and gift shop, it is back to the elevator heading down and back out again. If you have the time, don't forget Wall Street (where you can see the Stock Exchange building and some of the other historic financial related structures) and the Staten Island Ferry (where you can get great views of the harbor, Statue of Liberty and container ports all without paying a fee) both of which are in the same area.
Beautiful!. Another must see. Stunning piece of architecture. The location offers much to see with Wall Street near by.

Expensive but worth it. Visited Friday 14th August having pre booked online. The area around the new building is beautiful, the way they’ve handled the 2 memorials is profoundly moving and it really gives you a sense of scale and perspective when you see the size of the footprints and the names of the victims around the sides.The observatory itself is a fantastic (if expensive) experience. You enter through a fairly stringent security check point where you follow a staged underground passage simulating the bedrock on which all the Manhattan skyscrapers are built. The lift to the top is an experience in itself as it simulates the growth of New York from the early settler’s through the early skyscrapers up to present day. At the top you watch a presentation about New York projected onto what you think is a wall but it’s really a screen which lifts slowly to reveal the view to midtown. It’s brilliantly handled and it really takes your breath away. After that you’re free to explore on your own; there’s a regular presentation but the real star is the view. We were lucky as it was a crystal clear summer day with the perfect azure blue sky. Seeing the whole of the New York area literally at your feet is an amazing experience and it gives you a genuine feel for the scale of the place.It is expensive but I’d say no visit to New York would be complete without a visit here.

Busy day. Good job we booked online still probably 45 mins to get in but a great attraction with as promised great views, would be better on a quieter day, Labour Day weekend was the issue otherwise great

Tarnished by obnoxious staff. Pros: probably the best views in NYC, well designed queueing area inside, interesting lift "experience"Cons: terrible, terrible attitude on the staff manning the queues outside (although it was Labor Day weekend and so extremely busy), booked online but still took an hour of queueing, have to walk through sales areas (guides and photos) before getting to the viewing platform, extortionate food/drink options, reflection on the glass in the sunCocnlusion: the views were just about worth the ordeal to get up to the top

Amazing views, if a bit expensive.. Firstly, the views are incredible. full three sixty views around NY that will take your breath away. $55 (priority access) seems quite steep, but the views are so good it wouldn't stop me paying it again. Went on a Monday at 5pm and it wasn't that busy. Plenty of space by the windows to look out. Also ate at the restaurant, which is ok, but again expensive. Find dining prices ($84/pp for 4 courses) for not quite fine dining quality, and sat on a mezzanine level with the observatory below so lost of noise and announcements. In hindsight we would happily have just gone up to the observatory and then gone elsewhere for dinner.
Still amazing in poor weather. We went up the tower on a zero visibility day and it was still an amazing experience. I could not imagine what it would be like on a full visibility day.

Cannot be missed - essential visit. We decided to visit early to avoid the queues, which worked really well. The downside was that there was a heat haze which obscured the view.
