Incredible!. My son, my 11 year old grandson, and I thought this building and all of the views were incredible. We could have spent the whole day just looking out at all of the city! Very well organized. No lines at all.We all enjoyed this!

It's like going to space!. I don't want to spoil all the cool thing this new observation deck offers, that's I'll just say that it's nothing you have seen before. This attraction is very modern and state-of-the-art. They try to amaze their guest from already first seconds after you entered. And watching the city from above is like watching it from the window of a plane when it is descending to land in NYC. Amazing experience and totally worth the money for it! P.S. We visited in the beginning of August and came inside at 7.30 PM to catch the city before sunset, the sunset itself and the night illumination.

Go early, stay as long as you can. Miracles can happen.. The elevator alone is worth the price of admission. Enter 15th century past and rise to 2015 as the surroundings change around you. You are in a time machine! Once at the top, the view is miles and miles of all around 360 degrees. It was a clear day and I got great photos. Go down and ride the elevator again!

See Forever . With such a massive meaning to the American people this is a no brainer. Having visited many observation towers in the past this by far beats them all. Once out of the lift and the first surprise is a video of NYC history and the huge reveal which must be seen. Words can not describe the feeling you get when this happens. If I was to say anymore I'd spoil it. If your in NYC, don't leave without visiting One World Observatory.

seren place in the middle of the city. what a place .beautiful serene and at the same time so sad.... this is a place that everyone should see so they know how special is this land we live on...and how short life really is...
Beautiful!. It is a beautiful building. The architecture is miraculous! I look forward to going into it on my next trip!

One World Observatory - You Need to Get Your Act Together. Bought a priority ticket at $54 ($9 cheaper than a priority ticket for the Empire State Building) for Sat 8 August. So, that got us past a few of the lines, however, once you pass security, there is no one to guide you to the priority line for the elevator to the Observatory. In fact, generally there is a huge shortage of staff around to answer questions and guide you - BIG MISTAKE.We got to the Observatory and made our way to One Dine, where we had a reservation. Got a nice table. But a few things need to be improved with One Dine. The menu is too limited, if you are allergic to a few ingredients, you have no choice. A few more choices would not hurt. Our waiter did accommodate our wishes by offering alternatives, so it all turned out OK. As for the noise, the ridiculous circle thing right below the restaurant is unnecessarily loud and obnoxious, although if you are seated at the back in the booths, it's less obtrusive. The food was OK, the steak pretty good, but I can't help thinking that brasserie style food would be better, rather than the pretence at fine dining?Having spent the best part of $600 on dinner and a further $54 each on priority service, we were expecting some sort of priority treatment to get us back down again. But NO! We had to wait with everyone else, unlike the Empire State Building where the priority ticket gets you up and down in double quick time. I know it's not all about money, but if you do spend more than the average punter, you expect a little more! We joined the enormous line and were struck by the fact that in a throng of at least 500-700 people there was only one member of staff. Now, given what this building is and what happened to its predecessors, it would have been useful and reassuring to have several more members of staff on a busy Saturday evening. I would be interested to know how often evacuation drills are practiced?!? It didn't help that two of the elevators were closed for a private function - in which case, they should have limited the number of paying guests that wanted to come up to the Observatory. A whole lot of people will be left with a memory of a slow-moving line to descend, rather than the great views. In addition, there was a poor lady in a wheelchair having to wait in the line too - again, the Empire State Building gives disabled people priority for the price of a normal ticket.Now, the views are great, but they are obstructed by the construction of the building, or the reflections of all that is going on inside, so it's difficult to get a nice clear view/shot. Why didn't they use non-reflective glass and why no outside observation deck? Overall, it was pretty underwhelming and I believe the Empire State Building offers a much pleasanter experience...I was really looking forward to the whole evening, having visited the Memorial Garden dozens of times and spent hours in the fantastic 9/11 Museum. On the positive side, many of these things can be improved and it is early days, so let's see.

The best view ever!. What to say for this amazing tower! It is the highest tower in new York, recently build with a 360° open view in the whole manhattan. Very friendly personnel, a wonderful rooftop restaurant where you can enjoy a nice drink or meal. If you are a holder of a mastercard credit card, you have priority in the queue and you can go at the time you arrive upstairs. A wonderful experience even though the elevator that will take you to the top of the world. Don't miss it!

Observation floor is amazing!. long line to buy tickets on site. Go to web and buy there.. Show the app and walk right in... cafe and restaurant inside are nothing to speak of and very small... Plan eats elsewhere.. view was amazing..

Sky has not limit!!!. I have visited the top of the highest building in the west world (541m) and the second in the wolrd after the burj Khalifa.*very import you: if you the tickets with Mastercard you have vip instant access at any time you want, without need to wait.The view is spectacular, you can see all the New York. You can rent an iPad that you could learn about all these huge buildings in manhattan (cost 15$).It is more beautiful the view than empire's state building because the "One world" is in the south side and you can see better the central manhattan (midtown), and the Booklyn bridge. Also is very good the view to the elis island and the statue if liberty.Best expirience is the elevator that you can enjoy a marvellous video on the walls about the history of this area of new York from the 1600 (I remember) till now. And all this in only 1 min.....that is the time to go from the 0 to 102 floor....My advice is visit absolutely the "One World".Enjoy

Wonderful view from the top, but overpriced and long queue if no fast pass ticket. Beautiful design, modern interior, incredible view from the top where you could stay for hours. The restaurant up there is good, too, but no chairs around the tables. We had the fast pass, which was really good because the queue can last up to 2-3 hours until you get up. But the entrance fee, even without fast pass, is an insolence. People come here from all around the world and they pay for it, because everyone wants to see what happened here after 911. But it's definitely overpriced!!!

Astonishing view and state of the art presentation. Expect your wildest elevator experience ever!
The view is excellent as you are 100-200 meters above all other skyscrapers.
They will offer you to rent an ipad with some basic information of the view. I will not recommend this - it's too basic and you will find that you know it all already.
Buy tickets online to avoid the queue!

NYC views. The entry process is very smooth and the group sizes aren't too large which is great. The detail provided about the building process is very good. I did not like that the two exhibitions were both in spots where they blocked the best views of the city, seems bizarre. I understand that the layout can't change but there are also thick pylons at windows

Very emotional abd breathtaking!. The elevator movie is incredible and sad at the same time. Seeing the towers and then them being gone was very sad. Then you walk into a room and watch another movie, but the ending is amazing! Great views!

Make sure you save money and visit the Top of the Rock. Don't get me wrong, this observatory provides wonderful view of downtown Manhattan and Status of Liberty. But for someone like me, I have visited the Empire State building, Top of the Rock and today One World Observatory, I have to say, Top of the Rock is the best of the best! You can feel the mid town Manhattan vibe and the crowded skyscrapers nowhere else can provide. One World has long line and some unnecessary wait and presentation when you wait. The whole observatory is inside which means your picture reflects a lot of inside image. It's almost impossible to get a wonderful portrait picture like the one you can take at Top of the Rock which gives full outside natural light. If you are first time visitor, no matter where you go, the view will be wonderful. But if you want to pick and choose and get the best experience, try Top of the Rock. The only thumbs up for One World is its easy Restroom facility and elevator ride. I am not affiliated to any places. Just someone who has been living and working in Manhattan for a decade and been to all these touristy places.

Awesome.... But!. It was an awesome visit. I managed to get there, first thing on a Saturday morning, without having any huge crowds. Most of the staff were courtesy and friendly.My only issue, is with the design of the observation deck. They should have angled the glass, so that glare is reduced, from the inside and outside. It's next to impossible to take a good picture on the sunny side.

top-notch :) First thing to do in NYC!!. I will not describe in detail since you may better be very pleasantly surprised like we were!! Does it sound persuasive if I say that after visiting One World Observatory I promised myself to take with me to NYC (from Europe) my mom and one other special person once again ...just to see THIS? Perfectly organised, made with passion and pride. A big positive surprise for me, including a very nice, smiley and skilled staff. Thanks to great organising, almost no lines to wait...Out of all the well-known tops of the roofs in NYC (Empire State, Rockefeller etc) I would do this one definitely FIRST. Go best 1 hour before sunset if you can afford to stay 2 hours...so you would see the city during the day and also during the night. Take there one iPad with great audio-video app per small group of family of friends (for 15 USD), it's definitely worth it. I just would add (in the app) even more sightseeings described in some parts of the city (the only super minor comment to make it even better). Many thanks for this experience.
Astonishing. Barely few words to describe the sensation and the view, it is just incredible. The tower is superb and shines from dawn till sunset, you will never forget this experience.
Freedom Tower. The elevator ride is worth every dime. Buy tickets ahead of time so that you don't have to wait. the view of course is amazing, even on an overcast day.

Impressive building. We didn't go inside (not sure if that is possible either) as when we visited it was still under construction. However, was super impressed with its height and architectural style, a beautiful sky-scraper that stands out in NYC's skyline.
Worth the time and the trip.. An amazing structure and one to see to heighten the patriot in all of us. Try to go early as the crowds swell after noon.

In one word..."fantastic". Was at the memorial garden 3 years ago and can not believe the change. Worth every penny spent to visit this fantastic place. Did the Empire State and the staff were rude and you were herded like cattle round the attraction... Staff could do with some serious customer service training.The One world was the exact opposite with friendly chatty staff and a relaxed and pleasant atmosphere.I am I total awe of how something so fantastic can be built out of situation that changed the world. Respect!!

Go to Top of the Rock instead. The view is beautiful, and when they open the screens to give you the first view, it really is breathtaking. That being said, Top of the Rock was always my go to, and that hasn't changed. Because One World is so far south, you do get a great view of the Brooklyn Bridge, but you miss out on Central Park, and all the amazing midtown buildings (the empire state and Chrysler were quite far). Because the entire thing is encased in glass, photos can be quite difficult, due to reflection. The fake bedrock that you walk through at the bottom was really tacky, and I took issue with the giant gift shop that takes up most of the observation floor. I understand it is a tourist stop, but the complete lack of reference or acknowledgement of the twin towers didn't feel right in my gut, and I don't think it would have hurt putting the gift shop on the way out. The elevator ride was cool re: the time lapse of Manhattan, though I wish the top was glass so you could have the choice of seeing the speed in which you move.

Spectacular but not the best tall view. 45 seconds in the lift makes you feel you are on a ship at sea for a few minutes. The screens clear to give you a stunning view of NYC. However you are completely sealed behind glass. No matter how clean they attempt to keep the glass clean the view is tainted by the glass. You simply cannot take the best photos through glass. Also coupled with the NYC smoggy haze I must admit I was a bit disappointed...Try the unobstructed views of the ESB or even better Top of the Rock....Also there is a cicular disc you can walk across to see the traffic beneath your feet. However the view is a bit naff and is clealy simply a projected view...Sorry to sound a bit negative..The WTC is still a must to visit. However my stand out favourite was Top of the Rock.

Beautiful building but sad memories. Beautiful building but would have rather seen the original buildings in it's place. The events that took place at this location were devastating and just bring back terrible memories.
world trade center memorial. Awesome experience...recommend everyone see the exhibits...allow 3 to 4 hours to immerse yourself in about 50 percent of what there is to see

Elevator show is great.. Not a long wait to access the tower (unlike Rockefeller and Empire). Excellent AV videos for the elevator ride up and down. Can rent a tablet that gives spatial tour guide of the surrounding skyline and buildings once you're at the top. View from the windows is great with full 360 degree access. After visiting the tower head over to the mall (Westfield World Trade Center) for food and shopping.
Wonderful. The freedom tower is like the twin towers in one. This beautiful architecture is fantasticly made and very, very high !!

top view. nice view of 360 degrees around even if the best places are occupied by big circles and windows reflectîg a littke bit inside light on the pictures so put your camera and cellphones on the window! and enjoy

Favorite monument in NY!. My favorite monument in NYC! The view is incredible of course but the staff and multimedia displays in the elevators and all around the observatory make it so special! Get the premium ticket and skip the lines, it is so worth it! Loved the fellow who was there giving us tips for seeing NY! Want to go back as soon as I can!

New and progressive. Must see. For many reasons:- Unique attraction in NYC- Historical site, related to 9/11- Highest point in NYC- New and very technological; elevator, presentation, photoing- The view is not the same, as from Empire or Rockfeller. It is the Southest point and the Ocean is beautiful.
Amazing!!!. First rate. Very well organized. The elevator ride was awesome and the views are incredible. A must do when in NYC.

A simply monumental attraction. I took my 15 year old daughter to visit the One World Trade Centre on our Dad and daughter trip to NYC. The last time we were here as a family in 2009, she was poorly and my son and I walked from Grand Central Terminal to Ground Zero to experience the scale of lower Manhattan, particularly in the light of its 2001 history. Back then the site was in the process of what looked on paper to be a poignant and powerful transformation. Today we experienced the product of that transformation in all it's stunning majesty. For this is not simply a trip to the top of a building. This is an unbelievable experience that will, quite literally take your breath away. I won't spoil it for you - (others may!) - but from the moment you are thro the strictest security I've ever experienced (they found a Metro pass in one of my hidden pockets) you are part of this building. In a quite indescribable way, the designers and architects have constructed something utterly unique. The lift journeys up and down are SO much more than lift journeys. The stunning audio visual in the little theatre at the top before you access the observation deck is stunning and its denouement has my neck hairs dancing and my throat choking with emotion. And then there is the deck itself. State of the art interactive options; glassfloors, and the most iconic views of NYC imaginable. Many, including myself, assumed that with the lossof the Twin Towers, these views would be lost forever. That they have been restored and indeed enhanced is a phenomenal testimony to the vision, tenacity, perseverance and sheer defiance that says to the world "The good guys will never give in." We are all part of the history of this building. Visit it if you do nothing else when in NYC - and spend some reflectivemoments around the 9/11 memorial where the inspiration for this magnificent masterpiece was born....

They erased the hate with pure love, creativity and devotion.. They pulled it off, all the workers and architects created a place where you can almost touch the love and tenderness that went into creating every inch of it. They erased the hate and horror and replaced it with love. Who knew that was even possible. I feared going to the new WTC, afraid the anger and sorrow would overtake me but it was remarkable, the love that went into building it is what remains. I do not say this lightly as I am not the existential sort. Where I expected to find sorrow I found overwhelming love. How amazing. I wish I could thank them all for creating it. I honestly had no idea that that much love could erase so much evil and hate. The experience is different than the old WTC, you do run the gauntlet of waiting in the different lines. But the view is amazing, the elevator video is amazing as well along with the interview videos of those who built the new building. Buy the tickets on line as others have mentioned, it will save you grief. You do go through a security checkpoint just like the airport so dress accordingly. It was worth the cost of buying the flexible ticket. Park near the site as access is confusing.
A must!. Great views, highly recommend this observation deck/observatory. Very special picture taking experience! A must!
No Mall But Excellent. i went to the one world trade center, hoping to see the mall. but there was no mall (yet), even though i had a very fun (Kinda) time here.
Redemption. This is a great example of American redemption. We strive ever high and climb above any obstacle. A Must see

Fabulous!. The elevator ride up to the top is FABULOUS! It was just too short! The panoramic CG video of the building of NYC from the 1500s to today is not to be missed. I would have loved going up and down several times just to see it all. Have your camera ready after the initial welcome video because at the end they open the blinds onto a spectacular view of Manhattan. And then the 360 degree observation deck where you can see deep into Brooklyn, New Jersey, Staten Island and north to Central Park is delightful. Well worth the visit.

Building is amazing - the top is average. Who wouldn't love to be 108 stories above NYC. The building, which is all glass is truly a work of art in-itself. I found the top to be a bit crowded and bit cheesy for tourists. It was also very over-priced in my opinion. I would skip this if you don't have the time and visit the museum instead.

Not as impressive as Top of the Rock. I visited a few weeks after the tower opened, so there were very long lines (even with my purchase ahead ticket - which is a must!). I expected the lines, so that wasn't really the issue. I didn't realize that the top was completely closed in (only glass windows). I preferred the Top of the Rock and the Empire State Building since they have open viewing platforms. I do like that you can see the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island from this perspective.
Important Site to See. It was such a beautiful tribute to the victims. I would definitely recommend going to visit this. It is free and worth the time from a historical perspective.
Freedom tower. fabulous, saw it form the outside. So majestic and stands tall over ther memorial fountains. Did not get to go inside this time, perhaps next time.

Unsurpassed views of New York. We visited early morning in August. We had pre-booked the regular tickets for 10.45am the day before our visit. The queue looked quite big as we arrived and the staff were telling visitors the next available tickets on open sale were for 2pm. So book early and save your tickets to your phone! The queue did move pretty quickly. The lifts take about a minute to the observation deck and have a 360 degree screen with showed the development of the NY skyline. Once at the observation deck you are made to sit through a short film showing different NY scenes-there is a nice surprise at the end of the clip but the presentation just delays what you came to see-the view! The view is excellent-no other observation deck can capture the NY skyline looking back over Manhattan. The deck also provides good views of the key bridges and also Liberty. The glass used in the building was slightly reflective but not as bad as in some places. Even though the deck was busy it didn't feel cramped and you could easily reach a window. My only complaint was the signage was poor from the subway station.

Great views, well organized.. We left the building very satisfied with our experience. When you spend $32 to view the city you want it to be worth it and it was. From the moment we arrived we felt it was very well organized, we showed our tickets and were instructed where to go. Friendly staff, clean facility and overall a neat experience! We spent $15 on the ipad, which keeps you entertained. Spent about 1.5-2hrs total.

Tremendous from the Start. I was a bit reticent about going to the Observatory as 9/11 hit close to home. That said, this experience stresses the importance of rebuilding and even taps a number of the workers who speak to the camaraderie and spirit that infused the project. The result is nothing less than amazing!The attraction starts off with a high-tech and speedy elevator ride and ends up with an off-the-charts view. For $15 you can enhance the experience with an iPad that helps you identify many sites (with a few videos peppered in). While not necessary, it adds to the gee-whiz factor.I recently went to the Empire State Building which is certainly the iconic attraction, but it really doesn't compare to One World Observatory. Top of the Rock is also nice, but doesn't have all the bells and whistles. For the money...and the experience...I would go here.

Top of New York. This is a must-do in New York. Book your tickets online in advance, get your timeslot and turn up half an hour before and there is no problem. Particularly if you go early in the morning, there are not too many crowds and we went mid August. Kudos to Kyle in the entry queue outside who chatted to us, entertained us and made us feel welcome. The views are stellar in every direction - the observatory is peaceful and relaxing.

One World.. This is amazing. The lift to the top of the new One World is an attraction in itself. 102 floors in 47 seconds while watching a timeline video all around you of Manhattan forming from green pastures to the huge city it is today. Then the world trade building is built around you!! Truly breathtaking and a must for everyone as is the 360 degree view from the top.

Observation Tower and Dinner at ONE fine dining. The ride up to the observation floor is fabulous and the views are breathtaking. All the observation staff were helpful and courteous. Once you get off the elevator the initial film and your first exposure to the view are terrific. All in all a very special experience. However our dining experience was much less special. First I want to say the meal and service were very good and although we thought the charge for the elevator was over the top, the cost of the meal ($84 pp) was worth it. Now to the problems, if you are going to call it a fine dining restaurant, it isn't just about the food. The restaurant is an open space directly overlooking the observation floor and there is nothing separating the spaces, so what you hear throughout dinner is loud talking among the people down below, guides yelling above the talking, and loud music. You cannot hear the person sitting next to you. Even the food and view cannot compensate for the crazy noise and the inability to hold a conversation. Last but not least after dinner, ready to head home and guess what, you have to wait on a very long line for an elevator to leave. There is no difference for the ONE dining customers and the people there only for the observation tower. One would think maybe a restaurant elevator. Once in the elevator, another exciting trip.The company running the restaurants is actually more like a food vendor, I think they are more comfortable with a ball park environment....and the ambiance was kind of like that. We are from the tri-state area, raised in NYC and have spent a lot of time at fine dining restaurants, this is definitely not Windows on the World or Cellar in the Sky (where we had many great times), and definitely not a fine dining experience. Better to have only the hot dogs etc. and forget the "fine dining" unless you can do it right, especially in a place considered so special by so many.

Great views!. We bought our tickets before we traveled to NYC, which was nice because we did not have to wait long once we arrived. We have not been to any other Observatory in NYC, but the views were incredible. The elevator ride up was one of my kids favorite parts.

Amazing Building in Many Ways. This building is one of those amazing structures that you just need to see. There are so many mixed feelings regarding it due to the tragedy that took place on 9/11, but it is a marvel to look at.

Fantastic views. Well worth the entry fee. It's a great view from 100 plus stories high. Staff are friendly and the best part is they are super organized. A travelers must whilst in NYC. Buy your tickets online as they are timed entry every 15minutes or so and save your feet standing in a queue! Graphics in lift (45 seconds to top) are amazing as well. Thoroughly enjoyed one world observatory.

Quite a view. I thought the express ticket was expensive but then again the whole thing is expensive but the express ticket is worth it on a hot day. I'm not a big fan of the sales pitch for the ipad, just makes a obvious commercial venture even more in your face commercial and forget about the gift shop prices. Having said all that the views are spectacular. Really mesmerizing when you think about the fact you are in a building that high up (helicopters are flying below you) and the elevators are very unique. I also found it fun just to pick out landmarks and observe the city and boroughs.

Wawooooooooo!!!!!!. Really great observation deck... beautiful view of the city... the buildings guide is a nice addition... and even the queues were not too long...Everything is new and shining... The visitors count... really nicePrice was on the high side but definitely worth paying...With the surrounding amazing memorial park and the history we all remember too well... a strong MUST.

A must !. What a beautiful building complex was created here... even without the history and other connotations... amazing!Adding now the history and treating is as a memorial park for that event... even more amazing !Definitely a must visit!

A Must See. The building it self is as impressive as the sights from the top. Unfortunately we visited just before it was opened to the public. With the history about what happened on the grounds and the basis for the new building it gave me goosebumps. It is both a landmark and a memorial.

One World Trade Center. Just like any other observatory - you get to the top, look out, and go back down. Can see all the sites - Brooklyn Bridge, Ellis Island, Statue of Liberty, NJ, etc. Somewhat expensive for what it is, but ... it's NYC. Plus, very sobering being on the WTC site. Paid my respects properly. Glad I visited. Wouldn't need to do it again.

Emotional. This was a pricey but amazing experience. It was very emotional. The staff was very informative. Take your time and enjoy your full experience from entering the building to seeing forever. Love it and will go again.

Top of New York. my family was lucky enough to visit One world trade centre in july 2015, we booked our time at sunset so we could get nice photos of the city with the lights going on at dusk. At $30 a pop its in line with the other 2 main buildings so price is ok, the elevator ride is awesome, a video of the changing new York skyline, your up there fast too, 102 floors in 50 seconds! There is a café and restaurant at the top and the views are great. Worth every cent.

Spectacular views!. You feel like you are on top of the world when you visit. From the moment you enter the lift and arrive at your destination you know that this will be amazing. Once the video finishes and you see that view it truly is spectacular. Definitely visit here and book online unless you want to wait in the queue. Enjoy!
One World Trade Centre. Well worth the money. Enjoy a full 360 degree view of New York and surrounds. The lift ride up and down is very impressive.
Nice walk in a man made jungle. The skyscrapers make you think how the man is able to build something so amazing. It is impresive. Nice walk with clean streets.

Great views. The views are spectacular and very different, so you should go even if you've been to the other two observation decks (which are located midtown). It's also a great and very smoothly run attraction. Just note that it might be easier if you get your tickets beforehand, as it'll speed up your entry.The only drawback is that because it's an entirely indoor observation deck (the other two have outdoor sections), reflections from the glass can make photos somewhat more difficult.Overall, I'd rank this the 2nd best of the three observation decks in NYC (Top of the Rock is still my fav).

Brought tears to my eyes. Yes, it cost $90 for two adults and one child. Yes, we should not have spent $152.25 on lunch (2 burgers with fries, 1 chicken sandwich with fries, 2 cocktails and 1 mocktail). However, I am so happy we went. We took the PATH from Jersey City. The WTC station is still being renovated, but it already looks quite impressive with its white marble. We went from the train directly to the entrance, never once having to go above ground. I suggest buying your tickets online & printing them out since the signal strength is poor in the ticketing area and you might not be able to pull them up on your smartphone. They did a fantastic job in offering an emotional and breathtaking experience. We went on a Monday morning so there were not a lot of people there.
Fabulous views. The best way to see New York! The 46 second elevator to reach the 102nd floor was informative and breathtaking experience.

Stunning view. Amazing view from the 102th floor. 60 seconds to reach it and view the story of new york in the elevator. Great visual experience in the elevator when ypu go down in about 45 seconds. One negative point: business is business I know but the price of the various gadgets for sale before you leave is a little bit prohibitive , just to add a "one world" logo....

Great to be on top of the world again!. At last the response to 9/11 has been built. An even better and more beautiful replacement. A fitting tribute to all those who lost their lives. The elevator ride up is spectacular as are the views. Also the admission lines and security is all handled by very pleasant staff. Overall a great must do in NYC

Amazing views but a little expensive. I purchased a "Day Flex Priority Admission" ticket which at US$65 was quite expensive. It allowed us to by pass the long queues, which given the high temperatures made the visit much more enjoyable. The views are, of course amazing, the lift ride exciting and it is a must see place to visit. It brought back memories of 9/11, but it is also wonderful to see the new buildings rising from the ashes.I was disappointed to get out of the lift to immediately be offered more things to buy - a tool to identify specific buildings and a photograph taking service. This felt too pushy. Regular cleaning of the glass would be good - we got there mid afternoon and the glass was covered in children's handprints. It's okay if you are sufficiently tall to see over these.

One World Trade Center - recently opened. The One World Trade Center had just been open for six weeks to the public when we visited at the height of the summer vacation period. There was a wait, but we could buy a ticket and were told when to come back, giving us time to get some dinner at a nearby eatery and look at the memorial site next to the new tower. We wanted to visit because of the view and the history of the building. The visit had a bit of a theme park feel which visitors may or may not like. The staff were professional in their guidance and informative presentations. I suggest hiring the 'Explorer' tablet device they offer when you leave the introductory presentation and enter the viewing area. The Explorer gives names and gives information about the sites you are viewing.

Amazing, a must see. My niece booked this trip for not realising i hate heights, but i have to say i made it up in the lift [that is extremley quick,] without panicking,I am so pleased i did, the view was absolutley amazing, we went on Sunday 2nd of august , we were up in the bar area when the sun went down, all i can say is that the view was stunning, it is well worth the trip ,but you are better off getting tickets before you go as it gets extremley busy.

One World Observatory. Awesome experience, the elevator ride was amazing showing the time lapse and the speed of it. It was so smooth that if it wasn't for my ears popping you couldn't tell it was moving. The view was like no other, you could see the statue of liberty, the memorial park, ski scrapers amongst others. The staff was very friendly, helpful and organized. The one thing I wasn't very disappointed on was the price of food/drinks. Over priced! a bottle water was $3 just to mention one thing now imagine the food!

Average.. If I'm perfectly honest this was the most disappointing part of my trip to New York City. Although I don't think the tickets were too expensive (with the exchange rate at the time they were around £20 each - no more than the London Eye), it wasn't as good as I thought it would be. It was completely packed (although it was close to the 4th July weekend) and you couldn't help but feel herded the entire time. The views were impressive although would have been better on a clearer day. The lift resembles a theme park ride however, who is not to be impressed with a lift that takes you from 0 to over 100th floor in less than a minute... I'd go if you're really desperate too but otherwise go up the Empire State, it's more iconic and a nicer experience.

Senior NYC sisters visit. Early May book reservation..Staff most helpful..walked right up to reserve lineand in 15 minutes we were on our way up to observatory. Read all about presentationbut still was surprise ...Window views on this clear day were spectacular ..Can spendas much time as you like viewing photography, listening to presentations asking questions..Very safe ..very clean and glorious views ...Even being a New Yorkerthis is an attraction to put on your bucket list...Stay away from pricey gift shopand food available..We ate afterward in Little Italy...

Spectacular Views & Great Experience . Spend the additional $$ for priority tickets. It allows you to skip not only the line to the building but also for the elevator. The elevator ride is a visual timeline on the development of Manhattan. The views are stunning even though it is "just a window" - 360 degrees.A must do. The entire plaza incl the memorial and new transportation hub are very well designed and a great place of remembrance and reflection.
Nice overview. Great view and not too long lines. That being said I recommend to buy tickets online in advance to avoid potential busy times.Gives nice overview of Manhattan and the skyline.

Do not miss this attraction.. This was my second visit to New York, on my previous visit I didn't go to the Empire State or Top of the Rock, so on this visit I was determined to do the ESB and One World. If you have to choose one - go to One World, they have done it so well - astounding views and the trip in the elevator is worth noting, too.

Scary and thrilling at the same time. I have to admit I was quite sad and scared when getting the tickets to the grand opening of One World Trade Center. Sad, because of the reason there was a new building to visit on site, and scared, because of what I would feel going up.I am happy to say that everything just washed away in a flood of joy as soon as I stepped inside. It was the most amazing feeling, knowing the strength and pride underlying the new structures. The tour was also extremely well-organized, with almost zero queuing, because of time-slots and great staff. I don’t want to spoil the experience, which is why I won’t mention anything else from the inside. Just that it was absolutely brilliant.
One World Tower visit. Worth the effort. Breathtaking views. Well worth a visit. Book on line for early morning mid week visit. Everything moves along swiftly and seamlessly.

Great view- hats off to Christopher too. I did not rent the iPad , that would've made the experience better.The guide named Christopher, who was one of the people conducting the short interactive films was nice and kind- he agreed to my request to do Money and Finance, even though he wasn't too keen on it, and he did it in an interesting way. On that day, he wanted to do Pizza again and again!
Emotional. Two waterfalls where the North and South towers once stood. Very emotional. You can take a tour of the new Freedom observatory.
A great view of the NY skyline.. This is a beautiful building with amazing views but the elevator ride to the top was our favorite. The wait time was very minimal and worth the trip.

Great experience. The elevator ride to the top of the Observatory was unexpected and awesome! The views were great of course. We went at about 9:30 PM (June 2015), it wasn't very busy and it was cool to see the views at night. Make sure to go when it is clear, not cloudy, or you really won't see much. The only downside of going at night was the reflection on the glass from the lights inside the observatory. Made it harder to take good pictures.

Amazing building. When we visited in November, it wasn't yet possible to go inside and up in the new One World Trade Center. But the outside views were already very promissing. This will be for a next visit to NY!

Best views. Out of all the skyscraper, I would say that One World Observatory is the best because it hosts the best views from all the sides. You can see the Statue of Liberty, 9/11 Memorial and even the Empire State Building. The lines are not that long and you should buy your tickets online so you can save time. It does not matter what time you get the ticket as long as it is on the same day. We bought tickets for 10:30 Am but we visited at 3:00 PM. The elevator ride to the 102 floor is amazing. The tickets are $32.00, but well worth it.
Amazing . Sticker shock at first with the $32.00 pp price tag but once we went up it was well worth it! Amazing views, friendly & informative staff.
Shock and awe. Go. Check it out for the memories and the shock value. I think we all should see this place and revel in the efforts and rebuilding.
Architecture takes your breath away.. Great architecture, A new Icon for NYC and very important building in New York Financial district. Must be seen visiting New York City.

Amazing view!. The view is amazing. It is a little pricey if you do the priority pass but in the end worth it because of the long lines. It was bittersweet to be there. The elevator ride was truly incredible.

amazing views. both sad and happy to visit this. I clearly remember the events of 9/11, so it brought back unpleasant memories, but it's hard not to appreciate the "phoenix rising from the ashes" effect that this building provides, along with the other development of the trade center complex.Lines and waiting at each juncture, even with advance ticket purchase. But they moved quickly enough, with great positive employee engagement along the way. Of course an amazing view.Be prepared for several opportunities to spend money - (1) having your photo taken with photo backdrop of the city, (2) renting an ipad for tour information, (3) souvenir shop on the observation deck.But amazing views, all around, of course.four not five bullets, as there's not much available to help explain what you're seeing, unless you rent the ipad. No brouchure, no labels on the window sills, no "mapping" of buildings to explain what you're seeing.

Way cool!. Fantastic views! Everything about the experience was way cool, starting with the incredibly fast, and unique elevator ride up. The history of the development of NYC is on the walls as you rise. Interesting short intro film, with a very cool ending. Spent about an hour walking around, then had a drink in the bar, looking out over Manhattan. Nothing about it is inexpensive. But, then you don't have to buy anything except for the entrance ticket. We purchased the standard timed ticket. The wait was not long. Fun, fun, fun!

Great view but disappointing fine dining restaurant 'One'. I want to write a review on the restaurant One however couldn't find it under restaurants.The attraction and view are amazing, of course as you are 103 floors in the air.What was terribly disappointing was the restaurant One. We booked this before leaving Australia and expected a lot more for the prices we paid. There is no fast tracking for reservation holders. Although we did organise the fast track with the concierge. You should be taken up and not through the cheaper bar type eateries.Once you finally get into the restaurant there is no atmosphere as all you can hear is the tour groups going through and the tour guide on the loud speaker. This is due to the fact that One is on a mezzanine so the sound travels.Also the service was shocking. Not fine dining as you expect from the prices.lastly there should be a fast track or someone taking you back down from the restaurant but instead you have to que up with everyone else.The good itself was ok but the entire experience underwhelming... book at one of the many other amazing restaurants & just go for the view.

Totally designed to create a great experience. After watching this building rise from the ground, making it to the top was a must on my to do list. Buying tickets was easy enough on line. They offer a couple different options. Cheapest tickets are around $30 and must be used at a specific time. They will not let you enter the line until 15 minutes prior to your admission time. Flex tickets that can be used at any time are available but cost more. And VIP tickets are also available and let you skip the lines. It took roughly 25 minutes to get through the lines and make it to the top. The elevator ride took only 51 seconds and was incredibly crafted to add to the experience. Once off the elevator, they created another experience. I won't go into a lot of details as to not spoil the experience. Once at the top, you are not rushed and the crowds are not overwhelming. After seeing this attraction, I would certainly consider it a must do in NYC. No where else can you get a view of the concrete jungle that is NYC like this. Not to mention, being on the 102nd floor of the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere. Visiting NY requires a trip to the WTC site. And since you are down there, you might as well add this attraction to your itinerary.
A Must See. Words can not begin to capture this new experience in NYC. An amazing elevator ride, followed by a short presentation and then WOW!!

Must see!! . Our second trip to the memorial. Still very moving. I will have to agree with other Trip Adviser people, the museum should not charge admission. I understand why they do, but even still. It should be a free of charge museum, like they do in DC. Although everyone should visit at least once. The memorial pools outside ARE free to everyone. The museum itself is expensive.

Amazing views. We were not planning on going there since it was still new and were expecting long lines. Fortunately the waiting was just 15 minutes and we were glad we did it.The elevator ride itself is awesome and once you're up there the views are fantastic.I'd recommend going during lightime.

It's just a window really!. The building is beautiful and the elevator ride is excellent. However, if you don't give in to the high pressure sale of the tablet guide ($15) you are really on your own. No helpful pictures or explanations of what lies before you. Just windows! The whole experience is sadly lacking in technology. They need to visit the Seattle Space tower to see how it should be done! Once you have had your fill of the spectacular views you can collect your $30 green screen picture and go and visit the 911 memorial which is stunning. We won't be back.

Beautiful!. A must see!! The ride up was quick and when the doors open, it takes your breath away. While the cost $32 might be high, I felt it was worth it. I would however NOT pay for the ipads ($15) that they pretty much insist you need...they are not needed!

Awesome Sunset Views. My wife, my granddaughter, and I purchased advance tickets on-line and visited the One World Observatory just before sunset. What extraordinary views!! Recommend it to anyone who wants a nice view. Only downside is that it is very noisy.
Worth the wait. The elevator ride was in itself an attraction. The view fr.o.m. The observatory was exceptional. The café was a bit boring with little view, the bar probably has a nicer view.

this is the new wtc. Hard to review (even think about!) the new wtc tower because memories of the old twin towers and the tragedy are still too fresh. But, I think I can generally recommend viewing this new attraction, whatever your feelings. Reservations are recommended; but if you find yourself here without reservations, you may still be able to get in, though there may be a wait. The elevators seem to defy the laws of physics, both up and down. On a clear day, the 360 degree view (from the enclosed observation deck) is spectacular. There is no external deck. The restaurant was not cheap (of course), but the food was appropriately good and you have that jaw-dropping view while you're eating. You can take as long as you want to look around; there aren't any other attractions up there. IMHO the towers should have been rebuilt twice or three times as tall; but looking past that disappointment, this is now one of the new, must-see attractions in nyc, at least until another, taller building opens in the Hudson Yards area with a higher observation deck. The admission fee is similar to other tall buildings in nyc which permit sightseeing.
Amazing!. Breathtaking! State of the art technology and wonderful presentation. Get your tickets in advance, sells out quick.

Underwhelming. I don't know what it was but it just didn't do it for me. It just seemed like one commercial exercise. The queues were non existent (5:45pm on a Thursday). There were one or two bits that made you go wow but given the cost there were not enough. You just felty they were looking at ways of getting more money off you.

Great Views of City. Great views, beautiful building, they give you an iPad to help you locate buildings in the city. I suggest ordering tickets in advance online, the lines can get really long. The observatory is inside so you can go year around.

Good, but it could have been better. My Husband and I visited the One World Observatory on Sunday 2nd August at 10.15. As advised on our ticket, we arrived 15 minutes before our alloted time and we pleasantly surprised by the lack of a big queue! Once through security  (which was no more than 10 minutes) we were quickly on our way up to the observation deck. The views were breathtaking and you could see the south of Manhattan, including the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. The staff informed us that it was fantastic visibility on the day that we visited and that it isn't always as easy to see. Whilst I would recommend this experience for those visiting New York, we were left very disappointed by the lack of information about the building of the tower. I found myself looking on Google to find answers to our questions! There was also no reference to the Twin Towers although this may be something which is discussed more at the Memorial Museum. Worth a visit but do your own research and be prepared to queue to get down!

The HIGHlight of our trip!. Visiting the Observatory was the HIGHlight of our visit! Amazing views. Several years ago we did Top of the Rock but the OWO is definitely a superior experience. Ear-popping lift ascent takes about 60 seconds. No queues to speak of either. You just keep walking round and round once you are up - so much to see!

Awesome view.. Great views from the top but overall experience was disappointing. The elevator ride up is fantastic with the entire walls of the elevator presenting a time-lapsed history of the area surrounding the building. After that a short little video before the screen rises and closes back to get a quick glimpse of what lies ahead. Then, the obligatory picture for purchase photo op. Then a short spiel to encourage you to rent an IPad that will show you what you will be looking at. This may come in handy if you are not familiar with New York as there are no display signs anywhere. Finally, you do down one floor to the observation deck where you can enjoy the spectacular view at your leisure. Food and drinks are available and also an assortment of overpriced souvenirs at the gift shop. One example, logo golf balls, which I do collect but had to pass on these, were 3 for $30.00. I get this is NYC and the tallest building in the USA, but that was just a little too high for me. Overall, great views, but we spent less then a hour there.

Great views, great architecture but you can take it or leave it.. NYC has a couple of options for getting up high and enjoying the view. Whilst One World Observatory affords a unique view looking North toward the whole of Manhattan, the Mid Town vistas probably give you a better all around view of NYC.The area around the old WTC site has obviously been through a major transformation over the years and One WTC is certainly an amazing addition in terms of scale and grandeur, from the PATH station through to the tower itself.We visited the observation deck on a Thursday morning in June and there were relatively small queues. We wanted to be time efficient so bough fast track tickets, which would come in really handy when it came to exit.The views and vistas are amazing but since it's all enclosed behind glass you do get less of a sense of the height than you might do at Top of the Rock.It's a pretty big observation deck though, so even if it's busy there are plenty of vantage points.There are no public seating areas to speak of other than in a small canteen type area that gets very crowded. There is also revered seating in a bar/restaurant but you'd need to be eating from an overpriced menu to snag a table.Now back to the fast track tickets. The exit line snaked around the whole of the observation deck so getting out would have taken much longer then to get in had it not been for the fast track entry tickets which also gave us fast track exit.......If I were to return to NYC I think I'd be 50/50 about going back to the observatory. I'm not sure it's worth the hassle. Much better to spend time at ground level and at the museum underneath the Reflecting Pools.

Exceeded expectations!. It didn't hurt that it was the most beautiful day of the summer, but my son and I had a wonderful time here. Extremely well done, from the ticketing (lines were very manageable) to getting everyone to the elevators. The staff was incredibly friendly and helpful. The elevator ride was something to behold, so brilliant and informative, and the emotional movie about New York once you get to the top is just beautiful (and the big reveal of the view is spectacular). Very calm and serene, believe it or not, it was a beautiful morning.

Great view, HUGE lines . Astonishing view. Nicely executed. Super long queue to get in, even with a pre-booked or express admission ticket. Super long queue to get down when you exit. Leave enough time. Most of you trip will be spent in line.

freedom tower. i would recommend reservations, the walk up line was very long at 2 pm. it is new and modern so the walls of the elevators were video boards that showed the outside view as you were ascending too the top. there is food and a gift shop on observation floor. a downside for me was it is a closed viewing instead of open air like the empire state building but overallgood experience

TONY: Top Of New York. Tickets are $30 for adults, small price to pay for the amazing views and experience.The elevator are super fast and smooth, it will take you up to the 102nd floor in less than a minute. Skip the iPad not worth it.The best 360 views in the city period. life is about making memories.This is one you won't regret.

Good. Its a beautiful view however, None of the workers on the first floor or the top floor know anything about the building. I asked if it was bigger then the old twin towers and nobody knew until I got to the gift shop, there was this wonderful girl who new all the answers to my questions. She had great energy too and was well educated on her stuff, her name was Christina. The managers need to educate their employees a little better and use Christina as a example.The prices of the tickets were ok, I would suggest buying them online to avoid the lines outside.The restaurant is too pricey.
Must see. Definately a must visit place when in new york for the obvious reasons and the design of the new building along with the museum is quite something!

WOW - absolutely stunning views on NYK. Timed tickets so no waiting in long lines anywhere. Excellent services and great info about the place as you gop in and up to the elevators. Once up, there are a couiple of different viewing places. When you get to the first and do the little show, there is an absolute wow moment - wont give it away though. Unobstructed views everywhere - absolutely stunning. We stayed and had lunch in the cafe and continued to be excited by all that was going on and the views. Oned of the best NYK events we did - so much better than the Empire State experience and a touch better than Top of The Rock experience

Average, unfortunately. Compared to the Rockefeller Centre, unfortunately the Observatory is simply average. The building itself is fantastic and is a fitting replacement of the WTCs, however the experience at the top just seems a bit too corporate and sterile. After having paid to get up there, you're then asked to pay extra to borrow iPads which explain the view, then in order to reach the Observatory you must first pass by the cafe and the gift shop - all seemingly designed to get the most dollars out of you. Luckily though you're not forced to pose for a cheesy photo, which seems to be the case everywhere else!That all being said though, the views from up there are pretty stunning. Perhaps the highlight for me was actually the lift/elevator ride - you have a 180 degree time-lapse simulation of the building of Manhattan which moves in time with the ascending lift. There was included a nice, poignant reminder of the twin towers as they appear to the side for only a brief second. Very clever, very well done.If you've never been to New York before then it's probably worth a visit, but I would personally go to the Rockefeller every time.

Dont miss this top of world experience.. We booked our visit through their website. This tour just opened 4 weeks ago. We had no wait and it was not crowded. The elevator flew up 100 floors and you didn't feel it and it was done in less than 10 seconds. There is so much to see and the security is just like the airport. The restaurant was good and at a reasonable cost.Out of the ashes of the Twin Towers arose a great tribute to the men and women of 911 and the One World Trade Center honors all the great heroes, don't miss it.
More than just a good view!. Not just a "go up and view" kind of experience but much more interactive, with information given by the staff and a bit of a show put on. Loved the experience!

Freedom Tower. We booked this from the UK and are so glad that we did. It was a fantastic experience especially as we had previously been to the top of the Twin Towers including a dinner in Windows of the World. We thoroughly recommend this as the views are spectacular..

Freedom Tower. We booked this from the UK and are so glad that we did. It was a fantastic experience especially as we had previously been to the top of the Twin Towers including a dinner in Windows of the World. We thoroughly recommend this.
Great experience. We were positively surprised by the great views but even more so by the swift entrance and the spectacular entrance.

Sunset from the World Observatory. View was magnificent. I believe the best 360 degree view in Manhattan. A nice bar as well but unfortunately must pay for the observation deck even if just a visit to the bar.

Appreciate the resilence of the American spirit at One World.. It was very emotional going to this sacred spot. The defecting pools and names were so hard yet mesmerizing to look at. I booked a priority pass which was a smart move. I skipped all the lines. The panel show opening to the view brought tears to my eyes. And the elevator ride up and down was an incredible show!! I bought some unique gifts in their shop. I enjoyed spending time enjoying the view in the restaurant with a crisp Chardonney but the calamari was over cooked. Overall, an amazing experience!

Stunning!. We booked for the 7:00 trip, which was a bit early, as sunset was not until 8:15pm. The weather had been horrendous, with prolonged downpours, so visibility was severely restricted. Nevertheless, it was a stunning view at the top, and we knew that it would get better after dark. Fortunately, we had enough money to be able to afford some fries and beers and so relaxed and soaked up the atmosphere. Hey! We were on holiday.Once the sun had set and the city lights came on, everything seemed to appear sharper and we managed to get a few decent shots through the glass.Tripods are not allowed, quite reasonably, but I was able to use my mini tripod and set the camera at a slow speed, which resulted in some decent pics.An extremely well organised holiday attraction.

Tears of humanity. "Big strong bloke fight anything" reduced to tears, this is one if not the most moving places I have ever been, thousands of people in the square but not overcrowded very little noise although people were talking although quieter than normal for NY. The water.......... well whoever designed this memorial did a fantastic job it is such a special memorial to all of those poor souls and two fingers to terrorists every ware, YOU WILL NOT WIN.

Saoring high in the Manhattan Skyline. This one sky scrapper is really soaring high on the lower Manhattan skyline. You can't miss it. We took several cruises past the lower half of the Manhattan where East river & Hudson river meets and wherever you look, it is right up there shining like a blade.

BREATHTAKING. My wife and I visited One World Observatory on 21st July 2015. Definitely, definitely worth the visit. Firstly you travel from the basement in a lift at -2 to the 102nd floor in about 10 seconds and you don't even think you are moving. You then step out onto a gantry where there is a slide show, film about New York and then the blinds go up. It took my breath away and I must admit I cried. It was breathtaking and absolutely stunning. Thats not it, you then have the opportunity to walk all the way around the observation deck and you can see 360 degrees of New York. Absolutely brilliant. Refreshments, food, drinks are available, a bit pricey but so what.

Spectacular!. Absolutely fabulous experience! Start from the very beginning, the elevator ride - splendid! Then a really fun video right before you're entering the observatory, and then the observation itself! Loved everything about it! If you want to beat the crowd to get in, book your tickets online, it's so easy! Also, if you're going there to take pictures, keep in mind that the reflection is pretty bad, so put on dark clothes... I would highly recommend this to anyone, if you're a tourist or a New Yorker, it's a must!
Top of the world!. The view is beautiful. New York is at your feet! Had dinner at One and it was excellent. The food was delicious and we were treated to a spectacular sunset.
Beautiful. What an Amazing building, it kind of shimmers and stands tall. Such a beautiful building and can be seen from afar.

Waste of time.. At the beginning of June on a hot and sunny Sunday afternoon, we treated a visitor to NY to a visit to One World. The tickets were purchased in advance for $34 and $32 for the 2 seniors accompanying us. BTW, for an extra $20, you can purchase VIP tickets that allows to skip the lines. We were advised to arrive at least 30 minutes ahead of time, we got there 45 minutes early with our 3pm tickets. We joined the line and waited and waited until eventually it was our turn, to enter the blessed air conditioned building at 3:20. Inside there was a line for the escalator down to the elevators, a line through security and a walk through a "multi media" display of the workers who built the new WTC. Now another line to get on the elevator to the observation deck. The elevator ride was interesting, it showed you layers of the bedrock, old New York and pictures of the NYC skyline. On the observation deck, a big whoops. To me a New Yorker for more years than I care to remember, it was no big deal, While it was a sunny day, looking out from the observation deck, there was a definite haze limiting your view, Many years ago I had the pleasure of visiting the 107 floor of the WTC on a cooler and much clearer day. The NYC skyline has not changed that much in the years in between. We spent about a half hour on the observation deck.My opinion, it's not worth $34, if you are a resident and have visitors, buy them tickets, drop 'em off and pick 'em back up.Problems especially in the summer, no shade in waits of an hour or more for most people. Long waits all around and very crowded. The only area that was not crowded was the restroom on the observation deck. There was also a 15 minute wait to descend back to the lobby. My visit occurred about 2-3 weeks after the opening of One World.

Top of a Tower. A fab visit to NY City's newest talk tower. A classy place with dining and souvenir shop atop the tower. Fully enclosed, though, and you can't get outside like the Empire State or the 'Top of the Rock', etc. Very fast elevator ride to the top with a video shown on the inside walls of the elevator. No, you can't see outside while in the elevator. A nice place to visit. Price was $32 for adults.

Not to be missed!. With all due respect to ancient worthies like the Empire State and Chrysler buildings, THIS is the one to go for! The high speed ear-popping lift rapidly has you at the 102nd floor with its little surprise before you get all the time you want to look over the sights of New York. The view is AMAZING. We didn't pre-book, even at the height of season in late July. Just waited for a clear day, turned up, queued for no more than 5 minutes and got straight in with standard tickets. Whatever you do, don't miss this! Open all day and evening.

Sad but great show of honour to the fallen. Really gut wrenching. Great depiction of the truths of 9/11. Not being American, it was hard to understand the loss they felt, but seeing what they have done to preserve the memories of their loved ones moved me to tears. Every one understands loss when it is expressed so vividly.

Great View - Emotionally Moving. The view is the best and they make you pay for it. Then, they ask you to pay $15 more (above the $32 you lay for entry) for an iPad that tells you what you're looking at when you enjoy the view. Cafe is VERY expensive. Eat before you go up or wait. The view of the twin tower footprints from that vantage point is sobering. We got tickets in advance and walked right in at 9 a.m. That part is very efficient. $150 for four of us, for one hour, is a bit steep for what you get.
World Trade Center. The new muesum is awesome. The staff is warm and friendly. Do the tour it is amazing and thought provoking!
Simply Stunning. Amazing view, pretty spectacular, and lunch at the restaurant was fantastic, ribs were the best and service top notch, and the setting of which to indulge in was second to none

Crowded and Better Views at the Top of the Rock. We purchased tickets to One World Observatory to visit after we had our guided tour of the 9/11 Memorial Museum. The cost for this was $29.39. We waited in a huge line to get to the elevators. We planned it so that we would be at the top for the sunset. When we reached the top, it was so crowded that we couldn't really get close to the windows. People were camped out sitting on the ledges. The windows had a coating on them so photography was difficult. The views are much better at The Top of the Rock. I would recommend the museum guided tour but skip this.
Time Travel and see like a bird. The elevator turns into a time machine as you rise to the top. WOW! From 1400-2015 in seconds. Witness it or you will miss the opportunity of a lifetime.

Amazing views. Less than a minute to reach the 102nd floor 1600 feet up. Cool video walls in the elevator in the way up. Lots of security and lines, so buy tickets ahead of time. Once your in top views of Manhattan and surrounding Burroughs are amazing. Worth the visit and money.

Good viewing option. Open since May 2015. The ability to move people through was great. Even with crowds our wait was ok. A bit more expensive and commercial than the Empire or Top of the Rock. No open air views but being that far south gives a great different view. Passed on the restaurant.

Great employee.. I met this young lady here who was absolutely amazing. I was terrified of heights and she walked me through the whole observatory distracting me so that I wouldn't be scared. I had a wonderful time because of her.Thank you so much Katherine S. there needs to be more people like you in this world.

Amazing!!!. Amazing! From the moment you enter the lift you are taken on an incredible ride. Big surprise at end of 'presentation' prior to going to main observatory which I won't spoil here. Will go again and again on return to New York

AMAZING. My family had a 7.30hr wait at Newark so we decided to take a chance and visit the tower. We pre booked taxis and the priority tickets at a cost of $54. It was worth every single penny. We were lucky enough to have visited the Twin Towers and this is a fitting tribute. The staff were fantastic and the presentation had a excellent surprise. This is a must visit you will not be disappointed.

Start spreading the news.... What a spectacular view from One World Observatory! I didn't have any expectations beforehand but this experience was special. The associates working were curious, knowledgeable and enthusiastic about all things related to One World Observatory. I don't want to ruin any body's experience but the elevator and theater experience is something to behold and ponder over afterwards. The space available is expansive however can become, at time, over crowded. Be patient and if you can, go before 11am, as the rush flows in! The area serving food and beverage is okay however a bit pricey? The shop full of souvenirs has a reasonable collection of the usual suspects however, if you're a collector of patches then this venue doesn't have anything. I purchased a pin online for $12 and received this after showing my original booking via phone or printed on paper. The window does have a slight reflection for taking photographs, but the angle of taking a photograph negates this. The windows were at 10am full of finger print marks, particularly from kids and adults alike - merely from the fact that they were in awe of the spectacular view. I would recommend you get there before midday or before dusk sets in to reward you with perfect viewing opportunities.

Great View ! iPads for Information !. Getting There - Take a train from New Jersey or New York and walk straight into the Observatory entrance from the Path Station.Tickets - Buy tickets online. It's easy and saves time. Carry a print out but tickets on the Smartphone work as well. There's a line for security as well after the tickets are checked and validatedElevator - The elevator ride to the top is magnificent. It takes about 45 seconds to reach the top floor. The elevators are on of the fastest in the world and are setup with digital screens to give you some cool facts about the elevator ride. Here's the actual video: http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/apr/20/one-world-trade-center-elevators-500-Once Upstairs - you have a small presentation about the city of New York which leads into the blinds opening and you getting a terrific view of the city. You proceed to enter the observatory after this. iPads for Information - you can rent iPads with pre-loaded softwares for $15 which provide a better understanding to the views from the top. I highly recommend these if you are new to the city and if this is your first time in the city. They are informative, easy to use and definitely provide a better understanding behind the history of the area. Tip: The guys working for the observatory are super nice. They gave us 2 iPads for $15.Restaurant - There is a restaurant with seating as well as a quick pick and go area. Enjoy a nice meal on the top. The Flatbread Pizza's were delicious.Overall - a great way to start a tour of the city. Even if you live in the city, this is definitely a highly recommended site.

Fast elevator. fast, efficient, cool movie going up and the spins on the way down. I LOVED that it was enclosed in glass (I was on top of the WTC as a 9 year old and it was not glassed in, it was very windy) At one point there is a sales pitch for a computer device that tells you what you are looking at and if you clicked on that building you would get more information As that it was only two of us I did not splurge but had I splurged we would have spent more time looking - without the device telling you the oodles of things you can actually see I focused on the ones I knew and then we left. On another trip I might splurge.

Beautiful view but.... Once you get through all the security you will see a wall with visitor information on it. The week of our visit they had approximately 62,000 visitors at about $30+ per person- do the math. Next you will get in line to get into the elevator. The 60 second ride up is fast and fun. Pay attention to the elevator screen because the scene changes and you see the city evolve over time. Once you get off the elevator you go into a room with a screen/covered window that has an audio presentation then the window cover goes up and the city is revealed. Next you encounter yet another line to have your picture taken. They don't offer a way around the picture if you don't want it taken, you have to wait until you can walk through what would be your turn to take the picture. After you get done in that room you get shuffled into another room for a "presentation". The presentation turned out to be a sales pitch for iPads you can rent for $15.00. The iPads will identify surrounding buildings and allow you to take pictures. The view is amazing but didn't like to be nickeled and dimed. Why charge visitors more money to identify buildings? Why not just have iPad stations set up for visitors to use at will? They are clearly making a lot of money and it seemed unnecessary to be so greedy. They have a gift shop (t-shirts around $36.00) and they also sell food. FYI- this place is NOT affiliated with the 9/11 memorial and museum. If you're set on visiting the Freedom tower I highly suggest you purchase your tickets online and select the time you want to visit. If you purchase tickets there you will stand in line outside (direct sun- no shade) for about 15-20 minutes just to get inside to purchase the tickets and be given a time to return. Save your self the hassle and purchase online or use your smart phone. If you want to purchase priority tickets (no waiting) plan on spending $54.00 per person. Overall the view is beautiful but the steps to get to that view left me disappointed. My alternate suggestion to getting a good view of the city is to go to Rockefeller Centers Top of the Rock where you get a beautiful view of the city and Central Park, plus you get to step outside for beautiful pictures.

Astonishing. We visited just at dusk -- kind of hokey beginning with the counter of visitors and a map of recent arrivals, a rather standard video of NYC scenes, a fast elevator ride, the grand unveiling -- ok for tourists, maybe, but just too over the top for me.But then inside, oh my goodness, the views and the great iPads with views and names of buildings and other features. A great way to learn about Manhattan and Brooklyn and a tiny bit of the Bronx and Staten Island.Expensive but worth the money.

AWESOME views!. Wonderful exhibit and view of all surroundings of NYC. We went on a cloudy day and the staff was very concerned that we would not enjoy our visit but it was still fine. Very organized and it never felt crowded. The elevators are enclosed with video screens, so you get to see a simulation of traveling up with no walls at all. Very next experience. Once on top, there rare 3 different levels to "explore." They had food and drink for purchase (one cup of coffee was $5, so it's not cheap!) and they had a person giving a talk about all the different things you could experience in NYC. We lingered and took our time and spent a little over an hour up there. I would love to take my kids next time. Neat exhibit.

The most impressive observatory in New York. There are three important observatory in New York, and for me this one is the best. The elevator telling the New York's history was impressive at the beginning, the video before being introduced to the view was incredible, and the view itself (luck me) was clean. Everything was comfortable for family with children.

Top price for top view. State of the art presentation and cool elevator ride, but too expensive. No line when we went on a Thursday due to $32 cost. Then they try to rent you an iPad for $15 and take your photo like at Empire State Building for more. Shame on making money off others misfortune. Don't know how a family does it.
New observation deck. The new observation deck has opened in the Freedom tower and the view really is spectacular though I don't understand why people feel the need to applaud a view...!!

Astonishing Re-development & Very Classy Memorial. I have not been in this area since 2008, but I was extremely impressed with the revitalization and development of the new Freedom Towers and 911 Memorial. It is a huge undertaking the amount of work done to show respect to the fallen lives on 9/11 and moving forward to making this area the symbolism of financial freedom in America. Visited July 2015

Same view as Empire State, don't bother with the restaurant. Although the view was beautiful, you can see the same from the Empire State Building, and be outside. After watching what amounts to a lot of city street scenes, you are ushered out and made to wait for a pitch to have you rent an ipad that lets you know what you are looking at. Then down through the restaurant area, and down again to the viewing area. We were looking forward to having a drink and a bite to eat, thinking that with it being a new attraction and where it was, it would be quite the experience. After waiting 15 minutes for someone to even approach us, we ordered Bloody Mary's and something to eat. 12 minutes later (I set the timer on my phone just to see as being waited on seemed to be taking a long time) we were told that they didn't have any bloody marys, and the salad I wanted wasn't available We decided to pass on the eating in the clouds experience, and went to the section where you can either pick up a sandwich or order a flat bread. The staff seemed like they had no idea what was going on or how to take care of the customers. We again decided to pass and headed down to the viewing area. A lot of people, many sitting on the window ledges just hanging out. All in all it was a huge disappointment. I would recommend the museum, and for the view go to the Empire State Building.

Amazing view but...... We pre-booked tickets for the One World Observatory so did not have to queue for long to get in. The security was tight and the lifts up to the viewing deck were fast and smooth with "views" of New York evolving through the decades. The views from the top were amazing even though we were there on a grey humid day, the whole of New York stretches out before you. We were lucky though, 3 hours later the cloud had descended so I can't imagine you could see anything from the top.Downsides.....the cafe and the souvenir shop were overpriced (for example: a postcard of the Observatory cost $4.95+tax). We were ignored by the counter staff in the cafe who were more interested in chatting amongst themselves than serving us and the muffin/tea we eventually purchased were expensive. There was also nowhere to sit to enjoy said snack, you could stand at a table but not sit, they obviously don't want you to linger over your refreshments to enjoy the view further.So I would recommend the One World Observatory, the views are spectacular and different to those from the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock (we have done both) but save your money and spend it once back in the city rather than at the Observatory.

Amazing Presentation. Get your tickets online to save time. (Pricey but worth it.) Read the directions and get there just a little early. (If you are there too early, you can't go in.)
