Arrived at 1:30 for a 2:00 and walked right in. Presentation was amazing from the point that we walked in. You walk through bedrock, see artfully done video presentations about the construction and what it meant to everyone involved as they were part of rebuilding from 9/11. Then came the elevator ride (102 stories in a minute; watching a video of New York being built and unfolding from nothing.) At the top, the view was amazing. Even the elevator ride down (simulating a helicopter dropping down and circling the tower on the screens) was great. This is not JUST any scenic overlook. It was professionally put together for the whole trip. Lots of folks mention the expensive photographs and Ipads. Keep walking if you don't want them. We got 2 Ipads (buy 1 get 1 free) and enjoyed the tours and content.

So positive and hopeful!. Our visit to One World Observatory was flawless. I purchased my tickets on my phone three hours before our visit, and I was able to reserve a time-slot and move straight to the front of the line when we arrived! I lived in NYC when 9/11 happened and moved out of the city shortly thereafter. I hadn't been back since the new tower was built. This experience was positive and hopeful, not at all what I had braced myself for. I was expecting to shed many a tear over the loss of the Twin Towers. I was happy to find the memorials and museum served that purpose, and that the One World Observatory focused more on hope for the future. Well done.

Amazing and emotional all at once. There are just no words that can describe this place...Even though the view was dismal because of the horrible weather that New York had, it was still breathtaking, I have done Top of the Rock and this one is so much better

Awesome building and view. Its fantastic and the view is marvelous.Just a quick note, it has a Disney snaking line type of layout to get in and a silly, jam you in a room video at the beginning. You will need to suck up the 15 minute of line and video but it is well worth the time to get into the actual observation deck.

Fantastic View. This was worth it. It was easy to buy tickets on-line with a smart phone. Get the expedited price - well worth it. The elevator ride up 102 floors was in an instant - couldn't tell we were moving. The view was outrageously incredible. Would go again.
GREAT EXPERIENCE. Unbelievable experience...beautiful views...only knock on this is the restaurant.... it's extremely expensive...Wanted to buy some souvenirs but won't pay for a $35 t-shirt.

Awesome Views!!. Visited the observatory last night. We went after 7 so that we could see NYC by day and then by night(about 8:30). Went with friends from overseas. We all especially loved the elevator ride up, showing you New York through the ages,from the 1500s to present. Experience it! You won't be disappointed.

See The Futher. Purchase your tickets in advance to save you time in a line. The elevator ride to the top is very fast, but when you get inside the open window viewing is like no other. Vast distance and landmarks can be seen. There is a gift shop and a restaurant at the top.

360 degree view. I was very eager to visit One World Observatory - so keen I made my reservation in the UK before even arriving in New York! We had a timed entry which meant we walked straight in at our appointed time; there's the usual airport style security before you enter. As other reviewers have noted it is a bit like a theme park ride, following a clear path with clips about how the building was constructed, which makes it dramatic and extends the time you spend there but I must admit I would have preferred to get straight into the lift. That said it's all done extremely well. When you board the lift there's a fantastic history of New York explained in the short time it takes to get to the top, then you have to wait before the view is revealed. As you exit you are corralled to get your photo taken and offered an iPad reference guide ($15 I believe). If that's not for you, there's no pressure to partake. We had a beautiful sunny day and the views were incredible, they are on 2 levels and guides are on hand to advise on different aspects of New York eg culture. There are a couple of eateries, but unless you go for the table service restaurant, you have to stand to eat. We got around this by having a drink at the bar with a delicious cheese plate - and of course the magnificent views. There is a large gift shop area with souvenirs for all budgets. When you descend, there is a different experience in the lift. It's good value and there's no pressure to rush.

Not to be missed. I visited here twice during my recent stay in NYC. The first was on a Sunday morning arriving at the ticket office at 9.40am. I requested a single adult ticket for $32. Curiously I was then told the first ticket available was for 9.30am which I gladly accepted meaning I could go straight down to the entrance and security checks. With only a handful of people in front of me I was soon through the airport style checks and was able to enjoy the video wall displays. Having watched these it was into a lift (with more video walls) to floor 102. The See Forever display was all part of the experience with a climatic end ( no spoilers!). Having bypassed the slightly irritating attempts to offer iPad tours and a cheesy photo I was into the two floors at the top. Great views of the surrounding area which shouldn't be missed. Sadly all behind glass which does make photography difficult but not impossible. On the Sunday morning it was relatively quiet. The Tuesday evening visit around sunset was much busier. Having said that after booking for 8pm on my iPhone I then arrived at 7.30pm to find I could go straight in. At the top, with the sun setting after 8pm most people sat by the windows so opportunity to get a good view / photo opportunity were initially limited. The windows also showed the handprints of all that day's visitors which I hadn't noticed at my previous visit. Although not used there is also a cafe at floor 102 together with restrooms. A very enjoyable experience well worth a trip to the top at the right time for the standard admission price of $32.
Don't Miss It. I had an unforgettable visit to this area. Not to be missed when you are in New York City. It is almost over whelming in a respectful way.

Hard to believe. We we here for the tenth Aniversey of 9-11 and it was very traumatic at that time but now that the 9-11 museum and Memorial is open it becomes a reality that you will never see again. It is well worth your time to pay tribute to the ones who lost their lives and the servisors. Just seeing the artifacts in the museum will remind you what a great country we live in and that we will stand together for our Country.

Great view but..... So the views are awesome. But... unexpectedly surly staff and too many attempts to separate you from your money. Cost is already high just to get in and after you get to the top and the big reveal, they try to cram you into a tiny space and rent you an iPad to "enhance" your visit. Fine if you want it but they make you sit through their spiel in a room not designed to hold the people they are cramming in. Then... they try to take your picture and sell you that too. Really!!! you just did this big reveal and then they slow you down and accost you as aggressive as any panhandler you've ever encountered. Also, in this brand new building they have set up temporary lines outside in the hot hot sun to line up and get tickets. The summer was awful, imagine the rain and the winter. They have got to figure out a better queue system. I can't tell you how much these things took away from what would otherwise be a Terrific visit.

What a view. Went up to the observation deck , what a view. Starts with a video of the story of the tower and the Manhattan skyline, then the screens go up and you see the real thing. Breathtaking, if you thought the views from the shard were good wait til you see these
stands out from the rest. nice building. you can't miss it. in fact it is visible from various spots of NYC. looks even more elegant at night, with all its lights on.

awesome but overpriced. the observation deck does provide a brilliant view of the city from the very top. and if you go at night time, it is like descending into space and watching the stars shine below you. in fact, even the elevator ride and the short presentation before the entry on deck were awesome. but i do feel that the place was overpriced. imagine going in a family of 4 - 2 parents & 2 kids. it'll be like a small holiday - without food and souvenirs - as they are overpriced too.

The World at your feet. I visited the Freedom Tower with my adult daughter and my spouse. The tour experience is very organized and well controlled with lots of security and guides who were very friendly and helpful. Beginning at the base of the building you will find yourself moved by the video presentation which are extremely well produced and evocative. The elevator ride to the top is amazing. You will never forget it and I could do it over and over again. NYC unfolds all around you from it's early beginning to present day. I felt like a molecule in the center of all that growth and change. When you get to the top you are asked to line up and view another extremely well produced video and then, presto, you are looking out the windows at a magnificent view, really breathtaking. The next room you are ushered into is where it gets dicey. The minute you enter the room where many employees are waiting you get that feeling one often gets on the streets in NYC and other cities...you are about to be hustled. They want you to rent the IPADs.....at 15.00 each, which are pretty cool, but the hustle, the pitch, is somehow demeaning of what that place stands for. As you moved into the next area there are a couple of places to get food and drink, but they are not special or really deserving of the history of that spot. So, finally, you enter the observation room which is in a ring around the entire top of the building. The view is, as you might imagine, astounding. All in all, well worth the price of admission with a caveat. Please take away the hustle factor, this place is like a shrine, a testament to a terrible event and all the brave and terrified people that died there. It is a monument to the spirit of Americans, don't cheapen that.
Majestic icon. Everybody should visit the observatory and enjoy the 360 degree view of the city and even the statue of liberty and all the bridges in the east river

The Herd. I had purchased a ticket for 10:00 am but I arrived at 8:30 am. Although there were few customers there at that time of day, they would not let me in until 10:00. So I sat and watched as other people arrived, bought tickets, and walked right in. When my time came I took the number 5 elevator as directed and found myself in a herd of people. When the herd reached the right size we were forced to watch a video showing flashes of people in New York City doing things like skateboarding. When the video was over, the herd was moved down the trail to an area where we were forced to listen to a sales presentation about renting Ipads. After that we were allowed to walk free to the restaurant and the observatory beyond.
Incredible sight. what an amazing building. It is something you must see in real. Kudos to the architect. this is simply brilliant art.

one World Trade Centre. Not able to access the viewing area as the building was covered in fog. But, the area that is dedicated to those who lost their lives is very moving....not a sound can be heard. It is an amazing memorial & so beautifully presented.
Best skyline on a clear day.. Great view on a clear day. Buy tickets in advance when you already have reasonable forecast., saves a long line.

Fantastic and well-recommended but BEWARE.... The price is OK and you get a fabulous 360 view of lower-mid Manhattan, and can see all the landmarks, as well as Brooklyn, Ellis Island, etc. However, there are two things that make this not a number one hit. One - the view is through glass. Two - you can not see Central Park at all. This said, you get value for money in other ways. It is extremely well done and properly organised. You get a proper tour as they inform you bit by bit on your way up how the city changed, etc., through presentations, and other exhibits. Still recommend it highly!

Great view but watch out for the gauntlet of over commercialization. I am a New Yorker and live in New York City. I brought visitors from out of town to the 9-11 Memorial and to the Observation Deck of Freedom Tower. It felt like a Disneyland ride and I felt like I was in the waiting area for Space Mountain or Pirates of the Caribbean on the way to the elevators. The elevator ride up is interesting since you are surrounded by walls of video screens that portray the skyline from the beginning to current time.You get off and you have no choice but to watch a movie. It again felt like Disneyland to the point where the guy inside said "please go to the left and fill all available space". They showed a cheesy New York moment video that was all flash. Then the video screens lift and you get to see real skyline for 25 seconds or so and the screens start down again and they tell you to exit to the right. They should leave it up at least until you get out of there. Then you are directed to an area where they are taking canned photos...for $19,99 against a horrible backdrop that isn't even interesting to prove you were there? They tell you to all stop. Don't stop unless you want that photo. I mean this AGAIN feels like Disney. But wait...not done yet. You get to another area and this woman is again telling everyone to STOP. Why you might ask? They are going to give you a spiel on the Ipad tour for $19,99. I asked the woman do we really NEED to stop or are you just giving us a sales pitch? Sales pitch.You don't need to stop if you don't want to get those things.They need a bypass so you don't need to watch the movie and they really need to stop making everyone stop for the 2 "buy this" spiels.Once you get through all of that it's a fantastic view. Make sure to walk all the way around to see Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island (with a great view of the Statue of Liberty, New Jersey. Take your time and enjoy. You have earned it. I wish there was way to get there without feeling like you are going through Disneyland and a sales gauntlet.The elevator ride down is also fun. They show a moving 360 view of what it looks like outside the Freedom Tower.
Must See. You must see site of trade center. Its a lovely site for remembrance of the lifes that was lost on that day. America stand strong

Top of the City. It is not just a place to see surrounding landscape of New York from 100th floor, It is something more. Almost in a minute the state of the art elevator takes the visitor to the 102nd floor. The view & experience inside the elevator is also something to remember. At 102nd floor there is a two-minute panoramic video presentation on New York City life - which is wonderful in content and technique. The observatory offers 360 degree view of the city covering Empire State Building, Statue of Liberty as well as New Jersy on the other bank of Hudson. It is a great experience spotting tall structures from the top as we are used to look up at them from the streets.

Wonderful Experience & View. This was by far the best observatory in NYC! It is a complete experience. The waiting queue has videos and tells the story of building One World Observatory. The elevator ride (up and down) is fascinating! The ride up shows NYC growing through the years (3 walls are complete digital screens). The ride down shows a ride around NYC. When you exit the elevator, there is a short movie with a remarkable reveal of the view. The observatory is completely enclosed, and you view through glass. 102 floors up, and I felt a lot more comfortable being indoors! Yes the lines can be long. We went one a Sunday afternoon with a group of 5. The ticket line was long, so I used my iPhone to purchase tickets immediately. We walked right inside and down to the waiting lobby for our 2:45pm time. As soon as it was 2:45, they began taking us through security. There were no lines from there!Do NOT plan on buying food at the top! They wanted $7 for a gatorade.

THE BEST THING IN NEW YORK. From being in a very upsetting area with the 9/11 memorial comes new life. It was by far and away the best experience of the whole trip and blows the empire state building out of the water. Everything is so clean and the experience is phenomenal, especially the moment before you enter the observatory. Gift shop is a little pricey . You have to visit, its awesome

A must for those visiting the 9/11 memorial. This was very impressive. It is taller than the original towers and very sleek. The views from the top are breathtaking and you can hire a tablet that identifies all of the visible landmarks.
Best views ever. i was blown away. Nothing sitting at home on a couch can give you. A must do! Worth every penny. Hate knowing why it's here so take a minute and give a little prayer

Well thought out! But, a few things you should know. The views are spectacular and the way they present everything is great. Buy your ticket online ahead of time and be sure to get the PRIORITY tickets. We got to bypass about an hour and a half worth of outside and inside lines because of it. People that were trying to buy tickets on location were told to buy them on their phones.My biggest sway from the experience is their giftshop. They have wonderful items, awesome staff, a great creative variety of items, availability of items, BUT THEIR $3.9 BILLION MORTGAGE IS INFLUENCING IT. A basic T-Shirt is $35. Magnets $5. Photo print posters $60+. Be sure to be prepared to not find seating anywhere unless you are in the fine dining restaurant. Everywhere is standing room only which leaves many resolving to sitting on the window ledges which blocks others from getting close enough to see down and take pictures. Their food area has two options. There is a casual "walk up to counter" service and a "table/server" area. The walk up area offers a limited amount of pre-made / warm up in oven sandwiches. Cost is about $15 a person / meal. The walk up food is ok. It is similar to the lunch shops found around the city panini,sandwiches, flatbreads, wraps. When it comes to where you eat, they have high tables without chairs for you to stand and eat from. The dining room will cost about $40-50 a person and it offers much more fine dining. There isn't a wait to get in so you should be fine to just walk up and get a table. Be sure to go there and enjoy it. As always with any experience, my conditions of encounter might not be the same as yours. Things can change as time goes on, survey responses come in, and crowds increase/decrease. Hope this helps!!

Spectacular Views. The newly-opened observation deck is spectacular. Staff is courteous and helpful. Merchandise is over priced and food options are limited. Come for view and the overall experience (especially the elevator rides), but eat elsewhere.

Just do not waste your time up there. Very disappointing. Nothing special about this place, lots of bla bla for a view that is not as great as the Empire State. Yes it is high, very high, but the atmosphere feels cold without a soul. There are so many other places to see in NY that are much better than that.

Unparralled experience on a clear day. With a flex day pass (for those of us not wanting to be on a precise schedule, with the premium well worth the price) entry was effortless, going to the front of the line, bypassing the long line. Had the opportunity to see all of New York on a clear day. Lots of interactive activities up there for a family to enjoy. Attraction is immaculate and well done. There is even a bar with a view... A serious and fun attraction that was a treat.

Not the best views of Manhattan. I agree with other reviewers who describe the One World Observatory as crowded and commercial. That being said, the visit was smooth thanks to how visitors are herded (for lack of better word) through it all in a very organized and mostly friendly fashion. The fact that I had booked my ticket online on beforehand probably helped reduce waiting time. The much talked-about elevator rides were neat but not exceptional. The views from the 102nd floor are not as great as the views you get from the Empire State Building or from Top of the Rock.In short, if you're only going to do one visit like this, to get great views of Manhattan and its beautiful skyline, then I would recommend either of those two instead of One World Observatory. However, if you're a frequent and recurring visitor such as myself, who've done Empire State and Rock several times, then by all means try something new and go here at least once.

Incredible Views - Cool Experience. We booked a VIP trip to the top of the World Trade Center, which gave us a set time to take the elevator up. In actuality, the time is a guideline; as we arrived early and went up ahead of our scheduled time. The VIP pass avoided a very long line waiting to ride up. The elevator ride goes fast, as a video is shown on all of the elevator walls depicting the history of what NYC would have looked like through time. Once at the top, we ate lunch at the restaurant up top (no reservations - jus show up). The food was only slightly overpriced, but not bad. It was mostly high end burgers and sandwiches. They had a good (not great) beer menu. A number of folks seemed to like the idea of enjoying a good beer while taking in the views. You can view out all the way around (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Statue of Liberty, New Jersey, etc.). We did not do the tablet rental that told you what building/history you were looking at, but we saw some folks that rented them. This is definitely a bit touristy, but it is a cool experience that you can't do anywhere else. We enjoyed it and recommend it.

Best view of New York city. I did not want to leave. The view from the observation deck is incredible. The elevator ride to the top was wonderful. The employees are knowledgeable and friendly. I loved it here. Well worth the cost.
What a view!. Went at 10am and there were no queues - straight in and into the lift which was an experience in itself. The views are amazing!

What an amazing experience. Wonderful experience. Touching. I am proud to be an American. I would recommend anyone visiting New York for the first time (or their first visit to One World) visit this. Breath taking.

The Tallest Skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere!. It was exciting and, at the same time, sad visiting One World Trade Center. It is the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere! Liked the waterfall, commemorating the victims of the 9/11 terror attack.

Emotional but beautiful. My sister and I walked over from Battery Park. The dual pools are breathtaking and the park area has many areas to sit and reflect. We did not spend a lot of time here as it started to pour. But very glad I came. I hope to get back and take a tour.

Fabulous Views, Moving Memorial. Went to observation level a few weeks after it opened - it was breath taking albeit that they hadn't quite got their organisation sorted out and entry was a little chaotic. Moving to see memorial at ground zero too.
Great View. Great View! Skip the restaurant-way over priced and you can get better food in the city. Try to go on a clear day.

A lift to a view not to be missed!. We didn't know that this tower was open for business until we visited the 9/11 Museum, if we'd known, we would have fit it in at the same time. As it was, I ordered tickets online later in the day and we visited it the following day. Again, what an experience - from the immersion cinema style lift to the absolutely breathtaking observatory on the 102nd floor. The lift was something else! You had no sensation of movement - until your ears popped - and the entire journey from basement to floor 102 took approximately 45 seconds! This is a real 'finger' to the terrorists and tells the rest of the world that America will not be beaten! Absolutely amazing.

Just Okay. This is expensive for what you get. The views are spectacular if you can get near a window to see. We had 4pm tickets, the place was crowded, there is nowhere for anyone to sit so people sat in the window wells (with their backs to the view) so you could not approach any of the areas to really soak in what was in front of you. You are stopped as a group on a few occasions - once for photos against a screen of NYC (you can just bypass this but it involves walking through it) then stopped again for a "presentation" which is really just trying to get you to spend more money on renting iPads that give you an overview of the view. Installing plaques with descriptions could work just as well and at $32 a ticket to keep asking people to "add on" is ridiculous. If I was going for a true NYC view experience I would say go to The Top of the Rock where you can at least see the scope of Central Park. The elevators going up and down with the videos that play was the best part of the experience. Sorry but I was disappointed in the whole event.

Stunning view. It began with an amazing elevator ride, which took about 47 seconds to the top floor. A short film is shown after your arrival on the top floor and by the end of it you can see the stunning view of New York ! The view is beautiful. Oh and there is even free wifi ! It was really amazing and I'm really happy I went there.

What a ride! What a view!. The system for getting tickets is excellent. Get yours online and avoid waiting in the line! Security was excellent and quick. The elevator ride is unique and the views are spectacular!

Spectacular!. This is a must see! The view is incredible and be sure to take your time and take it all in. Wonderful presentation of its' history. Best views are on a bright and sunny day. Be sure to spend the few extra dollars and get the VIP tickets. You are escorted to the front of the line avoiding the long wait lines.

Great view!. What a view!! We made reservations prior to the opening and were among the first 300,000 to visit. The line inside winds around (like a Disney line) but there are murals telling the stories of the people who were a part of its building and this makes the time pass quickly. I don't think I would pay extra for the express/fast ticket because you would miss these stories. Once up top, it is kind of like any other high tower -- you can see for miles if the weather and visibility is right.

One World Observatory. Amazing! (despite the queue). Lift 'show' on way up is fascinating and very well done. The 'big reveal' of the view is breathtaking. Actual observation floor is vast and airy so you don't feel crowded or rushed. Cafe was mobbed. Gift shop good and tasteful stuff.An excellent hour spent. Very moving to look straight down onto the 9/11 memorial.
Very emotional.. I visited the two pools and it was very emotional. Seeing what has been done with this space, it was a great way to honour the victims.
Beautiful Manhattan views. Worth the money. Buy your tickets prior to visiting, and enter through the concourse to skip long lines. Will make you proud of American perseverance.
Spectacular. The observatory is only half of the attraction. Before , during and after the elevator ride are great experiences.

Crowded and commercial. . The lift ride to the top was the best bit. If you want to see the best Manhattan skyline do Top of the Rock or Empire State.You are herded like cattle up to the first level where you are made to wait for a short speech which is actually a long ad for the iPad guides. You are then herded to where you wait for your turn to have a 'no obligation' photo taken against a green screen picture of Manhattan. You can't skip either of these 'no obligation' moments.Because the viewing is all indoors it is very difficult to take a good photo that balances the inside/ outside light properly through the glass.Do the 9/11 museum below but skip the observatory at all costs.

Great place to visit but you should know...... It was a great place to visit and great views. I booked online which reduced waiting time and the whole visit ran well.Highlights - waiting time not too long. Elevator gave a great story about New Yorks development and would love to see it again. The stunning view and the lead up to it was great. I thought the whole thing was well organised and not Too many people that you didn't get a turn looking at the view. There is a really good introduction to to the view.Low points - we waited for about 20 minutes before we went in. About 5 minutes waiting for the elevator. About 20 minutes standing waiting for the theatre show and watching the theatre show. Then standing in line for the obligatory photo etc. My husband has limited mobility and finds standing a problem so we really needed somewhere for him to sit and they didn't cater for that. Prices at the shop and restaurant seemed far too high. I prefer top of the rock as you are outside for photos whereas the fingerprints on the glass, reflections, people using flash made photography limited.A must place to visit.

The best part of the visit was at the very top on the observatory level 102.. Me and my family enjoyed the observatory level 102 this was the coolest part. We really enjoyed the twin towers as it was out in the open whereas this was indoor. One suggestion would be to serve visitors with a snack or refreshment very unique to New York City which will attract more visitors/tourist from outside of the country. Something really famous from New York and will enjoy their tour to the Freedom Tower. Tourist/Visitor will always remember that he/she was served .......during their visit to the Freedom Tower in NYC.

Spectacular views but less sales please.... Spectacular, of course, but mobbed, hard to make reasonable reservations and staff pushes too many offers. Good visibility at top though (use the ground floor restrooms...much faster!).
Incredible. This is a must see. The whole area is full of history old and new. Walk around this area and take it all in.

Worth the cost. We splurged on pre purchased Priority Tickets, well worth it! We walked past the line of people waiting to buy tickets, then took the escalator down, turned right at the bottom, and walked right up to the screening area - they have a separate screening area for Priority ticket holders, no wait, and we walked right past the huge lines and into a waiting elevator. The elevator itself is a marvel, as you ascend it shows you the skyline from hundreds of years ago (under water) to present time. Then you exit into a small hallway, and they open the screen for your first view of the skyline. Eye popping! The views were phenomenal - as were the crowds. It was sometimes difficult to get a place at the windows. Also, after you see your first glimpse of the skyline, they funnel you down stairs and hawk interactive ipads for $15. We barely used ours. Worth the expense, you can't get a better view in the country.

Stunningly Beautiful . It's our first visit with my bestie, just have your ticket online so you don't have to wait a long line, so I bought our tickets online, by the time went there just go straight to the entrance door, just one ride with the elevator with a beautiful digital view, and stops on the top, that's it, just one ride and your in 102 floor already.. The view is so spacious stunningly beautiful view, I love our first visit.
Stunning, dramatic presentation of NYC. Wow! Well worth the price to travel to the top. Dramatic presentations and a magnificent tribute to help us remember those who perished that day...

One World Experience. Not what I was expecting - views are amazing and the experience is great - from the organized way in getting tickets to getting on the worlds fastest elevator, the ride on the elevator and show at the top of the tower.

Nice but expensive. Fast elevators and good logistics makes the queues smaller than expected on a sunday. Nice view. But this is rather expensive for a short glimpse of the skyline when you are a family.

There are not adequate words.... My husband and I went into One World Observatory at night. About 9pm on a Saturday. I loved seeing the city at night time and the crowds were small, so we really got to take our time and enjoy it. More so than the panoramic views of Manhattan (which were breathtaking, BTW), we were touched by the testimonies of the workers and other people involved in the building of this amazing building. It was very special to us, as was the memorial pools. The elevator ride to the top was phenomenal as well. Cost was $32.00 apiece. We did not mind paying it, as it was well worth it! Next time we go up to NYC we will do the museum - - we just ran out of time this time, and plus with the crowds and heat we thought Fall may be a better time to do it. But I will say, do not miss going up into One World Observatory! As I said, there are not really adequate words to describe it!

Amazing - MUST SEE. We visited this and the cost is the same as the Empire State Building but MUCH better ... the elevator ride is so quick and the view is unreal. You are so high up you can actually start to see the curve of the earth > CRAZY !

Superb - with some caveats. It is indeed thrilling to be able to see the city (I am a native) from this vantage point again. I do wish it had an outdoors option as well (you can't have everything) - as there is considerable reflection in the windows, which shows up in one's photos. I made some of the vendors laugh when I asked if they sold Windex: I would have loved to clean the windows myself - grubby fingerprints and smudges everywhere. I imagine that early in the day they are cleaner (we got there at 5:15PM). Is it better than the ESB or Top of the Rock? Hard to compare - they all have their plusses. From the latter you see all of Central Park, and the ESB. The elevator is a wonder at 50 seconds, and the coup de theatre after the initial presentation merits the applause it receives big time.

Hopefully it's much better now. I attempted a visit within a week or so of the viewing platform being opened. I was put in a queue which turned out to be the wrong one. I was then sent to three different parts of the precinct and eventually back to my original queue, at which point I gave up and walked home.I expect better things when I try again.

One World Trade Center - Words cannot describe. Took an afternoon out of my schedule to do this. Been watching the tower be built for years.Take the subway if you are anywhere in town (A-C-E trains). Words cannot describe the feeling, the views, the experience.I recommend day time viewing for first round. Food and drink at top along with great views, history, insights. The Apple tablet is a good option for your first time.

Wow. Very efficient getting up there with a pre-booked time. (Why don't they do this at ESB?). They do a fantastic initial reveal and the view is spectacular. Highly recommended as its the best view and value in Manhattan.

Better than Empire State Building. I've been to the Top of the Rock and to the top of the Empire State Building, but the One World Observatory is the most enjoyable. The special effects in the elevator and the dramatic close to to the introductory video is spectacular...not to mention the view!!

Something different (Spectacular) for a tower visit!!!. My family visited this observatory in the month of July 2015. I booked our tickets online for early morning slot and were back to the street within 1.5 hour. We were happy that we do not have to stand in lines for hours as we have an infant. I have visited almost 4/5 towers across globe and each one has their uniqueness. Best part of this attraction was the elevator and the show just before the observatory deck. This fastest elevator takes you to the top with video view of the city. The show just before the observatory deck is an innovative idea where you get the glimpse of the city that never sleeps and then the complete 360 aerial view of the city. Mesmerizing and highly recommended!!!

One World Observatory. The architecture and the view are simply FANTASTIC !!! Definitely, something to do by night. The schedule was on time. The lift takes 47 seconds to bring you to the top (100 floors and 1,776 feet). Be ready to enjoy the most incredible attraction of NYC. BRAVO to those who contributed to it !!!!!Bakhtina57

Ok but badly organised. The views are great but you are inside and can't go outside like other skyscrapers. They have a lot of windows you can't see out of so everyone is hearded together looking out of a few windows.

It made me wish I was an American!. No spoiler alerts here…you have to go to experience the elevator ride and the opening theatre. we went on a sunday evening at 7. We purchased the express pass but it was unnecessary. There were no lines at all. Everything was done to the highest level (no pun intended!) and after the Sky Theatre experience our whole group burst into cheer and applause and my boyfriend (from Canada) said "It made me wish I was an American!" The views are amazing and the interactive iPad was very cool, though headphones would be a welcome addition. Another note on the iPad…one per group is plenty and they are a little shaky on the calibration. I was often facing with my back to a sight in order to get it to show up on the screen…no big deal, just letting you know!

Best view of Manhattan. The staff is very well organized and the whole experience is pleasant ... from buying the tickets to the elevator ride to the view! Definitely buy tickets online because the line was pretty long. They have timed admissions and it really spreads out the crowds so you don't wait in any line for very long. Getting there is easy on the Subway. It took us about an hour to go through, but you could stay longer. If you're not familiar with NY landmarks, they rent a fun, interactive iPad map for $15 to help you locate them. Food available but expensive -- $5.00 for bottled water.
Amazing!!!!!. It really has the WOW factor. It's a must for awesome views of New York State. A fantastic experience and excellent staff.

All you could hope for.. Went to the observation deck in early July. Get tickets ahead of time, it will be much easier. I remember going to the top of the Twin Towers several times as a kid, but the view from inside the Freedom Tower was amazing. I was slightly worried, because the Towers, had an outside observation deck, while this was inside but it did not detract from the experience at all. It is sometimes difficult to get that "perfect shot" cause a window beam would be in the way but no big deal. The elevator up took 60 seconds and was the coolest elevator I have been on, but I wont ruin the surprise. Even though I am familiar with many of the NYC landmarks, I still shelled out the $15 for the device that tells you what everything is and gives you a birds eye view of them. The devices image rotates with your point of view and is pretty cool even though I had to re calibrate it probably around 8x (not a big deal). The view from the top is amazing, and on a somewhat hazy day, you could still see the GW bridge about 10 miles away. You get amazing views of the downtown area including the Brooklyn Bridge, Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Jeresy City, and of course the entire skyline. If you are coming to NYC, I would say this is a must do activity. My nephew who was my tour guide is from Brooklyn, and he enjoyed it just as much as me. My only minor complaints are that it seemed a bit to crowded, the optional presentations are a tad to cheesy, and I guess its to be expected but the prices at the gift shop were beyond preposterous. Anyway, if you are going to the Big Apple, go for it. Try to get the tickets before hand, and try to plan your trip on a fairly sunny day.

Inspiring!. Pay close attention to the narrative that plays as you make your way from the ground floor into the elevators for your trip up to the observatory floors. It's very clear that the folks who helped to build this wonder invested a big part of themselves in the endeavor. It's truly an inspiring place and, along with the memorial and museum, a place that all Americans need to visit. We'll never forget our day here.

Great view of NYC!. Great way to see the whole city! Customer service was awesome as well.The best way to visit this attraction is to get there ahead of time, have a bite to eat at Brookfileld Place in Le District. Then go through the mall via the escalator and get to the entrance approximately 15 minutes before your ticketed time, and miss the lines in the direct sun out front.

Worth it. Great views naturally, and the lift is incredible and has a great video projected on the walls around you so "Manhattan through time" is shown on the way up while on the way down you see what it would be like to descend, spiralling outside the building. The opening display about the construction of the building is perhaps a little too schmaltzy for non-American tastes.I wouldn't bother with the iPad you can hire especially if you know even a little about the buildings in NYC: Save yourself $15.
Incredible!. Tip - you can get an Express Pass and bypass the lines for $54 pp. Worth the wait to see this stunning building with 360 degree views of the city.

Not to Be Missed. We combined this attraction with a visit to the 911 Museum. Both are not to be missed in New York City. The One World Observatory is organized extremely well, and the views are beyond memorable. We booked a 11:00 am admission; arrived a bit early and they let us go in at 10:30.

Iconic. It shines through and visible from miles in all directions. It almost looks like a church steeple, with diamond facets. The Memorial around is a sombre reminder of the dreaded past, even as this building soars towards the sky with hope. Excellent offices and easy to get to with many subway lines around.

Great . Loved the lift up and down (Charlie and the great glass elevator anyone?). Views from the top spectacular. We got the interactive screens you can rent for $15..fun although you do have to reset it quite often. You can book online to avoid the que but wasn't too bad the day we went and we got in quick enough. Great way to spend a couple of hours.

Amazing experience, amazing view. I have been to NYC a bunch of times and I have been up at 30 Rock and ESB a bunch of times as well...but the new WTC Observatory really nails it as far as experiences go. The timed entry with almost no wait (in and out in 30 minutes!), the great elevator experience, amazing video intro (the ending is what makes it happen) and the fantastic views of the city probably make this the best "observation deck" experience in the city. Completely worth every penny.

Been There, Done That. Yes, it's expensive for what you get.Don't bother to rent the ipad thingy. It's bulky, cumbersome, heavy and doesn't really add to the experience.You need to be really lucky to get a crystal clear day to really appreciate the views. There was only slight mist when we were there, so not bad I suppose.The glass is not non reflective and covered in smugged fingerprints so depending on your camera, you will be lucky to get clear photos."exit through the gift shop" is never more true. You have to struggle through this to get to the elevatorIt's not the sort of experience you want to linger over. It's really crowded, so views are a snapshot, before someone planks themselves infront of you to do a "selfie"Glad we did it, but been there. Done that. Didn't buy the T shirt

TURN OFF THE LIGHTS!!!!!!. I went at night at 11pm. You are indoors and not outside. There is too much light to see through the windows and take pictures. It is frustrating. If they turned off the lights at the observatory, it would be a much more enjoyable experience. The Empire State Building is still superior as you can stand outside, instead of being stuck indoors.
Shiny & New. Pretty awesome to see the new shiny building ! last time i was in new York, we stayed at the Marriot in front of the twin towers.

WOW!. Make reservations ahead of time, even the day of so you are not waiting in a long line. Adding this to the 9/11 memorial caps an experience of continuity. The observatory provides spectacular views of the entire New York area and should not be missed
View from the ground. Did not go into this building [not sure if you can] but seen front the water and the surround streets it is truly fabulous. Worth the walk

Amazing experience. My husband and I where on our honeymoon, and loved every bit of the tour! We honestly were amazed by the great views of New York. As we where going up on the lift we never expected it could be such an amazing experience! Definitely, worth a visit. Just one suggestion, if intending to visit other buildings just go one in the morning and the other one in the evening as you get to see the place differently by night!
Amazing Views, great experience. We visited One World Observatory in July 2015 and were impressed. The elevator ride is great, the views from 100-102nd floor are amazing. Definately worth the money.
Interesting and sad. Its sad to see down at where the world trade center once stood, but its Amazing to see the view, I felt like I was on top of the world, interesting and sad

Amazing view of New York city. We were able to go up soon as as we bought our tickets. Well organised. The elevator, theatre and the observatory itself were all outstanding. Clear viewing from the wide big windows. A must experience.
The Best Observation Post in NYC. They have done this amazing. It's inspiring and innovative and the best view you'll have in the world. The presentation is beyond anything you get elsewhere.
Beautiful. Amazing view, lots of information, great view of the city and everything was great! The top after elevator ride was a great surprise. A must see!

Great experience , but not worth the extra for Priority. Went with my family and paid over $ 150 for 3 "PRIORITY" passes.WE were put in the wrong line and ended up with no real benefit.Got out of elevator and was herded to the far left while another 50 people came in to the small viewing room.After a 2 minute viewing , everyone exited from the right so we were now at the back of the line being the last ones out. Not the end of the world, but when you pay extra for something, you expect to get it!When we were finished on the main floor 100, and finished buying over priced food and gifts, we then got on the end of a long line to catch an elevator down. I asked if there was a " Priority " exit line and was told NO !If seems a very good sales pitch to get unsuspecting tourist to pay extra !I will not be recommending to anyone to pay for Priority until they know what the true meaning of the word means.

On top of the world. We were looking forward to experiencing the observatory. We were blown away. From the very beginning we were in awe. The new terminal underground is beautiful. We paid extra for the VIP tickets and skipped all the lines. The separate security line really helped. The elevator ride up is so fast you will not believe it. Once there you are given a quick presentation, the bam, you are on top of the world. This was one of the highlights of our trip so we did splurge and ate in the restaurant. Very expensive, but the view we had made the bill more tolerable. See below and enjoy.

On top of the world. This building is spectacular. My suggestion is to buy the VIP ticket. You pass all the lines and basically go straight to the top. The amount of time saved is worth the extra cost. The restaurant on top will give you a view that you will never forget.

Full review with TIPS. Good and bad... We recently took the family to do the sites and included the WTC observatory. Great thing to do when in NYC. It is iconic, patriotic and the entire World Trade Center complex is amazing to see. I think everyone that appreciates FREEDOM should go to support that area. Here are our tips:DO:1. We paid the extra $ to fast pass and avoid the line. I have heard of line nightmares there so we did it and are glad we did. If it's in your budget -it will enhance your trip.2. The elevators are incredible. Be ready to take the coolest elevator ride of your life. If you have small children - pick them up so they can see better. The entire elevator turns into a video screen that tells the story of NYCs development - while appearing like you are in glass as you ascend to the 103 floor. Incredible.3. As you get off the elevator - there is guide that will give a presentation and its worth seeing. Look for the circular video screen. It's very informative.DONT DO:1. They try to sell you an iPad based screen you can hold up and as you hold it up to the windows - it labels the buildings do you can see what you're looking at. NOT WORTH IT. Our iPad really didn't work that well and when it did it was lackluster. It ended up being the thing nobody wanted wayto even carry around. If you do get one - get ONE per family. That way you guys can pass it around when you're sick of it. LolIn the end I highly recommend it. Great presentation, and there are a few surprises I'm not giving away. Definitely more than just a view and that's a good thing. After all, a view is just a view.

Amazing with some improvement suggestions ..... This observatory tour is very well conceptualized, the highlights being the innovative elevators and goosebumps-inducing show at the top.Three suggestions - 1. Toilet tissue needs to be higher quality 2. For families travelling with senior citizens, wheelchair availability would be strongly recommended. 3. Places to sit in the observatory, without having to pay at the restaurant would be nice. Families need some hang out space to feed infants and sit.

Well done. One World Observatory is the "new" world trade centre. You can reserve a tour time online (which means you need to know exactly when you will be in the area to make your time) or you can line up when you get there. The line moves quickly and then, based on your time, you can go look at the memorial pools, grab something to eat, walk to the department store to use the bathroom, etc. The elevator ride itself is amazing even though it only takes 45 seconds! When you get off, there's a short documentary about the building which really builds the audience's anticipation for the observatory view! This was the highlight of the experience for me. The observatory itself is cool if you like looking at streets, bridges, and the tops of buildings. Based on what time you go will depend on whether or not the sun causes glare on the windows which doesn't make for great photos. There is also a restaurant and gift shop for those who want a souvenir. Having stood on top of the original World Trade Centre in May of 2001 and watched in horror 9/11 on tv in real time, they have done an exceptional job of preserving a memorial for all those that perished in the 2 buildings in the plaza (and including the names of those from the other 2 locations) and by creating an amazing "show" of rising again in the observatory tour. I was impressed.

impressive presentation. The building is beautiful....but the admission is steep plus if you purchase their photos....but the presentation is amazing. We saw the night view which is beautiful. It is indoors so no wind though...

What a View!. I worked on Wall Street when the Twin Towers were being built and completed in 1973. Many New Yorkers didn't like the overbearing towers - they didn't fit into the landscape, but eventually we all came to loved them. One World, however, was loved even before it was finished. The observatory on the 102nd floor offers a view that is awesome! The whole experience, from the ground floor to the elevator ride to the top is amazing, and the is stunning. There is a coffee shop, and restaurants for light and fine dining on 101, plus book store and gift shop, and City Pulse - an educational station, and Sky Portal, which offers a direct view of the streets below (without looking out the windows).I heard one visitor exclaim, "It's like Disneyland for adults." You will love it. And be sure to visit the reflecting pools that are located on the exact spot where the Twin Towers once stood.

Impressive from the ground up!. We were a group of 10 and got there around 6:30pm. No big line but you have to get tickets ahead of time. Nice entrance hall. Your home city appears on a giant LED world map upon entry? Elevator ride 45 sec (just the first one in empire state takes over 2 min if I remember right, then you have to change). The walls of the vator then show the historical timeline of Manhattan. Cool!

Grand Views. Was nervous about visiting the observation area of One World Trade Center but loved it. Amazingly quick ride up. Fabulous views - overall, very well done. Surprised to go right up even in the busy month of July.

Great views ( on a nice day). I went up on my first evening in New york .The elevators were great as the walls became a timelapse image of the area from the 1600's (countryside) to the building of the skyscrappers but it moved a bit too quickly to take everything in . There are 3 levels to view and there were a lot of people sitting by the windows so it was a bit difficult to take photos sometimes. The clouds drew in and we had rain so visibility was a little poor but it would be great with clear skies. The gift shop is a little expensive but overall it was very good.

Wonderful view of the city. There was hardly any line when we went on a Tuesday around lunchtime. The elevator ride up is amazing. You go up 100 floors in a minute, but at the same time the walls of the elevator are screens that show you the changes in manhattan since the 1500's. It was incredible. The view from the top is great, but it is crowded and the line to go back down on the elevator takes a while. I think I liked the view from empire state building better, but this new building is beautiful and worth visiting.

A must visit when in New York City. The park area is very beautifully laid out to show the footprint of the twin towers. Surrounded with trees and plant life to give this a sense of peace. The fountains give you time to contemplate what happened there as the names of everyone who lost their lives are engraved into the marble surrounding then fountains.The museum has two aims I think. The official side is shown in a timeline of the terrorist act and how the various departments responded. Then there is the human side and individual stories. This is more difficult to read without being affected. There is a section in the museum which warns you that it shows images that many would find to disturbing. There is a ticket system in place to ensure people have time to visit the museum but be prepared for large numbers of people as you go further into it. There are too many areas to discuss here but it's a place everyone should visit to pay their respects to those lost and their families. It also demonstrates a solidarity against the horrors of terrorism.

Incredible views of New York. A must-do experience. Once you passed the airport-style security you are taken to the 101st floor by means of an extremely fast elevator. The ride itself is part of the experience (I'm not going into the details in order not to spoil this for you).The views over New York are incredible. With hindsight we would not book the iPad guide again, but we would definitely recommend a) pre-booking tickets and b) going early in the morning.Highly recommended.
Well organised with great views. We bought tickets and could go up 30 mins before our time slot. Very well organised with really friendly staff. Recommended for all age groups.

Must see. It is definitely worth stopping by. It is not just another skyscraper secondary to the history. They have done a great job, and the views are amazing. It is something you have to do when you visit NYC.

AWESOME!. We (family of 4 with 2 kids ages 12 1/2 and 15) had 10am tickets on a Thursday. I recommend going early in the day, so that the crowds haven't started accumulating. The ride in the elevator is very cool, with the video of the changing skyline over the years. There is a short video and then a surprise reveal, but I won't spoil it. It took my breath away, so I wouldn't want to spoil it for anyone else by revealing what it is. After that, you are free to walk around the observation level. The only thing I didn't like was that it was an additional $15 for a tablet which would point out the buildings that you're seeing. However, that didn't spoil anything for us. We really enjoyed the views and took many, many pictures. We spent about an hour here and would highly recommend it. To me, it's a more spectacular view than the one you get at the Empire State Building.

Top of the World. The views are simply one of the fabulous parts of the journey to the top of the Freedom Tower. The elevator ride and the entrance have their own mini-shows that are fantastic. Still $30+ a head is no low fee, but it is something for every American to see.

Loved it!. A great experience. Views are fabulous and 360 degrees. Crowds aren't too bad due to timed entry. Buy your tickets in advance if possible. Much better than the Empire State Building we did the day before where it took 1.5 hours to get to the top with advanced tickets purchased.

Poor people management,poor design of observatory, very crowded. Visiting the observatory was a very disappointing experience. After the long and confusing queueing process, we finally got to the entrance of the observatory where too many people were packed into a small area to view a short video. I could not see the introduction due to the overcrowding. Then, the gates were opened, and like a Macy sale, everyone almost ran into the observatory area but we were still being corralled past selling points for iPads and food. Finally when I get to the viewing area, everyone was sitting or standing on the air conditioning vents around the viewing windows, and not moving. The staff made no attempt to stop people standing on the vents to take selfies. These vents were bending under the weight of some. Taking a picture was an exercise in pushing, cleaning the window and having your groin in someone's face.There is little or no sound deadening technology so the whole experience was crowded, noisy and a long way from reflective, respectful or orderly. This was the worst viewing platform experience I have ever had. Management should look at the people management strategies of the Burj Khalifa for a lesson in how to do it right.Not good value for money and not a good viewing experience.

Amazing views. Terrific views. My wife suffers from vertigo, but the layout of the observation floor is superb and she was happy throughout. It was awet day when we visited but we were lucky - the skys cleared just before we were due to go up. Otherwise it could have been a disappointment.

No place to sit. We have resided in the New York area for quite some time and use to visit the World Trade Center on a regular basis and fondly remember Windows on the World. The new observation deck is set up as a pricey tourist destination. The new observatory is more spacious that the original but there is not opportunity to go outside. The staff is not particularly welcoming or accommodating.Of course the views are wonderful.The staff is somewhat brusque. The restaurant was not open and the alternative food area was stand up only. A cup of soda is $6.00. We asked to see the menu for the sit down restaurant, and was told "you need a reservation". I told the snotty person, (who was standing around chatting) we lived in the area and might make reservations in the future. I was reluctantly given a menu. It was not an exciting menu, four courses, pre-fixe for $84.00 plus one has to pay the observation deck cost.The overall feeling of the place, is that they want to rush you through. Sort of don't stay too long or we'll sic the dogs on you.

Must Visit. I was there but the observatory wasnt open... How I wish I were there on top...Its a must visit merely for the sake of paying homage to all those who lost their lives in September 11 attack on twin towers...The whole area is also explorable and as I said... A Must Visit..!

Breath taking view. There was nothing I disliked about the One World Trade Center. The obervation deck is something that you must see to appreciate.The elevator ride is exiting. Although I did not eat, the food court made the experience more appealing. It is definitely a must see.

Worthless!!! Don't do it!! I want my money back!!!. I am so shocked at this! I should have read the reviews but I decided to go on a bit of an impulse as I was walking by at night and there were no queues. The problem is that there is no open air view! You are just surrounded by glass all the way! So basically you pay 32 dollars and can't even take a good picture! Even worse at night when the reflections of all the people ruin the view! Man I regret paying this! I am currently standing in line to take the elevator down after 15 mins of being up here. Don't do it!!!!!!!! I'm shocked at how many good reviews this has!! I want my money back!!!!!!!!!!!!! (Ps I can't even get signal up here! So you can't even use your phone to battle the boredom of waiting in line). Seriously I'm weeping for my money at this very moment!!!!!!

A must see. Breathtaking. The view was amazing. There are long lines, but for an additional cost you can get an express pass. You go to the front of each line. Even the elevator ride is amazing. This was a highlight of our trip.

Great Time,Great View. We brought Our tickets in advance online,when we got there we saw the line and we thought the worst.But the people that run this place are on the money.Everything is done in a timely manner ,the security checkpoint to the lines for the elevators.The view from the observatory area are incredible.They don't rush you out neither you can take as many pictures as you want

Best sunset view. Go get timed ticket for a ride up about an hour before sunset for the best sunset and evening view. The only negative, the vent design. Raised vent along the edge just allow people to stand or sit on the vent along the windows blocking view and access. So play the game, get there early enough to stake your spot.Perhaps installing rails or sunken vent (like old world trade center) would solve the problem.

Just another nice view. We we're so excited when we got to the observatory. The waiting line downstairs was short due to timed tickets, the elevator ride was a crazy experience as well as the presentation on the top. The view is nice, but that's it.The reflections on the windows make it impossible to get good pictures on your camera. I really prefer open platforms the TOTR or ESB. Overall, the Freedom Tower is too expensive. I guess one has to go there once in a life time, but one time is enough.

Out of this world. My family and I visited the new World Trade Center and observatory which was out of this world. There's a gift shop and restaurant plus a 360 degree view of the city. A great place to visit.

Arrival at NY early morning on a cruise. It was early morning and after sailing past Lady Liberty we were awe struck by the beauty and symbolic significance of One World Trade Centre. It was not open to the public yet but is a wonderful addition to the skyline and the sense of arrival when one gets to NY by cruise liner
Beautiful!. Beautiful building that honours the twin towers. Great architecture and is located near ground zero (twin towers memorial).

Visually and technologically stunning, but too much manufactured 'experience' for my taste.. We live in New York so waited until we had out-of-town guests to see this extravaganza at the World Trade Center. The exhibit is fantastic, the visuals and the technology are amazing, but I come away feeling underwhelmed. The $30+ dollar admission is fair considering the amount of work to create this multimedia experience, but I would much rather have lower admission price to a simple elevator and a simple observation deck. I guess that fancy experiences are common to all the tall buildings now, but for me it is unnecessary. So, the Freedom Tower. The lobby is gorgeous, simple white marble in a style pleasantly reminiscent of the old World Trade Towers. One must pass through security just like at any airport. Then, you walk through thoughtfully-created displays on your way to the elevator lobby, These displays tug at your heartstrings, looking backwards to 2001, but it is not the same as going into the separate museum.The elevator ride is a hoot, with amazing time & distance videos. I love elevators, I love heights, so I didn't need this distraction, but I'm sure that anyone with anxiety about going up a tall building will appreciate the diversion.At the top, you get herded into a fantastic (but for me unnecessary) video montage of the history and sights of NYC, a fabulous display yet I would have rather just looked out the windows at all the sights I love.Then the crowd gets herded into a room where they offer iPad experiences for rent - I'm sure that they are wonderful, but I never buy audio or video guides anywhere. I prefer to experience things real time.Down one escalator through a food and gift court, down second escalator where we finally get to see the splendor of NYC. I loved this floor. Floor to ceiling windows, unobstructed views in every direction. We could wander to our hearts' content. There are some video demonstrations but we ignored them because I just wanted to look and look at all the buildings and streets. So, the actual observation floor is absolutely fabulous, open, spacious, and beautifully designed. I could stay there for hours. All of the extra stuff leading up? I could do without it.

Awesome view, queueing system needs work. The 360 view from that high up is always going to be worth it. However, we were sold 3 tickets instead of the 2 we asked for, as it was for a set time, we were unable to get a refund of the unused ticket. You have to queue outside the building, which is not ideal in any weather. Once your time selection is finally through the doors, felt like a free for all to the jig your places in yet more queues. The lift almost makes up for it, and then you get to the top, and I shall say nothing more.

Wonderful view, but where are the benches?. This tower offers a wonderful view of the city, but for us the visit was overshadowed by the fact that, except for the restaurant on the 101st floor, there was NOT ONE SINGLE PLACE to sit down during the whole time we were there. Having paid extra for Priority access, we were able to skip the lines out front, but it was still more than an hour of standing, which was very hard for my 86-year-old husband, and I'm sure for many other visitors as well. We were told that the only way to get a wheelchair was if you were being escorted out of the building, although later—given my husband's obvious need—one was provided for us. Ironically, our visit happened on the very anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act. Clearly, there's more work to be done!

The Giffords. Our families choice of a summers vacation, was New York City. Our family experience at the NWTC, has made a forever mark on our hearts. An emotional (solemn) experience. It was most definitely at the top of our list, of the places we visited & enjoyed.

I just want to look at the view. . Disappointing overall. The One World Observatory is just that, a place to observe the view. Don't go expecting to take a decent picture. It is next to impossible with the dirty glass, reflections and people sitting along the vent ledge on the entire perimeter of the building. I've never had to work so hard for a decent photo. Plus, they will be a bit grainy since you're so high. I recommend just walking around and take it in. I bought a Flex Pass before my visit so I could go any weekday and supposedly bypass, what they call fast track, general admission. I'm not a fan of the Disney-esque herd you from one area to the next with videos and up selling so I figured it was worth the extra money. I just want to look at the view. So, I did bypass the line for the elevator however you have to queue up for a 3 minute video at the top too. Ugh. I just want to look at the view. They reveal the view after the video but you are herded to another room for the iPad up sell. Again, I just want to look at the view. Then finally you're allowed into the observatory.I will say the staff I spoke to were friendly and the views were amazing but, check the box, I won't be back. The Empire State Building and Top of the Rock were a much more pleasant experience in the open air with unobstructed photo opportunities.

beautiful building. didnt go inside but certainly worth a look outside and in the surrounding area.it's right next to the twin towers memorial and stands high and proud above it, in defiance of the awful crime that took place there in 2001.
Special. Not only amazing attraction, with high tech presentation and spectacular views, but mainly special for its history. Early morning is a good time to go and order on-line the day before.

One World Observatory . One World Observatory is 102 floors up with amazing views. The round glass observatory gives you 360 degree views from downtown. Seeing the city at night was really special. You get great views of the bridges as you look down on them. The only thing that will disappoint some is that it's hard to take pictures with the observatory being enclosed, unlike Top of the Rock that is open air. The views are worth seeing, especially at night.

Go when they first open. We booked tickets for 9am and got in line 8:20.We were 3 and 4th in line. We got to go up on the first elevator with 4 other people.We had the whole observatory to ourself for about 20 min. It was wonderful .You could see and take photos without any interruptions from others. We were there for about 1 1/2 hours. It was very crowded when we left,harder to get a window spot..See forever!!!!

Good views, but hard sell. Don't get me wrong, the views are wonderful, but it's such a hard sell. At the price you pay it seems a bit rich that you are forced to listen to a presentation to rent the iPad viewers and then to have your picture taken.The windows reflect too much of what is happening to get really crisp pictures.But the views up and down Manhattan are world class.

The best view from the south of Manhattan. Great views!! It s the perfect combination with the observatory from Top of the Rock because from the second you can see the Central Park but from One World Observatory you can see the Statue of Liberty and Brooklyn, plus the bridges and all the skyscrapers great views. I booked tickets online the day before and it worked just fine. For me, the best time to go is in the late afternoon (we were there at 6 pm and there was no line or large crowd inside) so you can see the city before and after sunset and the night lights as well: you can get two great photographs of each side of the city. We stayed until about 8.45 pm waiting for sunset in the bar with a glass of wine! What else could you need for a pleasant evening and such nice views? The worst: Don' t go for the Ipad choice, it s a waste of money. Appart from that, we didn't like the attitude of the staff who lied by shouting to the bunch of people who were coming in to grab an Ipad without explaining FIRST that you have to pay for it. Seriously, that is dishonest customer service.The best: while going up, the elevator walls show you a movie with a recreation of the city and all the changes it has gone through. (And you don't even notice the elevator is moving, so don't be afraid of going up!)All in all, worth spending 32 dollars.

Sensational! with some down side. It is impressive to be on the higher skycraper of NY. In addition the emotion of beeing in a place for a memorial.View is quite good but I prefere other building with opne air.One World has Windows that make it difficult to take picture.

Amazing experience!. The 360 degrees view of NYC blew me away. When I first saw the view, my jaw dropped and couldn't believe my eyes. Not only is the view spectacular, the beauty of the One World Trade Center was also very stunning. No words can really describe the experience. This visit was probably the highlight of my trip. This is a MUST see in NYC. You won't regret it!I went mid-day on a Tuesday. Short line-up. Not too crowded at all!

Great view over the whole city. Don't panic for the lines going in, it passes quite quickly. The staff are doing their best, but it comes out wrong every time: asking for where to buy tickets, they were sloppy showing directions and not accurate so I ended up walking back and forth until I got the right lane. A simple sign would do the job: ticket holders this lane, buying tickets that lane! How hard can it be? Security are overdoing it of course, try not to bring much electronics. Everything must out of bags. Finally up there the view is spectacular and worth the money ($32).
Group Tour. After the lost of Twin Tower from 9-11,the Americans recovered their courage to rebuild a tower to show to the world that they can stand up against the odds.

spectacular views. This is very well done,and covers 3 floors and the views are terrific,as they were on the clear day of our visit.Go early since it gets very crowded and the staff are wonderful and very helpful.

Impressive. My first thought as I entered the entrance atrium was that it reminded me very much of the original WTC atrium. Lots of white marble everywhere. After navigating a few security areas and ticket counters, we finally made it to the elevators. In what has been advertised as the fastest elevator in the world. We were transported vertically over 100 floors in less than one minute. The walls of the elevator are a movie showing the evolution of Manhattan from its beginnings to the current day. Really impressive. You step out to a short film presentation, which ends with the "screen" lifting away to reveal the most awe inspiring view imaginable. The observation deck can get a little crowded, but it's not terrible. I'd recommend this to anybody visiting New York.

Brilliant. Well organized, maybe my favorite part of many fantastic experiences in NYC....li won't say much about it......go for yourself...you won't be disappointed....not like I was with the Empire State Building.

Great old/new NYC observatory. The views from the Freedom Tower brought back many memories of the Twin Towers observatory. The ride up take less than a minute, and is quite spectacular while watching a movie about NYC. The show on entrance is also great. The views are not as good as from the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock (because of the downtown location and the lack of an outdoors observatory).

A new view of Manhattan! . Having done Top of the Rock a couple of times before I was excited to see the city from a new angle!They really worked on the experience and without wanting to spoil it for you the lifts are no ordinary lifts!! It's totally worth the money, but your tickets online and they email your tickets if you don't have access to a printer. We got ours on the same day.Arrive about 10 minutes before your time as you will need to go through security for bags and walk through the metal detector. Set aside a 1-2 hours for the whole thing. Worth a trip!!!

Great experience. First visit to this attraction, and whilst familiar with seeing NY from such a vaulted position, it was quite cool to be able to do so from the bottom of the island rather than Top of the Rock or the ESB! We paid for the iPad guide where you can look at the skyline and click in buildings etc for more info, but it was quite gimmicky and not necessarily of any benefit unless you are a first time visitor. The timed tickets meant it didn't seem overly crowded and you could always get your 'spot' at the window. We went at 10am and there was minimum queuing time - overall I think we were there about an hour as we didn't stop for refreshments. The views make this so worthwhile.

The view is worth it. It's only been open since July, and the view is worth it. I've been to the Top of the Rock before and it was really nice. Was a bit worried it's going to be just the same with the One World Observatory, on top of the new WTC. However the view is simply different here - another perspective on the city. A better perspective of the Brooklyn bridge for instance. The entrance fee is 32 dollars and I recommend you go right a sunset - so you can see the city both by day and by night.

Time allocation. Purchasing a time slot online is well worth it. The lines were not long, it was well organised, the staff friendly and overall, a great experience. The elevator ride was essentially virtual although I think would have been scary if we actually saw the exterior rising and lowering (as was the Space Needle in Seattle). The views from the observatory were breathtaking and non-threatening (Space Needle had glass bottom so you can look straight down - ugh!) The beer in the bar was far too pricey but made up for it in the view and ambience. Will be back next year for the new pin.

Amazing View! - If you plan to go at night, buy regular tickets! :-). We went with our kids to the observatory and it was something unforgettable! The 360 degrees view of NYC is something you can't put in words. We bought the fast-line tickets, BUT, as we visited the tower at night (9:45PM), there were no lines at all!, so then we realized we could have saved a lot of money if we have bought the regular tickets as there was no waiting time at all.The observatory is incredible, far better than the one from the Empire State building, although there are two different experiences worth to live once in a lifetime.
amazing view. Very well run operation. Bought my ticket on my phone and was able to visit same day. Amazing elevator ride to the top. Had some wine and food in the bar, was great. A must see in NYC.

View from the 102 floor. We booked our tickets to visit the One World Observatory online. No problem booking with the option of buying an add on ipad experience, which we chose not to. We reached there 30 minutes in advance of our 11am slot. The queue was well organized. There is an entry directly to the observatory from the WTC path station. The elevator up offers a unique time lapse experience, showing the Manhattan skyline view as it has evolved over the years. The elevator takes you up 100 floors in a minute and is supposed to among the fastest in the world. The 360 degree view is great from the 102 floor. Jersey city, Brooklyn bridge, Governors island and ofcourse the skyscrapers. I guess you miss out on some of the uptown views such as central park which might be better from the Empire State building/Rockefeller Centre observatories. There is a little gift shop and a mini snack counter too. In conclusion, well worth a visit for both the views as well as recommended for a well managed experience.

Great views little to much . Came here after visiting the 9/11 Memorial Museum. Had tickets for 3pm. At 2:30 the guy told us we could get in line. He must have told us the wrong line because I think we got in before the 2:45 people. Made it thru security. Its amazing what dumb picture people will take in the security line.
