Elevator ride was cool. The ipads you can rent for $15. Wasnt falling for that extra. There is to much emphasis on wowing crowd with the little movie. Move your way down 2 floors to the Observatory. It was a nice day. Little hazy but you could still see everything. There are way too many inconsiderate people just sitting around by the windows chatting not looking out. Made it difficult to get a spot to take pictures. Overpriced gift shop. Would I go again? Maybe in a few years and go in the early evening.
Visit with grandchildre. Very well done. Rented IPad and it added a lot to experience. Food pricey but looked good. Amazing view. Recommend.

A highlight of our trip to NYC. We bought timed entry tickets for Friday morning at 9:30. Thinking that traffic might be difficult, we got our taxi at about 8:30 am, but the ride was quick and we had time to view the memorial pools. We got into line between 9 and 9:15 and were admitted very quickly. Once through security, this is almost like a Disney attraction because you are being informed and entertained before you even step on the elevator. It is very, very well done and I would highly recommend it. The views are spectacular.

Took Some Work Clients. The building is fantastic and very impressive. We purchased our tickets in advance online and getting in at our timeslot was a breeze. It is very organized and was not crowded however we were there on a Tuesday afternoon. It is great combination with seeing the 911 Memorial next door. The prices in the gift shop were kind of outrageous but I doubt that they will be lowered. All in all I would recommend it to anyone.

Awesome.. Only saw from outside but it's such an awesome building, you can't hel but see it whenever the skyline is in view. It looks so elegant and sits next to the memorial that is so thought provoking.Such a major part of New York.

WOW. We visited One World Observatory in the afternoon after visiting the 9/11 museum/memorial. It is a testament to the human spirit to build this after the horrific attack of 9/11. The ride up the elevator was amazing and we did a video on the way. Once you get to the top and they open the screens to the entire view it takes your breath away. We had a beautiful clear day so the views were fantastic. Buy your tickets online ahead of time as it saves time in the lines. The only disadvantage is if you buy them more than a few days out you will not be sure that the weather will cooperate. We were lucky but it could have gone the other way as we only had one day to spend in New York.

Good view, great experience. The view from OWO is great, but the complete experience is what makes it absolutely worth while. The lifts are amazing and the introduction both downstairs and upstair are very well made. Get more information from one of the city pulses or just enjoy a 360 degree view from 1200 feet.

Awesome. Awesome building helping to make a new skyline. We visited on 4th July and saw the One World Trade Center first hand. I love the way that the building looks like a triangle that reaches to the heavens.

Fantastic view - really well run attraction - book before you go. I was fortunate enough to go to One World Trade Observatory on opening day and it was one of those glorious sunny NYC days - you really can see a phenomenal distance. My advice is whatever you do book via the internet prior to going - you can book a time slot. If you can I'd recommend taking either the first slot or close to before the lines build as it took almost an hour to get to the actual deck (I had a lunch time slot and granted it was opening day but I don't think it will be less busy any time soon). Try to also go to the museum while you're in the vicinity its fantastic also. I'd also say try to get to either Top of The Rock or The Empire State Building as both are lower down and you'll get a complimentary look at the city - you're 102 floors up at 1WT so everything is tiny.

Spectacular Views. I wished that the weather had been better, but there is no other way to see the city of NY. With 360 degree view it was just amazing. The wait was not long, getting through security was relatively quick; elevator ride was fast considering it's going up 120 floors. The presentation you experience as you get off the elevator was a nice intro to what you will see. At first I thought that this was going to be it. Good thing there was more to see. Enjoy, something you won't soon forget.

See New York City from 1200 feet above the ground.. Experience the most beautiful, panoramic views of New York City from 1200 feet above the concrete jungle. Get a chance to be in the tallest building in the United States, the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere and the 3rd tallest building in the world. See forever; see progress; see New York City at it's finest! Well worth the ticket price!

Walkin with angels. Great view, good experience. We had prebooked tickets for 09.00 am. You begin by taking an escilator downstars, to go thru security. On the walk to the elevator there is a little exebition to look at. The elevator ride is fast and smooth. There is planty of staff to guide you in the right direction. The obesrvatory deck is spacious, and the view is great. From the side that is in the sun it is difficult to take pictures. We enoyed it and spent an hour upstairs.

This is an AWESOME experience. To be fair, the price is a little high - when comparing price and experiences...I'd suggest Top of the Rock as the observatory to visit first in NYC. When you add in the cultural significance and newness of One World Observatory, its an absolute MUST, though. I'm a New Yorker who wanted to go, and the presentation was insanely cool! I went in the evening, and the views are certainly different from the observation decks at 30 Rock and Empire State Building in Midtown..but this is just a cool experience. If you have the $30, do this.

Pretty amazing. I am so glad we visited the One World Observatory. Everything was top-notch, and the multimedia presentations throughout were excellent. As others have said, do buy your tickets in advance. Obviously, the view are not to be exceeded. The prices on the souvenirs were fairly high, but it didn't stop me from buying a couple things anyway. Anyone would be crazy not to visit this beautiful place when in NYC.
The best view of the City. This new building is a treasure. Was a wonder. It reaches toward the sky as a testament to all that makes America great. Beautifully constructed and wonderful.

The Observatory. This is a wonderful experience even for the experienced New Yorker. The elevator ride up is truly magical. The view at the top is equal to no other in Manhattan. I have been to the top of the Empire State Building. If I had to pick just one to do it would be One World Trade Center!

Spectacular View. A must see new kid on the block in NYC. We bought the tickets online, which i strongly recommend to reduce the wait. The ride up was great - 45 seconds. The elevator experience, and the video show were great. The views were truly spectacular. There are taller buildings in the world, but i am sure, none of them can replicate this view. I did a daytime and night time view separately. Both are spectacular, and different in their own way. This is a highly recommended experience.

Just Okay. My brother-in-law and his family did this a couple of weeks before our visit and loved it, so we wanted to make sure that we did it as well. My kids and my husband thought it was pretty cool, but we paid $154 to ride a fast elevator to see the city in a different way. Although all of that was cool and seeing the magnificence of the building is neat, I just feel it's way too overpriced just to look out the window. Not only that, but before you get to the observation deck, there are several people there trying to get you to rent an iPad so that you can "see" what you're looking at. I don't know if it was $7.50 or $17.50 to rent, either way, you would think that would be something that would be included in the cost of admission. I was disappointed, though my youngest son thought it was awesome to use the bathroom so high up. One helpful part is the guy who does a presentation of all that is happening in the city, so if you have the time to listen and then time to partake in the activities, he would be helpful to listen to.

The best skydeck.. Couple of years ago I visited ESB skydeck and was astonished (twin towers were already gone at that time). This year I came back to NYC and we decided to visit One WTC observatory, the view is just amazing, the show in elevators and up the deck is really cool. Definetely worth visiting
Beautifully done. The new One World Trade Center is gorgeous, the memorial is beautiful, treed and very somber. It is very moving. The area is close to the water and a great place for a walk
Wonderful experience and worth the price!. Beautiful views and LOVED the elevator experience -- worth the money and time. Getting tickets online was good move.

Amazing! Emotional! Breathtaking! . We visited Freedom Tower not expecting more than a cool elevator ride and a great view BUT this was so worth the $32 experience! It just opened in late May. Lots of friendly staff who are excited to share it. Be sure to use the restroom before going in the elevator as the line is longer up top. The elevator ride is AMAZING!!! Hard to explain - you just have to experience it but it shows a video of NYC over the last 200 years. Once you reach the top (102nd floor) there is another treat when they open up the blinds - WOW!!!! When you proceed down to the 101st floor the staff tries to rent iPads for $15 which are cool, however not really necessary (look over someone's shoulder). There is a nice food concession and gift shop. Plan on spending about 1 hour checking big out the amazing views and the elevator ride down is equally as cool. NOTE: while there is not one mention of 9/11 (they seem to be focusing on future,etc) I found it VERY emotional and my brain kept thinking "what if...? Those poor souls.... What were their final moments....otherwise, a very cool experience and a must see while in NYC!!!
Great observation deck . Great observation deck! Your ticket has a time slot so you won't stand in an "Empire State Building line". We really liked One World Trade Center!

Big, bold and a display of power. We never got the opportunity to visit the World trade centre but having visited this building today I am sure it's a fitting replacement for the original towers. It's simple: go in, buy a standard ticket $32 and wait in line for security checks before heading up in a super quick lift. Didn't take long at all and the observation deck is excellent with plenty of space to admire the views. Looking down into the memorial pools is quite special and there is so much construction going on in the area.Here's to the Americans for putting up this fantastic tower. It's an example to the world; come back bigger and stronger.

What a View. I purchased tickets on line one month in advance of my visit. Tickets are pricey but that's typical of New York. We did not wait in any line for long. I think it was helpful to purchase tickets in advance and to visit in the morning. The only down side to purchasing in advance is that you cannot predict the weather. We had fabulous views that surpassed the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock views. I found it particularly meaningful to visit this spot. I highly recommend visiting the Tower Observation floor when the weather is clear.

avoid lines, book online. Enough is said by other visitors, I only want to recommend to book your visit at the One World Observatory web site, if you arrive on the scheduled time, there is practically no delays, in just a few minutes you arrive on top, at the Observatory.I just would liked it better if they had informations about the view at each window. They offer iPads with the info but at an extra charge of course.
Breathtaking . This was a beautiful building. It's amazing how this was built. I'm glad something was made of such a tragic event. It's worth the fee.

I can see for miles and miles ....... We had the timed skip the line tickets which are probably a must unless you are prepared to waste a lot of time in a queue as this does get busy. (tickets are not cheap by the way) The elevators rise 102 floors in 47 seconds but you have little or no feeling of acceleration or braking. The lift is lined with TV screens so you get an ever changing view of the history of Manhattan shown in its buildings which appear and fade as time elapses. It is a very clever idea but you do not really get enough time to appreciate it because the elevator is so fast. By the way if you want to go direct to the elevators on the skip the line you can but the slower way through is worth it if you have not been before - you then get back into the skip the queue line after that.The view from the top on a clear day is stunning and we were very fortunate that it was a bright sunny day with no haze. If you want to know what you are looking at out of the window you can hire an iPad for an extra $15 which identifies the direction of view from its GPS and displays information on what you are looking at. You are not constrained about the time you spend there whether you are eating in the restaurant at the top or not. About an hour and a bit is probably enough.The ride down is in the same type of elevator with the screens but you appear to be flying down the side of the building.

Great views of the City. I visited the One World Observatory yesterday night with my family, it's a great experience, the view of NY and NJ are amazing, after all you're 102 floors up there.The walk through the elevators is pretty nice and informative, they also take a picture of you with the family so they can sell it to you later. Once in the elevator, it goes up there really fast, you have displays inside the elevator and when you reach up there you're shown a movie, when the movie finishes the screen goes up and you see the city. Then they offer you a tablet with a virtual map of the NY, it's $15, in my opinion is not worth it since you just can't see or photograph some of the places you see in the map.Now to the real treat, the view of the city is perfect, from one angle you can see NJ, the Liberty State Park and Downtown Jersey City, from the other Windows you can see the Hudson River and Downtown Manhattan, the best view is when you get to see Midtown and all the Bridges through the windows.My only issue being a Photographer is that the Windows are super reflective, at night it's really hard to get a nice picture without seeing some reflections, I suggest you place your phone, gopro or DSLR against the window and try to cover their area with a hat, a jacket that way the reflections don't show on your pictures or videos, most of the staff were very friendly.Overall its a great experience, I highly recommend you going with your friends, family or love ones, you'll love it.I'm going back with my DSLR but I'm going during the day, most likely before sunset to avoid the window glare.

An Awesome Experience !!. With several levels to view the New York City in a 360 degree panorama we awe struck. The 60 second elevator ride ( how do they do that without feeling that you're moving at all?) is fantastic as the walls change from bedrock to the construction of New York, ending in a modern day scene. At $32 for adults and $30 for seniors, I wouldn't tour it daily... but it is a must for either the visitor or the NYC resident. Please,Please don't miss the Memorial Museum, wow truly worth the price of admission and then some. Making your reservation for both on line is a must, and allow at least 1 to 2 hours for One World Trade Center and 2 to 3 hours for the museum.

Awesome views. We went here during our one day visit to NYC. It is very awesome. The price to go up is $32 for adults. Children ages 6-12 are $26 and under 6 are free. I think seniors are $30. You might want to go a little early because we got there a little before 10:00 and our tickets were for 12:15. You can also preorder tickets online and choose your day and time. We didn't really know we were going to go up in it before we got there or we probably would have done that.On the elevator ride up, the three walls are actually screens where it shows you the way New York looked in the beginning and, as you went up in floors, it changed as it did over the years to what it looks like today. Very neat. I just wish you could view that somewhere else because it was so quick you can't really take it all in.When you get to the top, they show you a short film about NYC and then you go into the observatory area. As you are going in, they offer for you to rent a tablet that will tell you about all of the buildings and areas that you are looking at from the observatory. That costs an extra $15. We only saw a couple of people with them while we were there. You can walk all around the floor to see all of NYC. It is amazing how small the really tall buildings look from up there. It was very awesome. We would definitely recommend it to anyone visiting NYC. Even if it is a one or two day trip, put it on the list.The only negative is the prices in the gift shop. I would have loved at t-shirt or sweatshirt but most of the shirts were $34.95 and the sweatshirts were $64.95. I saw a sticky note cube that was $21.95. Crazy prices. We didn't buy anything and to be honest, I didn't see many others buying anything either. They would sell a lot more if they brought the prices down a little.This is a must do for anyone visiting NYC.
Go at sunset. We enjoyed the views on a hot, sunny day but it was so hazy outside visibility was limited. On a return visit, I would go at sunset and to see the lights go on in the city....

Nice view. Overpriced but go if you've seen/done the things on your list.We bought tickets on internet but a glitch made us have to go have it fixed. Fixed quickly. Very organized lines, seemed overstaffed. Elevator ride was interesting.Upon arriving at the top, aggressive marketing took away from the experience.A request to go to a photographer (no obligation) was the first thing that greeted you.Then a sales pitch for a tablet which would orient/show you which landmarks you were looking at.After that you were on your on. Souvenir shop sold thirty five dollar t-shirts, forty-five for long sleeved ones. There was a short show & tell presentation.The view of New York City was as breath taking, think Grand Canyon of cities!Unfortunately you are seeing it from behind glass.I usually skip tourist traps like this but because of 9/11, this was a specially personal visit for me. It shows the resilience of the city after such a horrific event.It's too bad that once you get to the top, there was barely a mention of what happened there before. If you don't need to see the city from above, a walk around the building may be an adequate experience. It is a beautiful structure to see from below & the names on the pool are a poignant reminder of 9/11.

Amazing Views. When we last visited NYC, the observation deck was not yet open. We had heard about the fascinating historical video in the elevator and decided to go down, not sure what to expect in terms of a wait. We did not have advance tickets and went after lunch, but It was no problem at all. The operation is clearly geared to handling a lot of people expeditiously.Our experience with staff was totally opposite of a previous review. Very friendly, upbeat and humorous.And of course, the views are amazing. To bad so many now look at them through their cell phones as they take pictures.... Would be special to go at night...
Spectacular view. Well worth the visit. The elevator ride up is amazing. You'll see a video of the history of New York (from bedrock to skyscrapers going up) in just one minute.

Superb view, but to each his own. I'm fascinated with tall buildings, so I was eager to see NYC from the very top - OWO.If you buy ticket on-line and in advance you'd reduce the wait in line significantly(Note: no lockers on site). From there on it is a very efficiently transition through security and to the elevators. The elevators are super fast and there is a nice show while riding them. I liked how spacious the observatory level is, the layout allows for a smooth flow of visitors wandering around. The view is simply stunning! Souvenirs range from cheaper to pricey, but not much of novelty there. You can stop by the cafeteria, or sit down at the restaurant for a light meal and a drink (prices aren't exorbitant for NY). Staff was very kind! Enough restrooms to not wait in line. One can rent an iPad and learn some more, but if you don't go for that there is not much information about the building, one just enjoys the view. I'd go again after a while - I simply enjoy looking East and thinking of all the people who came to NYC over the hundreds of years, then to the West and see what an incredible city NYC is!

Overpriced elevator ride. We spent $30/ticket to go to the One World Observatory. While the view is spectacular from the observatory, there is little explanation about the sights. Of course, you can purchase for an additional fee an IPAD that has a description of the various sites in NYC. But, for $30/pp, we were disappointed that there weren't more exhibits inside the observatory featuring historical data and landmarks. I would definitely recommend purchasing tickets in advance to avoid long lines. There is a lot of staff would do a good job keeping the lines moving and getting you in at your designated appointment time. Overall, it's a landmark building with an amazing view. It's just unfortunate that the ticket price couldn't be more affordable, especially for a family.

This place makes you think. You can't help but think about the people who died on Sept 11 th 2001. I appreciate the design because you can actually see the footprint of the former twin towers. The running waters around the edge is nice too, because it is an understated kind of fountain. It was good to see the names of everyone's name from the original bombing of the World Trade Center to the tragedy on Sept. 11.

Awesome. We were a group of six and purchased our tickets on line. That's very useful to cut down the waiting time. It's a bit expensive but the overall experience and the sentimental value make you ignore that .The elevator pods and the views from the top are something beyond words. They are awesome. We were thankful that we were not rushed thro' our visit. The cafe and restaurant were good. We preferred the cafe as the choice was adequate and saved time. Food lines and payment channels in cafeteria have to be stream lined and "no outside food" rule must be strictly implemented. We saw people smuggling in food and don't know how they escaped the stringent screening before getting into the elevator pods. The presentations on the floor were superb, both at the East and West points. Any one coming to New York, must spare a couple of hours and some dough to experience, the out of the world experience

Worth your time--a bit 'cheezily' done though. Visited here on Monday July 13. The line was not too long. Although the elevator ride (with video on the walls) was fun, it is also cheezy and "Disney-esque." The observatort itself has a great INDOOR view but no where as cool as Top of the Rock. You are in front of floor to ceiling windows with a a raised floor in the back and hundreds of people. it was good but an outdoor view would be better. Keeping with the way that New York communicates with visitors, the EXIT was not marked and we walked around for 10 minutes trying to find the way out (kind of hidden.) Got yelled at by a worked for going the wrong way. they purposely let you out in a gift shop (who doesn't these days?) and and expensive restaurant. That is tacky. Was an enjoyable time but a bit expensive ($32 pp) and cheesy.

Extraordinary !. We went there with our 10 years old granddaughter. extraordinary experience! Happily, we had booked our tickets in advance, in order to avoid the long queue. The organization is perfect: you don't loose any minute before you enter the lift (it was on a Thursday at 2:00pm), the directions are very clear and there are numerous staff to direct and help you. The lift in itself is a must: screens on the four walls, which show the NYC development through ages while you go up to the 102 bs floor (in less than 15 seconds, I think). The view from the Observatory is of course stunning; we had a beautiful weather (do not go on a rainy day, you would be in the clouds).

Good experience, but avarege view. This is something you should visit, just to have been in the WTC, and for the experience around the view. The elevator etc are great! But the view, it's avarage, better than the Empire, but Top of the Rock is so much better. You stand behind glass everywhere, which you'll see on your pictures on most of the days. It was kind of a bummer, but still don't regret doing it, it is something I wanted to experience, but the entrancefee for this view, is too high in my opinion. Don't expect to see Central ParkThe whole entrance is very smooth and well organized and security works fast and well trained, compliments for this!

Great views, shame about staff attitudes. Great vantage point for views and beautiful building but staff seem to think they are airport security and don't treat guests politely. It's an attraction and your continued success depends on good customer service as well as public safety. You could use some Disney training in this. The woman who introduced the short film and first viewing at the top was downright sarcastic and borderline offensive to guests in her haste to rush them into the room and close the doors. Many guests are non-English speakers and did not understand why she was making fun of them for not following her instructions promptly. I'm Australian and have lived in 6 Asian countries, and her accent was not 100% clear to me let alone a non-English speaker. Smiles wouldn't hurt either.

Well worth a visit . Views! Views! Views! Wow! Make sure you're there early to wait in line - they are pretty big! Really friendly and helpful staff to make sure you get in as fast as you can. I had a bit of an issue getting through security. Apparently there was something metal in my bag, still haven't found out what it was two weeks later. After 10 minutes they said it was fine to proceed upstairs. You don't have to wait all that long, and the waiting line has been designed to distract you with interesting facts and heartfelt videos of people involved in the construction of the tower. When you're in the elevator there is a really interesting and entertaining video that shows you NYC throughout the years. The views at the top are amazing. We had an especially clear day and were able to see the curvature of the Earth - truly amazing! It was busy, but didn't feel crowded and had plenty of rest areas and viewing points. The only downside was that the glass was really reflective and so taking photos was quite difficult - a really minor gripe!

Awesome view and a great tribute showing the American spirit cannot be stopped!. The video and elevator ride up were informative and entertaining. At the top you can really get a feel for how big the tower actually is when looking down on skyscrapers that look small. We didn't plan on visiting here and arrived on Sunday morning without tickets. The wait to get in to purchase tickets was about a half hour then after that was around a 20 minute wait to get in. If you plan ahead I would recommend purchasing online to avoid the wait. We loved the view from every side. If you are looking for the museum it is across the street.

Fantastic View. One World Observatory was a great way to see NYC! the elevator ride up is fantastic and maybe one of the most interesting technology additions. We ate at One Mix the bar/ small plate restaurant. The Service was great and the view was fantastic. I would defiantly see this attraction again if ever in the area.
WTC1. Great experience, very well done. WAY TOO EXPENSIVE. If we were not there with the kids we never would have gone to the top.
A NYC must for tourists.. Follow the hype evolving.Go and see the Statue of Liberty converted to the size of a Smurf. No need to say more: Just do it. !!

Impressive from every vantage point. We were a party of eight and purchased tickets online in advance. Efficient system if you plan this way. We were there on a gorgeous summer day with a mix of blue sky, sun and white billowy clouds. To see all of this reflected on the observation tower is stunning! Looking up from the outside made me dizzy and made my stomach flip. Then you take the elevator up 1776' and it only takes 48 seconds! The technology on display throughout the experience is highly advanced. Views are stupendous and will take your breath away. A work of pride and an honor to visit. The architects and all involved did a spectacular job of building this tribute. A must see for anyone visiting the city!

A Million Dollar View!. We visited One World Observatory in July. There were long lines to wait in to purchase tickets, long lines inside to go through security, and long lines to wait for the elevator. Once you arrive at the top, you file into a theater which has a short presentation. Then the panels open, and you see a million dollar view! Next you go down an escalator to see a 360 degree view of NYC and New Jersey. There are 2 kiosks that have lots of information about NYC- presenters touch different subjects such as parks, food, attractions, etc. The view is absolutely spectacular! We were there are in the late afternoon. Just wished that we didn't have to wait in such long lines outside and inside.

Amazing!. The view from the top is definitely the best. The staff of the observatory are friendly and cheerful. You'll want to soak up the views for a while. While you are there, have a drink at their bar. And getting to the top is wonderful, too. The elevator displays a changing view of NYC from colonial days to the present.

Great Views. Myself & my husband was looking forward to going to going but when we arrived to buy our tickets there barriers up everywhere but no signs pointing you in the right direction to buy them or what queue to be in. I approached a member of staff for advice & she was very abrupt. I said they should have signs up & she said that it was a new building and to them time to organize it. When we eventually got our tickets & discovered where to stand next we got into the lifts taking you up to the observation area. The lift ride was,awsome & I captured it on video. It's is a beautiful building & they should be proud of it. We had seen a sign saying restaurant we decided to go & have a look & we were met by a small corner with 2 fridges of beverages & a selection of sandwiches and rolls & there was a muffin stand who's staff couldn't understand plain English & just a blank look on their faces. There were a small amount of tables with very few seats & the whole process was very confusing. Apart from that the views were amazing over the city in any direction & they also had a good gift shop. I would go again but more signage is needed for it's visitors

A View Like No Other. We purchased our tickets in advance online which I recommend as they do keep the lines moving by timed ticket. We arrived early as we had one member of our party that uses a walker. The staff was incredible! Professional, courteous and kind. Thank you Joel for helping us! Take the time once you enter to listen to the sound bite videos of construction workers. Many people were barreling past that to get to the elevators. Once in the elevators you travel through time (depending on where you look you can also watch how many floors you've passedi). Please note: if you have any kind of motion sickness issues keep your eyes closed until you get to the top! A short, dramatic video is given (also watch out motion sickness people) before the curtain is raised for your first glimpse of the view from top floor. It gets a bit gimmicky as you go down a flight and pass the iPad rentals, photo ops against green screen. Food is available for purchase as well as a gift shop. We bypassed all this as we are all native New Yorkers and went around and around to pick out favorite landmarks and discover new areas. Again, staff was very helpful (thank you Ryan from Sunnyside). We spent 2 hours and probably could have stayed longer. A wonderful experience highly recommended.

Amazing views - Pick a good weather day if you can.. We visited all 3 Ny main skyscraper attractions during our visit, and this was only just beaten by top of the rock, and it certainly beat empire state. The view is impressive, with floor to ceiling clear glass throughout the observation decks.The restaurant was nice, we had a pleasant light meal, but that was much to do with the fact we lucked out and were sat at window facing table staring out over the city below.We arrived at 2pm and walked straight in, on departing there seemed a 10 minute queue. I wouldnt bother booking. The Ipad hiring was not worth it and would recommend not bothering - they dont work very well keeping compass settings and didnt add much despite our limited NY knowledgeThe animated elevator up just made us laugh. whats the point when the lift was so rammed we could hardly see - great idea, failed in practice.The customer service was very poor, its to be expected at an attraction like this, but the staff seemed disinterested and not concentrating so the confusing arrival queue downstairs was a free for all Tip - Watch the forecast for a sunny day for the best views. if your schedule is flexible then delay deciding what day to visit until you see forecast. Our day was overcast and views were limited to 5 miles - impressive but can imagine could have been better.

Good experience. Excellent experience, a bit pricey but special. Buy tickets online, or you'll have a wait. If you show up and there's a line, you can buy your tix on your cell phone. The view is great, the staff polite.

Incredible views. Not a fan on heights but could have spent hours up there.....advance tickets worth the extra investment, but do nt plan to buy too many gifts up there as they are EXPENSIVE.....the direct downward view on East side to 911 Memorial is heart breaking, while very impressive

Excellent!. Very impressive! Very slick operation, amazingly fast lifts. The view is really good, I always preferred the view from the world trade centre to the Empire State Building so it's great to get that back again

Breath taking views.. This is a must if you are in NYC, the views are breath taking and the less than 1 minute long elevator ride to the top is an adventure in itself.We went on a beautifully clear and sunny day and the sights will amaze you, they certainly did us.There is a gift shop too.Entry was $32 per person which was fair.

Amazing views . It all starts with the elevator up to the observation deck which is an awesome experience. The observation floor itself is spacious and has amazing 360 degree views as far as the eye can see. A must do in NYC!
was nice. We visited after a week of opening. We bought the tickets in advance but had to line up anyway. The view is great.

I wish I could give it 10 stars!. This is like nothing you have ever experienced. It's costly (I think it was $34 or $32 a person) but worth every penny. It's not just an elevator ride up, it's an experience. From the moment you pass security, which is like airport security including body scans, it's an interactive experiment. Very high tech, when you come in they ask your zip code and at security check there is a huge map of the world and it shows when visitors arrive from different places. The elevator ride is like nothing I've ever seen. It's fast, smooth, and wall to wall video screens, I won't spoil the surprise but the ride up is unreal. Then you watch a short video which culminates in a grand view of the city. It's spectacular! You won't be disappointed!

Awesome views! . We were there on a beautiful sunny day and there were spectacular views of Manhattan. You feel like you are literally on top of the world! If it's a cloudy or foggy day I would think that the views would not be as good. Amazing experience if you get a chance to do it. It is a bit pricey but I think the view was worht it!

Freedom tower - forever beautiful . We loved the entire tour. Booked ahead of time on line highly recommend. Absolutely beautiful. A must see in NYC. Food is expensive but it is simply beautiful and tastefully done and very clean. All that work there are friendly and helpful.

Worth doing. Lacks the depth and history of places like the Rockerfellar and ESB. Very state of the art and a good experience. Views are very good, no outdoor viewing but 360 views will keep you entertained. Elevator and presentations well organised and designed. Worth doing only after other views have been done.
Wow.... What an impressive building. $35 bucks to get to the top. We did not do it. but the are is so impressive.

A highlight of our NY trip. We purchased tickets online in advance which I recommend to avoid queues. The view was simply stunning and quite possibly the best in NY. We went during the day but I think it would be spectacular at night too.

Better than the Empire!!!. The views from the top are incredible and without the wind!!!! It is a bit pricey, however. We got the senior rate of $23. I loved being able to walk completely around and see the city views without the weather being a factor. Crowds are heavy this time of year. (July)

It's the elevator, pardon me, the "Skypod". Ok, everybody is going to talk about the impressive view etc. etc. obviously so. Thus here a different angle. The whole area around the building and the entrance to the attraction is kind of sober. Concrete, rock, rather on the cold side, to give a solemn impression in memory of 9/11. Queueing system quite efficient (recommend buy ticket online, very easy), and while you wait for the elevator, a voice starts talking about a "Skypod". It is still an elevator. But it has these screens from floor to ceiling on three sides which show different movies going up and going down. EXCELLENT, WELL DONE! Wanted to take just the elevator half a dozen times to be able to absorb the whole things, as it goes really fast. Of course up there the view is breathtaking as to be expected. Only point of small complaint, why can they not have non-reflective windows? While taking pictures it is very difficult to remove the reflections of the people around you or yourself. Even a pol filter on the lens does not take them away. Other positive note, they have some guys telling stories of NYC and what you see, using combination of different screens, video and their narrative. Nicely done too.

Nice but expensive . This is a nice observation deck with panoramic views of the city. The restaurant and wine bar look like a nice place to linger and take in the skyline. Other than the views and some photo ops, there's not much to do. I was underwhelmed for the price.

Breathtaking, but the same. If you've been to the top of the ESB you know what I'm talking about. Same view, different building. I wish they had a gimmick like the Willis Tower in Chicago.The presentation in the elevator, however brief was spectacular.

Nostalgic. It's hard to describe the haunting feeling of being at "Top of the World"...If I put aside what happened on 9/11/01... Wonderful experience! Great job of keeping the queues moving. Amazing wow-factor after the "See Forever" movie. Spectacular 360 degree of the city. Awesome sunset. Super-fast elevators - 100 floors in 50 seconds!!

The elevator ride was the best. My brother was visiting ang wanted to see the city from above. Seemed like a no-brainer that I should take him to the one world observatory (more modern, better positioning, etc) You can't take away the breadthtaking height and positioning of the building, but after paying $32 dollars to go up you expect that at least you'll get some good pictures. All surrounded by glass, the pictures come out hazy. Although you have an impressive 360 view of Manhattan and other burroughs, you are quite far from all the buildings and it's harder to appreciate their magnitud and even capture them in a pictureI have to say that the elevator ride was very well done and I enjoyed it very muchI haven't been to the empire states in a few years, but I remember being able to take awesome pictures and feel the breeze in my face...I was expecting more of the one world observatory. In summary, next time I have someone visiting I'll take them to the Empire States...
Best Views of Manhattan. It is a great place to see the world of the city that never sleeps! The WTC cite is still growing and it will be great once it finishes!

Too crowded. The One World Tower is the tallest building in New York and therefore the observatory should have the best view. Constructed as the new symbol of this city, this modern skyscraper has a lot of wow factor both inside and out. Traveling to the One World Observatory is easy as the building is in close proximity to a few subway stations like Cortland street, Chambers street and Fulton Street. There is no missing this building upon exiting as it simply dominates the down town skyline. Making my way there is interesting as one goes thru a heavily guarded underpass and then make it to security. The tower management employs airport style security and all bags were screened. I have a VIP ticket and makes it thru the queue faster but if you are not going to the Observatory during peak period, I don’t think that is necessary as there is a small difference in time. Going up the express elevator is very cool, as the lift itself comprises of a wrap around LCD video screen that shows the transformation of New York from the last century until present. Once insider the observatory, we were shown a few videos and also offered the opportunity to have our photos taken. The observatory itself has a gift shop and a restaurant and of course they are all overpriced.The views are spectacular for sure as the observatory has a 360 deg view of New York city from downtown, including the Statue of Liberty, the Hudson river and the Brooklyn bridge. As sunlight give away to evening night falls, the view gets more spectacular with all the lights on. This is where one notice NYC really have a traffic jam problem. :DAny drawbacks? Yes of course. First there are huge crowds as this observatory is new and it gets bigger by the minute once reaching the prime “sunset” timing. The crowd seems to be dominated by two group of people. First are the couples that choose to occupy certain vantage points of the observatory and refuse to move, thus depriving others of a closer view while they wait for sunset and kiss and snorkel affectionally for all to see. I suppose that “adds” to the view but doing so is very selfish and irritating. Then you have a lot of what I supposed are professional photographs and enthusiast that take seemingly ages to take a picture. Lastly, the glass windows are highly reflective so it’s very hard to take a good picture and I have to jostle with the crowd for a spot. I have to choose certain special spots where the lighting in the room doesn’t reflect badly to damage the view. See the attached pictures. By around 8:45pm ( Sunset is at 8:30pm ), the place is swarming with people and it gets too much and too crowded and I cannot wait to leave the place. Going down is quick and doesn’t have a long queue fortunately. Overall, I enjoyed the Top of the Rock experience better due to open unblocked views vs the glass windows of the One World, and a small crowd makes it much more relaxing.

Tasteful. Given the tragic events on 11th September 2001 I think this is a very tasteful memorial site. As a non-American I have no personal connection to the place, but I thought it was a good place to sit down and reflect on how the events have influenced the world. The monument itself is beautiful and the rounding skyscrapers, especially One World Trade Centre, are excellently designed.

Sobering experience.. The complex alone is worth the visit, when adding the memorial it can bring tears to your eyes. The infinity pools are breathtaking, reading the names etched on the outside reminds you of this day in history. Please take the time to visit this wonderful tribute.

Great views on a clear day. Worth it!. Wait until the day of the visit to make sure you have clear skies. We had a gorgeous morning, so we reserved our time that morning on our bus ride into NYC, and were able to still get the 9:15am slot. Recommend getting as early of a time slot as you can, as the observation levels will get crowded. Having timed entry made it really convenient, as you don't have to wait in a long line to get in. Simply show up 15 minutes before your time slot and then get in the line for your time. Very cool "movie" going up the elevator (goes very quickly) and then excellent views from the top.

City Slickers. Very well executed tall building experience. From the entrance process through the high speed lift and onto the viewing platform itself, this was a well organised, engaging and innovative approach, offering a peek into the history, topography and geology of the city. The view is spectacular, even on a drizzly day, plenty of space to move about and a nice buzz of excitement from the visiting crowds.

A bit expensive but a great experience. We bought tickets online which is recommended due to the long waiting line at the ticket booths. Another recommendation is to print the tickets. Mobile connection is flaky at the WTC making it very difficult to download the tickets on our mobile phones when we were there. The admission is a bit pricey (like all the other skyscraper's) but especially the elevator with the audiovisual experience, and the small show on top of the tower make it worthwhile. A must do in NY.

awesome view / better service. what an amazing view and experience. i am very grateful the manager on site Robert Stazza was very helpful and friendly in getting me and my elderly mom in after our late arrival. The manager and staff made this a fantastic experience.

Excellent experience! I took my 9 year old daughter and she loved it.. Loved everything about my experience. Not happy that they sell products in the gift shop that are not made in the USA. That needs to be changed.

...a slick operation.... One World Observatory is the latest in the observation towers in New York City, and is the highest, and slickest.It is a smooth operation, but once at the top the views are stunning as expected. I find the process a bit annoying at most of these attractions, you get herded from one place to the next then get your photo taken even if you don't want it, but that's the price to see the end result.My advice is to get the Day Flex ticket for just a bit more, so you can go anytime of the day or night. If you're locked into a time and the visibility is low, it's a wasted experience. It's also worth it to skip the queues, although you still have to queue up to get back down.Despite my cynicism about the process, it's a beautiful building that stands out in New York, and worth the trip to the top for the views of the city.

Hard to mess up the view, but thier process it poor. First off, the view is fantastic, beautiful, wonderful and just plain outstanding. The process to get you there is terrible. We paid for preferential early entry. They had no clue how to handle that. They just us to the line with everybody else. But, they sure took the money early entry. The after you clear security, you wind around in a very tight, ridiculous display of bedrock. Then you que for the elevators. Then off, and you que to be forced into this silly little room, where they say if you can see your feet, you are not standing close enough to others. NICE. Then the show this stupid moive that has nothing to do with anything. Then the open the blinds, and you see the city. No kidding? Then you are routed out through very tight spaces, where your are bounced upon by people trying to see you a stupid ipad that will identify what you are looking at for a stupid sum of money. Then once you get past all that, you have to wind around the Resturants and then finally you get to the observation area. So again, the view of one of the best city's in the world is great, but the people that run the place are clueless.

Better Than Expected. Living here in Manhattan, I have been to the Empire State Building, Top of the Rock and of course the old WTC many times. I was curious to see how this was going to be. Now recently opened, the talk of this observatory is the elevator ride and of course the view at the top. There was a surprisingly short wait at the bottom outside of about 20 minutes after we purchased tickets inside the building. We didn't do any advance purchase. The price is a bit steep ($32), but it's NYC. The elevator ride up was very interesting, showing NYC from the 1600's, and as you rise up higher in the building, the time changes as is shown on a date counter in the elevator. The higher up you go you see the city change as taller building are built, and familiar buildings also go up. Before you know it you are at the top. You exit and there is a great view all around. There were a few issues I really wish the staff here would address. One, they cannot do much about. The lighting inside causes a lot of glare on the glass and makes taking pictures of the great view rather tough. The other is the number of people sitting around on the window sills at every point of the observatory. I was on top trying to get photo's for about an hour, and noticed that the entire time, many areas had the same people sitting in the blocking the view and locations to get good shots. Many times these people didn't even move when you moved up closer to the glass, and I was forced to lean over them to take pictures. It was very annoying. You might think after sitting in a window for 10-15 minutes these people would have moved just to let others get a view and or photo's, but many of the same people I saw at the beginning, were also in the same place at the end. There are some areas that are not as bright from the ceiling lights as others, or are away from the lights from different displays, and it seemed these are the areas these people sat the longest without moving. I heard several people talking about this. The staff really need to get these people out from sitting in the window sills, so others can get better shots. Other than these two things, the ride up I'd say is worth it.

Fantastic building. Wow! What more can I say! Truly futuristic building with awesome lift experience, very professional presentation and fantastic views from the 102 floor observatory! Missing the experience of being able to go outside like the Empire State Building but a much bigger viewing area! Definitely worth a visit when in NYC!

Observatory Heaven. All I can advise about this newly opened Observatory at the WTC is just don't hesitate - go and visit. We got there earlier than our 12.30pm entry time and had a drink in FiDi beforehand which was a pleasant area. I must advise that the system in place for directing people where to go is INSANE! All they need at the front is a couple of signs that say - Pre Booked Tickets or Buy Tickets Here to clearly mark each line. hat you have in fact is just a mass of people who have no idea which line to join or what to do. Therefore everyone who is working for WTC at the front gets constantly bombarded by questions from the public about where they should go and what they should do. Craziness. For your reference the queue on the right (facing the entry to One WTC) by the security booth is for tickets to buy today, the queue on the left which is by the steps is for pre booked tickets. The same is true for the actual entry when you have pre booked. People join the lines ahead of their schedule times and someone has to organise them via a Megaphone (is this 2015?) to sort them into their timed entries. In the blazing hot sunshine this was just too much to handle what should have been an exciting occasion. Being one of the first people up to the WTC observatory should have started on a better foot.I don't want to ruin the surprise of your visit here so I will keep the running order of the visit secret, but I can say that the trip to the top is around 60 seconds to the 100th floor which is amazing!The actual views themselves are out of this world. Loving NYC and everything about the city it was really emotional to be there in One WTC and everything it stands for - absolutely amazing. We didn't dine here after seeing the Eater reviews and also the hassle from entry and mingling of all the visitor upstairs which put us off staying any longer. I would advise not to miss the opportunity to go up and see the views and support the observatory. You won't regret it. I just hope they sort their queueing system out sooner rather than later.
Great place to visit!. Amazing views across Manhattan and beyond. Very friendly staff, an altogether great experience. Would recommend to anyone.

Excellent visit. Very organised entry system in place - you have to buy a ticket and generally return a few hours later. This means that they have a steady flow of people throughout the day and the tower doesn't get too crowded at any point . The trip in the lift to the observatory at the top was amazing - the lift has projected images on each wall so it looks as though you are in a glass lift and can see all around NYC as you travel higher. The observatory itself was great, offering unrivalled 360 views across the city - better than both the Empire State and Rockerfeller centre. Back to that lift again...on the way down , again it offered similar views as on the ascent , but it actually felt more like a theme park ride. The lift 'appeared' to leave the tower and spiral around the outside of the tower like something out of Charlie and the chocolate factory! Well worth the entry fee. At the base of the tower are the two memorial pieces where the original tower1 and tower 2 stood along with the only tree in the square that survived 9/11. Other trees have been planted around it since, but the original is chunkier and has a small fence around it so is easy to spot. Would recommend a visit to this site.

Amazing! . Order priority tickets for my girlfriend and myself. Worth the extra money. Got to go straight in at the time we chose snd go right to the top. Amazing view on the observation floor. I got proposed to her overlooking the bay! Beautiful place.

Awesome. So glad we did this. At first the entrance price of $32 each made me think about not doing it but we decided to go for it and I am so glad we did. It was an amazing experience. We had a gorgeous day for it so we saw forever, actually 43 miles according to a staff person. Everyone was super friendly and helpful. Special effects is what makes it expensive but worth it. Go for it.

Amazing experience. Make sure you go on a day with clear visibility since you want to stay there for a while and enjoy the views as much as possible. We were even offered the possibility of changing the tickets to another day with better weather (it was raining and very cloudy, but luckily it cleared up in the end). The staff in general were extremely friendly, except for the ones at the cafeteria who couldn't care less.

Fabulous. Saw this advertised while waiting for our bags at JFK.Fabulous attraction from start to finish. Staff were very polite and helpful and the whole visit went seamlessly.If you are visiting New York this should be on your list. At the same time you should also visit the 9/11 memorial which is incredibly moving.

The new no. 1 view in NYC. We were so impressed by this new observatory. Amazing organisation meant we hardly queued to get in with prebooked tickets. Up 102 floors in under a minute and the videos inside the elevators are so well done. Then you walk through an area where you can watch some videos about the construction and then the view just appears in front of you. Amazing! There is a cafe, gift shop and every 30mins or so someone gives a presentation about the city and all the great things to do which I thought was a nice addition to the experience. You don't see Central Park which was my only disappointment but apart from that - GO!

Fantastic views. Fantastic views. We decided to visit on spur of moment rather than book online and glad we did as weather had been overcast in the days before. We joined the right hand line for this and didn't seem any longer than the line with prepaid ticket holders.$32 for the standard ticket and we didn't go for the tablets they rent you or photo's etc.The ride up in the lift is fantastic with graphics showing you New York as it has grown over the years.You then go into another room with kind of 3d video footage before going out into the observatory itself. Breathtaking views but through huge panes of glass so photography isn't as good as at other towers like Empire State and Top of the Rock.Really glad we did this and would recommend.

A Must-See in NYC. The views are spectacular. I could've spent all day here. I've read reviews from others comparing it to the Empire State building or Top of the Rock. I think the history of September 11 and the rebuilding make it even better. It made me proud to be an American. We bought tickets online and had zero wait. I thought the security process and getting to the top were well-managed. I won't ruin anything, but the elevator and theatre were my favorite parts. This will be something I do on each and every visit to New York City.

beautiful building. The building is gorgeous, but was a little unorganized. I had purchased tickets ahead of time, (which I recommend you do). Glad I did..the line to get tickets was really long. But there is no place for people to go who purchased ahead of time so make sure you ask an attendant. Once inside had to go thru security which was pretty quick.  The views are amazing, but there is a lot of people up there at the same time. can be difficult getting pictures without having to wait for people to move. Don't know if I would pay that much to go up there again. I thought the fee was a little steep at 32.00 per person

Let Freedom Ring!. The whole complex is a sight to behold. The memorials themselves, the surrounding plaza and the building are all stunning and truly awe inspiring. One cool tip -- there's an underground corridor under the tower to the World Financial Center across the street. In that building (also gorgeous to behold!) there is a food court -- Hudson Eats -- with fantastic choices. There's plenty of seating in the hall itself, but just outside is an enormous plaza right on the Hudson! GREAT day trip.

What a view!. You must do this once while in NYC. The experience is one of a kind. If its busy get the priority pass and by-pass the lines. The views are super. The elevator ride was amazing so fast to the top but you hardly feel it. Do not bother to eat at the One Dine restaurant. Go to the bar and order the food there instead and enjoy the views.
Amazing. The Memorial at World Trade Center Tower is unbelievable and a must see. Make reservations and buy tickets and go early for best attention and get VIP pass for no wait.

Glad We Visited. A great experience. No lines at all! We visited last Tuesday, July 7 about 4p.m. The weather forecast had been for a chance of rain but that did not happen. When I first read of this opening in May, I decided to put this on our Grandparent/ Grandsons NYC trip instead of Top of the Rock. I studied the reviews on here and became worried about the wait in lines so I purchased "expedited entry" tickets for anytime that week. There was absolutely no need to do that or spend that much money! Not only was there no line outside for tickets, there was no line inside for the regular or VIP elevators. You walked directly into the elevators! It was very organized from entrance to the building to when you were in the observatory. The staff was informative. While skies were not a totally clear blue, you certainly had great views. My grandsons (ages 14, 10, and 8) found it easy to get to the windows to take their own pictures. I am glad we visited this new attraction in NYC.

Amazing. This is an absolute must. We headed down to the financial district early on Sunday morning. It was so quiet and serene just standing at the base of the twin towers taking in the waterfalls and reading the names of those who lost their lives. We headed up the Freedom tower at around 10. The views are spectacular and there is a glass floor for the brave. It was very well organised. There is a restaurant at the top should you want a drink or snack. Loved every minute!!!

Assault on the senses!. Outstanding view. Had priority tickets so got taken to front of queue. We missed our time slot, but wasn't even mentioned. The lift view was fantastic, shows you exactly how fast you travel. The film set was a wonderful shock. Not sure what to expect, so great surprise. Then the breathtaking view at your own pace.All rounded off nicely with a lunch and a glass of fizz in the restaurant, with wonderful, helpful staff. Well worth the money

What a view. Great place to visit after hitting the 9/11 memorial. Very good job done by Legends here. Wait was a bit long, but other than that it was quite the experience and view. They have some cool iPad gadgets that show you what you are looking at and the elevator ride up was really cool. And I'm not one for elevators. Just a warning it is a virtual ride, so if those make you sick, you may want to close your eyes. Really cool place to visit and we had a couple drinks at the bar. Could have stayed there all day and looked at that view.

Tourist Trap, High Pressure Sales, Too far away from Midtown and too high. Airplane like view. You can see a long way, but it is too high and too far away from the Empire State and Chrysler buildings or the Statue of Liberty. You can see them but they are very small. Like flying in on an airplane. You are assaulted by salesman for renting ipads and then forced in to a picture taking and then routed into a cafe before ever getting to the view and then it is very crowded. I would skip it.

Overpriced and underwhelming . NYC has many towers to visit, such as the Empire State building and the Top of the Rock. This is no better and in my opinion, not nearly as impressive as the Top of the Rock. The elevator trip is very impressive, as is the little movie, but the actual observatory is not. The glass is not clear enough and there are reflections from everything that make good photos difficult to take. There are great views and obviously it is downtown, but I feel that most people, like myself, went up this tower in memory of those who died. That is perfectly fine, but don't milk it too much in the shop and all around. Decent, but not as good as it should be.
Phenomenal Experience. My parents travelled halfway around the world and were pleased to be at One World trade center. Everybody who visit New York city should definitely visit WTC.

Two Lines: One for tickets the other for the elevator.. OK. Everyone knows the views are fantastic. Here's something that will really help you. Get in the right line first. There is one for tickets and another to go up. Get in the ticket line first if you didn't buy them online. The tickets are for a specific time as well. The elevator is crazy fast but you can't eve tell it's moving, hardly. The trip up is a bit over $30 per person. But it's worth it.

spectacular , amazing views, very pleasant experience ,to be recommended. i had been on top of the old world trade centre a few years before their destruction. here the views are even better and it is perfectly organised. we were blessed with a crystal clear day , and it was simply breathtaking

What a view!. Now this is how to do it! Lovely staff at the ticketing booth, amazing elevator ride, wonderful 'big reveal' and jaw dropping views of Manhattan and beyond! The only reason I haven't given this 5 stars is down to our treatment by the bar staff at the observatory bar. As honeymooners, my husband and I fancied a drink at the top of the world and made our way to the bar. We found a seat, checked the menu and not finding any staff on hand to take our order, my husband went to the bar to purchase our drinks. I then had a staff member appear to tell me that I couldn't sit here and that since he had placed his order at the bar we must sit at the bar. I explained that I didn't realise this was the etiquette and offered to cancel our bar order and place it with the waitress. The bar staff said that it didn't matter and that we should enjoy our drinks at our table so we took our seats and thanked them. A few minutes later, another waitress came and told us that we couldn't sit here and when I explained what has happened she said well 'you shouldn't have been told that and you cannot sit here' and stood over us at our table. Not one for being intimidated, I apologised for the misunderstanding in the service etiquette but told her that we would be finishing our drinks where we were. The waitress's parting shot was 'well next time you will know how it works here' We were allowed to then finish our drinks but it did take the shine off of what should have been a very special moment. Little did she know that this was our 'once-in-a-lifetime' holiday and there may never be a 'next time'. Despite all this hoo-hah, we loved the observatory and the views over Manhattan were stunning! A total must see.

Fantastic Views!. This was my first visit to the observatory of the new Freedom Tower and I was with 3 others who had never been there. Two of us had been to the old World Trade Center observatory 3 or more times before it fell victim to the terrorist attack. It is amazing how fast the elevators take you all the way up to the 102nd floor of One World Trade Center. They start with a very good video presentation and then you go down an escalator to the observation floor where you can get views from all side of the building. You are on your own and can stay for as long as you wish. They offer souvenirs for purchase in a small shop and you can go to a nice restaurant with great views on another food if you wish. Unlike the old World Trade Center, you cannot go outside in the open air on the roof. They are extremely efficient. It is amazing how easily they handle such large crowds in a friendly but efficient manner. A Tip: Buy your tickets on the Internet. Saves standing in line.

Awesome!. What a building and what a view! I experienced the trip to the top on a hot July day. Had to buy a ticket for 1.5 hours after I visited the window but it wasn't horrible. Went and had a cocktail at a local pub. When I arrived back to the location I waited about 20 minutes before heading inside to wait yet again to go through security a little mini tour of the history of the bundling etc. That was ok but all that I really wanted to do was go to the top and check out the amazing 360 degree view of the NYC skyline and boy did it not disappoint. Nice and clear day made it all worth the wait. Anyway the price tag is steep as with anything in the city and the wait was too long but other than that I would return if I went with someone who had not been. However I would book in advance and possibly pay the extra for the VIP.

Nostalgic. It's hard todescribe the haunting feeling of being at "Top of the World"...If I put aside what happened on 9/11/01... Wonderful experience! Spectacular 360 degree of the city. Awesome sunset. Super-fast elevators - 100 floors in 50 seconds!!However, I think the restaurants and cafe are too small to accommodate the visitors, especially One Mix.

Amazing 360 views of New York and New Jersey. Surprisingly, this was cheaper than a trip to the top of the Empire State Building. The view from downtown north towards Central Park is amazing. Tickets are based on an admittance time, we walked right up and waited in line for 10 minutes at most. The elevator ride up is really cool, but I will not spoil the surprise.

Wonderful views- nice little unexpected suprise on the way to see it. Went up with my husband and 2 kids. We pre-purchased tickets. Note: if you have tickets for a certain time, it's okay if you get there a bit late- they will just let you in. We were there too early b/c I had to guess when we were arriving in NYC so we waited, but there were lots of earlier time people and the kids were hungry, so we ended up leaving to grab a quick bite to eat- that then made us about 8 minutes late, for our 'noon' time, but as I mentioned, they let us right in. Once in, they have you queue up (think Disney) in a line and have done an okay job of making the line interesting by posting things on walls, videos, etc... Eventually you make your way around to the elevators. I didn't think the elevator was as 'interesting' as I thought it'd be. I appreciated its speed. And our ears popped on the way up. Once you're at the top, they show you another short video. While the video is nice, they have an even better surprise at the end. No spoilers here. Then they finally let you into the 'viewing' areas. We didn't partake in the gift shop or food- just the views. And they really are spectacular. It was crowded, but not ridiculously so. That said, I have a tip, (insert image of Bill Lumbergh here), if you could please be courteous of other people and not sit against the window ledge blocking other people from checking out the views while you scroll through the photos you took with your friend - "that'd be great".I definitely think it's a must at least once.
Well run trip to the top. We enjoyed this tourist activity and we're glad that we had express tickets. That shortened the lines all the way.

Amazing view!. Very exciting to experience the One World Observatory! We ordered ticket on internet, and then we didn't have to line up in the hot sun for hours! Great views and lot's of space to walk around in the Observatory.

Wonderful experience. well organised friendly and no queues...so we didnt really need our priority ticket...we didnt buy a viewer used the money for cocktails instead!...interactions and presentations very good...no time limitations at the top...so we stayed about 3 hours until sunset...great that it looks forward and is a positive experience...would definitely recommend to everyone

Great views of New York City. Book your timed ticket online, that way you just bypass the queues and be on your way up to amazing 360 degree view in no wait time.After security check, you pass though the history of the building construction.The elevator up is something to see, and all walls turn on and display the history timeline of Manhattan from 1800's to current day. Get your video cameras ready for that.Once up there, you view a short video on the massive wall display. The walls open down and the view appears...There is a food court with tables and chairs for some eating time with a view.Available are iPad interactive infoviews, but we did not elect to hire them.You get to walk all around the building, giving you the 360 degrees of views to the horizon (depending on weather) with no interruptions.There are two areas with hourly presentations about New York City and surroundings.The all glass walls sometimes gets in the way for good photographs, but bit of creativity, you can manage to avoid glass reflections (spread a dark coloured jacket or sheet just below the glass and reflections gone!).We spent around 2 hours taking plenty photo shoots.The elevator down. Now this is one hell of a trip down! I will not spoil it for you by telling about it. Be prepared!
Well worth it. It was truly spectacular - what an incredible experience. From the map when you first walk in right through to the elevator ride and of course the views. Wow, just wow. A must do

Best view of Manhattan. . The view from one world observatory beats all others in Manhattan. The queue is quick and fast moving. The price was $29 for adults. The observatory is high tech and modern and we felt we had time to wander around enjoying the sights, rather than be rushed and pushed by the crowds that you will find elsewhere. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Fireworks from One World Observatory. My wife and I decided to view NYC July 4th fireworks from One World Observatory. Tickets were $185 each, which included viewing from 8:00 PM till 10:00 PM with open bar, hot dogs and soft pretzels (a tradition). We choose this since we were not comfortable viewing the fireworks in a crowd and we wanted to see One World. Why not do both at one time! First, security around and in One World was good; like airport security. We felt very safe. The view of NYC from the observatory is 360 degrees...the best you will find anywhere. Food and drink were plentiful and good. There were some lines at the start of the night for food and drink. We thought for the price we paid, they could have had better access to the food and bars (who wants to wait too long at that price!) The fireworks show seemed small from so high up. Also, you didn't get the sound effects so it did diminish the event a bit. We wish they would have piped in the sounds of the fireworks. Would have made a big difference. Instead, they piped in the event going on in Times Square. Overall, very interesting experience for the 4th of July. Worth doing once in your life. If visiting NYC, One World is a must see. Tickets anytime for Observatory are, of course, much less expensive than the 4th special event.

The Experience Begins at the Base. This is really a time when you can enjoy the journey, not just the destination. Before you go in, look up from between the oak trees surrounding the reflecting pools. Once inside, note the global visual display of where visitors have come from as they are passing through the security checkpoint. Read information regarding the bedrock as you move toward the elevators. Watch an amazing movie (360 degrees) on the ride up one of many elevators. Be entertained by staff before the curtain is raised. You can't imagine the view. Pictures can't do it justice. Look for the footprints of the Twin Towers from the top, and reflect. Staff knows every nook and cranny of sight below so talk to them. There is a restaurant at the top. If you are looking for a good place to buy t-shirts for the kids this is it (at the top). Buy tickets/make reservations on-line in advance, so you can walk right in at the designated time without having to stand in line. Check weather and visibility in advance.

Beautiful!. The view is amazing. Go just before sunset and get the DAY and NIGHT views (Super Fantastic!). Impt to Note: If you cannot see the top of the building when you are standing at the base - then you wont be able to see out the windows when you get to the top (come back another day when it is sunny and enjoy!)

A MUST SEE FOR NYC!!!!!!!!!!. The observation deck at the One World Trade Center is a MUST SEE DESTINATION for New York City. I highly recommend getting the I-pad addition for $15, because it shows a good description of all the views you can see.

1WTC. Rarely does a family outing generate so much anticipation and more rare still, does that anticipation get met in full.
If you only get to do one thing in your visit to New York, do this....
Breathtaking....

Good Experience. Visited on a lovely sunny day in July - view is fantastic from the top , well organised to get in - the evelator trip is amazing! - unfortunatly for some reason , the line to leave was soooo long - it took us about 45 mins to get an eleavator down!!!Just one suggestion - choose which to do - Empire State, Top of the Rock or One World - no need to do all three!!!

Beautifully Done. I've had the pleasure of visiting the observatory twice in the short time it has been open. It is wonderful! Views are fantastic. On this last trip I also visited the Empire State Building for the first time. Although another important NYC landmark, I found it very cramped in the observation deck. Save your money and come here!
Must do in NYC. Absolutely wonderful. Not a fan of views but this place was definitely worth the money. Avoid the VIP psd on rainy days. Get the iPad

a must do attraction in NYC!!!. Awesome mind blowing views of NYC and NJ. You have to get one of their IPads that tell you the history of every major skyscraper and monument all fed in live time! Very well organized. A true tribute to the 9/11 families and the world saying America won't be taken down! 5 stars +++

Awesome View. Whether climbing a mountain or riding an elevator to the top of the tallest building in North America, elevation always provides an amazing view. One World Observatory provides that amazing view of Manhattan, the surrounding boroughs, Long Island and New Jersey. Make reservations in advance and schedule your visit for early in the day to avoid the crowds. We ate lunch at the top of the building. There are no reservations accepted for lunch, it is first come first served. The food is good, the view is spectacular, but the service was poor.

Great views, everything else poor!!. Apart from the views I'd say everything else is rubbish. From the rudist people on the planet to the restaurant with no chairs, it's really substandard. First you get "told off" by the staff outside because you're 5 minutes early! Then you go through security where the people with the little paddles, you know who you are Mr.Pig Ignorant, with the suits and little wires in their ears who talk to you as if you were dog dirt on their shoes!You get crammed in the lifts like sardines.Up to the tight corridor , again packed in, and watch a short video and then get to see the view.The it's up, then down to the viewing floor!Great views, but more very rude, obnoxious people doing talks right in front of where you want to see!! (Empire State building, Central Park)One guy actually pushes people out of the way without saying excuse me so he can do his rubbish speech!There's the "restaurant/cafe" with fifty tables and ten chairs!!!And then when you've done it's like trying to find a needle in a haystack looking for the exit!!All this for the princely sum of $32 each!!I'd say if you want to go up a high building in Manhattan try the Rockafeller or Empire State Building.
One of the Best Observation Decks. Everything about the experience was great. Impressive technology, amazing views. Only negatives were the price and the line to get back down.

Graceful trip to the top with obviously great views. You must go fairly close to appointed time. That said minimal wait and the elevator ride is very exciting with scenery as you would see from the level you're at the time. It is amazing that you cannot feel the acceleration/deceleration at all. (your ears may pop). Once on the top level you can enjoy 360 degree views of the city and surrounding points of interest ..Ellis island, Statue of Liberty etc. A rentable iPad is worth it if you are not familiar withe the skyline. Annoyance to me were the typically selfish people sitting on the window ledge on their iPhone preventing a view from that spot.
Fantastic. Wonderful view over Manhattan in all directions. Special trip with the elevator shows the history of Manhattan i pictures

Beautiful exterior, long lines!. We did not enter the One World Observatory but experienced it from the outside.
