The lines were too long and from previous reviews we didn't feel it was worth the price. The building is HUGE and gorgeous! We were visiting the National September 11th Memorial and the One World building can be seen from there. Very stunning!
A brilliant view of the surrounding areas. It joins the Empire State Building and Top of the Rock as a great vantage point to see New York. Entrance is well organised and the views are amazing.
Must do. Try to go early and book ticket online. The views are great. It's a pity it is behind glass, but nevertheless great experience.

Not Worth the Price. We visited in July and were pretty disappointed with the experience, especially considering the price. The highlight for us was the elevator - the imaging was very cool. The story of the building construction wasn't very interesting. The view was amazing of course but the day we visited was grey so that had an impact. With no open air area photos had to be taken through the window which wasn't great. The whole experience felt very contrived - this wasn't a highlight for our family.

Wow!! Just wow! . From the moment you round the corner and see the 1776 ft of glass and metal your heart soars. This is truly one of the most amazing must do experiences for any traveler. It's not just another tall building. It's a triumph. The Entire experience is spectacular. From the lobby of shining marble to the amazing tour through the the bedrock foundation. Then the elevator ride that makes your jaw drop with the video history of NYC. But that all pales to what awaits. I will not ruin the surprise of what awaits when you exit the elevator ...but I will say this- stand at the railing and get your tissues ready. As a world traveler I can confidently say it is in my top 5 amazing moments. A tip-be sure to get online and book your tickets. Then prepare to be amazed.

beautiful building - great experience. This whole event is very well organised, with plenty of people around to advise you and answer questions. Good idea to buy tickets in advance on line. The views from the high observation floor are amazing, although no better than from the Rockerfeller Center or the Empire State. There is a restaurant at high level, and a well organised gift shop for small items.The attraction is owned by private enterprise, so nothing you buy contributes to the families of those lost, unlike on other 9/11 sites.As you walk out, you can now walk straight to the Reflecting Pools, which is a very sobering experience. They will never build in the footprints of the Twin Towers.

Excellent - A must do for all visitors to NYC. Wow! Simply excellent. From the way the skyline is revealed to the fantastic views, this is a must see. 360 degree views at the top along with interactive element simply beat the Top of the Rock and the Empire State Building - plus you get both buildings in your photos.I would say this gives better views than a helicopter tour. Recommendation would be to do this along with one of the EMpire State/TOTR in a day/night combination.Also if the ticket line is long, go onto the website to book and pay for tickets. You can then use the QR code in your phone to beat the queue and go straight in at our desired time.Excellent attraction on what is a very moving site to visit.

I suggest adding this to your NY travel experience itinerary.. As a native New Yorker I've waited til this day when I could return back to the placed I've worked in the past and share it with my family. I took my wife and son to this location and shared with the others there sadness of those lost and the excitement of our countries resolve not to let terror deter us on this day we went into One World Trade Center. I suggest getting the VIP Tickets to by pass the long lines to get in. Once inside via the VIP we by passed the line to the elevators and got in - the Elevator walls are a screen that surrounds you on all corners and provides a historical time line presentation - a must experience - both up and down. Once on the observation deck the views of NY are breath taking. I suggest adding this to you NY experience Itinerary.

Up In the Sky. Went with friends to see this wonder of architecture and a symbol of the USA resiliency and innovation. One point of advice is to check the weather for rain or low clouds. At the height of the observatory floors (levels 100, 101, 102) you are in the clouds. Unfortunately for us the clouds were low and visibility was zero. If you purchase tickets ahead, you are out of luck. The elevator ride was nice, among the fastest in the world. We occasionally did see the Hudson and East rivers when the clouds opened up. It's worth the visit. Casual foods are available as well as a fine dining area.Remember to be there at least 15 minutes before your selected time and date.

Touching experience. This is a must in NYC. Get tickets in advance and enjoy the outstanding 360 view of Manhattan. The lift ride to 100th floor is also something you will not forget.Book the 09.00 am tickets and avoid a big rush. The site is easy to access, take the yellow line and the subway will take you to Cortland St in 20 min from uptown Manhattan.We also ate nice bagels at the restaurant, and bought the picture taken by a photographer as this is a once in a lifetime experience. Memorable and worth every dollar.

Incredible Views!. Though it was sprinkling when we arrived at One World, the views were still incredible. The entire experience was amazing. We ate lunch while looking down at the Statue of Liberty!They offer a tablet for $15 which will help you identify buildings & other landmarks. We didn't get it, and wished we would have as we kept wondering what various buildings were!My daughter has a gluten intolerance & there wasn't really any food she could eat. I think she ended up with a drink and we had to eat later. I think they also had melon, but so often those don't taste good so we didn't give it a try.

One World Observatory. Amazing. Humbling. Beautiful. We chose to go up even with zero visibility. The pre-show and videos of the making of this building give me chills and bring tears to my eyes. The pride! Don't miss this if you are in NYC. The staff here are kind, pleasant and very helpful. 1984...visited the twin towers2002...visited Ground Zero2015...One World ObservatoryFull circle...

Teething trouble but a great view. We booked a timed ticket, but this didn't seem to matter they let us up 30 mins early anyway, so didn't really save on avoiding crowds.The view is fantastic, but i think they should stop people sitting on the window ledges as it was hard to get close to the window to take photos, also need someone going round with window cleaner to clean finger marks etc of glass now and then,The souvenir selection was terrible, I think whoever designed this needs to re think, the fridge magnets were awful apart from the round glass ones that we found by chance, the colored metal ones were awful (If this is something you buy).All in all, it is a great view.The obligatory group, green screen photo should be available to purchase at a later date using a code like most other attractions around the world.The way out was a bit weird, it dint seem like we were going the right way at first as it was through some emergency looking type doors and up a car park like ramp, was a bit strange, maybe this is just temporary or we went the wrong way lol.

Just Nice. So, New York has three different observatories now: Top of the rock, Empire State and the New One World observatory. I've been in all of them and they are all alike. From this one you get to see the 9/11 memorial and the brooklyn bridge and the statue but not central park. I would recommend the One World observatory because I think it has more history behind it

so beautiful. My friend made me go up, I hate tall buildings, usually because you can feel a sway. I was amazed at the fact that you felt absolutely none of that when you were up there. I went at night, it was breathtaking and the presentation and everything around you was very moving. I was so glad I overcame my fear and got to see it.

Enjoy the view, but remember to reflect. I am reviewing One World Observatory for the singular reason I decided to go up - to enjoy the view and reflect on what the Freedom Tower means. The views are incredible, first of all. There is a 360-degree view of New York from the main observation level, and my favorite vantage point was absolutely the view toward Midtown. Astonishing. I couldn't snap enough pictures, especially since it was morning and the angle of the sun kept changing. (Tip: If you are interesting in great photos, go early and head straight for the north side, there was no glare or reflection on the window at that time.)Like I mentioned, I also went up to reflect. For any American, your first time up to the observatory should not be judged upon the price for a water or a ticket, or the lack of seating or the fact that it is not an open-air observatory. Save these critiques for your second or third time, and the let observatory age a bit. The main reason to go up is to look out over New York from this spot, look down in the pools where the former Trade Centers stood, and reflect. For a purely emotional experience, One World Observatory is absolutely can't-miss for any visitor to New York.To give you something to consider, I decided to pay extra for expedited entry. I walked right in past a huge line of general admission tourists and families, and was the 5th person through the security line. I arrived at 9am and was exiting the elevator at the top by 9:15. I was able to have the observatory practically to myself for about 15-20 minutes before the crowds filled the space. For an extra $20 as a solo traveler, it was worth it to me.If you're visiting New York, just go. Save your critiques of the smaller details for a repeat visit, and don't go up for the wrong reasons. Enjoy the view. Reflect. Appreciate it. That's why you're there.

A must see!. Definitely you need to pre-purchase tickets and print/get them before hand. There was a long line to purchase/pick up tickets, but having tickets, we walked right in! The elevator ride was fun, and the view from the observatory floor was fantastic! I heard remarks that you could only see the south end of Manhattan, true, but it's a Great view. If you want the middle of Manhattan, go to the Empire State Building or Top of the Rock. Then you can complain about not being able to see the south end of Manhattan! *sigh* You can't please eveyone.Benches would be a nice addition though. I know they are probably not there, to discourage people from staying up there for overly long periods of time, but one does get tired!

Fantastic, magic.... What a visit... 102 floors in 60 sec, and a panorama which is really stunning. I highly recommend to visit, that is a real revenge/response from/to the 9/11 attack.The view is just stunning.... You have to see it to believe .

Simply Impressive. Having visited the original 9/11 centre and then the group zero tour followed by the memorial pools, this visit to the top of the tower was amazing. No mention of 9/11: no need to. The view speaks for itself. Worth every cent
worth a visit. it has a great view of surrounding. Getting tickets in advance will save lots of time in line. We went there at sunset, and it was beautiful scene over the Hudson river.

Crowd, but worth the trip!. We visited this Observatory back in late June when it was opened for less than a month, and I have to say that I actually like this observatory more than at Rockefeller or even ESB. First of all, I had a ticket for 4:15pm that day, and reached the top level within 15 minutes from the ticket time, which is quite impressive considering the new staffs and all the processes (it took me like an hour for me to get to the top of Empire State Building few years ago). This was possible mostly due to the presence of several high speed elevators.The observatory itself offers an impressive 360 degree view of New York City (and Jersey City). The side of the observatory that face most of the Manhattan was slightly more crowd than the other sides, which is kind of understandable. The window panes are not anti-reflection though, so you have to get your camera really close to the window to avoid reflection. Another minor negative point about this place is that everything is a little bit too commercialize from the online ticketing add-on offer and people trying to sell us the add-on package again when we reached the top.

Wow. This building is something to see, it is also known as The Freedom Tower as it replaced the twin Trade Centre which was blown up in September 2001. The views from the Observatory are very good but on the day we went it was quite misty. The glass also makes it difficult to take photos.

Great view and elevator ride would be an E ticket at Disney. A bit pricey but it's NYC of course. Skip the photo. We also skipped the iPad's but think they might have been nice. We were with locals who could point out sites, but there were two great presenters at North end and South end who gave a great overview and stories for visitors. For me the elevator was the best part--a trip through time I the way up and a 360 tour on the way down. Very cool

Fantastic Views. This is so well organised. Obviously new but the journey from the entry up to the observatory floor is interesting and entertaining. The highlight is Floor 100 where you can spend as long as you like checking out Manhattan and beyond - 360 degree views.

Amazing view of New York!. This is an NYC attraction that is not to be missed. We went in June a month after it's initial opening to the public. A lot of time and effort went into the presentation of the observatory. You must purchase tickets in advance. You can buy admission tickets for a certain admission day and time for $32 or buy a ticket that allows you entry at any time of day ($65 weekdays) There is a security checkpoint (naturally) just like an airport before boarding the elevators. The elevators are said to be the fastest in the world - 102 floors in under 60 seconds.Once you are at the observation floor, the views are breathtaking. The windows are floor to ceiling 360 degrees. It's very easy to get photos of almost any landmark in New York if you have a powerful enough zoom. You are allowed to stay as long as you like. There's a gift shop with overpriced trinkets (only 3 different style of coffee mug - all expensive and all ugly!) and a restaurant.Even though it's pricey, I believe that it's a must-see attraction when visiting Manhattan.

Great view, but criwded. We booked online and spent the extra $20 to get priority access, which means you can skip all the lines. Once up there the views are fantastic, but the windows are also busy, especially with people just sitting on the ledges and resting and looking at their phones.... Texting updating their Facebook, etc. they should really add some benches for the people to sit and not allow people to sit on the window ledges, making it impossible for other people to take a few pictures. It never seems to astonish me how many people are using their flash to take a picture from the 102nd floor. or taking a selfie, and then wonder why their pictures we crappy.... A flash will reach maybe 3meters.... And flashing the window will cause the iris of your camera to close... So turn the flash off!! We went to the bar to wait for the sunset, and take some night shots of the awesome view. The bar was very busy and with the concrete floor, all the glass and the hard surface ceiling the background noise level was very high, also no music, and I think they turned it off as it just adds to the noise. The bar staff was very friendly and the drinks and the cheese plate we had was very good, pricey, but hey, on the 102nd floor that's expected.... We had to wait at the bar for a table and once a coupe left we had to fend for it as another couple tried to swoop in a take it, but once I told them we've been waiting for it for almost 30 minutes they backed off. The observation deck was not very busy anymore around 9:30 so we could enjoy the night view and take some nice pictures. Btw, The elevator ride is around 40 seconds......with a nice visual show....

Incredible!. We went to the One World Observatory while in NYC over the weekend. I have to say it was worth the $25.00 admission. The views were incredible. The video in the elevator was really neat. It was very clean and organized. I didn't wait very long at all. The people working there were helpful and friendly.

First Class Process & Facility (Getting Down Again Cost It a 5 Star Review). We visited the observatory as a family having booked our time in advance. I was skeptical about the system but it was flawless going up. The queuing system was excellently executed and the building is nothing less than extraordinary. The inclusion of images, video and voice overs from those involved in the project is very well done and reinforces the cooperation required to deliver the building and experience. This is all the more poignant given the history of the site. You can't help but feel emotional and in awe of their achievement in building the observatory. The trip up in the elevator was incredible as a video presentation fills the walls of the space chronicling the development of NYC over the past 100 or so years. The iPad viewing option at the top was also helpful and we certainly enjoyed it (was worth the extra $15). Of course, there was all the usual merchandise to buy at the top which gets on my nerves a little bit and the food was crazy expensive which made me mad and would have excluded many families. Having said that, I guess you just need to suck that up and enjoy the experience. The only down side to our visit was leaving the observatory. Something was amiss with their systems as it took almost an hour of us waiting in line for an elevator to get down. This was the one part of the experience that let it all down. We were cranky by the time we reached the elevator as were others. Overall, it still beats the pants off the Empire State Building experience which is a completely flawed process and needs serious review. That ride is also completely dated and should be revamped or ditched completed (will review that next!).

Not the best to overlook NYC. Even if brand new, just new opening last May, this is not the best way to overlook New York City.From here you can see the sount of the city, Brooklyn Bridge and the bay and clearly Liberty Island, but you miss all the north look, including Central Park and more.

wonderful view. Definitely a must see location in the city as a visitor. It was quite busy but that's to be expected, had tickets booked for 2000hrs but didn't make it to the elevator until 2030 and almost missed the sunset. Protip, if you're trying to get up for the sunset plan on getting up there an hour before so even with delays you will get up there in time to catch it. Also, there are metal detectors and X-rays to go through so review the prohibited items list before leaving your hotel.

Breathtaking views, creative presentation. There was a lot of time and creativity that went into the creation of this observatory, from the walkway through Manhattan schist and the incredible elevator tour, to the 360 degree views. The City Pulse presentations that focused on all things NYC were also really a great touch. There were definitely enough windows all around for us to get a great view of any angle we wanted, even with the number of people that visited. The elevator ride was so cool - they have images on the walls as you ascend which take you through the history of NYC's development in less than a minute, and from pre-historic to current day. The descending video in the elevator takes you outside the Freedom Tower and made it seem like we were in a helicopter, circling the tower to take in the building from all different angles. The one surprising and disappointing thing was there wasn't any information on the building itself and the background about its build, the relationship to the WTC, whether there was any particular reason for the 102 floors, the overall design of the building, etc. We hope the One World Observatory puts something together about this amazing building and how it came to be, given the 9-11 Memorial site just next door.

Awesome views, building still fresh.... Organizationally is better than Empire State Building. You buy (better) online time slots at every 15 mins. Get there 20 to 30 minutes before and take your line. If not, there is a line to purchase and another to enter. After, security check. Amazing elevators to 102 after a nice cooling of line... The trip up is a great experience, same the one down. Up there you go to 102, take a pic or not... Meet the dining area at 101... Good stuff... Observatory with amazing views at 100. An a lousy overpriced souvenir shop reminding me the Burj Khalifa... But the views are views... Oh, and the entrance... Less majestic then the late WTC...

Impressive. Wow, the building that was built to replace the original trade center towers is very impressive. The tickets were very expensive. The elevator ride was so smooth and fast. Enjoyed the "electronic" elevator views. The observatory was a little crowded but we enjoyed the view. We did NOT pay for the ipad so we could tell what everything was. I would recommend bringing a cheap map of the area and using that while up there, save yourself $15.00.

OWO WOW. OK, hold on to your @SS WOW the experience with blow you away. Starting with the ride up the elevator which takes about 48 seconds to get up to 102 (??) stories. But while you are traveling up you are surrounded by screens that give you a history of the skyline outside the building/area. So friggin awesome. The views are spectacular and just GO SEE IT.

Top of the World. One World Observatory is breathtaking. Just the elevator ride makes the experience worthwhile -- 60 seconds to get to the 104th floor! Lines to get in are a bit long -- they could take a lesson from Disney for crowd moving -- but once you get up to the observatory deck it's worth every penny. The lines were not too long when I was there but I imagine they will get longer as more and more people hear that it is open. This is definitely a must-see while in New York City.
Fantastic. Views are fantastic. I would recommend stepping up to the plate for the express tickets to avoid the long lines

On Top of the World. One World Trade Center isn't the prettiest building in the world, but when you're standing on the observation level looking down at the beautiful city of New York, it's a sight to behold. This all glass skyscraper gives you 360° views of midtown Manhattan, the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, the Hudson river, and anything else you wish to see. The $32 price maybe steep, but it is well worth it to stand on top of the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere. Combine this with a visit to the 9/11 memorial, the 9/11 museum, and anything else in lower Manhattan, and you've got yourself a great day out.
Visit to new york. Now a very busy tourist area with many many quick service food counters that realy all want missing .

Weekend Trip. Along with the 911 Memorial, this was an awesome experience. Ticket prices were much less than other observatories. We actually got to go up earlier than out ticket time. Never rushed. Go early in the morning. Crowds got bigger as the day went by.

Best place to visit.. I was so proud to be here and also visit the museum. What an amazing thing. The veiw was breathtaking. And there is a presentation at too before you saw a burning and in the elevator on the way up was the best. Worth it!!

Go when the sun is shining!. Putting aside the emotion and history of the surrounding area (a beautiful tribute to obscene events), One World Observatory is exactly what you expect. A monumentally tall building, ~70% higher than The Shard in London, that on a clear day will let you "see forever". On a less than clear day, you will see about five blocks. The relentless up-sell of iPad apps, staged photographs and assorted souvenirs is tacky in the worst commercial way. But the viewing gallery itself, essentially a 360 degree walk-around view that gives a perspective on Manhattan that no Google Earth electronic reproduction can do justice to, is well worth your time and has become an instant essential for any New York tourist.

Must see after The 9/11 Museum. After the sobering 9/11 Museum, it is important for your family to see what has risen from the ashes! The elevator ride to start your adventure is really cool. The views from the top are magnificent and well worth the admission. TIP: Buy your tickets online in advance!

Great experience marred by bad staff and poor organisatiin. The attraction itself is great and very well presented, but the queuing system is terrible and the staff outside are unhelpful. This marred an otherwise great experience.Some tips to help:1. Get there 15 minutes before your allotted time, they'll send you away if you're even 2 minutes before this.2. If you can afford it, get the fast entry ticket. We didn't and there was another 30 minute wait inside.3. Make sure you have suncream and water for the queue. We went on a scorching day in July and the outside queue is very exposed.4. If you want to be sneaky, go across the road and enter from the underground entrance from Brookfield Place. Time it right though. We did this accidentally, but turned up 20 minutes before our time; they sent us to queue up outside as we were early.Good trip, and good value for money, but you have to be organised to make the most of it. Don't rely on the staff to be organised for you.

One World Wonder. This is a must see. It's expensive($35.00),but what an amazing building. You have to visit at least once. The elevator gets to the 102nd floor in seconds and the City views on a clear day were absolutely breathtaking.

Great views, poor organisation.. Worth a trip just to say you've done it! Fantastic views from the top.Organisation was pretty poor. People with tickets after us (not priority passes) were let in before us and we had to wait a long time outside. Staff seemed really confused as to what was going on.If they can sort the organisation out then this has potential to be a really enjoyable outing.

Excellently done, very enjoyable . Building is very well designed and built The elevator ride up and down is just wonderful, well thought out The views from the top are, as always, magnificent The observatory is quite small though The cafe is very ordinary Entry queue management at the base can be made more efficient and visitor-friendly

One trade center. You can feel the tragical day in this place.The resilience of people is amazing.Almost fifteen years later, the construction is still in progress.Many towers are still in construction. A lot of money is there.But the most important is the memorial with the two pools located at the two towers. We have to remember of this day and to all the people died in this tragedy. The new tower, the highest in the united states, is the symbol of the resilience and the power of this country. The architecture is very special compare to others and very beautiful.

One World Observatory. Breathtaking view of NYC. It was so much more than I expected. The thought that went into designing this incredible structure is AMAZING! So worth seeing. Would highly recommend this!!

WHAT A VIEW???!. Went on Tuesday, July 6th with my niece...as native New Yorker's we are truly proud of the work and dedication that went to making this a reality. We went on the 9:30am tour and it was fabulous! Lines went very quickly and we were able to enjoy the views...WOW. The elevator ride was amazing...it gives you a timeline and it's really worth it. The views are spectacular...highly recommend it.

A new view on the world!. This building and all it stands for is a testament to the people of New York and how they wouldn't let the events of 9/11 stop the drama from continuing.
We were totally humbled by the whole visit and the official slogan 'See Forever' is very fitting.
Well done!

Stunning Views. I visited on the 6th July and decided on a visit to coincide with sunset. The elevator ride to the 102nd floor was fast and had a stunning visual effects. A short presentation leads to an exciting finale!!!. Then you can visit the 100th Floor observation deck. There they have spots for staff giving a little history and explaining New York attractions. The views are stunning. The only negative for me is that there is no outdoor observation deck. The glare from the light on the windows takes away a tiny bit from the view. Nonetheless a great place to visit and a must do if in NY

Tower and views are amazing, but employees seemed confused. The views are simply amazing, especially since you can get right up to the windows and almost look straight down. My 10 year old spent lots of time doing just that and studying the city. The presentation value of the elevator ride and entertainment/education at the top are top notch. Where the visit fell short was with employees who were in charge of moving people through the line and up/down the elevators. They seemed to be confused about who was supposed to be doing what and how the flow of the visitors was to proceed. One of many examples: We paid for the fast pass (well worth the money) and were not properly directed in where to go. We had to fend for ourselves and find our own way even after attempting to get the attention of employees. The One World Observatory could certainly learn a lesson from the Empire State Building in this regard.

Surprisingly pleased. The elevator ride up and down are amazing and different for each direction. Going up you get a time lapse of New York City and going down it is like you are swinging around the building. The video presentation was nothing impressive but then the screen rise up and you get a great view! The tower was great, but it is all indoors, it would be better if there was an outdoor level like the Empire State Building has. Ticket line is run well and mostly on time, you do have to go through an airport like security screening. Plan for about an hour in order to have a good visit.

Go on a clear day!. Honestly, I think the best part of the entire trip up One World Trade Center was the elevator/lift. Watch the walls and see the New York skyline evolve from the 1500s to modern day. I only wish the elevator went up slower so I could have seen a bit more!!Once you're up, it's the standard thing. Don't get me wrong, the view is amazing!! but, it's the view from a tall building!One huge pet-peeve is that they try to sell you the rental of an iPad that has a special app on it. You hold the iPad at whatever you're looking at and it will tell you what you're looking at. To try to force you into renting the iPad, their wifi kindly blocks access to Apple maps, Google maps, the app store and others - and don't think that you can just use your data plan because chances of getting a 3G or 4G signal up there is slim...Other than that, really - go on a clear day - you can see for about 100 miles. It's a pretty amazing view.

Bad pricing policy. They have a crazy policy: while kids 12 and over must pay the Adult price, they must be accompanied by an adult until they are 17!!!!! This is absurd.My kids take the NYC Subway to school every day; they know the city better than a lot of locals, but I wasn't able to delegate the trip to my 16 year-olds and their friends (and save myself the expensive thrill), because they are "too young to take an elevator" by themselves. Stick to the Empire State and Top Of The Rock for an easy and safe way to keep your teens busy and entertained in NYC.

Just to Check it off the Bucket List. at $30 a pop (more or less) the mortgage should be fully paid in a year or so. the best part for me was the one minute ride up the elevator. you're surrounded by a video of the neighborhood over the last few centuries. very interesting. the views of new york and vicinity are great, but it must be miserable on an overcast day. you can rent a tablet for $15 that points out major buildings and stuff. you can buy a patriotic rubber ball for $6. plan on no more than an hour unless you're really bored.

Holy Queue Batman!. On a Monday afternoon in June we visited the new One World Observatory, and I would encourage you to wait.We waited in a queue to buy tickets, but if you bought them online you could skip this queue. The we waited in our time queue (every 15 minutes supposedly) to get into the building. Then we waited in a queue to go through security. Then we waited in a queue to get on the elevators. The we waited in a queue to see a short vidoe before being admitted to the observatory.All in all it was nearly 2 hours to get in to see what we wanted to see. We walked around the 4 compass views and took some pics (always waiting for others to clear out because it was CROW DED DUH)! After just under and hour, we bypassed the high priced drink and snack offerings as well as the gift area and waited 40 minutes- (you guessed it!) in another queue for the elevators to get out..Now, in all fairness the queues were well managed and moved steadily if slowly. The issue was the mass of humanity attempting entrance. The employee at the elevator said they process 10,000 visitors a day.One cool feature is the elevator to the top. All the walls are large view screens. As it starts the elevator ascends it simulates the development of New York City from undeveloped land into present day as you come to a stop. At the same time it portrays a simulated view of the outside as if you were in a glass elevator on the exterior of the building. Pretty cool, but I'd love to do it in slow motion to take it all in.The views at the observatory are impressive as they usually are in such a place. You can see all of the harbour, past Staten Island and the bridge, out to the Atlantic. You can see all three bridges to Brooklyn and Queens, and out past the airports. You can see across the Hudson and Sully's landing spot, the far into New Jersey. To the north is is just a bit disappointing as you can only really see up to the cluster of buildings around and including the Empire State Building. This means you cannot see more than a sliver if any of Central Park and more in that direction. If that is of interest, and it should be to get in ALL of NYC, I would suggest going up in the Empire State Building instead. It's about the same price, less crowded, less waiting and a bit more comprehensive a view.it was interesting to see nearly 2 dozen cranes and projects ongoing, and there were more green spaces in Manhattan that I would have thought. Also, unlike many observatories there were no fixed or adjustable telescopes to use to see things in closer view.So, if you're going to put this on your itinerary, buy tickets online and be prepared for the queues of your life!

Could be better organised but worthwhile vies if you have the patience!. Outside it is simply chaotic, no one knows where to stand for their viewing time and other tourists standing in wrong timeslot queue. Some neurotic worker screaming at everyone via a tanoid and no direction. We almost gave up as everyone was so worked up and annoyed. Doesn't help when we are oversplilled onto the sidewalks causing mayhem. If you can survive to get inside the views are gorgeous and a complete 360 view. Glass could be cleaned more often, no excuse. May get better with time but not on this visit compared to top of the rock and empire stated. Visited 24 June 2015 YB.
Love it, Worth it.. The building is gorgeous.The view upstairs is amazing. Its a little crowded but spaces clear up. It was worth the money.

brilliant. what a magnificent building and the views are outstanding. The staff are all friendly and willing to answer questions. The café seemed a little pricey as did some of their solvenires. It offers really outstanding views on a clear day but on a foggy or miserable wet day its hard to see anything. Really enjoyed our day the sights will be with us forever.

On the top of world. Opened in Mai this year close by Ground Zero. There was a queue for 5 minutes, I think we were lucky. First thought as buying the ticket was that in is expensive 32$ per adult but the tour and view was worth it. Just amazing view from a amazing city.
A gem of the city. The One world observatory is beautifully completed. High tech and informative. Not really need to purchase the guide - just enjoy the scenes from the top

Fabulous. Firstly, I am a little confused as to the title of this building. I thought it was called Freedom Tower, anyway, whatever it is called, it is well worth a visit.We started at the Memorial pools and then went around the corner to the entrance of the Freedom Tower. There is a line to buy tickets or you can do it online. The line wasn't long at all. We bought our tickets outside on the net and proceeded inside. We went on July 6 at 4pm and there were hardly any people around. It certainly wasn't crowded. There is the usual security screenings similar to an airport. Also the phones don't work so take a photo of your tickets if you have bought them on line. After you clear security you are shepherded to a lift that takes you up to floor 102. The lift has a timeline of the NYC skyline which is really interesting. The lift is quick and not at all scary. When you arrive at 102 you are again corralled in an area to watch a video about the building. This was fine for us as it wasn't busy but I can imagine it would be awful with loads of people. The best bit is the end of the video. I'm not going to spoil it.Then you descend two floors to level 100 and it is a panoramic view of New York, Brooklyn and New Jersey. There are floor to ceiling windows all the way around. It is quite breathtaking. My only complaint is that they have some advertising directly at North which blocks the view of uptown and everyone is trying to take photos from a small space to the side. There is, of course, a gift shop with the ubiquitous t shirts and caps etc. You can stay as long as you like, there is no ushering you on once you are on the 100. It was quite an experience and I highly recommend it.

Spectacular views of the City. Lines were quick and well organized. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful. We bought our tickets on site and and only waited about 15 minutes to get in. . The elevator ride and viewing room are well done. Watch for staff selling pictures, iPad tours, etc. The line to get back down was long but moved quickly. We enjoyed the experience quite a bit.

Skip this place. I have to say that I was really looking forward to visiting the One World Observatory but the reality was such a let down. This venue is a one trick pony in terms of the view and to be honest I would have been happy with that but the owners spend a lot of time trying to draw the experience out and all of this is rubbish....a waste of your time. The young men and women working here try hard but their faux whimsy just grates like nails on a blackboard. Spend your dollars in the WTC museum or even Macdonalds but don't waste your hard earned cash on this place.
Expensive but worth it!. Even on a hazy day the views were stunning. We got some excellent photos and the elevator ride was a plus for the kids (all 102 stories)!

Worth It.. We went on a Thursday at 7 pm. We had bought tickets online. We walked right in and went downstairs and directly to the elevator line. It was super quick. The view upstairs is amazing. Its a little crowded but spaces clear up. It was worth the money.

unorganized. The building is gorgeous, but there was a lot of chaos. There was no place for the people who purchased tickets ahead of time. If you didn't happen to ask the attendant then you probably would have stood in line with the people who were waiting to purchase tickets. The view is incredible and worth the trip up. The price is a little high, but was ok for a first time trip.

Hitting the heights. Booked our tickets online - they cost $32 each for three adults.No queuing involved as we had pre-booked. Lift took about 30 seconds to reach the top.Very slick presentation for about 5 minutes then uninterrupted spectacularly jaw-dropping views of the city and beyond. Reasonably priced cafe and gift shop.The one big drawback is once you are up there, there are massive queues for the lift down. So my advice would be join the lift queue sooner rather than later, as you can admire the views as you advance in the line.Definitely not to be missed.

Stunning view and visit with many suprises !. The One World Observatory was one of the first things we have visited in New York and it is still one of my favourite things to see and do ! We've booked the tickets a little bit in advance in order to jump the queue (there are a lot of tourists in June and summer season in general, so you should either get up early or buy the tickets in advance if you don't want to wait forever). This is the most recent observation tower built in Manhattan and they have used the most recent technology to impress visitors from the beginning to the end of the visit. I do not want to say too much but the elevator ride is definitely worth it and the observatory deck gives you a 360° view over the South of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Liberty Island and Jersey City. Even though it is not an open air observation deck as the one of the Rockefeller Center, you still have a beautiful view from behind the glasses.

Even the Elevator to the Top is a Show! Plenty of tickets available at the cheaper price.. It is difficult to give a rating of less than excellent because of the accomplishment of rebuilding such a stunning structure. The history behind the construction and stories told by those involved await you as you prepare for your ascent to the top. The staff was very helpful in advising you to the possible observatory viewing limitations due to the weather. The weather was a factor the day we visited, but we knew it would be the only time we could visit. The exhibits on the lower level and interactive presentations about NYC at the observation level enhance the visiting experience even when your view of the city is limited due to the uncooperative weather. The elevators are unique because the surrounding walls from top to bottom are a constant changing image of the NY City skyline dating from the wilderness area in previous centuries to the current day image as the elevator reaches the top in less than 80 seconds. The 9-11 Memorial and Museum are in the immediate vicinity with long lines which prompted us to choose the observatory. We found that there were plenty of tickets available online for access within the next 15 minutes (the tickets are for a timed entrance) to the observatory without having to purchase in advance. You will have several purchasing options to move ahead of the line, but we found that there was no line so we saved almost 50% by buying the cheapest ticket offered. The bathroom facilities are the cleanest you will find in NYC!

So much better than The Empire State Building.. Its expensive. It pays to get the higher priced tickets so there is no standing in long lines. The elevator is sooooo fast! There are three floors of observation deck, a restaurant, a coffee shop and of course a gift shop.

102 floors up with floor to ceiling glass, much view!. I wasn't fortunate enough to visit the original world trade center observatory, so I can only compare this to the taller buildings I have visited in NYC. I must say, this is pretty well done... [Spoiler Alert] the Elevator trip up is freaking awesome!The observation deck is over two floors with massive floor to ceiling glass windows, which offers spectacular views over the city (360 degrees). I highly recommend going up, even if you live in the city. Totally worth it.

Must see!. Skip the crowds at the Empire State building and forget about Top of the Rock....One World is here! We overnight in NY frequently and always like to try something new so we reserved times for the observatory online. Our reservation was for 12:30. Keep in mind that you won't be able to access the line more that a half hour before your timed ticket and the line is in direct afternoon sun. So choose your day and time carefully. We were lucky it was cloudy since the weather was hot and we did not wait outside more than 20 minutes. The lines moved quickly, security process was efficient and staff very helpful. I have to say that you should not read the reviews that share too much info before you go so that you will have a couple surprises in store. LOVED the elevator (surprise #1) and those lines also moved very quickly both up and down. After getting off the elevator you file into a room that shows a short clip of NY then (surprise #2) and off into the observatory you go. There are also gift shops and a restaurant. This building has the best views I have ever seen. Wait to book tickets until you can plan around the weather for a good day but even in heat, view was fantastic and whoever designed this building definitely deserves an award. One last suggestion, when exiting the elevator and before you go up the escalator there are doors which lead out to a hallway which will eventually lead to the Bus, Subway, Path hub which is under construction. If the sign is not up to prohibit your entry, take a sneak peak and some great picks. It is a beautifully designed, futuristic piece of architecture!!!

Breathtaking . The visit is one with a flood of emotions and feelings. The view is one of a kind. Being able to see all corners of Gotham and all its iconic sites is highly recommended. Not even a helicopter will allow for the ability to see everything at the pace you desire and ability to stop and reflect about a particular view or location. Speaking of sites, the ability to look down onto the foot prints of the World Trade Center buildings and the memorial garden and museum allows for a time to reflect and remember all who were lost. Looking down on some of the most hollowed grounds in our country while standing in a building that is an example of America's perseverance is a feeling hard to adequately express as it encompasses so many different emotions. I kept having the image of the Phoenix and it rising from the ashes.

Enjoyable. Buy your tickets online in advance. The whole thing is very well run, it didn't involve too much queuing initially, lift only took about 30 seconds to reach floor 102 & the views are unparalleled. Getting back down does take a lot longer. For me though you can't beat the top of the Empire state or Rockerfeller.

Incredible. The best sightseeing trip during my last 8 years in the U.S. Incredible show of resilience combined with unbelievable views and modern technology that provides an incredible show of resilience, heroism, and the ultimate patriotic experience. A must see must do trip

Really expensive so make sure it is a clear day.. The lifts have been given a bit of Disney treatment but as it only lasts for a minute it doesn't justify the high price. Souvenir shop needs more quality merchandise, instead of the usual pens and mugs.
Amazing and Humbling . Definitely a must see, must visit when in New York. Breathtakingly beautiful view of the city and surrounding areas. Altogether, very humbling.
Amazing Views. Beautiful Building and amazing views of lower Manhatten to Mid Town. Enjoyed the initial viewing room with short video.

Very good experience!. We visited this place only a few weeks after it opened and it was absolutely amazing, spectacular with breath taking views of the city that have not been seen for a while by the general public. It costs around $32-35 per person over the age of 12 I think, but it was definitely worth the trip up there! It's a great experience and there's alot of space to see the sights of battery park.

Amazing view!. We went the second weekend it was open. We bought our tickets online, which I really recommend! It's a timed entrance, but run well so its not a horribly long wait. The views are just amazing! The only negative for me was that the elevator ride up was so crowded, you can't really experience what is so cool" about the elevator...and it is a "wow!"

What else can you say except amazing experience. Make sure to book a reservation. If money is not an issue, you don't miss much by skipping the line and missing the "preshow". Maybe do it once, but if we go back we'll skip it. The view from the observatory deck is stunning. We rented the iPad which was really cool because you could sync it to your view, and it would tell you what most of the buildings and sites that you could see were, and you could click on them to get more information. My kids could have spent 2-3 hours doing this alone. We had a cheese tray and a beer/glass of wine in the observatory bar which was very good and more reasonably priced than I expected, which was a nice touch. The elevator ride is incredibly cool, make sure to look around!

Lovely views. Fun experience. Once you pass the security check points there are videos to help you understand the construction of the building. In the elevator, you are treated to a display of NYC history. As you ascend the tower, all 4 walls of the walls of the elevator display a video of the island changing from fishing village to modern metro. It is fun to see the changes in a 360 view. The day we visited there was limited views due to clouds and rain. But we were warned that we would only have about a 2 mile view before we purchased tickets. Good customer service. But we were glad we went up. The view was still interesting. Fun visit.

Unbeatable views, a must do experience. They have really done their home work and delivered a terrific experience. You HAVE to book on line ahead of time. The queues are still long but they move quickly. It is very well managed by cheerful and professional staff. The views are of course unbelievable and they pack in as much experience for you as possible

Amazing Views. After visiting the 9/11 memorial and gardens, we walked over to the latest attraction in New York. Please note you need to book timed tickets online before your visit. If possible, book just prior to sunset so you can have both day and night views.Arrive 15 minutes before your time slot and get into the security line (pretty well organized wherein your tickets are checked and you are directed to correct line)Post security, you walk over to the super-fast elevator (47 seconds to go up 100 floors). The elevator has screens all around and you can see how NY has evolved over the years. Next is a short film about NY and then you can finally walk over to the observatory floor to get 360 views! There is a small section wherein you can see what is happening below on the ground (makes you feel as if you standing on a transparent ledge).

Amazing Experience. I was so happy to have a new tall building to take visitors to as opposed to the Empire State & Top of the Rock! The booking experience was easy, we booked the day before and there was a lot of availability and on arrival there was no queue! You do have to go through security so you cannot take drinks in. The experience is amazing! It literally is a journey to the top, with videos from first responders and survivors of 9/11 as you make your way to the elevator. Even the elevator is amazing, and keeps you entertained whilst you travel 102 floors. All the staff were really nice and enthusiastic and made you feel VIP. Then it is time for the big reveal! Everything about the experience is very hi tech, with the iPads available (extra $15) to zoom in on the view to tell you about what you are seeing. There is also 'The Buzz' with staff talking about the history of NYC & things to do in the city. It was nice to have staff walking around on hand to ask questions about particular buildings. There is a restaurant and bar up the top as well, which I thought was really cool and the prices didn't look too bad. It was nice to see the city from a different perspective, as you are downtown. You are closer to the Statute of Liberty and Ellis Island and Jersey. If you are looking to see other iconic buildings, such as the Empire State, you can only see if from a distance, whereas you would see it closer up Top of the Rock. Overall a great iconic building to visit. Nice to be in a building all shiny and new with great views.

amazing!. it was my first trip to new york city and my first attraction was one world trade center. it was amazing technology and amazing. the view of the top was wonderful can see the water and other beautiful buildings. it is worth it!

Good experience. I booked this in advance on-line as we were visiting NY in mid-June, and I was aware that the observation deck was only due to open end-May i.e. expected it to be a brand new and busy attraction. So, as such, booking a month in advance, had to take pot luck on the weather conditions! Sadly it was a wet Monday afternoon, so when we got to the observation deck and had the introductory hype and 'film show' it was a huge disappointment when they drew open the blinds to a wall of cloud! Everybody laughed to save the embarrassment of the kids acting as hosts - but of course nobody's fault for bad weather....... the plus side was that we virtually had the place to ourselves. On a good day it must be fantastic.
Beautiful. This is the most beautiful site in NYC! Ioved the Empire State Building, but this place was the best. Don't miss it!

Heart Stopping Views. The entire experience is well orchestrated with the exception of the priority access, which we purchased. There was a special entry with our ticket, but then we were herded into a mass waiting for elevators. There was a specially long wait since there were too many in the observatory and so we were allowing people to come down first. The problem was, the attendants were a bit rude and uncertain with the crowd and I had to ask twice before I got the answer that we could stand in front of the velvet rope and be loaded on the first available elevator. If I had not persisted in getting this answer, we would have stood with the crowd who paid significantly less per ticket.
Visiting the observatory. Excellent is worth every Pennie you are going to be 100% satisfied most beautiful piece of work breath taking view excellent job guys
Visit the observatory. I expected a beautiful experience but it was far much better than that congrats to all the people evolved in this magnificent creation 100% satisfied

Great Attraction, hard to do in a wheel chair. When they build a new building that they intend to be tourist attraction, one might think they could work out the transitions for the disabled. But, they don't. After you take a really cool elevator ride to the 102 floor, where they try to rent you an iPad for $15 that tells you what you are looking at, you need to get to floor 100. Escalators don't work well for wheel chairs. So, you are directed to wander through the service hallways to find elevators that go between 102, 101 & 100. So, you go through an unlocked door marked, "No Admittance." Each time, some one pops out of an office and offers to help. But, it's clear that the One World Trade Center plan for a staff member to escort the disabled doesn't work. I suggest the lead architect try to use a wheel chair for a week to broaden his horizon. He should be ashamed, really.

Awesome view of NYC. For people who take interest in finding out more about places, there is a lot to learn about NYC here. If nothing else, the view is awesome, make sure you go on a sunny day. I want to try the night view as well; I'm sure it'll be no less in comparison to the day view. I'm definitely going back for this one.
Soooo high. Short lines and breathtaking views. You can do the museum and observatory in half a day. Very friendly staff and security.

To infinity and beyond!. One World Trade Center refers to the main building of the new World Trade Center complex in Lower Manhattan. It is the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere, and the fourth-tallest in the world........what an outstanding piece of architecture! We visited early July having prebooked tickets, paying $32 each adult and $26 for our 10 year old son. I thought that this was rather expensive at the time, but I was SO wrong - it was worth every single cent - IT WAS AN INCREDIBLE EXPERIENCE and I cannot recommend it highly enough to you. On booking, you select a timed ticket, but be aware, you will need to arrive 15 minutes prior to entry time in order to queue.Entry is swift and efficient though with the usual airport type security screening. Baggage size is limited and no food or drink can be taken in - so I advise you to familiarise yourself with any restrictions prior to your visit Restrooms are available inside at the bottom of the lifts. The elevators are FANTASTIC and show images of the growth of NYC during the 1 minute ascent. The lift travels at 7 miles per hour, but you do not notice it. On reaching the top visitors are treated to a wonderful film show on a series of screens which is quite amazing. When it finishes the screens rise to reveal the first glimpse of the view!!!Then it is time to enter the 360degree observation deck. There are no words to describe the view - you MUST go and see for yourself. There are 'educators' on hand at a couple of points, who use a collection of interactive screens to inform visitors about many different aspects of NYC. They were excellent and well worth stopping to listen to. In addition, it is possible to hire an interactive information tablet to use as your own personal guide as you go round at your own pace. To hire this guide costs just $15 and can be useful to the whole family. There is also a cafe and a restaurant at the observation deck - pricy, but that's what you'd expect. Similarly the gift shop falls into that category too!Now, I'd advise a morning visit as there were certainly more people waiting to enter when we came out than there had been when we entered at 10.30am. This attraction far outshines the Empire State Building in my opinion. At the top of the ESB there are SO many people that it can be difficult to make your way to the front to see. The Top of the Rock is better than the Empire State Building in opinion, but One World Trade Centre outshines them both as there is plenty of room, fewer people, and some incredible photo opportunities. Don't hesitate in visiting, I'm certain you'll enjoy it!I hope this helped.

Top of the World in forty-eight seconds. Not to be missed. If you are thinking of not doing the observatory trip because of the elevator ride, don't let that stop you. The ride up is very educational and you don't even realize you are moving. There is a video show shown on three of the walls as the elevator ascends. It starts thousands of years ago in the bedrock beneath the tower and continues on through present day depicting the development of lower Manhattan. Once you reach the top, they take your photo(which you can purchase later) and then you are free to roam. There are also periodic "360 shows" which are informative, and amazing usung multiple screens arranged in a cire- this is free and worth your time. I would not rent the iPad unless you are really into locating individual buildings In Manhattan.The only thing I was disappointed in was that the observatory level was not open air. Go early to beat the crowds.

So well done - Great Experience. Traveled to NYC with wife and 10 year old in June 2015, noticed that One World was now open at the observatory and tickets were being sold, so we bought some tickets online for this while eating lunch and then went inside to get the elevator up to the 102nd floor.Firstly they have a very high level of security, which I found very reassuring given past events. Once through security you get into the elevator. Once you are in the elevator the experience begins, the elevator appears to be a glass elevator with a 360 degree view of NYC skyline as you go up. It's actually a really well done LCD screens surrounding you, but it gives the appearance that the elevator is on the outside of the building, but it's in the middle.Once you get out of the elevator you assemble around a window that has like a movie screen in front of it, a short 3-4 minute video is played then the screen and drapes/curtains come up with it revealing the awesome view, such an excellent effect.The observatory is actually down a ramp to the next floor and it circulates the whole building. iPads are available for hire as an audio/visual tour for a few dollars. If not there are 2 small stages that are at opposite corners of the building running constant talks on tourist type topics.There is a restaurant up there, we didn't go in as it looked like a fine dining affair and that's not our style. The gift store is also up there and they have a good range of gifts, although they are a little on the pricey side.The views are stunning, the financial district skyline view is really second to none, get great views of the islands (Liberty, Ellis etc) and both rivers (Husdon and East).My advice is do this trip before it becomes really popular. We were able to go in with no wait time and also move freely in the observatory due to lack of people, this won't be like this forever.

WOW. Great to have this space back again.
The cafeteria style restaurant and steak house are 2 letdowns.
They do not hold up to the magnificent space.

Standing Tall and Proud. Fantastic, this place is stunning, a great experience, super fast lifts, and the wow factor at the top. A huge mix of emotions as a repeat visitor to this area. Beautifully Done
Extraordinary. Worth visiting. Amazing views of Manhattan as well as Liberty and Ellis islands. Loved the elevators and the surprise after leaving the elevator and before entering the observatory.

Husbands 50th bday visit to NYC. Long line even though we had reservation tickets. Long wait for the elevator after that. Was a nice view but if you've been to top of the rock or the Empire State Building you have seen it. And you didn't have hundreds of people with selfie sticks standing in front of your view. Was expensive for what you got.

Uplifting experience. We ordered tickets to One World Observatory on-line shortly after it opened to the public. The tickets are time-stamped, so make sure you estimate your travel time correctly. We went through a short security check before entering the elevator "experience". As the elevator ascends, you're shown a video of the transformation of New York City over the centuries. It was fascinating, I wish the ride were slower so we could really take our time viewing this clever visual sight. Once at the top, we were brought to an area where we stood to view a movie about NYC on a multidimensional screen. Spoiler alert: once the movie ends, the entire screen is raised to reveal a breathtaking view of the city. Dramatic music made the "reveal" a real spectacle. We were then escorted to an area where we were offered interactive tablets to carry around to learn about neighborhoods and iconic sights. Only downside, once we took the tablet, we were then informed that it would cost an extra $15 to use. No sign or indication of an additional fee. It was worth the cost if you're not familiar with NYC. It allows you to point the tablet at any point of the 360• floor-to-ceiling windows and explains what neighborhood you're looking at and any landmarks. Fabulous! We didn't eat in the sit-down restaurant, but did have a snack at the snack bar, offering everything from sushi to franks to hot gourmet sandwiches. All in all, an extremely uplifting activity, particularly after the somber experience of the 911 Memorial.

Good on a clear day. We went on an overcast day and the sights were not so great. For a $34.00 entry fee, you want to get the best view. If you get there a little before sunset, you get to watch the city come to life at night, as the lights on the other landmark buildings come on. It was disappointing that there were no legends to show what part of the city you were looking at. You have to rent an ipad for that. If you are a native New Yorker, you can pretty much figure out where everything is but would have been nice to have some signage. There is a pricey gift shop (what else is new) and three restaurants. One restaurant has fast food, another has small plates and the third is supposed to be the upscale restaurant. It is pricey. The food is good but the ambiance is not. The noise from downstairs, where he observation deck is, is very loud and the restaurant overlooks an exhibit with lights that are distracting and presentations that are loud. So much so that you have trouble hearing your company. Very poor designing for the location of the upscale restaurant.

Not to be missed. The wait in line - even with pre-purchased timed tickets will exist BUT you will enter at the stated time if you arrive before that time. Could not enter the line until 30 minutes before the time. You might want to set your camera to "Video" for the ride up the elevator ... it is a great ride and unbelievably quick. IF you get the iPad device (which names main things you view and tells more about each - be sure to get complete instructions about it's use when you get it. Food service in the restaurant was excellent as was the selection and presentation.

Ian o top of trade centre. Amazing views 360 views very good as you are inside must visit attraction on day we visited queues not to long suggest purchase tickets in advance little queuing cost 30 dollars per person

Amazing building, stunning views. After security you get in the lift which is one of the three highlights of this amazing building as it has a projected view onto the lift walls which is the pictoral story of New York starting as a settlement and then growing as a metropolis. Then you come out and face a image show projected onto screens followed by the coolest reveal ever - the view!. The interactve pulse demonstration just add to the amazing views. If you can only get to one skyscraper whilst visiting it must be this new kid on the block. On cloudy misty days there may be little or no view so beware. Staff friendly and there is a cafe at the top with a decent selection and reasonable prices. Hired an iPad with an app which pointed out landmarks and then 'flew' you to them with background information - paid I think 15 dollars but we didn't use it much as we were limited time-wise. loved it! You must go!

Freedom Tower. This is a must see if you visit NYC. The history around this site is very humbling. The effort it took to rebuild the site (and done so well IMO) was worth the wait. We had a blue sky day so the views from the 103rd floor seemed to be endless. The docent at the top was a hoot to listen to as he described NYC and the surrounding areas.

WOW. I am normally intimidated by heights, but this ticket was a birthday gift, so I put my brave face on and am so glad that I did! The presentation is awe-inspiring, there were audible gasps in the basement, on the elevator, and especially at the dramatic reveal of the view. Rent the I-pad like device that is offered. It is well worth the money. One per group is probably okay. It answers many questions you will have. Even native New Yorkers around me appreciated this, as knowing how something looks from the ground and looking down on it are slightly different experiences.I simply cannot say enough about that view from 102 stories in the air!Be sure to buy your ticket ahead on-line. People who just walked up got admission times about 6 hours after purchase.

BEST view of NY. It will never be as open and immense as the old observatory where you could actually go outside. Even if you were not fortunate enough to go up in an original tower and are a first timer, the views are still AMAZING. NY and NJ from every angle. If you are not familiar with the city guided Ipad tours give you a description of what you are looking at in the boroughs. The ride up is so much faster and the digital experience on the way up is a cool touch. The view is better than Top of the Rock or the Empire State building. Put this on your must do if you are visiting the city and pre-purchase tickets to ensure a no wait.

The View from the Top. Please, please, if you are travelling to NYC anytime in the future, put this on the top of your not-to-be-missed attractions. First, you need a reservation time, easily done on-line. This is not only necessary, but you will find, unlike other tourist draws like ESB, Top of the Rock, Statute of Liberty, there is no long line to way in, either getting or getting out. Visitors are ushered in in 15-minute intervals, and of course, you can stay as long as you want, all day if you wish. The scheduling is a great idea, but the attraction itself would be worth any wait time. There are photo ops that you will find nowhere else. The history of the building, in fact the past 500-year history of Manhattan, is flashed on the walls of the elevator during your ascent to the top of the 100-102 floor. So, the short version is this: GO! See it for yourself and marvel at what a world we live in that a building like this can be a reality.

The Price Is as High as the Building . The views are stunning and so is the price. We were herded like cattle, with handlers barking incomprehensible orders; one was loudly complaining about a coworker while directing traffic. There was inadequate signage and we went up and down the escalator three times looking for the restrooms and exit. Cool tablets are available--at an additional charge--to describe what you're seeing. They could at least have signs identifying the direction you're looking without charging extra. I can't recommend One World Observatory until the price is lowered to something reasonable and the process is friendlier. Until then, buy a few aerial view postcards.

Spectacular view!. The view from the observatory is just spectacular, commanding and impressive. There are 2 observation floors. The ride up is just 60 seconds in elevators whose walls are video screens that show a virtual reality video as you ride up, taking you on a chronological view of Manhattan's growth & progress throughout the years. Once you step out of the elevator you realize you are close to heaven. Your ear may pop as you go up. Don't forget your camera. The observatory area is quite ample and you may move around the building though all cardinal points. They have restrooms, a restaurant, seating area, a bar, and souvenir shop. Since they are practically new, they may need a bit of more organization. We arrived there around 11:00 a.m. on a sunny Monday. There were confusing groups of people outside and we had to ask. It turned out that there was a line to buy tickets and a line of people who already bought the tickets waiting to get in. The lines moved fairly quickly, but this was a slow day, as evidenced by several other unused closed roped lines. This is all outside. I wonder what would you do if you go on a rainy day. However, they sell priority tickets for a higher fee so your wait isn't that long. In the Empire State Building the lines are indoors. I suggest they build some roofed waiting area outside for really hot or rainy days or figure out a way to do this waiting indoors. There's no parking, so you will have use nearby parking lots.

it is not a real observatory. It's just a place with big windows and a little "show business". Expensive. U$ 35.00. it is not a real observatory. It's just a place with big windows and a little "show business". Expensive. U$ 35.00. U$ 3.00. for a coke or water. A lot of LCD screens everywhere, includind on elevator.There is nothing really interesting. Only a view in the highs. there is no sky above. It is only a very big and huge room with tall windows surrounding, in resume: there are some movies on the way to the "observatory".you shall miss not anything.the sunset at hudson river side is much better. and for free. just sit and watch.
Incredible Observatory Experience. Outstanding views and overall experience at the One World Observatory. The extra $15 for the iPad guide is well worth the money.

Very well presented but not the best observatory in NYC. The whole experience is really well presented and well thought out and a lot of work was put in to make this more then just looking through a few windows, from the talking heads about how it was built to the amazing video in the elevators and the presentation before you get to the viewing deck and there are also guides located at 2 seperate corners of the viewing floor with 360' touchscreens where they will point out various areas of interest.The only reason it loses a star from me is that it just wasn't as good as Top of the Rock (Rockefeller centre) as that was in a better location for views and also was completely open air. While their wasn't as much effort put in in terms of presentation at Rockefeller, it did feel like One World needed all the extra flash to make up for the fact that it wasn't quite as impressive as Rockefeller I felt. I do recommend this but if you're only going to do one observatory in NYC I'd personally pick Top of the Rock as they are both at a similar price level.

Brilliant View - worth a look. The whole experience was great, from the lift up to the observatory to the views through clear glass and an opportunity to sit in the cafe.Good experience by all 6 of us travelling and we would definitely recommend as an alternative to the Empire State or the Rockafella.Great organisation, not over crowded and I like the fact you can choose a time to visit.

Add to your bucket list. Amazing. Better than anticipated. We went at 10:45 at night. New York is an amazing sight all lit up. We rented one iPad when we got to the observatory deck. $15.00. It allows you to pinpoint what you're viewing. We missed out on the bar, too late. Would have been nice to sit and have a glass of wine with that view. Will go a little earlier next time. No lines at the time we went. We felt like VIPs! Staff so accommodating. Add this to your things to do while visiting NYC.

Highlight. This was our very favorite thing in Manhattan. The view was so awesome--We bought our tickets the day before so we didn't have to stand in line. The One World Trade Center Observatory has the best view in NYC.--be sure to spend the extra 15 dollars for a programmed I-pad. You point to a building and it tells you what it is and even tell you about it if you want more info.
Pretty Cool... Was a bit expensive (they could just give you the group picture) but well worth it. GET TICKETS AHEAD OF TIME.

Worth going. They did a great job with the new tower! It's a definite place to visit. I would also make the suggestion to buy the upgrade to bypass the line to get it, which saves a bunch of time. Though be prepared to stand in line to go down, though if moves fast. The food available it also really good to plan so plan on grabbing some eats!

Superb. This is fantastic. The whole experience was great. The experience in the lifts was amazing, the views were stupendous. We prebooked our tickets for 10:00am but we worried whether we would see anything as on the two previous days you could not see the top of the tower. There were minimal queues at 10:00 to buy tickets, but it may not always be that way. I would suggest going on line the day before, checking the weather and then buy your tickets from the website.Food was pricy and service was slow.

Amazing experience. We took famiily vacation to NYC in June. Myself, the Hubs, and our two daughters - ages 20 and 17. For weeks before vacation all I could talk about was how excited I was to go to One World Observatory. I'm sort of a self proclaimed geeks about city Skylines, so this was a big deal to me. Prior to this trip I think the highest I've been was to the top of EQT Plaza in Pittsburgh - about 30 stories. Out hotel in Times Square had a rooftop bar on the 54th floor so that wet my appetite just a bit. Both of these prior experiences were open air views which I love! So...my family was happy for me to get this experience, but not quite as excited as I was. After doing my homework I found out about the "great reveal" after exiting the elevators but I didn't share that information with my family. They were amazed!! Their jaws just dropped to the floor. The views are stunning, the atmosphere is calm and excited all wrapped up together, and the staff was amazing. I will recommend this to anyone I know visiting NYC in the future.

Worth Every Penny - VIEW from the Tallest Building in the U.S.. My family & I recently spent 5 days in NYC and had a lot on our list of must-do's. This wasn't on my radar as an attraction to visit, but when we found ourselves with some unexpected free time we made the decision to buy tickets to the One World Observatory. What a great spur of the moment choice that was! The views are outstanding and kept al entertained for for hours. I suggest planning your visit to begin 30 min before sunset & staying for the incredible sights to follow.

Very touching, yet healing experience.. We did not pay to go to the museum but just taking in the view of the new site and the reflecting ponds was a meaningful experience. It was healing to see the new structure replacing the rubble I saw my last trip to NYC.

Spectacular views & the coolest elevator ride in NYC!. From arrival to departure the experience was amazing. Efficient check in and security process. Enjoyed the viideo re: th building of OWO. The elevator ride was AMAZING!! It really kept your attention and was so quick. The 1st glimpse makes you feel like you can see forever. Amazing views and did not feel rushed. I am hoping to go back to the restaurant.

Fabulous Views. We had a wonderful visit wandering around the observation floor from window to window identifying the many spots in our great city. The presentation given was enjoyable and the "museum" about the building of the tower as you approach the elevators to go up was quite moving to me.I can't wait to take our grandkids back there so that they can enjoy the sights of NYC for on high. Take binoculars so you can get a view of some of the special places. We got a couple of pieces of fruit with were reasonable, but there were no prices on the food before you got to the cashier.Nobody rushed us out so we spent a number of delightful hours.

Worth a trip from anywhere. So many memories and images fill your mind as you view from the newly opened Observation deck. It is well done and offers a small snack bar, a full bar and dining and a gift shop. The view is unmatched and they have interactive displays and other features making it very personal. Worth a trip from anywhere

If you are into views.. If you are in NYC and are into great views, then do it. Adult fees are $32.00, lines long but it moves very quickly. The elevator up is very fast but you do not look out, there is a digital display on the elevator walls that you watch on the way up and down.The experience of ascending that many floors could of been awesome if the elevator glass was clear. There is a restaurant/ snack/gift shop up there. The view was amazing but the overall value was not there. If you have the funds, maybe do it once?

Awesome Views - Worth the price!. Loved every aspect of this experience. The elevator ride up with the LCD screens and time lapse was really well done. You can see for miles from up there.
