My only suggestion is they should have used a different type of glass or coating on the glass to make it less reflecting, we were there around noon so every picture we tried to take showed a reflection of the people standing around me. You can see what I mean about the glass reflecting is some of the photos that people have posted here. However, it was still a great experience.

Really nice experience- offers more than other similar places. We went on a Friday night at just after 10pm and apparently that was a great time because there was NO LINE at all. AWESOME. we got all the personal attention without being herded in like cattle. They really took it up a notch by giving an experience like the elevator being very engaging and some other touches. At most other towers they just get you on the elevator and release you on your floor to do your thing. They also had 2 displays with live presentations going at all times with all kinds of information and you could also ask questions. Definitely was worth it.

If you don't do anything else, do this!. The Freedom Tower is beautiful from the outside, but when you enter the doors and go inside it is a whole new experience. We went early morning, so not many people were there and didn't have to wait in lines because we had the premier tickets that let you skip the lines. As soon as you pass the security section and walk in, there are videos playing on huge screens with people talking about when they were building the tower and then you get on the elevators. You go up about 100 stories and then you are on the observatory in the tallest building in the greatest city in the world!

Anti Climax.... It's 95 degrees, the sun is beating down and a gathering of equally misinformed tourists and staff gather at the top of the steps. "I'm booked onto the 1330 tour, which is the correct line?""Please head to this line, Sir.""Actually, it's this line", a confused colleague informs me before a debate ensues between them.Alas, I join a line, it's moving steadily, no complaints. I check myself in the window. I'm not sweating too much, probably looking a little fat, but that's what New York does to you.Ushered into the foyer, I feel the cold blast of air conditioning hit my face and we proceed quickly through to security. I empty the inordinate amount of possessions in my pockets into the tray and proceed through the 'beepy beepy' machine.I'm through, I'm nearly there. I've just got to get through this...cave? I enter the faux granite wonderland wondering if I was actually going to an observatory deck or exploring Mordor. I cleared the area, free from Orcs and boarded my elevator.The doors close, the tension builds, the elevator starts to move. My fellow explorers and I disembark to be herded into a dark room. I stare at a wall, an animation starts, an animation ends. My eyes struggle to adjust to the light, but I make out some buildings and some sky before the view is hastily taken away from us. The tension."Great", I think to myself, I can finally get to the observation deck and take in the sights of NYC. Before I know it, I am approached by an overly enthusiastic member of staff who asks if I'd like to purchase a flying tour on a cumbersome tablet, I politely decline, still no views the tension mounts. I'm being forced into a photoshoot area. I politely decline once more and continue on my way. "I'm through, I'm through.......Oh, it's a restaurant."By this point, a cold beverage, preferably with an alcoholic content seems like the perfect way to quell my frustrations and cynicism. I sit down at the bar, I order a cold beverage with an alcoholic content, I finished said beverage, I pay my check and continue on my quest.I walk round to the stairs, I'm ready, I'm humming the Indiana Jones theme tune - loving life.I duck and dive through the assault course of selfie sticks, take the obligatory instagram snap and leave.One World Observatory was as anticlimactic as this review.

Great view. The view was amazing of the entire New York City skyline! We rented the $15 iPad to help identify the buildings. It was pretty expensive for what it offered. It did have a link to check out the labeled sites. May want to just take a picture of the poster in the sales area if you do not want a detailed history of each site from the links.
Best observatory in NYC. Definitely worth the price (which is substantial) if you are in Manhattan. They also provide a pretty nice show after the elevator ride, which in itself is fun.

Great views of forever. Very friendly staff, elevator ride up and down was AMAZING. Great views, not overly crowded. The staff was very accommodating and very knowledgable about the whole city. It exceeded my expectations!

Pick your day based on weather. So it's well worth it, views on a good day forever....So my tip is work out how long it will take your to get there. Go online and book the next session allowing for your transit time.Some sessions will be booked out but if you time it right, you can rock up with your tickets and jump straight up to the front door and down into the security.The ride up and the view are great and if you get to pick the day, then you're in for a treat.
Nice view of NYC. The 360 degree view was really awesome!However I think the tickets and merchandises were too costly. Staffs need to be better organized and polite.

Family of fdny. Although 14 years since the attack on our city and the landscape and skyline changed. .the pain still haunts any of those who were closely affected by the attack..although this newly constructed architecture is beautiful there is something so strange about being there. .the museum offers a lot history and memorials to those who have perished. .I feel that it's a place to reflect ..but it has a circus feel to it...you visit and leave your thoughts. .but please remember thousands lost their lives here that day. .some bodies never recovered..when people take those "selfies"It a little sickening

Very average experience. It was all a bit disorganised (and nothing like the efficiency of Top of The Rocks). Staff were friendly until we got to security - who were just plain rude / obnoxious. I did complain to the manager. The lifts to 102 floor are pretty good - the 'reveal' show is ok - but it is all a bit sanitised. You need to be behind glass but taking photos is hard. I would;t go back. Just a tick in the box and an expensive one at that!

Great view, modern streamlined design, definitely recommended, especially for visitors. We just visited Toronto Tower a month ago and could compare the two. The NYC Freedom Tower observatory design is very contemporary, much more spacious and of course view is superior as NYC architecture has longer history and many outstanding older skyscrapers. The famous imaginative elevator ride through time is amazingly fast and do not allow enough time to see what exactly changes over the centuries since Europeans purchased the island. The entrance corridor with multiple screens presenting people involved in designing and building of the Tower is very moving and well done.Also, view of the Hudson, East river, Brooklyn bridge etc is incredible. It's quite amazing to see reflections of the passing boats in the middle of skyscrapers. We live not far from Manhattan and work there, so we know the most of the landmarks. But devices that one can rent and point at the windows to see the major landmarks on the screen with the names next to them must be very useful for the visitors from the other parts of the country and abroad.The buffet on the 101st floor is quite overpriced ... but it is to be expected. The restrooms on the 100 floor are too small for the crowds, even men's has a line. But ones on the bottom floor are empty.I would like to come again during the dark time to see all city aglow,

Best experience in NYC. Purchase the timed ticket and hang on! Very impressive from the ground floor up. Elevator ride amazing. My 15 year old son can't stop talking about it and he isn't easily impressed.

Amazing City Views. A spectacular building and observation deck with some extremely magnificent views of the city and beyond. The elevator ride to the observation deck takes about 45 seconds and during that time you experience the growth of what is now known as NYC! Upon exiting the elevator you are greeted with an amazing video and a truly surprising reveal. Many, including myself, gasped with approval and delight. In every corner and niche of the observation deck is an amazing, unobstructed view of Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Empire State Building, the Statute of Liberty, the bridges, landmark of where the twins use to be, the views are endless. We pre-bought timed tickets and found the line to move along quite quickly and efficiently. It also didn’t feel so rushed and crowded and you could linger a bit to take photos. Without a doubt, One World Observatory should be added to one’s to-do list when making a trip to NYC.

"Got to do it!". We did have to queue in the heat for 45mins so be prepared ! Once in though a really exciting experience.I'm not saying more because I don't want to spoil it! We did have a cocktail-had to wait ages to be served-it was ok.The rest of the experience was worth it.

Buy times tickets online!. The One World Observatory was spectacular! The elevator ride is awesome and the views once you get to the top are amazing! Buy timed tickets online and you will avoid lines and waiting!

The Newest NYC Must-See. We expected to wait on many long lines.....but we got there early in the day so we did NOT! The exhibit opened recently so there a few little kinks in finding your way about to get in but there are many staff members on the plaza to direct you. If you have a Citi-Bank credit card you can get the expedited entrance. The ride in the elevator is a show in itself and there are two different ones to watch for the up and down ride. When you reach the top prepare yourself for a breath-taking view. There is plenty of room to wander about and two small restaurants to relax and enjoy the view. There is a narrator that stands in front of a large wheel of computer screens and gives you information about the sights. We felt that the fee was well worth the experience!

A MUST SEE. If you only do one thing while in NYC, see this...you won't be disappointed. First Class all the way.... but the secret is buy the priority tickets... this will cost you a little more but well worth the price. The advantage you select the time you want to go, and instead of standing in line for an hour or more, you show your ticket and walk right to the front of the line and are escorted all the way to the elevators NO WAITING.... then after your spectactular expreince, you show your priority ticket and get to go to the front of the line to get out...another hour plus savings....and the veiw are world class... TRY IT you won't be disappointed.

Monument to resiliency. This is our answer to those miserable excuses who destroyed the original WTC buildings and took thousands of innocent lives.This magnificent edifice shows the strength and resiliency of America and her people. This is a living monument to those who perished and the views from the top are stunning. One can only hope that at some point they will put in a restaurant that can be a worthy successor to Windows on the World. In the interim, enjoy the view and revel in our ability to rise from the depths to the greatest of heights.

Greater 360° view over NYC. The One World Observatory is not only the newest and tallest observatory in NYC, but also the most organized one. The possibility to reserve tickets online makes your stay even more relaxed/organized.Pros:- very quick ride with the elevator - amazing view over Manhattan (and further)- fast-lane access- online-reservation- food and drinks availableCons:- at time of travel not included in New York Pass

A $75 per person MacDonald's Meal. Ms. Jean van Burren and I live in New York City, and we dine at nice restaurants fairly often, so we were anxious to experience One Dine, hoping that it would be similar to the Windows on the World experience that one could have at the former World Trade Towers. WE CERTAINLY HAD NO SUCH EXPERIENCE.First one must navigate through another restaurant and arrive at a very unprepossessing entrance to Dine One. When we were seating, we were given menus which showed a fixed price of $75 per person. That's not a bad price at a fine restaurant, and as it turns out the food at Dine One was splendid. We loved all of it, but it was spoiled by the ambiance. The tiny dining area is on a balcony overlooking the loud tourist observatory of the 100th floor. I have nothing against such areas, I just don't want to be Immersed in them while I'm trying to have a fine meal. IT REALLY WAS THE EQUIVALENT OF BEING IN A MACDONALDS. Lectures were being given below about the history of New York City, and we couldn't hear each other speak. Constant tourist traffic below was terribly distracting. Also the decor is deplorable. I know designers of fast food restaurants who do better. WHO PLANNED THAT RESTAURANT? I'M AN ARCHITECT, AND I'VE GOT TO BELIEVE THAT THE PLACE IS EITHER AN AFTERTHOUGHT, OR ITS DESIGN WAS SLASHED FOR BUDGET CONSIDERATIONS. I AM TELLING EVERYONE I KNOW THAT THE RESTAURANT IS A DISASTER BEST LEFT UNVISITED.John Szubski

Great views... but much left for experience. to be in place of 9/11 for July 4th weekend and experience joy/pain together is speechless. We booked our tickets on-line with selection of the time when we can go (better option to wait in line and then get tickets especially when traveling with children) and preferred the evening time so we could capture some good pictures with lights and city skyline. The ride to the top with the "new generation elevators" speeding you through the history of NY city is a good kick for children. Views from the top are surely spell-bounding but facility in itself can do a lot more for the price they charge for admission. It does not take much to keep some benches on the floor for elderly and families with children to take a break and enjoy the views instead of sitting on the floor vents and preventing others from coming closer to the glass windows to take in the views and photos. You have to pay a fee to get gadgets that tell you the landmarks you can see... it can easily be made free by posting sign boards atop the roof on what you see from where you are. Overall we wouldn't call it a "must" to see but then can you really leave such a historical event place without seeing/experience it??

Glad I went but won't go back. It's quite the site. They move people in and up very efficiently and the views are spectacular. But once you been, no reason to go back. Rather, spend some time contemplating that fateful day gazing at the names surrounding the 2 memorial pools.

Summer and the City. Spending the Summer in the BIG Apple and was excited to see that the observatory would finally be open during my stay. I patiently waited to go until my nephew and husband came to town. We had tickets for 10:15 am and it was a breeze. No line, no wait, perfect...go early. I was very impressed with all of the visual technology. It looks like no expense was spared. I don't want to give anything away, but it is worth every penny. The views are spectacular, you will love it!

Wow - oh wow!. Lucky our trip coincided with the opening of this Observatory. Even though we had a timed ticket queues were long, but they moved reasonably quickly. From joining the queue to actually getting onto the observation deck was around 45 minutes. The staff were wonderful - warm and very welcoming. This whole experience is totally worth the $32. This is the same price as the Empire State, but so much better.
Well done New York. Well worth seeing I was very impressed ! view amazing ! Well done New York ! Cost $32 worth every penny the lifts alone show new york from the begin until to now .

Buy timed tickets online. Great unobstructed views, and timed tickets prevent crowds. Views on four sides. Even the elevator rides up and down are remarkable. Highly recommend. Requires a little time to get through lower level and to the top so expect to spend at least an hour - and more if you take lots of pictures or eat at the restaurant.

Amazing views!. Great experience and so happy we spent the money for this. The elevator ride up is so short and really cool. It's amazing you can get all the way to the top in 47 seconds. You first go through a theater introduction and then they reveal the views of the city which are unreal. You can see everything in the city. It is somewhat Difficult to take photos because of the glare on the windows, but otherwise, no complaints! Beautiful views and a must see in NYC!

MUST SEE, modern, greta elevators, wonderful views. In 45 smooth seconds, the quiet elevator will get you up to the Observation Deck, but you won't notice it because a video will be playing and you'll be there before you know it.You exit the elevator and you see an awesome video, with a surprise at the end (I won't spoil it for you, but the audience gasped in approval). There are awesome views of Manhattan, the Empire State Building, Brooklyn, the bridges, Governor's Island, Statue of Liberty, New Jersey... you can really see forever and for a long way...Note about tickets: We purchased the 'Day Flex' tickets and went straight up to the from to the line. Flex means you can go up anytime that day, otherwise you wait in a long line till your appointed time. Also after entering we went to the front of the elevator line (VIP line). That was a nice surprise and we congratulated my wife who bought these tickets online a month prior.The views are spectacular. There is also a great feeling of overcoming evil, that we resurrected a building after evil people destroyed it. I had a lump in my throat while visiting. I recommend this to anyone.When you're done, visit the adjacent 'Brookfield Place' where there is a lot of shopping and food. If you are a fan of 'Shake Shack', there is one across the street.I enjoyed this immensely, and I am not usually a fan of touristic attractions :-)

Magical Experience. Not a cheap adventure but worth every penny! Starting with the entrance through the bedrock upon with Manhattan stands, then ascending in the swiftest elevator ever with scenes of the transformation of New York from beginning times videoed on the walls, and finally arriving at the 101st story with 360 degree views of the City from unbelievably high in the sky, this experience is indescribably magical. You drink in the views up the Hudson, across to New Jersey and the Hackensack River, down to the Statue of Liberty and Governors Island, up the East River with all its beautiful bridges and across all of Manhattan where the tallest buildings are still far below you. There are restaurants and a gift shop at the top but we were too busy soaking up the scenery to care! Visiting on July 4th with distinct memories of September 11th made it especially poignant and made us very thankful for the strict security measures we encountered.

The entire experience is geared to tweens. It is insulting to adults.. I made reservations for myself and three other adults for dinner at One Dine. When we arrived, there was no direct access to the elevators, we were expected to follow lines that wound through some kind of childish maze. We had no interest in the sixth grade history lesson, but were forced into the line anyway. We were dressed for dinner, but everyone else was in todays casual attire of sweats, T shirts, and sneakers. The elevator ride was ruined by some kind of freakish animation on the walls of the car. We arrived at One Dine and found that the dress code was “dressed”. The couple in the table next to us were wearing sneakers and T shirts. The menu was plain, food was OK, and the bill was $500. If the setting had been tasteful on any level, we could have overlooked many faults, including the constant automated history of the World Trade Center that blared on speakers one open level down making it almost impossible to converse. I can see the intent of this operation is for a one time gouge, not for the return customer. Oh how I miss Windows on the World!

Great views maybe the best in nyc.. Went to observatory after the top of the rock and empire state and was preety expressed was probably my favorote. 9/11 memorial is right next door aswell and most tour buses take you there. The staff seemed to have no idea what they were doing or maybe didn't care. To get tickets you have to go inside first then join the big line outside the door!

nice views but nothing special. Having been at the top of the rock a few times before, we went here after it had been opened. The tower goes high (100+ floors) and there was not much of a line to get in. Bought tickets on site, as buying them beforehand would require specifying time of visit very precisely. Wait was maybe 30 min if not less on site. Was fine for us. The views from the top are generally nice, although for some reason I preferred top of the rock. Maybe just the newness aspect of it or the location I don't know..Definitely worth the visit and the experience though.

One World Trade Center July 3, 2015. We bought passes for 2 adults & 1 child totaling $90. We rode subway from Times Square and arrived 30 min early. Line up for tour was 15 min before tour time. Lines moved quickly and security check point went smooth. Elevator ride up is great, pay atrention to the walls. Observation deck view is excellent with views from 360 degrees. Downside is certain viewing areas may be crowded but eventually they clear up. Good experience and great view.

What a view!!!. This is definitely a must do especially during fine weather. The view is very impressive.Although it was a bit over crowded, it did provide a maganificient view of New York city. You will not be disappointed. Although you should buy your ticket a head of time if you want to avoid long queues

Breath Taking. One World Trade Center is absolutely spectacular. It beats top of rock observatory out of the water. It is truly amazing to see this place even with the history behind it. The building is really looking into what the future holds. Levels 100-101 had the most amazing 360 panorama views of the city I have ever seen. You really need to plan it on a nice day with clear skies or plan it so you can see the sunset. I will return to this place next time I am in the city with my friends because I think everyone should experience this place at least once. They have a restuaruant upstairs it's a little pricey but I mean you are eating on top of the world with the best views of the city. Even the elevator ride up to the top was cool, they gave you a 3-D visual and it only took about 45 sec! This is a Must see! From Start to finish.

Best views of NYC and beyond!. Loved this observatory - get timed tickets in advance. Go early! It gets crowded throughout quickly. After riding up the elevator (very fast) you see a short film and then the wall is raised for you to get your first view of Manhattan - very nice effect! People applauded when this happened. You can stay as long as you want. It's worth listening to the observatory docent and the technology-based virtual tour of the skyline. Very relaxed - plan for one hour once you reach the top.

Highly Recommend. We figured, while here, we may as well go to the top. Was $32 (as I recall) per person. Was a weeknight and were able to get up right away as it was later, about 7p and a bit questionable on rain. Have inner ear problems and worried about 102 floors in 60 seconds. Took decongestants before the elevator ride. I think perhaps that the elevator is pressurized somehow because my ears hardly bothered me and the ride took, as promised, 60 seconds. The "video" that displayed on the walls of the elevator as you ascended was fantastic and I really wish the ride had taken longer, or been able to view it again with nobody blocking it. Upon arrival at the top we were herded, again, to watch a video / show on the wall. We were hungry and needed to use the bathroom and didn't want to be held in a holding area watching another presentation. Plus, we were too close up front (the only position you could be because it's standing only) to appreciate the entire thing. Well, you have to go for the surprise after it was over. WOW. Well worth it. I understood why. Then, found the bathroom (several and adequately sized) and then wanted to eat. 3 options - snack type stuff, make while you wait (outstanding - many choices including healthy) or formal sit down. We did a combination of the snack type (coffee, fantastic dessert) and make while you wait (out of the world flatbread-we got two different types) then sat at a tall table to eat. Here, unfortunately, not enough seats. And of course, people on their SmartPhones not even looking out the windows but taking up prime eating space where those that wanted to eat had to sit on the floor. If you're not eating, you shouldn't be allowed to sit at a table, especially on your phone. Were unhappy about that. We made sure to give our seats to people who were wanting to eat and didn't want to have to sit on the floor to do so. Afterwards we walked around and looked at the 360 amazing views. As expected, could hardly find an opening at the windows. At two locations there were presentations on a variety of topics related to NYC and the speakers were excellent. Eventually people cleared out as it got dark and we spent a long time speaking to Matthew (?) from Ohio who as I recall said he moved to NYC for theater and works there. We could only stump him on one question (Ellis Island, have the other buildings ever been open or just he main one). We asked all sorts of questions and he had answers. We really appreciated his time and never felt he wanted us to leave. I would highly recommend this. There is a gift shop too. iPads are available where you can point and push a button and get all sorts of details about the buildings you're seeing. We opted not to do that and probably should have. It wasn't that clear as rain was moving in but on a clear day, do it. As I recall, maybe $15. Well worth it.

Interesting but not great. Visited by timed ticket, very little information on where to get the lifts. Found them great journey in the lift good graphics. Got out, nice little surprise video link to your first views. Go through the door to the hard sell of renting an iPad so you can tell which buildings you are looking at-poor show, very pushy! Go down the ramps to the views. Ok not bad but windows very dirty with finger prints and the glare off the glass results in poor photos. No where to sit and gaze out so people sit on the window ledges therefore others can't see out. Go to the restaurants all full no seating available. Overall disappointing and should have gone back to the top of the rock. Classy and a better experience with better information freely available. Very costly just to wander about an open plan office!

See Forever. An amazingly fast lift takes you to the observation deck for 360 degree views of New York City. A great ipad ($15) lets you pick out the key landmarks, with decription and video. Sit down cafe was also pretty good.Queues are very long - suggest paying extra for priority access which lets you jump all the queues - also buy online - its quicker!

Ah..Freakin'...Mazing!. Maybe it was just what the building stands for, but I could not get enough of One World Trade Center. The building itself is amazing, but then you get to the top and can see everything for miles. You really can "See Forever".There are a couple things you should know before you go. #1- Buy your ticket online and skip the LONG ticket lines. #2- Eat before you go. They have food, but there isn't much to choose from and it is REALLY expensive.

Very disappointing. yes, it's very impressive and, booked in advance for VIP access at a preselected time is worth the extra bucks to get in quickly without endless lineups.The layout of the viewing platform however, is just the same crowded concept as at empire state. The prime spots are always blocked, there is no "layered space" allowing to view above first, second, third row, it's all level and busy.Great to get in on an expensive VIP ticket, try to get out ?,it's an endless queue once around the entire viewing level, taking longer than the entire experience of getting up and trying to get a decent view of any direction.Buy the "add on" i-pad" ,is a total waste of money. If you are lucky to get an explanation with the device, good for you.I was just told it was self explanatory. Well, it wasn't, Until the end I didn't really figure it out, but it was a clumsy, heavy of distracting piece of electronic equipment to carry around
Great, but too expensive!. The views are spectacular, and you get there in 43 seconds, as you see Manhattan through the elevator. Fantastic!

Great views, not too crowded. Really enjoyed visiting the observatory at the top of the world trade center. The views are obviously spectacular but what was really nice about it was that it wasn't too busy so there was plenty of space (may just have been when we went as it was a rainy day), the elevator ride (would love to do that 10 more times to see everything) and a decent bar with some good appetizers (cheese plate etc) and a good beer and wine list, much better than you would expect in a tourist attraction. We stayed up there for a drink and the skies cleared and we were rewarded with an amazing sunset and colors in the sky.

Must see attraction. This really is the new place to see ,on the 9/11 site the observatory was opened in May this year on the 104 th floor. The views are stunning and a must for the photographers amongst you. From the minute you enter its full of surprises (tip) have your video camera running when you enter the lift !!! There is a cafe and gift shop at the top so sit and have a coffee while the world carries on below you. Another tip the queues are enormous so if you can purchase vip tickets online before you go you walk straight past the queues and it's not much more expensive.(don't go into the queue ask a guide and they will show you where to go to bypass it )

Must See. My husband saw the Twin Towers when he was young, so when we were in NYC, we knew we had to visit the One World Trade Center. The elevator shoots you up to the top in 47 seconds! After getting off the elevator, you'll end up in a room where they start a video. I won't spoil it, but it's great. Then you move out into the observatory. Since this tower is so close to the water, one side of the observatory faces toward the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. We thought the view of New York from The Empire State Building was better, but this tower is gorgeous and it has a lot more flash and style than you get at the Empire State Building. I highly recommend you see both buildings!

Disappointing, not horrible just ok.... For the cost, I was expecting a better experience. To start, it is inside which is great if you are going in the winter. But it leaves a glare if you try to take a picture. Unlike the Empire State Building where you have an out door observatory. The food wasn't great and was obscenely priced even for New York standards...$6 for a bottle of Gatorade?The only thing that was unique was the ride to the top. It was literally 50 seconds to go up 1200 feet. And the elevator walls were giant LED screens that showed Manhattan being built up around you over the last 100 years. It was a cool novelty, but not worth the price of admission.In all, if they cut all the prices (admissions, food, gift shop, etc..) by 25% I would say this attraction was worth doing. But given the prices, you would be better off putting your money into something else (ESB or the Natural History Museum).
1st visit. Great view of the city, must visit even though price of admission is a little pricey. Plan on visiting again in the future.

Amazing view. I had to choose between Top of the Rock, Empire State Building and One World Observatory, and I believe I chose the right one. 360° view of NY. Go there when it opens as it can get crowded up there fast. Take amazing pictures and enjoy. We only stayed up there for an hour but it was still worth the money to see it once in your life. It is a very beautiful building.

Much prefer Top of the Rock!. We visited yesterday and to be honest, I was a little disappointed. The elevator ride to the top was great, as was the film presentation with a little surprise at the end! The views are great, but the viewing areas are all inside and taking photos is a bit 'hit and miss' because of the reflections from the glass. Tickets are expensive and in my opinion, the Top of the Rock is a much better option.....here, you are outside and can feel the wind in your hair and appreciate not only the spectacular views to the Empire State Building and Central Park, but hear New York too! On the plus side, the staff at the One Worl Onservatory are very enthusiastic!

Amazing Views. This is a "must see" experience in NYC. We purchased our tickets online in advance, which worked out beautifully. Even on a drizzly day, the views were beyond spectacular! Although I am not wild about heights, this did not make me dizzy or fearful about being at the edge. The scenery overshadowed any anxiety that I might have otherwise felt.

Amazing Views But A Little Disorganized . The scene in front where tickets are purchased is a bit chaotic. I had to ask a number of workers how to buy tickets before I finally figured it out. There are multiple lines to be navigated. Walk up wait was over 4 hours. Express wait was only 1 hour for X2 the price. Strict security inside including remove your belt? Neat elevator ride up to 102nd floor. Walls of the elevator are digital screens with a nice video presentation on the way up. Once up there is another video presentation in a room which is good. Then into the observation deck. Amazing views. Tons of people hogging the windows. Be patient. Expensive gift shop and small restaurant up top. IPad with an interactive multimedia presentation looked fun. Very good attraction worth doing once.

Great time - even in the rain. We purchased advanced tickets which we didn't end up needing as the crowd was thin on the day of our visit, but our experience was great. A wonderful ride up to the top and great views. Also there were information presentations at the top about NY. Our view was of some fog and rain, but it was still awesome.

Rip off. It was ok but the price was too expensive...I was expecting for more but when we went there, the skyline was hazy. I don't think it was worth the price. Also, when I asked the staff as to where the bathroom was, the reply was I will show you the bathroom after the 3 minute show.i am pregnant so what do you expect.. Anyway, I was not happy with my visit at this place.

SPECTACULAR. This is a statement of the American spirit. From the elevator to the wrap around views.This experience is worth every penny and I won't share every detail to ruin the experience for you. We started the day in the 9/11 Memorial and museum, then had lunch off site and returned for the Observatory. It was an emotional day and I might recommend splitting the two into different days.However, Go visit, don't live in fear. This was worth it.

Definitely worth going but ... . We went here and everything worked well - the presentation and views are excellent. It is expensive for what it is though and my photos would have been better with an outdoor viewing platform. It felt new as well - some of the staff were still learning! I remember the old World Trade Center as being better for photos but sadly that is not an option anymore. This is definitely better than the other tall buildings to visit as the view back to midtown is what you want I think.

Small observatory; $5.00 cokes and $5.00 refills; exiting can take up to an hour!. Very small. Timed entry, but no organization for exiting. We got stuck in a 50 minute line trying to exit all at the same time. This can be a problem if you have another times site you are trying to make. The elevator rise is really short but fantastic, be sure to have your video ready to capture it. you will not have time to pull out your phone! eating options at top are very small and cannot accomodate a fraction of the people that arrive, so plan to avoid. Also, if you are lucky to get a seat in the dining room, the coke is $5.00 per glass -- they will be happy to refill, but they failed to tell us that the refill is $5.00 Rather deceptive not to tell folks this. We did not see the bill before our credit card was charged, so we had no idea until we look at the bill as we left. Note to management on the folks seating for the restaurant: we witness some pretty terrible behavior in this regard. Ignoring folks in line and telling some people they need reservations while telling others no reservations are taken and it is first come first served. There were at least 3 people at the desk on our day and we found what we observed very unprofessional. Indeed, I was first told I needed a reservation; then when I asked to make one the smae person told me that they do not take reservations and it was first some and first served and they expected a wait of an hour. I just kept coming back ( as there is not much to see after you walk around once or twice and take in the views) and when I spotted an opening at the bar I specifically asked for that and got it. So, we spent about 30 minuted getting up to the observatory and taking in the site -- 30 mins dining and about 45 minuted trying to get out. Limited toilets at the top so that is also a problem in exiting as folks are lining up for the toilet in the same area where you are trying to exit. Exiting procedures seem to be not well considered.

Better views at other spots. Average attraction. View is disappointing and nothing like what you see on TV. The timed tickets were a good idea, but the trip down is a nightmare, as everyone is in line at the same time. I wasn't impressed with the view. You can see the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and other landmarks, but the air is mostly hazy, so pictures were not optimal. I would not spend the money to go up if you have been in other venues. The elevator ride is entertaining, and you stand in a room so they can "drop the curtain" on the view initially, that was ok, but would be better on a clear day. The day we were there, they were expecting 250,000 people to attend! Only 5-6 elevators to take 10-12 people at a time.

Unforgettable. One of my favorite things that I did while in the city. I went around 3pm and would love to go back to see the same view, but during sunset/night time! The view is absolutely insane, and everything you get to see and experience on your way through the line & going up in the elevator just adds to the great experience.

Maybe not Forever, but well worth seeing Far Enough. Slogans often trend towards hyperbole. See Forever. Indeed. From the observatory on World Trade One, you can see plenty far in all directions. Simply awe inspiring. It was clear for us with a glorious sun on a blue bird day. We went with the priority pass saving at least an hour with the line cut it afforded. Yes, it was worth the extra upcharge to me. Lines suck. The experience itself has a few surprises making it more than just a marvelous view. Staff was helpful and friendly to us. We ate a bite at the top. Price was reasonable for two soft pretzels and a banana. At the end of the day, it's mostly about the view but being able to wave my private parts and middle digit from the top of a new World Trade One at the terrorists who thought they could subdue American culture is priceless.
A "must do" in NYC. This was a great experience. I will go back and plan on spending a lot more time. There's much to do and see at the top of NYC!

ONE Restaurant. We visited OWO on June 1, a few days after it opened. Unfortunately, it was a rainy day and all you could see was clouds. We (two of us) decided to try lunch at the ONE restaurant, but waited 50 minutes to be seated, even though there were empty tables the whole time we waited (were told tables were reserved for larger groups). The menu was sparse. We tried the sliders, which were very small and tasteless. No coffee or tea was available...you could have water or a bar drink. The $42 tab was ridiculous for the small servings... no sides. Save your money and don't eat here!

if you have a baby think twice before booking. we really enjoyed...only thing is, it is not in any way baby friendly. once you get off the elevator at th 102nd floor, you need to take your baby out of the carriage and fold your carriage and carry it, huge pain in the neck..., also i went to the bathroom to change the baby and the hand driers were so loud, she got so scared i had to take her out...i also nursed her on the floor outside the bathroom..other than that, the kids really enjoyed from start to finish, so if you have a baby think twice before booking.
A must! . Me and my husband came on our honeymoon and this had only opened a few days before. This was a must on our list! The views were fantastic and the whole experience from start to finish!

Beautiful Site. Very neat and great place to see New York. You can get to see Manhattan, Bronx, etc. plus you can purchase a visual iPad to tell you what you are looking at and zoom in on whatever you want and it will show a close view. I recommend it to everyone.
Absolutely breath taking!!. Go it's beautiful. Just opened And super clean. Buy tickets online so you don't wait in two lines. May change things but once you get inside things move right along.

Beautiful view!. The new, One World tower is very modern. While visiting Empire State Building, visitors are able to go to the top of the tower and get outside on a balcony and take a picture, but at One World Observatory, visitors are staying inside. The view is beautiful, and there is a small shop, where visitors can purchase gifts.

amazing. im scared of heights but wasnt afraid of this. was very good. worlds fasted elevator was the best part as you couldnt see outside but was great animation! one thing you have to do if youre in the city!

Worth a visit!. I have been in New York before, and since I have visited Top of the Rock, I wasn't planning on going up in the new sky scrape, One World Trade Center.. But I did it anyway, and it was nothing like Top of the Rock. This is like the most modern sky scrape in the world, and they have really put an effort to make it an experience. Do it! :)

The elevator ride is worth the trip!. Ditto purchasing tickets online, and arriving early!! We were among the first groups inside after it opened, and there were some "issues" but they were minor and did not really affect the experience. The elevator ride is amazing and makes the trip. The "guides" know their stuff and present their spiel in a professional manner. Weather limited our visibility to near zero, and the inside of rain clouds is not exciting. Check the visibility before you go!The gift shop and cafeteria are nice with the expected mark-up for this type of attraction.Visitor data in the entrance area is interesting.Don't miss this tour if the viz is unrestricted.

Must do. This is a great place to visit if the weather is good you can see for miles You can hire a small iPad when you are going round and as you point it towards North South and so on it will tell you about a all the places you can see so glad we did this sue

Head in the clouds, which was a problem.. It is perhaps unfair to be critical of an attraction if the problem encountered was that the cloud was low enough so that visibility from the observatory deck was zero, however you are encouraged to pre book, which we did but obviously this means that should, as in our case, the weather worsen during the day, you are in a position where you can get to ride the elevator, see the well presented talks on New York but manage to see nothing of the city, which is essentially the point after all. We did think that in event of low cloud there should be an alternate viewing area perhaps at say the 80th floor or if you do pre book you ticket and on arrival visibility is bad perhaps being given a credit to return when the weather is better.The staff were very courtious and helpful, but there is quite a bit of encouragement to purchase additional services in addition to the $32 entry fee.

PRIDE DAY NYC. Comparing with the original WORLD TRADE CENTER, Is nothing besides the toll buildingTo me is not really good view even thought is 360 degrees because the polarized glass disturb significantly all pictures. I been here 3 times already May 22, June 12, June 28 but I keep thinking the TOP of the ROCK view of New York City is much better than this building. Food is nice and reasonable prices, souvenirs to me are very expensive.The entrance fee (basic package) is $32 dollars and is very organized the process to go up and down.

Unforgettable experience. They've done a good job here. Others may prefer the "outdoor experience" of Top of the Rock, or the Empire State, but this one is truly unique. First things first. Definitely book online (some have complained about the price, but for NYC it is not exorbitant for a 'once in a lifetime' experience. Bring a hat and wear sunscreen. Also bring a small water bottle that you can throw away on entry. Take the Number 1 train to Cortlandt Street. Expect to stay in several lines, at least one each for entry times, security and a couple for elevators. You go up in under a minute, viewing a historical story of Manhattan (face the rear as you enter). On 103 you will see another video shown on large wall screens with more detail about thE City. At the end of this video, the screens suddenly roll up, and there it is - the view...but it is not 360 degrees. Neither is the view on 102 which is blocked by eateries and restrooms (water costs $5.50+ per bottle...see why I recommended you take a small throw away). Only when you get to 101 do you get unobstructed 360 degree views. Again, there is no 'outside' involved here...which could be a good thing if you don't feel comfortable about that sort of thing. There is also a movie on the way back down, and plenty of eateries in the immediate vicinity. Enjoy!
Beautiful. Enjoyed our time, purchased tickets on line so there was very little waiting.Hope to go back for dinner sometime!

Nice people keeping us organized.. Of course the view was beyond impressive. I was as impressed with the people working Monday afternoon in the late afternoon. I'm not sure how long their shift is out in the hot sun and at their other stations but everyone of them was kind, smiling and as helpful as they could be. When you need to be organized into groups its so much more pleasant not to feel like a herd of cattle. Thank you to all of you for a great experience. I will recommend it to all who are interested.

Fantastic . I went up this and the Empire State and this was way better. They are all very professional and you get through quickly and into he elevators. The elevators are really quick and once at the top they show you a cool movie after which you get to see out. Get there before 10am with pre-purchased tickets and you will skip all the queues

Worth the money. The interactive elevator ride, and the :guided tours" a the North and South Points are worth the $30 alone. But the view is amazing. I will be back and I will add the iPad device next time.

Get There Early. Well, the elevator ride up to the top is almost worth the price of admission alone. When the notices about vertigo-sufferers went up, they meant it.In a city where there is a lot of competition for views from tall buildings they do make an effort to add a little bit extra here. There is the walk through the basement to check out the foundations before you go up. Then, on arrival, you are shepherded into a darkened movie area where a huge screen shows a video about the city, and then - - - - - - . No, I won't spoil it for you. The view of course, is breathtaking. Obviously, make sure you go on a clear day. There is a lot of information about the building. Nothing about the fate of its predecessor though. That is covered adequately next door and is another story.Do try to get there as early as possible though. I arrived at 0930 and got straight in. When I came down, the queues were round the block.

Wonderful Views but could have been better. Great views and the City Pulse was interesting but not sure what the Sky Portal is about (disappointing). It is also totally enclosed (unlike the ESB and TOTR) so not great for decent photos. The elevators are good, views are great and the Introduction is good with a nice surprise.

Awesome!. I don't like heights but forced myself to go to the One World Observatory (actually my son and my friend forced me). It was amazing with wonderful views over downtown, the rivers, bridges, statue of Liberty and beyond. No sensation of height once up there so well worth a visit.

Best view in New York. Incredible view from the 100th floor - have your video set on your camera/ cell phone when you get in the elevator - there is film on the walls of the elevator going through all the years until 2015 on how New York has changed - really well done. Then there is another short movie until you see the view - try to stand in middle for best viewing of the whole screen if possible. You can go onto their website and request tickets at a certain time - this is so much better than the Empire State Building and the Top of the Rock plus the view is spectacular! Then come to the front entrance about 15 minutes before your tour and wait in line to the left of the building - goes very quickly. There is also a restaurant at the viewing area - not sure on prices.

A Must-Do!. While in NYC for an educational convention, I had a free night and went to One World Trade Center. Not knowing exactly what to expect, I was very impressed with the service of the staff on hand, the elevator ride to the top (I won't give it away), and of course the observation areas. I went on a Tuesday night at 8:30 and got right in.

Amazing!. Amazing view inside and out! The lines moved quickly if you pre-purchased your tickets. The elevator ride up was fast and the review after a short video breathtaking. The restaurant inside offered three different types of dining options - all affordable. The 360 degree view is breathtaking!

Nice View!. They request you to arrive at least 15 minutes prior to your scheduled tour time ( I recommend buying tickets online vs when you get to the ticket office). Once you enter the building, you take an escalator to the basement level and go through security there. We were able to move along pretty quickly, despite the long line. They took us up to the 102nd floor. There was a video that played on the elevator walls on the way up of New York City from time past to present. It took 48 seconds to go from the basement level to the 102nd floor. When you get to the top, the elevators open and you are led out to another room where you stand in line and await being able to continue further. Once leaving this room, you enter a final room before the observation deck where a short video is shown. And then…the screen lifts up and you get an amazing view of the city. The screen then lowers back down and you are led into the observation deck. There are curtains blocking the view on the 102nd floor, but you are able to get a quick glimpse as long as you don’t get caught staying too long. We then took the escalator/steps down to the 101st floor, which allows a view of the Hudson River side of the tower. The restaurant/bar keeps you from being able to get a 360 degree view of the city. Once you drop down to the 100th floor, you are then able to get a full 360 degree view of the city. There is also a gift shop on the 100th floor and restrooms.

now that's a view! but $32.00 really???. This part of our trip, was the thing I was most apprehensive about. It turned it to be the best. I frown on the cheap $2 discount for military veterans...these people are making a ton of money from the place and charge over $30 per person. The military veterans put their lives on the line to defend the very freedom we enjoy. They really need to re-visit the military "discount". Once inside, a water costs $5.49!!! That is a rip!!!!

The "New" Top of the World Experience. We just visited the newly opened One World Observatory in the also new One World Trade Center and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Of course, the views are outstanding but there is much more to the visit. It's best to reserve tickets on line for a prompt entry as visits are mostly on a timed entry basis. The smooth, swift elevators take you to the 102nd floor before you know it with interesting videos on the walls as you ascend. Then it a short film about the rise of New York City over the years with a surprise ending. Next you move down a level to the 101st floor where there is a café and restaurant. We were there at 9:00 am and didn't sample the restaurant and bar as it doesn't open until 11:00am. Finally, you descend to the 100th floor where you have 360 degree views. There are guides to answer questions and also present interesting trivia about the City. We heard stories about the ubiquitous hot dog vendors (ask how much a license costs) and about the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Wait until you hear what goes on there! The only disappointment was the souvenir shop - Everything I checked was NOT USA made. We did not buy any souvenirs but did take lots of pictures. All in all an very enjoyable morning and a "must do" in New York City

Disappointing. We went there after being on the Empire State Building 3 yrs ago. When I compare it, I definitely prefer the Empire State Building experience much more! There you really have the chance to see NY from above. At the One World Observatory you stay inside. Behind a big screen you see all of NY from high above but you are not outside. A completely other feeling. Furthermore the screen irritated my camera as well as my eyes, so I had no fun taking pictures. I would always recommend to go to the Empire State Building instead!

Amazeballs!. I bought tickets for this before I travelled, so I wouldn't be disappointed. This was open when we visited NY previously. Well we weren't disappointed, it's magnificent. Tickets are a tad pricey, but most definitely worth every penny. This is a must visit, the views are phenomenal and there are a few treats in store before you reach the observatory.

They Outdid Themselves! 2 Thumbs Up!. We took my husband here for Father's day since he really wanted to go and it was the perfect gift. We were travelling from NJ on a Sunday so we had to time everything pretty well since the trains only run once an hour. First off, we should have left earlier, we left around 1pm and when we got there we had to buy our tickets which was not a good idea. The lines were so long and you just saw a crowd of people. To buy a ticket there you have to walk around the crowd and enter the building and there you will see where they are selling the tickets. We ended up getting tickets for entry 45 minutes later at 3:30PM because they were running late and the times were fully booked. My advise? Book ahead by purchasing online so you can arrive for your specific time and not have to wait around like we did. What made things worse is that it was blazing hot and there is nowhere to sit and rest your legs in the shade. There is sitting just in front of the entrance so if you can withstand the heat go right ahead. Our time finally came to start lining up and they have specific lines for the different times in 15 minute increments. So even though we lined up we still had to wait another half hour to get in since they were running late. So we are standing in line, in the hot sun. I felt like we were going to die. We didn't have any water and none was being sold in the direct area and the sun was beating down on us. I tried my best to shield my two small kids from the sun. Finally we moved into the building to form another line because now we had to go through a security check, with bag and body scanners like TSA at the airport. We then had to form another line to board the 5 elevators that would take us up to the observatory. By then my legs were numb from standing for so long, and my poor kids, such troopers, didn't complain. The elevator ride up and down was really cool because all three sides was like a screen showing you what the city looked like from decades back till now. So when you go in, make sure to face the back of the elevator. By then it was just after 4pm when we got off the elevator to then form another line to wait our turn for the short movie we would see. It wasn't a long wait, maybe 5 minutes, and then we were ushered into a small wide area that had huge screens against the wall. They played a show of the city and the people in it and at the end the screens scrolled up showing us a quick view of the actual city from where we were. AMAZING! At the end of the video we then made our way to the observatory at long last where we were free to use the bathrooms and take pics etc. The views were absolutely stunning and so worth the wait. A once in a lifetime opportunity cause I doubt I will pay that money and do that wait again. We were hoping to get some water at the restaurant but it was so ridiculously over priced at $5. Good thing we didn't waste our money because as soon as we left the elevators on our exit there was a water fountain. By then we were starving so we walked past the 9/11 memorial and there was a burger king and a pizza place just around the corner from there. Here is some advise: Like I said before, book ahead of time and make sure to go on a weekday during working hours to avoid the crowds.

Must See. After 15 years without a 102 story view of NYC, going to the top of the World Trade Center is a must. The one minute elevator rides up, and later down, are spectacular for the "movie" shown, showing the history of the site and then zipping thru the building on the way down Try to go on a clear day, of course, when the views go on for miles. Even looking down/across to the immediate area is wonderful: Woolworth Building, Statue of Liberty, Governor's Island, and all downtown Manhattan. I did not try them, but there seem to be interactive tablets for rent---point the tablet out the window and it tells you what you're seeing. Great idea if you don't know where you are. Get timed entry tickets online (expensive: $32 full price), and lines and security will delay your entrance. But totally worth the wait and the cost. Definitely a must do.

Incredible View. I've been to a lot of places around the world - but the view from the One World Observatory is just one of the most incredible ones I've ever seen. You really feel as being on top of the world up there.

Beautiful!. The view was excellent. We went on a rain day and were advised that the visibility was less than a mile. (We did ask in advance but saw others were being told as they were buying tickets). We decided to go back when it was sunny and were lucky since the lines were short. Amazing view, amazing video and surprise at the top. The elevator alone was worth the trip. The top was very interactive!

What a view!. Ir it impossible for me not to remember 9/11 tragedy as I entered the new building. But once inside, the beauty of the view overcomes you and there, you find a new beginning!It is beautiful !

From NYC to the World, THE BEST VIEW of NYC and NJ!!!. It's was the best experience in NYC, is a mandatory visit if you want to know and see Manhattan and NYC from the sky. It is incredible and amazing, you MUST visit the One World Observatory of the WTC!!!!

NYC Must See: One World Observatory. This is a must on any visit to NYC, but a few things you need to do before you get there and during you stop:1. Buy VIP tickets online. You want to avoid long lines, pay the extra money it is well worth it. We got there and just walked in quickly thru the front, then security and up the elevator to the top. 2. Avoid the weekends. Let me say that one more time…avoid the weekends. We went there on a Saturday to check it out on the outside and the lines went on forever, and it was kind of rainy. Go inside during a weekday. We went on Tuesday and there was plenty of room at the windows to take lots of photos. 3. Have lunch on you. Yes, take a bottle of water and a sandwich and have a small picnic up there. We found a place to sit and just look outside. That's why I recommend to go during a week day. 4. Restaurant: We didn't go inside, but it looked nice. There is also a place to buy snacks. But I say take your own. 5. Bathrooms: They were super clean. 6. Souvenir shop: They are pricey but you only live once. A water bottle was 20 bucks. Magnet 6 dollars. 7. Start taking pictures and video even when you get inside the elevator on the way up. There is a cool video that gives you the timeline of the building of the structure. Awesome. 8. Everyone there is super friendly and willing to give you information of what you're looking at outside the window. This place is a must see whether you're with family or going alone…worth the money. Happy travels!

Not 'photography friendly'. You can bring a camera, and take pictures. But the fact that you are shooting through 2 panes of glass with some sort of protective/polarized film, riddled with fingerprints and grease spots, combined with the glare, make the conditions way less than optimal for any sort of decent photography.Don't get me wrong - the view is amazing and the elevator ride is pretty cool. But with all of the technical achievements within this building, I was hoping that measures would be taken to make it more 'photography friendly'...If you don't care about taking photos add 2 points. But if you do, you may want to consider Top Of The Rock or The Empire State Building
It starts the minute you step in the elevator!. The best observation decks I've ever seen and the elevator ride was SO fast with a great surprise video!

Very nice - could have been better. The view is magnificent, of course. We expected they would have a great video to watch beforehand, but they don't. They do have a nice casual restaurant and bar. Had some drinks. Did not eat there, but the food looked great

Inspiring . This is a good place to see the city and remember why it was built. The staff was very nice and made you feel comfortable. The lines move fast and with ease. Depending on what time of day you will get some glare from the sun. It is very important to go on line and get tickets early for all locations when in large city's and for sure in the summer.

Only visit if weather is good!. On the day scheduled for the visit (tickets bought on line) the visibility was zero. I was very disappointed they could not refund our tickets money or at least issue vouchers to spend the money at the memorial museum. The only alternative offered was to reschedule another visit but we were leaving the next day back to Europe. So instead of waisting 60$ we took the lift and waited for 3 hours for the clouds to partially lift...This no refund policy is not very customer focused..

Empire State is way better. I've never been to the top of the rock. But I've been to the Empire State B. and I've been to the One World Observatory and I can say, it is not worth the money. The Empire is cheaper and the feeling of being up there is way better. Besides, you are able to see more things, like the park, which you can't see from the OWO. Sure, there's a whole gorgeous show prepared for you to get all excited, and the space of the observatory is more spacious than the one at the empire. But you can't feel the same. The best: the video from the elevator that shows you the evolution of the city since the beginning of the 20th century while you go all the way up to the 102th floor in a blink of an eye.

Breathtaking . Wow! The building is beautiful, the sky line is incredible, a must see for all traveling to NYC. Buy your tickets online!! Expect a line unless you pay for priority tickets. The elevator ride is amazing you fly to the top. Then a short movie next off to the observation deck! My family love the views its a great way to get a real feel for how truly awesome this city is. Enjoy!

Beautiful Tribute. We made reservations to go up into the iconic tower the day the tickets went on sale. The outside of the building is amazing...the architecture is fantastic. I am afraid of heights but had to go up top to see. Expect your ears to pop on the short ride up the 102 stories, they show slides in the elevator..but I'll admit I kept my eyes closed. Once up top the views are amazing as would be expected. the day we went was clear and you could see all around...Though we had made our reservation for 4 pm a couple months in advance, I was disappointed to find out that they were selling tickets to anyone who walked up and wanted to buy one. The problem with this was obvious, once of top, It was so incredibly crowded, you had to wait for people to move away from the window to get a good picture. And several just parked themselves in the window seat, which was spectacular. It is something I would do again. I noticed however from previous reviews that a clear day would be necsessary.

It's a great experience!. The observatory atop One World Trade Center is very well organized. Tickets are available on-line -- $32 for adults and $30 for seniors and free for children 5 years or less -- they're not cheap and they tie you into a specific date and time. Tickets are timed at 15-minute intervals and they run three ques at a time. Once you get through the security check, you get in line for one of four elevators that take you to the 102nd floor in 60 seconds. Three walls of each elevator have LED screens that portray the evolution of lower Manhattan from primeval forest to day skyscrapers on the ascent and on the descent twist you through the structure of One World Trade Center. At the top, in addition to the spectacular views of New York harbor, Jersey City, midtown Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn with attendant bridges and ferries, there are two shows with live announcers and 'magic' special effects that tell you about different areas of NYC, current free attractions and events, and interesting bits of history and culture. There's also the expected gift/souvenir shops and restaurants. You can spend as much time as you want visiting the three floors of the observatory.

Absolutely amazing. I was lucky enough to be there on the day it opened to the general public (May 29). It was a little confusing before entering the building itself but after that it was just amazing. They thought about every single detail and the whole experience is thoroughly enjoyable. The elevator ride is unbelievable. Once up there, they show you a short video which is just an excuse to what happens next, the entire screen lifts up and you can see the views for the first time. It's difficult to describe it but it will give you goosebumps! It's worth every penny!
Don't Miss!. Freedom Tower was absolutely fantastic! The elevator ride, the movie, the view, the bar.... all were amazing. Pay the extra for priority; it was well with it.

Highly recommend!. We went to One World Trade Center on June 29, 2015 and we are glad that we did. This was our fifth and last day in NYC and we got the earliest possible tickets, 9:00 am. That is a great time because you are among the first to go up. The elevator ride up will be the best the elevator ride you have ever taken. The young people working this attraction are well trained and know how to handle the crowd. Someone did their homework on how to train the staff. The views are spectacular. SUGGESTION: buy your tickets on line and skip the big line.

Make sure you know how visible the view is!!. My husband and I went to One World Trade Center. It was a rainy day and we expected the viability to be low. And we were told that the visibility was low. We were not told that we could get a refund if we did not go up. We went up and there was absolutely no visibility and in fact, looked like there were screens on the windows. We were then told that we could send an email and we would receive a promo code to use for another time. I sent them an email and received an automated respond that I would be contacted within 48 hours. That was a week ago. I don't think that we will receive a promo code! So just make sure you know about the visibility before you go up! Also, they rent IPads for $15 that will show you an up close view of what you are seeing. You just point the iPad in the direction where you are looking! This is a waste of time and money!

Not to miss. Just open to visitors on May 29, 2015. Very nice experience, timed tickets you can buy on line (no queue) fantastic elevators to take you from the ground floor to the top (floor 102) in 40 seconds without feeling any slightest movement!! panoramic view for Manhattan from the top as it is the highest building in the western world!!! . Do not forget your camera with zoom lens.

Don't bother if the weather is bad.. When we went up to the Observatory, it was raining and we were advised to reschedule our visit when the weather was better. However, we going back to Florida the next day, and did not have that choice. However, we decided to experience the ride up to the 102nd Floor, anyway. I'm giving this a 5-Star rating only for the venue and the facility would make this a spectacular and everlasting, memorable experience. We saw a simulation of the view which was, and, having been up the top of the Empire State Building a couple of days before, it was a similar experience, but not as high. One of these days when we return to NYC, we will try it again. Caution: there are restaurants up the top, but are expensive. Eat something before you go up.

On A Clear Day, Its Slogan MIght Be True. However, it was hazy when I visited, having bought a ticket weeks in advance from our of town, and although the Empire State Building was visible, there was no Central Park to be seen another 25 blocks north. And this is an expensive place (a draft beer, by the way, was $12.69 with tax and 18% tip). .

Spectacular views - time your visit!. The views from the observatory are excellent but there was a lot of glare at the time of day when I was there. And a lot of greasy head/fingerprints on the glass. If you can go for sunset cocktails, it would be incredible. Also, make sure to have your camera or phone in video mode and be ready to record in the elevators.Note to the One World Observatory people hopefully reading this - please stop overloading the elevators. I would rather wait another half hour than be stuck in a packed elevator. We shouldn't be crammed in there like the subway at rush hour. As one who has been stuck in more than 1 modern high rise elevator for more than 45 minutes, I would probably never go back until rules are in place.
A must see. I would suggest that you purchase tickets in advance. The employees are friendly and keep things moving. Amazing views don't even come close to what you see. A must do

SKY HIGH. The elevator alone makes the destination worth the time. During the ascent, travelers are treated to a display based on Manahatta, a book/website by Eric Sanderson showing a time-lapse transformation from the wilderness Henry Hudson saw in 1609 to NYC's modern urban skyline. Up on top, One World has 3 floors of 360 views from floor to ceiling windows. The observation deck puts visitors eye to eye with helicopters and "see-forever" views like one of NYC's $99M penthouses. Mostly you look out on water, (the Hudson, the East River, the Statue of Liberty in the harbor and the ocean) but also landmarks - from City Hall, at the foot of building, to the George Washington Bridge. Unlike most of Manhattan, the observation deck offers plenty of open space to wander and the three levels allow visitors to press their noses to the glass without rubbing elbows. No one seemed to miss the binoculars mounted on the Empire State observation deck, but I wished for a pair to bird watch or for close-ups of roof top gardens. The food and bar makes for a great excuse to linger. This being NYC, expect lines, (the wait for the elevator down when leaving was as long as the wait to get in). Planning ahead and purchasing tickets on-line cuts the time in half. Enjoy the Vertigo!
Unforgettable. I live here and I have put it off forever- so glad I finally did it! This is not just for tourists. It makes you proud of the city we live in. Kids were actually impressed.

AMAZING VIEWS. Because of anticipated lines, we bought Priority Passes which eliminated the necessity for standing in line and going through metal detectors like airport screening lines. Priority Pass has it's own metal detector point. Very fast. Would do it again. Truly an incredible structure, the videos, etc are very moving. We visited the Twin Tower memorial pools. AWESOME .
Overwhelming!. Better buying the ticket on line in order to avoid long lines. Prepare camera for breathtaking pics.
Every Americans duty. Truly a sight to see and behold. Thank you to everyone and anyone who had a part in this memorial and my thoughts and prayers to those who lost loved ones.

Double Check Weather B4 BUYING TIX!. No Refunds. Visibility happened to be zero the day we went to 1WTC. We even checked the weather forecast before buying our tickets. Though it was offered to come back another specific day and time, no refunds. We were leaving town and had no future plans to return to NYC. Total waste of money. Bad policy.

Visibility Zero. Couldn't see a darn thing, even though we waited two hours for the weather to clear. So we went to the restaurant, very plebian decor and the worst Bloody Mary ever. So, I can say I did it but it cost me about $100 for the three in our group and was disappointing.
Fantastic visit and so well presented.. Do not miss this new New York attraction. Well worth the money. Staff helpful and friendly. Views unbelievable. The whole experience amazing.
One world observatory. Best experience I have participated I from start to end. The rides up and down in the skypod elevator and show on arrival. Very professional. Loved every moment of it.

They made it. If you have just enough money for one observatory in New York city, you should spend in the one world trade center. The building is spetacular, the elevator is fantastic and the view is literally the climax.

Great views and inspiring stories. We booked our tickets online. Once we got there, there was no waiting. On your way in, be sure to stop and listen to the stories of the people who worked on the tower--they were really heartfelt and inspiring. The elevator ride was fantastic!! Once upstairs, the views are great!!

Awesome Views!. What would you expect besides awesome views from this beautiful building. You really get to see the layout of Manhattan. PLUS, the elevator ride is incredible - you have to see what they have done to make the experience even better.

BEST nyc attraction. I live in NYC and have had many visitors come to town. I have done my fair share of touristy things in Manhattan and surrounding areas. I was absolutely blown away by one world observatory. It has fantastic views and the whole experience is made fun. Even the elevator ride was interesting!I had some lunch at the top too and the food was great!

Incredible view of New York!. This starts out as a line to purchase tickets, which I learned While I was waiting that I could purchase tickets online beforehand. It saved us 20min to go online and purchase tickets using my phone. Tickets are $32. Once you have tickets, you go through security and wait in line to take an elevator up 1248 feet. You see a brief movie and then see a spectacular view of Manhattan. There is a restaurant which also favors a great view. Then you travel a path down steps to enjoy a 360 degree view of the city. A professional pic costs $20. Then there is a line to take an elevator back down to the ground floor. The elevator was the smoothest I've ever been on, only feeling pressure by the ears.
Amazing View!. And experience from beginning to end. An amazing view and incredible technology made this a fantastic and inspiring experience. Must do when in NYC!

Great view!. This is an experience from the moment you get in the elevator to go up, to the moment you get out again at ground level. Needless to say, fantastic views from the top. There are a couple of presenters on the viewing level, who use some nifty video technology to give an entertaining ten-minute presentation about NYC. If you're in town for a few days, our top tip is to buy the open ticket that gives you a choice of which day to go up. This lets you pick a fine day, because if the top is covered in cloud (as it sometimes is) you'll see nothing. Get the expedited-entry ticket, this whisks you straight to the front of the (long) lines. A few more dollars, but well worth it.

Fantastic View. That is what you are going for !. We visited early to avoid any long lines. We booked our tickets the night before for the 9:15am arrival and turned up and only had to wait about 2 minutes before we could be let in.We paid for just regular tickets and then passes through security. After security you walk through a little history about how the new tower was constructed and the workers who made it.Then we quickly bored any elevator and were told to face the outside, the Elevator ride then begins and you see the history of new york city and it being built up, it was fairly fun for the 60 second ride to the top.Once at the top you head into a room with a bunch of people and wait in the dark for a minute and then watch a 2 minute video about new york city...at the end of the video the screens lift up and you are presented with a fantastic view of New York City. You are then free to wonder around and take in the views in your own time. We spent about 30 minutes looking at the views.We did not eat at the restaurant or buy any merchandise.Overall of a Major tourist attraction it was very well done, I find nothing worse than waiting in long lines when visiting tourist places and feeling like a sheep. This was not the case here, it was done well, and quickly and the staff had been trained well.A great new attraction in New York City for fantastic views

Commercialistic and overrated. I was very disappointed with our trip to OWO. It's beautiful, and the scenery is amazing, but it's truly overrated and I hated that they were constantly trying to sell stuff. If you want to have a beautiful skyline view, try Top of the Rock. Being outside is so much better than being behind the dirty windows at OWO.

Amazing views for miles. It took 60 seconds to climb the 102 floors in the elevator. The visual experience successfully distracted even the wary from this elevator ride. At the top the views from the 360 degrees observation platform were amazing on a clear day. Staff very friendly and helpful.

Best views of the city. Getting in and up was easy - waiting time was around 10 minutes. We went in at 7:15pm which was before sunset. The views are INCREDIBLE.However - I dont know if it was just the day or time of day but there were way too many people up top. That was quite a mess and staff really should manage that a whole lot better. Loads of people just sitting on the window sills.
