Also taking pics is challenging though not impossible - the windows reflect quite a lot back at your camera. My companion preferred it to Empire State and Top of the Rock.

Fabulous!. We went to he Observatory this past weekend. We really enjoyed it. We had tickets for 10am on a Saturday, and we got right in. I noticed when we left about 11:30am that the crowds were starting the grow. The views are amazing, and the history lessons about New York are really good. Elevator ride is incredible.

Incredible View. Opened only one month, this place will be THE place to visit for NYC (and world) views.Claims to be the tallest building in the western hemisphere are easily believed when you get to the top.Unlike a previous reviewer, we simply walked in with a wait of probably 5 to 10 minutes Sunday morning. View was incredible and free guides at top were friendly and informative. As more people hear about this, I'd seriously recommend buying tickets online for a scheduled time: when we left the building a VERY long line had formed outside for walk-up hopefuls. An MSN article claims the Empire State building collected $111 million dollars in observatory fees last year. This is a competitive business and I'd bet the One World Observatory will at least be up in that arena. If you're sensitive to altitude changes, take your decongestants or antihistamines before you take the 60 second or so elevator up or down. It's pretty amazing how you barely feel the acceleration/deceleration at those speeds.Definitely recommend this trip, no need to rent the portable tablets at top, and brush off the usual photography operation at the top, which slows down your path to the actual viewing area.

Had to go!. My wife and I had to visit the freedom Tower, and the museum. The tower, even from the outside is something inspiring, but the ride in the elevator with its electronic screens and incredible super fast ride made the journey to the top all part of the build up. Views, you can imagine are spectacular and if you go late evening, to can witness the sun going down, and the city lighting up, but be prepared for the crowded windows. Well worth the effort though, a must see.

On top of the world. We had a great time visiting this amazing building. We paid online for the tickets quite some time in advance.The normal admission is $30 bucks,but we paid $65 for the express any-time tickets (I can now hear new Yorkers shouting ,you paid whaa?).The top tickets turned out to be a good option. We had to choose a day of our choice to visit online ,but didn't have to choose a time(9:00am to 11:15pm) unlike the standard tickets. The extra $ means you can also jump the line .So upon arrival at 10am we found a guide tell a visitor that they were still only letting in 9:15 bookings, the line for visitors with tickets was already a good 100 deep which meant an approx.1hour wait. I showed her our printed out tickets and we just jumped the line and went straight through the revolving doors to the right hand security check point with no queue.The security here is the same level as an airport so belts off and everything out of your pockets and stand in the scanner .We then walk along a route along the ground level and watch a film presentation of construction guys and officials revealing some of the history of the building .Its now time to take the express lift to the 100th floor .As you ascend, the lift is wrapped in video and shows the history of NYC over the centuries as you ascend .In super fast time your up to the 100th floor. There is now another short 5 minute presentation on a screen.From here you are then free to wander around the 101st and 102nd floors with 360 views, with the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges being in close view. There is a small café, bar and usual gift shop as well as toilets and drinking water fonts. There are helpful staff around who were happy to help with any questions as well as presentation points with staff giving talks integrated with a unique circular tv display setup.The only downside is the glass glare makes it difficult to get quality photos, the Rockefeller is my top choice for pictures as its open air and has my favourite views from a skyscraper, however I feel this One world building is very well organised as well as the only south manhatttan skyscraper observatory and I found it to be a must see experience.

Beautiful and iconic building. We booked a visit to the top of freedom tower for 10pm the views from it are obviously stunning, and the views from across downtown just keep coming. the whole area is stunning and very moving to pay tribute, having seen the site develop over the years

80k 360degree view of New York. Pre book your tickets to avoid the queues, you get given a time slot and we had to queue for around 10mins to get inside. More queuing and airport style security once inside. The elevators are very impressive - they are lined with computer screens that display New York city developing from a green grass island to the metropolis we see today all taking place before your eyes as you shoot up the 150+ floors in a matter of seconds. Once on the observatory level all the glass is frosted so you must get close to see the view. We could see out to the statue of liberty and up past empire state building and everything in-between. Its an amazing building and stunning view. A word of advice do the 9/11 museum first and this view will help pick you up after.
Best elevator ride ever. The elevator ride to the top is amazing. You will want to have your camera ready to film the 60 second ride. The downside is that some of the souvenirs are expensive.

Great view and well done! but........ We were impressed with the attention to detail that went into completing this project. The architects, designers and craftsmen should all be proud of the work that was done! My only negative from the experience was from the actual visitors. There were far too many people who were "camping out" and sitting on the windowsill and making it hard for others to see. I had my children with me and they had a tough time getting a look out the window.

Imagine the view from the Twin Towers. I very much enjoyed this experience. The Observatory just opened and you ride an elevator up 102 floors above New York. The World Trade Center Towers were only a bit higher 110 floors. From this vantage point you get a stunning view of NYC. There is a video, employees who share the city with video technology and I saw some that had rented technology that would let you identify different buildings in their view by just pointing. If you are from out of town sounds like a wonderful addition to this experience. There of course is the glass observatory where you could take that Facebook/snap chat picture. I was really impressed with the friendliness of the staff everyone was helpful cheery and seemed very happy to be there. I was not at all disappointed with this experience. TIP there is fast pass entrance if your purchase you admission with a MasterCard. You get to go to the head of the line...sort of like Pre at the airport. So use the MasterCard, but pre buy your tickets so that you don't have to wait in the ticket line and waist valuable time.

Too much like a theme park. The views are unbeatable but it is much too much like a theme park. I grew up enjoying the World Trade Center, so this was just too gimmicky for me. The cafe and restaurant are ok. I won't go back unless I have to take an out of town visitor.

It will give you chills!. Very well done and emotional when you realize that we, as Americans, always rebuild and life goes on. The way it was done and they view from the top is awesome. I won't comment too much on the specifics because it would take away some of the surprises that you will experience. I will say that the people who work there were very helpful, accomodating and cheerful. They really treated the visitors in a welcoming, considerate and patient manner. Kudos to them! The experience doesn't take that long once you enter, but it is not to be missed.

Disorganized, Trying Too Hard. The One World Observatory is in the recently finished One World Trade Center. Almost essential that you pre-order tickets or you will wait on line for a long time to buy your ticket there. Very disorganized line system, every "guide" has a different story. One told us to go inside and when we got in they told us to go out, get in that line "over there" (of which there were several). Once you get in you get in another line for the elevators.The ride up is interesting in that they project views of NYC over the eons, to the present day. Once at the top, its another cattle call as they give you a hoakie presentation that I suppose they think is artistic. All I wanted to do was look outside, but you are locked into this presentation. Once finally out of there, you get forced into a picture taking line (for a price of course) . Finally, you get to look at the views out the window. Great views of NYC, NJ, Long Island. I have not been to the Empire State building for years, but that view platform was outside and the views were just as good (as I remember) and maybe the lines are shorter there. I'd try that first.

Impressing area of NY with the Freedom tower close to visit ( a must ). We asked the taxi driver to drop us close to the One World Trade Center, but so that we could just have a nice 10 minutes walk to it. Was a good idea, it is an outstanding area to see modern buildings, skyscrapers. The One World Trade center is a quite impressing with the several towers. Some of them are still in construction as well as the modern monument of the Spanish architect. The Freedom tower or One World Trade tower is impressing with it's 540m hight. It is certainly worthwhile to visit, although the entry fee is quite high for European standards. It is a must. Ground zero is ... well, no description possible. Just visit it !From the One World Trade we were close to the Battery park, a boat trip and a walk through the Financial district, Wall street and Broadway bridge.

Good weather is a must and this said : The views and the experience are overwhelming. I thought to write a review for the complete experience of seeing ground zero, One World center and the Freedom Tower, but I have to start with the observatory due to multiple entries in TripAdvisor. We bought the entries online from Europe and I was very happy I did so when I saw the large queues to buy a ticket. We were 1 of the first 3500 non Americans to visit the Freedom tower on 3/6.The experience starts down when you arrive walking to the One World Center. Most beautiful architecture I saw in complete NY. Really outstanding. Then the organization to enter was flawless. The walk to the elevators is a good start to be impressed and when the elevator takes you up the floor 101-102 in 45s with some animation of NY skyline history you remark that all has been worked out in detail. There are no dramatic scenes or remembering, that is OK, we don't have to be remembered, WE KNOW and don't forget. The view from about 520m hight is fantastic. We have been 1 hour just enjoying that 360 view. I would say : A must in NY, a visit to ground zero, One World Center and the Freedom Tower ( One World Trade Center Observatory ).

Tallest in Western Hemisphere!. Because of our visit to Financial District of New York City, it wasn't possible not to see the tallest building in Western Hemisphere and fourth-tallest building in the world!The shape was amazing and even surreal due to its blue color and diamond shape that reflected sky and sun.Even now, we continue looking at this building everyday on the souvenir plate hanging on our wall. And this plate with a view of New York is among the best!

Stronger than Ever!!!. It's not how many time you fall is how many you can Stand Up....and with this building we show the world how strong we can rise after something so bad and tragic like 9/11....It's a beautiful building, but it has lots of beautiful and talented people behind it. This building to me represent the Great Nation we live on...I was born in Cuba...but I'm very proud to be part of this Country and be an American Citizen. Don't miss out.... See Forever......

Too many reflections in the glass of the observation deck.. We visited on Monday 22nd June after our previous visit on 18th June had to be abandoned due to zero visibility. On a positive, it has to be said that the staff were all excellent and helpful, and changing our tickets was a pain-free experience. Your visit begins with the obligatory airport-style security checks, and then up in the elevator to the 102nd floor, where you enjoy a very impactful short video presentation. Once in the observatory itself though is where the real issue arose, which is the reflection in the glass that surrounds your view. The views are excellent, however taking reflection-free photos is near impossible, and this made it a real let-down for me.For me, the Top of the Rock was the better observation deck, because you can be exposed to the open air and have narrow slits between the glass panes with just about accommodate a camera lens for glare-free photography.If you're not too bothered about the photography aspects, then you do get great views of the Statue or Liberty, the Brooklyn Bridge, and the other iconic sights of lower Manhattan
Brilliant. Top any to-do list. Fantastic. Like all the reviews go early 10am is great. The staff are so friendly. Sit down on the edge to take a great selfie
Looks great..!!. We didn't go up to the observation deck we just stayed at the bottom but it's just beautiful standing there and looking up at it..!! Looks really well from a distance as well.!

Fantastic views but disappointed. It's hard to say I could leave disappointed after having seen some of the best views of the city and New Jersey, but I did. It felt more touristy and gimmicky than I anticipated from the beginning walk through fake bedrock to the many digital displays that don't quite show you a full picture of anything. Thick glass smudged with fingerprints made me feel even more disconnected. I had hoped for an exhilarating experience and ended up bored.

Amazing views!. We visited the one world observatory the first day it opened to the public.Thoroughly enjoyed our experience. We first visited the 9/11 memorial and it was quite a moving experience coming from there and then going to the top.We had pre-purchased tickets though there was still a bit of waiting around.The views are definitely worth it though! This and Rockefeller are my top picks for views of NYC.

Good - but prefer 'Top of TheRock'. This is a nice addition to the possibilities to get up high and take a look at NYC. It's a fun ride in the elevator and the video presentation of the observatory. But for the view I will always prefer 'Top of The Rock' above the Observatory and above Empire State Building.

Go for it!. Well worth the money. Go early to avoid the lines. Our 10:15 Saturday morning ticket had minimal lines but when we left at 11:30 the line outside was a mess. Don't waste your money on the iPad's. You'll spend too much time figuring out how to use it. Cafe and restaurant was a nice touch! Go for it!

The View was the Star of the Show!. First and foremost, I will say that I was there on June 26, 2015, when the initial viewing time was still cloudy. The view wasn't so bad, so even if the forecast calls for an overcast sky, be a daredevil and get to the top of the world.When I took the cab from Residence Inn WTC hotel to the West Entrance to the World Trade Center, I was a bit worried dye to the cloudy skies above us. Plus, we had our 93-year old grandmother with us who is afraid of heights but we couldn't leave her in the hotel. As we entered the lobby of the WTC from the Observatory Plaza across World Financial Center, and descended via the elevators, we got special access to the priority VIP venues because of our grandma. We passed through specialized security checks as well. The ascent to the 102nd floor in the Skypod elevator was incredible as we saw the New York skyline change from the 1500s to the present in addition to a quick glimpse of the Twin Towers, and the building of One WTC around you. When you got to the 102nd floor, you would enter the theater venues that (like the elevator) was dizzying, it was all worth it and the experience was magnificent.But let's face it, you are here for the spectacular view of New York, New Jersey and all the way to Pennsylvania. So everyone clapped and cheered for the rising of the theater screen for the reveal of the breathtaking views. Then, since we had a senior with us, we had access to the elevator across the Skypods. We then went to the 100th floor main viewing galleries, where you could take in the spectacular views in 360 degrees. Some people would complain due to lack of seating, but you can sit on the vents lining the windows on the 100th floor or on the 101st floor dining piazzas. I will say that the addition of the Sky Portal was cheesy and clearly fake. It was said to scare even adults, but even 4-year old children were on it and didn't get an ounce scared. We paid for the One World Explorer, that might be more costly, but gives you a quick yet thorough overview of the Big Apple, while looking down at the curvature of the Earth. That's when the sky started to clear up.City Pulse was also a great experience and we would constantly wait for a new concierge man to start another session of it. We then headed to the 101st floor dining level, and the formal restaurant was a dinner place, so we ate at the semiformal One Mix, with four-star food. The view from there was also splendid. The sky was brilliant. If you want to keep memories of NYC and the WTC on top of the world, pay extra for the tickets for pictures behind the green screen on the 101st floor. You can pay for as many as you want and take as many as you want. They will give you two versions of the same picture-the Lower Manhattan skyline at noon, and the Lower Manhattan skyline at dusk.If you love souvenirs, you are going to love the gift shop on the 100th floor. It has everything, from paintings to water bottles, from wine glasses to sunglasses, from shirts and caps to cards and envelopes, all inscribed with the signature logo of One World Observatory.We headed down at around 1:30 pm, and while the red-lit elevator lobby was elaborate, the descent via the Skypod was even more dazzling, as it circled around the WTC 1 tower and re entered it via windows, also giving a glimpse of the completed/future WTC site. Overall, the experience at One World Observatory was amazing, exceptional and unlike any other, and we are definitely coming back. It was so sad to leave NYC. :'(P.S.: This is just my own personal experience and don't complain if you end up having a substantially worse one.

One World was disappointing. We went to the One World Observatory. I was expecting to see and hear more. All we did was to ride to the top and look out over the city. The view was beautiful but there was nothing else offered for $30.

WOW. Spectacular views of New York City, the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and surroundings make this a "must see." We purchased our tickets online and access into the building was easy, staff was very polite and walking around the Observatory was comfortable and uncrowded. You ride to the 102nd floor while watching images of the growth of New York City. In less than a minute, you truly can "see forever." HINT: See the 9/11 Memorial and Museum first and then view the Observatory. Your spirits, like your vision, will soar.

One World earns the top spot. One advantage in having a son and his family in New York City is how often we get to visit.Combine that with move junkets over the years and just being old, you do get opinions.This one is about which top of New York building is number one.The Empire State building is historic and offers a nice view downtown and uptown. Top of The Rock is a modern space with even better views to the north.But if you could only do one, I would recommend the observatory at Freedom Tower.We went a few days after it opened this summer. The cost is a whopping $32, with a couple buck break in you old.They sell advance ticket time slots and I can’t recommend strongly enough that you go that route instead of standing in line to buy tickets.We weren’t sure exactly what time we would arrive so we didn’t buy our time slot until we got there. They offer one every 15 minutes. While we walked right in, people were lined up for long periods in the sun waiting to just buy the tickets we bought with a few keystrokes at the same price.You see some visuals about the building of the freedom tower and you can touch original footings from the World Trade Center. Then it is on the elevator for an incredibly fast and visually interesting trip up.I won’t give you details to spoil the effect but when you come off the elevator there is another short visual before you are cut loose on the tower. It is a dramatic moment.As for the view, it is impressive. The Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Governors Island, lower Brooklyn, Verrazano Bridge, all look close with the ocean in the distance.Move and you have New Jersey and lower Manhattan at your feet. Then midtown, then Wall Street and the Brooklyn Bridge. And our day was partly cloudy. Imagine a totally clear day. (Another reason not to buy tickets to far in advance, a bad overcast day would make it a waste. I just hope they don’t start selling out time slots in advance)It is a comfortable walk around the observation deck even with the crowds. We found a bar and seats and enjoyed a drink and a cheese plate at New York prices (but not crazy prices) while we took in the scene.One nutty thing is that to enjoy the fancy restaurant or bar and cafe up top, you have to pay the $33 to get there. That is goofy and will have to change.After our food and drink, we took another swing around the top to let the views sink in.I think it earned the price. They are pushing it, but the Freedom Tower Observatory is special.A couple of side notes:I worried that it would be a bit of a downer, taking the place of the World Trade Center.I visited the observation deck on top the World Trade Center several times. It’s open air experience was very different. And I was sickened like everyone else on 9/11.It turned out the Freedom Tower has more of a sense of awe and looking forward than one of sadness and looking back. Not that we forget.Finally, while I rate Freedom Tower tops, the bar at the Top of the Rock is special, with great views. It is worth the $25 drink to take it all in.
"Freedom Tower". The new plaza replacing the World Trade Center is fantastic. Here's a photo of the new "Freedom Tower." Well worth a visit.

Felt Like I just got off a cruise ship in Jamaica!!!. Granted, it was cloudy, and the guy at the bottom said we would see much if anything if we went to the top. BUT, we had one day in NYC, the tickets were bought ahead of time and were non-refundable and we didn't have an option to return at a later date........so, we didn't anticipate much. That's good.The elevator ride up was amazing!! I think we were in there 30 seconds and flew up to the top. I knew to look at the sides of the elevator to watch the development of NYC, but I just wanted to savor the experience, not just whisk through it. Once we got to the top, it was like entering a Jamaican flea market. Employees in blue t-shirts were selling their souls, their wares to the point of being annoying. IF we just paid a LOT of money to see nothing, why weren't the ipad viewing things for rent FREE??? The brash commercialism of this place was annoying and of course the view a total blanket of grey. The best part of this trip was going up and going down. Invite me back when you remove all the HAWKERS!!!

Enjoyed every minute. We left visiting the Freedom tower towards the end of our trip because of the bad weather we experienced whilst visiting NYC. Tried booking a ticket in the morning but the line was so big we thought we might aswell visit the muesem instead. We returned in the evening and got a slot for 8:45pm when we finally got to the top of the tower it was night which was lovely. Managed to spot the famous citys landmarks. One annoying thing was it was too light and when you tried to take a picture of the view there was a reflection. Amazing design and alot of thought has been put in to making this. The lift was a good buzz, felt my ears pop. wish to return in the near future.

magnificent views. Great experience - a must do in NYC!On the way to the observary, also the elevator journey and "high level reception" were very nice.Subject to weather conditions - pick your preferred time slot and make reservations online (even with smartphone) to avoid waiting lines

A Must See. Growing up in Brooklyn I visited the World Trade Center many times, and I couldn't wait to get to the top of the new One World Observatory. Wow! They did a great job. You line up outside (bring an umbrella if it's raining) in a time specific line. Once inside you go down to line up for the elevators. Don't miss the video screens with the stories of those who built this fabulous building. The whole experience is a little Disney like, in that they keep you entertained while waiting and even on the elevators. You even need to walk through the gift shop to leave. It is expensive, even by NYC standards, but you need to see this place at least once in your life.

Amazing!. What a view from the top!!! So much good about this… not a long line to wait (timed tickets-but arrive early), easy elevator ride, intro movie is cool, and the walk around observatory is awesome.The gift shop in the middle of it all is nice as is the restaurant.Nothing to say no to here. Go experience it!

wonderful addition to NYC skyline. Great to see the new building back in the place. The observatory was opened a couple of weeks ago and we pre-booked the ticket before reaching there. The new building is more stylish than the previous one, but the observatory is an enclosed one, unlike open terrace. Must see if you enjoy aerial views of the beautiful planet, the waterways/hudson , statue of liberty and the bridges connecting the Manhattan. The queue /waiting time isn't long.

High prices with an average experience. My family and I had the opportunity to have visited the Empire State Building prior to our One World Observatory experience. That set the bar very high, especially since you are able to have the outdoor experience at the Empire State.The elevator ride up/down was interesting but not amazing. Very crowded and I felt that we were just a herd of cattle being directed to either pose for the picture that they try to get you to buy or to pay extra for the 'special' observatory tour. There wasn't much learning experience along the way. Nothing interesting to read about or see on display. Just the 360 degree view which after awhile, was boring. All indoor.Do yourself a favor, spend your money at the Empire State Building.
Great view.. Loved going to the One World Trade Center Observatory. Expensive, but worth the view. Beautiful building.

Cloudy skies. The wait was long and then when we got to the top all you could see was white fog and clouds. Make sure that the weather is going to be good before you buy your expensive ticket. On a clear day you can see for 50 miles.........on a foggy day you see zilch!

The tallest building in New York. This building had been open less than 2 weeks when I went, I hadn't prebooked but hardly had to queue anytime at all, though I think later in the day it would probably have taken longer & obviously as more people get to hear about it, it will get busier.The views are amazing & the lift ride up & down (because trust me they are different) are great fun. There is a restaurant, nice gift shop & clean toilets. Suitable for everyone & quite reasonable I would reccomend this attraction.

A must see. With so much to do in NYC, it's hard to decide what to see during a visit. Don't miss getting to go up into the new One World Tower. First of all, it's just amazing getting to be on the 102 floor of a building, and the elevator ride up is actually pretty cool. They do a great job with an introduction to New York and it's sky line. Then, the view is unforgettable. I had a wave of American pride being up there.Tip: go early in the morning, because the line gets very long.

Wow.... What an experience. From the elevator ride to the top (I won't give it away) to the amazing views. They did an excellent job. We went to the bar to have some drinks and food. They have very good beer selection (Tap & Bottles). The bar food was also very good. You can't beat that view.

Allow at least 1.5hrs to do this. We arrived with plenty of time to walk around the reflecting pools and find where we were supposed to enter the one world building. Be aware that there are no signs as to what queue is for what (unlike the 9/11 museum who seemed a lot more organised.) We queued as early as they would allow us, at 11:45 for a 12pm ticket. From the queue we were ushered in at 12:10pm. From entering we reached the elevators at 12:25pm after security, which was fast, and having to walk around a "cave"..... The lift only took a minute or so but once at the top it took us another 15 minutes before we actually got into the observatory area, including having to watch a video and more queuing. So, for a 12pm ticket we did not reach where we paid to go until 12:40pm, almost 1 hour after we were advised to queue. What annoyed me was that people who had arrived late for their ticketed times, 11:30 and 11:45, were able to join another queue and enter before us, even though their entry times had passed. This queue was then allowed in before ours was, even though everyone in our line had made the effort to arrive before time and not to be late.The only thing worth the money paid is the views. The lift ride video up is pretty cool but what should be expected for a $32 ticket. Make sure you go on a clear day to get a good view. Be prepared to have to walk through One World employees trying to sell you the $15 Ipad experience, which is totally unnecessary. We had purchased 1.30pm tickets to the Memorial Museum next door thinking that 1.5hrs would allow us plenty of time for the Observatory and a quick lunch in between as well. However with all the queuing we only had about 20mins to look at the view (in crowds of people all trying to get window space as well). We felt rushed as we were running out of time and had to join yet another queue to get back down the elevator again. So overall felt a bit ripped. And we had no spare time once we got back outside. If you are doing both the museum and observatory on one day and are going to buy timed tickets then make sure you give yourself PLENTY of time. Overall an average experience.
Mind blowing. Booked a flexi ticket on line from the UK and on the first available clear day ascended to the top. What a view and what an experience - sublime.

On top of the World (Trade Center). We purchased priority tickets (slightly expensive at $54 each) and sailed past the long queues, straight to security. There was minimal queuing for the elevators, which are extremely fast and have been fitted with HD screens showing the incredible rise of Manhattan over the centuries, from empty land to the skyscrapers we see today.Once at the 102 floor you are then ushered into a long thin room to watch the 'See Forever' montage of New York City life. This is cool, but hard to see properly as it is very long and the room is thin so you cannot take it all in. Regardless, the icing on the cake, and something that I will not reveal so as not to ruin the surprise, comes at the end of the montage, and truly took my breath away. There were gasps from the crowd followed by a huge round of applause. And that's all I have to say about that.After the montage you are then free to enter the main observatory. And, once again, it is breathtaking. We were lucky with the weather and had a cloudless blue sky. Of course, everyone wants to look out of thew windows so at times it was hard to find a spot, but you cannot complain. There are two levels, with the upper floor housing the ridiculously expensive cafe ($5 for a small bottle of water), and the lower floor housing the main observation area. There is a fake glass floor showing an 'aerial view' of the street below but this was empty and no-one seemed interested. It was a little tacky to be honest, especially compared to the real thing in Toronto's CN Tower. Having said that, the views from the windows are incredible and well worth the ticket price.In total, from entering, security, and time at the top, we spent an hour there, but as I mentioned, we had priority tickets. I'd say definitely pre-books your tickets and if you can afford it, get priority ones.

100% inadequate management ruins our dream. Day 7 - Final Day in New York and what a great way to finish - a trip up One World Observatory....or so we thought. Let me set the scene.Both Liz and I had been to the top of the Twin Towers back in the 1980s and when we heard that One World Observatory was due to be opening in 2015, we really hoped that its opening would coincide with our holiday during the last week in May to New York. So with that in mind I registered with the One World Observatory website and waited to hear when it was opening.So when it was announced that the inaugural opening was on Friday 29 May 2015, which happened to be on our last day in New York, we were over the moon.I received the e-mail to say when tickets were going on sale and allowing for the time difference it meant that I would need to leave a Board meeting early to ensure that I was online at 3pm UK time. I duly made my excuses and left the meeting and logged in on time, actually about 5 seconds after 3pm UK time (10am NY time when the tickets first went on sale) and was hugely disappointed when I got through as there were no time slots left for Friday 29 May and as we were flying back to the UK that day I thought that was our chance gone. Big shame as it would have been great to have gone up on opening day.Later that day, Wednesday 8 April as I left work and was sitting on the train home, my iPhone alert announced an e-mail had come through and I saw that it was from One World Observatory offering tickets. A bit masochistically I opened the e-mail expecting to see time slots available for 30 May which would have been after we had arrived back in London; to my amazement there were Priority Access tickets available for a 2.45pm time slot on Friday 29 May. I literally had less than a minute to book the tickets on my iPhone before I knew I would be losing any reception on my iPhone. I managed to get two tickets for the 2.45pm time slot literally a couple of seconds before my phone lost the signal. I was ecstatic with excitement and couldn't wait to get home to tell Liz.We arrived in New York on Friday 22 May and had a fantastic week and on Friday 29 May we finished our lunch in Les Halles Downtown on John Street and paid the bill at 1.03pm and made our way towards Vesy St and One World Observatory. we arrived at 1.15pm and joined the back of the queue which was alongside One World Trade Center on Vesy St. We knew we were one and half hours early for our 2.45pm Priority Access time slot (N.B. The ticket reads "...On a tight schedule? Priority Admission allows guests who have pre-selected a specific date and time to enjoy VIP expedited entry, bypassing the general admission line...") but joined the back of queue and waited for a One World Observatory member of staff to come along so we could check where we needed to go with our 'avoid the general admission line' tickets. After about 15 minutes a member of staff came by and when I asked they said that we still had to stay in this queue and wait for our time slot to be called.It was an exceedingly hot day as we stood waiting, and waiting, and waiting, and waiting....there was no shade, no water vendors nearby and no communication from One World Observatory staff. By 2.15pm, half an hour before our time slot a member of staff came past calling out for anyone with 1pm time slots...yes 1pm time slots. Again I asked the member of staff where we needed to be for our Priority Access 2.45pm time slot and was told to stay where we were and await to be called.I did a quick calculation that if we were running one and a quarter hours late we would have about 10 minutes up at the top before we needed to come back down and get our transport to JFK for our flight back to London.At 3pm another member of staff came past calling out for any one with 1.30pm time slots, again I repeated my question, reinforcing the point that we had Priority Access tickets and this time saying that we needed to be at JFK to check in for our flight by 4.45pm and it was going to take at least an hour to get to the airport. Again I was told to wait until our time slot was called. I hate to admit it, but we did what everyone else appeared to be doing and 'jumped our time slot' and proceeded along Vesy St to the front of One World Trade Center only to be confronted with another enormous queue.By 3.30pm we had moved forwards about 15 feet in the queue and looking at the size of the queue still ahead of us, I left the queue in search of a Supervisor and eventually found one, showed her our Priority Access tickets for a 2.45pm time slot, only to be told that they were running about one and half hours behind and we would have to wait. I said that we were flying back to London and needed to be at JFK in one and quarter hours time and with it being Friday it was more than likely going to take that long to get there (it actually took one and a half hours); and her response was to simply shrug her shoulders and walk off.So despite having already queued for two and quarter hours, as the queue ahead of us was still likely to take at least another hour + just to get to the front door, we hd no choice but had to leave so that we would get to JFK on time.We were obviously bitterly disappointed as we had really been looking forward to ending our holiday 'on a high', but it wasn't to be thanks to the diabolical organisation, or lack of it by One World Observatory staff. Added to which that was $104 worth of tickets wasted.Thankfully we had been up both the Empire State and Top of the Rock so we already had some great memories and pictures.

Amazing views of the city. We had the opportunity to go to the observatory and the views and the experience were amazing. We really enjoyed the presentation and the great views of the city. The flex pass gave us a VIP experience and was well worth it. I highly recommend this attraction if you are in the city.

Fabulous views and information. . This was well organized, welcoming and informational. It was so nice to have space to view the city. Never felt rushed nor crowded. Well worth the time and the money if you want to see the whole city

New king of the high buildings. In a city that specialises in going to the top of tall buildings, I think one world observatory is the new king.
The overall experience is good and well managed.
Being inside probably dulls the experience a bit, but the view is great.
Terrible bar maid. Amazing venue but so let done by an extremely obnoxious and over inflated ego of a bar maid working the bar on June 25th. So disappointing as the venue was stunning.

Expensive per person, but what a view!. The view here is absolutely terrific, if you're lucky enough to have a nice, clear day. But there's a lot of herding of the many, many people who also want to see this new attraction. We had an appointed time and were a bit early, so we had to wait outdoors. Be sure to pay attention during the elevator rides - they're pretty fun and informative, kind of like a ride at Disney. The film before being allowed to enter is nothing but an annoyance. There were too many of us in one place and the film was not particularly good, though it's glitzy. Then we were shepherded to another area and not allowed to draw back the gauzy curtains to see outdoors. Seemed like poor planning to us. The view would be terrific, but I know seeing it would cause people to stall.

One World Trade Center observatory. Visited it yesterday.best tip is to be there as early as possible.we booked 10 am and the queues where already getting big.and it was a bit of wait at some of the windows as there was so many people at the windows.the lift was'nt what I thought it was going to be like it shown on u tube.it was false trying to make you think you was really going to see the streets through the glass.dissapointed so many people are allowed in at the same time.

Go at Sunset. My daughter, granddaughter (13) are here in NYC for a week on a 3 generations tour. I have been blessed to see views from observatories around the world and this one is the best. We were fortunate enough to just make sunset on a beautiful evening which only made the view more spectacular. We had an 8 o'clock ticket and got to the top at 8:31. Although it was very very crowded with some folks camped out in the window seats taking selfies we are glad we went when we did. We were in the area at 6 pm and there was no crowd but still kept the 8 time. Don't miss this.

Most incredible view of NYC ever.. The observatory has incredible views of NYC. It is still new and very clean. The tours by staff are wonderfully organized with some local humor thrown in. I scheduled so I could do both daytime and through the sunset and was blessed by fantastic weather. Dinner options are limited and a little pricey but worth it due to the view. The memorial outside is inspiring and definitely makes you think about what has happened.

Stunning. Absolutely mind blowing trip to the top of the new World Trade Centre. Brilliant day so views incredible. Get there nice and early to beat the inevitable queue. Food and drink available but expensive!

must see if you're visiting the city. Spectacular views, very interesting journey to get to the top... very cool and very fast elevator ride with video displays making up the walls of the elevator... views of the city, harbor and West towards NJ are spectacular... sunset from the top is amazing and not to be missed

A bit Disney . After being up the Rockefeller this was a bit of a disappointment. I think they should have left it a bit more bare and had less stuff up there? The height is staggering although as your are completely enclosed the experience is numbed and the windows can ruin your photos with reflections and glare etc

Amazing. We had the perfect day for our visit, with wonderful visibility. The elevator ride is so smooth that I would not have known we were moving other than for my ears popping and the media show on the walls. The ending of the multi media show when you get off the elevator is incredible... Not going to say why. Then it was into the observation deck and views that were amazing. We spent 2 hours there, including a quick snack int eh cafe. Highly recommend.

Incredible Views Too. The elevator ride up and down is worth the price of admission!Once you're at the top, you walk through a tunnel and then have to watch a movie before you get to the observation deck. I really just wanted to see the view and was impatient to get to the observation deck--I was wrong!Relax and enjoy the show. The observation deck itself is the culmination of a well thought out trip from the ground to the top.

Mixed reaction. Visited the One World Observatory on June 22. We booked tickets online in advance and the organisation of entry for ticket holders is very efficient.The Global Welcome centre is very impressive and gives information on visitor numbers etc to date. The Sky Pod elevator is a fantastic experience, taking you through the history of New York City as you ascend rapidly to the observation area. Before going to the observation deck there is a walk through theatre with a three dimensional screen which shows a spectacular movie about NYC and ends very dramatically. Disappointingly , however, the space is too small for the number of visitors and if you are not at the front the experience is somewhat diminished. Why not have a sloping floor so those at the back could have a better view.There are 2 levels of observation deck with wonderful views of the city. We were there at sunset and also watched the city become illuminated, which was beautiful.We were very disappointed with the dining facilities. There was a severe shortage of chairs in the cafe area and a limited range of food. Also the prices matched the height of the building, sky high!!! Exorbitant!! 8 dollars for a chocolate croissant. And that is just one example. Why try to rip people off in this manner? The visit was worth it for the views and also was moving in light of all the lives lost there on 9/11. So I would recommend it but wait until you are back at ground level for your refreshments!

Incredible views.. This is a must do when in NYC. Save yourself some time and book on line. You can wait in line to buy tix for a fair while otherwise.There seemed to be a lot more people at the morning sessions (15 minute time slots for entry) than the afternoon sessions.TIP : If I went again I would probably take the Express entry option for the extra $20. You will miss a bit of the "wow factor" in the entry but once you are in the observation area there is plenty of wows.

Really Awesome. In the literal sense of awesome.. I tagged along on my wife's business trip to Lower Manhattan. I walked past the One World a couple of times while we were in the neighborhood and finally decided to get a ticket on a clear day. I'm glad I went early. We ended up getting through the line in reasonable time. They have a dramatic elevator ride and entrance. They clearly want to outdo the Empire State Building tour and they easily do. You can walk around once at the top as long as you like. I saw some low flying planes and joked to my wife that I always get uncomfortable when I am in a WTC bldg. and I see airplanes flying close by :-) It's an awesome view in all directions. People from all over the world there to check it out. My wife sat down to a meal while gazing out. Most of the tourists probably also take in the 9-11 Memorial museum across the street as we did the night before. I would highly recommend to anyone. Enjoy

Highlight of our visit to NYC. Brilliant experience despite the negative reviews I read before we went. We arrived at the attraction, bought tickets, enjoyed the attraction and left within 1 hour. The elevator ride was amazing as well as the view from the top. There is a sign at ground level to indicate the current viewing distance from the top. As the weather changes so quickly in New York, this is only a guide.

Must do!. Pay attention in the elevator :) A great view of the city that is completely different than Top of the Rock. Did not appreciate the Ipad people trying to upsell the experience. Got to see the cruiseship make its way down the river.

staff need more training. We have been to empire state, statue of liberty, etc, but this location is extremely unorganized and it kind of ruined the experience.We had tickets for a Saturday evening, but it was cloudy. We walked right into the tower with no que. That day, the staff was friendly and helpful. They knew what to do. We exchanged our tickets for the next day at noon for a better view.The website indicates that you should arrive 15 minutes in advance of your entry time. We arrived 20 minutes early. When we arrived, there were no signs. One door had a long line, the other door was propped open, with no sign. We thought the line was for people buying tickets and that the other door was for pre purchase. The night before, we had walked right in, so we thought the entry line was inside. Immediately, a staff member started yelling art us and all of the others entering that door. "This door is exit only!" We walked out and tried to figure out what to do. There were no signs or staff on the right side except for the yelling staff member, but he didn't tell us what to do instead. We walked to the left, where there were more confused staff members. We told them ticket time 12:00. It was 11:30. They told us to go away and come back in 15 minutes. When we got back, the 3 staff members were all asking each other which line was which, which was loading. Was the 12:30 line loading? None of them knew.Finally, were allowed into line, waited a while and then allowed in.Once inside, we moved quickly to the ticket taker. She was pleasant and efficient. Security line and staff were fine. Then, you move into this line/movie experience. We were moving along fine. Next you get to a cave. The line was moving along OK, but then a staff member shouted out, "this is not a line! Everyone move into all sections, left and right! All of a sudden, the area was smashed with people and barely moving. It was dark and crammed. I don't know what you would do if you needed to get out of there. No staff were in the winding part of the cave. There were no apparent exits or bathrooms. Anyone with claustrophobia should not go in there. Finally we were at the elevators. Staff there were fine.The elevator experience was amazing!! The show at the top was also awesome.When you enter the observatory, you are in a cafeteria, with an elevator down to the viewing area on the right. It was kind of odd. The view was amazing! It was just tainted by all of the stress of the queing and staff issues. We pre ordered tickets, thinking we could avoid these issues.We ate a snack at the dining area. After, we couldn't locate the trash, so we asked a cafeteria worker, who also said she couldn't find the trash can! What? Bizarre.Anyhow, I am mainly writing this review so that hopefully, the management of the property can properly train the staff and so that the outside line area can be reconfigured. I also suggest an exit area in the cave section. I know this observatory is new, but peak season is coming soon, so they should probably re train and reorganize. Make signs!

great view. Great view of the city. The elevator ride was great too. face the walls when you get in. all 3 walls are video screens. on the way up it shows you what NYC probably looked like without any buildings and then it progresses to current day. the ride down is even better.

was good - view was amazing. we went there 5 days after the official opening. The organisation was kind of confusing. But as soon as we were inside it was awesome. The view was amazing even though it was not a sunny day.
Best experience ever . If is your first time in NYC is a great opportunity to have a nice view of the city. And if you like architecture you gonna love this building. It's a awesome experience.

Must do in NYC. One of the best attractions. extraordinary experience for every NYC visitor and resident to gain a different view of the city incorporating the latest available technology. easy tickets purchase and they do respect the time on the tickets as long as you are there at the specified time. line was moving quickly and we had no issues to use mobile for access. just be sure to save the tickets directly on the device due to weak signal and spend the extra 15$ on the ipad rental. totally worth it.

A view like none other. It is expensive, but it brings the map to life. Standing up there and looking out you see the neighborhoods and landmarks. Take your time and don't feel rushed. The elevator ride is amazing---don't blink or be distracted.

Amazing. I guess this isn't number one in New York only because it's so new. Booked online and went straight up. Great elevator feature and amazing view as they lift the curtain! Then you have as long as you like to relax and enjoy it. We went in the bar after and had a spectacular view as a thunderstorm passed right through us. Drinks were reasonable considering the view too! Went for an hour and stayed for 4!

Wow. This was a highlight! We booked day flex tickets so were able to walk right in. The whole experience is amazing - the lift is the best lift experience I have ever had, and the theatre of the introduction is brilliant. Wasn't the sunniest or clearest day, so we couldn't see forever, but having the ipad presentation certainly helped us see what it would be like on a great day. The cafe at the top is great too. Well worth the money - it's not cheap!

My visit to New York City for the first time. I'm visiting my boyfriend in New York City. This is my first time visiting. We went to the One World Observatory.....it was awesome! We went all the way up to the 102 floor.

A once in a life time must visit!. This visit is a special occasion for those of us who have been on top of the Twin Towers before 9/11. The One World Observatory is the modern version of the former. The elevators are perhaps the most stunning experience of all with video projections on the walls both going up (travel through time) and going down (fly through the air from top to bottom). The observation floor is nicely done with both a virtual and real guide available. The view is, as before, stunning and depending on the weather the visibility can be huge!

New World Trade Center. Even with timed tickets line was very long and not very well organized. Since I visited only 1 week after the opening, I expect some improvement in near future.49 seconds elevator ride to 102nd floor is amazing! It's even better on the way down.After watching 6 minutes movie on 102nd floor (optional), you go down to 100th floor and enjoy the panoramic view.The whole observatory is enclosed. so you can only look through the windows.The best view of New York Harbor.View of the City is very nice but not great as the tower located at the southern tip of Manhattan.Great feature, which Top of the World (observatory on top of old #2 World Trade Center) didn't have is City Pulse, high-tech interactive stations at the north and south of the observatory where knowledgeable professional guides give additional information about the city and landmarks.At $32 per person One World Observatory is overpriced.

Skip the others, but not this one!. This is by far the best observatory of the city. First, the ride up the elevator is very cool. They project images on the walls of the City changing over time. I wish I would have recorded it. The Observatory itself offers 360 degree views and many opportunities to take great pictures. Just make sure to go on a clear day.

The Best View in New York. I came to New York to see this magnificent edifice that just this year. Got my ticket online with time of visit to avoid the line. Took r train from time square to camberland to 911 museum signage guide. The security to go in was as hard as tsa security. Once in, I took the world fastest elevator to 102 floor.The ride was very fast. On the north and south, there are collage of lcd monitors that forms a circle and guide explain things about New York. Although when I reach there, the view were cloudy, but once the cloud lifted, the view was awesome, and you can see all the 360 degree of Manhattan to Jersey, Statue of liberty and all the top of the sky scrappers. One World is the 4th highest building in the world. It could have been design to the the worlds tallest, but instead it chose to be the sysble of New York reborn after the 911 trajedy. The building around the world trade center are coming up one by one again. Form me, it was a wow experience.

A lot to see. As I did not pre-book a ticket, I was fortunate to buy a ticket and be allowed almost straight in.There is a little show given before hand to add to the drama, which some might find fun.The view was great. I made 2 rounds and did not have such a problem waiting the too long for a window to take a photo.I was not rushed to leave or anything like that.There was a lack of seats around the windows, but there was a restaurant.

Great experience. A fantastic experience that was well worth the entrance fee. The whole thing is very well thought out from the amazing lift ride to the stunning views over NYC. My only slight criticism is there could be a bit more information outside as to where you need to be to either buy tickets or where to queue if you've already got them.

Disappointing - lots of marketing and missing "real glass floor view". Last night I had booked two tickets for this newest attraction in the big apple to go up right before sunset. And it was very disappointing. I have been on top of the old WTC and the only thing that really got better was that there was nearly no waiting time at the bottom. If you buy your tickets (32 $ for the cheapest version) online, you can book it for an exact time (15 minutes steps) which I did. that worked out really well. The rest was by far not as good as expected, because it is more important for the owner to get additional money out of your pocket than enjoy the view. Including a nice "time travel presentation" in the elevator you climb the 102 levels within a minute. Once arrived in floor 102 they give you a little presentation before opening the screen to give you a first real view of Manhattan. But then you have to walk through information, where they try to sell you a "wallpaper"-background-pic with yourself, you have to pass a restaurant/cafe and climb down to floor 100 to finally see the 360 • panorama. When we were there it was extremely crowded (sunset/lightening of the city). They have too big monitors positioned in a circle in my opinion which are located in that area and they also could not resist to put their shop on that same level (!!) (why not when leaving the building downstairs?)Also there are obviously no rules there. People sat right next to the glass and sat there forever with all their bags surrounding them. Besides that I think this is a security issue it was also annoying if you want to take pics. The darker it gets, the more reflection you have in the windows and that means you have to bring your camera very close to the window. But you can't because so many people sort of "picnic" there. Very disappointing for me was that though they do have some kind of a big bulls-eye with glass you do not get what you would expect from such a modern building: to have a real view to the ground!! unlike in many other cities they only play a video!! Of course the view of Manhattan is still worth the trip (but don't pay more than the standard prize which is expensive enough). And at least I didn't have to wait over two hours this time compared to the old WTC. By the way: you can't approach the memorial fountain at the bottom after 9 p.m. real close for security reasons.

Long wait. Better View elsewhere. Poorly organised. We arrived on a Saturday around lunch time. When we got there, there was a massive crowd of people, some queuing some looking lost like ourselves. There is no signage around. There was 2 staff directing people but it was a nightmare. Eventually we found the ticket office and we had to queue for 30 minutes outside in the sun for our ticket. Then we were told to come back at 2:15. When we came back at that time we had to queue again and it was down the steps onto the sidewalk. A disaster. People were so mad. 40 minutes later the queue started to move. It takes a further 30mins of queuing to get through the security checks and finally up the the top. To be honest. The view is nice, but the view from The Rockafellar is much better. The Rockafellar has indoor and outdoor viewing areas. One World is super busy so it's not relaxing whatsoever. People pushing to the window to get photos. One World seems too enclosed and loud. So my advice is to skip One World Observatory altogether unless you want a day of waiting, queuing, frustration and disappointment. Go to the Top of the Rock. You won't be disappointed there.
WOW!! Breathtaking!!. An absolute must if you are visiting the city! Absolutely breathtaking views. An amazing experience for only $32 per person! Highly recommended.

Cool Elevators. You need to know what you are looking at in order to get the most out of this experience. If you don't fall for the IPad upcharge, then you are on your own to locate anything. There aren't any maps or any location guide posts like on other observation deck experiences. It is a beautiful view and a VERY fast elevator!

New York. Wow! Reservations are required. An elevator ride to the top is fast and smooth. A movie of the NY skyline is shown on the way up and down. When you get off the elevator the guide talks and then the shades are pulled up and you can see all over. After this you can go to floor 102 and take amazing pictures. This is a must see.

Great Experience. We visited just over two weeks after this attraction opened and were pleased with the detail put into it. This far exceeds the Top of the Rock or Empire State Building. The elevator ride is where the adventure begins. Then they show you a video before you see the stunning view from the 102nd floor. They did it right and the price of admission was worth it.

Great views but painful to get to see them. Once you finally get to the top 102 floor views are impressive. But the manner to get there is less than desirable and you need to be prepared. First you must pre purchase tickets and even then you will necessarily enter on time. Then you start moving forward in a long line into some underground area like a cave and you keep walking in the dark narrow underground. Then to a line to get on an elevator . Once at top you are corralled into a standing theatre and forced to see some gimmicky video. If you still have any patience you will finally be set free in the observation room.

Amazing!. Stunning views, this is a must. If you can get a seat ( a little disorganised!) the food and ambiance in the restaurant is fantastic- we had the sliders and a bottle of wine sat right next to the window..so memorable.

Great New Place. This place is new, so understandably there were a lot of people but nevertheless it was a great experience. You can buy the tickets online and then make a line to go up. The view from up there is amazing, you can see very very far away. You can stay up there as long as you want. They have shops, bathrooms and places to eat.

My expectations were not met. The views from the Empire State Building and the experience there was SO much better. OWO is going to have to work out a lot of kinks to make this a better sightseeing experience. To begin, unless you pay a ridiculous amount for an untimed ticket, you will have a timed ticket that comes in 15 minute increments. We were a little early for ours so we had to wait on the sidewalk by the stairs up to the building. This was early in the morning on a gloomy day; if it was busier it would have caused a big random crowd. The line that you stand in once it is your time is completely outside...this will be a nightmare on rainy days, humid days, and cold/snowy days. It was drizzling a little bit while we stood in line but luckily it was right before we were let in. I don't think there is anything they can do to fix this since everything is built but I can't believe they didn't take this into account. I know the lines are notoriously long at Empire State Building (it wasn't for us at 6:30pm on a Thursday) but at least the whole line is inside the building. The quick elevator ride up was cool-it shows the progression of NYC over the past few hundred years. The floor above the discovery floor is small and I saw a lot of confused people thinking it was the main observation floor. The main observation floor gets packed so it feels small too. Even though tickets are timed, that is just for entrance and security purposes; anyone can stay on top for as long as they would like which makes things very crowded. Since the building is in lower Manhattan, it is hard to tell what all the Midtown buildings are. There were at least 2 stations set up where a worker was explaining some buildings, which helped. Or you can pay extra to rent an iPad that has some sort of information on it (I didn't pay much attention to this, as we had already paid enough for the tickets alone). We stayed up top for a while but only because I was "trying to get my money's worth." The last thing we did before going down was get a bite to eat. I was shocked that a normal sized water bottle and small apple juice were $5 EACH. This is the only place our whole time in NYC that had such exorbitant prices. Overall, I think OWO is a waste. We didn't do Top of the Rock but that may have been a better choice to add to Empire, which we did do. However, OWO has a lot of significance so I know that most will want to go regardless of this review. If you must go, pick a day with mild and sunny temperatures and also do at least one other skyscraper because there is no WOW factor here. (The 9/11 Memorial is amazing though, but not considered a part of this).

Great views. Very cheap at $32 per person, we went 4 days after it opened and it was organised chaos with people arriving too early for their designated ticket time, too late for their ticket time, people who wanted to buy tickets, and people who wanted the 9/11 memorial (which was just around the corner). Unfortunately too few staff too ill equipped to deal with it, although after 1 hour of queuing we did get in, you take a lift up, too much CGI stuff going on in my opinion, bypass the people with ipads and look out the windows for the best views in NYC.

Really worth going. For 25 dollars you must go and see the view from this building. The lift takes 69 seconds to get to the top and shows an interactive video of New York being built. You get to learn loads about the sense of community after 9/11 happened and is really interesting. When you get to the top you're shown a quick presentation and then the amazing view is revealed. The only thing that was annoying was the queue. to get out and back down I wouldn't recommend it if you're claustrophobic. The views are breathtaking though, we went just as the sun was setting and you're allowed to stay at the top for as long as you want. If i did it again if go early and go to ground zero and the museum in the daytime and then visit the observatory around 8 as the sun goes down.

A great way see NYC. A great way to see NYC from downtown a experience not to miss and very emotional. We booked tickets in advance which was fantastic as we were admitted on time no waiting in long queues. Excellent value.

Impressive views but not worth the $. We paid well over $120 for a family of 5. Even with reservations there was a line to get in, a line for the elevators, and the observatory was very crowded (on a weekday evening). The elevator ride and reveal of the view were pretty impressive. There wasn't much else to keep the kids interested so they were ready to go in about 10 minutes. We decided to grab a bite to eat so we could relax and enjoy the view. After purchasing our food we went to sit down and realized that over 1/2 the tables didn't even have chairs. Our 3 kids were exhausted and had to stand to eat. For the price people are paying to get in and then to eat they could at least BUY SOME CHAIRS and maybe add an activity or two for younger kids!

An unforgettable moment in the floor 102. After the Twin Towers tragedy is an unforgettable experience to see again Manhattan from a very similar altitud and with all the magnificence of one of the most powerfull and magic cities in the world.The tragedy comes to your mind and its almost impossible not feeling the emotion that brings back in your mind where were you on Sept 11.There's an epic moment when visitors discover the view, I will never forget that. 100% recomendable!

#1 Must do in NYC. Quite simply amazing, jaw-dropping and inspiring. Book the extra cost VIP tour, you skip all of the lines and go straight to the top saving at least an hour. When you arrive at the top there is a cinematic introduction and incredible surprise that I don't wanna spoil but trust me this is going to be the no.1 must do in Nyc and the highlight of my trip. It made me feel like a small child in wonder at something incredible and new.

Stunning views of Manhattan!. After being entertained with a multimedia show up the elevator and in the lobby of the top floor, showing the history of the site, the curtains open and one comes upon the most stunning views of NYC.

Great Views and Nice Presentation. We purchased Day Flex admissions. This is a higher price than the timed admissions, but allowed us flexibility to attend when it was convenient for us (we waited til later in the day to allow some of the cloud cover to burn off). The Day Flex admission allowed us to skip all lines. It was crazy that we literally walked up and were told to step in front of all the people queued up outside waiting to get inside. Once inside, there was a line for airport-style security and we were by-passed to a separate queue that had no wait. After the security point, we had a choice to queue up with the regular ticketed folks (which apparently walks through some artifacts or something as you wait?) or walk directly onto an elevator...again, we chose to skip directly to the elevator. While others probably waited quite some time to get in, our Flex passes allowed us to virtually go straight up. The elevator ride is somewhat crowded which takes away from your ability to see the 'elevator show,' but it happens so quickly that it didn't bother us. The 'show' when you get out of the elevator was spectacular and I won't spoil it for those who have yet to attend. The views were amazing and, although it was crowded, we had no problem getting a view of everything we wanted to see. Others here have commented that people "hog" the windows or sit and block the views, but I can say that, during our visit (about 2pm on a Friday afternoon), it wasn't much of a problem and people were generally courteous about moving so others could take pictures. All in all, I would do it again and would suggest it to my friends/family.
wow. Amazing experience and the views are breathtaking. You can take your time to take in the amazing views but does get busy.

chose flexible ticket to manage weather conditions. This was the second time we visited N.Y., but first visit to One world observatory. Convenient to book tickets online (we chose tickets for a fixed day with all day flexible entrance hour. Afternoon was a bit rainy and cloudy, ie less good view from the tower, so we could wait until the weather was clear and then go straight to the top). By doing so, we also got to see the Manhattan view in both daylight and after dark (with all lights). Enter the premise from Vesey street and the building from West street side. After passing security elevators take you to the 102nd floor in less than 60sec. Amazing video show on three walls inside the elevator during ride. This could have been further explored in the exhibition area or in the iPads available for rent, as this was maybe the most interesting part except for the view itself. We had added pay for iPads in advance (not really knowing what to expect), but these were a bit of disappointment. In short they were an interactive satellite map of what you could see from the tower with some points marked out specifically, ie you would point at f.i. Empire state building and the iPad would zoom into that building and show a 30 sec video about that building. If you have not been to N.Y. before, probably this could be of some use, but you could just as well do with a good travel guide book/map. As there were no headsets to the iPad (not possible to plug in external ones either) and the noise level is quite high, you would either watch the movie without hearing what they say, or put it near your ear to listen to the story told without seeing the movie played. Hopefully they will develop the software over time and add more content, for instance including the video shown in the elevator, to bring more value for the money. Otherwise the iPads will be hanging around your neck instead of being used, as happened to us already after a few minutes. If you are a family or a group, you can definitely share one iPad per several persons. The view from observatory deck is spectacular (as is the one from Empire state building, but here you get a better view over Statue of Liberty and Brooklyn bridge).We had planned to eat from the "One Mix" menue while enjoying the view ("One Dinner" is the full restaurant menue and you can reserve table in advance, "One Mix" has a bit smaller or simpler dishes but does not allow pre-reservation and "One cafe" is what it says - sandwiches, wraps and pastry). However, it turned out that One Mix menue is not available after 3 or 4 pm (!), so we decided to go for some sandwiches/wraps in the cafe instead. Any alcohol had to be bought separately from the bar in the restaurant (separate queuing). Prices for food and drinks are naturally much expensive as in all tourist attractions like this. The souvenir shop had a quite well developed assortment.

It's high alright. We visited the observatory shortly after it opened to the public, indeed I believe we were amongst the first 100,000 visitors. On balance it was a good experience. The star of the show is the view of course. The whole of Manhattan - and beyond - lies open at your feet. Unfortunately, the main attraction has been surrounded by cod theatricals involving projections of New York 'through the ages' as the lift carries you in short order to the 102nd floor. I found this cheapened the experience and gave it an unnecessary flavour of theme park. However, once installed in the observatory area itself, the floor-to-ceiling glazing ensures that the views take centre-stage and not even the appallingly kitsch retail souvenir offerings could detract from that. There are presentations made at various vantage points on the deck. I missed out on these but my son told me that they were entertaining and informative. The service agents were, to a man, enthusiastic and geed up by their ambassadorial roles. They did a good job.I think I was just a little surprised not to see any reference at all to the twin towers that had occupied this airspace previously. Of course I realise that there is a monument and a museum dedicated to the memory of those who died, and that these are no more than a step away. However, it seems strange that it is possible to enjoy a visit to these outstanding panoramas without being reminded of that appalling day we all share. Perhaps I missed it, but I would have liked to have seen at least a quiet corner of the attraction dedicated to that memory.

WOW!! Great views!. Visited the observation deck and was so impressed by the glorious views. Much broader than the World Trade Centre views. The experience on the elevator and at the arrival were really well done and done with a terrific flair!! Don't miss this observatory. The restaurant food was delicious and enjoyable. Stay awhile at the top....it is an enjoyable experience!!

Pick a sunny day get there early!. Good things.Yes, it's spectacular, as high as you can go in NYCThe facilities at the top are good, if pricy.The elevator ride up and down is quite entertainingThe pre amble to actually seeing out is extremely well done.Bad thingsUnless you have a very good forecast, don't pre book!if you turn up without a ticket the q system outside the building is shambolic, totally un sign posted, very little information, or apparent organisation, they need to get a grip on this ASAPOverall, pick a good day, get there early!

It's Hard to Screw Up such a Breathtaking View, but OWO Does It's Best. We visited OWO on an early evening in June near the summer solstice. We got up early enough to see the endless vista and a stunning red sunset. Inside, at 1,200 ft (approx height of observatory levels), OWO is a cesspool. The promoters have made every effort to appeal to the lowest common denominator. Examples of the many awful aspects/features of the joint:Hawkers giving a blasting presentation on the north and south corners of the building that was as insipid as it was loud. The only place to sit is on the 8" high radiators that surround the perimeter. People sitting on this uncomfortable spot block views and prevent people from taking pictures. The building itself is not built in line with the Manhattan street grid so efforts to look in many directions are obstructed by the slanted mullions between the glass. I could go on but, other than the sunset, I'd rather forget the experience. My family greatly enjoys the Empire State Building, we treasure visits to the RCA/NBC/Comcast observatory, we loved stepping out on the top of the old WTC observatory, but nothing will drag us back to the pit that is OWO. I should add, there are two good features (other than the view): the elevator ride up features a surround film of the construction of NY over time. I'll look forward to seeing that at a pace where it can be inhaled as opposed to the impossibly fast pace in the elevators. Also, at these insane prices, there was virtually no line!

Definitely Worth Visiting. I'm a native New Yorker who now lives in New Jersey so I'm not a tourist. This attraction is definitely worth seeing for both tourists and locals alike. For anyone who lives in the area, this is an emotional experience. It was thoughtfully done. The testimonials from people who helped to construct the building as you wait for the elevators was quite moving. I bought the day flex ticket ($65) but it was worth it. I didn't have to wait in line which on the day I went must have saved me about 90 minutes. The views of the city were spectacular but I do agree that you need to try to wrangle window space. I liked that there were staff posted to explain where to go as well as someone who gave you the culture and history of NYC and the neighborhoods.I will definitely return with family at a later date and to see the 9/11 Museum which I didn't have time to see.
Can't miss it. A must in NYC. Great experience and quite impressing the elevators' videos. Amazing views of the city.

EXCILLARANT!. Just the trip in the elevator is worthwhile, they show you how New York was from the start and through history. And in just 60 seconds! The view at the top is of course great. They also have restaurants. Very well organized, deserve a visit when you are in NYC. The only dark side is that to your mind comes 9/11 when so many people were brutally assesinated in that spot. But is also a great statement of coming back!

Amazing views. We visited a few weeks after opening and were very impressed. The lift ride up with the animated displays was very cool, plenty of information from the ambassadors, particularly Matthew (young gentleman) who was operating the 'city pulse' and took time out to answer our questions about particular buildings in the area. He was very enthusiastic and helpful.The views were amazing, we were lucky to be there in a clear day with visibility over Manhattan, New Jersey almost perfect, this is a great way to see the city.Highly recommended to all visitors to New York.

Spectacular. Traveling with grandkids, we gave them choice of one city view. They chose the newly open One World Observatory. We all agreed it was spectacular in every way. Check out the website to see a brief video that you see when your elevator ascends, it's definitely pricey but a memorable experience.dont miss it! Eat before you go because the snack and sandwiches are simply outrageously priced for families, even by NYC standards.
