Could have been so much better. I booked this in advance from New Zealand and really looked forward to it. The view from the observatory deck is great apart from having to fight for window space. You do get a fab view of the city. Luckily for the time slot we booked, we were told there would be no visibility as it was raining and we were able to rebook.BUT: The ride up in the elevator where you are supposed to see the development of NY is 'a have' as they crowd so many into the lift you cannot see what is happening on the three screens. Next you are herded into a narrow space to see another AV but again the screen is too wide and you are too close to see what is going on.Then the screens are raised so you can see the city but you are hustled off again after about 30 seconds. There is no interpretation unless you pay another $15 for an Ipad to explain what you are seeing. Nothing to explain about the tower or what you are looking at. Pretty rubbish when you are paying $32.The grills and glass don't make for great photos and the food area is the most unbelievable disorganised mess. You select or order you food and then have to go elsewhere to pay for it. I waited for my pizza slice then had to queue with my hot food to pay. The cashier was stressed out and totally pissed off and unfriendly. I was tempted not to bother paying and I'm sure many people just walked off with their food and didn't pay; would have been easy to do. Getting a drink from the bar meant a separate queue.We didn't bother. There was one chair for every 1-2 tables and no-one cleaned them off.The best part about the whole experience is a lovely man at the entrance on the ground level called David who welcomes visitors. He is a star!Otherwise it feels like their motto is Turn 'em and burn em'.It should and could be so much better

Fantastic. The place is clean, marvellous, and just fantastic! The view is beautiful, you can see both New Jersey and New York. The only bad thing is when you take photos, the reflection is shown. Either way, this is an experience every tourist should see.

This isn't just a view but a whole experience. Having been told by everyone that for our first visit don't bother with the Empire State, we agreed to go to the Top of the Rock. Then the chance to visit OWO came up so we did that too. From the moment you enter the building and go down a couple of floors the whole experience leaves you breathless. Even the ride up the elevator offers something new. And as for the show at the top even before the view makes you want to cheer - many did when we were there. The view is, obviously, spectacular and that is the real attraction. It was very busy but if you wait a few moments then the chance to grab the photo you want soon arrives. We spent nearly 90 minutes up there in the end. And even the somewhat overpriced drinks were tempered by the fact you are sipping cocktails with the whole of Manhattan stretched in front of you. It was an experience I'll never forget.

Give the feeling of being back. It was a great relief for me to be atop the new WTC observatory. It has taken a lot of time but result is astounding. Great view, beautifully done. The staff outside is not helpful at all even rude which was anoying. Buy tickets before (i recommend the VIP tickets) otherwise the waiting will be long.

Helpful staff, and a great experience!. Travelling from London, we booked for this attraction in advance. When we arrived on the morning of our timed ticket, the whole top third of the building was in the cloud level. We spoke to the box office, and they changed our ticket to another of our choice (advising us that later that same day there would be thunderstorms). We chose to return two days later. Such a great experience - very efficient system to get to the top. Great views (obviously), and there is a lovely restaurant on the 101st floor with great views looking uptown. Would recommend.

Gorgeous Views. I visited the One World Observatory on it's opening day (May 28, 2015).Despite having a scheduled admission time, my group had to wait approximately 30-45 minutes before even getting through the doors.Beyond the wait times, the experience was quite incredible. The elevator ride to the top is amazing....I'm afraid of heights, and I expected the elevator ride to be scary (I was expecting a similar elevator to the CN Tower), but it was actually so cool, and not scary at all!You watch a brief video before entering the 360 degree observatory! The video has a pretty amazing ending!The observatory itself was extremely busy...but that obviously was due to the fact it was opening day.The views were worth the wait!

Moved to Tears. I don't want to give it away but from the boulders of the great island to the top of this new building, the tour is outstanding. Get there as fast as you can! I recommend arriving a little before dusk to get the best effect. Leave enough time to have a drink in the cafe. It's fairly priced and has the best views!

Legends Hospitality needs to manage observatory better. The view is nice but the observatory has some major flaws due to mistakes by Legends Hospitality (the managers of the observatory):1. All the windows have air vent boxes at their base. These boxes are used as seating by sloppy tourists who lazily sprawl out and block the view for everyone else. It's really annoying trying to enjoy the view while hovering over some random Eurodorks.2. The lighting inside the space makes it impossible to take nice photos after sunset. Too much glare and reflection. 3. The most popular and crowded viewpoint is looking towards Brooklyn Bridge and midtown. Legends Hospitality placed the tacky gift shop in the same viewing area making it more even more crowded. Skip this. Head to Top of the Rock.

Stellar experince. From the ticket window, the quick moving lines to the absolutely incredible ride in the elevator to the top in 60 seconds with an outstanding 360 degree experience I'll keep for a surprise should you go, this is an amazing resurgence to Lower Manhattan and way to see the City. For $64 in advance for two tickets, it is a MUST DO.

Unforgettable experience. We went to the top of the One World Trade Centre on opening weekend and we were blown away. It is a truly unforgettable experience and I would recommend it to anyone! There is also a bar at the top where you can sit and have a few drinks with possibly the best view of New York, what's not to love?!

Beautiful Experience. Unfortunately for us, the day we visited the Observatory, the sky was cloudy. We were able to have a limited viewing of the city, which was fantastic. I cannot imagine the views on a clear day.

Seriously good!. We did all three of the major towers (WTC, Empire State and the Rockefeller) on this trip, and hands down the One World Observatory is the best. We went early on a Sunday and were at the top within about 30 minutes of arriving. The entrance area is great, security efficient and we really liked what they have done with the elevators. You then go in to a very good video presentation which ends with plenty of oohs and ahhs from the group you're with!A couple of reviews have mentioned the reflections from the glass, and it is a shame that it gets on some of the photos. But don't let that deter you because the views and the experience are just incredible!

Gorgeous experience!. I decided to have a tower tour during my NYC visit; but i became undecided between Empire State, Rockefeller and OWTC. Before i thought that Rock is the best choice, coz it offers both Central Park and E.State panorama. At the end i decided to have One Wolrd Observatory Tour to get the newest one. Sure the NYC panorama looks fascinating from all asaid buildings but the ambiance of corridors, information screens, special elevator, the theater etc. upgrades your experience..Since long time nothing charmed me like this place.. By the way, buy the ticket from web to gain time..

Incredible!. As a first time visitor to New York and after already seeing most of the other main attractions earlier in the week, this totally blew me away. The experience in the lift, the teaser presentation on the big screen and then the views! It was absolutely amazing and was probably helped by the clear, sunny weather.I felt this was better than the Empire State Building because you can see the tower from the outside which gives you more of a connection with it.One slight negative is the restaurant. It is a bit of a shambles with poor overpriced food, not very good service and too few seats. But please don't let this put you off, if you only do a few things in New York, make sure this is one of them.

The observatory experience is simply amazing. We were among the last visitors to the top of the old World Trade Center towers and among the first to the One World Trade Center Observatory, and the new tower offers an even more memorable experience, if such a thing is even possible! Wait til you get on the elevators and see the surprise that is in store for you (no, I won't ruin it by giving any more clues)! All I can say is, whoever designed the new observatory really put a lot of creative thought into it. Oh, and it's MUCH easier to get to the top than it is with the Empire State building, and it costs less too! This has to be one of the most fantastic/engaging attractions now available in the city that never sleeps.

Great view but teething problems. Like many others I was blown away with the first views of the city - as articulate as I can be there's few words I have which can come close to doing that instantaneous reaction justice.The views across New York are incredible, from a view standpoint it's incredible, but with the windows & the reflections if like me you're a "point & click" kinda photographer don't get your hopes up! I went up at night specifically to see the city at night having done ESB during the day and I can't say I was disappointed with that decision, the city lights just add to the view of New York.Can't say security was a problem, nothing you wouldn't expect although I'd imagine during peak hours this would be time consuming if you're lucky you can get through in minutes.Overall I'd recommend it if for nothing else than that first view of New York from the observatory, you'll know what we all mean when you see it yourself.

Great View of NYC. As the title says, you get a great view of New York City from the Observatory. Hope you pick a day when the weather is clear, as we did. I wish it were possible to get outside; all viewing is through windows which make it difficult to take reflection-free photos. This is a one-time experience, especially at the $32 admission price.

Amazing. They did a fantastic job with the entire experience. I was concerned, since it had only recently opened, but everything flowed smoothly. I won't spoil it, but the way they lead up to the view is great! We also had lunch up there, and the food was surprisingly good! Only advice is pre-buy tickets, but a must-do in NYC

Spectacular views . You can't match the views of NYC from the observatory. The admission and security processes are smooth and there is an interesting video history of the city on the ride to the top. Maybe just a bit overpriced at $32 admission for adults.

Overproduced. Saying this was the Disney version of a New York view isn't quite right. Disney would tell a cohesive story. This was disjointed thoughts woven together with emotionally manipulative music. The videos in the elevator would have been interesting if I could watch without getting sick. The theater wasn't interesting and you couldn't get good photos through the glass. Empire State Building is better.

High in the Sky Observatory with a Disney World Ride to the top. One ust pass through security before going down to go up. You walk into the actual bedrock and see people talking about building the building on screens as you go. It is a salute to the greatness of the building and the architect. The ride to the top is documented by a little picture of the building that shows how high the elevator is climbing with a graphic illustration. Once you leave the elevator there is a short movie before you are ushered to the stirs for the observatory deck. The view can be spectacular if you have a sunny day. You are confronted by people who want you to rent an ipad with photos of what you are seeing. Name tags pop up for famous buildings. Ours wasn't working very well so I would say that it wasn't worth it. All in all, the observatory experience does not seem to be worth the price of the ticket. I wouldn't go back.

Amazing. Do not miss going to this if you are visiting nyc. Cannot explain how amazing this observatory is. Even going up in the lift pod was unbelievable. 102 floors in 60 seconds & you don't feel a thing. You get the history of nyc in your short trip. When you get to the top - it will take your breath away.

Forever is right. This was my favorite attraction on my recent visit to NYC. The presentation is spot on. I don't want to give anything away but the elevator ride up was fantastic and the views are breathtaking. The nice thing is you are not rushed to leave, we sat in different views for quite some time taking it all in. The staff is extremely friendly and accommodating. A must see in the NYC

A night time experience. We decided to go up to the Observatory at night and see the city in the dark and we weren't disappointed. The lights and the goings on below us were marvellous. I'm sure it was just as good during the day!!

UK traveller. Visited 14/6/15. Booked online and the time slot was very good and on time. Quick lift takes you to the top. There is a surprise that awaits you at the top, so I won't spoil it for you. Views are worth it and not dissimilar to the windows of the world on the twin towers. Worth the money to say you've done it.

Not great for photographers. Too many reflections. I am going to write this review from a photographers point of view in hopes it helps someone later. We chose One World over the other observatories mainly because it was newly opened. We chose a 8:15 time to hit the 8:30 sunset. We arrived at 7:40pm and were allowed to start lining up around 7:50 for the 8:15. At around 8 they started letting us in the building. You have to go through airport style security so that takes a while. Then you walk through a set of exhibits with various bits of info about the building. Then you line up for the elevators. Once at the top, you wait in line again to enter a theater where you have to wait to watch a presentation with a reveal at the end. Then you are let into another room, but wait! You still aren't there yet! There are some small windows in the corner of the first level that everyone squishes up to slowing everyone else down. You have to go down 2 levels to finally get to the 360 degree views. Point being, it's gonna take a loong time to get up there, so plan accordingly if you are trying to time sunset. for night viewing, the observation deck is terrible for reflections. There are tons of bright lights inside making reflection-free photos pretty impossible without bringing a black cloth of your own. Luckily my mom was wearing a black cardigan that we used as a reflection blocker to get good shots. There is no outdoor area. The restaurant closes at 4 and the cafe was out of most everything at 8PM. So they haven't quite figured out the food thing yet. Overall it's good if you don't care that much about taking pictures and you enjoy a very controlled scripted experience.
Great View. Pros: Great views, plenty of viewing area, fun 'surprise' after coming out the lift.Cons: 20 min delay in getting in, even with pre booked ticket, quite expensive, iPad tour costs extra.

Great view!. We went up in the tower and it was great! Book your ticket in advance is a good advice. Good organization and service, excellent view - and very good restrooms, something you really appreciate when touristing.

Don't count on the time of your entry. Fortunately, Mother Nature cooperated with a clear day and some bright sun that I had to stand in for 45 minutes while waiting for entry. I made it into the building at 2:20 with tickets for 2 o'clock. After airport style security screening and a walk through the bedrock another que was formed to wait for an elevator. A very quick ride with an interesting time view on the way up to the 102 floor brings you out on a balcony and a short boring video presentation that ends in a dramatic way with the screen being raised to present a spectacular view of the East River and the Brooklyn Bridge. As you work your way down to the 100th floor you get a 360 degree view through some very crowded windows. It is tough to get good photos without reflections. If you want good photos, the outdoor observation platforms at the Top Of The Rock and The Empire State Building will provide better images. For me, this was a disappointment after visiting the outdoor deck of the south tower of the WTC in the summer of 2001. My only advice is to not wait until the day of your visit to buy tickets. The line is very long and it will detract from your visit. The views are great, if they could only be outside, they would be perfect.

A fantastic view but there are much better available in NYC. We arrived early which was a good plan as it seems to fill up quickly, however the reflections in the glass meant that our photos were compromised. Top of the Rock and The Empire State Building offer glass free views and the wind in your hair.

Do it!. Not much else to say really. This must be on the list of every visit to New York. Most spectacular and exhilarating panoramic views from the Observatory. Only opened a week and we were 81,000th ish visitors so book early!Don't want to spoil it but be prepared for the reveal. Well organised - best in New York actually, good ticketing and queuing system, swift security. For those expecting to turn up book a ticket and go up - forget it. It is so popular and for obvious reasons. It is a timed ticket allocation. As long as you go along with this in mind and are prepared to have an alternative plan to fill any void then this will be an enjoyable experience. For the record - a Sunday morning. Arrived 09.30, queued for ticket office 10 mins - entry time 11.15, start queuing in line at 10.45am. This was enough time to pay our respects at the 9/11 Memorial and grab a coffee. we were in the security line at 11.15 and in the elevator about 11.30. Enjoy!

See Forever. I visited the One World Observatory atop One World Trade, to get a birds eye view of NYC.First things first: BUY your ticket online, which is what I did. I also paid the up-charge for the expedited entry - well worth it. The on site ticket counter is inside the building and has limited space, so the lines snaked around the block.There didn't seem to be a system for the expedited entry? We lucked out with a young man who was informed and we got it about 15 mins before our scheduled time.Once inside, the expedited line seemed to be non-existent? Again, luck shone and we our tickets were scanned and we were directs to a segregated screening area. Once inside you wind through some informative videos and then onto the elevators. The elevator video is awesome - no spoilers. There's a different one coming down so stay keen.Once you arrive, you're corralled into a video viewing area - very cool. There's a very cool feature at the end of the video so have your cameras ready!Once you leave the arrival video area, unless you want your image taken, stay left. It's one of those screens and your picture gets taken.The viewing area is set on two floors with very expansive views. Although it was sunny, there was quite a bit of haze, but the views are spectacular.Noticed quite a few selfie-sticks, annoying actually and although I was able to get some great shots, too many people just sitting on the sills. There is a restaurant, but to be honest, nothing like Windows On The World - an amazing place with a strict dress code and incredible views, especially at sunset. One thing I noticed, in order to get out, they make you walk through the Gift Shop - I lucked out since a side door was open, so I bypassed the store.I have to say I found the architecture of WT1 uninspiring, even the interior? Nondescript and not at all like the former buildings that had this amazing lobby and those great cathedral like arched windows, but things change.

A must do. I must admit I was sceptical as we had already done the "top of the Rock", but I was persuaded to go by my wife, and it really is a must do.The organisation, show in the lift, and the brief cinema style presentation when you get to the top are excellent and the views are stunning!We booked the day before when we knew the weather would be fine - yes you are enclosed by glass, but the staff are really helpful and show you how to take pictures to minimise the reflection.One to add to your NYC list!!.

Amazing Views - a Worthwhile Experience. I went up the Observation Tower at 6pm on a Friday evening. I don’t want to go into the full experience detail as I feel that some of the things you see need to be experienced first-hand, and are better if they come as a surprise.The overall experience here was very good though. We got tickets online so did not have to queue on the day to book tickets. All staff seemed to be friendly and willing to help. There were very little queues when we went and so we went through security and were able to head up to the top very quickly.Words cannot describe the views available from the observation deck! They are stunning. A slight downside is that if there is glare from the sun you can’t get the best pictures as you are taking them through glass windows which reflect that glare. It was busy up there, but people were on the whole very patient and would take it in turns to step up to the windows to take in the views / take photos. I never felt rushed at any point and enjoyed the experience. You can rent an iPad for the time you are up there that is set up to give information about the sights seen out of each window. These cost $15 for the rental. I did not rent one but could see plenty of people using them as they walked round the tower.All in all, a very worthwhile trip – yes there were a few downsides but I wouldn’t hesitate to do this again if I ever get back to NYC.

One World Trade Center - Strength & Resilience. Everyone will claim a certain pride, relief and healing with this monument to freedom. While remembering the past, One World Trade Center symbolizes hope for the future and the resilience to bring it back for all the world to see.During construction the building was known as the Freedom Tower. In March 2009, the Port Authority announced it would be known by its name, One World Trade Center. Opened on November 3, 2014, it is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere and fourth tallest building in the world. Chicago may argue this point and new building construction may change this designation. Antennas and spires are a touchy subject with architects and those certifying building heights, the CTBUH. With its antenna/spire, One World Trade Center stands at 1776 feet - a reference to 1776 when the Declaration of Independence was signed. Regardless, One World Trade Center is back and stands where 6 World Trade Center was located.If you visit, take the last subway stop at City Hall, then you will only have several blocks to walk. Because the building is so tall the walking distance appears shorter from the subway station. Due to continued construction in the area, you must walk around and between buildings to One World Trade Center. The walk is easy and many sites are in this area (1) the 9/11 Memorial and Museum; (2) St. Paul's Church; (3) Battery Park; (4) Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island embarking on the ferry from Battery Park (4) City Hall; (5) Brooklyn Bridge; and for shoppers (6) Century 21 (people were taking photos of this store)! Many great views from all of these sites located almost next to each other. A short walk to Tribeca or the Stone Street District and you'll find lunch or dinner. For those with any mobility concerns, construction makes the trek somewhat longer at this time. One World Trade Center is definitely worth the time to see this magnificent structure. Thank you New York City!

Great views.... This wasn't our favourite observatory that we visited, but it has great views of the ESB and statue of liberty. Go at sunset, we just missed it because we were so tired. Also, there are no toilets on entry you have to wait until you are right up and past their "surprise" so don't go in desperately needing a comfort break! Buy tickets online in advance to save waiting in the line twice!

A magnificent view from a wonderful observation deck. The recently opened One World observation deck is modern and spacious and allows for wonderful views of New York City. Unlike the Twin Towers the building does not allow visitors. The only access to the building for the general public is by separate entrance that leads to the observation deck on the 102nd floor. The observation deck is wrapped around the center of the building, protected by floor to ceiling glass, and affords 360 degrees view. There is no access to the open air, though, like in the Empire State Building. The panoramic view is beautiful, but the reflection on the glass sometimes makes it difficult to take pictures. Tickets are expensive at $32 and may be reserved online. The best time to visit is just before sunset, so as to get both the day view and the night view of the scenery. There are two posts, on the northeast and the southwest of the deck, where guides periodically explain the scenery below. There are other guides who walk around answering questions. The status of One World Observatory as the highest observatory in New York will last for some time, but the One World Trade Center building keeps its title as the highest building in the Western Hemisphere only because of the height of its spire. Measured by rooftop height, 324 Park Avenue building is 28 feet taller, and the soon to be built Nordstrom tower will be taller still. Nonetheless, those two buildings are strictly residential, and do not allow access to the public. The visit to the One World Observatory is very sleek. It starts in a tunnel with mock displays of the natural rock foundations of the building and continues to a fast elevator ride straight to the top. The walls of the elevator are used to project the view of New York going up, and the history of New York going down. Once on top, there is another digital presentation before a screen opens to reveal the view. There are also souvenir photo takers and a gift shop, as well as a restaurant with the best views in a town. Overall, a very enjoyable visit.

One World Many Reflections. Disappointing visit to this new attraction. Expensive for what it was. The lift was great - really fast and the time lapse views of New York were really clever, The observatory itself is completely enclosed in glass which doesn't lend itself to photography. Most of my photos include reflections of either the air conditioning grilles below the window or the people standing behind you. Even the glass floor was a disappointment and not a true glass panel like the Sky Tower in Auckland. Book your photo package online before you go. its much cheaper.

Magnificent. Only been open for 2 weeks and I was so pleased that I was able to see this new One World Centre. The tour was so well organised and on the ground floor you walk through an Audio recording and images of the construction explaining concept for the building. From there you are taken to an elevator which is so fast although you don't notice it, up to 101st floor and when you get out the views takes your breath away 360o view of the city. All I kept saying was WOW. There's a shop and cafe at the top. Take your time and soak it all in. When we came out we visited Ground Zero. You must visit.

see the world...on a clear day!. This was a wonderful surprise. We had visited the site of the World Trade Center many times in it's transformation to a memorial site and business mecca of New York city. The entire experience is both breathtaking and emotional. The white marble floors and calming colors could not possibly prepare you for the view 101 floors above the memorial fountains and the financial district of NYC.My advise is to NOT make a reservation too far in advance, as we did. Unfortunately, it was a rainy, overcast day and we were not able to see as well as a clear day. We will return again and again, so we are not concerned.

Fantastic view. Long lines. Fantastic view. Even though I bought the tickets online and took a printout, there was still a long line outside and inside. But it was absolutely worth it. The views are beautiful. I was lucky to go on a nice day.

Value for money . Great price you go to the 102 floor and the view is just breathtaking the building itself is the tallest in New York friendly staff very easy find if your walking around plus you can visit the 9/11 memorial after you have been to the top of the building.once in a lifetime experience
A good place to pay respects.. It was good to visit and pay respects, but I felt a bit uncomfortable that this has become a 'tourist' destination, and that costs are continuously on the rise.
Stunning building .... stunning views. What an exciting experience to get to be among the first to visit the OWO (one world observatory) Everything about it is top rate.

Wow! More than a great view.. I went here not expecting much, having already been to the top of the Empire State Building and Rock Center. A great view of NYC is always beautiful, so how different could it be? There is a lot more to the experience than the view. The walk through the bedrock on the way to the elevator, the amazing elevator ride (and I'm nervous about 100-floor elevator rides), the show before you go into the observatory--all so much fun. I would highly recommend renting one of the ipads they have to explain the view. You can stand looking out at the view with the ipad, and click on different buildings on the ipad and get a little video and history of the site. Really great experience.

Fantastic view of the city. We didn't have time to visit the whole site, but we saw the fountain and visited the observatory. It was an incredible view and a meaningful experience. The fountain with the names of those who died there gave me goose-bumps. Someday I will return for a closer look plus a visit to the museum. The nice people who worked there on the day we visited (4 adults and 2 children) made our experience better. Thank you for being so pleasant!

Disappointed. Completely disappointed with the observatory. I would recommend going to the Top of the Rock any day over the One World Observatory. First off its completely unorganized. There was one older gentleman outside policing the main entrance since there weren't any signs directing people (ticket holders) where to queue up. The lack of signs and direction continued throughout. The elevator ride up was the highlight of the visit. No maps were offered (that I could find) showing landmarks out the windows. That is because they want visitors to pay extra $$ over the entrance fee to rent an iPad. The other disgrace was the $5 charge for a 16oz bottle of water or Gatorade? $5, really?? Was the same price for fountain soda, but with that I suppose you'd get to have refills. Lastly, the guest photo that can be viewed/purchased at the end of your visit must be viewed/selected on an iPad BEFORE you enter the imaging line as indicated on the ticket. This forced me to stand in numerous lines more than once, because of inadequate communication. Some signs or handouts explaining these things sure would have been useful. Overall I'd skip it. Absolutely visit the 911 museum next door though. That should be a must do for any visitor to Manhattan. Their 1hr guided tour was fantastic and worth every penny.

Amazing View. The elevator ride was really cool and the view was amazing. Do not wait until you get there to get tickets. We assumed that because all timeslots online were still showing as available the day prior to going that it must not be all that busy and we'd be able to get right in but that is NOT the case. Once we got there, the line to get tickets was so long that they were recommending that people use their phones to purchase tickets. We were able to do that, but the time slot was two hours later, so while we waited we visited the 9/11 memorial, had lunch, and walked around the area.

$2 Military Discount? Top of the Rock offers $20 off. I HATE complaining about military discounts, but One World Observatory talked about offering a "special discount" for military members in their press releases leading up to the opening. I couldn't find how much the discount was online, so I went in person only to find $2 off a $32 ticket. In this circumstance, it seems like they wanted to brag about a military discount more than they wanted to offer one.One World Observatory - If there was ever a time when military members deserved a discount, this would be it. You should at least be able to match the 70% off discount that the Top of the Rock offers. With as many american flags as I saw, you seem to want to be a symbol of patriotism. If so, you need to treat our military members accordingly.

The Latest Must Do in NYC. Recently opened, this is a new must-do attraction in The Big Apple. Located on the 102nd floor of the One World Trade Center building (formerly called Freedom Tower), it affords spectacular views of the NYC region from a height more than 1600 feet. We went on a beautiful clear morning, and the views were impressive. You need to buy date and time specific tickets at https://oneworldobservatory.com/. We showed up 45 minutes early and were allowed right in BUT it was early in the day and there was no one in line. When we came out an hour later there was a long line. Recommendation 1: Go early in the day. Access and crowd control measures were excellent; all well organized. The elevator rides up and down are really interesting. The walls of the elevators are video screens. On the way up they show what the view would look like starting in about 1600 and aging as you go up. On the way down, it looks like the elevator flies outside the building and circles it. Very cool. Recommendation 2: Be ready if you want to take video—it happens fast. The elevator ride is very fast but smooth. You exit the elevator into a long wide room with a screen on the long wall on which a flashy video about New York City is shown. Recommendation 3: Be ready for what happens at the end of the video. The observatory itself is on two floors; one on which you can walk all the way around to see the whole city and the other with a café and gift shop. Be aware that EVERYONE is taking selfies with the skyline, which can get annoying. We were never more than two deep to get to the floor-to-ceiling windows: but if it were more crowded, it could take a while to get up to the window (to take your selfie). There is a coffee and juice bar with sweets, a counter for roll-up and sandwiches, and a full-service café and bar.

Stunning views but glass is disappointing for photography!. To begin with, the price for the observatory is 32$ which I think is a bit overpriced. The building is magnificent. The entire experience right from the entrance to the elevators to the presentation is super! The entrance to the tower has various digital presentations and facts on a rocky wall. All four sides of the elevator are digitally enhanced with NYC views. The presentation in the cinema theatre when u get on floor 101 was the best bit. You think its a normal presentation with some NYC facts and when you are least expecting all the slides go up in the wall revealing a 360 panoramic view of NewYork City! The observatory offers some stunning views of the NYC bridges, statue of Liberty, Empire State, Chrysler building and others. But its not as great for photography as the Top of the Rock because it has glass panels all throughout which make it difficult to get good pictures even with a good camera. The observatory has an open bar and a small café where you could relax, eat and get great views too. As it has newly opened, its highly commercialised. They offer an ipad audio tour which is an additional 15$. Also, they click some pics for you with artificial NYC backgrounds which are 20$ each. Overall, great views and an awesome digital experience but disappointing for photography. Note that the best time to visit is the evening slot in summers as the sunlight is too harsh during the day. Go around 7.30 in summers where u can see the views in daylight, can see the sunset at arnd 8.30 and then twilight.

Wow, what sights. But treat this like a museum to get the full experience.. Of course the view is amazing. But there is so much more here. You can go to the Louvre and see the Mona Lisa in 5 minutes, of you can experience the Louvre. Same here. Invest some time and a few extra bucks and this becomes a memory for life and both the center and highlight of your NYC visit instead of just 5 minutes of amazing views.Tip 1: Buy tickets online and skip the lines. Many people spend more time in line than they do up in the observatory . Tips 2. As you head to the elevators take the time to read the stuff on the rocks etc... instead rushing to get there first. Just like the lines at a well done amusement park attraction there is a lot to enjoy here before the actual "ride" begins.Tip 3. Be ready for the "view" on the elevator going up. It is amazing. I won't spoil it but make sure you've put away the phone, the camera and if you have kids you have told them to be ready for the experience on the elevator. It's only 60 seconds so don't miss any of it being distracted by something.Tip 4: Don't rush to the windows once the beautiful arrival video is complete. That's what the crowds will do and you'll be fighting with them. Instead go to one of the other two floors and start you viewing there.Tip 5. Rent the explorer ipad for 15 dollars. When ever I go to a museum I always book a tour or rent headphones so I can understand the story behind what I'm seeing. Otherwise its just pictures and statues. Same here. Want to just see building and water or hear and see the story of NYC and its best sites including helicopter rides? If the answer is yes get the explorer. You'll be mesmerized for at least 1 hour, you'll get tips for the rest of your stay in NYC and just like the best museum guides and audio programs there is special attractions for younger children. It will even save a cloudy day with poorer views.Tip 6: Visit the observatory at the start of your stay in NYC as you'll get info and tips on other places in this amazing city (see tip 5).Tip 7: Don't miss the Portal which lets you look straight down to the ground through the floor!

I wish I had chosen Top of the Rock. "See forever"?! We bought our tickets in advance, before the attraction was even open yet, since we came from across the Atlantic and I was afraid there won't be any tickets left. Paid 150$ for a family of five. Our view: white. *Completely* white (clouds). Not a "bad" visibility, but *zero* visibility. I understand that whether is not a controllable issue, but taking people's money for zero return is quite impudent. They were selling tickets as usual as we came in, as if there was anything to pay for.The person in charge absolutely refused to let us come again with the same tickets another day, or even to allow for discounted new tickets.From the website of The Top of the Rock: "Guests will be advised about weather conditions and visibility prior to entry. Top of the Rock will not refund tickets in the case of inclement weather, however we will reissue your ticket for a future time and date." Now THAT's a way to treat customers!Other than the view, the elevator video is very nice and unique, but can also be freely watched on Youtube. Absolutely not worth 150$.

On a clear day, you can see forever. Book online for this spectacular new experience, but wait until the day before and check the weather reports. On a clear day, the view is mind-blowing. But at nearly 100 stories above ground, you're above the clouds - and if there is cloud cover, that may be all you see. With tickets for 9:45 am, we got right into the building, and there were just a few short periods of waiting inside. The elevator ride alone is worth the price of admission. I think the attraction is managed very well. It's not horribly crowded - you can get right up to the windows to take in the stunning views. There's now another great reason to come to New York City's rapidly transforming downtown area - and this is it.

Excellent experience. Spent the day in the Bronx for the Yankee stadium tour, and decided to take the ride down to the WTC for the observatory tour. While I didn't stop at the museum, I recommend you purchase your tickets in advance as you will get through and up to the observatory level quick. The line was very long for those looking to purchase tickets, while I was able to take the advance purchase line and walk right in. Kind of like when your online to board a plane and elite diamond passengers are able to bypass the line and board at anytime. It was a hazy day, but still had a good view. Typical for this time of the year, but If your looking for a clear crisp blue sky, than the fall and winter season might be your best bet. But all in all, you will enjoy no matter what you choose.

Beautiful view. It's definitely worth to go up and experience this 360 view of NYC, although my favorite remains the view from Top of the rock building. Make sure you buy your tickets online ahead of time to select the time of your visit. You can show tickets on smart phone.

Breadthtaking!. Glad to be here shortly after the opening day. Decided to get tickets online only in the morning on the day of visit itself, as weather the few days before was really bad, and surprisingly it wasn't difficult to get a time slot just pass noon. The line to buy tickets is pretty long if you didn't book online and I think it costs more than the $32 admission ticket to get in.The line waiting to get in was quite long and we were held back slightly passed our timeslot, but once you get pass the security you don't feel that crowded anymore.The walk through the tunnel before the elevator was quite unusual, and the ride up was even more of an experience with the elevator rocketing up to the 102th floor in mere seconds without feeling any air pressure! Everything moved so quickly including the digital imagery of the city skyline.As you walk around the main observation deck on the 100th floor, the views of Manhattan and the surounding neighbourhood are just under your feets. Particularly impressive was the view of the East River with the bridges over to Brooklyn, and the circular Sky Portal projecting the real time image of the street directly below.Looking north gives you a true sense of what really Manhattan looks like beyond the street map. It is a pity that Central Park is no where in sight with all the other buildings towering ahead.For the shutterbugs it is best to bring along a polarising lens to get a good shot through the thick glass panels.

Fantastic View. What a way to end a holiday in NYC! We were able to observe New York City from 102 floors up and we could see just how much we'd managed to explore, and just how much there was left for us to explore in the future. We were at the One World Observatory on opening day and all the staff were extremely excited to be there. (NB: If you follow the signs for the 'Observatory' through the 'P.A.T.H.' underground hub, you will be able to avoid all the queues outside. We did anyway! Whether or not everyone else has discovered this yet, I do not know!) They were being very strict on ticket times though and we had to wait at the side for 15 minutes before they would let us through. We also observed a lot of people had purchased 11PM tickets online instead of 11AM tickets and were being turned away. Perhaps the website should offer ticket times in 24hr clock to avoid confusion?After security the queuing does get a little bit boring especially going through the 'bedrock' of NYC. They could do with a couple of monitors in here showing was was on the screens just before we got to the 'bedrock' section as we were ushered through that part of the line quite quickly and didn't get a chance to watch the entire video.The observation deck is split over 3 floors, so don't waste your time trying to see the view when you first walk into the observatory. Go down the stairs/escalator and you will get the exact same view, but with a lot more space to view it! Enjoy!

Breathtaking views. Wonderful views from the observatory if you can get near the windows. We found that people flocked towards the windows...obviously, but then after taking in the views, they didn't move a side to give anyone else a chance they sit in the window ledges, not even looking out at the view, on their phones, chatting and no one else can get near.... This really annoyed me.

Missed the museum but..... We had the city pass..pay attention to the times you are permitted to use them for the 911 museum. We didn't make it in time and settled for the fountain memorials. Wish we could have used our tickets but only available from 2pm-6pm for the city pass holders. The fountains were amazing though.

On top of the world-Once Again. Today I visited the OWO which has opened very recently-on May 29, 2015.The immediate emotion was of elation at being able to take a 360d view of New York City and its surroundings once again.The fees for the visit ($32 for adult) are somewhat stiff but the view is fascinating and makes you want to return.No visit to OWO is complete without paying respects to all those who lost their lives in the terrorist attack.The Phoenix-like structure which has come up at the towers destroyed earlier in terrorist attack represents victory of good over bad.

Was there on opening day! What a view from the top. Wow that's all I can say, could not believe my luck at getting tickets to the opening day while I was in NYC on holiday. We also got invited to the ribbon cutting at 9am.This has been done with the utmost in taste as well as the latest in technology.Views are out of this world, we were lucky that opening day was blessed with blue skys and brilliant sunshine. Lifts are fast and smooth. I wont spoil the experience just to say its worth it. A view not seen in 14 years and full 360 degrees. Being in the first 100 people to the top is something I will treasure for the rest of my life and I will go back again as I could never tire of the view from the top.

Unbelievable view, but something definitely needs improvement. I know this place just opened not too long ago but they need to seriously figure out a better way to deal with the crowds and ticket times. We pre-purchased tickets online (your best bet) for a 2:15 appointment time. We showed up at the base of the tower about 20 minutes before our time slot and it was absolute pandemonium. No one had any idea where to go for their ticket times or what to do. There were a few employees standing at the stairs trying to direct people but it was chaos. There were lines of people everywhere that were just like us, had no idea where to stand or go. Some people were trying to buy tickets while standing in the already purchased ticket lines. They started calling appointment times over a mega phone and people were rushing and pushing.  My suggestion would be to have clearly marked signs everywhere informing people where they need to be and what time they should be there. It was a Sunday and probably more crowded that a weekday but something has to change especially when you have so many non-American speaking people that have no idea what is going on. For the amount of money that everyone is paying for tickets, I think there can be a way to have electronic signs at the head of these lines that update as the time slots occur. It would just make it so much easier for everyone. Other than that the elevator ride is fantastic and the views are second to none. You can take as much time as you want up in the observatory. There are bathrooms as well as a place to get something to eat/drink, and a gift shop. The price of the tickets are relatively on the higher side, but the views are tremendous and definitely worth it.

Incredible. This is a MUST see! We really knew we wanted to go but did not know the Observation deck was open. WOW is all you can say. If you are only going to do one thing in NYC...this should be the first on the list. They have not been open for long so the flow was a bit difficult, but I am sure that they will come up with processes to make moving people around a bit easier. It was a bit disjointed until you reached the first theater. The elevator experience was really cool. We took a ton of pictures and enjoyed the interactive part. There is a place to eat. I wish we'd been hungry. The price was reasonable.

Great Attraction. The views from the One World Observatory were amazing, it is also a well run and planned attraction. I do not want to spoil the suprise but prior to getting to the obseravatory floor the perfomance is great. We had great views of the city and then watched the drizzle come downtown through Manhattan. The city pulse interactive talks were very good and I learnt alot.We went at 9am and we did not have to queue at all. We paid for the one world explorer which were ipads with an interactive views with information about the landmarks, this was definetly worth the money especially as it was my first time in NY and our first full day there.I would definetley recommend visiting.

Amazing views. The building and views were breath taking! Really glad we have experienced the One World Observatory and you will not be disappointed but my advice is get up early to miss the queues for the best experience!

Cameras at the ready. If you can withstand the up, down and around about to get to the viewing area, it's well worth it. The lift experience on the way up is really good too. Highly recommend. But book a timed entry to save yourself time queuing.
What a view!. Started by visiting the impressive memorial, and then went up to the Observatory. The elevator is superb, and the view, even with cloudy weather, is awesome.

One World Observatory - Spectecular!. One World Observatory on the new World Trade Centre 1 New York is a must see to experience!! Only opened in Late May, the place get nearly 800 visitors an hour and the lines are long, but its worth the wait !!Not to spoilt the surprise... But the whole experience and the incredible views from the roof observatory is worth the entry fees. Bring your camera, camera phone and videocam... its a must-do when in NewYork.

Excellent, simply amazing. Beyond this world experience, from elevator to the theatre to the actual 360° view. It was terrific view from floor 100. Hats off to the makers of this observatory and piece of architecture. Very scenic view of the whole New York and Jersey city as well along Hudson river.

Great views. Typical of the type. 360 glass walls allow spectacular views of NY and surrounds. This is what you go for and it is magnificent.Caveats: 1. Book online if you can to avoid the long queues.2. The cafe is terrible. Rude staff. Horrible food and coffee. No seats. Messy. Maybe it is still teething problems as it had only been open a week, but the cafe really undermined the professionalism of the rest.3. You may get the impression that the sky portal is direct view of the ground but it is real time cameras. About as exciting as walking on your TV.

You can see forever. The view was amazing. The wait to get in was very disorganized. There were people standing in line everywhere and some people didn't even know what they were standing in line for. We had a scheduled time and they did stay close to that time, so once you figure out where you are going you will enjoy the amazing views.

Bucket List. We were fortunate to have visited the twin Towers before 9/11, and visit the site a couple years after 9/11. It was very moving to be able to visit the nearby 9/11 museum and the new one World Trade Center. The elevator ride up was nicely developed-- I won't say more. The curtained area was awkward but the top floor observatory was an amazing view. I would have liked to see some maps with the view explained and maybe that will come later. All in all it is not to be missed.

Get here. Do this. . A fantastic experience. Many of these reviews recommend buying your tickets online in advance. It's probably a good idea but I did not have an issue with buying the tickets here on location. I went on a weekday and there was no line at all. I don't know if that's always the case so you may be better off buying them online if you have access to a printer. The observation center experience itself is fantastic: an interssting entry way video experience, an amazing ride up in a digitally enhanced elevator, a fantastic observatory floor at the top. The dining leaves a little to be desired but that's not what I came for. Combining this with the 911 Memorial udt outside made for a fantastic couple hours of sightseeing

Stunning!!. Incredible from start to finish! I pre-booked tickets just in case the queues were long. It was the best option. We got our tickets scanned and we were on our way. There is quite a build up getting to the elevators etc but the trip up and the views themselves will have you saying 'WOW' quite a bit!

Reviewers need to get real!!!!. I am so fed up with reading reviews rating "terrible" because of the weather! get real people!how can you rate a business terrible because it was raining... some people just don't have a clue...Ok the weather was not perfect when we went but let me tell you, the view is amazing and the way they have made the visit a whole experience will blow you away! We should not give out too much on here as you need to surprised too! and at one part of the visit I had goosebumps!This is a must see, pick up the right day, we booked the night before so there was no need to plan this days and days before. We loved it and even had drinks at the bar, it is so well done, they do not deserve the criticism of some silly reviewers blaming them for the rain!

Spectacular views of NYC from One World Trade Center. Visiting the One World Observatory was a highlight of my recent trip to New York City. The building is magnificent. Seeing the bedrock the building is built on and walking through a tunnel of bedrock provides a great entrance to the elevators.Recommend buying your tickets on-line. There are two lines. One for buying tickets and the other for entering. Once we bought our on-line tickets, the line moved quickly and we were inside in no time.Recommend visiting the observatory and 911 museum and fountains the same day. All have been done extremely well done. Prepare to be touched.There are cafes at the top of the observatory including one with fast food like yogurt and fruit.If you have a choice between this or the Empire State Building - choose the One World Observatory. The Empire State Building has been over-commercialized and it will take you far more time due to the number of exhibits and you will be overwhelmed by solicitors trying to sell you tours.

Awesome, spectacular, do it!!!. This was $33 well spent. It was a fantastic experience - they have created a "wow" moment unlike anything I have experienced before. I won't spoil it for you by telling you what they do, but I will say prepare to have a major "wow" moment. A great visit, highly recommend it.

A "must do". First off, buy your tickets on line so that you won't have to wait in a LONG line to get in.It is a typical observatory with a great view. If you've seen these in other large cities, it is similar. It was very nice being able to see JUST EVERYTHING ...

A must in New York. Awesome, amazing what can I say, one of the best things I've ever done, fantastic views over the city, beautiful building and situated in a lovely area next to the 911 memorial fountains. Would definitely recommend, but please book your tickets well in advance online like I did as they only let so many people in each day 😀😀😀
Amazing. We were there the day after it opened. They do a great job of crowd control. Highly recommend getting tickets in advance on the web. The views are wonderful.

Couple days in NY. I was very excited to go to the top of the new World Trade Center Freedom Tower but it was a disappointment for the cost and they nickeled and dimed us the whole visit. They don't have their act together to move people there effectively while preserving the excitement. Getting there from the 9/11 memorial there were no signs to direct folks WITH timed tickets vs no ticket to completely separate entrances. Person there told people but signage would have been much more efficient vs that person saying it over and over. Ssecurity checkpoint was significant which I completely understand but security guy said I had a water bottle and emptied my whole bag only I had no water bottle. Time to go up then. They bring you in the elevator and it is truly fast like a rocket to the 100th floor. You first walk thru what looks like fake bedrock saying it's built on bedrock. Guess we then feel better that it won't fall down if something happens. At the top when elevator stops, You get your picture taken against a green screen that looks like NY skyline and given a ticket for a 20 photo at the end. (I think this was where but might be before elevators.) at top, You get herded into a long narrow theater where they show a disjointed short film about New York with loud music and lots of movement to build excitement. Then, they bring up the curtain to reveal floor to ceiling windows with a breathtaking view up toward midtown and the Empire State. Then they lower the wall within 20 seconds and ask you to move to the right and out of the area into curtained corridors over the windows cover the spectacular view which was frustrating since I came for the view. Then, you come through these curtained areas and they descend on you to sell you rental of an iPad to tell you what all the buildings are for another $15 after it was already $32 per ticket to go up. The guy said he would LET my sister and I share. I said no thanks. Then past another curtained area...where is the damn view??!? There was no good flow. Don't plan on eating or drinking anything. It was 10.85 for a 16oz diet coke and a hot dog. No posted pricing. There were also no seats outside the cafe area unless you went into the fine dining area. No areas for folks to sit even away from the windows. In the gift shop there were workers standing around and not processing purchases. It was ok but felt like I would have liked 30 rock or Empire State Building as much

Totally amazing!. We got tickets for the first public day! We had to wait outside for 1 hour or so, after that we went to the elevator or better said the spacepod! Wow the experience started already! The elevators are amazing! When you are at the 102 floor you will see a video of NY and then.. surprise! One word! Amazing! Don't miss this when you are in New York!!!!

World Trade Center Observatory. On a cool, clear afternoon in NYC, the view is spectacular. Visiting also sends a message that you can knock the U.S. Down. But not forever. Thirty-two dollars seems a bit high. I wondered about the price to summit the Empire Stare Building coupled with being in the outside air when paying the admission price.

Breathtaking . Saw this last weekend, absolutely beautiful! The elevator ride up showcased an amazing projected video and once on the observatory floor the view was unbelievable. It's truly inspiring and highly recommended!

Really worth the trip if you see just this!. Amazing structure, easy to get into. On 102 you can rent Ipads that show what buildings you are overlooking! You can see the world called NYC from here! No time limits, great gift shop. Food was good but slow but had been only ope 10 days so some adjustments still being made. Saw the well done tribute to the lost after leaving, a very original waterfall with names of the hundreds lost on that fateful day.

Rainy Day-SAVE your money!. We purchased tickets before we got to NY and it was a rainy night. No one mentioned that we wouldn't be able to see anything so they scanned our tickets only to see our reflections in the windows:( We asked for a manager so we could revisit on a clear day and she wasn't helpful so I would only recommend this on a beautiful clear day or not at all!

Make sure the weather is good. I booked in advance but made sure the forecast was good and went for a late afternoon slot so I knew the sun would be high in the sky to burn off the morning clouds. Avoid the late night slots as apart from looking at building lights you can't then make out the Statue of Liberty, memorial pools and other sights which aren't as illuminated.The views are good, it is a small shame you are inside the whole time and can't get out to take real photos. I previously visited the Twin Towers and Empire State Building so was glad to be one of the first to see the views here and especially glad I booked for the baking hot Saturday not the stormy Sunday (where with thunderstorms and clouds all you can see is a grey window).So check the forecast, take your camera and take your time. I was in there for about 2 hours, making use of the Free Wifi to FaceTime home and take lots of pictures.Souvenirs are outrageously expensive. Was about $20 just for a pack of cards. Food was expensive but considering the views not too bad.Staff are good and the video displays are gimmicky but quite interesting.Avoid the iPad extra - not worth it for extra $15 you can recognise yourself the major landmarks or just ask one of the many staff members in blue shirts.The lift (elevator) journey up is pretty cool. The lines once you're inside are OK, maybe 15 minutes tops.Still good views all over NY but whereas with the Empire State you can see Central Park, despite being so high up, you can't see it from here.
Simply amazing. we got here on opening day of the observatory, although the staff had no idea how to handle the crowd (long lines crazy delays in heat) the views are amazing and a must see

Dining at One Dine. Dinner at Dine One was very disappointing . It is nothing like Windows of the world. $75 plus 18% added to the Bill for service for 3 courses. It is stated to be fine dining , but it is far from that with plain wooden tables no table linen. I had dinner there on Sunday June 7 at 8.30pm. First of all ordered some glasses of wine and they had cork in them. This should have not been served to the table. One waiter took them away without as much as a comment, another then apologized and then finally after 10 minutes the new glasses of wine appeared. One of our guests was celeriac allergy and the courses had to be checked or returned due as not suitable after asking the server at time of order. We ordered the one special on offer as a starter and was later informed that only one available for the table so we had to re choose. On Deserts the offer was restrictive due to more of the limited menu not being available. Overall the food was good but not exceptional. I would say not worth the price and the staff who served us were not very professional in dealing with our complaints. In fact the Manager never came to our table to review our service. The other issue that bothered us was the first option on the menu is a larger steak and the meal price then goes up to $110 . Also no tap water available only bottled. The service charge was added. I got it removed due to the poor service. In fact the waiter gave me a stare I had never seen before when I informed him to withdraw the service charge. He told me he would get the manager but the manager never appeared. When I tried to explain why the service was not good enough he was not interested. Save your money and go to a nice restaurant.

view from the top. This visit was the highlight of my trip to NYC. Allow a few hours for this visit. It is not something to be rushed. The view is breathtaking! There are long lineups to get in and to an even longer line up to get on the elevator to get back down. The staff are efficient at keeping it organized. You can purchase food and drinks but at they are quite expensive. One negative I have to share is that we purchased food and took a seat at one of the tables only to be told by one of the staff to "eat our food quickly and leave" because we were sat on the side where drinks are served and seats for those eating are in the other area, where there aren't any tables but one long counter style seating that you can sit to.

Spectacular in every way. I won't spoil the surprises but safe to say that the experience is well worth the money. Super slick CGI and some amazing drama herald the entry into the observation floors themselves. Pre-book your tickets online, so simple and will save ages queueing. The bar is well worth a stop for a quick drink if you have time too!

Great views,meets more organization. Went this past weekend. Enjoyed the overall experience. Elevators are fast and obviously great views. They need more signage telling you where to line up. Signs at security telling you want to take off and what to leave on would be helpful. Sure over time this will improve, but stopped me from giving them 5 stars.

AWESOME EXPERIENCE!. Awesome experience. First of all I made a huge mistake when I purchase our tickets. The same day I purchase our tickets I forgot to choose our dates and noticed when we where ask for our tickets at the entrance of this attraction. Staff was so kind to direct me to the customer service desk so I could explain what had happen and I was given new tickets to enjoy the attraction no questions ask. That only is an A+ for me. This is a must see attraction if your in NYC at lease once in your life. Is an unforgettable experience and a breath tacking view.

The BEST in New York City. I am SO happy I was able to visit this while in NYC. It was literally the HIGH light of my trip. First, while at One World, visit the 911 Pools and grounds. They use to be only assessable with a ticket and were closed grounds, they are now easily assessable but still equally as moving. Second, visiting One World is VERY organized. I would also say purchase tickets online and PRINT THEM OUT. It makes it easy on everyone. (While you can arrive with the purchased tickets on your phone.. AGAIN... PRINT THEM OUT!)Everyone with tickets enters at a specified time. You should arrive no earlier than 15 min. prior... if you arrive earlier you will just be waiting longer. 15 min is enough. I have to give a few SHOUT OUTS to the following workers who REALLY made the line, and waiting, ORGANIZED and pleasant....Kyair, Luigy, Teurean and Tissuea... You all worked very hard and it was appreciated.Once inside the EXPERIENCE really does begin and surprisingly it was NOT crowded.I don't want to ruin it so.. once at the top it is AMAZING!!! 360 degree views.. SO much to look at. there are also restaurants at the top and to food was very pleasing. It was nice to get a snack while looking out on New York!We stayed at the top for about an hour and a half and it never got TOO crowded. Again.. not to ruin it... the Experience doesn't stop until you are back at street level.One World Observatory is A MUST if you are going to New York. Again.. Purchase tickets online before you arrive and print them out. You'll be glad you did. (P.S. I am not adding a photo because I don't want to ruin it )

Impressive. Very well constructed and organized. We had 10:45 am tickets for the Observatory and I looked at my watch when we were admitted into the elevator and it was 10:45 am. The ride up 102 stories takes 60 seconds and you see a movie from when the area was first developed until current as well as where you are on the way up. It was a hazy day for us, but we could see down just not out. Since it was raining we decided to have lunch at the One Restaurant. I'm glad we did, the waitress was so friendly and the food was good. Not a big menu but just enough. If the weather was good, the view would have been tremendous.

Great Views. The observatory had only been open a week when we visited. The elevator ride is very, very fast as you rocket to the top. The views are magnificent. The restaurants were still working out the details as there was confusion and interesting processes for waiting, even when they just opened. If you come in from the subway, you end up in the middle of the ticket line. It was difficult to find the beginning of the line at the top of the escalator and also outside the building. I'm sure they will work out the bugs with a little more time. Overall, a nice experience.

WTC opens in "beta" mode but worth the price of admission. It is with the utmost respect for the tragedy of 9/11 that I write this review. As the WTC Building One World Observatory just opened please keep in mind the program is still in the process of testing, experimenting, failing and debugging.First, a few recommendations for visitors: buy your tickets in advance as the entries are time and date stamped, go early or late as the lines are longest mid-day, take the bus or subway as there is no parking, bring binoculars.Now, a few needed improvements on the visitor's experience:1) Add signs at ground level as the line for the box office is different from advance tickets, that's an easy one2) The restrooms are deep within the ground floor and not near the entrance so visitors must seek them out with some difficulty, not fun3) Please give out Floor Plan maps of the 3 observatory levels, real easy one4) Why is there no WiFi in the building?5) Why can't visitor's purchase a DVD of any or all the video exhibits (especially when they can't see anything due to bad weather), so easy.6) Pushing the iPad tour for the extra $$ is just obnoxious7) Please have price tags on all Gift Shop items8) I know the reason there is no seating in 2 of the 3 dining areas, it is to push people to use the very pricey restaurant that has the only seating. But how about just benches around the circumference of the dining level?

Amazing!!!. Get tix early! Many people want to get the chance to see this amazing site. The elevator ride up was so fast that my ears popped! The elevator ride up is so incredible... It's a timeline. Hard to explain. You can see for miles and miles once you are up to the observatory, where there is a bar and restaurant as well! This was a once in a lifetime experience that is a must do!

Phenomenal views, but observation deck is poorly designed. We went to the One World Tower observation deck on Sunday, June 7th at 9:00 AM. The good: the elevator trips up and down is very entertaining; the views at the top are indescribable---you actually look DOWN on the Empire State Building. The bad: the design of the observation deck leaves a lot to be desired. First, they "make" you stand in line for a fake picture, hoping you will buy it later. Then, you have to go downstairs to find the actual viewing areas. It's very confusing. Finally, the prices in the souvenir shop are ridiculous ($35 for a tee shirt). Overall, it's well worth the trip to the top for the views, but the logistics of the observation deck could use a bit of tweeking.

Disappointing. This attraction could have been so much better!! The arrival, lift and theatre experience were all amazing. Innovative thinking has gone into the start of this experience. Unfortunately actually being able to see any of the view is impossible because there are ledges all around the floor which enables people to sit and stay. I appreciate this isn't the fault of the venue but something needs to be done about people just sitting and not allowing anyone else to enjoy the experience. Also the bar area / restaurant is very confusing and again badly laid out (and somewhat cheap looking) You shouldn't have a bar completely covered in with bar stalls as no one else can actually get to the bar.

Fabulous. This is a "MUST" see. What a fabulous job they did, and the stories told inside from the workers were heartwarming. I would advise that you buy your tickets on-line, otherwise you might have a long wait. I bought my tickets on-line for 10am on a Monday, and went right thru. The staff is is fantastic and the views are indescribable. Elevator takes you to the 102nd floor is about 42 seconds. I just cant say enough about this.

AMAZING. TOP TIP!!! Book tickets online in advance or you will have to queue for tickets and a time, which means you will have to come back to queue again! It is $32 for a basic Adult admittance or $26 for a child but it is truly worth it!

Worth the Price...Period.. You know you get what you pay for...right? And this is one pricey admission. But what a journey! From the minute you step on the elevator and are surrounded by high definition monitors that show the history of the city as you are swooshed into the sky this is the city adventure in this urban jungle. Take in the skyline at sunset from the bar and you have experienced the city as few have. First-class in every way.

Highest Spot in Manhattan. This observation experience allows one to see the skyline of Manhattan looking north, and to view the waters around the Statue of Liberty and surrounding areas. This is the highest place in Manhattan, higher than the Empire State Building. The experience starts with being shot up some 1200 feet in less than 60 seconds in an interior elevator, whose walls have a multimedia display of what you would be seeing if the elevator was on the outside of the building. The observation area itself is quite large and circular. However there are no chairs or seating areas, so many people camp out on the low ledges next to the windows, making photography a challenge. The Empire State building's 86th Floor observation deck has an exterior walkway open to the elements, unlike this one.  There is an area where there is a café and bar with limited seating arrangements, and a pricey sit-down restaurant called "One".  This attraction just opened on May 29, 2015 so ticket reservations are a must. One can do the following in one day with some prior planning and reservations: Staten Island Ferry, Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island, 9/11 Memorial and Museum, One World Observatory - it makes for a full day, however.

A must see with Breathtaking views of NYC. We visited June 7th on a Saturday afternoon. I had checked the weather to make sure it would be sunny before ordering tickets online the day before. Ticket prices are Adult $32, Senior $30, Child $26. Through Sept 7th open from 9 am to midnight 7 days a week. Tickets said to meet outside at the Intersection of Vesey and West St. 15 minutes prior to your timed ticket. We waited 1/2 hour outside until we got into the building. The only thing I wondered about is what do they do when the weather is lousy. You enter the building and go down the escalator to the Global Welcome Center where the check your ticket and you go through security. Next you go through the fake bedrock that the building sits on and hear the " voices" & video of the people that built 1 World Trade Center. Then you go into the Skypod elevator with images of the bedrock that takes you to the 102nd floor in 60 seconds.My ears popped a few times. I couldn't believe how fast and smooth the ride was. The elevator and floor to ceiling images of NYC from the 1500's to today was cool. When you get off you are ushered into the "See forever theater" that has random images of the streets of NYC. I thought this a waste of time, but thoroughly enjoyed the surprise that was next. The wall lifts and you see a spectacular, short, real view of NYC.Then you can go to the Main Observatory on the 100th floor with panoramic views of the city and beyond. Getting pictures of ourselves was tricky. Lots of times we were in shadow. Later on the sun shone in on us and we were able to get some nice pictures of people and the skyline of NYC. It was a beautiful clear day so we could see the Statue of Liberty and all of NYC and even the mountains beyond.The SKY PORTAL you can step on and it gives you a real time view of the street below. We decided to eat at the One Mix restaurant on top because you where able to sit down. The One Café just had tables with no chairs. the food was good and the view spectacular.There is a gift shop as you exit to the elevators down. On the way down you get a view of NYC at night probably shot in an helicopter.We spent a couple hours in the observatory. The crowds weren't too bad. Overall a great experience if visiting NYC.

Great experience. Line up outside was total chaos. We were told to queue up in one place then someone else decided the queue should be somewhere else. Teething problems. Once inside everything was much smoother. Staff all obviously very proud of the attraction. The introduction and elevator ride very impressive.View from the top absolutely breathtaking.A must do New York experience.

Absolutely mind-blowing. We ordered tickets online for a timed entrance. The whole experience was efficiently organised, and wonderfully interesting and moving.The elevators are just amazing and are the fastest in the world, incorporating the most fantastic technology.Once at the top, the views will delight and amaze. It is an experience I will never forget, and also is very good value indeed. Go experience this for yourselves!

Still Working out the Kinks. The start up was probably the best part, a 60 second elevator ride up 102 stories with a great video history of Manhattan on 3 sides of the elevator, and no sense of how FAST you were going up. The views once you get to the viewing areas are very impressive, but the whole layout is still being refined and seems awkward. After buying tickets at ground level you go down escalators through metal detectors and security and then walk through a long fake rock underground area (the rocks are fiberglass) and this will probably be a long waiting area during the high season.Getting off the elevators you are crowded into a wide area and shown a video which seems to just be a time waster, until it ends and the backdrop opens to reveal the view. Then everyone is bustled out one end and past the first add-on booth where they try to rent you an iPad with info on it. The whole layout is not well defined and it seems like you have to go down and up several times before you are "allowed" to actually get some good views.In another area they lead you in front of a green screen and take photos, sort of like when you board a cruise ship. The photos will be available for sale later.There is a fake glass floor area which is really just a video feed. Nothing like the real glass floors in other towers like the CN in Toronto.We went to the sit down restaurant area and it only has two food options: a cheese plate and a salami plate. We ordered one of each and waited a long time for them to arrive. The staff was so apologetic that they gave use another round of drinks for free. Bottom line - they are still working out start-up issues in regards to crowd flow and service. I am sure this tourist site will be immensely popular and there will be long lines very soon. The views out of the windows are impressive, the layout and service inside are not.
