Awe inspiring!. After visiting the 9/11 Museum and Memorial which were rightly difficult and heavy, the One World Observatory renews your hope in the American spirit and the beauty in the world. There were people from all over the world visiting and we were struck by how happy and inspired everyone seemed. The view is absolutely amazing and the general admission line moves very quickly. We had 9am reservation and were at the top just a few minutes later. It is a must do!

Incredible view of NYC. Loved the Observatory from the trip up to the top. The 60 second elevator ride is FAST and with the monitors on the inside of the elevator with the history of NYC is impressionable. The first intro with a kind of movie about NY is boring but after all it is all about the view from the top! We had an amazing view from the top and definitly worth taking the trip!
Amazing. Best place to visit not only do you get the best 360d view there is such a touching amount of love for this building

The most frustrating experience. I bought tickets for the One World Observatory when they first came up on sale, weeks before the day the observatory opened. I got the tickets for June 1st, and you had to pick a time to visit -- I picked 7 pm. On June 1st the forecast called for heavy rain and fog. I called customer service to see if I could exchange the tickets for another day, but nobody picked up the guest services phone, and the voice mailbox was full. We went to the venue and asked about changing the date when we got there. They told us they were not responsible for the weather, as they claimed in their website. I understand that, but there has to be an exception when they cannot offer the service that their website states --best views of Manhattan. I can understand limited visibility, but when we were up on floor 102, all you could see was a white window. You couldn't even feel that you were high up. Nothing. It was like staring at a blank wall.They offered an iPad with the "explorer experience", that would give you information about the buildings and places you could see from the observatory (if there wasn't fog!), but you had to pay an extra $15. Since we couldn't see anything, it would have been good customer service to rent it for free to the handful of unlucky visitors of that foggy day. But they didn't.When we came down I went to the Guest Services window and asked to speak to the manager, she was not even nice about it, and just said "tickets are non-refundable, not exchangeable", and that It said so on their website. I said that their website also said that we'd have the best views of the city, and that a day like that, with 0 visibility, should be an exception. She offered no solution at all. They just got our $32/per ticket money --for nothing. I felt cheated.My advice --Don't buy tickets in advance unless you know there's going to be nice weather!

Amazing Experience. We were very lucky to go to get tickets on the Opening Day and we saw the opening ceremony.This is by far the most amazing view I have ever seen - I could have spent hours just looking out.The only downside was that some of the large blinds were pulled down, obscuring the view in places - when I asked the staff if the blinds were down permanently - they said they were.A lovely coffee shop/café is in the building too, which we visited.There were not too many places to just sit and watch the world go by though as the coffee shop just had standing places - if you wanted alcohol or a larger meal there were seats available for you to sit and have your meal.We also found that the staff (very pleasantly) encouraged you to go to the next floor etc to look out. I presume this was so that each floor didn't become over crowded and they could control the flow of people. Anyone going to New York - this attraction is a must - I totally loved it

The Lift. The lift was the best bit. 40s from ground to floor 102. A video of NYC growing/building up over the year, really good. The observation deck is enclosed so taking photos can be a nightmare with the glare from the windows.
One more observatory.... The led lift was really fast, I was hopping to be amazed by that, just tvs all around the lift. The view is spectacular, but NY is spectacular, so...

Brand New And Open. Hubby wanted to visit here during our New York stay this past weekend. The tickets are $32 at the cheapest and go up from there. I debated heavily whether to pay that to see yet another tower but was chatting with a group of Canadian tourists the night before who had been in NYC all week, and they told me that it was well worth a visit. Remember Canada has the CN Tower (separate review) which we saw several years ago and really enjoyed, but according to the Canadian fellow, One World was taller and better. We got in line the next day for our turn. I have to say that the process for getting into the line to enter the building is a mess and needs badly to be improved. There is no signage telling you where to go if you don't already have a ticket (and I recommend getting tickets ahead of time online) and when you do get to the proper line, people that have paid for "premium access" are still going to get in ahead of you. However, we did get inside within 5 minutes of our 2:30 time and the flow seems pretty good once you are inside. You walk past and around some of the exposed bedrock foundation which states that this is the strongest built building in the world. It is striking to look at, I have to say, inside and out. After watching a short presentation, they raise the window panels and give you a glimpse of the view. Then you go to another line to wait for an elevator. These are a bank of 5 high speed lifts that get groups up to the 102nd floor in about a minute. Covering the windows, for some reason, are floor to ceiling drapes which completely obscure the views that you're there to see unless you move the drapes. If you walk two floors below, you get the full and unobstructed views. That is worth $32 to me, but no more. Of course, there are the overprices gift shops, way overpriced restaurant and bar, and verbal presentations selling different NYC tourist experiences. I guess the theory is that the longer you stay, the more you'll spend. I myself am not turned on by a $5 bottle of water or muffin or a $10 bottle of beer. Plenty of people were partaking though. There are stands outside too that offer rubber bracelets ($5 donation) or a color photo book ($21.75.) If you go, bring lots of money, as I have said about some other cities we've been to. This was great for someone who hasn't been to NYC yet or loves high towers.

Amazing Views. we went on the day it opened and it was chaos - the ribbon cutting ceremony overran, there was loads of press and lines and lines waiting to get in. We had 10pm tickets by mistake and the lady int he box office kindly changed them for 2.15pm on the same day so we headed off to Century 21 for some retail therapy and some lunch before heading back. I'd guess that we queued until 4 before we got in - You get to security, get your bag scanned etc - just like at the airport - then there is a wall of TV screens of construction guys - this takes around half an hour. You are then filtered single file through a bedrock exhibition which takes another 20 mins or so of shuffling. Then you get to another line which is for the lifts. Once up there there is yet another short presentation before the skyline is dramatically revealed to you - its all nicely done if a little long winded. Amazing views of the city, you can see right up to the park and beyond, lady liberty in the distance, jersey city, brooklyn and queens and the brooklyn bridge - really worth the wait!!

Great view of the whole city. If you never been to an obervatory before, this is one of a kind experience, specially when its just opened a week ago, the building just dwarfs every other around. If you are lucky to get good weather, the views can be great.They have a very good visual presentation before they take you to the main area which is very good.The skycar as they call the elevator is a great multimedia experience as the car goes up and down.. Its an experience to check out if you are visiting the city.TIP - book the ticket on the same day you want to vist and do it online to avoid queue, **CHECK THE WEATHER** there are no refunds ..yet..try to get in by 8 PM to get the best view of evening and night ( june - july)

Fantastic View. The system works good for timing people so you dont have a long wait. The initial presentation shows you and amazing view before being released to the observation desk. There you get a 360 degree view of everything. The cost was $116 for 2 adults and 2 children, under 6 are free. The cost is cheaper than the empire state building. We spent 2 hours looking out the window and it was amazing.

Amazingly slick and breathtaking!. If you can, don't read any spoilers. just go up there and enjoy. It's a great experience!!Before you even go up the videos, screens, and mock bedrock make the queue more than bearable. The lift is part of the show, and it just gets better when you get up there.Only bad point is the shop, ridiculously expensive and lacking anything genuinely nice as a memento.

amazing views worth a visit. Visited yesterday, the day started out rainy but cleared up nicely by the time of my 1:30 pm ticket time, I only reserved my ticket the day before online, (to my surprise there was availability) and I paid attention to the weather report. If you reserve ahead of time and the weather's bad, you're going to be disappointed and complain, so doing it the way I did made a lot of sense. Yes, there were crowds, and lots of long lines for different times, staff were nearby trying to explain things but it did seem a bit noisy and disorganized outside on the sidewalk. Getting off the PATH train across the street made for a bit of an adventure, a few exits were blocked, and crosswalks were closed due to ongoing construction, so it seemed going up, down and all around was necessary. Perhaps in the rush to open the observatory, convenience in getting out of the PATH station and to the site was overlooked. Anyway, the elevator ride up was pretty amazing, viewing the history of Manhattan on the way up, from the 1500s to the present. I was thinking it would have been really amazing if the elevators had actual windows with real views of the outside, but this was the next best thing. The short film right after you get off the elevator was nothing much, and a bit of a waste of time, but at the end the wall rises, and the real view appears, and it's spectacular. Read a lot of nitpicking complaints here, but you get off the elevator on the 102nd floor. Really, how many times in one's lifetime can you say you've done that? The clear views all around are just amazing. There are no seats, but I didn't come here to sit. Yes, it's crowded but it's to be expected. The price is a bit on the high side, but it's New York City, and it's quite an experience.

Moving Experience. We had not intended to visit this site, but our friends in NY wanted to go so we accompanied them - and we were so pleased we did. The views are spectacular, the presentation and whole experience was excellent - won't give away any surprises though! It is definitely a top tourist attraction.

Not what we expected. Pro'slift to the top is visually stunning.Good views of the city but depends on weather.ConsGlass flooring was a bit of a con as it was just glass over a pre recorded video scene. Very poor for taking photographs at night due to reflections on glass as there is no outdoor viewing area. Very pricey for alcoholic drinks (£10 for a glass of wine) . We had some issues regarding seating in bar and café area. We ordered our glasses of wine at the bar, so obviously we sat at one of the smaller tables in the bar area to drink our wine. However this was an issue to one of the members of staff who stated we weren't allowed to sit there Because we didn't order any food (yet others were sitting with just drinks but nothing was said to them). So we got up and moved to the cafe areas seats which was next to bar area, and again this was another issue for another member of staff, who insisted we couldn't sit there unless our alcohol was in a plastic cup. BE AWARE of some staff being a bit of a jobsworth and this ruined our overall experience. Put it this way, there are better places in new york to see the city skyline

Great views. We got there early enough to beat the lines, and glad we didn't have to wait too long. The elevator ride up is amazingly quick. Led screens showing history of wtc. 48 seconds to get up 101 floors. Great sights, yet little disappointed it was cloudy and rainy. But worth it.

Wheelchair accessibility at One World Observatory. I was in New York City for a disability awareness campaign and learned that the observatory was opening on May 29. I made a point to visit on its second day of operation, Saturday, May 30. Wheelchair access was pretty good, though access to some of the elevators was behind closed doors. The dining area was also very crowded - tables too close together, etc. Hopefully that level, 101, will become more accessible as the crowds lessen. I took some video and wrote a review of the experience, which is posted at http://wheelchairtravel.org/review-wheelchair-access-at-one-world-trade-center-observatory/There were a couple others in wheelchairs at the observatory as well.

Unrivalled view. Going to the one world observatory needs to be done on a clear day! The organisation of the queues is slick and the lift up to the top shows graphics of the history of this part of Manhattan island. At the top, there is a short film presentation and then a 'reveal' to show part of the view. You are then shepherded onto the observation floors. There are restrooms, a cafe and a souvenir shop too. It's not cheap to visit but well worth the money and you can visit the 9/11 memorial too which is stunning in its simplicity and absolutely beautiful.
cool new attraction. Really well done attraction. Having gone up the empire state building this place tries to make it more than just an observatory

well worth the wait and admission. the newly opened observatory is located at the 100-102 floor of the new one world trade center.the 360 view is more then amazing, it costs $42 but worth every penny! and the whole experience is very well orchestrated, however, i do recommend getting tickets online, to avoid waiting 1.5 hours (which we did)

WTC Observatory. I feel like there should be a seating area because a lot ot people sat along the windows just sitting and not allowing other people to take photos and observe the sights. Some people even had their backs to the city view which is very rude. If you are done observing and taking pictures, you should get up to allow others the opportunity. Other than that, the observatory is a very nice place for all ages.

Beautiful View, a tad "Disney-fied". Had the opportunity to visit One World Observatory. The view is spectacular... were it not for the memorial pools and the museum, I don't think the view was any better than would be seen at the Empire State Building or over at Rockefeller. It's a tall view. Meh. So, yes, spectacular view. What disappointed me was how "Disney-fied" it all seemed to be... from the lines that you "think" are ending, only to turn a corner and find you are in a new area of yet more lines (and we prebooked and prepaid.) Apparently the presentation in the elevator is excellent, however if you are right up against the wall and are short statured, like me, you won't see much of it. Yes, the view at the top is lovely, we're talking NEW YORK HERE... OF COURSE it's spectacular. Be prepared for them to want you to open your wallet even more once you are at the top... souvenirs, a bar, a restaurant, photos like on a cruise ship, renting ipads for tours, etc. They have found lots and lots of reasons to try to get you to spend more money. I know that's what makes the world go round... but after the unspeakable tragedy happened there, it just feels like they turned an opportunity to be a little bit better into another way to make big bucks, and instead of presenting a dignified place to see New York, they let Disney handle it. I half expected a costume character called "One World-Y" to wander around waving for photo ops with little kids. That said, the view is incredible. Will I go up again? Nope. Will I visit the memorial pools and the museum? Yes I absolutely will.

On top of the world. I was fortunate enough to be one of the first visitors to have visited viewing deck on opening day of 29 May 2015. Initially the lines were long, but soon this was resolved, as there were some formalities that had taken place. An EXPERIANCE has to be the elevator to 105th floor (fastest in the world) in less than 60 seconds. Whilst in the elevator, you do not see the outside , but instead , the surrounding glass in the elevator has an impression of height and this is surreal. Once you arrive on 105th floor, you step out of the elevator and enter a dark theatre where you watch a video of the building whilst being constructed. The screen on which the video was played, then lifts and daylight enters, with the most magnificent view of NYC,Manhattan, Statue of Liberty, Hudson River, an array of bridges. This panoramic view of New York, reminds me of Alicia Keys's song New York ( where dreams are made of and can inspire you) this resonates well with me as it made me feel on top of the world . This is a worth while visit and has to be on list of things to do when in NYC

Fantastic experience !. Do not miss this place ! For those who have visited the old World Trade Center, it will be an unforgettable experience ! Everything worked accordingly. One recommendation: buy the tickets in advance.

Pricey and plastic!. One World Trade Center Observatory is an amazing place. On a clear day you are guaranteed a great view - but because you must book far in advance and choose a specific timed entry... you are at the mercy of the weather and you can't change the time of your ticket (unless you can afford the expensive tickets that let you enter at any time and skip the lines). But for $32 a single ticket entry is expensive for what you get.The first thing I noticed before going down into the security area was the cheap faux plastic marble on the walls. Just tap it with your fingers and you can see it's very cheap finishings. Passing security there is a neat waiting area where you can dress yourself again (put on your belts, etc.) as it's airport style security. They have a neat board that when they scan your ticket it knows where you came from and it says "guests now arriving from..." and where you are from appears on the screen.Your are first hurdled through a fake exhibit of bedrock. It's cheap plastic again and I was a little disappointed by it. It felt too much like a disney land line. Just tap the walls and you'll know it's fake. They could have splurged for nicer. Then you get to wait in the area where the elevators are. We were there on a miserably rainy day so it wasn't very crowded. A lot of people opted to skip their entry tickets. Then we went up the elevator which was fun and they put you in a holding area where they show a 3 minute video that ends by the screen lifting up and revealing your view - which for us was a wall of white clouds. Couldn't see anything.For $32 I'm glad I went but I thought it was too pricey. The finishings in the place weren't as nice as I'd have expected. Plastic? Really? But I am still glad I went. This continues my tradition of going up to the WTC (the old building and now the new) and only seeing a wall of white. Haha!Once you make it up to the top, you only need 30 minutes or so there. The long wait you'll have is through security and in line for the elevators and in line for the movie they hurdle you through. Your timed entry ticket cannot get you past those lines... it only lets you in the building itself at that time.

Too crowded. The best part of the trip was the presentation in the elevator showing the development of Manhattan Island over the centuries. It went by too quickly and can't be repeated. The views of course are amazing, and if you are 6 feet 6 inches tall, you can see over the throngs of people pressed 3 or 4 deep at the windows, otherwise, you fight and wait for each sliver of view. overprices1 Over crowded! and yes, as Limehouse Traveller wrote, "too Disneyfied"!

Breathtaking. . Not much to say...BeautifulBreathtakingStunningTotally worth the ticket price. The views are amazing and the building has a wonderful calmness. Visited the day the observatory opened and was impressed with how organised it was. DO NOT MISS THIS

Great views, long queues, too Disneyfied. They have to compete with The Empire State Building and The Top of The Rock so it's not surprising they've turned this into 'an experience' rather than just an elevator ride to look at a great view. We were there on a baking hot day and there was no shade for the first part of the queue, outside the building. Once inside the air conditioning was a welcome relief. You go down before you go up, supposedly into the bedrock below the building but it's clearly fake - that's the Disney bit. The elevator ride up is superb - watch out for the brief appearance from the twin towers. The presentation once you come out of the elevator is pointless - we couldn't hear most of what was said and the video is just random New York street scenes. Once you finally, finally get to the viewing level it's a great 360 experience although taking photos through the windows can be tricky due to all the smears and fingerprints on the glass and the reflections if you don't have your camera right up against the glass.

Incredible!!!. This is an absolute must do in New York City! I strongly suggest buying your tickets online in advance. The site receives massive amounts of visitors, but the site staff have a wonderful system of processing everyone in and through security screening in a surprisingly short amount of time. Once at the top, the view is nothing short of spectacular. For the same price as the Empire State Building Observatory and Top of the Rock, this is a way better view for the money. It is truly a 360 degree view that seems to stretch forever. And just outside the World Trade Center are the 9-11 Memorials. They no longer require advance tickets or lines or screening to enter, and they are a very beautiful and somber tribute to the lives lost on 9-11.

great views. Over crowded. The place is really all about the views. The problem is, they let so many people up there, they are standing 4 or 5 deep at the windows and it is really difficult to truly enjoy the setting. Kind of pricey for what the experience. Apparently the security people were hired from the least employable. We were delayed 15 minutes until they finally searched my wife's purse. Seems they thought her sunglasses looked like a knife. Warning women: don't carry glasses in your purse while going through security, Ha!

Spectacular . We visited the third day it was open. Everything is so new and clean and the staff so enthusiastic its a breath of fresh air. There was a lightening storm the evening we visited and we only had visibility for a short time but it was still worth it. The moment the curtain is lifted is absolutely breathtaking. This is one place I would revisit in New York City. Booking tickets online worked well for us didn't queue at all.

HUGE disappointment. After over 15 years I thought I was lucky to go back to the "new" World Trade Center in New York.I got the tickets online and schedule to visit on Monday June 1st at 8 pm.When I got on top there was ZERO visibility and despite that the staff still charged 15 dollars for an ipad simulating the view. No refund/reschedule policy on this so good luck if you get bad weather.On top of that the new building seems finished in a rush thus basically incomplete. The wind shakes him and if you are afraid of earthquake like movements just don't go.The whole area around is very much work in progress ...

Wonderful, Rewarding Experience. How can you not be completely awed and renewed by this experience??? It makes you so proud to be an American and is such a tribute to the real spirit of Americans. The building itself is beautiful. The layout of the observatory is very well done from the entrance to the observatory deck. I must also give complete compliments to the staff. Everyone was smiling and helpful and energetic. They made it all a great experience. Obviously the view is spectacular. We "rented" the iPad for $15 which give you the opportunity to walk around and identify all the sites you are looking at so it was definitely well worth it. There is no time limit on your visit but there are no seats available in the observation floor so it may be a challenge for anyone who have a hard time standing for a longer period of time. Definitely buy your tickets on line before you go so you can walk right in. The line to buy tickets was very long and a waste of time.

good but not for photographers after sunset. i had high hopes for this observatory and was very excited when i saw that it had opened to coincide with my visit to NY. Some of the architectural elements at the bottom are really amazing (near the exits) . The presentation and videos about 9/11 are very moving and help to set a mood while you wait to go to the top. Once you're there an elevator whisks you up. The video that plays while you're ascending was a bit cheezy but kids will be sure to love it. As a photographer i wanted to get great photos of the area like Top of the Rock and ESB. Unfortunately there's just way too much light that is reflected off the glass windows. If several people are standing behind you waiting to take your spot then that's a workaround. there were also some corners where you can sit your camera down flat and take some decent pics that way but not many that had little light. Otherwise the views are superb. An open air terrace would have been great. I arrived just before a storm moved in and the place quickly emptied once all you could see were clouds. I would return but this time before sunset.

Views and experience worth every penny. Make sure to get your ticket online ahead of time, and arrive 10 minutes ahead of your chosen time.Getting inside was not much of a wait, the people working there were organized and pleasant.Once you are passed security don't waist your time on the exhibit downstairs, just get to the elevators fast. Have your camera ready for the elevator, is quite an amazing ride.For the 3 minute show upstairs, wait for the very last minute to record, you'll get a very pleasant surprise.Enjoy the amazing views.Don't buy anything, it's all overpriced. You can get all the same tourist crap in Chinatown, and much better and cheaper food anywhere else.Again, enjoy the views.

It is worth $32?. I don't like to waste money nor do I like to be taken for a ride, but the admission ticket to the new Observatory is well worth it. Hard to put a $$$ value on the sensational view of New York City from the 100th floor of 1WTC. The truth of the matter is that you could spend hours on the Observatory. Those of us who were fortunate enough to have been on top of the Twin Towers will be surprised: this is a totally different experience. The view is a lot better now, perhaps due to new technology that allows for extraordinary windows on the entire city. And what about the elevator? I know, I know. Many stories have been written about the 47-second movie of New York evolving over the course of 500 years. But I have to admit: it is pretty extraordinary. I love the concept and the final product. You ride up the elevator an on three of the four walls you see projected images of the evolving landscape on downtown Manhattan. I must admit: I was fortunate enough to ride the elvator with only two other people, therefore I enjoyed the full experience. Not sure what it is like in a crowded elevator where perhaps it is difficult to fully appreciate the experience.

Poor customer service and all about making money..... We went on the first Monday of opening after buying tickets the month before.It was a terrible day weather wise when we arrived but I assumed that there would still be a view, possibly above the clouds which would have still made it worthwhile. As there was no warning or signs and people were still coming down, this further reinforced it would still be worthwhile.The lift up was he highlight, showing New York develop over the years but it was over far too quickly. The big ' reveal' is a good idea and could be ok on a nice day, but nothing special. What we got was just white, you could not see anything and it looked like someone had painted the windows white. I don't see how they can't warn you beforehand and feel this is a total rip off. I would have been even more concerned if I had bought the ticket that day which hundreds of people were being allowed to do with no warning at all.Inside there isn't that much to do. A restaurant, a shop and a couple of presentations that were ok and again nothing special.I had seen advertised before I went a glass floor you could walk over that gave the impression you are actually walking above the city. As it was raining outside you could clearly see this was just a recording of the city below. Another disappointment.When I got back to the bottom I asked if we could be refunded or if we could come back the following day if the weather was ok. The women just looked at me and said no and then looked away. I found her very rude.A very poor experience and I don't think this will offer anything better than the Empire State or Top of the Rock. At least you aren't stuck behind windows there.

Quite impressive but not the best view in town. This is a place to see, the whole experience is nice (particularly what they show you as the elevator climbs to the 102th floor!). We were there the first day it opened, at the inauguration. There appears to be little organization for the queue, though it's worth getting to the top floor (worth the 32 dollars it costs). Not very good for pictures, due to the glare coming back from the glass.

A fantastic experience. We visited on 29th May, the opening of the observatory. It was excellently portrayed although I really thought that the President himself might have opened it due to the history behind it. However, the Broadway Youth put on a brilliant performance. Security was paramount but organisation was somewhat lacking. All in all, a most memorable occasion with the tour itself being excellently done. It probably requires a second visit to take in parts that were missed but it was well worth $32, although nothing will equal the feeling when the "curtain goes up".

This is an unbelievable experience. This is definitely the best experience in NYC. They opened it this last weekend and it is an over the top experience. You start with a timed ticket that they were just on time. The elevator to the top was such a very cool experience. The view from the top was spectacular.

Wonderful experience!!!. I had the opportunity to book a ticket online for ONE WORLD OBSERVATORY-SEE FOREVER in the first days after its grand opening to the public! Unfortunately, the weather in New York was terrible on June 1st: rainy, foggy... Half of the tower was in ...the clouds! my ticket was already paid so no choice to go up. And the experience was still amazing! 1200 feet in 60 seconds in an elevator offering a panoramic view of New York through the years (and the descent is even more spectacular). The roof deck is just beautiful, the staff was very nice and joking about the "no" view. I got very emotional at some point when I remembered the horror of the 9/11 I witnessed from my apartment in Paris where I grew up. Being at the top of this beautiful tower meant a lot to me. FREEDOM is priceless.A beautiful experience I highly recommend... Better on a clear and sunny day! lol

Beautiful views and spanking new building - must see on a clear day!. The building is finally up and open. Went the weekend before it was open to the public. ALL staff were super nice and friendly. Hopefully they stay that way!Try to go on a clear day as you can see for miles. We spent about an hour there with a tween and a pre-tween. 3 floors of observatory, didn't feel too crowded but then again it was not open to the public fully then. Elevator ride was fun, and they show a quick video before letting you into the observatory decks. Bring binoculars!

A bit disappointing. We booked this tour and were able to go up the second day it was open. As expected, the views are awesome, and the visuals on the elevator ride up are amazing. They have really planned well for crowd control as well so people with a reservation move along. I am honestly not sure if the observation deck was complete..... There were literally no signs or information indicating what buildings or other sights we were looking at all the way around the observation deck. For someone who does not know NYC, we did not always know what we were looking at, for example, the Statue of Liberty was obvious, but we did not know which island was Ellis island. There were no signs or people to tell us or to ask questions. All the employees were downstairs working in crowd control which was excellent, but no one to actually guide while you were up ther. They had iPads for rent, with a guided tour. We did take this option, as we felt we had already paid $32 per person to be ther. The people who did rent iPads were walking around looking down at their iPads to see what their view was of, rather than looking at the real thing. Kind of sad. I wish they would put more of the manpower at each window for information and questions,. Also, I am very hopeful that signs indicating what each view is showing are still to come, and were just not ready yet.

You can almost see forever. I was invited to attend the preview period prior to the grand opening on May 29th. The views were spectacular as I remember them being at the World Trade Center. The elevator ride up was an 8 time ear-popper. Pretty amazing for less than a minute ride! It was a bit "Disney-ish" but for $32 I guess you expect something other than the gorgeous views. My favorite part was even before we got in the elevator- it was the short presentation of people who were involved in the building of the Tower. Awesome and worth standing and watching- and letting all the people who were in back of you go by. They missed something very special.

Stunning view and presentations. The elevator ride is a real treat. Be sure to watch the panels showing New York growing on the way up and scenic tour on way down. It's the best available view in New York at present if you want to tour lower Manhattan.

Rainy Day Rip-off. A couple weeks ago I paid $32 online for a "timed ticket," whereby you make a reservation to visit the Observatory at a specific date and time. And then you hope the weather cooperates......aaaaand for me yesterday, it didn't. You can't see a thing on a rainy day. They have interactive tablets you can get to see what the view would be, based on the direction you're facing out, but they want to shake you down for an additional $15. So I paid $32 for a glorified 47-second elevator ride (video presentation on three sides). At least I avoided paying $47 total for the privilege of gazing at an iPad.The Observatory can't control the weather of course. And instead of the timed ticket I could have bought a flex ticket instead for $85 (weekdays) or $90 (weekends), but I think you can understand why I declined.One World Observatory really needs to rethink their ticket options and provide a reasonable remedy for zero visibility days, like maybe offer tablets for free or half price. Until they do, they're just going to be ripping their customers off every time the weather turns sour!Look at all the 1-star reviews, One World Observatory — and get a clue.

Arrive early to get tickets for the day. Best to reserve tickets prior to arriving in New York. We got to the ticket counter at 1200 and we were able to get tickets for 4:30pm. Well worth the visit and wait. If you have about 3 hours you can take in the 9/11 museum. The elevator ride to the top of the trade center is very fast, apparently the fastest in the U.S. The images on the walls show the view through computer graphics. The time spent on the observatory floor 101st is excellent. Great views of the city and New Jersey.

Beautiful Views, Expensive. We had timed tickets for 6:45 p.m. the day of the official opening, so we expected some delays. Fortunately, the weather was beautiful that day so the long wait outside wasn't too bad. There were lines everywhere, and the staff was clearly new at this, so there was some confusion. Once inside the building, it ran pretty efficiently. The elevator ride is fast and smooth, and I have to agree with one of the other reviews that with the elevator full of people it was nearly impossible to view the video that was being shown on the walls. Ditto for the "movie" that was shown when you got to the top - it was very nice, but you're standing so close to it (maybe 10-15 feet away) and the screen is probably 60 feet or more across, so it was really hard to see other than what was right in front of you. But the "reveal" of the view was definitely quite spectacular. The views overall were beautiful, but taking photos was problematic for two reasons - many people were sitting along the windows so it's hard to get an unobstructed view, and secondly the glare from the glass makes it difficult to get photos without reflections in them. There was definitely a lack of seating - actually none unless you were buying food at the restaurant, and this resulted in many people sitting along the bottom of the viewing windows which made it even more difficult to see. They really should have included some benches or other seating for people to be able to sit for a few minutes (but maybe they don't want visitors to tarry too long?). Overall, I would rate this attraction as very good, although the $30 price tag seems a little steep, and would be really disappointing if the views were obstructed by weather. We bought our tickets online several days earlier and they are timed tickets, so you have to specify the time you want when you make the purchase. But if it's a rainy or foggy day, that money would be pretty much wasted. It was extremely busy and crowded the day we went which was their opening day, so hopefully once things settle down it won't be so bad. We were able to get to an elevator to go down pretty quickly so there were no long lines to exit. In many ways, it felt similar to the Seattle Space Needle but without any outside viewing options which was unfortunate.

Amazing Views and Experience. We booked to go up on the opening day and it was fantastic. The views are great back over Manhatten and down to Statten Island. We also did the Rockerfella the day before and it gives you a different view of New York. I would highly recommend doing both. The experience in One World is far superior.

Amazing 360 degree view of New York City. It is one of the must see NYC attractions. From the moment you enter the elevator to go up and the views from the top, the whole experience was just simply amazing!!! It's well organized and layout.

Nothing Like It!. We were already planning on going to NYC and buy luck, the World Observatory had it's grand opening just a few days before. I purchased tickets online through their website.They will only allow you to get on line about 20-30mins before your scheduled time. The experience starts as soon as you walk in. There's tv images on all the walls showing you where the visitors are coming from and how many have visited. You then walk through what looks like bedrock, and there are lights with sayings projected on them. Then you get into the elevators to take you to the top. WOW.....they are amazing. I've never been in an elevator that's a big 3 sided tv screen. On the way up they portray images of what NYC looked like over the past 100 yrs. Once you're at the top the views are amazing. You get to go on floors 100,101 and 102, and view the skyline. It's a wall of windows with 360 degree views. Workers are friendly and informative and will answer any question you may have. Theres a cafe for food and snacks. And of course....a gift shop!Be prepared to be wowed by the views. Rain or shine it's still beautiful!

Amazing Experience & Views. Wont give away what you experience as it will spoil it for anyone visiting, but the experience is very different to that of the Empire State building & Top of the rockYou are allocated a time, which makes for much less queues than you get at the Empire State Building, we joined the queue to get in at our allocated time and were looking out of the observation deck about 25mins later.Once you are up (and getting there is an experience in itself) there is a bar/restaurant,cafe, shop and 3 floors to view the skylineIt's an amazing view from there, unfortunately we only got to see it during the day, but must be equally amazing on a clear nightThoroughly recommended for anyone visiting NYC

Great but boring!. Visited on the first day of opening (fri 29th May). We had to wait in our 4pm Queue for an hour which was not an issue but then when they started letting the queue in they also let anyone in with a 4pm ticket regardless of them beinging in the queue or not which was very unfair. The list journey to the 102nd floor and the initial 'revealing' of the view was the highlight for us, very spectacular. What I think does let it down is the 'enclosed' nature of the observation deck, compared to the Empire state or Rockefeller observation decks which are outside you get this disjointed feeling - i.e. no wind, no sounds etc. The view is spectacular but unfortunately being behind the windows (covered in hand prints and greasy nose marks!) spoils photographs. Worth a visit yes, but go up the Rock after as its much better.

Amazing views, great experience and well organised. We visited One World Observatory on its 2nd day of opening and were a bit hesitant about how chaotic it might be but went ahead and booked an allocated time slot of 3pm. We were pleasantly surprised at how well organised it was. You just need to turn up 15 mins before your time slot which avoids long queues. There were plenty of helpful staff around the entrance to point you in the right direction if you get lost. Once you're inside the building you feel as if you're queuing for a ride at a theme park. The experience in the elevator is really impressive and is really fast. But once you're up at the top it's just unbelievable. The experience is really positive. There isn't any reference to 9/11, just a focus on the amazing 360 views of New York. I'm not sure if we were just lucky with our timing, but we managed to get 2 seats at the bar without waiting at all and the service was great. There were 45 min wait times for food though and you weren't able to order food at the bar as it was really busy. Perfect for us but if you're looking to get food there it would be better to make a reservation. Well worth the visit. Fantastic experience.

High expectations, low result. I have been to OWO on the opening day. Apart from the fact I have on the line for 2 hours and entered the observatory 45 minutes later than my booked time (no problem, it was the first day) I have been really bothered from the continuos lines even once inside. First line to enter the security area, second line to look at the basement made of stone, third line to look at the screens where all the workers of the tower tell their own story, fourth line to enter the elevators, fifth line to look at the presentation screens before arriving in the observatory itself. After all this, you arrive on the top and the view is really stunning, but...everything is covered by glass (sure, we are at the 102 floor) so photos often contain reflexions and moreover, many glasses are dirty, so photos loose a lot. It is an experience that has to be done, but these details must be improved.

New York comes back with flying colors with this great addition to its unique skyline!. As a native New Yorker that has traveled all over the globe, I have felt that recently other large cities had been taking over with really exciting and modern skylines. Well as of last night visiting the One World Observatory, New York City can count itself back on top. The views from One World are truly amazing. Along with the really well done digital displays and story. The dining options are fine. Not as amazing as the views but you will have some nice options while up in the sky. I highly recommend going to see this world class attraction.

Cracking views . We went on the first day... Outside was chaos but I won't base the review on that. We had been at the opening ceremony and knew it had ran late so knew we would be delayed. There just seemed to be no organisation for the queues and there were hundreds of people there, hopefully a kink that will get ironed out because an hour and a half wait in that heat isn't funny!! Once inside it all went very efficiently. The elevator ride and video were excellent and the views from the top are amazing, we were lucky to have a gorgeous day and could see for miles. The only issue is the glass is very reflective so be careful when taking photos to position the camera just right or you will have the reflection of a pillar or people in the picture. Definitely worth doing on a nice day..
Awesome. Went on opening weekend. Super dramatic presentation. Sweet views. Beautiful building and photo ops.

That view.. What a rush to exit the elevator and to see the view. The view north, in all its glory - just like the 'old days'. The view from the top of the Freedom Tower is back and better than ever. Lots of technology has been added to the 'experience', not unlike any other similar attraction these days, and there is even a sort of high-tech interactive panel for those who are unlucky enough to be up there in the clouds. The elevator up provides an interesting panorama of the history of NYC, while the ride down can vary. Either way, it's wicked fast and smooth - ear-popping fast and high.

The Spectacular Views Are Back. My company had its holiday party at Windows On the World in the North Tower of the World Trade Center in December 2000. I took my nephew up to the Observation Deck in February 2001. By September, it was all gone.So when I went up to the top of the new World Trade Center Tower 1, I was overwhelmed. I hadn't forgotten the breathtaking 360 degree views or the helicopters flying below us from the previous tower. I just never thought I'd see them again.It's a wonderful experience from the moment you walk through the doors. There's a ground floor exhibit, and the you get in to elevator for a dizzying ride to the top. The video in the elevator is my favorite part of the whole thing (after the views, of course). I love the Empire State Building Observatory and Top of the Rock, but One World offers views of the New York Harbor that are unsurpassed. There is a bar, a cafe and a restaurant way up there too, so make your reservation before you go! http://www.marketsofnewyork.com/2015/05/opening-day-of-one-world-observatory/

Looking down on Manhattan - what a view!. I noticed the One World Observatory was due to open while me and my family were visiting New York so purchased tickets on the first public viewing day for a 2:45pm viewing. Unfortunately due to the formal opening proceedings over running earlier that day meant all the viewing times were running about an hour late. When we arrived to the building there were queues of visitors in front of the entrances and down the side of the building and we thought we wouldn’t get in for hours but this wasn’t the case as the staff called out for anyone with tickets for a certain time to come forward and took us to the entrance.After proceeding through security checks we made our way to the lifts passing showreels of interviews of some of the people connected to this new building so this made the route to lifts more interesting. The lift ride and the short presentation was another experience - but I won’t say anymore as I don’t want to spoil it for anyone visiting.Finally in the viewing area – well what can I say but WOW! The views are amazing not just of Manhattan but into New Jersey, Brooklyn etc. You can rent tablets that pinpoint particular landmarks/buildings, we didn’t do this as we have been to NY before so felt confident in spotting places ourselves but I guess they would be helpful for anyone not that familiar with NY. It would have been even better if there was a viewing area outside to take better photos like you can at the Empire State/Top of the Rock viewing platforms – but I can also understand why there isn’t.Overall - after the slight delay getting to the viewing deck I would say it was definitely worth the wait and we will plan to return but next time in the evening to experience Manhattan at night.
One World Observatory Pre Publc Tour. I was one of 1000 people invited to go to the top of One World observatory. It was thrilling, exciting, and impressive .

Stunning. Obviously the views are incredible, but this is a very well planned attraction. Don't Rush up, enjoy the video montages before you get to the lift- quite moving actually. Gift shop is crazy expensive and their is a restaurant where we were advised would be a 45 min wait so didn't bother, and a cafe with no seating! So book a table before you go! So pleased we went

Visited on Second Day Open! Very Dramatic!. Absolutely loved this experience. For those who don't want to revisit 9/11 due to painful memories, this is the way to do it. There was very little focus, if any, on the actual events of 9/11, but instead focused on the incredible views. The elevator travels 102 floors in 46 seconds, one of the fastest in the world. As you rise, the walls take on the development of the area over the years, starting with bedrock, rising into swamp, then small buildings, all the way into the skyline you see today. You are then shepherded into a long narrow room for a short film, after which the screen rises and you get your first view from 102 stories in the air. People clapped, cheered, and cried. It was incredibly dramatic. Then you can walk 360 degrees for views of the entire city. Not to be missed! There is also a lounge and restaurant, gift shop, and staff to answer all your questions. We were visitors number 13,571!!!

Top of the World, A Number One!. There was a real sense of occasion on opening day. It was historic and the staff treated us like we were VIPs. Rolling up on my mobility scooter with no ticket I was escorted to the top of the line and up to the top of the 'See Forever' observation deck of the World Trade Centre. The whole experience is designed to excite - the 47 second elevator ride has suround sound and vision, a virtual bird's eye view of Manhattan rising up from the bedrock through the centuries to the present day. Then the anticipation as we file into a darkened room for a minute long kaleidoscope of New York life before the screen rises to reveal the City skyline beneath us in all its glory. The crowd cheered such is the impact. Then onto the observation deck proper where you can wander at will photographing the various Boroughs of New York at you own pace. Only 150 people enter at any one time so there is no sense of overcrowding and there is no-one ushering people on.The glass reflects shadows and hand and breath prints so that the visitor will inevitably end up in someone else's photo.There is a little visitors' shop and a restaurant but given that it was opening day the line was too long to sample its fare.The ride down is virtual too. An experience I will never forget!

5* view, 2* experience. We went to One World Observatory on the day it opened, which would explain one - but not the other - of my issues with the experience.The view is just wonderful - and you should ago in any case, just to see a 360º view of New York from that fantastic height. To look down from that elevation on familiar tall landmarks like the Empire State and the Chrysler is quite an experience. And you really can see the curvature of the earth.One more amazing thing, as well - the smoothest and quietest lift ascent you'll ever have made!But the level of organisation on that first day was appalling. Despite pre-booked tickets, the queue was endless and the attempts to move people through it confused. It was a good thing good will (generally) prevailed.My other issue was that the whole experience felt a bit Disney-fied. There is an amazing - and moving - story here, which some of the video vox pops did a good job of telling - but really the attempt to impose an exciting narrative felt rather forced. The view can speak for itself.

One World Observation ~ See Forever. The new World Trade Center Towers are very beautifully constructed. The observation deck is well placed and is accessible with elevators which reach 102nd floor in 47 seconds. The dining facilities are well equipped and the serving staff are very professional and happy to attend to the visitors. Even though none of the towers are the highest in the world the buildings are grouped in such a way that the epicenter is in the warmest and most friendly environment. The World Trade Center buildings are an example of a classic American architecture which have the most original design of anything else built in U.S. or abroad. Kudos to the people of Big Apple, your are still the best of anything I have seen.

Working out the kinks. Not the best view IMO. We went on opening day. We bought tickets at about 4pm and viewed at 9pm. We selected the time of 9. It didn't take much time to get the tickets or get to the top. Nothing was marked very well but I am sure they are working that out. It was day one. So I am overlooking that.The elevator ride is fast and very entertaining. There are two different shows in the elevator, one on the way up and another on the way down. Both were very good. The view was great from the obeservation deck but the glare from the interior lights was pretty bad on the windows. There is no open deck, all is behind glass. The observation deck is completely enclosed. The glare makes it very difficult to take pictures. If you take a hoodie or some other dark piece of material with you, you can shield your camera lense against the glass and get some great pictures. IMO, the views from the Rock and Emprie State Building are as good if not better because you can get on an open deck with no glass. It took us about 30 minutes to get down. The line wrapped the observation deck twice, but it moved fast.If you are interested in the notoriety. Go up the Trade Tower. If you want the view and you want to see these two towers, select the Rock. If you want A really great view where you can see the park and the Statue of Liberty. Then go with the Empire State Building.

great views. We bought tickets online the week before for the 11:15am time slot, when my wife and I arrived it was very disorganized on how to enter the roped off area but they stated to figure it out. The elevator ride is awesome and the view is great, it was a very clear day on Friday. I rented the Ipad for $15 and it shows the landscape of New York with marked landmarks and flyovers and a small video. I don't think the Ipad is a must have but its ok if you aren't very familiar with all the landmarks in the city.

Touist. Visited day 2 - entry well organised, film show and unveiling of view is awesome. View from observatory is great can see for miles. Only criticism is cafe too few staff and not enough seating or space. Not sure they expected as many people to take up this service. Great to have been one of the first visitors

Bad weather no warnings no view. Two tickets purchased one month in advance, 32 dollars each, no way to obtain a refund or to change date in case of bad weather. We have just looked at grey windows...so we kindly suggest not to purchase tickets online unless you have checked carefully the weather forecast. Actually my garage would be exactly the same...but definitely less expensive.

So proud of NY. Was able to preview before official start date and was awestruck by the intro when you got to the top! Won't give it away but that alone is worth ticket prices. The elevator ride up was incredibly fast and very interesting with the video footage. The views at the top were amazing! I was lucky to have a clear sunny day so we could see far. And the staff was very helpful And very friendly. I was so proud to be a New Yorker that day (and every day)! I also felt that building one trade and having the observatory opened was an emotional and bittersweet occasion. The rebirth at ground zero doesn't erase the tragedy but it strongly symbolizes, for me, the hope and resilience of Americans.

Gorgeous view of Midtown, New Jersey, and Brooklyn. I've lived in NYC for 3 years and have been to the top of the Empire State Building as well. The observatory at the top of One World Trade Center is well worth it. The three observation decks are spacious; the theater is amazing; the line and elevators/sky pods are not that bad of a wait; and it's quickly becoming an American icon, so make the trip! The view of midtown and the Empire State Building is nice, though not spectacular; everything looks so tiny. We went around 7:30pm, so we watched the sunset over Jersey - again, not the most exciting thing. The view of where the twin towers stood got me a little choked up, and the Brooklyn Bridge and East River looked beautiful. Cough up the $32 and go for it - you won't regret it!

The view is breath incredible. We heard this was open so we headed to the city. We bought tickets on line and arrived at 11:00 PM. There were no lines and we went straight to the top. The view of the city lights was awesome. Judging by the ques that were set up it looks like it would be a pretty good wait during the day, but at 11:00 PM it was quiet. We were able to see out the windows around the selfie takers.

Wanted something special and the weather ruined it. If you're planning to come up here make sure the weather is great. Otherwise it's a waste of money. Bought ticket one month ago. The weather today is miserable and the ONE doesn't take rain checks - so I just feel like I threw a lot of money 1776 feet up in the air.

Beware. No rain checks. I had a very poor experience at this attraction. The whole point is to see a view of New York. As it was a misty day, there was no view AT ALL. no rain check or refund was available and there were no signs saying that your visit could be rearranged if weather was bad.Despite complaining to senior management, there was no attempt to help by offering to rearrange a time. Very poor customer service which needs to badly improve

History Meets Technology, But cant beat Empire state or Rockefeller views. Entry to one world observatory starts with a long line and routine security checks... Actual visit starts with the elevator ride which is by far the best i have ever seen or experienced, 102 floors in 50 seconds with a video showing how america was built.then wait in line to go into a auditorium to experience a show called "see forever" which is breathtaking, the end of the show is the best of the best ( don't want to break the suspense by revealing what happens )There is a desk where they rent IPADS to experience the views of NYC and to virtually go the places that you see from the observatory tower like statue of liberty or empire state etc.. its 15$ and if you like technology then worth a try.Then walk into the floor to see the 360 views, there is a deck called "sky portal" which is a supposed to be a see through floor to the bottom but it is a virtual see through floor where a screen at the feet shows the live traffic and roads beneath, not so impressive except that guests use this dock to sit and relax.Keep walking and you come across a circular structure with multiple TV monitors called "City Pulse" where the designated tour ambassadors connect guests to the city landmarks with some crazy technological arm bands and some circular motions..this show runs for 10 min every 30 minutes and worth the watch.Now coming to the views of NYC from the observatory tower: The views are not so great as in empire state building or Rockefeller as "One world center" is located in the southern most tip of NYC, but it has the best views of "Statue of Liberty", "Brooklyn bridge", "Manhattan bridge" & "New Jersey" but cant get good views of mid town and up town which is a huge let down for people who like top views of midtown and up town.The elevator ride to the bottom is more interesting and engaging than the ride up its more like a roller coaster trip from top of World trade center to the bottom.

Don't pre-book!!!. We pre-booked because we assumed it would be rammed having only been open a few days. Unfortunately if you pre-book you can't tell what the weather will be like. We arrived to find the observation deck in thick cloud, so in effect paid £40 to have a similar view to that of the inside of the hotel wardrobe. No facility to refund or re-book. A good old fashioned rip off. :(

If I could give it 6 stars I would. We were in the first 200 members of the public to go up on opening day. Bright blue sky, the elevator ride in itself was fantastic. 102 floors in less than 60 seconds. You have a short film with a massive surprise at the end, but can't tell you what. Then down 2 floors for a spectacular 360 view of Manhattan and up to 50 miles on a clear day. I can not stress enough how fantastic this was.shop had some nice souvenirs. Had a coffee and croissant, they may need to work on the organisation of the food operation as it would be very confusing and long winded when they are really busy. It was just over £20 each to visit and is much better than the Empire State view. We did feel a little strange from the slight movement of the building, but would go again tomorrow if we could

Sad and awesome. Worth the price the views were extraordinary, the staff professional and extremely competent, moved many people from bottom to top quickly and vice versa, additionally they were extremely helpful and nice. What a pleasure to see such professionalism

Rip off policy that needs to be changed!. As this attraction has just opened I decided to pre book to avoid lines and delays as I expected it to be very busy. Unfortunately the weather was very bad for the evening we had booked to go but we headed down there anyway. We arrived and had our tickets checked and "stamped". Because of the bad weather we weren't expecting amazing views but the whole of the top half of the building was actually in cloud so we could see a grand total of nothing! Visibility was zero. We didn't hang around and when we got to the bottom we asked about a refund policy and were told that there were no refunds or options to change to a different date. My husband pointed out that when we arrived no one told us the visibility was at zero however the woman on the counter pointed out we were in fact told when we arrived as our ticket had been stamped to say low visibility. Of course we weren't told why they were stamping it at the time and infact you could barely even make it out when we looked. Overall an extremely disappointing experience we appreciate that no one can control the weather but they really should have an policy by which you can come back another time for free. It cost us 40 pounds for two so not like t was even cheap!

A must. Amazing view. everything about this was amazing. Once you get inside its all air conditioned and they take you through the journey of building One WTC. The journey up is a surprise which takes you through history of the area and it whisks you up to the top very quickly. The view from the top can be enjoyed at your leisure so take your time and enjoy.

Doesnt have the sizzle of the original. I expected a huge WOW factor and didnt get it. Kudos for the efficiency of the process on day two of operations. We had 9:15 tickets (the second time slot of the day) and we were in the security screening line by 9:15. The elevator ride is touted as an important part of the experience, but it left me frustrated. The elevators hold 15 people and they are not enormous. So we were packed tight to the walls, making it difficult to see the video images that moved quickly as we ascended. The elevator presentation was not like the media coverage which was obviously shot in an empty elevator! As we leave the elevator we assembled for a rather hokey 5 minute film that was also difficult to process. We were lined up close to the screen with 3D representations of building forms, so that some portions of the video jut out a foot or more, which I found distracting. A tourist would get a lot more out of that I suppose than anyone familiar with the city. The crowd did clap as the screen lifts to reveal the skyline. The 3 levels of viewing are not immense, but rather feel like enormous hallways - not the drama that the Twin Towers had. Likewise the windows feel shorter and smaller than the original. Children loved the exhibit with a glass floor above a video of a street scene. There is no outdoor space which is definitely a drawback, given that Empire State has that exciting element. Staff was friendly and helpful and obviously proud to be part of the history. I think the attraction is overpriced.

DO NOT...... .....buy an advance ticket for this..... Arrived in good time for our visit....took photos of the outside of the OWO, and even though latish on (10pm) still took best part of an hour to get up to the Observation Deck. Guess what... by that time surrounded by cloud... and no view of anything. Ask about being re-ticketed on the 102nd floor and was directed to Customer Services on the ground floor. At the desk was told to look at my ticket. As part of the "validation process" our tickets were stamped with an orange stamp which apparently says "Zero Visibility"...although illegible, and no mention of this when stamped. Now....I clearly accept that there is nothing that they can do about cloud meaning Zero Visibility...but there must be a re-ticketing option, as there is with every similar attraction we have visited. Even though the tickets specify "expansive and panoramic 360 degree views of Manhattan's iconic skyline any beyond" which they clearly did not deliver, they think it fine to say we should simply walk away several hundred $s down.I shall be emailing a complaint (since curiously enough there was no-one on site who could actually deal with a complaint), and will repost as/when I receive a reply.

Very impressive presentation and views!. We booked our tickets online only 1 hour before going and did not have to wait at all. That said it was 7:45 pm and a thunderstorm was raging. What they have done with the presentation at the ground and even in the elevator is absolutely top rate. However, arriving at the top there are some things I'd describe as hokey. Let's just say they have some kinks to work out. I'd say the $30 ticket was worth it. If you are planning a visit I'd try to avoid peak times.

"See Forever".....or see nothing at all.. Rather than being the highlight of our trip to NYC, it became the biggest disappointment. Beware the potential for low cloud: if you get to the top and there is absolutely nothing to see, there is no refund, no option to return at another time, no nothing.Now, I understand that the weather is totally outside the control of the staff there. But here's the issue. When we arrived, we could see that clouds were covering the mast and we specifically asked the guide at the entrance if you would be able to see anything. We were repeatedly assured that there were fantastic views at that time. So up we went. Through TSA-style security including getting our tickets stamped (more on this later), up the elevator to stand in queue to watch a short video presentation then out to the observation deck. We were shocked to find that we were in dense cloud and there was no view at all. The staff were wandering around looking a little worried, talking amongst themselves as to what should be done in such a situation (clearly they hadn't planned or trained for such an event). So back down we went to the "Client Services" area to ask for a replacement ticket so we could come back at another time when the weather was clear. No such luck. We were told that the "policy" is that no refunds or replacement tickets are possible, even for bad weather. We pointed out that we had been told that the visibility was good. The Supervisor was then called (by this time a large group of disgruntled visitors had gathered) and she unhelpfully explained that there was nothing she could do about it and that we had all received stamps on our entry tickets showing that there was zero visibility (this was well after we had already paid for them), so basically it was all our own fault. Every single person in the group looked at their tickets and were surprised to see this so-called stamp saying "zero visibility". Except that on most peoples' tickets, it was smudged and unreadable. And not a single visitor had been told by the person doing the stamping, or anyone else involved in the process, that there was the slightest issue with visibility (when they clearly knew there was). Yet they were very happy to keep taking everyone's money, and usher them up the lift. This is blatantly deceitful and a complete ripoff. Shame on you, One World Observatory. This is not the legacy you should be leaving on this important building.

Great Views - Slightly Overpriced. We came the 2nd day it opened - purchased tickets online as tickets were selling fast. At $32 per person, it is not cheap. In fact, I've been to 76 countries and for an observatory, it is ridiculously expensive. Tickets can be printed once you purchase online. We picked 6:15 pm entry.Entry requires going through medal detectors and the elevator is fast - 60 seconds to the 101 floor.Once there, you watch a video and then pass through to the Observatory. It was packed with people but the worse part is that they would sit by the window and just stay there and not move. I think this should not be allowed as the rest of us would also like our turn to see the view. We spent about 1 hour here.I've also been up to the Empire State Building multiple times and it is the same price. One World Observatory is definitely a better experience. However, I am glad I went but probably would not go again as the price is prohibitive.

Most visit!. 15 years ago i visited the top of the Twin Towers. I was lucky to be one of the first 1000 ppl to get to the top and see this amazing view again. I know it's not open air view and for some it will be expensive but the view is spectacular and the history behind this place definitely deserve a visit.

Views that don't quit!. Amazing panoramas and great job of organizing visitors - the elevator ride and introductory video are well worth the trip!Visited the first hour it was open, glad to have seen it!! Highly recommended!

Circus without respect. Visiting One World Center was a great disappointment! A big show, sort of Disneyland experience. People staying to check their Facebook, making selfies, blocking the view. Which was already disappointing, for the glas reflected in photos you might want to make. Skip it, visit Empire State Building instead!

Dont expect open air view !!. We visited during the night with our kid, the night time view was really awesome and the short presentation before you get on to the elevator was something different that I haven't seen before, also the newyork history from 1500s to the present shown during your short elevator travel was good. Some flaws,1) Since the viewing deck is not outdoors you cannot take any pictures due to the reflection2) The imaging center can be more organised

Working out the Kinks. It was a wonderful event. However , they are working out the kinks in getting you upstairs at your appointed time. It is newly opened to the public on May 29, 2015. My appointed time was 7:30 I was on line definitely more than the recommended 15 minute advised prior arrival time. My group was let in the building at 8pm. The trip through Security was fast and efficient . The only other thing was that you had to jockey a little to get in position to take photos. To those of us who live in the area go in non peak times for tourists.

Top of the World Trade Center. We just finished our tour of the Observatory at the new World Trade Center. The views are great and the interactive computer generated displays were very interesting. However, even though we bought tickets for a specific time of day we still had to wait almost two hours to get in and, when we finally did get in, it was way way overcrowded. Maybe in a year or two the demand will taper off and it will be a more enjoyable experience.

Excellent but caution parents!. Its just been 2 days since the observatory is open and I must say that they have done an amazing job. I have been to similar observatories in Chicago and London but nothing really compares to this one.There was video presentation that got tears in my eyes being a New Yorker myself. Its an absolute must see.The views...I dont think I have words to describe the views... Its New York and its the tallest building...Ofcourse the views are best in the world... Looking forward to the Staten Island Eye coming up soon...Like all good things come with a bad side sometimes, the only issue I have is the use of strollers.I was asked to fold my stroller in the elevator and the ground floor which I though was unnecessary. They could have just let one less person enter the elevator and enter the next one. Maybe its early days but am sure they will get over the rule of no strollers in the ground floor and elevators.

Gasp!. Don't want to give away too much, but the end of the introductory video will make you gasp. And yes, the elevator ride up (and down) will amaze. This new observation area gets everything right -- something the original never did. This needs to be on everyone's To Do list. It took six hours of hitting the refresh button on the browser, but we snagged tickets for the second day. According to the big counter at the entrance, we were something like Visitor 14,567. Reserve well in advance. And plan on eating. There are two restaurants but the steakhouse is sold out for months. The more informal restaurant takes guests on the same day. We put our names on the list and got in an hour later. Prices were high but not outrageous.

This has to be the Top Attraction in NYC. Be sure to plan to visit this sight when vacationing in New York City. It is a great way to experience the Big Apple. We visited during the evening, and enjoyed a spectacular view of the city lights. There are no lockers available for the storage of large bags or suitcases, so plan accordingly.

It's lonely at the top...! . The iconic One World Observatory opened its doors to the public on 29th May, 2015. I was fortunate to visit it before it opened as a part of a school field trip. So can't comment on the booking, ticketing, lines aspect. Neither am I able to comment on the cafeteria or the gift shop. What I can tell you is the awesome experience of the elevator and the views. I think this entire visit is worth it for the experience of the elevator which shows you the 3D timeline of New York city. It's nothing short of fantastic! The elevator takes you to the 102nd floor and you enter a dark room with a screen, which shows you one of the most well-made clippings on New York. Anybody who is a New Yorker will see his life being played out in those 2 minutes, for others it's just a great clipping on New York. What follows after the clipping is over and when the screen goes up is what literally takes your breath away! You have the city of New York unveiled in front of your eyes! Now coming to a critical review of the views - the views are well, great! I have been to the Top of the Rock and I must say that the views from TOTR are more relevant because you can actually see the skyline and the iconic buildings which make New York New York. From the one world observatory - it's great, no doubt, and you can see for miles in all directions, but it's kind of a very lonely view where one is disconnected from the rest of the city. So, if you want to experience the skyline of New York, go to TOTR. If you want to experience cutting edge technology and the One World Observatory, come here! All said and done, I am only reminded of the old adage...it's lonely at the Top!

Amazing views that you cannot capture.... Wow, spacious, well designed and the show around it just cool. The views are truly breathtaking and you always find a space at the window. The elevator rides up and down are kind of virtual reality flights through Manhattan's history (up) and around the tower (down). Some flaws: 1) the windows are very reflective, ie you hardly can take reasonable fotos, 2) at the entrance you have to discard all bottles (guess to increase sales upstairs) 3) the line-up was totally disorganized, maybe a beginners thing (we were among the first 500).At the 101/100 level there are some hosts in video installations that desperately try to get the attention of the audience. Sorry, this is not only not needed, but rather disturbing.

Good concept, fantastic view.. Lucky enough to go to the opening ceremony on the first day, the lift and the 'show' are just awesome. Some aspects are strange, I'll do a separate review of the cafe, which was not good, there also appeared to be some poorly designed spaces, with walkways next to windows, but with screens to stop you enjoying the view, I understand the need for people not to block up the corridor, so why not make the corridor wider? The views make it all worthwhile.

One Word - Amazing. Was lucky enough to be in New York the day this opened and also staying in Conrad New York which is two blocks away. Amazing attraction with the best views of the city. Would highly recommend but suggest you get there early or book a early session.

Another Tourist Trap. 1. Long queue outside the building just to get inside. No chairs, no shades and no PA system to announce what ticket time are now being allowed to go inside. 2. When you get inside the observatory, another long queue awaits you for security screening and elevator service. 3. Allot 2-3 hours for this visit. The time in your ticket is not followed, I purchased a 13:45 ticket and was only able to get in the building after an hour and at the observatory past 15:00. 4. Don't purchase your ticket in advance, bad weather means depressing view.5. When Riding the elevator, you should be the last one to get in so you can enjoy the 60 second presentation.

AMAZING!!. We were visiting New York for our second visit. We found that this was due to open today and purchased tickets yesterday. You are given an allotted time slot. Upon our arrival, the mass crowds had gathered!! The cost was US$32 each. We were told that the opening ceremony has taken longer than expected, putting everyone back an hour.Our wait was worth it.
